column2: Seventeen young women will be presented to society at the second annual Cotillion of the Junior League of Englewood, N. J. The dance will be held Nov. 28 at the Aldecress Country Club in Demarest, N. J.

THIS is not the proper place to discuss the merits of the sacked look -- and this statement should not be taken to mean that it is thought to have any merits in this quarter -- but one has to assume that the reappearance of this relict of the Twenties has inspired to some degree the current interest shown on disks in the popular musical styles of that decade.

THE summer just now departed produced one literary phenomenon I found of particular interest. One of our popular magazines, aiming at an audience somewhere between what a contemporary sociologist would describe as the lower and upper middlebrows, devoted a large part of its August number to what is known as the literary life.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Rain marred the opening of the eighty-ninth Danbury State Fair today. A crowd of 5,456 confined itselff to viewing exhibits under the main tent and in buildings.

The French Union is composed of France itself, Algeria, the overseas territories of Black Africa and scattered possessions around the world -- a total of 85,000,000 people and 4,348,000 square miles. Since World War II, this vast empire has suffered from weak government at home and colonial revolt abroad. When Gen. Charles de Gaulle came to power in June, he promised to give France a strong government and to end the four-year-old war in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon accused a State Department "subordinate" today of seeking to "sabotage" Secretary Dulles' policy by revealing that 80 per cent of the mail reaching the department from the public opposed the decision to defend Quemoy and Matsu.
A 36-year-old mother was arrested yesterday for assertedly leaving her 6-week-old baby lying on the white dividing stripe of Ocean Avenue in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.

THE pendulum of fashion does not, seemingly, swing entirely of its own accord. It requires a little push. A few years ago the designers and manufacturers of men's clothing decided that men were still slaves to the double-breasted suit and that it was time for a refurbishing of wardrobes.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 27 -"Tribes That Slumber," a book on the rise and fall of Indian cultures in the Tennessee Valley region through 15,000 years, was published here recently by the University of Tennessee Press.

NEW cameras placed on the market stress low cost for models that include such modern features as built-in rangefinder, luminous-frame finders, and built-in meters, devices formerly associated only with cameras in the higher-price brackets.

THE pictures that account for more than half this book are some of the finest this reviewer has seen of bullfighting, a subject that lends itself to photography but rarely is treated with such skill., Peter Buckley, the author-photographer, spent six bullfight seasons in Spain taking several thousand pictures of which 109 appear in his book.

HONG KONG, Sept. 27 -- Judging conditions in Communist China from the conventional standpoint, the present would not seem to be an appropriate time for Peiping to engage in a showdown conflict with the United States in the Taiwan Strait.

The David Chipp article, "How 650 Million Chinese Are Controlled," (Sept. 14) provides a grim and unappealing picture of the constant vigilance decreed by Peiping. What especially interested me was the writer's revelation that "a group of top-flight scientists were at one time last fall spending four afternoons a week discussing each other's philosophy of life and making sure that all understood the 'correct' approach and ideas."

In his otherwise excellent article, Senator J. William Fulbright obviously ignored the most tragic example of "what is wrong in our own national house." By overlooking the problem of segregation in the South, Senator Fulbright is himself missing "the larger meaning of the United States and its role in the destiny of mankind."

BUFFALO, Sept. 27 -- Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for Senator, defended the Administration's handling of the Quemoy dispute today. He declared that Democratic critics of the policy had given "aid and comfort" to Communist China.

HAMIL KENNY (whose letter to the editor concerning a review of Mario Pei's "One Language for the World" was recently published) evidently is uninformed as to the tremendous advantages already secured by the use of Esperanto.

HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- The Chinese Communists are proceeding somewhat more slowly in the formation of people's communes than the initial publicity from Peiping about this new system seemed to indicate a month ago.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- The Republican campaign to perpetuate a half-century domination of California ran into choppy seas this week while the challenging Democrats swept ahead under full sail.

IN a suburban shopping center abuzz with housewives and small fry, a jauntily caparisoned Dixieland band blares "When the Saints Go Marching In," beneath a sign reading "Meet Pat Brown Here at 4 P. M."

SCENE designer Jo Mielziner, busy as he is at his drawing board, still would be a producer. His first venture as a sponsor was the musical "Happy Hunting." Now he has taken an option on a new play by Eugene Vale, a Hollywood writer, also a toiler in behalf of television.

A UNITED NATIONS ten-stamp program for 1959 was announced last week by Reidar Tvedt, Director of the U. N. Postal Administration. In addition, there will be a 7-cent airmail embossed stamped envelope and a 5c airmail postal card, in conformity with rates recently fixed by the United States Post Office Department.

PITY the poor oyster! This year, especially on the Eastern seaboard, the delectable bivalve has had a rough go of it. During the spring there was an overdose of rain and for the past few months there has been a superfluity of starfish.

The flickers have been gathering in flocks, which means that they are at least thinking about migration. Drive back a way into the country and you will see them, their light-colored rump patches conspicuous as they dart away in their undulatory flight. Sometimes twenty or more of them will be together, usually in a clump of trees but occasionally on the ground in a pasture or meadow.
BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., Sept. 27 -- The soft, yellow glow of lamplight has finally been extinguished here to close the gaslight era on Long Island.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The rise of an anti-Communist regime in Burma seems likely to bring strong new Red Chi nese pressures on the neutralistAsian republic.

ONE of the happy by-products of the post-war interest in American country music has been a revival in the playing of the five-string banjo. In folk-music circles the banjo has become so popular an instrument that it has given many guitarists something new to fret about.

TELEVISION presents another re-run this week when the New York Yankees and the Milwaukee Braves meet in the world series. The clubs starred in the same attraction last season, although this year's script may undergo revisions. The eager public, however, will just have to await the on-the-air performance. Unlike "Harvey," there'll be no preview for the critics.

Ever since the man in the gray flannel suit, the so-called Ivy Look has been mjor influence in men's clothe, s---and c mxtjor topic of debate. Here's what a representattve group o! the sartorial minded hale to sag on the matter,
LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 27 -The voters of Little Rock, both white and Negro, met their day of decision eagerly but quietly today.
LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia accused the United States today of lobbying in the United Nations with the aim of raising troops to fight Communist China.

IN June the B. B. C. presented a ninety-minute program devoted to an exposition of "the Method," which included filmed scenes of activities at the Actors' Studio in New York and recorded interviews with prominent theatre folk.
HONG KONG, Sept. 27 -- Communist China started operating its first atomic reactor and cyclotron today with a warning that atomic weapons were not the monopoly of "United States imperialists."
The disappearance of more and more "non-smoking" areas in public places presents a most unsatisfactory situation for the non-smoker who finds smoke disagreeable to him.

TRENTON, Sept. 27 -- The civil rights issue was discussed at a public forum of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People here today by the New Jersey Republican and Democratic candidates for the United States Senate.
Water-borne commerce at the Port of Philadelphia exceeded the 100,000,000-ton mark for the first time last year.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Purdue overwhelmed Nebraska, 28 -- 0, today. A crowd of 42,000 saw the first football meeting of the Big Ten and Big Eight representatives.

I had expected to see many objections to Edwin Dale's fine article on realistic approaches to our self-created farm problem ("Our Six Billion Dollar Failure," Aug. 24). But the one published in the letters column on Sept. 7 really surprised me.
The question of how the conflict in the Taiwan Strait could be resolved short of war continued to dominate the international scene last week. It apparently remained as far from solution as ever.

A slender, dark-haired colonel, dressed like any officer of the Women's Army Corps of the United States, was studying the WACS at work at First Army Headquarters last week. She was Col. Kim Hyun Sook, founder and chief of the WAC of the Republic of Korea Army.
The 1959 Oldsmobile will go on sale here Friday at prices generally $66 higher than a year ago.

RABAT Morocco, Sept. 27 -- The Moroccan Government has named a commission to set up an inter-Arab coordination center for education, science and culture. This center will operate within the framework of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and will include the Arab states that are members of that organization.

The current edition of The Book of the States,that excellent compendium of state activities which is published by The Council of State Governments every two years, has an interesting section on Uniform State Laws.
WARSAW, Sept. 27 -- Poland's Communist leadership has called for fundamental changes in the school system to link it more tightly to the country's production needs and to Socialist ideology.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Gus Zernial's pinch single drove in the tying run and Al Kaline hit a three-run triple to lead an eighth-inning rally today as the Detroit Tigers beat the Cleveland Indians, 5 -- 1.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 27 -- The celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of the nearby Borough of Ho-Ho-Kus will be marked by the annual tour of old homes by the Paramus Historical and Preservation Society next Saturday from 1 to 5 P. M.
Faulty diet, flabby bodies and aimless living are among the things that make old age unhappy, a committee of the American Medical Association has decided.

THIS brief, export novel opens in France in 1470, at the time of Anne Neville's cynically contrived, ruthlessly enforced marriage to Edward, Prince of Wales, the Lancastrian contender for the English crown. Immediately after the ceremony the bewildered 14-year-old bride (daughter of Warwick, the Kingmaker, formerly chief supporter of the House of York) found herself deserted except for her loyal maidservant in an enemy stronghold.
DAFFODILS usually are thought of as golden, although sometimes the trumpets or cups are pink or white. Some or the new pink and white varieties can be planted now for novel effects next spring.

ONE afternoon last week the only lights in Carnegie Hall were on the stage. Leonard Bernstein was leading the New York Philharmonic in a rehearsal of the Beethoven Seventh Symphony, one of the works that will appear on the opening "preview" concert Thursday evening.
BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Following is the text of the address by Secretary of State Dulles tonight before the Atlantic Treaty Association:

Some of the patrons of the Nov. 5 theatre benefit for Union Settlement, an East Harlem settlement house, have been announced by the committee. The event will be at the performance of "A Touch of the Poet" at the Helen Hayes Theatre.

IN recent years there has been a markedly increasing interest in Chinese art in the world at large and in the United States in particular. Interest was first roused in the early eighteenth century, when Chinese art struck the Western world as something strange, queer, quaint and exotic in form and texture.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The British Government has sensed a slight easing of the Far East crisis over Quemoy in the last few days, authoritative sources said tonight.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Sept. 27 -- In its first year of operation, the Harry S. Truman Library here was visited by 101,-530 persons.
Columbia's sophomore-studded football team bowed to Brown University, 22 -- 0, in the first game of the season at Baker Field yesterday.
HONG KONG, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Communist China has recently been a heavy buyer of chemicals and fertilizers in Hong Kong, according to trade sources.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 -- The Federal Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit unanimously affirmed today lower court orders requiring immediate racial integration of schools in Norfolk and Front Royal, Va.

" A SINGLE death is a tragedy, a million deaths is a statistic." Stalin's epigram is admirably illustrated by Ernst Schnabel's pointilliste portrait of Anne Frank during the few months she lived after the last entry in her diary, Aug. 1, 1944.

FEW garden flowers are more versatile than narcissus. They add touches of early color at the edges of borders and paths or in naturalistic settings. Some of the smaller varieties are ideal for the rockery. In the cutting garden, certain kinds of narcissus will furnish magnificent blooms for cheerful spring bouquets.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Delegates from nine Arab powers will meet in Kuwait next month to study further means of tightening a seven-year economic boycott of Israel.
BECKELY, W. Va., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- A junior high school at near-by Edwight will open Monday on an integrated basis, ending a dispute that found Negro parents opposing integration.
COLMAR, France, Sept. 27 -- Alsace is virtually solid for Premier Charles de Gaulle on the eve of the constitutional referendum.

By a long-continued series of political and military commitments based on the premise of an ultimate war of mutual annihilation with the Communist powers our Government has now brought our country close to that pathological goal. For the war that now threatens could not be fought at all without our utilizing nuclear weapons, weapons of genocide.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 27 (AP) -- The New York State Association of Children's Court Judges urged today the establishment of a family court as a court of record in every county of the state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -Optimism about one important sector of the economy and some caution about a second are expressed by leading Government economists looking ahead into 1959. The optimism is over automobiles, the caution over housing.
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Shah of Iran said today that the question of forming an Aryan confederation composed of Iran, Turkey, Pakistan and Afghanistan was under serious consideration.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Ohio State downed Southern Methodist, 23 -- 20, today before a crowd of 83,113.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon heads west Monday on his first major campaign tour of 1958.

ANY new Marquand novel -including "Women and Thomas Harrow" -- will be a solidly constructed book of around 500 pages. Its hero will be a member, or about to become a member, of what C. Wright Mills calls "the power elite."

HOW to get from here to there is a complex and fascinating subject in this day and age, what with atomic submarines, sputniks and such. The tricycle set will be grateful to Mary Ann and Norman Hoberman, author and illustrator of last year's delightful "All My Shoes Come in Twos," for skillfully simplifying the vast field of transportation in this crisp new picture book.

THIS is the forty-third annual collection of America's "best" short stories, a project begun by Edward J. O'Brien, continued by Martha Foley, and now produced by Miss Foley with her son, David Burnett. As usual, one must remember that "The Best American Short Stories of 1958" is a title, not an edict, and that no collection published in September can cover the 1958 story output.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Meade Alcorn, the Republican national chairman, charged today that a House investigation into the award of Pittsburgh's television Channel 4 had been "shut down" because "prominent Democrats became involved."

SEVERAL aspects of stereophonic disk recording are beginning to bother the collector; and, looking over the repertory that is available on stereo, one begins to see why. Stereo is ideal for symphony, opera and organ, and also for the larger jazz combinations, and current stereo disks take full advantage of those types of music.

DETROIT -- The sad lament of frequent air travelers to and from Detroit, that the thirty-five-mile trip between downtown and the Willow Run Airport takes longer than the flight to this city, can be abandoned on Wednesday.

THE year 1908 hardly seemed auspicious time for Harvard University to open its new Graduate School of Business Administration. The nation was experiencing a depression and big business was being subjected to much muckraking.

PUT two or three eat addicts in a room together, shake lightly, and the anecdotes celebrating the sagacity, humor and general delightfulness of the feline race will fill a book. Such anecdotes have, in fact, filled many, but none more sprightly or funnier than Doreen Tovey's "Cats in the Belfry" -- a title, incidentally, which neatly expresses Mrs. Tovey's attitude toward the whole cat matter.
A high-ranking school official warned last week that reading might become a lost art among the city's pupils.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -Dock workers of the San Francisco Bay area plan to halt all ship loading and unloading for twenty-four hours starting Wednesday evening.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- A hard-hitting line put Pittsburgh in position to score a touchdown and get a field goal and a sophomore, Chuck Reinhold, tallied on a 20-yard run today as the Panthers defeated out-manned Holy Cross, 17 -- 0.
ALBANY, Sept. 27 -- The new master plan for school district consolidations has not exactly produced a head-long rush to meet its objectives.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Albert P. Mathers, Superintendent of Schools, said this week that Center Elementary School's plan of grouping children by ability appeared to be working.

A WELCOME note of sophisticated fun runs through the fall lines of records for children. Where only a few years ago records for youngsters were tainted with the title, "kiddy pops," and that's the way a lot of them sounded, too, the diverse and advanced tastes of many children are recognized by record makers for this market today.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- A scientist, a former ice-breaker captain and a Navy physician, the three senior United States representatives in the Antarctic, recently returned from a five-day camp on Kainan Bay, a few miles from the main station at Little America.

The faster the ticker the higher the prices. That was the stock market story during part of last week. By Wednesday the list, as measured by The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks, had risen to new highs for the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27. -- Dr. Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Republic, paid tribute here tonight to the contributions of the Jewish people toward the advancement of education.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -The billboard industry is waging a last-ditch, sometimes bitter campaign against stiff Federal regulation of its product along the interstate highway system.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., Sept. 27 -- A hand-drawn cart, an old iron rail that served as a fire alarm and fund-raising barn dances will be among the old-time customs remembered tomorrow at the fiftieth anniversary of this village's Hose Company 1.

This South African Scot was an oddity. The poet who fought for Franco in Spain, who swashbuckled in English letters and who made a dismally unpleasant rhetorical parade of his zest for insult, violence and war, settled in his later years among the most peaceable people in Europe.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 27 -- Six Norfolk senior and junior high schools were officially closed tonight by Governor Almond shortly after the Norfolk School Board assigned seventeen Negro students to the schools for the fall term scheduled to open Monday.
Commodities had a difficult time last week.

STILL another aspect of the Battle of Cassino is revealed in this war story by an Italian womam. A number of books about this battle, which became the symbol of the winter war of 1944, before the conquest of southern Italy, have been written by various Allied soldiers who fought there.
GENEVA, N. Y., Sept. 27. -- The Democratic State Campaign Committee will pay for the use of state-owned airplanes by Governor Harriman in his campaign for re-election.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Federal spending to inspire communities to stem the rising tide of water pollution reaches the $100,000,000 mark this month.

With the same setting as a year ago and only a slight change in the cast of characters, another world series -- the fifty-fifth in the modern string between pennant winners of the National and American Leagues -- moves on to the sport scene this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- A new element was injected into the turbulent school segregation picture this week with the suggestion by Gov. Leroy Collins of Florida that the next Congress speedily enact legislation to deal with the issue.

IT'S a dirty trick to play on the guy, a quiet and unassuming fellow who is kind to dumb animals and ballplayers. But there is just no way of-escaping the obligation. The Manager of the Year, beyond question or cavil, is Daniel Edward Murtaugh of the Pittsburgh Pirates.

The first of a series of six seminars on Islamic culture will be held on Wednesday at 3:55 P. M. in the Building for Brotherhood, 43 West Fifty-seventh Street. The five other sessions will be held Oct. 15, Oct. 29, Nov. 12, Nov. 26 and Dec. 10.

With two multi-millionaires competing for Governor, New York's state election campaign has got off to a slow and decorous start. Most of the campaigning to date has been of the "get-acquainted" rather than the issue-raising type.
BIRMINGHAM, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Lloyd Nix sparked a second-half uprising that carried Auburn to a 13-0 triumph over Tennessee today in a nationally televised football game.

Retail sales in the eight-county Philadelphia area increased more than 96 per cent between 1929 and 1954, while the number of stores declined about 5 per cent, according to the City Planning Commission. It said a new study also showed that retail sales in Philadelphia rose some 50 per cent, while those in the seven surrounding counties increased 230 per cent.

SADDLE RIVER, N. J., Sept. 27 -- The Northwest Bergen Regional Planning Association decided this week to study transportation, apartment-house zoning and water problems in the area. The subjects will be assigned to committees, which will report in the spring.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Two Dartmouth reserves, Alan Rozycki and Seth Moger, sparked a second-period touchdown drive that started the Indians to a 20-0 victory over Lafayete today before 5,000 fans.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Spectators were plunged into a tangle of timbers when end-zone bleachers collapsed at the Louisiana State-Alabama football game tonight. More than sixty persons were injured, some seriously.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 20 -- Switzerland's attitude toward the European Economic Community, or common market, is determined by the dependence of her economy and her high standard of living on foreign trade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Foreign Agricultural Service said that France, normally a small wheat exporter, may have to import some this year.

THERE is more than music in Bruno Walter's masterly recording of Mahler's Second Symphony in C minor, "The Resurrection," which has just been issued in a two-disk Columbia album. It is a confession of faith, a most moving human document and a valuable piece of living history.
BERKELEY. Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Budge Patty of Paris upset Barry MacKay, 8 -- 6, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 4, today in the semi-final round of the sixty-ninth annual Pacific Coast tennis championships.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 24 -President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes has told Guatemalans that "if one day the country awakens in a blood bath and with its free institutions fettered by a state of siege, it will not be my fault or my Government's."

A REMINDER of photography's origin, the mirror-like, silver-coated copper daguerreotype introduced by its inventor, Louis J. M. Daguerre, in France 120 years ago, can be seen in a show that opened here last week.
The New York Public Library will open its seventeenth year of free art lectures at 6:15 P. M., Oct. 21, in a new location.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller conducted a rain-spattered campaign tour of four Westchester County towns and one Putnam County village late today.
Five films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

An essential aspect of the grave Pacific crisis is that neither superpower wishes it to worsen. This is not unusual for the United States, but it is a feature to which we are not always accustomed in Soviet attitudes.

PIQUANT, salty green olives and mild, nut-flavored black olives are favorites for the cocktail or relish tray, but their glamour-giving quality as an ingredient in many everyday dishes is often overlooked.

Vice President Nixon objects to a story written by E. W. Kenworthy and published in this newspaper, to the effect that more than 80 per cent of 5,000 letters received by the State Department since the Quemoy crisis began were critical of the United States Far Eastern policy.
The Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, or Succoth, began at sundown yesterday.

Most world series have their fair share of ifs and buts. A year ago, as the Yanks and Braves prepared to meet for the first time, the Bombers had Mickey Mantle moving on shaky underpinning and Bill Skowron out of it completely with a lame back.
Sarah Elizabeth Katz, pianist who was a pupil of the late Isidor Philipp, made her first appearance in a major New York concert auditorium at Carnegie Recital Hall late yesterday afternoon.
After four months of reconstruction and the expenditure of $850,000, the Museum of Modern Art is, on the eve of its reopening, one of the best fireproofed museum buildings in the country.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- Steel mills are looking forward to a further improvement in order volume and production next month. The consensus here is that the rate for the industry should average 75 per cent of capacity in the fourth quarter.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Off-track betting on horse races has been legal in France since 1933. A horse player who does not want to bet at a track can do so at 650 tobacco shops and cafes throughout country, or he can telephone bets the morning before a race.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- An X-ray unit that will permit physicians to examine the heart at work on an eight-inch television screen was unveiled here today.

The Long Island Lighting Company announced the acquisition of its own natural gas supply over the week-end. The utility has signed a twenty-year contract with Valley Gas Transmission, Inc., for the purchase from them of natural gas in amounts up to 32,500,000 cubic feet a day by Jan. 1, 1960.

The chaplain of Columbia University set forth the aims of education yesterday as "not only to furnish the minds of men but also to set their hearts on fire for goodness, beauty and truth" and to teach that "life is essentially unpredictable."
ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Governor Harriman today appointed his assistant counsel, Herbert B. Evans of New York City, to fill a vacancy on the State Parole Board.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- More stability in Washington in handling National Guard affairs was urged here today by Maj. Gen. William H. Harrison Jr., president of the National Guard Association.

SOUK-AHRAS, Sept. 28 -- An expected nationalist guerrilla offensive from Tunisia had not materialized here in the Algerian frontier region as the three-day French constitution referendum ended tonight.

Army, a top power from 1944 to 1950, and Oklahoma, the most successful team of the Nineteen Fifties, gave the college football world something to think about on Saturday. Both used new attacks to open their seasons with scoring parades.

ROGER VAILLAND'S "The Law"* is a brilliant and horrifying novel. Last year's winner of the Goncourt Prize, a selection of the Book Society in England and a selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club in this country, this ferocious and ironic study of the nature of man in society is obviously designed to give its readers an intellectual shock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Willie Mays/ collected three hits in five trips to the plate today but fell short of catching Richie Ashburn in the down-to-the-wire race for National League batting honors. However, the third-place San Francisco Giants beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 -- 2, before a closing day crowd of 19,435.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The Nationalist United Front, an extreme Leftwing coalition that has supported Premier Nu in Parliament, denounced today his planned transfer of control of the Government to the country's top soldier.

PARIS, Monday, Sept. 29 -- France and her empire voted yesterday overwhelming approval of the new Constitution designed to provide a strong, stable Government under the leadership of Premier Charles de Gaulle.
A SEVEN-PART television series on politics was opened yesterday by Eric Sevareid with a documentary on a "ward boss," Jack E. Russell, Democratic leader of the Sixteenth Ward in Cleveland.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Paramount has worked out a two-picture deal with Clark Gable. Neither the star nor the studio has any particular story under consideration.
God's mercy toward sinners was best exemplified when He allowed His Son to become man, Msgr. Charles J. McManus said yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Norfolk officials awaited today the impact of the biggest closing of schools under Virginia's laws against mixing the races in the classrooms.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The gross income of cotton farmers may rise as much as 17 per cent this year, the Department of Agriculture indicated today.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 28 -- Off-track betting here accounted for $11,418,261 of the $20,098.675 taken in bets during 1957 by El Comandante Race Track at Rio Piedras, the only one operating in Puerto Rico. The Government collected for its general fund $2,625,195 form all sources connected with the track.
Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther and Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover will be honored on Oct. 27 by the Theodore Roosevelt Association. Both will receive the Theodore Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medal.
Dartmouth Callege, in Hanover, N. H., may become the western world's chief center of polar research.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The stock market "boomlet" hesitated last week.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Mary Martin, the sophisticated tomboy of Broadway, transformed a gymnasium into a theatre and audiences into claques here last night and today.
The steamshp charter market registered improvement last week, both in volume and rates, but a level of pre-slump activity has not yet been approached.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for United States Senator, was not permitted to speak at the annual Interfaith Day Celebration yesterday afternoon on the Central Park Mall.

PARIS, Monday, Sept. 29 -- The French Communist party, Premier Charles de Gaulle's strongest and most active opponent, appears to have suffered a stunning defeat in the constitutional referendum yesterday.

The Scudder Fund of Canada, Ltd., has announced the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commision of a registration statement covering its transition to a fully open-end fund, with shares continuously available for purchase.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Sept. 28 -- Legal off-track betting began in New Zealand in the autumn of 1951. It was such an overwhelming success that the institution known as TAB seems likely to be part of the country's scene indefinitely.
THE major event of the week-end in the ballet field was the local debut of Claude Bessy with the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Eighty-two Warren County citizens formed a committee today to seek the reopening of Warren County High School, closed by a Virginia anti-integration law.

Textron, Inc., has purchased the Shuron Optical Company, Inc., from the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation, according to a joint announcement by Royal Little, Textron board chairman, and Howard A. Newman, president of Philadelphia and Reading.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, was reported today to have recommended the postponement of Britain's "partnership" plan for Cyprus pending a conference of interested parties.
The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association recently adopted a resolution concerning selections to the Federal judiciary. The core of the resolution reads:
The Archbishop of the Anglican Church in Jerusalem pictured in a sermon here yesterday, the role of the church in the Middle East as one of "overcoming prejudices" and promoting understanding.

Robert Moses has reported that since 1949 the clearing of 905 acres of slums was undertaken in the city under the Title I reconstruction program. The cleared areas have provided space for 65,000 modern apartments, as well as commercial and cultural buildings.

In 1709, in a field north of town at an intersection then known as Broad Way and Wall Street, the Charity School of the City of New York held its first class in the belfry of the original Trinity Church.

" Let My People Go," a series of dramatic and musical sketches based largely on Negro spirituals, was presented yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by a cast of some twenty singers, dancers, mimes and players. They were directed by Michel La Rue and Alex Foster with the assistance of Silvia del Villard.
A purely political rally on the Sabbath may have been ruled out for Governor Harriman yesterday -- but not the pointed political sally.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Willie Galimore threaded his way for three touchdowns today as the Chicago Bears defeated the Green Bay Packers, 34--20, in a National Football League opener.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian Christmas tree producers, who last year supplied about one-quarter of the United States demand, are being warned to lift their standards to meet growing competition from cultivated trees.
BUFFALO, Sept. 28 -- For the present, at least, New Yorkers may stop fretting about the Giants -- the gridiron variety, that is.
DALLAS, Sept. 28 -- The Air Force's Thor has been chosen over the Army's Jupiter as the basic mass-produced intermediate-range ballistic missile weapon of the United States.
NOW that fall is here, the time has come for the homemaker to forget her summer lethargy and spruce up the house.

The ten-story office building at the southeast corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Forty-fifth Street has been purchased by Sam Sockol and Lou Adler for a price reported at more than $2,000,000.
WILMINGTON, N. C., Sept. 28 (AP) -- North Carolina coastal residents struggled today to restore essential services battered yesterday by hurricane Helene.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 28 -- Philip Bonacorsa of Little Neck won the open jumper championship with Continental Lady at the Long Island junior horse show at the Thomas School of Horsemanship today. Reserve was Laughing Boy, owned by Jane Richmond of Northport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- Pablo Casals was formally invited today to come to Washington to be honored by the Organization of American States for his work on behalf of peace and better world understanding.

In times such as the present the public's appetite for articles dealing with the state of the economy, and more particularly the outlook for the future, is almost insatiable. And, since there are many persons and institutions of varying degress of expertness in this field, each with his, or its, own private set of conclusions, production, too, can be counted upon to be maintained at a high level.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- San Francisco's Giants will be doing their entertaining for another season in their little "honeymoon cottage" -- Seals Stadium.
WHEN the filmed series called "Target" went on the air for the first time Saturday night over Channel 2, there was Adolphe Menjou, looking as debonair as ever.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Forty-year-old Ted Williams won his sixth American League batting championship with a closing-day flurry today. Williams got a double and a homer in four trips while Pete Runnels, a Boston team-mate and his chief rival, went hitless in four chances.
Contracts awarded for construction work throughout the nation during August amounted to $3,466,576,000, an increase of 23 per cent over August, 1957.
Nelson A. Rockefeller, Republican candidate for Governor, charged yesterday that the Harriman Administration had failed in rehabilitating the physically disabled.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Sept. 29 -- President Chiang Kaishek said today that Nationalist efforts, aided by the United States, had "nullified" a Communist blockade of Quemoy Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The French Embassy reported tonight that French citizens in the United States and Puerto Rico were 95 per cent in favor of the new Constitution proposed by Gen. Charles de Gaulle. The count of votes stood 6,200 in favor and 300 against.

SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Two balloonists preparing for a high-altitude flight said today that a sniper had fired at them seven times with a high-powered rifle as they were drifting over Iowa. The balloonists landed safely.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- France's new republic, her fifth since the revolution of 1789, will attempt to conciliate the virtues of authority and of democracy -- two concepts that have not got along well together in the past.
DUBLIN, Sept. 28 -- Ireland, with the introduction of a betting act in 1926, was one of the first countries in Europe to legalize off-track betting and to end all underground gambling.
TOULOUSE, France, Monday, Sept. 29 -- An official in charge of a polling place sternly rapped his pencil on a ballot box. "Enough of that," he said. "Take your ballots and vote."

Consolidated net earnings of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation for the nine months ended Aug. 31 rose to $7,540,631 from $6,223,181 in the corresponding period of the preceding year, according to the report released today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Crude oil imports exceeded the national quota during August for the first time in eleven months, the Department of the Interior reported today.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, appealed yesterday for television sets for city schools.

" The House of Flying Objects,'' a story of the Long Island poltergeist that Duke University parapsychologists could not explain, will be televised Oct. 29 from 10 to 11 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Sometimes it requires devious and even odd ways to accomplish good purposes. This helps to explain the paradox contained in the current experiment in Burma. In the hope of preserving a constitutional democacy Premier U Nu is turning over his government to the army and its Commander in Chief, General Ne Win.

A "JAZZ OPERA," Alonzo Levister's "Blues in the Subway," had its first performance Saturday at midnight at Loew's Sheridan Theatre, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street. The presentation of Mr. Levister's brief work did not resolve the question of whether there is, or can be, such a thing as a "jazz opera" for it was offered under circumstances that made any rational judgment of it impossible.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Top Justice Department officials decided today to hear the Supreme Court's opinion on the Little Rock case tomorrow before selecting their next move in the case.

TOBY COPPOCK'S custom hat collection should delight all women. Mr. Toby, whose salon is at 23 East Sixty-seventh Street, designs with one idea in mind: to make his clientele look as smart and as pretty as can be.

Sol Z. Rosen in his letter which appeared in The Times Sept. 17 asked that Governor Harriman and Nelson Rockefeller "be forced" to express their position on the issue of direct-primaries for state-wide elective offices and to promise if elected to "prod" the Legislature into action.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The British are a gambling nation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- After The New York Times printed yesterday a report of the extent of public protests reaching the State Department against the Administration's policy on Quemoy and Matsu, Vice President Richard M. Nixon issued a formal statement saying he was "shocked."

Mayor Wagner still has off-track betting in mind as a source of additional city revenue despite the probability that Governor Harriman would veto legislation permitting such wagers. The Mayor said yesterday he would go ahead with a plan to name a committee to study the situation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The General Assembly will open full-scale discussion this week on the Middle East situation and the presence of United States and British troops in Lebanon and Jordan.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28 -- The last United States Marine battalion in Lebanon began moving out today.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Bob Palermo of Rochester, N. Y., set a course record today in New Martinsville Regatta's 225-cubic-inch speed-boat competition. He was injured moments later in another race.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 28 -- Hugh Gaitskell pleaded for unity tonight on the eve of the Labor party's annual conference.
V. K. Krishna Menon, India's Defense Minister, declared yesterday that the people of the United States "must realize that Chiang Kai-shek is trying to gear this country behind a war of adventure."
ALGIERS, Monday, Sept. 29 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle has won the referendum in Algeria by a majority of about 96 per cent, according to returns at 4 o'clock this morning.
Traffic signals that count the vehicles passing an intersection, and then change to give cross traffic a chance are in operation at five intersections here.
Governor Harriman admonished Senator Jacob K. Javits at a cornerstone-laying ceremony yesterday to "bear in mind" a need to expand now-depleted Federal funds for college housing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI). -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney called today for a full airing of Vice President Richard M. Nixon's charge that a State Department subordinate was trying to "sabotage" Secretary of State Dulles' policy on China.
PARIS, Monday, Sept. 29 -- Incomplete returns from France's overseas territories showed overwhelming acceptance of a Federal community with France.
When Arturo Toscanini made his debut in Rio de Janeiro at the age of 19, Italian newspapers caricatured him as "il bambino," conducting in short pants.

Local taxes place a substantially higher burden than state taxes do on the average manufacturing concern in the larger localities of the metropolitan area, a report to the Regional Plan Association, Inc., said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A hundred-year-old letter speculating on the world of 1958 has just been discovered in suburban Garrett Park, Md.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower, it was reported tonight, will complete the reorganization of the White House staff with the appointment of Under Secretary of the Treasury Fred C. Scribner Jr. of Maine as the Deputy Assistant to the President.
LYNBROOK, L. I., Sept. 28 -- The Lynbrook Fire Prevention Club, composed of eleven members 10 to 12 years old, is busy handing out posters for National Fire Prevention Week, Oct. 5 to 11.
The expansion overseas of American advertising agencies is continuing. Benton Bowles, Inc., has added billings estimated at $6,500,000 a year through the acquisition of Lambe Robinson of London.

International aid and technical assistance may take a variety of forms. Two years ago an American industrial designer, Russel Wright, was sent to Vietnam by the International Cooperation Administration to make a study of the possibility of exporting Vietnamese handicraft and, if necessary, adapting it at some points to a foreign market.

The Carr R. Purser Agency, New York's largest general agency for the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company, has leased office space in the building under construction at 355 Lexington Avenue, at the northeast corner of Fortieth Street. Samuel Rudin is the builder and owner.
Rarely if ever have I been in accord with opinions expressed by Khrushchev. However, his recent remark that Chiang Kai-shek is a military corpse is only too true.

ANY housewife with some spare time and energy can easily broaden her horizons this fall. There are an astonishing number of daytime and evening courses that cover a diverse range of subjects. Volunteer work, particularly in city hospitals, can be equally edifying.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The United States put a strain on its friendship with Canada last week during maneuvers to keep Communist China out of the United Nations.

Off-track betting on horse races has had mixed results in places where it is now in effect. The good and bad sides of legal bookmaking were reflected in a New York Times survey of Britain, Ireland, France, Australia, New Zealand, Puerto Rico and Nevada.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 -- Maybe the fans in Brooklyn can't exactly say "we told you so," but their errant Dodgers aren't in much of a position to crow either.

BROCCOLI and Brussels sprouts, two vegetables most plentiful in the fall, are the aristocrats of the cabbage family. Characterized by a pronounced flavor, both lend themselves to several interesting methods of preparation.

After a firm beginning, cotton prices in the domestic market eased last week and closed with mixed changes. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 10 to down 25 points for the week.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Eddie LeBaron led the Washington Redskins on two fourth-period touchdown drives today for a 24-14 National Football League victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 28 -- The Government has repaid about half of the $68,750,000 stand-by credit granted in September, 1957, by the International Monetary Fund. A reserve in dollars and gold also has been made for repayment of the balance.

The 13,350-deadweight-ton cargo liner Hoegh Drake will make her initial appearance here tomorrow. The latest addition to the fleet of Leif Hoegh Co. A/S, of Oslo, Norway, was built by Kieler-Howaldstwerke in Germany.
The champion Yankees wound up their regular American League season at the Stadium yesterday in a manner to please Casey Stengel and a crowd of 17,763.
President Eisenhower broadcast an appeal last night for United Fund and Community Chest campaigns all over the country.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts scored twice in the last quarter today to beat the Detroit Lions, champions of the National Football League, 28 -- 15.

THE batting championship of the Ameri-League was won yesterday with one of the least fancy averages in the history of the competition. Perhaps that isn't important, though. Ty Cobb captured twelve hitting crowns in all, but he ranged all the way from a handsome high of .420 to a low of .324.

If man were wholly a rational being he would look about him at all his unsolved problems, he would catalogue them and then proceed to tackle them one at a time -- beginning with the most important (if agreement could be reached on what is most important) until they were all solved.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Bullish periods in the grain futures market generally have been scarce and feeble recently but occasionally one comes along with some muscle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Administration has been systematically seeking bipartisan support, through individual and collective contacts with Congressmen, for its policy on the situation in the Taiwan area.
DETROIT, Sept. 28. -- The United Automobile Workers suddenly postponed today its Tuesday strike deadline against the General Motors Corporation. The new deadline is 10 A. M. Thursday.
Union employes of Youth House in the Bronx went on strike at one minute after midnight this morning.

Earl Brown, Democratic City Councilman and Liberal candidate for Congress against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., will conduct only "a nominal and perfunctory" campaign, and even that reluctantly.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 28 -- Split-level peace prevailed today in Little Rock.

Do-it-yourself mutuel ticket-selling machines are the latest step as automation goes to the races. Now being introduced at selected tracks across the nation, the device accepts currency, and, in connection with the usual mutuel ticket-selling machine, issues a ticket bearing the number of the horse chosen by the bettor.
A large, illuminated flight arrival information board will be placed in operation today at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 28 -- The only legalized off-track betting shops are in West Australia and Tasmania. There, bookmakers pay an annual license fee and a turnover tax, which is divided between the Government and the race clubs.

The new Grace Line cruise ship Santa Paula will make an unusual maiden arrival. Instead of stopping here on her delivery voyage from Newport News, Va., the $25,000,000 vessel will make a leisurely cruise up the Hudson River to Albany, where she will make her first bow to shipping society at a formal evening reception Oct. 12 at the state capital.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The battle for Congress goes into high gear this week. Vice President Richard M. Nixon will start a campaign tour for the Republicans and the Democrats' newest United States Senator will do the same for his party.

EVERY time Bernie Fein listens to the jokes of nightclub, television or Broadway comedians, he chuckles, roars, slaps his thighs and doubles up in convulsive laughter. Mr. Fein is a professional laugher. He will laugh at anything for a fee.

An appraisal of America's scientific achievement and military potential in relation to Russian achievements is the subject of a book by Drew Pearson and Jack Anderson. Called "U. S. A. -- Second-Class Power?" the book will be published by Simon Schuster on Oct. 13, Mr. Pearson is a syndicated newspaper columnist and co-author of "Washington Merry-Go-Round." Mr. Anderson is co-author of "McCarthy: The Man, the Senator, the Ism."
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The French steel industry plans to increase its production from 14,000,000 to 18,500,000 tons a year. It will start a bond drive at the end of October to finance this expansion.
States Marine Lines is nearing the final stage of its three-year struggle for an operating-differential subsidy on four steamship services.
A benefit dinner on Oct. 7 in the ballroom of the Pierre will mark the sixty-fifth anniversary of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York and the opening of its 1958 fund-raising campaign.
PERCIVAL BORDE and his company, with Pearl Primus as guest artist, are dancing these nights at the St. Mark's Playhouse, Second Avenue and Eighth Street, and will continue to do so all this week.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28 -- A young dog who is still struggling to earn the fifteen points necessary for his championship rating, created quite a stir at the thirty-sixth annual Westbury Kennel Association all-breed event today.

A renaissance of Indian art is evidenced in a display of Ecuadorian textiles now on view in the Secretariat Building (South), of the United Nations. The exhibit, which is under the sponsorship of the International Labour Organization, a United Nations agency, will be open 9 A. M. to 6 P. M. daily through Nov. 30.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The native African political leaders of Nigeria, Britain's largest dependency, have assembled here to negotiate their independence in a conference with colonial officials that will begin tomorrow.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 28 -- Members of the Little Rock School Board and of the Little Rock Public School Corporation conferred tonight on arrangements for leasing the city's four high schools.

The grapevine advises that "Follow That Fellow," a new musical by Gore Vidal (plot), Howard Dietz (lyrics) and Arthur Schwartz (tunes), should be listed as a spring contribution. The show is to be done by Saint Subber and Paul Feigay.

EAST VIEW, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- An autopsy today failed to establish immediately the cause of the death of Mrs. Rose Stradner Mankiewicz, former actress, whose body was found yesterday in her summer home on Croton Lake Road in Bedford Hills.
The New York Central Railroad has offered to cede to the city the tracks and other operating facilities in town upon which it pays special franchise taxes.
EASTON, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Today was Ambulance Sunday in this Fairfield County town.

NEAR SOUK-AHRAS, Algeria, Sept. 27 -- In an unusually strong show of force, the French have ringed the hills of eastern Algeria with armor and apparently brought to a halt the Algerian Nationalist Army's first general offensive.
The recognition of Communist China was urged yesterday in a sermon here by the Rev. Donald Harrington.

Commentators on the choice of Maj. Gen. Wilton B. Persons to succeed Sherman Adams as Assistant to the President generally agree on three points: first, General Persons is a popular man with a pleasant way with him; second, he is on good and understanding terms with Congress; third, he doesn't desire, and will not have, the power held by his predecessor.
Carmine G. De Sapio charged yesterday that the decision to run Nelson A. Rockefeller as the Republican candidate for Governor was made "in a board of directors room at the Chase Manhattan Bank."

EASTON, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Today was Ambulance Sunday in this Fairfield County town.

NEAR SOUK-AHRAS, Algeria, Sept. 27 -- In an unusually strong show of force, the French have ringed the hills of eastern Algeria with armor and apparently brought to a halt the Algerian Nationalist Army's first general offensive.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Sept. 28 -- Horse race betting in Nevada is a relatively minor operation, but it is one of the most rigidly controlled of all types of gambling in a state where almost every type of gambling is legal.

At noon today the Supreme Court will meet to hand down the formal opinion it promised earlier this month when it decided against any delay in the integration of white and Negro students at Little Rock's Central High School. As we await that opinion it seems wise to look at the total situation against which the justices of the Supreme Court have been framing their interpretation of the law in this complex and tangled matter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI) -- The National Planning Association warned today that the nation's economic recovery could not be complete until jobs were available to persons now subject to "unworthy prejudice."
Ed (Whitey) Ford of the Yankees and the Braves' Warren Spahn yesterday were named the opposing pitchers for the opening game of the world series at Milwaukee tomorrow.
A fleet-fingered 'cellist, Robert Sayre, made his debut last night in Town Hall.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- France lost no time today in pushing the West African territory of Guinea out of the French community as a result of its rejection of the Constitution yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 -- The embattled Chinese offshore islands are "not strategically defensible in the defense of Formsoa," Under Secretary of State Christian A. Herter said here today. The Chinese Nationalists, he added, have a devotion to these islands that is "almost pathological."

In the U. N. General Assembly yesterday Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo of Indonesia expressed the hope that Russia would stop dumping "abnormally great quantities of tin" on the European market. The result of these shenanigans has been a 12 per cent drop in the world price of tin, one of Indonesia's main exports. Meanwhile the price of rubber, which accounts for nearly half of the island republic's trade, has fallen by 15 per cent.

HAVE you looked up Arthur Zimmermann (1859-1940), German diplomat, in the Encyclopaedia Britannica lately? If not, you may want to glance at his eighteen-line biography in the latest edition before you read Barbara W. Tuchman's book, a true, lucid thriller called "The Zimmermann Telegram."*
The Canadian Pacific Railroad experienced traffic losses in the first eight months of this year, as did most American carriers. But, like American carriers, it had been cutting costs hard.
CLEMSON, S. C., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Labor and management took opposing views here today on the relation of wages to textile industry ills.
In keeping with its compact-car concept, American Motors Corporation has retained the same basic exterior and interior dimensions for its 1959 Ramblers.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Two Left-wing political groups, the Independent Socialist party and the Socialist-Labor party, moved today to keep their places on the state ballot.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Millers won the little world series title tonight by crushing Montreal, 7 -- 1, for a four-game sweep that ran their play-off winning string to eleven straight.

The city school system is planning to undertake special projects in the Harlem and Bedford-Stuyvesant areas in an effort to raise the cultural horizons and educational performance of underprivileged youngsters.
The long-expected merger of Buchanan Co., with Lennen Newell, Inc., was officially announced yesterday, and Madison Avenue began talking about still another agency amalgamation.
CHICAGO. Sept. 29 (AP) --The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line Railroads will study "the possible advantages of merging," it was announced today.
Sixty young men were sworn in as probationary patrolmen yesterday by Chief Clerk Vincent E. Finn, who will retire at the end of today's duties.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 -- "Uh-huh."
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 29 -- The new president of the University of California cautioned today that without intellectual and moral vision "all our scientific achievement may be in vain."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States has made its first foreign aid agreement with the Sudan, officials here said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Justice Felix Frankfurter released a letter today describing his connection with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People before going on the Supreme Court. The fact that he gave legal advice to the association has previously been published.
The long steady decline of the Canadian Mounties' use of horses -- many movies, comic strips and stories to the contrary -- received emphasis on Fifth Avenue yesterday.

The leasehold on the new nineteen-story office building at 635 Madison Avenue, on the northeast corner of Fifty-ninth Street, has been sold by Joseph P. Blitz, Inc., and leased back for a long term. The leasehold was purchased by an investment group headed by Joseph Wolf and Benjamin Kaufman.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Virginia's first experiment in an emergency private school program began to assume the proportion of a cornmunity-wide effort here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Supreme Court turned to history today in emphasizing the precedents on the powers of the Federal courts, the duty of state officials and the meaning of the Fourteenth Amendment.
The Board of Health agreed yesterday to consider a delay in putting into effect a revised Sanitary Code to give the city's two labor federations additional time to study the code's new milk sections.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Unemployment dropped in 125 of the nation's 149 major industrial centers from mid-July to mid-September, the Government reported today.

Directors of the Merchants Bank of New York have called a special meeting of stockholders for Oct. 14 to vote on a two-for-one stock split. They will also be asked to approve the sale of an additional 6,000 shares, to be offered first to shareholders, at a price to be determined at the meeting.
Sales and profits of the Beatrice Foods Company in the six months ended Aug. 31 exceeded those of the corresponding period last year.

AURORA, Ill., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Mayor Paul Egan ordered the suspension of the sixty-eight-man police force tonight. He proclaimed a state of emergency and called on the citizenry to make arrests when laws were violated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas, who is chairman of the House influence investigating subcommittee, lashed back today at Republican charges that he had dropped an investigation because "prominent Democrats became involved."

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- A loud tie and the resonant voice of a skillful orator are the stock in trade of Sekou Toure, impassiomed young political chief of French Guinea who led the voters in his territory to choose independerce from France in yesterday's referendum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Meade Alcorn, Republican national chairman, accused former President Harry S. Truman today of engaging in "falsehoods, distortions and partisan venom" in his current campaign speeches.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 -- The last United States Marine battalion in Lebanon embarked today. There were good reasons to believe that the United States Army units remaining here were already preparing to leave.

A bright future for do-it-yourself trade appeared assured yesterday as the thirteenth annual National Hardware Show opened at the New York Coliseum. Most exhibitors of hardware and allied lines at the show displayed products designed for the do-it-yourself fan as well as for the professional builder and the maintenance industry. This was also true of those making lawn, garden and outdoor products.
THIS is a fish story about Macy's. From now through Oct. 11, about 50,000 aquatic creatures will be housed in the store's Pet Centre aquariums on the fourth floor. All are for sale.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that increased Democratic majorities in Congress would mean higher taxes, cheapened money and the stifling of investment and enterprise to create more jobs.
William Linton, a jeweler who disappeared Sept. 2 with diamonds estimated to be worth up to $100,000, was arrested on the lower East Side yesterday by two detectives.

The Lafayette High football team scored its first victory over Brooklyn Tech in five seasons yesterday at it subdued the Engineers, 8 -- 0, at Brooklyn College Field. It was the opening game of the season for both teams.

If, as has been shown, a baseball analyst finds himself rather badly stumped comparing the Yankees and Braves offensively, he definitely must be all at sea when he tries to match the defensive skills of the two clubs that are about to joust again in the world series.
RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 29 -- The army take-over of power in Burma continued to be a quiet affair today despite an emphatic denunciation from a Communist direction.
Twenty steamship companies, representing the backbone of the United States merchant marine, face a strike scheduled for midnight tonight.
The New York City Housing Authority is planning to borrow $76,773,000 with short-term notes to finance eleven housing developments.
A revised administrative set-up for the Fire Department and a shift in assignments for fifteen of the uniformed top command were announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A Senate small business subcommittee urged today appointment of a special coordinator in the Defense Department to bring more small companies into the missile procurement program.
Northwest Orient Airlines, Inc., is introducing a credit card for its passengers. It is said to be the first transcontinental airline to issue one requiring no deposit.
Nelson A. Rockefeller charged Governor Harriman last night with failing to stem a drift of business and industry out of New York.

AN Englishman may not be the best source of information on what constitutes the perfect Martini, but he usually can talk well on the cocktail's most important ingredient, gin. This is especially true if the Englishman is Sir Godfrey Nicholson, M. P.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- Governor Harriman asked Republican legislative leaders today to authorize a $1,400,000 advance from the governmental emergency fund to continue a new program for supplementing teachers' pensions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29--The United States and Britain have given Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold renewed assurances regarding the early withdrawal of their forces from Lebanon and Jordan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Supreme Court said today that neither direct opposition nor "evasive schemes" could nullify its ruling that racial segregation in the public schools was unconstitutional.

The Charfran Stable's Crafty Skipper, a 2-year-old chestnut colt, staged a speed exhibition for 21,698 Belmont fans yesterday in capturing the $34,875 Cowdin Stakes by four lengths over Four-Way Ranch's Atoll.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle had France and her overseas possessions in his hands today, but there was no clear indication of what he planned to do with them.

NELSON A. ROCKEFELLER, the Republican candidate for Governor, may prove himself an effective television campaigner, which presumably could be an important asset in his forthcoming tilt with Governor Harriman, the Democratic incumbent.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower was plunged into controversy today over California's proposed "right-to-work" law which would abolish the union shop.
Plans for resumption of labor-management negotiations at the General Electric Company were almost torpedoed yesterday by union objections to having the company pay the bill for the meeting room.

PRESIDIO, Tex., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Planes manned by United States border patrolmen and Mexican Government pilots moved food, clothing and medical supplies today to thousands isolated by record Rio Grande flood waters in this area of southwest Texas.

A troupe of cowboys entertainers led by Roy Rogers played the part of visiting physicians at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning. They performed for an hour -- riding, singing, dancing and clowning -- before children and other patients at the big municipal institution.
The appointment of Peter J. Reidy, an engineer, as Commissioner of the reorganized and much-investigated Department of Buildings was announced last night by Mayor Wagner.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)--The Bureau of Prisons informed a Congressional committee today that reports by its inspectors on local jail conditions were not available to the public.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Manager Casey Stengel led his New York Yankees into Milwaukee today for the world series, but declined to predict the outcome.
Underwriters led jointly by Morgan Stanley Co. and McDonald Co. are offering at par today $7,000,000 of 5 per cent, twenty-year debentures of the Harshaw Chemical Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Customs today ordered all its offices to make effective on Wednesday the import curbs on lead and zinc ordered by President Eisenhower a week ago.
TOKYO, Sept. 30 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi reaffirmed in the Diet today that Japan's foreign policy was based on cooperation with free nations, especially the United States.
In an operation carried out with almost military precision, 275 children aged 2 and under were taken a block to their new home in the New York Foundling Hospital yesterday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 29 -Nationalist China's two top leaders have joined in an appeal to win the understanding of public opinion in the United States on the necessity of holding the Quemoy and Matsu outposts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- United States scientists have successfully tested a shipboard rocket to be used in measuring stratospheric radiation during an eclipse of the sun.
Vincent J. Squillante, reputed boss of the $50,000,000-a-year garbage hauling business in the metropolitan area, was picked up for questioning last night in the murder of Albert Anastasia on Oct. 25.

We agree with City Council Minority Leader Isaacs that Mayor Wagner looks just a bit silly seeking enactment of a law that would permit him to designate "one or more officers or employes serving in his office to sign or execute, in the name of such officer or employe, any document, instrument or other paper which the Mayor is required by law to sign except local laws."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court's school integration opinion was denounced by Southern Senators today and hailed by Northerners.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Greater diligence in weeding out non-productive persons from Civil Service Government payrolls was urged by John W. Macy Jr., former executive director of the United States Civil Service Commission.
HUNTERS, anglers and trappers have just been reminded by Conservation Commissioner Sharon J. Mauhs that they will need new licenses tomorrow.
The Supreme Court opinion yesterday on the rights of children to be free of discrimination in admission to schools cited two word -- "ingeniously" and ingenuously" -- that are often incorrectly used.

Paul Windels Jr., New York regional administrator for the Securities and Exchange Commission, charged in Federal Court here yesterday that an offering for public sale of some $500,000 of Arvida Corporation stock was in violation of the Securities Act of 1933.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The conflict between the Teamsters Union and its court-appointed three-man board of monitors grew in intensity today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Indonesia supported Communist China here today in its dispute over the Taiwan Strait. Another "Bandung conference," this time at the United Nations, was seen by Indonesia as probably the best means of arriving at a peaceful solution.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Nigerian leaders asked Britain today to accede to their request for independence on April 2, 1960, in speeches at the opening session of the constitutional conference with British colonial authorities.
NORWALK Conn., Sept. 29 -- Several important zoning changes will be considered by city agencies next month.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Prices closed 10 points higher to 1 point lower than on last Friday. One point equals 5 cents a bale.
Hundreds of thousands of tree swallows gathering here for their annual migration south are delaying morning trains on the IND Rockaway division.
A strike of union employes at Youth House in the Bronx prevented the transportation of two dozen youngsters to court yesterday. A temporary court was set up at Youth House for Boys as a result.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Charles Schneer, whose Morningside productions is affiliated with Columbia Pictures, is planning to film "Gulliver's Travels" next summer. Universal-lnternational announced last year that it would produce the Jonathan Swift satire.

" N. B. C. Kaleidoscope," a one-hour television series encompassing public affairs, pictorial journalism and all fields of entertainment, will be introduced next month by the National Broadcasting Company.

France begins a new life on Sunday when the de Gaulle Constitution is promulgated. The overwhelming character of the victory in last Sunday's referendum proclaimed to the world and to history that the time had come for a profound change in a nation that has played a great role for many centuries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The State Department said today it had reports that the Soviet might launch an earth satellite from Chinese Communist territory Wednesday to mark the Peiping regimes's anniversary. The People's Republic of China was proclaimed in 1949.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 29 -- A garden containing the plants, flowering trees and shrubs mentioned in Walt Whitman's works will be established here on the campus of C. W. Post College. The garden, dedicated to the Long Island-born poet who wrote "Leaves of Grass," will be the gift of nineteen students in the college.
The rapid development of United States South Atlantic ports into increasingly important terminals for United States foreign trade was described yesterday.

The Junior Committee of Guide Post for Children, Inc., is sponsoring a fete being called the "Gigi Ball" on Oct. 11 at the Metropolitan Club.
Short term borrowing costs for business jumped in two areas yesterday.
OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 29 -- Two Federal circuit judges ordered the Little Rock Board of Education today to retain control of the city high schools and to maintain their integrated status.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Unexplained blunders, or blunders that remain unexplained until the principals publish their memoirs, have happened in every regime. But inexplicable blunders are less usual, and the Eisenhower Administration is beginning to acquire an impressive score in this category.
