BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- In the first test of a new union organization law the Argentine Labor Ministry has recognized an insurgent Peronist faction as leader of the Railroad Workers Union.
The Red Cross blood bank received 691 pints Friday. Included were 307 pints donated by members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at 201 East Sixty-ninth Street.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- Premier Toure called a meeting of his Government today after having been told officially by France that Guinea no longer formed part of French West Africa.

Across the Hudson River, as many commuters know, a state of confusion has come into existence as the result of a New Jersey tradition that has produced some of the biggest towns and some of the smallest cities in the nation.
The resignation of A. Philip Randolph as chairman of the Independent People's Committee for the re-election of Representative Adam Clayton Powel Jr. was announced last night.

The letter from former Senator Herbert H. Lehman published Sept. 23 contains a grave factual error in stating that "the offshore islands * * * have been used by Chiang Kai-shek for the past three years as military bases to apply the threat of force against Communist China -- as possible jumping-off places for an invasion of the Chinese mainland -- with American help, of course."
WARSAW, Sept. 29 -- The political drama of the Warsaw talks will enter its third week tomorrow still in search of a final act.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 29 -- Two employes of a :Newark rigging company plunged thirty feet to a concrete floor today when their wooden scaffold broke inside a factory building.
Most of the news was good yesterday and the stock market responded. The New York Times combined and rail averages made the best marks of 1958 in an advance that swept across virtually the whole list.

In the inner councils of industry the labor negotiations that are getting the closest attention these days are not the much-spotlighted strike threats in the automobile industry but the relatively unnoticed union-management talks at General Electric.
Charles H. Kellstadt, the recently elected president of Sears, Roebuck Co., predicted yesterday a "gradual improvement" in the economy rather than a "great boom."
DETROIT, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The auto industry increased production of 1959 model cars last week despite numerous work stoppages.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The British Government is willing to attend a conference with delegates from Greece, Turkey and the Greek and Turkish Cypriote communities to discuss modifications in its seven-year plan for Cyprus.

WITH THE ALGERIAN REBELS, Sept. 29 -- Leaders and troops of the rebel army operating in eastern Algeria kept their ears close to hundreds of variously battered radios through the night and into the morning.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29 -The Westchester Magistrates Association contended today that the job of prosecuting criminals and other offendetrs in the many local courts did not belong exclusively to the District Attorney.
LIBERTY, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Governor Harriman accused Vice President Richard M. Nixon today of having tried to censor news of public reaction to the Administration's Taiwan policy.

WITH quiet precision Richard Hunt, a 23-year-old artist from Chicago, has located the expressive dimensions of a difficult medium -- welded metal. His first New York exhibition is at the Alan Gallery, 766 Madison Avenue.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 29 -- The Little Rock School Board announced tonight that it would comply with a court order enjoining it from taking further action to transfer the city's four high schools to a private corporation.
The Board of Elections got back yesterday 58,062 of the 2,431,000 postcards it mailed out last week to registered voters to ascertain how many had moved since last year's election.

Shipping in the North Atlantic was beset by two severe storms yesterday -- Hurricane Helene, now reduced to the status of dangerous gales, and her younger sister, Ilsa, expected soon to cross the busy shipping lanes in mid-ocean.

Even though "Bells Are Ringing," the musical starring Judy Holliday at the Shubert since Nov. 29, 1956, is still doing almost capacity business, the show will be forced to close Dec. 13. It has to leave the Shubert then to make way for the arrival of "Whoop-Up" on Dec. 18.

ALGIERS, Sept. 29 -- French authorities in charge of supervising the referendum in Algeria were satisfied tonight that no irregularities of any consequence occurred during the three-day vote on the new Constitution for France.

In an opinion unanimously reaffirming its school desegregation decisions of 1954 and 1955, the United States Supreme Court has again laid down the law of this land for especial benefit of the nullifiers, the evaders, the race-rioters and the demagogues who incite them, headed up at the moment by the present Governor of the State of Arkansas and his Legislature.

State and city housing officials expressed fear yesterday that state bond issues of $200,000,000 for loans for public and private housing might be defeated in the November referendum. They urged supporters of the bonds to "make every vote count."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 29 -- Gov. James E. Folsom commuted to life imprisonment today the death sentence of a Negro convicted of robbing a woman of $1.95 in her home after dark. Night-time burglary is a capital crime in Alabama.

Music events today will include an organ recital by Searle Wright in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, at noon; a recital by Sophie Ginn, soprano, at Town Hall, 8:30; and a concert by the Metropolitan Wind Ensemble, Lorenz Segall conducting, at Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 29 -- There was no scrimmage for Andover's varsity football squad today. Steve Sorota, the Royal Blue's head coach, departed from his usual Monday procedure.
A half-century of service to the City of New York will be celebrated Thursday by First Deputy Controller Louis Cohen.

In 1915 Vilhjalmur Stefansson suggested to Sir Hubert Wilkins that specially designed submarines could "do wonderfully" in the polar ice pack to find a route linking the Eastern and Western hemispheres. In 1931, Sir Hubert made an unsuccessful attempt to open such a route under the Arctic.
Five New York-bound Pennsylvania Railroad trains were stalled up to an hour on the Jersey Meadows yesterday afternoon.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept, 29 -- Hungary charged in the General Assembly today that United States policies were endangering Hungary's relations with Austria.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 -- Frank W. Jenks, president of the International Harvester Company, Chicago, said today his company expected further improvements in the farm equipment business next year.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 29--Undiscouraged by the loss to Cornell in the opening game, the Colgate football team began work today for its meeting here Saturday with Rutgers, which scored its most decisive triumph over Princeton on record.
Few mergers would come as more of a surprise, if not a downright shock, to the railroad industry, and to Wall Street than one involving the Atlantic Coast Line and the Seaboard.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Sidney E. Smith, Canadian Minister for External Affairs, denied here today a report published in The New York Times this morning that an important policy speech by him last week had been changed at the request of the United States State Department.

WARSAW, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Polish police used tear gas and clubs to break up a mob of rioters protesting the removal of a religious shrine unauthorized by either church or state, Cracow newspapers reaching here today reported.

Tomorrow is "zero hour" in Cyprus, with Britain scheduled to begin implementing a seven-year plan for progressive self-government on the island on the basis of politically segregated Greek and Turkish communities under an overall "partnership" between Britain, Greece and Turkey. The Greek Cypriote underground threatens to drown this plan in blood and the Greek Government is under increasing pressure to leave the NATO alliance if necessary to kill it.

Today's new film is "Windoms Way," a British version of the novel, by James Ramsey Ullman, starring Peter Finch and Mary Ure, at the Odeon, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street. Ronald Neame directed the Rank Organization presentation, which was produced by John Bryan from a screen play by Jill Craigie.

Your editorial on New York City's proposal to legalize off-track betting in order to increase tax revenues was an impartial, factual presentation. Although the suggestion that a referendum be employed to determine the stand of the public on this issue was a good idea, it is unlikely to be followed.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 29 -- Pressure for the reopening of six Norfolk schools closed by Virginia's anti-integration laws was building up rapidly today.
ROME, Sept. 29 -Harry Belafonte, the Negro folk singer, told Italians today that "America will survive Faubus in the same way as Europe survived Hitler."

LONDON, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- One of the youngest British generals of World War II, Gen. Sir Francis Festing, took over Britain's top military job today as Chief of the Imperial General Staff. He succeeds Field Marshal Sir Gerald Templer, who is retiring.
PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization began urgent consultations today on the Cyprus problem.

The American Ballet Theatre last night gave the season's only scheduled presentation of William Dollar's "The Combat" at the Metropolitan Opera House. This is the same ballet, with music by Raffaelo de Banfield, that has long been in the repertoire of the New York City Ballet Company under the title of "The Duel."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Maritime Administration unveiled an artist's conception of a nuclear-powered cargo submarine today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP) -- A missing inventor was being sought today by a company that says the inventor's secret device to prevent air collisions could make him a wealthy man.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 29 -- A rich yield of 2,000-year-old treasures has been unearthed from the site of an ancient Greek city in Sicily by the Princeton University Archaeological Expedition.
Jose Torres, a swift-punching Puerto Richan middleweight stopped Otis Woodard of New York in the main bout listed for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the registration of the McGrath Securities Corporation, New York, as a broker and dealer in securities for "willful violation" of registration requirements.

The executive committee of the department of Christian social relations of the Protestant Council of the City of New York named a six-man committee yesterday to request a meeting with Henry L. McCarthy, city Commissioner of Welfare.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals today signed Solly Hemus, a former Redbird player, to a one-year contract as a playing manager. The selection was indicated several weeks ago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Active selling in all pits carried grain futures prices downward on the Board of Trade today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- The resurgence within five years of the major motion picture studios as the primary source of production in Hollywood was predcited today by Jerry Wald.

GARRY MOORE, one of television's more personable figures, inaugurated an hour-long variety show over Channel 2 last night. Unhappily, the program was ponderous and formal and never achieved the informality that has distinguished the star's daytime efforts in past seasons.
KEY WEST, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Aircraft looking for a Navy patrol plane missing with ten men aboard found airplane wreckage late today in the Gulf of Mexico, twenty-two miles north of Key West.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The stock market generally resumed its advance today. Gains outnumbered losses in almost all sections. This buoyancy was ascribed, in part, to yesterday's improvement on Wall Street.

SEVERAL first performances were presented last night in a program of chamber music at Carnegie Recital Hall. The Playwrights' Company has again taken up Christopher Fry's adaptation of Jean Giraudoux' "Pour Lucrece," now labeled "Duel of Angels." Scheduled until recently for presentation here during the fall of 1959, the play instead will be done on Broadway in the spring for a limited engagement.
Westchester County, N. Y., borrowed $8,555,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements. The money was raised by the sale of bonds due serially from 1959 to 1981.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Little progress was reported to have been made today toward a solution of the Cyprus dispute by the Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30 -- There were unusual and uncertain aspects about the Braves as they marked time today before the opening of their defense of the world championship tomorrow. Perhaps, the most unusual angle was Manager Fred Haney's departure from his normal genial mood.

Shareholders of the Bank of New York approved at a special meeting yesterday an increase in the bank's capital stock. The action was designed to provide for a 50 per cent stock dividend and a 30,000-share stockholder subscription offering,

Violette Verdy and Erik Bruhn danced the first "Nutcracker" pas de deux in the current season of the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, as the only novelty of the evening. It was a thoroughly expert performance all around, and one with charm and style as well.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has begun distribution to high schools here of a colored comic book describing its check collection activities. The book will be available to schools throughout the country through Federal Reserve Banks.

The Standard Oil Company of California yesterday announced substantial reductions in prices of heavy fuel oil and in heavy crude oils. The company sells heavy fuel oil and buys crude oil, which is used in the manufacture of fuel oil.
The American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc., wishes to thank your generous readers for their always prompt response to our appeal for clothing for the destitute Hungarian refugees, Koreans, etc.

As the proportion of older people in this country grows rapidly greater, and the labor force increases, the problems of retirement mount. The widespread requirement in industry and government that at some fixed age, usually 65, all employes must quit is being increasingly questioned.

RED SKELTON'S opening show of the season over Channel 2 last night was not without its weaknesses. Some of his prepared routines were on the labored side. Liberace, as a guest, did not improve matters.
Stockholders of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation approved yesterday a plan to liquidate the company, which owns property here and in other cities.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- In essence, opponents of the new French Constitution divided into two groups. Those on the Left wanted a republic without de Gaulle. Those on the Right wanted de Gaulle without a republic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Henry C. Wallich, professor of Economics at Yale University, was named today as assistant to Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Treasury. The post is a new one in which Mr. Wallich will conduct special economic studies.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- Bronze treasure that graced the palace of King Gordius in the Phrygian capital of Gordium 2,700 years ago arrived here by air today. It is part of an exhibit lent to the University of Pennsylvania Museum by the Turkish Government.
Two extremes in style are embodied in the 1959 Cadillac line that will go on sale today.
FORT JACKSON, S. C., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- A lieutenant and two sergeants were ordered held for a general court-martial today on charges of mistreating Army trainees.
Following is the text of the United States Court of Appeals decision yesterday in the case of Marie Torre's appeal from an order holding her in criminal contempt:
Army's "lonesome end" formation, introduced with such striking success against South Carolina last Saturday, has football fans buzzing.
Governor Harriman asserted last night that the state's economic health had improved under his Administration.
The Columbia Broadcasting System has completed plans for a new one-hour drama series titled "Pursuit," which makes its television debut on Wednesday, Oct. 22, at 8 P. M.
TOKYO, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China charged the United States today with trying to "trick" the Peiping regime into a cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Farm product prices increased about 2.79 per cent during the month ended Sept. 15.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. began his campaign last night to oust the Tammany leadership in Harlem.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Oct. 1 -- The United States has come to Nationalist China's assistance on Quemoy Island with new big guns, landing ships and cargo planes.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Sept. 30 -- Every morning at 11 and every afternoon at 4 a waitress in black dress and white apron and cap appears upon the platform occupied by the National Executive Committee of the British Labor party. Undeterred by the glare of batteries of lights, the eyes of television cameras or waves of oratory, she serves tea and biscuits.

The number of persons injured in city traffic increased last week compared with the same periof a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. At the same time the number of persons killed declined.
Four New Yorkers received honorary degrees last night from Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion at the opening of the school's thirty-seventh academic year.
LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 30--Jose Pires Cardoso, Minister of the Interior, announced today a ban on celebrations scheduled for Oct. 5 to mark the forty-seventh anniversary of the republic.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

SOPHIE GINN, soprano, the third recital award winner of the New York Singing Teachers Association, sang a debut recital at Town Hall last night. A Master of Arts from the Juilliard School, Miss Ginn has sung with the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre and other groups.
The Hooker Chemical Corporation's earnings for the nine months ended Aug. 31 were 3.2 per cent below those a year earlier. Sales were down 3.5 per cent.

Contributions of $93,998 were reported at the opening campaign luncheon yesterday of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York. Mrs. William R. White, chairman of the annual drive, presided at the meeting at the Barbizon Hotel for Women.
The State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday announced that it had won the first legal contest involving the constitutionality of an anti-discrimination law in Federally assisted housing.
WASHINGTON, Sept 30 -- Charles I. Schottland, Social Security Administrator, reported today that some recent Russian researches into disability merited study in the United States.
UNLESS the plot thins, the opening concert of the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall tomorrow night should be an important fashion event.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Dominican Republic spent about half a million dollars on the investigation conducted by American lawyers into the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez.

Futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Zinc, lead, copper, tin, rubber and hides rose; the world sugar contract and potatoes declined, and price movements for cocoa, coffee, the domestic sugar months, wool and cottonseed oil were mixed.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark. Sept. 30 -- A citizens' corporation canceled plans to open the four high schools here today after having been prohibited from changing their integrated status by a Federal court.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept, 30 -- The Most Rev. John Joyce Russell, for eight years Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Charleston, S. C., was installed today as Bishop of the Diocese of Richmond.
The National Arts Club at 15 Gramercy Park will give a Halloween gala at its headquarter Oct. 24.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today that the largest tractor train in Antarctic history was traveling between Little America and Byrd Station, a 600-mile trip through the Antarctic waste.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--President Eisenhower decided today to visit New York City on Columbus Day, Oct. 12, when the political campaign will be at its height.
The Welfare Department's policy on contraceptive therapy for its clients will be discussed at a conference in the office of Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, next Wednesday at 10 A. M.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower named his chief aviation adviser, Elwood R. Quesada, to be administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency. The appointment becomes effective Nov. 1.
The third annual New York High Fidelity Show opened yesterday at the New York Trade Show Building, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

Four new films will open in local theatres today. "The Big Country," a United Artists drama with Gregory Peck, Jean Simmons, Carroll Baker and Charlton Heston, is at the Astor, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- United States Ambassador Robert M. McClintock brought top leaders of Lebanon's warring factions together tonight in an effort to find a compromise setlement for the tense political deadlock.

YONKERS, Sept. 30 -- Belle Acton, though "not at her sharpest," answered William Haughton's urging tonight and drove down the Yonkers Raceway stretch to take the $50,000 Transamerica Pace by a nose. The 5-year-old mare just nipped her constant rival, Speedy Pick, to gain the $25,000 first money.

TWELVE kilometers out of Paris is Le Coq Hardi, a charming wayside inn where the food is superb. One of the specialties there is an individual chicken pie that looks like a turnover. The following formula for Coq Hardi chicken pie is among a collection of recipes from seven foreign countries that Pillsbury Mills prepared in its European test kitchen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30--A member of the Civil Aeronautics Board today lamented a "temporary paralysis" which, he said, prevented the board from approving fares that would generate more business for airlines.
Directors of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company authorized yesterday continued negotations for a merger of the two companies.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Britain narrowed the United States' lead today in the race to put the first jet airliners into service on the North Atlantic route.
LIBERTY, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Friendliness was bustin' out all over here today for Nelson A. Rockefeller, Republican candidate for Governor.

Federal District Court Judge Gregory F. Noonan took under advisement here yesterday afternoon a motion for a preliminary injunction by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Arvida Corporation, Arthur Vining Davis and two investment banking houses.

" Four--four--four I got, do I go to four and a half? Fair warning--sold!" A Steinway piano that had been played by Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Fats Waller and Erroll Garner, among others, was bought for $450 by a dealer named Frederick Cryde, and the Savoy Ballroom era of American jazz was over.

Bonds called for redemption in September before maturity totaled $56,254,000, the smallest amount since May. when $47,808,000 was redeemed. The total, however, though below the $79,814,000 for July, was the largest for any September since 1955, when prepayments were $235,241,000.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. Nat Koch of the home club won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Windle Challenge Trophy over the Fairview Country Club course today.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- The Iraqi Government tonight proclaimed an agrarian law limiting individual land holdings and Premier el-Kassem broadcast a warning over the Baghdad radio against any obstruction of the law.
DETROIT, Sept. 30 -- A new three-year labor agreement between the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers appeared close today, but a clear-cut settlement eludes weary negotiators.
MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 30 -- The autonomy amendment to Dade County's new home rule charter was defeated today by an unofficial vote of 72,475 to 46,197.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 30 -- After thirty years of discussion, the Sprain Brook Parkway is to be started this year.

LANSING, Mich., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Michigan's Attorney General Paul L. Adam's, ruled today that 1,200 employees of the Kelvinator division of the American Motors Corporation were ineligible to collect unemployment benefits if they also received a bonus.

QUEMOY, China, Sept. 30 (AP) -- More than 2,000 children on Quemoy and Little Quemoy are living in caves and underground shelters as winter approaches with threats of influenza, smallpox and exposure.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that the United States should press for a cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait and Nationalist evacuation of the islands of Quemoy and Matsu.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold made public today statements by the United States and Britain confirming their intentions regarding an early withdrawal of their forces from Lebanon and Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- There is a persistent myth in Washington that Walter Spencer Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, was once a missionary in China. When he speaks of China, Nationalist and Communist, he speaks with a fervor that is little short of religious.

Directors of the Lukens Steel Company declared a dividend yesterday of 25 cents on the common stock, half the amount paid in the two previous quarters. The dividend is payable on Nov. 14 to holders of record on Oct. 31.

The trustees of the New York Racing Association and the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association yesterday completed formation of a foundation to provide relief for needy persons connected with thoroughbred racing in the state.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 30 -- For the first ten minutes the Syracuse-Boston College football game was a nightmare to Ben Schwartzwalder Saturday as his Orange eleven trailed by 14 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Three railroads asked the Supreme Court today for permission to abandon passenger ferries across the Hudson River between New Jersey and New York while they fight out the issue in lower courts.
More than 6,000 storm-weary passengers trooped off six inbound trans-Atlantic liners yesterday after encounters with Hurricane Helene.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- Cardinal Spellman arrived here tonight from Naples heading a group of 607 pilgrims from New York. He is expected to have a private audience with Pope Pius tomorrow or Thursday during which they will in all likelihood review the most pressing world problems.

Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji carried 175 pounds in the $14,125 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Walsh's Independence.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- The Musicians Guild of America announced today the signing of its first contract in the field of independent motion-picture production.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States will open a recruiting drive tomorrow to interest talented young people in career government jobs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Eastern Air Lines today asked the Federal Communications Commission to revoke the license of Public Service Television, Inc., to operate Miami's disputed TV Channel 10.

RICHARDS RUBEN, a young California painter is having his first New York show at the Grand Central Moderns Gallery, 1018 Madison Avenue. He is concerned with broadly interpreted aspects of nature, particularly, it appears, with the buoyant clarity of morning light and the abundant flow of summer.
A statistical survey of 500,000 families to determine the relationship between personal habits and cancer is being prepared by the American Cancer Society.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Hungary over the last year continued to be dominated by Soviet military might despite the "decreased visibility" of Soviet uniformed troops and armor, a newly issued report asserted today.
Public offerings of bonds here set new highs in September. Industrial bond flotations set a record both for a single issue and for the group as a whole.
ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 955 persons who passed the bar examination given last July 1 and 2, A total of 1,916 had taken the test.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union has resumed test explosions of nuclear weapons, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

Vice President Nixon has officially taken umbrage at the disclosure by a State Department official of the fact that about 80 per cent of the mail concerning governmental policy in the Quemoy-Matsu imbroglio is opposed to our Government's decision to defend these islands.

Net income of the General Telephone Corporation and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Aug. 31 rose to $47,111,000, or $3.07 a share, from $46,561,000, or $3.18 a share, a year earlier, it was announced yesterday.
Five school children snipped ribbons yesterday to symbolize the opening of $16,000,000 worth of expressway sections in Kings, Queens and Nassau Counties.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Col. Abdul Salam Arif, one of the leading figures in Iraq's revolution against King Faisal, has been relieved of his posts as Deputy Premier and Minister of the Interior.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for Senator, promised last night that if elected he would lead the Senate fight for civil rights legislation against "Faubusism."
Vincent J. Squillante faces new questioning in the fatal shooting last Oct. 25 of Albert Anastasia.

Federal mediators worked out a ten-day schedule yesterday for labor-management talks affecting 70,000 employes of the General Electric Company. But company and union negotiators showed no disposition to agree on what they ought to talk about.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- The coal-conscious Chesapeake and Ohio Railway is confident that export of American coal will continue to be highly profitable for many years, even though export shipments in recent months have fallen somewhat.

The price of lead rose a half-cent a pound yesterday, to 11 1/2 cents. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Robert G. DEARBORN, Mich. Sept. 30 -- The Ford Motor Company has performed drastic surgery on its infant Edsel line in hopes of making it a healthy yearling for 1959. The highly-publicized car, which cost Ford $250,000,000 to bring to market last fall, has been cut back sharply in price and class range.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The British heavyweight champion, Brian London, scored a fifth-round technical knockout over Willie Pastrano tonight when the referee stopped the fight because of a bad cut on the American's left eyelid.
The Appellate Division upheld yesterday the thirty-day contempt sentence against Frank Costello for refusing to explain the meaning of a slip found in his pocket at the time he was shot last year.
A gang of teen-age boys stabbed two youths and beat two other persons in two attacks last night in the Claremont Park section of the Bronx. All four victims were released after hospital treatment.
HARTFORD, Sept. 30 -- Gov. Edmund S. Muskie of Maine warned the nation's Democrats tonight not to be over-confident because of the party's Sept. 8 victory in his state.
The Astor Ball, a gala dinner dance reminiscent of New York's golden social age, was held last night at the Astor Hotel for the benefit of the Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

The New York City Ballet, which closed the first section of its tenth anniversary season at the City Center Sunday, has announced one of the major productions to be made when the second section begins Nov. 25. This is George Balanchine's re-creation of "The Seven Deadly Sins," with music by the late Kurt Weill and libretto by the late Bertolt Brecht.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 (AP) --- The United States Customs Bureau ruled today that four pieces of imported manufactured metal also are "objets d'art." And as such they are duty free.

WARSAW, Sept. 30 -- United States diplomats met again today with Chinese Communist representatives and pressed for a cease-fire agreement that would include the withdrawal of large Nationalist forces from the offshore islands.

Stockholders of the Corn Products Refining Company and Best Foods, Inc., endorsed a merger of the companies at separate meetings here yesterday. The new corporation called the Corn Products Company will have sales of more than $600,000,000 a year.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the criminal contempt conviction of Marie Torre, television columnist for The New York Herald Tribune.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An Agriculture Department official said today that politics had nothing to do with the waiving of penalty provisions of the soil bank program prior to the 1956 general elections.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30 -- Right or wrong, the strategy Casey Stengel will employ against the Braves in the world series starting tomorrow will be his own. The Yankees' manager, who today admitted he had listened to the advice of National League "friends" last year, is hopeful of doing better on his own this time.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. J. Stuart Brown of Sewickley, Pa., and Mrs. John Wintersteen, Philadelphia, scored 38, 39 -- 77 in alternate-stroke play at the Westchester County Club today to win the Scotch foursomes phase of the thirty-third annual United States Senior Women's Golf Association tournament by six shots.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Sept. 30 -- The Babcock Wilcox Company had a nuclear field day here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Nationalist China said today that common sense barred it from trying to wrest the mainland from Communist control. However, it pledged its aid if the people revolted "as the Hungarian people did."

GREAT BEND, Kan., Sept. 390 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gov. Joseph Henkle, who went into debt to entertain Governor Harriman of New York at a dinner, said today that he had settled a suit for payment of the grocery bill.
A deck officer's strike began at 12:01 this morning that is expected to tie up more than 3,000,000 deadweight tons of United States shipping.
A fast-fingered thief with a long stretch got $20,000 yesterday from an unoccupied teller's cage in a crowded East Side bank.

The Queens County Medical Society voted last night, 68 to 53, to disapprove any insurance plan that uses the class of hospital accommodations a patient gets as the basis for determining his physician's fee.

To catch and hold their interest the information must be dramatized in terms of the adventures and emotions of particular individuals. If the information is unpleasant and not about Main Street and next-door affairs, most people are all the more reluctant to inform themselves about it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The United States paid $38,000,000 here today in honoring its promise of aid to under-developed countries.

EXETER, N. H., Sept. 30 -- Although Phillips Exeter's gridiron squad was beaten by Brewster Academy in last Saturday's mud, the Big Red players are taking the defeat in stride.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The National Institutes of Health announced today that during the fiscal year ended June 30, 9,534 grants totaling $136,112,014 were made for research, training and construction in non-Federal institutions.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Kansas City Athletics tonight purchased John (Zeke) Bella from the New York Yankees, completing the deal that sent Murry Dickson to the league champions late in August.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States was in favor of reducing Nationalist forces on Quemoy if the Chinese Communists would stop their bombardment.
Salomon Bros. Hutzler and associates are offering today $1,875,000 of Chicago and North Western Railway 5 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates, due from Oct. 15, 1959 to 1973.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- For the first time since the end of World War II the consistent upward trend of world agricultural production has been interrupted by a minor decline during 1957-58, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today in its annual survey.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 17 points yesterday. The rise equaled 15 cents to 85 cents a bale.

The Guardian Life Insurance Company of America plans to modernize its twenty-story home office building at 50 Union Square and to build a threestory annex. The plans have been approved by the New York State Department of Insurance.

MADRID, Oct. 1 -- Spain marked today the twenty-second anniversary of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's assumption of total power.

The outcome of the Treasury's offering of $3,500,000,000 of new certificates of indebtedness and discount bills for cash subscription will not be known until later today.
The Soviet Union yesterday defeated the Netherlands, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, in Section 1 of the preliminaries in a thirty-sixnation team tournament at the Deutsche Museum in Munich.
LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Eastcor, a 6-year-old brown gelding, today captured the Rolling Rock Hunt Cup race. His time was 4:41 1/5.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 1 (AP) Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, paid tribute to the nation's working newspaper men today. He called them dedicated professional people providing a vital service.

Fifty years at sea in sailing ships, cargo vessels and luxury liners ended yesterday for Capt. Ernest H. Nelson. He brought his last command, the American Export liner Constitution, into port for the last time.

Raymond N. Caverly has joined Helmsley-Spear, Inc., as a consultant on insurance district properties for which the company is agent. He formerly was vice president of the America Fore Insurance Group.

The Pennroad Corporation designated a subscription price yesterday of $16.25 a share for its offering of 1,286,619 shares of stock to shareholders at the rate of one new share for every four held. The offering will end on Oct. 15.
Any hope that the city could increase tax revenue by legalizing off-track betting got another rebuff yesterday from Oswald D. Heck, the Speaker of the State Assembly.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 -- Some of the "inner strains" of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were listed tonight by Gen. Lauris Norstad, commander of the North Atlantic Treaty forces, in a speech at a dinner of the National Guard Association.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Statements on China made by Secretary of State Dulles at his news conference yesterday have been widely interpreted here as a welcome modification of the United States position.

With commendable if somewhat belated flexibility the Eisenhower Administration is now undertaking a "clarification" amounting to a realignment of our China policy to bring it more in line both with the military realities and with overwhelming public opinion at home and abroad.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 1 -- King Hussein announced today that British troops would begin withdrawing from Jordan Oct. 20. His statement, in a speech opening Jordan's Parliament, was greeted with applause and shouts of "Long Live the King!"
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Belgium suggested today that Quemoy and Matsu be "demilitarized and put beyond reach of a coup, under the protection of the United Nations."

Town Hall's 1958-59 season opens today at 5:30 P. M., when its annual travel film series presents a motion picture on the Tyrol. Included in the new season's program are lectures and courses in opera, music appreciation and singing.

United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., had consolidated net earnings of $7,145,489 in the fiscal year ended June 30, after providing $4,474,129 for taxes J. W. Schwab, president, reported yesterday. The company is a highly diversified manufacturer, retailer and financing concern.

ONEIDA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County, Democrat-Liberal candidate for Senator, opened a four-day upstate tour today by reasserting his independence of Tammany Hall.

THESE menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

THE laureate of the Beat Generation, Jack Kerouac, is publishing a new novel today. It is called "The Dharma Bums"* and it should arouse jubilance among the Beejees as well as the generally more rewarding fury of those who by urging others not to read a book do so much to complicate an author's income tax problems.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 1 -- An attempt to charter a new all-white chapter of the 40 and 8 society to supplant one with a Chinese-American in its membership was blocked for the time being in court today.
A slum clearance project for the Bronx, which will provide 1,600 new apartments in the Mott Haven area, is to get priority over three Manhattan projects.

Automobile production in September fell to the lowest level for any month in more than twelve years. Model changeovers and labor walkouts reduced output, but even so the low tally came as something of a surprise. It was well below scheduled production.
New Zealand has arranged to borrow $46,000,000 from thirteen United States banks, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Arnold H. Nordmeyer, New Zealand's Finance Minister.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Navy's football prospects got a severe jolt today with the announcement that Bob Reifsnyder would be out of the line-up indefinitely.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The defending champion, J. Clark Espie of Indianapolis, scored his second decisive victory today in the national seniors' golf tournament. He overwhelmed Charles W. Williams, San Jose, Calif., 6 and 4.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 -- This city's five major hotels were closed today by a strike of 2,300 employes in a dispute over wage demands.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1 -- No one is satisfied with losing and Ryne Duren, charged with the overtime setback in today's world series curtain-raiser, is no exception. Still, the flame-throwing Yankee relief artist found it hard to find fault with his performance against the Braves.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 1--Britain's new "partnership" plan for Cyprus went into effect today. It was greeted by an island-wide strike of Greek Cypriotes who have so far refused to accept it.

DARIEN, Conn., Oct 1 -- A Darien group is working on a gift in return for the gift of a baby elephant. The elephant arrived here last year as a gift from school children of Mercara, India, to those in Darien as part of a United Nations Week observance.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Americans will sip a record total of thirty billion cups of tea this year and should drink two billion more next year, the annual convention of the Tea Council of the U. S. A. was told today.
TAIPEI, Thursday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- General Chiang said he was concerned about the lack of understanding of the Nationalists' position.

New York banks reported mixed changes yesterday in net operating earnings for the first nine months of this year compared with the same period of 1957. Several of the larger banks reported slight declines, while others had increases.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today the United States had the "biggest, strongest and finest body of scientists" in the world at work on missile development.

GUAM, Thursday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Defense Secretary Neil H. McElroy said today a reduction of National Chinese troops in the offshore islands as a result of a cease-fire agreemnt would not be a compromise with the Chinese Communists.
BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- McIvor Prickett's Hammer Mill, the only 3-year-old in a field of seven sprinters, romped through the mud to an easy victory today in the Touchdown Club Purse at Suffolk Downs.

More than a score of lower Federal judges in the country who have been asked by a national magazine for their views on a report criticizing the Supreme Court expressed incredulity, indignation or anger yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- If the Supreme Court in the 1954 school desegregation decision had plainly held what in 1958 it says it plainly did, so many good lawyers and conscientious inferior Federal judges would not have spent the intervening four years pondering over whether this or that Southern school district plan generally conformed to the 1954 holding.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Post Office Department reminded its customers today that postage rates to Mexico and Canada went up on Aug. 1 along with those in this country.

Stephen (Laddie) Sanford's purple and gold racing silks have fluttered home first in steeplechase stakes with some regularity this season. They have been worn by John Cotter, who is a bon vivant in a workaday world.
While gross revenues of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway continue below 1957 levels, the company reported net earnings of $6,205,000 last month against $6,080,000 in September, 1957.
" THIS IS YOUR LIFE" paid tribute last night to Roy Campanella. The telecast on Channel 4 was a moving and appropriate review of big events in the career of a gifted and courageous man.

CRYSTAL utility pieces and artware by Timo Sarpaneva, Finnish designer, are now on view at Georg Jensen. These modern designs of opaque and transparent crystal will be available to consumers after the close of the exhibition on Oct. 11.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1 -- Warren Spahn, after winning the opener of the world series, is ready to pitch again tomorrow. Not as a starter, because Lew Burdette will take care of that assignment.

Martins Rullah won the Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday, and the success was a fitting one indeed for George Lewis' colt. In the spring at Jamaica the Experimental Handicap was won by Martins Rullah.
RIVERSIDE, N. J., Oct. 1 -Harrison A. Williams Jr. carried his campaign for United States Senator today into rural Burlington, the largest county in New Jersey.

The Dollar Savings Bank sold the five-story apartment house for twenty-five families at 1027 Hoe Avenue, the Bronx, to Bernard Gordon. The property is assessed at $73,000. It was sold through the George Gault Company, broker.

In a recent editorial we commented on the numerous difficulties that confront the United States Treasury in its vital task of debt management at a time when economic activity, though definitely on the mend, is still convalescent, and when the problem of refinancing the outstanding debt, already a difficult one, has been complicated by the necessity of raising upward of $8 billion in new money to cover the Government's enormous budget deficit.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 -The life of raccoons in Westchester County is getting rougher.

Electric power production last week rose to 12,342,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,240,000,000 a week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Sept. 28, 1957, the output was 11,697,000,000 kilowatt hours.
HOUSTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- A United States entry today won for the second consecutive year the Italian Giovanelli Gold Cup of yachting when Sabre won by 59 seconds in Galveston Bay.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Sitdown strikers climbed of the tracks of the subway-elevated lines shortly before midnight tonight ending an eight-hour wildcat walkout.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon reported today that armed infiltration into that country had virtually ceased. It added that at least some guerrillas and partisans reported to have crossed the Syrian border earlier now were being evacuated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The nuclear submarine Seawolf has smashed the underwater record and is now aiming at staying down sixty days, almost double the old mark.
Denver, Colo., is planning to borrow $12,750,000 in the bond market on Oct. 29. The money will be raised to finance water supply facilities. The bonds will be secured by general taxation.

This year's operating deficit for the eighty-one member hospitals of the United Hospital Fund totaled $27,000,000, it was reported last night at the opening of the fund's 1959 campaign for $3,000,000.

A man charged with taking a fifty-two-foot yacht from City Island and sailing it to the Canary Islands was convicted in Federal Court yesterday of stealing the vessel and posssessing a forged Coast Guard certificate for it.
The heavy rain that made Fordham University's football field sopping wet yesterday did not keep the New York Giants from their appointed football rounds.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Chinese Communist artillery fire thundered onto the Quemoy Islands today in a sustained six-hour barrage at the rate of fifteen shells a minute.
TORONTO, Oct. 1 -- The Bank of Nova Scotia, fifth largest in Canada, today announced a major drive into the field of consumer financing.
LOOKING is almost as important as listening at the 1958 New York High Fidelity Show, which opened to the public Tuesday at the New York Trade Show Building, 500 Eighth Avenue (Thirty-fifth Street).
SOUTH BYFIELD, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Bill Sperry, head coach of football at Governor Dummer Academy, was bemoaning his luck today as he looked out on the Maroon and White's rain-swept gridiron.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -Archbishop Albert G. Meyer of Milwaukee will be enthroned as head of the Chicago Roman Catholic Archdiocese on Sunday, Nov. 16.

The New York Regional Office of the Securities and Exchange Commission confirmed yesterday that it was investigating recent trading in shares of the Artloom Carpet Company and the United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation.

An apartment house site on the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Thirty-third Street has been purchased by Asher Dann Sons, builders. The plot fronts seventy-six feet on the avenue and 110 feet on the street.
Plans for the Nov. 10 theatre party to benefit the Girls Club of New York have been completed.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The International Monetary Fund has advised Argentina to stop living beyond its income and take what may be harsh steps to check inflation, informed sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower called today on "all Americans, public officials and private citizens alike," to comply with the Supreme Court's decisions on school desegregation.
There was renewed account activity along Madison Avenue yesterday.

In Manhattan yesterday automobile traffic was slow, dates were broken and, in hotel lobbies, people slumped behind newspapers or walked aimlessly about with no place to sit, nobody to talk to, nothing to do.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Cisley Stable's Kit's Pet advanced another notch in the 2-year-old filly ranks when she took the Absecon National Purse at Atlantic City Race Course today.
Senator Jacob K. Javits urged yesterday that the United States open "a major offensive" on the international economic front next year.
DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Ten wholesale plywood concerns and six individuals found guilty of price fixing were fined a total of $50,500 yesterday in the United States District Court here.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 1--Gen. Ne Win denied today the charge that the army had seized power.

He may lose and in the process come down with indigestion, politica histeria and sore feet; nevertheless, Nelson Rockefeller is at least one of the few new things in politics since the invention of the voting machine.
Kings County Surrogate Maximilian Moss reserved decision yesterday on a proposal to turn over a $13,136 estate to two charitable institutions in New York State.

ANDY GRIFFITH, the amiable bumpkin of "No Time for Sergeants," who helped to boost the morale of G. I.'s and post-G. I.'s almost as much as a cease-fire order, has "re-enlisted" in the Coast Guard in "Onionhead."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- City spokesmen brought to the White House today a demand for a $5,000,000,000 slumfighting project. They got no backing for so big a program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower announced today that he would go to Walter Reed Army Hospital this week-end for his annual physical checkup.
Columbia University announced yesterday the activation of its new Institute of Nutrition Sciences, a graduate school that will train experts to combat malnutrition the world over.
Through noon yesterday the Board of Election had received 151,520 of the 2,431,000 postcards it sent last week to registered voters to learn how many changed their addresses since last year.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman said today his choice for the Republican for President in 1960 was Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
A strike by deck officers yesterday began to tie up the greater part of the United States passenger and dry-cargo fleets in ports on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.
Cheryl Crawford and Joel Schenker have acquired Norman Corwin's new two-part work, "The Rivalry," based on the epic Lincoln-Douglas debates of 1858.
The Oklahoma and Army football teams rank 1 -- 2 in total offense, according to National Collegiate Athletic Bureau statistics released yesterday.

WARSAW, Oct. 1 -- The Chinese Communists, despite their continuing sharp public attacks on United States cease-fire proposals, have given no indications that they plan to break off the negotiations here.
Imports of crude oil and products in the week ended last Friday established a record at 1,926,800 barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
It cost a woman $188 to be a Good Samaritan yesterday.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- New York State savings bankers turned their attention from Chicago and towards Albany today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- House investigators charged today that the armed forces were paying premium prices to private industry for foods obtained from Government surplus stocks.

A group of investors, including Canadian Johns-Manville Company, Ltd., has joined with Advocate Mines, Ltd., of Toronto to develop an asbestos ore body in the Baie Verte region, on the northeast coast of Newfoundland.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Commuters' wives in the four-mile stretch between the railroad station here and Heathcote Corners in Scarsdale will escape some chauffeuring duties Monday and Tuesday.
The Asia Society will present the Ceylon National Dancers in their only New York performance on Oct. 29 in the Hunter College Playhouse.
The City Planning Commission moved yesterday to clear the way for the city to sell the old Washington Retail Market.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Like Earl Blaik at West Point, Lefty James has come up with a new attack, and Cornell, like Army, appears to have its best team since 1950.

MOUNT SINAI, L. I., Oct. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. Howard Mann lost their fourth child in five years last night. Their 6-yearold son Edward died three hours after he had been hit by an auto near the Mann home on Echo Avenue, Mount Sinai.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower joined a small congregation today to observe a national day of prayer.
ABOUT 1,000 of New York's best dressed citizens jammed themselves last night into the 703-seat Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Yesterday I said that all was not sweetness and light in the Communist camp. We Americans make a great mistake and contribute to their solidarity by treating all the Communist countries alike. They are not.

Tennessee failed to make a first down against Auburn last Saturday. For his part in helping to bring this about Zeke Smith, an Auburn guard, yesterday was named the first lineman of the week by The Associated Press for the 1958 football season.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- The Soviet Government wants the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union to meet in Geneva Oct. 31 to negotiate a ban on nuclear tests "immediately" and "forever."

NANTUCKET, Mass., Oct. 1 -An investigation into the crash of a Northeast Airlines Convair on Aug. 15 was started today by a five-man board of inquiry from the Civil Aeronautics Board. Twenty-one of the thirty-one passengers and the crew of three were killed in the crash.

The concentration of the world's attention recently, first on the Middle Eastern crisis and then on the situation in the Taiwan Strait, has put other major international problems relatively in the shade. Yet these problems exist and they require solution. We welcome, therefore, the latest approach of the Western Big Three to the Soviet Union on two matters, the summit conference and German reunification.

Your timely editorial of Sept. 25 drew attention to the very serious problem the Treasury is facing in the current fiscal year in the necessity of raising new money to finance the indicate budget deficit of over $12 billion, besides taking care of maturing obligations of huge proportions.

In any free society there are few freedoms that can be absolute. Conflicts are bound to arise when one freedom or one right is weighed against another and the decision taken in the broader interest of the society as a whole.

HAVANA, Oct. 1 -- Dr. Che Guevara, the Argentine aide to Fidel Castro, who led a column of rebels westward from Castro headquarters in the Sierra Maestra of Oriente Province, has made contact with rebels in Las Villas province, according to information received in Havana today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Foot specialists working with President Eisenhower's Committee of Physical Fitness opened a nation-wide drive today to determine the effects of modern living on the feet of the nation's youths.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Chicago grain markets achieved a steadier tone today. Most grains ended with losses, rye showing the greatest weakness, Soybeans, lower in early transactions, rallied near the close and finished with fractional gains.
OGDENSBURG, N. Y. Oct 1 -- Governor Harriman accused Nelson A. Rockefeller today of trying to win his way into the Executive Mansion with empty promise.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 -An art "detective" has convinced himself and a jury of art authorities that a museum here possesses a "lost" marble masterpiece by Benvenuto Cellini, sixteenth - century Florentine artist.

YONKERS, Oct. 1 (AP) -Morgan Calhoun, driven by Melvin Pyatt, stepped the first half-mile in 1:01 1-5 and went on to win tonight's feature trot by one and a half lengths over Vicki Wayne at Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- The old dream of an Arab confederation stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf came closer to reality today with the admission of Tunisia and Morocco to the League of Arab States. The only gap now is Algeria.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Oct. 2 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek said yesterday that he was "incredulous" at statements by Secretary of State Dulles that seemed "completely incompatible with our stand" on the defense of Quemoy.
The Canadian and U. S. flags were raised yesterday at a ceremony opening the new twenty-six-story Canada House at 680 Fifth Avenue.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 1 -Under attack by the Roman Catholic Church and other important segments of public opinion for the open alliance of his party with the Communists in Friday's elections, Vice President Joao Goulart today charged his critics with "false Christianity."

SEATTLE, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States section of the North Pacific Fisheries Commission voted tonight to ask Japan to keep its fishermen from an additional 648,000 square miles of feeding grounds used by salmon spawned in Alaska.
The eight major departmenU stores in the New York metropolitan area topped volume for[ the 1957 month by a round 10 per cent, according to a survey by The New York Times.

Joan Marchesani, the airline ticket agent who seems to have lost her job for a period because she was deemed "too pretty," in time may stand out the history of her sex as another in the long series of martyrs to feminine recognition.

WHEELWRIGHT, Ky., Oct. 1 -- (UPI) -- A jeering, stonethrowing crowd of white students and adults forced dismissal of classes today at Wheelwright High School. It was the aftermath of a fight between a white girl and a negro girl in a restaurant.
More strong graduate schools in which professional scientists and engineers could be educated in an atmosphere of creativity were urged last night by Dr. James R. Killian Jr.
ALGIERS, Oct. 1--The feeling of expectation that has ridden this city for months reached a new height today on the eve of Premier de Gaulle's visit.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1--Fred Haney's gallant Braves, defending the first world championship they brought to Milwaukee a year ago, took a long stride toward another title today. They brought down Casey Stengel's Yankees in the 1958 world series opener, 4 to 3, in ten innings before a roaring crowd of 46,367.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Mr. Alcorn supported President Eisenhower's call today for a hard-hitting Republican campaign.

BING CROSBY moved up to television's top rung last night with the first of his programs for the American Broadcasting Company. The presentation was a musical hour of charm, diversity, humor and taste; it was produced with enormous style and sophistication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The American Jewish Committee urged the State Department today to undertake a program designed to stabilize South American economies and correct mutual misconceptions between the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- An attorney for National Airlines threatened today to subpoena Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, as a witness in the Federal Communications Commission hearing on the disputed Miami Channel 10 case.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Oct. 1 (AP) -- A spokesman said today the Air Force Academy would play football with the other service academies, Army and Navy, only if they agreed to play in Colorado in a home-and-home agreement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Railroad earnings continued to improve in August.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The German middle-weight champion, Franz Szuzina, bleeding considerably from a forehead cut, tonight gained a unanimous decision over Randy Sandy of New York in a ten-round outdoor return match.

Today's new film is "The Barbarian and the Geisha," a Twentieth Century-Fox production directed by John Huston and starring John Wayne and Eiko Ando, at the Paramount, Broadway and Forty - third Street. The 8:30 P. M. premiere is for the benefit of the City College Fund.

The American Electric Power Company became the first electric power company in the world to have generating capacity in excess of 5,000,000 kilowatts yesterday. The milestone was reached when Unit 1 of theClinch River plant at Carbo, Va., went into operation, raising the system's total power capacity to 5,113,000 kilowatts.
A state-wide "Vote Yes for Housing Committee" was organized yesterday under the leadership of some of New York's major real estate and construction men.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 -- The Associate director of the Farm Foundation said today that agriculture was not a direct contributor to the recession during the last year.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The stock market had another cheerful day today. Prices advanced in almost all sections in active trading.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1--The Soviet Union celebrated the ninth anniversary of the Peiping regime today with renewed warnings to the United States that the two Communist nations would fight side by side if the Taiwan crisis developed into war.
ALBANY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Governor Harriman appealed today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to abolish rate differentials on railroad freight shipments to North Atlantic ports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The growing role of scientists in international affairs may take a new turn this week with the formation of a special body to direct space exploration. It would mark the culmination of a trend in which men of science from East and West have been able to reach agreement in a number of areas where governments were unable to do so.

Several candidates for public office pleaded last night for a middle-income housing program that would help preserve the pattern of the Washington Square area and Greenwich Village. They said it was needed to keep middle-income families from moving to the suburbs.

The New York Philharmonic will have a gala opening for its 117th season tonight at 8:30 in Carnegie Hall. It will be the beginning of the orchestra's first season under the musical direction of Leonard Bernstein.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 -- A visiting Soviet youth mission was pelted with rocks, eggs and vegetables today by university students in La Plata. In Buenos Aires agitation continued over the private university bill, which was adopted last night.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Edward T. Dickinson, State Commerce Commissioner, said today that New York State was strengthening its economic leadership despite recent assertions to the contrary.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1 -- Ambassador Robert M. McClintock of the United States conferred today with President Fouad Chehab and the Maronite Patriarch, Msgr. Paul Boutros Meouchi, the most important religious leader in Lebanon.
ROME, Oct. 1--Pope Pius XII is suffering from a "slight indisposition" and has been advised to curtail his heavy working schedule.

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 -- Mainland China began today its tenth year under communism with the promise from a high official that the nation could expect to "enjoy a happy life of abundance" within "about three years."
Cotton futures moved 13 points (65 cents a bale) up to 2 points (10 cents a bale) off yesterday, with old crop months the strongest.

Many recent favorites lost heavily in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, but the averages ended the day with small declines.

Five young violinists and a 'cellist pitted their skills against one another yesterday morning at Town Hall for a chance to play next month with the New York Philharmonic. The musician who won the coveted solo appearance was Arnold Steinhardt, 21-year-old Los Angeles violinist.

NOW that autumn is on the boards and mornings are increasingly brisk, it seems a likely time to consider substantial and versatile dishes particularly germane to cold weather. Pancakes in one form or another are a universal choice for all meals, whether they are hooded with butter and doused with syrup or served as a base for creamed dishes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The State Department said today that Communist China had admitted an American newspaper man. Lincoln White, department press officer, said the writer is John Louis Strohm, who represents the Newspaper Enterprise Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States would not retreat before Communist force in the Taiwan Strait. But he also said that a cease-fire would open the way for negotiations in good faith.

The prices of the Sunday editions of three New York City newspapers are being raised in various regions outside the metropolitan area. The increase were attributed to higher production and transportation costs.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- A violent storm today disrupted the start of a new American trek in the Antarctic.
