Ground was broken symbolically yesterday for a sixteen-story residence hall for Long Island University on a new campus in downtown Brooklyn.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Walter Wanger and Twentieth Century - Fox are discussing terms of a contract under which the producer would join the studio to make a series of pictures.
MONTREAL, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Seafarers' International Union officials were mum today on the future of Canada's one-time West Indies fleet, now owned by a Cuban group.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 1 -The United Nations Day Committee here won official status last night and will probably get the $300 it had been denied for a United Nations observance on Oct. 24.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1 -The Westchester County Parkway Authority's indefinite postponement of the redevelopment of the Hutchinson River Parkway was protested today by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York.

THE portrait of a Russian schoolboy as being handy with a Bunsen Burner and slide rule, while his American counterpart toys with an abacus, does not correspond with the impressions gained by a recent visitor to the Soviet Union.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold urged today that the control authority to police future nuclear test bans should be established within the United Nations.
The nation's largest public aviation high school changed its name and its location yesterday without missing a day of training.

ALL kinds of new hunting and fishing "packages" are appearing on the market, many of them designed to pick the strong, hardy outdoorsman and his family from their beds, transport them, feed them, house them, hunt or fish them and return them to their beds unbitten by bug or frustrated whim.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) -- More than $450,000 belonging to Local 234 of the Transport Workers Union here has disappeared over the last six years, the union president, Michael J. Quill, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -The National Aeronautics and Space Agency came into being today and was given responsibility for a roster of projects ranging from earth satellites to the development of nuclear rockets.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. received today the first formal request from a Virginia community that he reopen public schools that were closed to prevent integration. His office indicated that he would take no immediate action on the request, which came from Norfolk.
The Kings County District Attorney's office began yesterday to organize a special unit to aid the grand jury investigating the alleged misuse of New York City welfare funds.

Cocoa futures closed at the highs of the day in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market opened firm, but rumors of an estimate of even larger supplies in Ghana than originally forecast weakened prices.
The opening of the New York Philharmonic season at Carnegie Hall last night brought out a chic but not an elaborately dressed audience.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 2 -- A resolution by the New York State delegation recommending the allocation of Federal funds to train National Guard recruits was adopted today by the National Guard Association of the United States.
MONTREAL, Oct. 2 -Charles Avery Dunning, one of Canada's most prominent political figures and a leader in industry, died last night at the Royal Victoria
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Winning by one stroke, Martin Issler of Essex County today regained the New Jersey Golf Association seniors championship.

DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 2 -- The Darien Planning and Zoning Commission has denied a petition of residents of Collender's Point to upgrade the area from one to two acres. If the petition had been granted, G. Sterling Brady, the zoning chairman, said, too many lots would not conform to area requirements.

The administrator of the Mary Manning Walsh Home for the Aged, 450 East Fifty-ninth Street, will celebrate her silver jubilee as a religious tomorrow. She is Mother M. Bernadette de Lourdes, Vicar General of the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and Infirm.
BUFFALO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Uninvited and unwelcome is how the president of Canisius College described the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, who visited the campus yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Eighty of the Rank Organization's 460 motion-picture theatres will be closed during the next three years because of falling attendance.

The United States Court of Appeals refused unanimously yesterday to act on the continuation of the vacating of a restraining order against the Arvida Corporation, Arthur Vining Davis and two investment banking houses. The opinion was handed down by Appeals Judges J. Edward Lumbard, Charles E. Clark and Leonard P. Moore.
A nation-wide study of juvenile delinquency, intended primarily for the benefit of classroom teachers, was announced yesterday by the National Education Association.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 2 -- A two-part program for redevelopment in the South Norwalk section was outlined yesterday by Mayor Irving C. Freese.

SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 2 -- The delegates at the annual conference of the Labor party accepted today the proposition that a future Labor government must have freedom to decide whether to continue manufacturing nuclear weapons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Union requested today that the General Assembly debate the failure of the United States and Britain to withdraw their troops immediately from Lebanon and Jordan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Claims took under advisement today a report on possible Government liability in the cancelled Dixon-Yates power contract.

A few tickets still remain for the Oct. 21 performance of "A Touch of the Poet," which will benefit the Institute of World Affairs, Inc. The tickets may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street. The Eugene O'Neill play opened last night at the Helen Hayes Theatre.

Prices of all three major base metals -- copper, lead and zinc -- advanced a half-cent a pound yesterday. The increases were touched off in the custom smelter field, and were soon matched by mine producers of lead and zinc. Copper producers, however, who account for 80 to 90 per cent of the refined copper sold domestically, did not go along with the new smelter price of that metal.

A hundred original daguerreotype plates and many enlargements of these photographs of a century ago will go on public exhibition today at the New-York Historical Society, Central Park West and Seventy-seventh Street.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 2 -- Former President Camille Chamoun said today that he did not consider proposals by Robert M. McClintock, the United States Ambassador, for a compromise of Lebanon's political difficulties as a suitable basis for a settlement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- James K. Vardaman Jr. has resigned as a member of the Federal Reserve Board. In a letter to President Eisenhower, he asked that his resignation be effective Dec. 1.

"I know what it means to be a soldier in a lonely land," an ex-soldier said, "to be in a strange land, to have around him some thing that means home; something that brings him back closer to those surroundings and to those people with whom he has lived -- where his heart is."

The four-day strike of about 300 employes against Youth House in the Bronx ended early today. The employes voted to accept the concessions made yesterday afternoon in negotiations with Youth House, Inc.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 3 -- The Soviet Union, confirming that it had resumed nuclear testing, said it had been "forced" to do so by the refusal of the United States and Britain to suspend their tests during the last half year.
Two Columbia features, "The Last Hurrah" and "The Seventh Voyage of Sinbad" have been booked for engagements at the Roxy Theatre.
PARIS, Oct. 2 -- France announced today that she had recognized Togoland's desire for independence.

Hope that nuclear weapons tests will be suspended, and possibly ended by Oct. 31, is darkened by doubt because of two new Soviet maneuvers. The United States and Britain have agreed to such a suspension, first on a one-year trial basis and then on a year-by-year basis, if the inspection system planned by the East-West experts is established, if it works and if progress is made toward other essential disarmament measures.

Two of the largest apartment house sales ever made in Hudson County, N. J., were consummated with the transfer of the Duncan Apartments and the Gothic Towers in Jersey City from Arthur J. Cale to the Duncan Gothic Corporation.
Theodore W. Kheel predicted yesterday that all transit fares would rise to 20 cents next year -- and to 25 or 30 cents soon thereafter.
An educator told 750 ad men yesterday that "much of so-called advertising research lacks objectivity" and would not be considered research in other fields.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff named Rear Admiral Frank O'Beirne today as Director of Operations, virtually completing the strengthening of their agency under the Pentagon Reorganization Act.

M. L. Brackett, who was obtained by the New York Giants from the Chicago Bears just before the National Football League season opened last Sunday, will start at defensive end against the Eagles at Philadelphia Sunday, Coach Jim Lee Howell reported yesterday.
Roman Catholic opposition to contraceptive therapy in municipal hospitals is defended in an editorial in America, a national Catholic review, published tomorrow.

Lumber production last week was 11.2 per cent above the level of last year, according to reports wired to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 23.5 per cent and orders up 10.9 per cent.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Some of the recent industrial favorites on the stock exchange here paused in their advance today.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 2 -- The Yankees are not discouraged. That, at least, is what they say. Casey Stengel does not regard as desperate the position of his team, now down two games to the Braves in the world series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Eisenhower has selected Dana Latham, a tax lawyer in Los Angeles, as Commissioner of Internal Revenue. The White House announced today that Mr. Latham will receive a recess appointment, subject to confirmation by the Senate next year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct 2 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon put himself forward today as an Administration spokesman for a policy of no enforced retreat in the Taiwan Sarait.

Average excess reserves of Federal Reserve member banks dropped $112,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday to $261,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Borrowings declined $139,000,000 to $198,000,000.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies set a goal of $18,000,000 yesterday for its forty-first annual appeal in behalf of its 116 member hospitals and health and social service agencies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today that the New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroad had filed formal notices of proposed passenger fare increases effective Nov. 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The dispute between the Netherlands and Indonesia over Netherlands New Guinea flared up again today in the General Assembly.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 2 -- Fred Haney's Braves scored virtually a one-round knockout today. Then they rolled on to gain their second straight triumph over the staggering Yankees in the world series before another capacity crowd of 46,367.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Union pressmen voted tonight to go back to work on Washington newspapers, permitting normal publication after one day's lapse by The Evening Star and The Daily News.
ROME, Oct. 2 -- Pope Pius XII appeared today to have recovered from the slight indisposition that had caused him discomfort and affected his voice during the last few days.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Emily's Pride virtually clinched the 3-year-old trotting championship today with a victory in the $53,330 Kentucky Futurity that saw world records surpassed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Labor's Committee on Political Education is distributing more than 10,000,000 copies of an analysis of how every member of Congress voted in the 1957-58 sessions.

Listed below are retail price ranges of produce available in this area. These prices, from the city's Department of Markets, are based on a city-wide survey of supermarkets, chain stores and neighborhood grocery stores.
On Sept. 22 Nan Robertson wrote, in your "About New York" column, a moving article about the city's unclaimed dead.

The courtship and marriage of the late Albert W. Barkley and Jane Hadley, a young widow from St. Louis, is told in "I Married The Veep," which Vanguard will issue next Thursday. Mrs. Barkley tells her story in collaboration with Frances Spatz Leighton.

The Glidden Company had a consolidated net income of $6,063,062 in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31, compared with $7,264,437 earned in the preceding year, Dwight P. Joyce, chairman and president, reported yesterday in the annual statement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Drastic Western action to aid under-developed nations is recommended in an official report by four international economists that was circulating among Governments of the free world today.

A SEARCHING and frightening study of the tragedy of alcoholism was contributed last night by J. P. Miller to "The Days of Wine and Roses" on "Playhouse 90." It was a brilliant and compelling work (Channel 2).
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A Federal judge rejected today the claim that the State Department had no legal authority to prohibit newspaper men and others from traveling to Communist China.

Chairmen of the various committees planning the Embassy Ball, to be held on Oct. 30 in the Plaza, have been announced. The fete, originally scheduled for Oct. 24, will benefit the children's fund of King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece and the Children's Asthma Research Institute of the United States.
John J. McCloy, chairman of the city's largest bank, will take on the additional post of chairman of the board of trustees of the Ford Foundation, the world's richest philanthropic institution.

It whirled about and fluttered upward, but it stung the eyes and it was neither cool nor pretty. It was sawdust sixteen cubic yards of it, and it was used by the Sanitation Department yesterday to test a snow loader.
NITRO, W. Va., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The furniture in the home of Mr. and Mrs. S. L. Burdette took a beating today, just as it did when Selva Lewis Burdette Jr. was a youngster.

YONKERS, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Chief Lenawee, a 6-year-old pacer owned by James and Mary Blanchard of Morenci, Mich., surged down the stretch tonight in a four-horse drive for the wire and scored a victory in a $10,000 free-for-all at Yonkers Raceway.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Attorneys representing twenty-nine employes filed a $1,885,000 Federal court damage suit today charging the Texas and New Orleans Railroad Company with discriminatory practices.
The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., reported yesterday gains in net income for six and twelve months ended June 30. Operating revenues for both periods trailed those of previous years.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A suit asking $1,000,000 for slander was added today to one for $4,000,000 damages. William Bufalino, Teamsters Union official and his local are seeking the $5,000,000 from Robert F. Kennedy, chief counsel of the Senate Rackets Committee.
Nine new singers and two prominent stage directors will join the Metropolitan Opera for the season opening Oct. 27 with Puccini's "Tosca."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Democratic party's foreign-policy advisers cautioned the Communist world today against mistaking the debate in the United States on Administration policy in the Far East as a sign of national disunity.
PLANS to establish a memorial for Claire McCardell, the American designer who died last March 22, were announced yesterday by a committee of persons prominent in the fashion world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a staff investigation to determine whether any irregularities figured in the award of television Channel 9 at Orlando, Fla., in 1957.

The Temco Aircraft Corporation has borrowed $5,500,000 privately on 5 1/4 per cent first mortgage sinking fund bonds due in 1970. The money will be used to retire debt and finance expansion of plant facilities, F. S. Smithers Co. arranged the deal.
The 1958 Gold Medal Award of the Hundred Year Association of New York was presented last night to Samuel D. Leidesdorf, civic leader and philanthropist.

The shaggy fringe, an innovation in rugs today, is evident in Bigelow's new group of carpets now on display at Altman's. The fringe, which is made of the same yarn that appears in the pile, gives the rugs a soft, handwoven look.

The appointment of Special Sessions Justice Louis I. Kaplan as Investigation Commissioner was announced by Mayor Wagner yesterday. Justice Kaplan will succeed Charles H. Tenney, who will be sworn in as Corporation Counsel at 4 P. M. today at City Hall.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The United States Lawn Tennis Association today named a Davis Cup team accenting youth, with two teenage players on the five-man squad that will play in Australia.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 2 -- The likely increase in the pollution of the nation's water over the next twenty-five to fifty years is a "cause for concern", a Federal Public Health official warned here today.

The National Manpower Council took some revealing measurements of the sweep and depth of women's penetration into the nation's labor force in its report on "Womanpower" last year. It found that between 1900 and 1957 the number of women workers increased fourfold -- to 22,000,000 -- while the civilian labor force as a whole grew but two and a third times.

A bill for $22,000, submitted to the city last December by James C. Sheridan, a real estate agent who occasionally appraises property for the city, has been sent to the Controller's office by the Corporation Counsel. The question now is whether it will be paid.

"The Gang's All Here," purportedly dealing with an undesignated President of the United States, is to be done as quickly as possible by David Merrick and Leland Hayward.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 2 -- Brazil's Vice President, Joao Goulart, denied today the existence of a secret agreement between his Brazilian Labor party and the Communists for cooperation in tomorrow's elections and subsequently.

MONTREAL, Oct. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Webb Knapp (Canada), Ltd. announced today that the company had contracted to sell at an undisclosed price the Dominion Square Building in mid-town Montreal to a group of Canadian and United States purchasers. The group in Canada is headed by Leopold-Candler Investments, Inc.

Last night saw the third Giselle and the second Albrecht of the American Ballet Theatre's season at the Metropolitan Opera House in the persons of Alicia Alonso and Igor Youskevitch as guest artists. This is a famous "Giselle" team, and their many admirers who turned out to see them found occasion after occasion to applaud them, and with ample justification.
Copper, lead and zinc were strong yesterday in active trading on the Commodity Exchange. The strength reflected 1/2-cent-a-pound increases in the prices for the three metals.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Competition between stockholder-owned commercial banks and depositor oriented mutual thrift institutions will increase so long as the world-wide demand for savings continues to exceed the supply, a leading European savings banker said here today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 2 (AP) -- An authoritative source said today the Shah of Iran had not intended to talk for publication when he told a news conference last week an Aryan confederation was under serious consideration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- With their restatements this week of the Far East policy of the United States, the President and Secretary of State Dulles have outlined a position to which the American people and our allies should be able to give general support.
No pleasure boat skipper in his right mind would tear up and down Chesapeake Bay as if in a hurry. It just isn't done.
PARIS, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- The ballet master at the Paris Opera, Serge Lifar, said today he was leaving the state-run institution at the end of this month after thirty years.

Patronesses for the tenth annual dinner dance that will further the work of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue have been announced by Mrs. Bruce A. Gimbel, chairman of the event. The dance will be held next Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 2 -- A rarity in the fraternity -- an optimistic football coach -- was discovered at the Choate School today as the Blue and Gold tuned up for two hours for its meeting with Loomis on Saturday.
A program to improve labor-management relationships, aid workers and bolster the state's economy was proposed yesterday by Nelson A. Rockefeller.

TEANECK, N. J., Oct. 2 -- A boy in the eighth grade took it as just a part of political ups-and-downs today when Gov. Robert B. Meyner refused to endorse his race for a student council post in the school on the ground that the issues were "purely local."

Ambassador Lodge yesterday characterized the speech he had just heard Soviet Ambassador Gromyko deliver in the U. N. General Assembly as "straight, unadulterated vilification," "billingsgate" and an attempt to "make a travesty of the U. N."

WHEELWRIGHT, Ky., Oct. 2 (UPI) -- Boone Hall, the principal, called off a scheduled meeting of parents at Wheelwright High School today because he believed it might touch off a demonstration similar to yesterday's.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The United States Court of Appeals here held today that evidence seized illegally by state law enforcement officers might not be used in Federal trials.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru returned today from a two-week trip to Bhutan with the impression that conditions inside Tibet were not "fully normal."
Three pieces of chamber music were expertly played last night in Carnegie Recital Hall by John Barrows, French horn player; Milton Kaye, pianist, and the Beaux-Arts String Quartet.
A fashionable audience of music-lovers and society and diplomatic personalities added a touch of glamour to the opening of the New York Philharmonic last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States will establish a training program to get business men into politics at the precinct level.
With eight tenement buildings and rooming houses already razed in the Lincoln Square area, wreckers will begin today to tear down a second group consisting of twenty-six buildings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Secretary of State Dulles reassured President Chiang Kaishek today that basic United States policy regarding China remained unchanged.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Harrison F. Flippin of Ardmore, Pa., retained her United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship by scoring a 43, 37 -- 80 over the south course at the Westchester Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture increased today by 100,000 tons its estimate of the nation's sugar requirements this year. This put the new total at 9,100,000 tons.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 2 -- District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of New York County charged today that "inaccurate and irresponsible" statements had been made about him by his Republican opponents for the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight rose 5,647 cars to 672,924 in the week ended last Saturday, the Asociation of American Railroads announced today.
New York University opens its 1958-59 athletic year tomorrow morning by competing in its first intercollegiate soccer match in thirty-three years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The supreme nongovernmental body in science moved today to perpetuate the cooperation in space research that has marked the International Geophysical Year.

The recent discovery of PAM, an antidote for deadly nerve gas poisoning, represents the first time in medical history that it has been possible to design a compound useful in treatment by paper - and - pencil calculations.

THE Practising Law Institute, a school for lawyers and prosecutors, was twenty-five years old yesterday. Close to 500 grave barristers, judges and teachers of law assembled in the Statler Hilton Hotel at sundown to quaff a discreet cup or two to the institute's astonishing career.
By winning a six-furlong sprint at Belmont Park yesterday, Ralph Lowe's Sherry Prince "qualified" for greater things to come.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points (25 cents a bale) up to 5 points down yesterday. Fluctuations held within a narrow range all day.

A group of Harlem business and civic leaders appointed a committee yesterday to devise means of establishing better relations between the retailers and consumers in the community.
A four-man United States golf team left yesterday for Scotland. Accompanying the amateur squad as non-playing captain, was one of the sport's most famed figures, Bobby Jones.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The Federal crop insurance program is expected to show a profit of about $12,000,000 this year. This would wipe out losses recorded since the program was reorganized in 1948, officials said today.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Dr. George Bennett, prescriber for ailing athletes, fixed up a support today for Navy tackle Bob Reifsnyder's sore heel and said he could play no later than Oct. 18.
Lawrence Anderson Jr., a 20-year-old junior converted from a center to an end last year, will start at right end for Columbia against Princeton Saturday at Palmer Stadium.

Windsor, Conn., borrowed $2,265,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school and other public improvements. The securities were sold to a syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. The price paid was 100.135 for 3 1/2 per cent obligations.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 2 -- Adlai E. Stevenson predicted tonight a great Democratic victory in California and the nation in November but offered his party a word of advice.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- Residual payments to writers from re-runs of television shows attained a new peak during the first nine months of the year. Collections totaled $817,000, the Writers Guild of America, West, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Dr. William S. Clark, director of medical care for the National Foundation, said today that next January's $65,000,000 March of Dimes campaign would stress the urgency of research into birth defects.

With excavation virtually completed, work on the Consolidated Edison Company of New York's Indian Point nuclear power station is well into the concrete pouring stage. The company reported yesterday that about 300,000 cubic yards, most of it rock, have been removed from the site and that the pouring of some 19,000 cubic yards of concrete back into the hole was on schedule.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The State Department will announce in a few days an exchange agreement with the Soviet Union involving representatives of the television industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The United States, chiding Czechoslovakia for "extreme sensitivity" about "innocent violations" of its border, has demanded the release of three American soldiers, it was disclosed today.

A syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and Dean Witter Co. is offering for public subscription today a new issue of 175,000 shares of $20 par value preferred stock of the Hawaiian Electric Company, Ltd.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers agreed on a new three-year contract late tonight.
A WOMAN who covets Paris fashions need not cross the Atlantic. In fact, she need not go beyond midtown Manhattan.
Five hundred volunteers in the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York were honored with a reception yesterday to open the council's annual fund raising campaign. The goal this year is $1,300,000.

In its first venture outside of the New York metropolitan area, All-State Properties, volume builder on Long Island, found immediate reception to its sales technique in Louisville, Ky. All-State has opened model homes there in a projected community of 400 houses in the $11,200 to $12,400 range.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Preliminary figures indicated new construction activity in September roughly equaled August's record high, the Government reported today.
The Kansas City Athletics traded a shortstop, Chico Carrasquel, to the Baltimore Orioles yesterday for a utility man, Dick Williams, and the Philadelphia Phillies bought two pitchers.
Two local laws designed prevent loft and factory were signed by Mayor Warren yesterday after a public hearing in his office at City Hall.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 2 -- British security forces moved swiftly today to prevent mass demonstrations by Greek Cypriotes against the new plan for self-government of the island.
GIVEN Eugene O'Neill and a cast of superb actors, the effect on the stage is electric.
DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 2 -- The basic styling that won Ford sales leadership in 1957 has been carried forward for 1959.
CAIRO, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- A special commission opened an official investigation today into charges that Vice President Sabri el-Assali had "plotted" to unite Syria with Iraq under the late King Faisal.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Joseph P. Kamp denied tonight that the General Motors Corporation or its "active officials" had financed his published attack on Walter Reuther, United Auto Workers president. He acknowledged that some booklets had been bought by the Ford Motor Company.
"YANCY DERRINGER," the filmed series that started over Channel 2 last night, isn't just a routine adventure series. It is distinctive in its silliness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Eisenhower decided today to do something to remove the "apathy and complacency" from the Republican Congressional campaign. He told his news conference yesterday that this feeling of some party workers and candidates was "incomprehensible" to him.

Loans to business by the seventeen major New York City banks rose $35,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a drop of $15,000,000 in the corresponding week of last year.

Senator Jacob K. Javits took his fellow Republican, Representative Kenneth B. Keating, into a Democratic stronghold yesterday. The idea was to try to imbue Mr. Keating, the Republican candidate for the Senate, with some of Mr. Javits' political magic.
HONG KONG, Oct. 2 -- Communist China expects its total foreign trade volume in 1958 to be 14 per cent higher than in 1957.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today granted Scandinavian Airlines System the right to provide air service between Scandinavian countries and Anchorage, Alaska.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Sleep can restore an old dog's virility and improve his appearance -- or so the Russians say.
The city's Welfare Commissioner has issued an order to members of his department reminding them that anyone who gives information to the press without authorization will be guilty of misconduct.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Oct. 2 -- The new Republic of Guinea was born here today with a Government decidedly closer in philosophy to the Marxist than the capitalist world.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 2 -- A. Princeton University undergraduate has ingeniously placed the college officials in a predicament. For nearly three decades Princeton students have been forbidden to use motor vehicles in this vicinity. was impressed, and even granted the young man a temporary car permit so that he could use his car to help set up his horse. operations here.
BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 2 -- A 450-mile-an-hour passenger plane that may bring the jet age even to small-town airports was demonstrated for the first time today.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The Treasury announced today that the gold and dollar reserves held by Britain as banker for the sterling area increased $31,000,000 last month.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Union, object of criticism from the tin-producing countries, in the General Assembly has so far not answered their accusations of dumping the metal on the world market.
The United States defeated Norway, 2 1/2 -- 1/2, with one game adjourned, in the second round of the team chess tournament at Munich, according to a report received last night from West Germany.

Demolition will begin soon of the former home of the New York Foundling Hospital at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street to make way for a $15,000,000 apartment building. The new structure will occupy the block bounded by Sixty-eighth and Sixty-ninth Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues.
Reduced cargo-handling costs that are achieved through automation will better enable American business to compete for foreign markets, it was contended yesterday.

WESTON, Conn., Oct. 2 -- Recent controversies over construction of a junior high school have prompted First Selectman Peter Robinson, a Democrat, to offer to build a school for $900,000, which he would lease to the town for ninety-nine years.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Government offered another clue today to why the recession is receding: many Americans have been taking on new debts.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 2 -- A lawyer said today he would ask the Arkansas Supreme Court to rule on the constitutionality of the law under which Gov. Orval E. Faubus blocked the opening of high schools here.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad became the first railroad yesterday to seek some of the $500,000,000 of Government-backed private loans provided for the railroad industry in the Transportation Act of 1958. The carrier has called a special stockholders' meeting in New Haven on Nov. 21 for approval of plans to borrow some $18,500,000.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 2 -- Maryland's policy ofgraual school integrahon, by .local!ties today ,was 'affirmed by tate Controller J. Millard. Tawes, Democratic nominee' for' Govelvlor..' ,:. ,'

The American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., will hold its annual luncheon and fashion show on Tuesday afternoon in the St. Regis Roof. Mrs. Ogden L. Mills is chairman of the event, proceeds of which will aid the A.W.V.S. national program.

The American Electric Power Company has signed a long-term lease for 100,000 square feet of space on the ninth, tenth and eleventh floors of 2 Broadway. The utility company's offices are at 30 Church Street.
Governor Harriman assailed the Eisenhower Administration's housing record last night, contending that it had discouraged home construction that was needed.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The French Academy of forty "living immortals" provided today a soothing note of permanence and continuity at a moment of bustling change -- when the Fourth Republic was giving way to the Fifth.

As the cartoon on your education page of Sept. 21 pointed out, there may indeed come a time when job applicants, by virtue of necessary advanced study, may be "well qualified but too old to work." Certainly the increased emphasis on "adult education," or, preferably, "continu ing education," promises help in this area.
The need for a more "realistic" approach to Jewish adult education was stressed yesterday at a conference devoted to "Zionism and Israel in Adult Jewish Education."
An exhibit on the history of naval medicine was put on display yesterday in the alumni hall of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center at 550 First Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Two officials of the Humane Society in the United States urged its members today to campaign next year for a law governing scientific laboratory animals.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -- The Freedom of the Press Committee of the Inter-American Press Association began today its annual review of press freedom in the Western Hemisphere. Cuba seemed likely to be the center of attention.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Tony Anthony of New York floored Archie McBride five times tonight and scored a technical knockout in the ninth round of their return fight at Baltimore Coliseum. The scheduled ten-rounder was televised nationally.

Now that President Eisenhower has signed the measure requiring textile fibers in a finished product to bear identification, manufacturers and others in the distribution chain can look forward to acquiring a giant-size headache.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Two of the nation's leading producers of automobile glass -- Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company and Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company -- were notified today that a strike deadline had been set for noon Friday, Oct. 10.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -Three students were critically wounded in Tucuman last night and there was an almost complete stoppage at the nation's universities and secondary schools today as student rioting continued.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Temporary halting of the development of a fast-growing and deadly bone cancer by radioactive sulphur was reported here today. The discovery was announced at the closing session of the fifty-ninth annual meeting of the American Roentgen Ray Society at the Shoreham Hotel.
TUNIS, Oct. 3 -- President Habib Bourguiba acted today to loosen the tight and growingly unpopular grip that Tunisia's sole political party holds on the country.

Two weeks after the New York Stock Exchange took action the American Stock Exchange yesterday suspended until Dec. 18 George K. Garvin, senior partner in Garvin, Bantel Co. as an allied member of the Evchange.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 3 -- An estimated total of 59,000 gathered in Plaza Bolivar this afternoon to show continued popular support of President Alberto Lleras Camargo.
ROME, Oct. 3 -- The Italian Parliament commemorated today the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Eleonora Duse, the actress.
Harland Svare, the Giants' right linebacker,will not be available for tomorrow's National Football League game in Philadelphia against the Eagles.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1 -- All India has been hearing the voice of doom since Jayaprakash Narayan returned from Europe two weeks ago to campaign for a new form of "partyless democracy."

REGINA, Oct. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Saskatchewan Government says that tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway and Welland Canal will put western Canada's wheat producers at an unfair disadvantage on the world market.

The week ahead will be a fairly light one in the new capital market. If the recent weaknesses in Government bonds should persist, postponements of some planned offerings might reduce the schedule still further.
A shortage of guards is forcing the Brooklyn Museum to keep certain galleries open only part-time, beginning Monday.

Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, urged local chapters yesterday to poll candidates for Congress on the question of weakening the powers of the Supreme court.
A 14-year-old boy was shot and critically wounded late last night while trying to elude a policeman in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. His companion, also 14, was seized.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Saturday, Oct. 4 -- Angry British troops swarmed through the houses of Famagusta's Greek quarter last night in search of gunmen who killed a British woman and Wounded another.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 3 -- The Sunday closing law that has been in effect in Saddle River for four weeks will not be enforced this week-end. The change results from a restraining order on the borough signed yesterday by Superior Court Judge J. Wallace Leyden.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Jersey Central Railroad today to increase its fares for joint rail and ferry service between Manhattan and New Jersey.

The New York Clearing House Association announced yesterday the election of William S. Gray as chairman of the Clearing House committee for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1959. Mr. Gray, chairman of the Hanover Bank, succeeds Harold H. Helm, chairman of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank. Howard C. Sheperd, chairman of the First National City Bank of New York, was reelected president of the Association.
WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct, 3 -- A squad that is small in size and lacking in experience has forced John O'Connor, Kingswood School's football coach, to use the two-platoon system this season.

The Salazar dictatorship in Portugal is trying to "exile" Gen. Humberto Delgado by assigning him to McGill University, Montreal, to study economics, according to a letter from General Delgado received here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A global scientific committee was formed today to devise means to perpetuate the cooperation in space research that has marked the International Geophysical Year. The group had the support of all the great powers, including the United States and the Soviet Union.
Miss Minnie Mark was appointed yesterday as director of the Hospital Department's Division of Institutional Inspection.
Commodity futures prices generally advanced yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions before the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

The Hertz Corporation, large car and truck leasing organization, has acquired three car rental companies in Florida. Although the terms were not disclosed, the three transactions involved about $700,000.
Billie Burke and Eva Le Gallienne have been signed for starring roles in Edward Chodorov's new mystery play, "Listen to the Mocking Bird." They will portray two of three ladies involved in a murder.

MRS. TAYLOR is a welcome addition to life at the Bar Z Bar Ranch in Wyoming or thereabouts. She has, Edward Streeter tells us, a husband somewhere, but nobody knows what she has done with him and none of the male guests cares much, for Mrs. Taylor is a very pretty woman.
A $150,000,000-a-year industry, that practically no one talks about, is quietly but lucratively servicing American homes and business.

The thirty-first annual benefit for the Near East College Association will be the performance of "Carmen" at the City Center on Oct. 16. Tickets may be obtained at the office of the association, 40 Worth Street.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The tergiversations of our China policy swung hesitantly toward a new tack this week. The fact that this tack at last seems heading along a logical course should satisfy both United States and allied public opinion. The only regret is that it came so late and under such obvious pressure.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman attacked proposals to "ban the union shop" today as an "insidious attempt to shackle the rights of labor." He urged the defeat of such proposals in the states where they come before the voters this year.

HOUSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ernie Fay's Sabre continued to dominate the international sailing races on Galveston Bay today, scoring its most one-sided victory yet on the opening day of the United States 5.5-meter championship.
Army and Notre Dame, two of football's top powers, undergo exacting tests today preparatory to their meeting at South Bend, Ind., next week in the final game they will play for some years.
BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today that on his return to Bonn he would discuss all aspects of the German question with Andrei A. Smirnov, Soviet Ambassador.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 3 -- The Zoning Board of Appeals last night reserved decision for two weeks on a proposed multimillion dollar shopping center.

TUNIS, Oct. 3 -- Algerian rebels here who had hoped that a spontaneous offer would come from Premier Charles de Gaulle once he had won his French referendum, listened glumly to his Constantine speech today.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Scene One: A deserted corner in downtown Stamford. Time: Just before daylight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, accused the Air Force today of violating the law by withholding information from the General Accounting Office.

Mark Harris has been elected vice president of the S. J. Landau Corporation. He will supervise leasing and management of apartment houses and office buildings. Mr. Harris is a former executive director of the Stamford, Conn., Urban Redevelopment Commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The State Department indicated today that it was not interested in a Soviet proposal for a foreign ministers' conference on a ban on tests of nuclear weapons unless progress was made first in lower-level talks.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Richard Grothkopp, East German Deputy Budget Director, has been dismissed from his post and expelled from the Communist party for immorality and "stamping on the honor" of workers, the Communist party newspaper Neues Deutschland said today.

Single men will do well to ponder the statistical review issued not long ago by the office of the Registrar General for England and Wales in which it was reported that bachelors are more susceptible to mental illness than married men.
WILTON, Conn., Oct. 3 -- The Senior Foundation, Inc., of Norwalk announced plans yesterday for a $1,000,000 residence for elderly persons.
A BRILLIANT book review by Joe Durso Jr. has just come in by mail, and since it concerns a good book to teach children how to fish it will be printed in full.

On Sept. 23 you published a letter I addressed to you, stating facts and reasons which led me to the conclusion that our Government should move immediately to liquidate our announced commitment to defend Quemoy and Matsu Islands. On Sept. 30 you published a letter from Prof. David N. Rowe, alleging "grave factual errors" in my communication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The State Department ridiculed today reports that a forty-minute conference with Harvard political scientists had induced Secretary of State Dulles to take a more flexible stand in his policy on China.

A six-story building containing 100 apartments at 220 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Realty Equities Corporation to William Michaelman for investment. It was sold subject to first and second mortgages amounting to $490,000.
The world series moves into the Yankee Stadium today and within a few hours New York fans may learn for themselves the answer to a question puzzling a nation: What's happened to the Yankees?
George Lowery tallied on a 20-yard pass from Vince Mazilli with a minute and twenty seconds remaining as Clinton topped Boys High's eleven, 14 -- 6, at Boys High Field yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 3--Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that if the Federal courts took final action to prevent the use of public school buildings here for segregated education "then the use of private buildings and private funds is the alternative."
Robert Ransom Rush, who will pitch in his first world series game today, is tall, blond and handsome and throws fast balls that are no comfort to opposing batsmen.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Four Communist MIG-17's attacked Chinese Nationalist supply planes off Quemoy yesterday. A Nationalist C-46 cargo plane was heavily damaged, but managed to land on Quemoy, the Defense Ministry said.
Roman Catholics In New York will mark a double anniversary on Oct. 19.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The Defense Department removed the secrecy label today from millions of military documents that had been stamped top secret, secret and confidential before 1946. Some are fifty years old.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Two men were killed tonight when a twenty-three-ton crane and an air compressor toppled into the excavation in which they were working. The ditch filled with water as a main broke under the impact of the falling equipment. A third man survived.
In connection with that tragic Jersey Central open-bridge accident in Newark Bay I would like to make one observation and one suggestion.

Earl Schenck Miers, hitherto best known as a Civil War expert in good standing, will have a book about Colonial Virginia published Oct. 29. "Blood of Freedom: The Story of Jamestown, Williamsburg and Yorktown" will be a volume in a series sponsored by Colonial Williamsburg and distributed by Holt.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The North Carolina Tar Heels turned a pass interception into an 8-7 triumph over the University of Southern California tonight before 50,000 football fans at the Coliseum.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Greece warned today that Britain's new plan for Cyprus would be imposed on the Cypriotes only by "repression and police force."

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Both Princeton and Columbia will be seeking their first touchdown as well as their first victory of the 1958 season when the elevens meet at Palmer Stadium tomorrow at 2 P. M.
Responsibility for producing four television quiz shows will pass on Monday directly to the National Broadcasting Company from Barry Enright.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Jordan cautioned the Soviet Union today to refrain from "fishing in the troubled waters of the Middle East" and to allow the Arab states to work out their own destinies.
A new course on motion-picture making will be held Wednesday evenings from Oct. 22 through Dec. 17 at the Brooklyn Museum, on Eastern Parkway.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3 -- Crowds of Christian women took up sticks and stones today to enforce a traffic blockade as a mark of protest against the new Lebanese Cabinet.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- A training accident today threatened to end the career of the fastest 2-year-old trotting filly in the history of harness racing.
CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The bread grains generally advanced on the Board of Trade today but soybeans turned downward, carrying all but the November delivery to new lows for the season.
Three Brooklyn youths, who were accused of killing a man to get the clothes he was wearing, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of second-degree murder in Kings County Court.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Harry Cooper and Mrs. Larry Manheimer of Metropolis, the last of forty-two teams to finish, captured the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association pro-lady Scotch foursome championship today at Leewood.
A 21-year-old Long Island roofer was accused yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, of stealing $2,800 worth of National Guard weapons to sell to Fidel Castro, the Cuban rebel leader.

The Lincoln Securities Corporation, New York, consented in Federal Court yesterday to a permanent injunction barring it from offering for sale shares of common stock of Shoreland Mines, Ltd., a Canadian corporation, until a registration statement is filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Army's heralded "lonesome end" formation will be on display before a capacity house of 27,000 at Michie Stadium tomorrow when the cadets play Penn State.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 3 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller opened a new, tough-talking phase of his campaign for Governor today.
A New York advertising man displayed yesterday a manila envelope bearing a rubber-stamped seal with the inscription "Remember Little Rock."
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was discharged yesterday from Harlem Hospital, where he had been recovering from a stab wound.

One year ago today mankind scored its first success on the road to the stars. Even as the first bulletins came in, telling of a sputnik put into orbit, it was clear that one era of history had ended and another had begun. The promise of that first achievement has already been partially confirmed by the events of the past twelve months.
West German steel production in September totaled 1,780,000 tons, Reuters reported yesterday. That was the lowest since February, 1956.

What Casey Stengel says about his Yankees -- in private or for public consumption -- is his business Whether he calls them "off the beam," "inconsistent" or just plain "bad." However, Casey will not use certain words in connection with his ball club and, dang it, no one else is going to use 'em.
MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The discontinuance of through passenger train service between Mobile and St. Louis on Oct. 14 was announced today by the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad.

THERE were no extra attractions at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon -- just the New York Philharmonic and its new music director, Leonard Bernstein, in a program of music. It was a good program and fine playing -- and it should have satisfied anyone who cares about music.

The annual visits to this country of Ted Heath's English band are becoming pleasantly predictable events. Last night at Carnegie Hall, where the group was making its third appearance in as many years, Mr. Heath's orchestra played with the bright precision and polish that one has come to expected his musicians.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Johnny Dawson of Los Angeles and Thomas Robbins, Pinehurst, N. C., reached the final of the national seniors golf tournament today.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he always had been opposed to the theory of the self-sustaining subway fare -- and still was.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
I would like to add a hearty "Amen" to Henry Waldman's letter published Sept. 29, and also one for your good but overly fastidious editorial concerning Vice President Nixon's latest boo-boo.

Elwood R. Quesada's appointment by the President to be head of the new Federal Aviation Agency surprised no one in the aviation industry. He had been marked as a "natural" for the post since Mr. Eisenhower chose him as his special assistant on aviation matters. A private in 1924, General Quesada retired in 1951 as a lieutenant general. His career was a brilliant one.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Supporters of Leonard W. Hall contributed $48,755 to his losing fight to win the Republican nomination for Governor, reports filed with the Secretary of State showed today.
Unemployment insurance claims in New York State fell last week by 3,000, Industrial Commissioner Isador Lubin reported yesterday.
Cotton futures moved 6 points off to 2 points up yesterday after holding in a narrow range. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)

Six huge aluminum coal haulers, said to be the largest light metal trucks in the world, have been delivered to Aluminum Company of America. The haulers, which are thirty-seven feet long, eleven feet wide and nine feet deep, were built by General Transportation Company, Chicago.

The six-story store and business structure at 5 and 7 East Fifty-ninth Street, the last of the Brandegee holdings in this city, has been sold by John L. Brandegee, Adolph J. Koob and Faneuil Adams as trustees for the estate of Mary B. Brandegee.

Wherever Visiting Nurses serve they speak a universal language -- service. The syllables may be hurried and short, but the message is the same to all who seek aid: "We are here to help." Once more the people of New York have an opportunity to contribute to the Visiting Nurses and assure part-time home nursing care to thousands of sick persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Robert F. Keller was named general counsel of the General Accounting Office today. He has been principal assistant to Joseph Campbell, Controller General, since 1953. He succeeds Edwin L. Fisher, who has retired.
Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second largest food chain, achieved the highest sales and earnings for any similar period in the first nine months of this year.

WARSAW, Oct. 2 -- The Hungarian Government has given priority to a campaign to speed up collectivization of the land. The Communist regime has set collectivization of 50 per cent of the land by 1965 as its new goal.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Judge John W. Murphy withdrew voluntarily today as presiding judge at the forthcoming Federal conspiracy trial of Representative William J. Green Jr. and six other defendants.
Five women, one a substitute English teacher at the William H. Maxwell Vocational High School in Brooklyn, were arraigned yesterday in Women's Court on charges of prostitution.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Navy divers today found three bodies in the submerged fuselage of a patrol plane that disappeared Monday with ten men aboard. There was no sign of the other seven crewmen.
Although he made a strong attempt to drift out in the stretch, Nashville of the Llangollen Farm beat the Audley Farm's Bull Strength in the feature sprint of seven furlongs at Belmont Park yesterday.
BUFFALO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, recently labeled by Governor Harriman as a "mosquito" who was always trying to bite him, promised today to keep buzzing.

THERE is man on Madison Avenue who says that anybody can buy a diamond because all one needs is money. And to buy diamonds, one does not need any individuality or taste. This is the opinion of Chester Lawrence, whose jewelry boutique, The Collection, opened last month at 38 East Fifty-fourth Street.

LORIENT, France, Oct, 3 (Reuters) -- Eight men were drowned today in the double rescue of Dr. Alain Louis Bombard, a survival-at-sea expert who was tipped out of two capsized boats within a few minutes.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice refused today to lift a temporary injunction that prevents the Secretary of State from removing the Independent-Socialist party from the New York State ballot this fall.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad said today that three divisional offices of its eastern district would be closed Oct. 26 under an administrative reorganization plan.

MONTREAL, Oct. 3 -- The Steel Company of Canada and the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, a subsidiary of A. V. Roe (Canada) Ltd., are going ahead with plans to build multi-million-dollar plants at Contrecoeur, about twenty miles east of here on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River.
UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Governor Harriman refused to say today whether he would serve out a second four-year term if he should be re-elected.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 3 -- Life has returned to normal in Burma from the excitement that resulted last week in an arrangement whereby Gen. Ne Win, the armed services commander, will take over the Government late this month.
The State Conference of Mayors moved yesterday to seek changes in the bingo law.
The United States took a 2-0 lead against Iran in Section 2 of the preliminaries yesterday in the third round of the international team chess tournament at Munich, according to a report from Germany.
BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 3 (AP) -- An American four-man team led tonight after the horse jumping event opening the five-day, five-nation modern pentathlon tournament here.

YONKERS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Frisky Thomas, owned and driven by Norman Wines, took command at the three-quarters mark and won tonight's feature pace by two lengths over Morris Eden at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:03 4-5.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Aneurin Bevan told the final session of the Labor party's conference at Scarborough today that the party's election campaign should start now.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- Occasionally on a crisp, cool fall weekend Louis Goermer Seaton likes to drive out to Middle Straits Lake, near Pontiac, Mich., and walk around the ten-acre tract where he hopes to build his dream house some day.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Frank S. Hogan's upstate campaign brought him today to the Albany - Troy - Schenectady industrial area.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- The auto industry is looking forward to three years of basic labor stability as a result of the new national agreement reached last night between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers.
