SADDLE RIVER, H. J., Oct. 5 -- A temporary restraining order halting enforcement of this borough's Sunday blue law permitted stores here to operate without interference today for the first Sunday since Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The United States Information Agency reported today that Communist China doubled its propaganda broadcasts to Western Europe and Latin America during the first six months of the year.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 -- The gain in steel output from a low of 47 per cent of capacity last April to the present rate of about 68 per cent is impressive, according to steel men here. From now until the end of the year improvement may be more moderate, they believe.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 5 -- Pope Pius XII was greatly improved today from the slight indisposition that affected him early last week.
Four children were injured, one critically, when an amusement ride mounted on a truck spun out of control at high speed yesterday.

The impartial chairman of New York's transit industry, Theodore W. Kheel, has written a seventeen-page report condemning what he calls the "self-sustaining" transit fare. He says that if the fare and service on mass transit lines are to be stabilized, a subsidy cannot be avoided. Mayor Wagner has eagerly seconded this criticism of the "self-sustaining" fare.

Mr. and Mrs. B. and their two ailing children shook the big city soot from their feet and moved out to a little house in the suburbs last year. This year they applied to a social welfare agency with a bad case of marriage strain.
A new marine terminal is to be built at Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. It is expected to be ready late next year, Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- American-owned Ballymoss, the horse that wasn't supposed to like heavy going, today won the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe Europe's richest horse race.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Following is the text of a draft resolution on test of nuclear weapons submitted today by India:
ALBANY, Oct. 5 -- The 107 recipients of the first Regents College Teaching Fellowships were announced today by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Commissioner of Education.
Budget - balancing through economies rather than new or increased taxes was urged upon the Wagner Administration yesterday by a spokesman for the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
A WEEKLY series of television dramas from Canada was started last night with a presentation of "Encounter" over the facilities of the American Broadcasting Company.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 5 -- The Little Rock school integration crisis was at a standstill today. Both sides awaited the outcome of a hearing tomorrow in the Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals. The court will decide at St. Louis whether to enjoin the Little Rock School Board from allowing the city's four public high schools to be opened as private segregated institutions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The International Monetary Fund said today the world movement toward freer trade might be slowed because of uncertainty abroad about the eventual outcome of the United States-Canadian recessions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Dr. Charles Malik, president of the General Assembly, said today there were growing indications that the United Nations "might be spared the agony" of debating the critical situation in Taiwan Strait.
Governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, now holding their fall meeting in Boston, announced today that Edward Rotan had been nominated as president of the organization.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The United Arab Republic Government today canceled the drilling concession of an American oil man and banned his companies from further operations in Syria, an official statement said.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions wasted four scoring opportunities in the fourth quarter today and had to settle for a 13-13 tie with the Green Bay Packers in a National Football League game before 32,053.
BUFFALO, Oct. 5 (AP) The Dean of Journalism at Syracuse University said today that politicians and labor leaders had "replaced big business as the chief foes of a free press."
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Oct. 6 -- The Chinese Nationalists saw duplicity in the Chinese Communist offer today to halt the shelling of Quemoy for a week.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) -- A sturdy blond housewife, conquering numbing fatigue and rough water, has become the first person to swim the twenty-two-mile Catalina Channel both ways.

William Black, president of the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation, has announced the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission of a registration statement covering a proposed secondary distribution by him of more than half the company's 800,000 shares.
MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev declared tonight that the Soviet Union would not interfere in the Chinese "civil war" unless the United States openly attacked Communist China.

Aga Khan IV, the 21-year-old spiritual leader of the Ismaili, yesterday told a nation-wide television audience that much could be done to raise the living standards of his followers. The Ismaili are a Moslem sect numbering about 20,000,000.

A Soviet scientist said yesterday that he had been "very favorably impressed with American computers that he had seen in the United States." Soviet authorities recently prevented a leading United States expert from seeing such devices.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 5 -- The stock market displayed strength last week. International issues, especially Royal Dutch, were bought for foreign accounts. Philips and Unilever met with good demand as did some domestic industrials and shipping issues.

DUBLIN, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Dublin the all-Ireland and National Football League champion, today won the St. Brendan Cup at Croke Park, defeating New York by 2 goals 6 points (12 points) to 1 goal 7 points (10 points).
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 5 -A United States Marine battalion lingering off Beirut provided something of a mystery today.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Two young Negroes were being held by the police here today after a fight on a bus in which a white man was beaten and stabbed.
The meaning of sainthood in contemporary life was the theme of a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- Miss Dunne said today that she had no direct comment to make on Mrs. Roosevelt's remarks. But she indicated she intended to stand firm on her position on the "right-to-work" proposition.
To the 71,563 who thought Norm Siebern should have caught Red Schoendienst's triple in the sixth inning of yesterday's world series game at the Stadium add the name of Norm Siebern.
STAFFORD SPRINGS, Conn., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Negro pastor of an all-white Congregational church told his flock today that he wanted to retire.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 5 -- Today was Armed Forces Day in Indonesia, and it was celebrated here with much pride, a few bruises and an air show featuring fifteen jet bombers and trainers recently acquired from the Communist bloc.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 5 -- The first elements of a battalion of deadly Nike-Hercule anti-aircraft missiles arrived here today. The missiles are expected to be ready for action by the end of the week.
THE woman who holds the nation's purse strings also must keep a firm grip on her own.
Leading candidates of the two major parties told Harlem citizens yesterday that they had a duty to themselves as well as to voteless Negroes in the South to register and vote.

Alexis de Tocqueville, the nineteen-century French traveler, lawyer and student of politics who wrote the world-famous "Democracy in America," was interested in the state of affairs in England also. He first visited England in 1833 and returned in 1855 and 1857.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The passing of Milt Plum and the running of Jimmy Brown today enabled the Cleveland Browns to register a 45-12 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game.

With General de Gaulle's decisive show of political strength, there is renewed interest in France and her economic potentials. This recently published book, undertaken as a Rand Corporation research study, is a readable story of business, people and government in France.
An exchange program between the United States and South Africa was announced yesterday. It will be administered by the African-American Institute, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.

FROM dawn through sunset on Oct. 12, islanders, fliers and voyagers in the South Seas will see varying phases of 1958's last solar eclipse. Scientists will watch it from Motu Koe in the Danger Islands in the South Pacific.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 -- Two graying and battle-scarred T-formation quarterbacks gave a stirring display of aerial wizardry at Franklin Field today. Before 23,178 sun-warmed spectators the New York Giants' Charley Conerly and Norm Van Brocklin of the Philadelphia Eagles engaged in a passing duel that had the fans cheering from the opening kickoff.

MILWAUKEE fans, who had tinkered frantically with their television sets during the third game of the world series, left the dials alone yesterday. The fourth game came in sharp, clear and undistorted. It showed the Yankees to be as futile, as maladroit and as luckless as they had been during the first two games out in the wiener schnitzel belt.

The text of two exceptionally thoughtful papers arrived at this writer's desk last week, both of them addressed largely, or entirely, to what many regard as not only the most controversial economic issue of our times, but potentially one of the most important. This is the question:

ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Alton C. Pierson of Queenstown, Md., won the national championship for 280- cubic-inch hydroplanes today as the two-day International Cup Regatta ended on Pasquotank River. Six world records were set today, making a total of nine for the event.
THEODORE BIKEL, who is perhaps best-known here as a television and motion-picture actor, appeared in Town Hall Saturday night as a folk singer as well as dramatic artist.

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Herb Elliott, who ran the fastest mile in history last summer, said today he would remain an amateur -- a decision which probably will cost him a quarter of a million dollars.
WARSAW, Oct. 5 -- After more than ten years of growing up under communism, the Polish university student seems to be clinging determinedly to moderation -- in politics, economics and religion.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Although they have not spent a day in classrooms this fall, Little Rock High School pupils, to hear them tell it, are busy. Some even find profitable uses for their hours.
TAIPEI, Monday, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Peiping cease-fire announcement sent Nationalist Chinese officials and United States military men here into a high-level conference today.
Another victory was scored by the United States chess team last night, in the fifth round of the team tournament at Munich.
The butcher, the baker, the candlestick maker, the cop on the beat, the housewife -- all have one thing in common today: they're pouring more and more dollars into mutual funds each week.
THE new television season became official last night when Dinah Shore returned to Channel 4 with a show that was as bright as her smile.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The stock markets resumed their upward swing last week as investors decided that favorable international and economic factors outweighed the unfavorable ones.
GREENWICH, Oct. 5 -Marines on training maneuvers here stalked the woods today muttering "bang! bang!', instead of firing blank ammunition at six of their number who played the enemy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- The New York perfume house of Evyan is going into the motionpicture business through a new company incorporated in Delaware as Evyan Productions, Inc.
Many tickets already have been purchased for the Oct. 31 ,theatre benefit for the Austen Riggs Center, the interna!ionally known psychiatric teatment' center in Stockbridge, Mass.
A retired major of the Greek Army was pulled from the Hudson River last night in exhaustion after struggling almost twenty-three hours in a futile attempt to swim around Manhattan Island.

Soft sell on the hard shell was the recipe for an unusual auction held yesterday in the refined hush of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South. The auc tioneer, himself a shell-fancier, did not raise his voice -- often he pointed out the flaws as well as the merits of the 1,400 sea and land shells he was selling for his friend, a cobbler.

Lew Burdette, who will pitch for the Braves today, was singing and dancing in the clubhouse after yesterday's game. The Burdette act, was of course, inspired by the great pitching performance of his roomie, Warren Spain.

AT one time in the fourth century, food was terribly scarce in Milan. The bishop of the city, St. Ambrose, noted for his courage and his generosity to the poor, conceived the idea of extending the little meat available by coating it with bread crumbs and egg. That, according to legend, is how veal cutlet Milanese originated.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5 -- The organization of a semi-independent Orthodox Church in Macedonia, southernmost of Yugoslavia's six republics, was announced today. The new church is to remain linked with the Serbian Orthodox Church.
CLINTON, Tenn., Oct. 5 --Three dynamite explosions destroyed most of integrated Clinton High School in the pre-dawn hours here today.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., Oct. 5 -- By placing second in today's third and final race of the series Walter S. Gubelmann's yawl Windigo won the eleventh annual Philip J. Roosevelt Trophy at the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.
A claim for royalties on a basic method of extracting nuclear fuel should be settled "in a matter of a few months," Dr. Willard F. Libby of the United States Atomic Energy Commission said yesterday.
Music events tonight include Thomas Arne's masque, "Comus," presented by the Little Orchestra, Thomas Scherman conducting, with Dorothy Maynor, Laurel Hurley and other soloists. In Town Hall at 8:30.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- A life-size bronze statue of Pocahontas, the first native American to come to England, was unveiled today at the place she was buried in 1617.

A maritime union leader charged yesterday that the future of inland waterway transportation was in jeopardy from competitive measures by railroads and projected legislative maneuvers to drive barges off the rivers.

The legality and economic soundness of the proposed sale of the city's subway power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company were defended yesterday by Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission.
Merlin E. Carlock, vice chairman of Calkins Holden, Inc., and a major stockholder, has resigned from the agency.
The Theatre Guild and Dore Schary, co-producers of Mr. Schary's hit play "Sunrise at Campobello," have teamed again to present a new comedy by a well-known Hollywood scenarist.

The Spector Freight System, Inc., has received the temporary approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission to control the properties and rights of Great American Transport, Inc. Full management of the Detroit interstate motor carrier by Spector became effective Oct. 1.
OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 3 -- The chiefs of the Strategic Air Command are confident that they could destroy the Soviet Union and Communist China in the event of war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that "right-to-work" laws were aimed at "the destruction of human rights."
What may prove to be the greatest oceanographic research effort in history is being prepared for 1961-62 by an international committee. It includes both Soviet and American scientists.
HONG KONG, Monday, Oct. 6 -- The Chinese Communists ordered today a one-week suspension of their shelling of the Nationalist offshore islands "out of humanitarian considerations."
A mounted patrolman jumped off his horse in the Bronx yesterday, commandeered a car and then a cabin cruiser and finally dived into Eastchester Bay to rescue two men clinging to an overturned kayak.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 5 -- Christianity was called upon here tonight to step down from its "ivory tower of irrelevance" and meet head on the crucial issues of contemporary civilization.
Around the National League, they call Warren Spahn "the mixmaster," which is another way of saying his fast ball isn't what is used to be.

A very firm undertone prevailed for the British pound sterling in active dealings during the past week. This was attributed to the greatly improved position of the gold and dollar reserves held by the Treasury. Canadian dollar moved narrowly on transactions to fill routine requirements.
The paths of Governor Harriman and his Republican rival, Nelson A. Rockefeller, crossed twice yesterday as the candidates appeared at functions of American Polish and Ukrainian groups.

The take-home pay of factory production workers in the metropolitan area of New York and northeastern New Jersey set a record in August. The rise in the month was 53 cents, the New York Regional Office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Women's place is less in the home and more on the job, Miss Bertha S. Adkins declared today.
Hot or cold, war is a grim business whether it is waged by old veterans or youths fresh from home. More than half of today's armed forces are of college age or younger.
Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week but closed with nearly all deliveries up.

A $132,000,000 oil development program in central Sumatra is nearing completion. The Caltex Pacific Oil Company, an affiliate of the California Texas Oil Company, Ltd., has carried out the program, despite three outbreaks of warfare.
The basic styling of the 1959 Imperial that goes on sale Oct. 24 is almost identical with that of the current models.
The Yankees skidded to a 3-0 defeat before Milwaukee's high-riding Braves in the fourth game of the world series at the Stadium yesterday.

TRENTON, Oct. 5 -- The youthful Republican candidate for the House of Representatives in the Fourth Congressional District of New Jersey is being run down by a political bandwagon manned by a trained and experienced team.

ALGECIRAS, Spain, Oct. 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Antonio Barroso, Minister of War, will arrive by air in the United States tomorrow. During the next two weeks he is expected to discuss a sweeping reorganization of Spain's army of 225,000 along modern American lines.
Governor Harriman declared yesterday that one of the "primary goals" of his administration was to restore New York State "to its historic role as a model government employer."

THE summer of 1864 was hot. It was hot and dusty in the trenches where Grant's army lay before Petersburg. It was hot and dusty in Atlanta, too, as that doomed city waited for its capture by "the vandal hordes" of "that devil incarnate," William Tecumseh Sherman. How Sherman captured Atlanta, outmaneuvering and de feating the stubborn and outnumbered soldiers of Hood's army, has been discussed at length by military experts.
Your editorial of Sept. 24 "Soviet School Troubles" strikes a note of overwhelming importance to the American people.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 --The Inter-American Press Association keeps a joyful date here next week with the free Argentine press.
Strong support by labor unions has spurred the new volunteer fire-warden system in commercial lofts, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Regional officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission meet here this week to exchange ideas on ways to step up enforcement of Federal laws governing the sale of stocks and bonds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Carlos Tobar Zaldumbide, Foreign Minister of Ecuador, denied today a Soviet charge that the twenty Latin- American delegates here were merely puppets of the United States.
Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday urged liberal-minded voters of all political faiths to vote for Representative Kenneth B. Keating of Rochester Republican candidate for Senator.
HONG KONG, Oct. 5 -- There was every reason for the brothers Li to be tempted. About all they had in life was their membership in the Young Communist League.
Grain continues to be the mainstay of the steamship charter market. Rate gains last week moved the dry cargo freight rate index up for the third consecutive week.

GWYNEDD VALLEY, Pa., Oct. 5 -- Champion Westhay Fiona of Harham, the imported airedale owned by Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago, completed a week-end "double" today by taking the top prize at the Montgomery, County Kennel Club's twenty-fourth annual all- terrier specialty fixture on G. Harrison Frazier Jr's estate.
Bishop Stephen C. Neill put the blame for ulcers on fear, "the first enemy of the human race," in a sermon yesterday.
Several hundred persons have made reservations here for Atlantic jet flights since the first commercial ones Saturday, according to the British Overseas Airways Corporation.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday defended the place ofethnic and religious groups in a democratic society. At the same time he rebuked those who "are a little bit condescending" in their professions of tolerance.

THIS is National Fire Prevention Week and the following suggestions for removing home fire hazards have been made by the Department of Agriculture in conjunction with the National Fire Protection Association.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 6 -- Turnovers in sectors of the market last week were so large that all Swiss stock exchanges had to remain closed on Saturday to bring clerical work up to date.

The letter of Lewis Mumford published on Sept. 28 deplores the stand of our Government relative to the aggressive actions and threats of the Chinese Communists against the islands off the Chinese coast. He holds that our stand against this Communist aggression is based on the premise of an ultimate nuclear war that must end in world-wide catastrophe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was saying the other day that this fall's political campaign would probably end an era in American political life.

The Atlantic Pacific Tea Company will lease, upon completion in November, a 19,000-square-foot Colonial-style supermarket structure on three acres at Route 46 in Hackettstown, N. J. The lease will follow a series of deals involving three real estate operators. The three-acre parcel is owned by the Lota Realty Corporation.
ALBANY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Voter registration in upstate cities for next month's election appears to be at about the same rate as four years ago.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Union College has received a collection of papers of John Bigelow, who was prominent in the last century as a diplomat and an author. They will be added to the college's Nott Memorial Library.

CAIRO, Oct. 5 -- The failure of Tunisia to send a representative to a meeting of the Arab League Council today caused the council to postpone the adoption of a budget to aid the Algerian nationalist rebels.

RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 5 -- The rivals for the House seat in the Third Congressional District of New Jersey are conducting the quiet sort of campaign that often marks political contests in one-sided districts.
PANAMA, Oct. 5 -- National guardsmen were arresting many students today following the serious wounding of a guardsman by gunfire late last night.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 5 -- A group of bird-watchers today ended twenty-seven days of observation here with a record report for the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

LONDON, Monday, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a message today from Marshal Peng Teh-huai, Chinese Communist Defense Minister, to the Chinese Nationalists, as issued in English by the official Hsinhua (New China) news agency:
Nine new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (AP) -- An inventor whose aircraft warning device made headlines after he left home broke and despondent last June has been found living as a hobo.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 -- Louis Lurie, San Francisco theatre operator, has sent a letter to local ticket brokers warning them not to scalp "Auntie Mame" tickets. If they do, says Mr. Lurie, they will handle no more of his tickets.
Directors of Gulf States Land and Industries, Inc., on Friday voted an initial dividend of $2.50 a share on the common stock.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The annual conference of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund opened today with a challenge to President Eisenhower's proposals for expanding both institutions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is a notable hold-out against the high-level Republican decision that a personal assault on Walter P. Reuther is the best vote-getting issue.

LYONS, France, Oct. 5 -- Having promised a new deal for Algeria and for France, Premier Charles de Gaulle flew back to Paris tonight. His four-day tour helped to consolidate his victory in last Sunday's constitutional referendum.
Ambassador Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines said yesterday that no nation could remain neutral today.
New York's first television course in Russian will start tomorrow on Channel 11.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- British officials took a cautious attitude today toward Communist China's announcement. They preferred to wait before making any statement until they had seen the text and attempted to assess the full meaning of the Communists' move.
The Long Island Opera Company opened its fall season Saturday evening with a performance of "La Traviata" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Wohlreich Anderson, Ltd., insurance underwriters, has leased most of the eleventh floor in the recently modernized sixteen-story structure at 55 John Street. Ivor B. Clark and Erwin S. Wolfson are the owners of the property. Benjamin L. Stilphen of Ivor B. Clark was the broker in the negotiation. The insurance concern will move to its new quarters from 405 Lexington Avenue.
Net earnings of the major New York City banks continued to show only minor gains and losses in the first nine months of 1958 from the level of the preceding year.

FROM now through October, long-cooking beef cuts, including stew meat and pot roasts, will be featured at chain and independent stores at especially attractive prices. The lowered cost reflects the large supply of this type of meat coming to market.

Many manufacturers of women's apparel feel that, with Columbus Day and Election Day promotions still ahead, the major portion of fall business is yet to be booked. This was reported over the week-end by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The long legal battle over school segregation goes into a new and significant phase this week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Rams, getting a great defensive effort from their line and a fine passing performance from Billy Wade, handed the San Francisco Forty-niners one of their worst beatings today. The score was 33 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Chinese Communist offer to halt the shelling of Quemoy for a week and talk peace with the Nationalists aroused intense interest in Washington today. But there was no optimism that it would lead to a settlement.

The litter baskets on street corners in residential areas serve as collecting points for disposal of garbage. They are far from serving as sanitary baskets for the disposal of paper and other "clean" street litter. In some residential areas, at least, large paper bags containing plain garbage, boxes containing food leftovers, milk containers, etc., are deposited in these baskets every day.

Governor Harriman, engaging in gentle understatement as he left Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, observed that the fourth game of the world series had been "disappointing for a Yankee fan." Milwaukee had won, 3 -- 0.

All of us must be delighted with the report on the President's health after his regular check-up at Walter Reed Hospital. General Heaton not only found the result of the tests satisfactory but went on to say, "Fine -- best yet." This is good news for him and good news for his countrymen.

There is increasing evidence that demand for goods and services will grow further in the coming months. This applies to both the private and the Government sectors, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's Monthly Review released today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 5 -- The specter of another period of "tight" mortgage money, less than a year after the last one ended, was viewed here today as representatives of the nation's home building industry met.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 5 -- Ankara for the moment is remaining silent on the Cyprus question while awaiting developments with some apprehension.

THE season before last a new type of musical series was announced in New York. It consisted of Sunday chamber orchestra concerts at the New School for Social Research with unreserved seats sold at $1 each. Even before the first concert, the demand for tickets suggested an additional unusual feature -- two sittings a program.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 -- In his strongest statement yet on a thorny question, Gov. Goodwin J. Knight asserted last night that he would neither endorse nor support Senator William F. knowland in his campaign for Governor.
Agonizing reappraisals of the big powers of college football are in order after the indignities inflicted upon so many in the top echelon.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- India proposed today that the General Assembly call for an immediate suspension of tests of nuclear weapons.
George Meany, president of the joint labor movement, yesterday summoned both sides in the strike of American-flag ship line officers to meet with him today.

Herman T. Stichman, trustee of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, put forth again yesterday his plan to link the Hudson tubes with existing rapid transit and railroad facilities to ease the city's transit and commuter problems.

Formal discussion of the possible revision of the mutual security pact between Japan and the United States has opened in a healthy atmosphere. There has been sobriety and restraint in Japan and an earnest effort in the United States to understand the Japanese point of view.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 -- Baltimore Pompei posted a 4--1 verdict over Fall River today in an American League contest. Ray Swinski, Joe Defonso, Oswaldo Morelli and Ray Sucock scored for the victors.
Major gas consuming areas may require by 1963 or 1964 at least four new, thirty-inch transmission lines of 1,000 miles each.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Britain's Minister of Defense, Duncan Sandys, said today he would like to see Britain go into the space travel business.

A SIMPLE and unassuming decor can be an asset in some restaurants. It is in the East Horizon, which opened recently at 116 East Fifty-seventh Street. The premises are immaculate and nondescript. The emphasis is on good food with an oriental character.
BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- The United States Army team regained the lead in the five-nation modern pentathlon today by taking first, second and fourth places in the pistol-shooting event.
" No pitcher picked," yelled Casey Stengel as a new batch of sportswriters barged into the Yankee dressing room after yesterday's world series game.

The near-by December cocoa position fell the daily limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by a belief that the third-quarter grinding reports, expected this week, would show a sharp decline below that of the 1957 period.

Minor adjustments were made yesterday in the positions of some of the principals to the controversy over the proposed roadway through Washington Square Park. But after a three-hour hearing in the office of Borough President Hulan E. Jack, most of the parties stood firm on previously established battle lines.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.

The appointment of Charles M. Odorizzi as group executive vice president in charge of consumer products and services for the Radio Corporation of America was announced yesterday by John L. Burns, president.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Evidence that some anti-cancer compounds hasten the growth and spread of tumors in advanced cases of the disease was presented here today.
Governor Harriman helped inaugurate a rackets-education program yesterday for the Queens District Attorney's office. In the process he took a chance on a woman's speech and reaped a compliment.

Richard Arens, staff director of the House Un-American Ac. tivities Committee, said yesterday tllat the United States was losing the war against communism, domesticaUy and internationally, "at an alarming rate."

A new Sport Fury series, with swivel front seats as standard equipment, heads the 1959 Plymouth line. In two-door hardtop and convertible models, the Sports Fury goes on sale with other models Oct. 16.
John M. Weiler has been promoted from director of advertising at the Manhattan Shirt Company to vice president in charge of the advertising division. He has been with the company nine years.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Work stoppages and suppliers' shortages continue to slow the auto industry's production of 1959 models.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 6 -- Under the first complete calm since Aug. 23, a convoy landed 2,000 tons of supplies today on Quemoy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- State laws prohibiting life insurance companies from paying pensions or bonuses to employes and from adopting deferred compensation and stock option plans are outmoded and should be repealed, an insurance company lawyer said in an address here today.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- A central organization to expedite the discovery and prosecution of Nazi criminals is to be formed by West Germany's eleven state governments.

The United Nations General Assembly is heading into a new disarmament debate, which makes it pertinent to clarify again the basic issue involved. This issue is whether we shall have real, balanced and controlled disarmament, pegged to a solution of the grave international problems that give rise to armaments, or whether we shall have sham disarmament based on paper agreements that disarm the West but leave the Communist bloc free to evade them.
WASHINGTON, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Republicans and Democrats must join to fight inflation if Social Security is to continue to be a bulwark against poverty, Representative Robert W. Kean said tonight.
Sir Rudolph Peters, a noted British biochemist, was elected yesterday as president of the International Council of Scientific Unions.
ROME, Oct. 6 -- The election of a non-Italian Pontiff was considered a distinct possibility here tonight should Pope Pius XII succumb to his grave illness.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The French Communist party acknowledged today, with rare candor, that it had taken a bad beating in France's constitutional referendum.

The nation's steel industry exceeded its scheduled operating rate last week and produced 1,901,000 net tons of raw steel -- more than in any previous week since the one that began on last Nov. 18, which was forty-six weeks ago. Another increase has been scheduled for this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The United States said today that if the Chinese Communist bombardment of Quemoy stopped permanently the United States would stop convoying Nationalist supplies.

THE first coast-to-coast classroom on television, offering a full year's course in classical and atomic physics, began at 6:30 A. M. yesterday over the National Broadcasting Company. It promises to be one of the more fruitful uses of the home screen for teaching purposes.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Documents written by King George III and his Prime Minister, Lord North, on peace, war and espionage were among manuscripts of Revolutionary Americana sold here today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6 -- The Board of Directors of the Inter-American Press Association opened its annual two-day meeting here today. The session was in preparation for the fourtenth annual meeting of the General Assembly of the organization, starting Wednesday.

The twelve-story building on the northeast corner of Broadway and Leonard Street has been sold to Estate Securities Company, real estate operators. The building, formerly occupied by the Veterans Administration, recently was renovated and now has office quarters.

Prices of cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The close was 15 points lower to 6 points higher than on last Friday, with the far months showing the most strength.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Governor Harriman today ordered a special term of State Supreme Court to convene in Utica on Oct. 15 to deal judicially with the results of the four-month old investigation in that city.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Republican leaders warned today that "nationalization and socialization of industry would inevitably follow" a Democratic victory in next month's Congressional elections.

CAIRO, Tuesday, Oct. 7 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser began a long-expected reorganization of his cabinet today to give himself tighter control over the Syrian region of the United Arab Republic. He dropped one of his two Syrian Vice Presidents, Sabri el-Assail, who was the Premier of Syria just before it was merged with Egypt last Feb. 1.
LONDON, Oct. 6 Industrial share prices forged strongly ahead today in the busiest trading session of this year.

The city and the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company were reported yesterday to be preparing to negotiate on a long-term guarantee of continued commuter service on Staten Island in return for additional tax relief and a possible subsidy.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The chairman of the yachting group which built Sceptre, the unsuccessful contender for the America's Cup, said today that the boat might try again -- maybe in 1961.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 6 -- The nuclear submarine Seawolf sailed triumphantly into her home port here late today with an underwater cruising record of sixty days. She achieved it at precisely 11:45 o'clock this morning when she surfaced in a sun-dappled sea fifteen miles south of Block Island.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Searchers who reached the wreckage of a plane missing since Sept. 26 with three Western Electric Company technicians reported today that the men might be alive.
BUFFALO, Oct. 6 -- Frank S. Hogan, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, accused New York Republicans today of having created a spurious political issue from the state's crime problem.
These U. S. O. statistics tell a dramatic story. In a recent twelve-month period the attendance at U. S. O. clubs, centers and lounges around the world was nearly 40,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Some 5,000 members of the United Glass and Ceramic Workers struck two near-by plants of Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company today in defiance of their international union. A strike was scheduled for next Friday.

Better news for steels and motors and nonferrous metals and higher hopes for a peaceful solution of the Far East difficulties brought a strong tone to the stock market yesterday. The New York Times' combined, industrial and rail stock averages made new highs for 1958.
Plans were formulated yesterday for a study of the library needs of colleges and universities in the city by the Council of Higher Educational Institutions.

A new era has started behind the Iron Curtain which could best be described as that of the persecution of the intelligentsia. Most of the twenty-one persons who were sentenced to death in the months of July and August in Budapest, a secret trials, were students and intellectuals.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 -- A feminine blockade cut two of the three main roads into Beirut again today.
ROME, Oct. 6 -- Roman Catholic churches in Rome started filling up today even before public prayers for Pope Pius XII were ordered.
Nelson A. Rockefeller was at the Museum of Modern Art last night but if anyone was concerned about the political picture it was not in evidence.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 6 -The Government deposed and arrested today a rebellious desert chieftain, the Khan of Kalat. Three persons were killed when troops fired on a crowd of his supporters.

NEWSPAPERS are peculiarly reticent about themselves. In general, they are inclined to tell what's happening from day to day almost everywhere except in their own realms. No one, apparently, has ever seen a reporter bite a dog.

The high-swinging stock market and some of its closest watchers do not discourage easily. Harold Clayton, market analyst for Hemphill, Noyes Co., reports that since the year began the 1,052 New York Stock Exchange common stocks have risen more than $50,000,000,000 in value.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Democratic victories in the town of Manchester and the city of Middletown today were the highlights of sixteen town elections in Connecticut.

Something new for the cows are the hay wafers. They're on the way, thanks to a hay pelletizing machine developed by the International Harvester Company. The device is still in the experimental stage, but results so far are described as "favorable."

The little Spokane International Railroad, which operates a 150-mile bridge line between Spokane, Washington and Eastport, Idaho, on the Canadian border, became part of the giant Union Pacific Railroad yesterday.
Milton H. Biow left the advertising business two years ago, but the ad business has not left him.
Isaac Logart gave Rudell Stitch a thorough beating last night to gain a unanimous decision in their ten-round welterweight bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Members of the committees for social entertainment in connection with the seventieth National Horse Show have been announced by James M. Wareham, general chairman. The show will open at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 4 for eight days of afternoon and evening performances. The Waldorf-Astoria will be headquarters for the committees.

This week marks the eighty-seventh anniversary of the Great Chicago Fire -- appropriately recognized, both nationally and by proclamation of Mayor Wagner, as Fire Prevention Week. It is a good time to realize the immensity of the losses caused by fire and to resolve, each of us, to do what we can to prevent them.

NEWARK, Oct. 6 -- Lloyd F. Wilburn, engineer of the Jersey Central train that plunged into Newark Bay through an open drawbridge Sept. 15, died of drowning, Dr. Angelo M. Gnassi, chief pathologist of Hudson County, testified today.

In the face of racial tension over integretion, private Negro colleges in the South expect to receive record contributions this year. This was indicated here yesterday at a meeting of the United Negro College Fund at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
The directors of the Protestant Council of the City of New York voted unanimously yesterday to oppose the legalization of off-track betting.
LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Peiping radio charged today that United States planes and ships had violated Communist territorial limits after the cease- fire.
WARSAW, Oct. 6 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka accepted today another invitation to visit the Soviet Union for conferences with Kremlin leaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The National Confederation of American Ethnic Groups urged Congress today to scrap the United States Information Agency and set up a new Cabinet-level information department.

The story of nuclear weapons and the men and women who developed them is told in Robert Jungk's new book "Brighter Than a Thousand Stars." The author discusses the nuclear contributions of Werner Heisenberg, Albert Einstein, J. Robert Oppenheimer, Enrico Fermi, Frederic and Irene Joliot-Curie, Lise Meitner, Nils Bohr and many others.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 6 -- A Virginia rabbi who criticized the political "machine" of Senator Harry F. Byrd for its "massive resistance" to racial integration said today that he had received expressions of support from both Jewish and Christian sources.
The British American Oil Company, Ltd. plans to sell 2,000,000 common shares to assist in financing its capital spending program, E. D. Brookett, president, announced in Toronto yesterday.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 6 -- Groups of army, navy and air force men turned themselves into clean-up squads here over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Harold Hitz Burton, an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court since Oct. 1, 1945, will retire next Monday.
Mayor Wagner handed out 345 medals to public and parochial school children in City Hall Plaza yesterday. The awards were for prize-winning essays on "The Fire- Safe Home."

In its October review of business conditions and the business outlook the Federal Reserve Bank of New York adds its testimony to that of other qualified observers that business activity in August and probably in September as well has further consolidated its gains of May, June and July.
The National Education Association's board of directors voted yesterday to fight for the enactment of the $4,500,000,000 Murray-Metcalf bill for Federal "support" of education.

THIS year's apple crop is the largest in nine years and apples will be in plentiful supply this month and for several to come. Consumers are urged to take advantage of the abundance by adding fresh apples to menus.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- The Government reported today that the rate of inventory liquidation slowed again in August in another sign of economic recovery.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 6 -- Victor J. Asche, the attorney for seventeen Negroes assigned to six previously all-white secondary schools, filed a motion for further relief in Federal District Court here today.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Despite a four-day-old national agreement, the General Motors Corporation could get only 8,500 of 275,000 striking workers back on the job today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Two groups of powerful men in Washington, each with the same objective for the national economy, are frustrating each other almost daily in responding to the demands of the money market.
CONAKRY, Guinea, Oct. 6 -European businessmen and civil servants here expressed anxiety today at the failure of the French Government to recognize the Government of newly independent Guinea.

OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Vincent A. Corsall, Mayor of Oswego and a science teacher here, was suspended from the faculty of Oswego High School today pending a hearing in New York City on Oct. 15 on a morals charge.
Two large Eastern food chains, the Grand Union Company and Food Fair Stores, Inc., have worked out store agreements expected to be beneficial to both, it was announced yesterday.
SOME of the giants of the nineteenth-century painting world -- calmed but not dimmed by time -- are represented in the Hammer Galleries' present exhibition at 51 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Khalita, a sleek California-bred 2-year-old filly, made her Eastern debut at Belmont Park yesterday and scored a four-length victory in the fortieth running of the $24,250 Demoiselle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Northern "liberals" who control the Democratic party have frequently and gratefully demonstrated their realization of the vital contribution made to this control by their alliance with the union labor leaders. The contribution cannot be overestimated, for it has also assured Democratic control of the offices in some great populous states.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Here in New Jersey's Fifth Congressional District, two personable young men are contesting the House seat at stake:

LUXURIOUS cloths embellish the festive table settings on view at the Alice H. Marks Shop, 36 East Fifty-seventh Street. The party cloths and imaginative holiday decorations, all of which were designed by Harry D. Bell, can be ordered from this shop.
LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 6 -- Although Lawrenceville opened its football season with a 27-0 success against Perkiomen last Saturday, Coach Ken Keuffel was not completely satisfied.
Blood will be given today at the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 31 Nassau Street, to the New York regional Red Cross blood program.
Harris J. Klein, a member of a former Transit Authority, said yesterday that the public was being "brainwashed" for a fare increase on privately owned bus lines.

Peter Langham, 30-year-old son of Willard M. Kiplinger, editor of the Kiplinger Washington Letters, was fatally injured Saturday when the motorcycle he was riding collided with a taxicab at Manhattan Avenue and 116th Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's ordinarily cheerful Ambassador, Mikhail Menshikov, protested bitterly today against an American television show entitled "The Plot to Kill Stalin."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Members of the Asian-African group put off further diplomatic action on the Taiwan question today in the light of "favorable" developments.
A drastic change in the qualifying system for the 1959 United States open golf championship was announced yesterday by the United-States Golf Association.

FEET first, says Delman. And this shoe salon has a sparkling collection of fabulous fall- into-winter designs to prove the point. Looking to a season more festive and formal than in many years, these shoes are geared to fill the bill.

Jack Stroud, the New York Giants' starting right guard, probably will not be available for duty against the Redskins at Washington on Sunday. Stroud suffered torn ligaments in his right knee in New York's loss to the Philadelphia Eagles last Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Following is the text of a joint statement issued today after a luncheon of Republican leaders with the President and Vice President:
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 6 -- Early action on a national housing bill next year was indicated today by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- South Africa's Foreign Minister, Eric H. Louw, strode out of a meeting of the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today after telling the committee to mind its own business.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare called today for "a sustained and vigorous attack on water pollution" and asked stronger support from the states.

Robert Lee Turley had not been on the major league baseball scene for long before he had earned the nickname of Bullet Bob. This tag, of course, was a respectful reference to the projectile-like velocity that the big right-hander imparted to his fast ball.
The Army football team's "lonely" end may not be lonesome on Saturday against Notre Dame. That is the opinion of Barney Gill of the cadet coaching staff.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 6 -- The Private School Corporation will go ahead "just as soon as we can" with the opening of private schools for white students.
TORONTO, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Sean O'Casey said yesterday the two couples who caused a commotion at a performance here of his play, "Cock-a-Doodle Dandy," had bad manners. The playwright added:
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The Mount Kisco team of Bill Goldbeck and Dave Taddeo won the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament at Siwanoy Country Club today.
YONKERS, Oct. 6 -- Dick Williams, a 41-year-old driver, suffered fractures of both feet in a pile-up of four sulkies during the seventh event at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Former city dwellers who have moved to the suburbs and clumsily conquered storm windows, seepage and crab grass, have often had to enter another "do-it-yourself" area -- the stimulation of their own social welfare services.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers today obtained Bobby Layne from the Detroit Lions in exchange for Earl Morrall and one draft choice in 1959 and one in 1960. No money was involved in the deal.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- With the exception of the distant July and September wheat deliveries, all grain futures finished lower on the Board of Trade today.

The first cold breath of winter brushed the metropolitan area yesterday leaving a mantle of early morning frost in the northern suburbs. For today, the outlook is fair and milder with temperatures near 60 degrees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Murray Talenfeld, 26-yearold former president of Cornucopia Gold Mines, Inc., said today the Securities and Exchange Commission was misusing its inquiry of the concern's financial dealings.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The dedication of a modern dormitory and the establishment of an endowed professorship have been announced at Vassar College as part of a $25,000,000 development program.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Three railroads serving New York City were prevented today from abandoning passenger ferry service between New Jersey and Manhattan until the Supreme Court rules.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Following are the texts of the letter of resignation of Associate Justice Harold H. Burton of the Supreme Court to the President and the President's reply:
A documentary about the late Knute Rockne, football coach of Notre Dame, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sunday, Nov. 9, from 6:30 to 7 P. M.

State and municipal long-term bond sales for the nine months ended Sept. 30 totaled $6,062,406,987. This was 21 per cent more than the previous record of $4,995,668,865 for the same period last year, according to the Daily Bond Buyer.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 -- The results of last Friday's nation-wide elections suggest that Communist support may have hurt rather than helped the many parties that had fervently sought it.
A representative of the airline industry criticized the Port of New York Authority's new jet rules yesterday.

ATHENS, Oct. 6 -- Archbishop Makarios' plan for an independent Cyprus has been proposed to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization by the Greek Government as a permanent solution of the dispute over the British island colony.
George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, brought an end to the six-day strike of ships' officers last night. The strike had tied up about sixty American ships.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 6 -- A suit to force Rye city officials to submit to the voters at the Nov. 4 general election a proposition for a new city charter was begun here in the State Supreme Court.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 6. -- A plan to study the conversion of the outmoded Cross County Parkway into a state highway linking the New York and New England Thruways was rejected today by the County Board of Supervisors.
PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Council was cautiously hopeful today of making progress toward the easing of tensions between Britain, Greece and Turkey arising from the crisis in Cyprus.

A sharp rise in earnings in the final half of its fiscal year enabled the Commonwealth Oil Company of Houston to lift its net income to $456,501 or 8 cents a share in the fiscal year to July 31. This compared with $173,143 or 3 cents a share earned in the preceding year.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 6 -- There was bloodshed and sorrow in Cyprus today as the struggle between British troops and Greek Cypriote terrorists went on.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Joseph M. Schenck has formed a new association with Twentieth Century-Fox, the company he founded with Darryl F. Zanuck in 1935 through a merger of their Twentieth Century Pictures Corporation with the old Fox Film Company.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 -- The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals today extended through Oct. 15 a temporary restraining order forbidding any change in the integrated status of high schools in Little Rock, Ark.

The Eastern Stainless Steel Corporation is planning to raise $5,123,600 by the sale of convertible debentures due Nov. 15, 1973. The securities will be offered for subscription by company shareholders on the basis of $100 of debentures for each fourteen shares of common stock held.

After sixty days of cruising, submerged in their atomic-powered submarine, the brave and competent men of the Seawolf surfaced yesterday to receive the well-deserved plaudits of an admiring nation. Their feat was perhaps primarily of military importance, giving testimony once again -- like the recent cruise of the Nautilus under the North Pole -- to the new dimension to military science created by the advent of atomic submarines.

About 75 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Associated Artists Productions Corporation have been deposited with United Artists Associated, Inc., Robert S. Benjamin, chairman of the latter company, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The trial of five European residents of Algeria accused of having attempted to assassinate Gen. Raoul Salan, French commander in Algeria, began today. A sixth man, the main defendant was absent.
CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the Algerian Provisional Government, left for Tunis with three of his ministers this morning for talks with Tunisian officials.

The United States chess team defeated South Africa, 3 1/2 -- 1/2, in the sixth round of the international team tournament in Munich yesterday to wrest the lead from Spain in Section 2. The Spaniards had a bye.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Shares of a new investment company -- the Wellington Equity Fund, Inc., -- will be offered to investors today by an underwriting group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co., Bache Co., Reynolds Co. and Dean Witter Co. The offering will continue until Oct. 23.
The Federal program for additional public housing for low-income families is bogging down in New York and several other cities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- (UPI) -- Godfrey P. Schmidt, a court-appointed monitor for the teamsters' union was accused today of misappropriating funds of a faction rebelling against the administration of James R. Hoffa.
PARIS, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- A new "squeeze" was put on Paris motorists today as traffic congestion reached the point of total paralysis.
Jurors of The Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation, said yesterday they had found no sculptor worthy of reward among the applicants for its 1958 awards.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- James G. Cross, president of the Bakers' Union, was indicted today on a charge of perjury before the Senate rackets committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, (Democrat, Minnesota), forecast today a coast-to-coast Democratic landslide in November. He said he did not believe President Eisenhower "will change a vote" with his all-out campaign for Republican candidates.
Directors of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company made a series of changes in its top management at a meeting in Akron, Ohio, yesterday.

Mabel Mercer, a singer whose normal habitat is the very intimate night club, transferred her activities last night to a very intimate theatre, the Cherry Lane. In the process, she lost none of the spellbinding qualities that have won her a fanatically loyal following here and abroad.

Bullet Bob Turley, breaking curves with razor-sharp precision and accuracy, handcuffed the Braves yesterday. Gil McDougald, accounting for three runs batted in with a homer and a dauble, supplied the vital power.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) reported a record year of both lending and borrowing today. The annual report for the fiscal year ended last June 30 showed new loans to eighteen-member nations totaling the equivalent of $711,000,000, three-quarters again as high as the average of the three preceding years.
In all the discussion of integration in the public schools relatively little attention has been paid to the children who normally attend such schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Ireland is drafting a resolution under which the nations of the world would agree that only the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union and France should manufacture or possess nuclear weapons.

I note with interest the announcement of the formation of a housewives committee on consumer problems. Protection of the consumer has been one of the chief concerns of Governor Harriman's administration and the last four years have seen passage of long-needed legislation against false labeling, bait advertising and installment buying abuses.
The Ruberoid Company, a major producer of asphalt roofing, yesterday announced plans to acquire the Funkhouser Company of Hagerstown, Md.
A sharp recovery in prices for long-term Treasury securities took place in the dealers' market yesterday. In some instances, gains of 1 1/8 points were registered.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) A Federal Appeals Court upheld today the second trial conviction of Junius Irving Scales under the Smith Act. It affirmed the six-year prison sentence.
Public housing authorities sidized by the Public Housing Administration plan to sell $172,291,000 of temporary loan notes on Oct. 15, to finance low- rent projects.
INTREPID hunters are tracking elephants for their tails instead of their tusks these days.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Farm land prices have risen 5 per cent to a record high this year.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan refused today to dismiss a suit seeking the admission of fourteen Negro children to Alexandria's all-white public schools.

CLINTON, Tenn., Oct. 6 -- State and Federal agencies pressed investigations today into the three explosions that wrecked racially integrated Clinton High School early yesterday morning. Meanwhile students and teachers worked together to prepare an abandoned grade school for classes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) -- Farrell Lines, Inc. has applied for Federal subsidies to help build five new cargo liners for Farrell's United States-to-Africa route, the Maritime Administration announced today.

THOMAS SCHERMAN, diligent searcher after novelty, opened the twelfth season of his Little Orchestra Society at Town Hall last night with one several centuries old. This was the masque "Comus," written by John Milton, adapted about 100 years later by John Dalton and set to music by Thomas Arne.
ROME, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- Pope Pius XII has told plastic surgeons it is morally unlawful to operate on a person who asks for surgery "only to satisfy vanity or the caprice of fashion."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A pleasant soft-spoken gentleman who has moved quietly through American public life for twenty-nine years is about to move quietly out of it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Justice Felix Frankfurter added some firm words of his own today to the Supreme Court's unanimous opinion of a week ago rejecting any delay of school integration in Little Rock, Ark.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation elected George Russell executive vice president-finance at a meeting here yesterday. Mr. Russell had been vice president in charge of the financial staff and a director since April, 1956.
Nelson A. Rockefeller trudged into the crowded garment center yesterday to try to sell the idea that this year it is fashionable to vote Republican.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 6 -- Pope Pius XII suffered a stroke this morning. Though his condition improved greatly during the day, he was still between life and death in his summer residence here.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The former University of Virginia football star, Barney Gill, had a costly homecoming Saturday when he returned to Charlottesville to scout the Cavaliers for the Army coach, Earl Blaik.
Nelson A. Rockefeller returned to television last night to tax Governor Harriman with responsibility for a slowdown in the state's economy and to assail him for taking advice from political bosses.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 6 -- This country's Christian leadership was called upon today by Gov. LeRoy Collins of Florida to develop a constructive "plan" for the solution of racial tensions.

Apart from glamorizing his chain of Broadway showcases, Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, is arranging further steps to improve the local situation. A small self-propelled tank barge loaded with flammable industrial solvents sank in the East River yesterday after a crash with a harbor tug. The possibility that fire might break out on the river surface sent Coast Guard craft and the city fireboat John P. Mitchell to the scene.
The complicated art of playing championship baseball, a gift the Yankees long have monopolized, apparently hasn't been lost by them yet.
The Vacation Camp for the Blind will be the beneficiary of a preview performance on Oct. 28 of "The Man in the Dog Suit." The play is scheduled to open at the Coronet Theatre on Oct. 30.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 6 -- An energetic Congressional freshman who is standing on her record and her equally energetic Democratic opponent are politely slugging it out in New Jersey's Sixth Congressional District.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 6 -- Prime Minister Nehru of India, speaking for the millions "who are no longer quiet," told the West today that an explosive ferment of change was at work in Asia.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Tuesday, Oct. 7 -- Pope Pius XII passed a quiet night and was reported steadily improving this morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating of Rochester, Republican candidate for Senator, told President Eisenhower today that he had found great enthusiasm among the voters for the Republican ticket in the coming election.
Fred Haney, the little pilot of the Milwaukee Braves, wasn't happy after yesterday's loss to the Yankees. Neither was his losing pitcher, Lew Burdette.

Directors of Trans Continental Industries, Inc., a holding company, voted yesterday to distribute some of its securities assets to its stockholders in the form of a stock dividend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A labor union today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to block a stock purchase plan that the General Electric Company recently started for employes.
A campaign for funds to purchase newspaper advertisements attacking Walter P. Reuther and other union leaders was described by its sponsor yesterday as highly successful.
