RYE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt, the women's golf champion at the host Westchester Country Club, scored a thee-stroke victory in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association one-day tournament today. She carded 44, 39 -- 83 over the West Course.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 6 -- Buck Luce of Sands Point carded a par 4 on the final hole to win the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association 36-hole championship by a one-stroke margin with 74, 71 -- 145 at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today.
A letter in your Sept. 15 issue written by WhitfieId J. Bell Jr. struck me as being worthy of comment.

GILA WILDERNESS AREA, N. M., Sept. 30 -- Twenty-six head of strong, hearty outdoorsmen and forty-three horses started this morning from the Nine Sixteen Ranch to do some fishing and hunting in the old style. Jim Bridger never had it so good: seventeen of those horses are carrying food and gear.

The Dec. 16 performance of "Flower Drum Song" has been chosen by St. Barnabas House for its annual theatre benefit. The new Rodgers and Hammerstein musical is scheduled to open at the St. James Theatre on Nov. 27.
THE end result was slightly different, but a few lines from "Casey at the Bat" seemed particularly appropriate for application to yesterday's fifth game of the world series.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Tenants unable or unwilling to pay higher rents under a Government act easing rent controls became subject today to court eviction proceedings. But the possibility of large-scale evictions now seems remote.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Air Force again discounted the validity of flying saucer reports today.
FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., Oct. 6 -- Plans for the first park and recreation site in this unincorporated area of the Town of Hempstead have been given out by Edward P. Larkin, Presiding Supervisor.
I was impressed by your reprinted editorial (Sept. 26) which gave a balance sheet of the Quemoy crisis in 1955. How admirably it fits the situation today!
A Board of Education committee warned yesterday that the city would have to raise its salary schedules if it hoped to attract capable teachers.

When bowling and teaching caused conflicts in Frank Clause's life, he solved the problem by merging the two activities. Now he is in great demand as a bowling instructor. But in order to devote full time to the combined effort, the husky 43-year-old bowler has taken a leave from the school classrooms and moved his teaching techniques to the bowling lanes.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Several local officials of communities near the London Airport have complained about smoke emitted by the Boeing 707 jet airliner during a take-off last weekend, it was reported today.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman criticized a "Democrats for Rockefeller" committee yesterday for using his name in an advertisement urging the election of Nelson A. Rockefeller, Republican candidate for Governor.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Oct. 2 -- In the event of an enemy attack, it may well be a division commander -- with the rank of brigadier or major general and not necessarily even an American -- who will make the decision on firing the first nuclear weapon of World War III.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 7 -- Chinese Nationalist guns fired at three formations of eight Chinese Communist planes over Quemoy at 4:25 P. M. today. This was the first fire from Nationalist guns since the shelling halted Sunday night.

The Philadelphia Orchestra began giving subscription concerts in New York in 1917. This means that for more than forty years its regular New York season has been a cherished part of the city's musical scene. And at Carnegie Hall last night, when the orchestra began its new season here, the event had all the earmarks of a pleasant tradition being affectionately resumed.

It was inevitable that when the commercial airlines had jet passenger airplanes ready for use New York International Airport would have to make way for them. The Port of New York Authority probably recognized this stern fact of life from the very beginning. However, there seems to be a tendency lately to cast the authority in the role of villain in this piece.
Marian Anderson was named Woman of the Year yesterday by the New York branch of the American Association of University Women.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Secretary of State Dulles warned the Chinese Communists today that a resumption of their bombardment of Quemoy would bring upon them "world-wide condemnation."
The City Planning Commission warned yesterday that New York City's fiscal picture was "deeply disturbing."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 7 -- The Danes, who have a tradition of opening their parliamentary session in a largely perfunctory manner, broke this tradition today with a flourish -- and carnations.
THIS is the story of a learned young man who, on his wedding journey in Rome four years ago, fell in love with another woman -- a beauty who had died more than 400 years before.
Aram Khatchaturian, the Soviet composer, says the composers in his country write music as they please, not as their Government officials dictate.

PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democratic candidate for United States Senator, extended his bid for votes today to the wooded hills and green-blanketed valleys of Warren County.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus accused the United States Internal Revenue Service today of seeking to persecute him because of his role in the school desegregation controversy. The service admitted it had made a mistake.

C. R. Mitchell, president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association, Kansas City, Mo., has been nominated for the presidency of the United States Savings and Loan League. He is slated for election at the league's annual convention Nov. 17-21 at San Francisco, succeeding Joseph Holzka, president of the Northfield Savings and Loan Association, Staten Island.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- The condition of Pope Pius XII was authoritatively described as "stationary" early this morning after he had passed an agitated night.

Cocoa futures continued to tumble yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The December position dropped the daily limit of 1 cent a pound for the second consecutive session. The volume, 881 lots (30,000 pounds to a lot), was the third largest of the year.

KESWICK, England, Oct. 7 -- At the Old Oak Inn, where travelers have stopped for drinks since the time of the first Queen Elizabeth, a young engineer asserted that what Britain needed was more concentration on her own problems and less on those of the rest of the world.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Thirteen oil concerns were indicted by a Federal Court grand jury today for allegedly conspiring to fix gasoline prices in the South Bend area in May, 1957.
The Waterfront Commission warned hiring agents in the port against discriminatory longshore employment practices yesterday.
WHEELWRIGHT, Ky., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Almost all of Wheelwright High School's 650 students went back to classes today, including four of the five Negro pupils enrolled.
Blood will be collected today for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the Bankers Trust Company, 16 Wall Street, and the Times Facsimile Corporation, 540 West Fifty-eighth Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7 -- Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican, of Utah, said today that the Federal Government might have to step in and protect consumers from inflation.

The New York Giants signed Melwood (Buzz) Guy, a 245-pound lineman, yesterday. Guy, a former Duke University player, was released by the Cleveland Browns before the start of the current season. He had been the Browns' third draft choice last spring.
CHICAGO, Occt. 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The United States Attorney's office for Western Pennsylvania petitioned United States District Court today to hold the Hoxsey Cancer Clinic at Portage, Pa., in criminal contempt of court. It charged that the clinic had violated a consent decree to keep out of interstate commerce.
REOPENING to the public today after four months of interior remodelings subsequent to last spring's fire, the Museum of Modern Art at 11 West Fifty-third Street is placing three exhibitions on view.
Governor Harriman opened his television campaign for reelection last night by blaming the Eisenhower Administration for rising living costs, unemployment and the danger of war.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 7 -- The Norfolk City Council disclosed today that a resolution was being prepared asking for an advisory referendum on the school crisis.
Joseph R. Vogel, president of Loew's, Inc., said yesterday that his company again was profitable.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 7 (AP) -- The head of the Defense Department's space agency said tonight "It is our plan to have a man in space inside of twenty-four to thirty-six months."
OASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Wednesday, Oct. 8 -- Following are the latest medical bulletins on the illness of Pope Pius XII:
An investment group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., is offering publicly today $20,000,000 of American Cement Corporation 5 per cent sinking fund debentures, due in 1978, at 98 to yield 5.16 per cent.
Prices of cotton futures were unchanged to 16 points up yesterday. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.) The July contract was strongest.
New York University lost a promising baseball player to the New York Yankees yesterday and promptly criticized the Yankee organization in particular and baseball in general for the action.

HAVANA, Oct. 7 -- Sporadic fighting between Government forces and rebels continues throughout the eastern provinces of Oriente, Camaguey and Las Villas, according to reports that filter through the thick curtain of censorship maintained by the Cuban Government.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller charged tonight that Governor Harriman had weakened the state's crime-fighting resources and reduced official pressure on racketeers. The Republican candidate for Governor accused his opponent of "yielding to political pressure from Tammany Hall" in discharging the man who was leading the state's fight against crime on the New York waterfront.

The Radio Corporation of America will produce a new electronic typesetting machine developed by The Wall Street Journal, under an agreement announced yesterday. The machine is said to prepare metal type more than three times as fast as conventional equipment.
Education is the key to new marketing activities of Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7 -- A bold man is Fred Haney, He left himself wide open to the second guess today when he nominated Warren Spahn as his pitcher for the sixth game of the world series on the morrow. Wondrous workman that he is, the gifted left-hander is still rather elderly to be rushed back into action with only a two-day rest.
Art Carney will star in a television version of Prokofieff's musical fairy tale, "Peter and the Wolf," on Sunday, Nov. 30, from 5 to 6 P. M.

THERE are still American premieres of operas by Richard Strauss to be had. The New York City Opera Company opened its fall season at the City Center with one last night. The work was "The Silent Woman," which has waited twenty-three years since its first performance in Dresden for a hearing in this country.
ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- More than 400 New York State plants using equipment producing radiation have safety records "as good as any industry," Governor Harriman said tonight.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today the farmer "never had it so good" with good prices, fairly stable costs and abundant products.
DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 7 (UPI) -- Dave Sime, one of the world's fastest sprinters, will play "lonesome end" for Duke University's football team starting Saturday, when the Blue Devils meet Baylor here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- The United States announced tonight it had renewed a demand for "complete information" about eleven American airmen missing since the crash of a C-130 transport plane in Soviet Armenia Sept. 2.

In your encouraging editorial of Sept. 11 on the proposals by the Institute for Mediterranean Affairs for the solution of the Arab refugee problem you ask whether this solution is practical and likely to be put into effect.
LONDON, Oct 7 -- The Shipbuilding Employers Federation agreed today to give 250,000 manual workers in shipbuilding and repairing a wage increase of about 4 per cent.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7 -- The police today arrested and ordered expelled Yuri Trushin, a Soviet correspondent, for activities "dangerous" to Thailand.
PASSAIC, N. J., Oct. 7 -- For eighteen years, Gordon Canfield, a Republican, has represented the Eighth Congressional District. This year he is trying for twenty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower formally accepted today the resignation of James K. Vardaman Jr. as a member of the Federal Reserve Board, effective Dec. 1.

The United Negro College Fund yesterday elected Dr. Benjamin E. Mays as president. Dr. Mays, president of Morehouse College in Atlanta, succeeds Dr. F. D. Patterson, who had served as president since the fund raising agency was chartered in 1944.

Sales of metals in large volume by Russia in world markets is hurting the credit of Latin American countries, according to Walter H. Diamond, director, Foreign Economics Department. McGraw-Hill International Corporation.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 7 -- The Governors of the International Monetery Fund formally approved today President Eisenhower's proposal for an unspecified increase in the national quotas of the sixty-eight member countries.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 7 -- The spiraling cost of administering religious activities is being viewed with considerable alarm by church leaders.
President Eisenhower will be in New York Sunday to attend a cornerstone laying and to meet with Republican candidates.
Whatitoldyou, an imported turf performer from California, won the featured $6,000 Montauk Purse by three-quarters of a length at Belmont yesterday.
The 1959 Dodge, although it holds to its basic lines of last year, is striking in a head-on view because of the "arched eyebrows" of chrome above the twin headlights.

DALLAS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The petroleum industry must act to stem the decline in its share of the world's crude oil market the Texas Mid-Continent Oil and Gas Association was told at its annual convention today.

The Metropolitan Opera will sign contracts this afternoon with four major unions that will insure labor accord for a three-year period. It is expected the agreements will be the last signed with these unions before the company moves to its new quarters in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

The retirement of Justice Harold H. Burton from the United States Supreme Court marks the close of the judicial career of a man who in his thirteen years' service with the high tribunal has won universal regard for his untiring diligence, unwavering fairness and deep sense of moderation.

WHEN the indomitable old woman in a red wig who was Queen of England died in 1603 a messenger left for Scotland and nearly killed himself to get there first with the news that Scotland's James VI would now become England's James I. James had been waiting a long time for the good news.

EDWARD WORMLEY, renowned as a designer for the Dunbar Furniture Corporation, has added another first to his career. It is a collection of extremely decorative fabrics for Franklin Harward Fabrics, Inc.

Enough returns are in from Congressional and gubernatorial elections in Brazil to see that it was a triumph for the centrist and moderate elements. Coming as it does so soon after the surprising Presidential victory of Conservative candidate Jorge Alessandri in Chile, one is entitled to wonder if an anti-Leftist trend has not set in around Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Potter Stewart of Cincinnati, a judge of the United States Court of Appeals since 1954, was named to the Supreme Court today by President Eisenhower.

H. C. Potter has relinquished his duties as director of "Patate," starring Tom Ewell. The resignation took place in Boston, where Gilbert Miller's production of the Marcel Achard-Irwin Shaw comedy is trying out.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct 7 -- The nation's home builders expect to produce about 10 per cent more houses in 1958 than they did last year. The emphasis will be on a price range about 4 per cent lower than in 1957.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will bolster its own production schedule of thirty-seven big-budget pictures with a supplementary program of at least twelve moderate-cost films to be made by Associated Producers, Inc.

The city fireboat John Purroy Mitchel, a secondary victim of an East River crash Monday morning, was back at her berth at Noble Street, Brooklyn, yesterday with a badly damaged propeller. The crash involved the tug Invincible and the small tank barge Josephine B.
A black market in Custom House pier passes has been uncovered by Treasury Department agents.

YONKERS, Oct. 7 -- Adios Claire, a bay filly by Adios from the Annroc Stables of Brooklyn, scored a one-and-one-quarter length victory over Kwik in the M'Lady's Pace, a $13,000 stake for 3-year-old fillies arid mares, at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7 -- The 1958 world series today returned to where it started, but under slightly different circumstances and with a decided change in the general atmosphere.
NEWARK, Oct. 7 -- A shortage of more than $200,000 in the employes health plan fund of an L. Bamberger Co. department store has been un-covered, Charles V. Webb, Essex County Prosecutor, said today.

The gradual rise in copper prices has been accompanied by brisk futures trading lately on the Commodity Exchange here. There were more copper futures outstanding as trading opened yesterday than ever before in the exchange's twenty-five-year history.
The fourth quarter outlook for department and specialty stores is "considerably brighter" now than it was three months ago, the National Retail Merchants Association said yesterday.
A preliminary injunction enjoining the Jay Street Connecting Railroad from ceasing its operations was unanimously affirmed yesterday by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
The memoirs of Fied Marshal Viscount Montgomery, beginning in the current issue of Life Magazine, give his impression of United States forces in the North African campaign of World War II.

Add one more to the list of extremely talented young American pianists. He is Joseph Schwartz, a young New Yorker, a student, of Rosina Lhevinne and Irwin Freundlich, who made his Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon as winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation competition.
OTTAWA, Oct. 7 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Wheat Board's wide powers as the sole marketing agency for prairie wheat, oats and barley were upheld today by the Supreme Court of Canada.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The village priest paused for a moment today to talk to a group of boys sipping soft drinks at a pavement cafe in Castel Gandolfo, where Pope Pius XII is gravely ill.

The New York County Medical Society has suggested that a physician not endorse proprietary remedies on television. The warning was made in "New York Medicine," the official publication of the society, after three young physicians reported to the county group in the last month that they had been invited to make filmed commercials.

ROBERTO IGLESIAS, with his Ballet Espanol, opened a week's engagement last night at the Broadway Theatre under the auspices of S. Hurok, and proved himself once again an artist of distinction, of creative imagination and, at his best, of something very like genius.
Despite Governor Harriman's expressed opposition to legal off-track betting on horse races, Mayor Wagner made clear last night that he still favors it and will have it studied.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- State Department officials said the Soviet announcement of nuclear testing plans "flaunts in the face of humanity the insincerity of their concern about pollution of the atmosphere with radioactive materials."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- The Army merged the reserve district activities of seven Southern states into two new Army Corps (Reserve) organizations today.
A theatre party to aid Lenox Hill Hospital has been announced by Mrs. William D. Sicher and Mrs. James H. Wickersham, co-chairmen.
German shipping will take a major step next wek toward full recovery of its prewar role in the Port of New York.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The French will vote for men instead of party labels when they elect the first Parliament of the Fifth Republic Nov. 23 and 30. The new system is expected to reduce Communist strength drastically.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Reducing body temperature by about 8 degrees can prevent brain damage that may result from prolonged heart stoppage, two research physicians reported today.
TO those who love Chekhov, even one of his second-best plays is captivating.
CAIRO, Oct. 7 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced tonight a central Cabinet of twenty-one members to rule the United Arab Republic. Fifteen are Egyptians and six are Syrians.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Rafael Caldera was nominated today by the Christian Socialsit party as its candidate for the Presidency of Venezuela.
WILHELM KAGE is a potter extraordinary. From his powerful, expressive hands and through his sharp, fiery blue eyes comes some of the finest stoneware produced in the world today.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 7 -- The Hill School's varsity football squad is in need of game experience. Today, Head Coach Frank Bissell concentrated on helping his charges get some as he staged a lengthy scrimmage on Dell Field.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 7 -- Premier Abdul Karim el-Kasem has smashed a revolt by soldiers supporting his chief rival, Col. Abdel Salam Arif.

HONG KONG, Oct. 7 -- Communist China's Foreign Minister declared today that the United States would have "totally miscalculated'' if it interpreted "the temporary suspension of our bombardment of Quemoy" as a sign of weakness or of knuckling under to Washington's cease-fire demand.

The Washington region's national sports car racing meeting at Danville, Va., last Sunday was, as usual, a well-run affair. Though the national point championships in most all classes had been clinched in previous races, a number of the champions were entered and a crowd of close to 10,000 came out to watch the contest.

Houses in the News A private eye whose hobby is investigating the case histories of old houses of New York's suburban area reports that he has discovered several causes for rejoicing. Washington Irving's Gothic castle at Tarrytown was visited first because "Sunnyside" has just popped up in the news.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the American National Retail Jewelers Association, New York, not to conspire illegally to fix retailers' profit margins in silverware.

Following are the allocations to city departments in the 1959 capital budget as proposed yesterday by the City Planning Commission. The amount for each department includes new funds and renewals of 1958 allocations:

EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., Oct. 7 -- This village, whose origin dates to 1688, when it was known as Near Rockaway, will dedicate a new $225,000 village hall Monday at 8 P. M. The new building, on Atlantic Avenue, is only the third structure on this site.
The Purex Corporation, Ltd., California manufacturer of detergents and Dutch Cleanser, had increased sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended June 30, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 7 -- New Jersey's Seventh Congressional District has been represented by a Republican since it was reapportioned in 1930 -- for the last eight years by William B. Widnall.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7 -- Rain -- "four days of rain" -- would solve the immediate problem that confronts Casey Stengel. The manager of the Yankees, faced with the job of finding a starting pitcher for tomorrow's world series game, said today in all earnestness he hoped weather would come to his rescue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Francis White as United States Ambassador to Sweden. Mr. White took over the post in Stockholm in June of 1957 after telling friends here that he expected to retire after about a year.
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company applied today to the State Public Utility Commission for permission to issue 700,000 shares of common stock at no par value.

The head of a prominent investment house defended yesterday the function fulfilled by speculation in the government bond market. He also said that the market's recent collapse was to be charged more to the excessive non-defense spending of the Government than on the activities of gambling interests.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 7 -- A new type of radio telescope, half-completed but already investigating the sun's atmosphere, was unveiled at Stanford University here today.

Users of corrugated shipping containers can expect to pay higher prices for these products in the next few months. This prediction was made yesterday by manufacturers attending the annual meeting of the Fibre Box-Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- The Army-Notre Dame game at South Bend Saturday, matching two of the top college teams of the year, will be the last episode of football's most celebrated intersectional rivalry until at least 1964.
The Catholic Center for the Blind will benefit from the Nov. 13 performance of "Goldilocks" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.

The meaning of the words "new operation," as they are used in the present longshore working agreement, was discussed at length yesterday in arbitration proceedings involving the Grace Line and the International Longshoremen's Association.
Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said yesterday that he intended to press vigorously for higher salaries for the city's teachers.

The Citizenship Clearing House, a nonprofit educational organization with headquarters at the New York University Law Center, has announced the appointment of Dr. Gabriel Hauge and Nelson Poynter to the board of trustees.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- One of the Navy's leading combat commanders said today that he opposed the use of even small atomic weapons in limited war, lest these bring on a general nuclear holocaust.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Napoleon used to counsel: "Treat the Pope as though he had an army of two hundred thousand men." Stalin inquired with sardonic respect: "And how many divisions has the Pope?" For even the most cynical of lay leaders acknowledge the immense influence in practical affairs of the chief of the tiny Vatican state.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Premier el-Kassem's success in suppressing a pan-Arab, pro-Nasser revolt consolidates a rather mysterious military dictatorship, United States Government analyists said today.
The New York City Housing Authority sold two issues of temporary loan notes totaling $36,650,000 yesterday to finance the development of medium-rent projects.
Jean Williams, pianist, made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night as the tenth and last event of the Interval Concerts presented there this season by Norman J. Seaman.
Last August I saw Christmas wares on sale in one of the large stores.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 7 (AP) -- A field of seven, including Calumet Farm's Bardstown, is scheduled for the $20,000 added Princeton Handicap, the feature of tomorrow's fall opening at Garden State Park.

Hobart Nichols, director of the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation, said yesterday that in the future, juries appraising art works for foundation scholarships would be elected. His statement followed a foundation jury's criticism of sculpture submitted for 1958 awards.
Two Peruvian diplomats suffered injuries early Sunday when they and a colleague were ejected from a Lexington Avenue bar and grill.
Not all imports are as stimulating as German cars, French perfume or Scotch whisky.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower looked on approvingly today as Wilton B. Persons, his old friend and comrade in arms, took the oath of office as White House chief of staff.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- The new Federal space agency today named John A. Johnson, general counsel of the Air Force since 1952. as its chief legal officer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Broadcasts from Cairo, sometimes attacked as "indirect aggression" against Arab states, were defended today by Mahmoud Fawzi, Foreign Minister of the United Arab Republic.
FOR VIEWERS who are not particularly interested in being educated, WNTA-TV (Channel 13) last night offered the first in a series of filmed programs called "How to Marry a Millionaire."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that Chesterfield cigarettes were no "milder" than other cigarettes and barred Liggett Myers Tobacco Co., the makers, from saying they were.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission removed today the stock of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., of St. John's, Nfld., from its Canadian restricted list. The move allows resumption of sales of the shares in the United States.
A supposedly destitute woman continued to draw relief cheeks for six and a half years while she was being supported by a man with whom she lived, the Welfare Department said yesterday.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced the end of his feud with Carmine G. De Sapio yesterday and pledged to work for the election of Governor Harriman and the Democratic state ticket.

GILA WILDERNESS AREA, N. M., Oct. 7 -- The right way to be introduced to bear hunting as it is done in these parts is to start without the bear, and that is what was done today. I wouldn't have had it any other way.
The General Electric Company asserted yesterday that James B. Carey, union leader, was "totally wrong" in his interpretation of Securities and Exchange Commission regulations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 7 -- The Soviet Union announced today that it would continue nuclear explosions until it had equaled the total reached by the United States and Britain since last March 31, when Moscow suspended its own tests.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Egyptian-controlled radio stations and newspapers unleashed a campaign of vilification against the United States and President Eisenhower over the week-end.
EARLY copies of distinguished pieces of French furniture are in a mixed collection of imported antiques and reproductions now on sale at Bergdorf Goodman.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals tonight traded a pitcher, Billy Muffett; a catcher, Hobie Landrith, and a utility infielder, Benny Valenzuela, to the San Francisco Giants for Ernie Broglio and Marv Grissom, pitchers.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 7 -- Studebaker Packard showed its new compact car today, admittedly its last chance for survival in the highly competitive automobile industry.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- M'hammed Yazid, Minister of Information of the Algerian Provisional Government, declared today that he would seek to be heard in the General Assembly debate on the Algerian problem.
ROME, Oct. 7 -- The illness of Pope Plus XII has added to the responsibilities borne by a small group of Cardinals in Rome.
We must correct an inaccuracy in an item carried in your Sept. 26 issue which stated that our organizations had expressed opposition in a letter to Mayor Wagner to an increase in the sales tax.

OLEAN, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating warned today that Democrats who contended the nation was not united behind the Administration's Taiwan Straits policy were promoting Communist aggression.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved a 3-cent increase today in fares paid by passengers of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad between points within New Jersey. The increase in fares from 12 to 15 cents will not affect the 25-cent interstate fare from New Jersey to New York or the 15-cent intrastate fare within New York.

BERN, Switzerland, Oct. 7 (AP) -- An American team captured the five-nation modern pentathlon today by winning the fifth and last event, the cross-country race. The United States emerged the strong favorite to take the forthcoming world championship at Aldershot, England.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Income tax problems were discussed today by executives of more than 1,000 concerns carrying 96 per cent of the nation's life insurance business meeting here at the American Life convention.
The roughhouse sport of ice hockey returns to the sports scene tonight when the 1958-59 National League season opens with one game -- the New York Rangers vs. the Black Hawks at Chicago.
The importance of the lowly tin can in emergency mass feeding was demonstrated by the Emergency Welfare Division of the Office of Civil Defense in Queens yesterday.
TRENTON, N. J., Oct. 7--A report on city planning here indicated today that Trenton's central business district had a sales potential 48.8 per cent greater than its present sales.
A score of United States-flag cargo vessels sailed yesterday after ships' officers ended their six-day strike.
The 105-family apartment house at 1040 Park Avenue, northwest corner of the avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, has been purchased by Kay-Zee Associates.

A look at the infancy of the territory that included much of our forty-ninth state is given by Pierre Berton in his new book "The Klondike Fever." The author recreates the great Alaskan gold rush of sixty years ago with intimate glimpses into personalities.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 -- The new member-elect of the United States Supreme Court, whose choice was announced today, has been a judge only a little more than four years.

The Transit Authority insisted yesterday it had not yet reached a decision on a fare increase next year. It refused at the same time to commit itself on whether a subsidy would be necessary to maintain the 15-cent fare.
BEIRUT, Labonon, Oct. 7 -- At least twenty-nine persons were injured and one was killed today in a rash of civil disorders from Beirut to Tripoli.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Some profit-taking after yesterday's advance and a little more selectivity in buying took some of the buoyancy out of the stock market today.
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Mickey Homa of the Westchester Country Club gained a one-stroke lead as the metropolitan championship of the Professional Golfers Association opened today.
FREEPORT, L. I., Oct. 7 -- A nonprofit private school here for emotionally and organically disturbed children may have to close for lack of funds.
It is known as the "hardship circuit" at the Department of Defense and at U. S. O. headquarters in New York, where Jerome Coray heads the U. S. O. Shows department.
"DON'T choke -- Russian's a very easy language." In this way, Katherine Alexeieff concealed from her students that the worst was yet to come in New York's first televised course in Russian.
The United States team faced defeat in its match with West Germany in the international chess tournament at Munich, according to a report received last night.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Oct. 7 -- The first world amateur golf championship will begin tomorrow where the game of golf began. One hundred sixteen players from twenty-nine nations will start team play on the uncompromising terrain of St. Andrews' Old Course.

THE culinary skill of Paul and Trudy Gottlieb, evident in the fine dishes they provide through their catering service, shows itself again in a new product for retail sale. Butter pastries, a Viennese specialty often served by the couple at catered affairs, now are frozen and offered for $1.75 a dozen.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- Milton M. Unger of Newark, a former president of the New Jersey Bar Association, was acquitted early today of one of three counts of making false statements to the Government.

FAR HILLS, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Representative Robert W. Kean tonight praised President Eisenhower's call for national unity in the Quemoy-Matsu crisis in the face of "partisan attacks from Democrats who seek political gain."
YONKERS, Oct. 7 -- A team of fifteen players representing the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today won the Mrs. J. J. Thomson Trophy over the Hudson River Country Club course.

Gross revenues of the United Artists Corporation for the third quarter this year rose to a record $23,678,505 from $18,476,637 for the similar three months of 1957, Arthur B. Krim, president, reported yesterday.

Eight persons were killed and 976 injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. Last year during the same period, twenty-one were killed and 923 injured.

The backlog of state and municipal bond issues awaiting marketing was swelled by $125,000,000 yesterday as California and Cook County, Ill., announced forthcoming offerings. California said it would put up $100,000,000 of various purpose bonds for competitive bidding on Dec. 3. It gave no details of maturities or other information.

The Chinese Communist announcement of a week's cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait has been accorded a cautious welcome throughout the world in the hope that it may open the door, if not to a final settlement of the Taiwan problem, at least to a stabilization of the military situation that will eliminate the danger of war.
MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- Not from bourgeois hacks who befuddle the masses but from deep within the soul of the new Soviet man comes communism's newest gift to the world: The art of advertising.

The United States Steel Corporation is "exposing" its products on the roof of its headquarters building at 71 Broadway, opposite Wall Street. An "exposure rack" there contains samples of its stainless steel and vitreous enamel, part of a new corrosion study program being conducted in eight large cities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The renewal of tension in the Taiwan Strait coupled with indications that export demand is developing combined today to lift most grain futures a cent or more a bushel on the Board of Trade.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 7 -- Greek Cypriote terrorists continued their hit and run war against the British security forces today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 7 -- President Iskander Mirza declared martial law throughout Pakistan tonight. He also annulled the Constitution and dissolved the national and provincial assemblies.
The New York State Thruway will extend an eighteen-mile arm to the east today, inviting traffic to and from New England.

Wavering has begun in college football coaching ranks on the best way to try for the conversion after the first touchdown of a game. Going into the season, a sizable majority of the coaches felt that the "percentage play" was to kick for one point, rather than try for two points by running or passing.
MIAMI, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The nation's newest Roman Catholic diocese installed Bishop Coleman F. Carroll as its spiritual leader today.
City youngsters who insist that pavements are the best place for playing games have scored a point with the City Housing Authority.

After four hours of drifting at levels little above those at Monday's close, the stock market came to life yesterday. In doing so, it added about $1,400,000,000 to the market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange and made highs for more than a year for all three New York Times stock averages.
Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said yesterday that he would announce a number of big new pier-construction projects in the next several months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Murray Talenfeld repeatedly refused to answer questions at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today. He claimed the constitutional guarantee against possible self-incrimination.
DETROIT, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers served a ten-day contract cancellation notice today on the American Motors Corporation as wage talks, recessed almost four months ago, were resumed.
JOE COLLEGE is about to receive a lesson in practical economics. He soon will be picking up the tab for his own education, experts predict, simply because nobody else can afford to pay for it.

A growing shortage of room for freshman students in nursing schools will be apparent in the next two years and will be more than four times as great by 1970, Dr. Dominick F. Maurillo, regent of the University of the State of New York predicted yesterday.

The right-hander, who used to make his home at Cazenovia, Wis., a little more than 100 miles from here, was a star among stars.

The College of Cardinals will meet to elect a new Pope in the Sistine Chapel in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. The chapel is used very little for ecclesiastical offices, but tourists know it well. In the last 400 years millions have visited it to see the masterpieces of Michelangelo on the ceiling and altar wall.
The deep interest of Pope Pius XII in the Roman Catholic Church of the United States led to criticism of him as "pro-American." Soviet propaganda even pictured him as an "American agent."
Canada is studying the possibility of building an atomic-powered icebreaker as part of an effort to exploit its vast Arctic resources.

RAY DUDLEY, Canadian pianist, played a recital at Carnegie Hall last night that reaffirmed the good impression made by him at earlier hearings in this city.

THERE is no impatience with Japanese tradition in Genichiro Inokuma's recent paintings at the Willard Gallery, 23 "West Fifty-sixth Street. Montreal plans to borrow $28,000,000 in the United States market. The money is to be raised in debentures maturing in twenty years and not callable for ten years. The financing is to pay off bank loans incurred in financing local improvements and to replenish the city's funds.

The Synagogue Council of America joined last night in the expressions of regret on the passing of Pope Plus XII. News of the Pontiff's death reached the council as it was holding a plenary meeting at its office, 110 West Forty-second Street.

ONE of the soundest investments a home cook can make is in the common stock called bouillon. This rich, clear broth, which is made with beef bones and vegetables, provides a warming and nourishing introduction to autumn and winter menus.
An outdoor fashion show and ballet on the transformed steps of the Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street last night opened the city's second annual Salute to Fall.

The New York Giants received some good news yesterday. Frank Gifford, the star halfback, was released from the hospital and will be ready for the National Football League game with the Washington Redskins at Griffith Stadium on Sunday.

Marine Midland Corporation, New York State bank holding company, reported yesterday consoldiated net operating earnings of $11,096,609 or $1.28 a share for the first nine months of 1958. The calculation was based on 8,697,828 common shares outstanding after preferred dividends of $319,491.

The Waterfront Commission yesterday lost its motion for an injunction barring the union-ordered hiring of six so-called "casual" longshore workers. The bi-state agency's rules bar union pressure in hiring.

" Crisp and unequivocal" are the adjectives the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago uses to describe the present business upturn. WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- George Meany said today that it was "a lot of bunk" to talk about labor's taking over control of America.

Prime Minister Walter Nash of New Zealand advocated yesterday continued cooperation of Western nations in raising the standard of living of Asian peoples.

The National Conference of Christians and Jews is to be congratulated on its new president, Dr. Lewis Webster Jones. By the same token, Rutgers University, which Dr. Jones headed from 1951 until a few days ago, has had a major loss.
Petroleum imports and production in the week ended last Friday retreated from the high levels of the week before, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Continued selling and placement of stop-loss orders opened cocoa lower yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market recovered in what was termed a technical reaction to recent weakness. Prices fluctuated in nervous trading throughout the session.
Jean H. Jackson, a patrolman who confessed stealing more than $25,000 from offices of the police property clerk, was sentenced yesterday to serve fifteen months to two years in prison.
CHATHAM, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Governor Harriman denied as "outright slander and absurd" charges by Mr. Rockefeller that he had not been vigorous in fighting crime.

As a further step in the reconstruction of France, Premier de Gaulle has followed up the triumphal victory of his new Constitution by decreeing a new electoral system. Like the Constitution itself, the new system is designed to help end political anarchy and establish a more stable Government by complementing the strong Presidency created by the Constitution with a more responsible, if less powerful, Parliament.

Pope Pius XII was a diplomat and statesman for more than half a century. His experience in international affairs was vast and his influence was incalculable, although his temporal domain consisted of little more than the 108.7 acres of Vatican City.

Stephen W. Brener, vice president and sales manager of Helmsley-Spear, Inc., will address the Real Estate Society of the Baruch School of Business and Public Administration at City College this evening at 9 o'clock. He will speak on motels and hotels.

The Handicapped Children's Home Service, which provides recreational activity for children in their own homes, will gain from the Nov. 17 performance of "Goldilocks" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.
Local 1 of the Photo Engravers Union will give blood today at New York Red Cross Regional Blood Program Headquarters, 214 East Twenty-first Street.

Prices of copper, lead and zinc advanced a half-cent a pound yesterday, reflecting lively metals demand both here and abroad. And two major aluminum producers announced they would increase output during the next few weeks because of improving business.
School officials voiced strong disappointment yesterday over the City Planning Commission's proposed cut in requested school construction funds.

GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- The anomaly of horse-and-buggy politicking in an era when mass public attention is available through newspaper, radio and television has been painfully evident on the present four-day swing by Representative Kenneth B. Keating through western New York state.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Howell E. Jackson's Tick Tock, close to the pace all the way, grabbed the lead deep in the stretch today to win the $22,725 Princeton Handicap by a head at Garden State Park.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 8 -- Thousands of Romans and pilgrims gathered in this hill town today to be near the dying Pope and to pray for him.

Pope Pius XII had the ill fortune -- or, as he might have thought it, the opportunity and responsibility -- to be the Supreme Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church during tragic years of dictatorships, wars and the melancholy division of mankind between the free and the enslaved, between those who accepted the great tradition of Judea, Greece and Rome, and those who had turned their backs on it.
ROME, Thursday, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- A new Pope may choose to be known by any one of eighty-one names, all used by one or more of his 262 predecessors.

The sixty-one-family apartment building at 112-14 Tudor Place, the Bronx, has been sold after an ownership of twenty-five years by Max Goldstein to a client of Bernard Resnick. The structure, on a plot 109 by 125 feet, was sold for cash above mortgages of $165,000. Sidney Newman Company was the broker.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York yesterday voiced its "unanimous and unqualified opposition" to Mayor Wagner's proposal to legalize off-track betting as a possible tax source.

The Miserciordia General Hospital moved from Manhattan to its new $9,000,000 building in the Bronx yesterday. A caravan of twenty-four ambulances accomplished the transfer of thirty-four patients in less than an hour and fifteen minutes.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 9 -- The governors of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) adopted a United States resolution today calling for speedy action to raise the authorized capital of the bank.

Edgar Faure, twice Premier of France, visited China in 1956 at the invitation of Mao Tse-tung. While there he exchanged views both with Mao and Chou En-lai. Among the topics discussed were Formosa's future, diplomatic recognition by the United States, Red China's entry into the United Nations in place of Nationalist China and the position of Hong Kong.

A car went out of control on Stone Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, killing an 11-year-old girl and injuring three persons. It also smashed a store front and knocked down a traffic light.

Three new films will open at first-run theatres today. "The Decks Ran Red," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama with James Mason, Dorothy Dandridge and Broderick Crawford, is at Loew's State. Andrew L. Stone directed, wrote the scenario and co-produced with his wife, Virginia.

He was a brilliant papal envoy in Portugal, Chile and Brazil for nearly forty years before Pope Pius XII called him to Rome and gave him the red hat in the consistory of February, 1946.

The election of Ray C. Fish of Houston, Tex., as a director of the Witco Chemical Company, Inc., was announced yesterday. The company makes paint driers, detergents, emulsifiers, plasticizers, stabilizers and carbon black.

The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation has signed a fifteen-year lease covering 150,000 square feet of space on the fifth to the eighth floors of the New York Central Railroad's building at 466 Lexington Avenue, between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets.

WHEN Col. Marcellus Hightower died (he was only a lawyer but all lawyers were entitled to be called colonel in South Georgia in those days) he left a wife with whom he had never once discussed business matters. He also left a large tract of land with a lot of good timber on it, some potentially valuable clay deposits and some rich swamp fields ideal for raising cotton.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9 -- The fellow whose homer sealed today's victory and the world series for the Yankees, William Skowron Jr., answers to the nickname Moose. There are several versions of the origin of that nickname, but the most popular one concerns the way he had his hair cut when he was a child in Chicago.
Net assets of the One William Street Fund, Inc., a big mutual fund sponsored by Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, were $252,013,907 on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks dropped $55,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $132,000,000 in the like week a year ago.

A strike by the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots continued to keep seventeen colliers tied up in New England and Atlantic ports yesterday.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday in generally dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges. The world sugar months, zinc and rubber rose; cottonseed oil and lead declined, and price movements for cocoa, coffee, copper, the domestic sugar contract, potatoes and wool were mixed.

Governor Harriman worked strenuously yesterday to build up registration in New York City for the Nov. 4 election. He toured six Queens business districts in a four-hour afternoon effort, and then went to Harlem for a series of street rallies.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP) -- An Army Jupiter rocket blew apart twenty-eight seconds after launching tonight and rained debris on the cape area.
An extensive program to promote American straight bourbon whisky was announced yesterday.
Louis Lotito was elected president of the League of New York Theatres yesterday. The group, which represents producers and theatre operators, held its annual meeting in the Astor Hotel.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Officials of the nation's colleges were told today that they must keep their doors open to youth of average means and ability or risk immense harm to democratic society.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 -- Wanted -- airplane pilots. Salary -- $7,030 to $9,890. Experience -- seven years and 2,000 flying hours. Duties -- test experimental equipment. This call came today from the National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center here, where the Government is developing and testing systems for safer control of air traffic.

"THE BALLAD OF BABY DOE," introduced into the City Center repertory last spring as part of its all-American season, returned last night to seek a place in the severer competition of the Western world's operas.
The city of Venice, Ill., is going to market today to raise more than half the cost of buying from twelve railroads a toll bridge that has spanned the Mississippi River since 1910.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Court of Claims has rejected a legal effort by the Government to avoid paying back salary to employes unlawfully discharged as security risks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- A Pittsburgh lawyer refused to tell a Securities and Exchange Commission examiner today why he had brief possession of a $50,000 check that allegedly came from the funds of Cornucopia Gold Mine, Inc.
ROME, Friday, Oct. 10 -- Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, arrived here shortly before midnight last night after a hasty sea and air journey.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- A pill that induces labor in expectant mothers and later stimulates milk flow was described here today by an obstetrician.

A politician's guide on how not to develop hand calluses was outlined yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. He should know. He shook about 500 hands in midtown, Queens and the lower East Side during the day.
