WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 677,016 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 9 -- Premier Djuanda declared today that President Sukarno would welcome a visit by President Eisenhower to Indonesia.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 9 -- The North Greenwich Association successfully defended eighty seven acres of backcountry property against the Marine Corps Reserve yesterday.
BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- More than 150 prominent Americans have signed a petition asking President Eisenhower to recommend a charter amendment authorizing the Red Cross to work for the prevention of war.

MALVERNE, L. I., Oct. 9 -- Pines Pond, an old Indian camping site and later an auxiliary reservoir for New York City, has disappeared from the suburban scene. In its place is the new $2,980,000 Malverne High School, which will be dedicated Oct. 19.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 9 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn said today that he believed Democrats could reach a compromise on civil rights in the 1960 national convention that would be acceptable to both North and South.

Lumber production last week was 16.1 per cent above the level of a year ago, according to reports wired to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 18.5 per cent and orders down 6.7 per cent.

HOBOKEN, N J., Oct. 9 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democratic candidate for the Senate, canceled his campaign tour and his planned talks with party leaders today as the result of the death of Pope Pius XII.

The National Foreign Trade Council, Inc., has selected W. Rogers Herod, president of the International General Electric Company, to receive the 1958 Captain Robert Dollar Memorial Award "for distinguished contribution to the advancement of American foreign trade." The award was announced yesterday by George W. Wolf, chairman of the trade group.

New York City has more Girl Scouts than any other city in the world. They represent almost as many races, backgrounds and creeds as exist in present-day society. In Scouting, these girls find a common interest which reduces differences to the vanishing point.
Stocks went up a little and down a little yesterday and closed with a small gain in some market averages and a small loss in others.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Marek Hlasko, one of Poland's top writers, has fled to the West and asked for political asylum in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A sharp shift toward tightness in mortgage money is revealed in a set of unpublished Government figures.
HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 9 -- Suffolk County's $1,250,000 Children's Center was dedicated here today.

The State of Montana announced yesterday that it would offer $6,000,000 of serial bonds on Oct. 29 to finance the payment of bonus compensation to veterans of the Korean War. The bonds will be secured by special revenues and will come due from 1959 to 1963.

A former truck driver convicted of manslaughter who has protested his innocence since 1933 -- during eleven years of imprisonment and fourteen years of parole -- had his conviction set aside yesterday. As a result the man is no longer on parole.

Pierre Wigny, Foreign Minister of Belgium, predicted yesterday that the establishment of the European Common Market would create a greater export market for American products. M. Wigny spoke at a lunchean meeting sponsored jointly by the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce and the Belgian Chamber of Commerce at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
QUEMOY, China, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Nationalist China poured record stocks of supplies to Quemoy and withdrew about 1,100 of the beleaguered island's 47,000 civilians by ships today.

As one of "the young generation" that Aaron Feinsot, director of special services, New York University is so concerned about, I read with interest his plea on Sept. 23 that New York stop "throwing down buildings" and instead think of preserving communities.
CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 9 -- A stream of mourners filed past the body of Pope Pius XII here today from morning until late at night.
An integrated forest-products center designed to get the most out of every log will be dedicated today at Red Bluff, Calif., by the Diamond Gardner Corporation.
The cost of shipbuilding in Japan is becoming a prime factor in the calculation of ship-construction subsidies in this country.

A few days ago you reprinted an editorial of The Times of April 3, 1955 -- a very good one, too. Will you allow me to summarize some of the statements from a letter of mine which appeared in The Times of Feb. 18, 1955?
The immediate development of international law to govern outer space was urged last night at a panel discussion by space experts.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- President Tito said today the time would come when the Yugoslav Communist party would triumph, despite attacks on it by Soviet bloc countries.

Sixteen members of the Greene Avenue Stompers in the Cypress Hill section of Brooklyn were arrested yesterday. It was reported that the police had prevented a battle between the Stompers and another teen-age gang.
"THE Time Of Your Life," William Saroyan's warm and boozy appreciation of the human race, was revived with care and feeling last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2. It was a decided hit.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- A new three-year contract, with a 10-cent hourly wage increase for 4,000 workers at two atomic plants, was agreed upon today at Oak Ridge.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- A lack of funds threatens to close London's famed Covent Garden Opera House, it was reported today.
Officials in the Pentagon and the Atomic Energy Commission have expressed concern about the accuracy of Soviet announcements dealing with United States nuclear tests.

A fifth material witness was held in $100,000 bail yesterday in Kings County Court in the unsolved murder of John Robbilotto, the New York undertaker, whose body was found on a Brooklyn street early last month.

TOKYO, Oct. 9 -- The Socialist party went on a strike today, bringing proceedings to a stand still in both houses of Japan Diet (Parliament). The minority party acted in opposition to a Government bill to strengten police powers against strikers.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9 -- The Yankee triumph today brought to the most successful organization in baseball another world title to add to a record that long has stood in a class by itself. For this was the eighteenth series to go to the Bombers in a span of thirty-eight years.

WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 9 -- Ralph Erickson, Loomis School's football coach, is not one to waste words. "We're green and we've got a lot to learn," he said today as his charges continued preparations for Saturday's game with Williston Academy.
The Stouffer Corporation, in the fiscal year ended July 31, had the highest sales and earnings in the 34-year history of the food and restaurant organization.

Juan Atilio Bramuglia, Foreign Minister of Argentin in the Per6n regime, arrived yesterday for a visit to New York and Washington. Sefior Bra. mugli said he hoped to see Secretary of State Dulles, "if he's Inot too busy." He arrived by i plane ironHBuenos. Aires.
Governor Harriman asserted yesterday that his Republican opponent, Nelson A. Rockefeller, had "surrendered" to reactionary forces within the G. O. P.

Appeals to Manhattan-based foundations and business to aid the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences have brought "a gratifying trend in the right direction," the institute said yesterday in its annual report.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Oct. 9 -- A couple of New Zealand bank clerks threw the world amateur golf team championship into an uproar today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 9 -- President Iskander Mirza took personal responsibility today for the overthrow of Pakistan's parliamentary government and the voiding of her Constitution.

Virginia McManus, a 25-year-old substitute school teacher, was acquitted yesterday in Women's Court on a charge of prostitution. Magistrate Hyman Bushel also cleared Jo Anne Moore, 28, of 320 East Fifty-fifth Street of a similar charge.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd is expected by informed circles here to meet Archbishop Makarios at a conference sponsored by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to discuss Cyprus.

Net income of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation for the six months ended Aug. 31 declined to $3,928,479 from $5,036,957 in the similar period last year. This reflected the drop in volume to $40,476,936, from $44,207,890, according to the results disclosed yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan flew back to London today after two days of consultations with Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.
From the East and Southwest yesterday came hopeful earnings predictions from the chairmen of two major oil companies.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development yesterday lent the equivalent of $13,000,000 to the Guayaquil Port Authority of Ecuador for construction of a new port more accessible to ocean-going ships.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Each of the six committees of the General Assembly that met today opened its session with a moment's silence in tribute to Pope Pius XII.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The United States plans to propose before the United Nations the suspension of all tests of nuclear weapons, pending negotiations for a permanent prohibition.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9 -- Whatever else may be topsy-turvy in the world today, baseball at least is back to normal. The Yankees rule the roost again.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- State Department officials were fairly confident today that the Chinese Communists would continue the cease-fire in the Taiwan Strait beyond next Sunday.

Member banks throughout the country operated under somewhat lessened reserve pressures in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserved Bank of New York reported yesterday. On average, net free reserves -- excess reserves less borrowings -- increased $79,000,000 to $171,000,000.

GLEN RIDGE, N. J., Oct. 9 -- George Davidson of Forest Hill shot a one-under-par 70 on his ball today, good enough to give the title to his team in the New Jersey Golf Association's annual best-ball tournament at Glen Ridge.
MONTREAL, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight in the National Hockey League opener for both teams.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Dr. James B. Conant, former president of Harvard University, said that too many states had too many small high schools. He asked a "drastic" reduction for better education.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold estimated today that it would cost $65,000,000 to run the United Nations in 1959.
Many prominent persons observed the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue at a dinner dance last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza.

CLINTON, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- Clinton High School students rode a segregated bus caravan today to new borrowed school quarters in Oak Ridge for their first classes since their school was wrecked by explosions last Sunday morning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The chairman of the Democratic National Committee said today that Camille F. Gravel Jr. "is still the Democratic National Committeeman from Louisiana."
The United States chess team defeated Iceland, 3 -- 1, in the ninth and final round of the team tournament at Munich, yesterday, to finish the preliminaries with a score of 23 points.

TORONTO, Oct. 9 -- The Quebec Government has signed an agreement with Cyrus S. Eaton-Alfried Krupp interests, to start the development next year of the vast iron ore deposits of Ungava Bay at the northern edge of Quebec Province, it was reported here today.

THE abstract sculptor John Rood, who teaches art at the University of Minnesota, has come a long way from the ponderous realism of his work twenty years ago. For the visual world, though still his basic inspiration, no longer serves as a model for the kind of work he is doing today, a selection of which may be seen at The Contemporaries, 992 Madison Avenue.
Wilson Brothers, 95-year-old Chicago manufacturer of textile goods, men's shirts and underwear, has acquired for 50,000 of its authorized but unissued shares the Scaife Company of Pittsburgh.
Directors of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company yesterday increased the quarterly dividend 10 cents on the common and class B common shares to $1, payable on Dec. 5.
The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it would halt operation of its ultra high frequency television station in Hartford on Nov. 15.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Stock market prices continued their advance today at an accelerated pace.

One-sided losses to Brown and Princeton have not disheartened Columbia's football team. The Light Blue squad is looking forward eagerly, and even with a measure of hope, to its game with Yale at Baker Field tomorrow.

MONSEY, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Dr. Frank E. Stirn, whose charred body was discovered at 3 P. M. today on the lawn of an estate on South Monsey Road, was apparently a suicide, according to Dr. M. J. Moses, Rockland County Coroner.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 9 -- R. A. Butler refused today to "turn the clock back" one hundred years and reintroduce flogging as punishment and as a deterrent to crimes of violence.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee today dropped the controversial oath of amateur intention from the rules of future Olympic games.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- In predominantly Catholic Ireland flags everywhere were at half staff today. In Dublin the blinds of many houses were drawn. Radio Eireann scrapped most of its programs and broadcast solemn music.
GILA WILDERNESS AREA, N. M., Oct. 3 -- There is competent medical testimony tonight to the effect that Bob Brister is not delirious or even ungovernably emotional.
A black-draped catafalque, surmounted by a silver papal tiara and with the coat of arms of Pope Pius XII in front and back, was erected yesterday before the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Training for family physicians in psychiatry might keep out of mental hospitals a third of the patients now committed to state institutions, it was estimated here yesterday.

Governor Harriman recently challenged his Republican opponent to "begin to talk about the real issues." Nelson A. Rockefeller, in his Elmira speech this week, certainly picked up one of these, and a major one, in discussing the state government's fiscal situation.
ANY woman who wants to play it safe this winter by wearing only "mousey" colors had better stay indoors. The fall picture is brightly colored and the new clothes scream it.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating's swing into western New York picked up momentum today as he completed the rural phase of his Senatorial vote-seeking trip. The Republican candidate's four-day tour will end tomorrow in the industrial area of Schenectady, Albany, Troy and Rensselaer.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- The "Regime of the Vacant See" or Interregnum between the death of one Pope and the election of a successor began for the Vatican today with the election of a Cardinal Camerlengo, or Chamberlain, of the Holy Roman Church.

THE American home and way life and the dressing habits of American, men came in for sharp criticism yesterday. At a Fashion Group luncheon-meeting attended at more than 800 persons, most women, Edward D. Stone called for a rehabilitation of all three.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9 -- A Freedom of the Press Committee of the Inter-American Press Association reported today there was freedom of the press in Cuba, Paraguay, Haiti, Bolivia and the Dominican Republic.
Following is a translation of a message by President Chiang Kai-shek today to the armed forces and civilians of Nationalist China, as made public here by the Chinese news service:

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Doug Ford retained the metropolitan championship of the Professional Golfers Association today after a concluding sub-par round. Over the Briar Hall Country Club course, Ford sealed the issue with a 69 for an aggregate of 278.
PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Oct. 9 -- Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts is quietly but diligently building support these days for the 1960 Democratic Presidential nomination.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Pentagon has cautioned military commanders to be careful about making statements on military subjects that could have serious political and diplomatic repercussions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Eisenhower left today on a three-day holiday, which the White House described as a pre-birthday celebration. He will be 68 years old next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, accused his Democratic counterpart today of making a "phony repudiation" of Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas in a bid for Northern Negro votes.

The largest commercial vessel ever built in the Delaware Valley, the 45,500-deadweight-ton tanker Philine, will be launched tomorrow at the Camden, N. J., yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation.
Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland said yesterday that although some court decisions were being criticized, he believed in the American system of justice.
PARIS, Oct. 9 -- France, "the eldest daughter of the Church," bowed her head in sorrow today.
TELEVISION networks offered impressive memorial programs after the announcement Wednesday night of the death of Pope Pius XII.
TEKAMAH, Neb., Oct. 9 (AP) -- "Agriculture must not be sacrificed on the political auction block," Ezra Taft Benson. Secretary of Agriculture, told a Nebraska audience today.
The following words were penned by Jonathan Swift in his work Cadenus and Vanessa: "Whoe'er excels in what we prize Appears a hero in our eyes."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The American Ship Building Company said today that the International Association of Machinists had ratified a new contract and that work would resume shortly at yards in Lorain, Ohio; Toledo, Buffalo and Chicago.

PARIS, Oct, 9 -- Hopes that Gen. Charles de Gaulle will get France's Fifth Republic safely under way from the Premier's office rather than the Presidency have been voiced privately in political circles.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 9 -- The specter of cooling relations with the Soviet Union haunted today's session of the Finnish Parliament.
HAVANA, Oct. 9 -- The police are rounding up hundreds of opponents of the regime as the Nov. 3 election approaches. The arrests came in the wake of a number of bombings in the city last week.
The Citizens Budget Commission warned yesterday that the imposition of new or increased taxes by the city might jeopardize its position as the world's greatest business and management center.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 9 -- Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock won the first prize today in a Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play-against-par tournament at Cherry Valley. Mrs. McGrath was all even on her round.
Nearly 72,000 new names were added yesterday to the voter registration lists in New York City. This brought the total of registered voters to 2,344,838 in the five boroughs.

Free Chinese all over the world today celebrate their most important national holiday. This is "Double Ten," the tenth day of the tenth month. It was on that day, in 1911, that Dr. Sun Yat-sen proclaimed his great revolution of the Chinese people against the Manchu dynasty and set China's steps on the road to national and personal freedom.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9 -- A crackpot with exhibitionistic tendencies clambered out of the stands in the eighth inning today, just after the Yankees had put the lock on their world series victory. He staggered out toward the center of the stage and wound up in a cloud of dust with a slide into second base. Then he warily evaded the tackles of onrushing gendarmes before he was trapped and carted off.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 9 -- Ten years, nine pennants and seven world championships after Casey Stengel had joined the Yankees, he was more excited about winning today than he had been following any of the previous victories.
Earnings from operations of the Consolidated Foods Corporation in the twelve weeks ended Sept. 20 increased 25 per cent to $1,116,995 from $893,999 in the corresponding period of last year.
PAYETTE, Idaho, Oct. 9 (AP) -- An Air Force transport carrying nineteen crewmen and passengers crashed and burned in southwest Idaho tonight. The state police said there were no survivors.

The preview concert of the New York Philharmonic last night started on a solemn note as Leonard Bernstein asked the audience to stand for a minute in silence "for the passing of a very great man, Pope Pius XII."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield pledged today that no Christmas mail would be left undelivered at any post office anywhere in the nation on Christmas Day.

Plans were announced yesterday for a $2,000,000 celebration here next year to mark the 350th anniversary of Henry Hudson's discovery of the Hudson River. Statewide participation will also mark the anniversary of Lake Champlain's discovery by Samuel de Champlain.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic national chairman, said today that "more heads of more Government agencies in the Eisenhower -Nixon Administration have been involved in wrongdoing and corruption than in any Administration's since Grant's."
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The stock market finished a busy week with prices still rising. Industrials rose briskly. Some leaders gained 1 shilling (14 cents) or more but most gains were in pennies.
National Airlines said yesterday that it would dispose of the bulk of its piston-engined airliner fleet starting next spring, in anticipation of operations with pure jet and turbo-prop airliners.
A little shrub was planted in Central Park yesterday by a teacher in honor of her nature-study class.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- There was a three-way tie for the medal in the fourth annual mixed Scotch open golf championship over the Dellwood Country Club course today.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 10 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower appointed Lampton Berry of Columbia, Miss., as Ambassador to Ceylon today.
The International Business Machines Corporation had net income of $91,453,043 in the first nine months of this year. It was the highest for any similar period in its history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Treasury bill rate for next week rebounded sharply after a brief fall earlier this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,800,000,000 of the ninety-one-day discount bills was 2.927 per cent, a shade higher than the 2.920 of two weeks ago and the highest since Dec. 26 last year, when the rate was 3.173 per cent.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The French Government decided today to send an official mission to Rome for the funeral of Pope Pius XII. A Minister of State, probably Pierre Pflimlin, and two members of the French Academy will be included in it.
Voter registration was slow here yesterday for the second straight day.
CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- Bobby Boyd, a Chicago middle, weight, avenged a previous defeat by Jimmy Beecham with a unanimous decision over the Miami Beach fighter in a ten-round bout tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) A volume of crops surpassing the previous record by about 13 per cent is pouring from America's farms this year. It is being grown on an acreage restricted by Government controls and a soil bank land retirement program.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 10 -- The largest steel mill to be built in Asia with technical and financial assistance from the United States went into production in Jamshedpur in Bihar State today.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10 (AP) -- United States Navy headquarters announced the American rescue today of 131 Chinese passengers from a ship that had run aground on a voyage from Communist China's port of Swatow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The rebel Algerian provisional government has told the Asian-African bloc here that it will release "about a hundred" French prisoners of war to the International Red Cross.
Nine-year-old Keiko Ito -- who comes from Osaka, Japan -- captivated 250 children yesterday morning at a special assembly in Public School 161, Springfield Gardens, Queens.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 10 -- Mother Pasqualina, a German nun who for many years headed the household staff of Pope Pius XII, left the pontifical summer residence here today, presumably for a convent outside Italy.

MIAMI, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Louisiana State's speedy backs scored in every period tonight, and its hard-charging line repulsed every threat as the Tigers from Baton Rouge swamped the University of Miami, 41 -- 0.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 4 points up to 6 points off the levels at the last previous close. (A point represents 5 cents.)
President Eisenhower will spend six hours in New York City tomorrow.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 10 -- It's hail and farewell once more for Army and Notre Dame.
The New York Giants tapered off with a light practice at Yankee Stadium yesterday in final preparation for their National Football League contest against the Redskins at Washington tomorrow.
Music events today: Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," New York City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- A glass manufacturer today forecast disaster for small retailers as a result of the General Motors Corporation's price cuts on glass supplied to its dealers.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 10 -- The sudden death of Pakistan's parliamentary Government this week caused neither loud mourning nor rejoicing in this sun-scorched capital by the Arabian Sea.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- The largest opening audience in many years gave a warm welcome to Max Rudolf, new music director and conductor of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra as the orchestra's sixty-fourth season got under way this afternoon.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Oct. 10 (AP) -- A twin-engine Navy plane out of Quonset Point, R. I., crashed and burned today about a quarter mile from Harriman Airport.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Oct. 10 -- This quiet, residential community in Nassau County will mark its fiftieth anniversary with a week's celebration starting tomorrow. The village, incorporated Oct. 15, 1908, has retained its suburban characteristics despite its proximity to New York.

Our free, sunlit days of reading are over for this year. Those city borrowers who left their libraries in June with armfuls of books to read on their vacations had to return them -- many, alas, unread -- as the October return date drew near.

I want to join the voices of James Warburg and Lewis Mumford in protest against our China policy. That the country of the Monroe Doctrine should defend its integrity on Chinese shore islands is the peak of absurdity.

The college football season's biggest Saturday to date showcases East vs. Midwest games. Today's major attractions are Army vs. Notre Dame at South Bend, Navy vs. Michigan at Ann Arbor and Pittsburgh vs. Michigan State at East Lansing.
ROME, Oct. 10 -- The Sacred College of Cardinals, acting as the interim government of the Roman Catholic Church, began preparations today for the conclave to select the new Pope.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 10 -- The third annual Indian Harbor Yacht Club-Stratford Shoal race, a sixty-four-nautical-mile overnight sail which closes the long-distance season on Long Island Sound, started off Flat Neck Point tonight.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Foreign Office moved swiftly today to pull a monkey wrench out of the machinery for the Cyprus negotiations.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Twenty-nine cars of a southbound New York Central Railroad freight train left the tracks just north of Poughkeepsie at 10:10 A. M. today. Traffic on all three main-line tracks was tied up.

SO many currents fill up a century that it would be a mistake to accept attempts to characterize in a single epithet any particular century. This is especially true of the eighteenth century, too often considered a "frivolous" period in art history.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 10 -- Bruce Zator, who pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter after shooting a classmate in Massapequa High School, received a sentence of ten to twenty years today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) --A Federal judge today gave Richard A. Mack until Nov. 7 to appear for arraignment on charges that he had conspired with Thurman A. Whiteside, a lawyer, to influence the award of Miami television Channel 10.
The Pennsylvania Railroad said yesterday it had requested permission from the Interstate Commerce Commission to increase fares between four north New Jersey shore points and New York.

Speedy legislation to provide operating differential subsidies for American-flag tramp shipping was urged yesterday by James C. Anderson, executive secretary of the American Tramp Shipowners Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A new major horse show got off the ground today with all the appearance of immediate success and ambitions of some year becoming America's greatest.
With the stock market vigorous and the economists generally optimistic, an occasional voice of pessimism or caution can barely be heard.
ATOMIC TEST SITE, Nevada, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Another small but mighty nuclear device was exploded today as the Atomic Energy Commission ran off the fourth test in its current series.
A major effort will be made today to alert the United States to its civil defense obligations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The Undersecretary of the Treasury renewed an appeal today to savings institutions to buy more Government bonds and thus help the Treasury out of its serious debt management problems.

Plans for the annual dinner dance of the Mayflower Society will be discussed Wednesday at a meeting of the dance and floor committees at the organization's headquarters at 122 East Fifty-eighth Street. The fete will take place in the Plaza on Oct. 30.

THE third of the great French troupes to come to America arrived at the Broadway Theatre last night and, commendably not waiting for the inevitable latecomers, swiftly transformed its stage into a gaudy but solemn pageant out of Renaissance Italy.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 10 -- The French Government has protested to Rabat against proposals for oil prospecting in the Moroccan-Algerian border area, a high Moroccan official disclosed today. The protest, delivered earlier this week to the Foreign Ministry by Alexandre Parodi, French Ambassador, is to be made public when Morocco replies.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 10 -- The National Science Foundation has awarded five research grants totaling $109,950 to Rutgers University.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Oct. 10 -- The countdown was reported to have started at Cape Canaveral today for the nation's second attempt to hurl a rocket around the moon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent, to 118.7 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The rally in bond prices, first noticeable in the Government securities this week, carried over emphatically yesterday into the trading in corporate obligations on the New York Stock Exchange. The volume was one of the heaviest of the year, totaling $7,300,000.
Three solemn pontifical requiem masses will be sung in St. Patrick's Cathedral for Pope Pius XII.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 10 -- Robert Reilly, 31 years old, of North Bergen, was convicted today on a charge of death by auto. The victim was Eugene L. Remy, 26, of Astoria, L.I., who was killed on the New Jersey Turnpike last Nov. 15. Reilly was found guilty in forty minutes by a jury of ten men and two women.
WARSAW, Oct. 10 -- United States and Communist Chinese diplomats met today to discuss the continuation of the ceasefire in the Taiwan Strait.

The United States and Britain have called upon the Soviets to decide whether the projected suspension of nuclear weapons tests, hailed as a first break in the twelve-year-old disarmament deadlock, is to go into effect on Oct. 31.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The United States renewed today its offer to stop all tests of nuclear weapons for one year after the beginning of negotiations in Geneva Oct. 31 for a permanent prohibition of such experiments.
The two largest domestic copper producers raised their prices of refined copper 1 cent pound yesterday, to 27 1/2 cents -- the same level quoted by the custom smelters since Wednesday.
Last year tulips and daffodils, the gift of Mrs. Mary Lasker to the city, sprouted on Park Avenue. This year yellow chrysanthemums have sprouted on Beekman Place, where Mrs. Lasker lives.

TUNIS, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -- The head of the "free Algerian Government" said today that he was ready to negotiate a cease-fire in Algeria and that French troops captured by nationalist rebels would be released "shortly."

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Harry Biltz picked today a future in which he could never sit down. The choice was forced by an automobile accident nearly a year ago.
Four choreographers and three soloists will make their debuts with the Metropolitan Opera Ballet during the coming season.

The Chase Brass and Copper Company has installed a new kind of equipment at its Cleveland, Ohio, mill that will improve its processes for putting U-bends in tubing. The operation now will be possible immediately after the tubing is formed on draw-benches.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- Pope Pius XII, in his last will and testament, made public today, implored God's mercy for his failures during the troubled years of his pontificate. He also asked the forgiveness of anyone whom he might have offended by word or deed.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 10 -- Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss appealed today for Socialist support of West Germany's growing army against divisive Soviet political tactics.

WITH the reopening this month of social dancing classes in major cities and suburbs throughout the country, the white glove, the bow and the curtsy take their place again in the lives of at least a few American boys and girls.
Copper options rose in all positions yesterday in active trading on the Commodity Exchange.
The Angels Ball, an annual fund-raising fete of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, will be held on Nov. 20 in the Plaza.

The joint sponsorship of Paddy Chayefsky's comedy-drama, temporarily referred to as "The Dybbuk from Woodhaven," has been entrusted to Saint Subber and Arthur Cantor. As of yesterday, however, it was learned that contracts had not been signed by all parties concerned.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 10 (UPI) -The Arkansas Supreme Court was asked today to rule on the constitutionality of the law under which Gov. Orval E. Faubus closed Little Rock's four high schools.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today congratulated President Chiang Kai-shek on the forty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China. The message, as made public here, said in part:

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 10 -- Mrs. Hobart C. Ramsey of Baltusrol and Thomas Berberain of the host club posted a 35-35 -- 70 to win the New Jersey Women's Golf Association Pinehurst Scotch foursomes tournament today at the Forest Hill Field Club.

A LARGE and highly diverse assemblage of paintings, sculptures and drawings -- work acquired in the last eighteen months by purchase or the gifts of stanch supporters -- will go on view today at the Whitney Museum.
YONKERS, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Irish, driven by Jimmy Cruise, won tonight's junior-free-for-all pace by a head from Canny Scot at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:04 1/5.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 10 -- The Polish Government's efforts to force his return by refusing to prolong the validity of his passport led Marek Hlasko to seek political asylum in West Germany.

TRENTON, Oct. 10 -- Representative Robert W. Kean predicted tonight a sweeping victory for himself and his party in the Nov. 4 election provided he could get his "message" to a sufficient number of voters.
A soft-spoken but vigorous engineer who holds fifty-six patents will celebrate his sixty-fifth birthday today.
A ten-year association between the Khedivial Mail Line and the Stockard Steamship Corporation will end early next month when the mail line changes its general agent.
Cinema 16 will present the season's first "Children's Cinema" program for ages 4 to 8 at 11:15 tomorrow morning at the Beekman Theatre, Second Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- The death of Pope Pius XII left to his successor a diplomatic problem bearing on relations between Roman Catholics and Moslems.
Columbia's football team will be host to Yale in an Ivy League game at Baker Field today. The contest, the thirty-sixth in the series, is slated to start at 1:30 P.M.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Coast Guard acted today to end local violations of the Federal law requiring certain United States ships to carry pilots in Federally controlled waters off Rhode Island.
The annual Columbus Day parade will be held tomorrow on Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth to Eighty-fourth Streets, beginning at 1 P. M.

Harold C. Burton, a Harlem Republican leader, accused Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. yesterday of double-talk and double-cross.

THE New York Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon did not come fully alive until the slow movement of Chopin's F minor Concerto. Here Guiomar Novaes, the piano soloist, played with the control, maturity and incandescence that have earned her a place as one of today's finest interpreters of the romantic repertory.
ROME, Oct. 10 -- The Italian Communists appeared today to be impressed by the mass turnout of Romans to watch the cortege that brought the body of Pope Pius XII from Castel Gandolfo to the Vatican.
DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- A debate on racial integration flared at today's session of the twenty-first biennial conference of the United Lutheran Church in America.

With Captain Ben Cinovitz, a former Israeli Olympian, contributing four goal and two assists, New York University's "Informal varsity" soccer team yesterday crushed Pratt Institute, 13-0, on Ohio Field.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- The body of Pope Pius XII lay in state tonight within the somber majesty of St. Peter's Basilica after having been borne in solemn procession from Castel Gandolfo.

THE horse show and the opera no longer signal the opening of the New York social season. It begins not long after Labor Day for most women. For those on a budget or for those who have problem figures, a wide selection of cocktail and evening dresses is available in the stores here.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10 -- The Hunter Radiation Therapy Center, described "as one of the noblest benefactions to the cause of medicine," was dedicated this afternoon at the Yale-New Haven Medical Center.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 10 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon struck for labor votes in the coal-steel country today by rejecting the philosophy that the Republican party should oppose organized labor.
An Indiana grandmother celebrated the beginnings of her second century by leaving by plane yesterday for her native Belgium as an unofficial "grand lady" of the Brussels World's Fair.
United States dry cargo operators have demonstrated complete disinterest in the St. Lawrence Seaway, statistics issued by the Seaway's development corporation indicated yesterday.
UNTIL this week, politics in Pakistan was a thing of many parties. But for President Iskander Mirza, it was no picnic. Now he has undertaken to clean up the "mess" in Karachi.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Democracy is not proving to be a particularly viable political form in Asia. Sukarno's experiment with what he euphemistically called "guided democracy" seems to have produced something akin to chaos. The Burmese attempt at representative government has strayed down the road of military dictatorship. And now Pakistan's parliamentary system follows the same path.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Increased export demand for grains prompted active buying of wheat futures today and prices for the bread grain finished steady on the Board of Trade.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- Formal French recognition of the new independent republic of Guinea is being delayed.
TRENTON, Oct. 10 -- A Negro inmate was fatally stabbed in a battle between Negroes and whites at the State Prison here today. Fourteen prisoners were injured.
Offerings of new securities will be made in the capital market next week in better than average volume.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 10 -- The United States Government plans to finance a five-year program of fundamental research estimated to cost 76,000 ($212,800) at Shirley Institute, Manchester. This is the headquarters of the British Cotton Industry Research Association.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 10 (AP) -- A Methodist Bishop made a strong bid today for the consolidation of his church and the Evangelical United Brethren Church.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Specialists in gynecology and genetics recommended today that physicians check carefully into the radiation history of patients and use minimal dosages of X-ray in all cases, especially with expectant mothers. They noted that ten roentgens is the lifetime limit for a person.

SOMERS POINT, N. J., Oct. 10 -- The need to awaken interest in statesmanship and government affairs by the nation's young people was emphasized today by Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democratic candidate for the Senate.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Saturday. Oct. 11 -- A large build-up of Chinese Nationalist supplies on Quemoy was reported yesterday in anticipation of the possible resumption of artillery warfare.

WILBRAHAM, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Tomorrow is Father's Day at Wilbraham Academy and is a safe bet that Coach Jim Samson's strong and spirited football team will go all-out to make the fathers' week-end visit a successful one.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 10 -- High officials of the Indian Government will visit Washington before the end of the year to negotiate with the United States an agreement for the avoidance of double taxation. A motion requiring the Board of Elections to allow persons of Puerto Rican descent to take a literacy test in either Spanish or English for the purpose of voting was denied yesterday in Bronx Supreme Court.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 11 -- Any hopes entertained by Brown's football team for Ivy League honors were rudely shaken today by Dartmouth's outfit Coach Bob Blackman's Indian scored three times in the second quarter to defeat the Bruins 20 to 0. The homecoming day crowd of 17,000 at Brown Stadium saw Dartmouth manhandle a sluggish Brown eleven in a dull contest.

BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 11 -- Britain and the United States must be ready to act to prevent aggression as long as the veto can be exercised in the United Nations Security Council, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today.

Two 14-year-old Manhattan Boy Scouts visited Bernard M. Baruch, the 88-year-old retired financier, at his home, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street yesterday morning to present to him a copy of the new Civil Defense booklet.

THIS is a big week in television. Each night of the week will bring a special show -- the type that runs for at least an hour and features big stars and big budgets. There also are several program series making their debuts.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- A pair of substitute quarterbacks kept the Southern Methodist aerial attack moving today as the Mustangs roared back from a three-touchdown deficit in the first half and defeated Missouri, 32 -- 19.

A world-wide search is in progress to find persons who have survived heavy doses of radium radiation for more than two or three decades. Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced last week that it has asked physicians, nurses and hospitals to look for long-term survivors of radium poisoning.
Columbia University alumni and their families will return to the Morningside Heights campus and to Baker Field this weekend for their annual homecoming reunion.
Governor Harriman last night likened modern exploration of the universe to the era that produced Christopher Columbus.

A month-long exhibition of fine and folk art from thirty-seven member countries of the United Nations will open at 375 Park Avenue on Oct. 24, United Nations Day. The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York will benefit from the International Art Festival.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Babe Lichardus of Grossinger and Maureen Orcutt, White Beeches, the defendnig title- holders won two matches today to gain the semi-final round of the fourth annual mixed Scotch open Golf Championship at Dellwood C. C.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Bob Horan and Phil De Santis each scored twice as the University of Connecticut scored a 28-14 football victory over the University of Massachusetts today before a homecoming crowd of 8,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -(UPI) -- B. F. Goodrich Company, one of America's biggest tire manufacturers, has announced that it will build a big rubber products plant in Iran.

WITH the addition of these two books, Viking brings to completion its Armed Services Library -- a project designed to help boys of secondary-school age in selecting the branch of service in which they would prefer to serve.

Nearly every day the young prize fighter is told to get lots of rest, avoid smoking, watch his diet, shun women and stay in shape so that, if he is knocked down, he will have the strength to get up and get hit again.

Christopher T. Chenery's First Landing won the richest race of the local season at Belmont Park yesterday, the $151,300 Champagne Stakes. In the minds of the 36,527 fans on hand, there was complete agreement that First Landing's victory came about mainly because of the excellent ride given him by the master jockey, Eddie Arcaro. He urged the colt to victory while riding on a slipped saddle.
Jupiter has what resembles an immense island floating in its atmosphere. It seems to consist of massive, brick-red mountains, occasionally whitened by ammonia show.
Spiny lobsters are like men insofar as their voices become deeper as they grow older.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sunday, Oct, 12 (AP) -- Nationalist China waited out today the final hours of the Communist-proclaimed seven-day cease-fire in Taiwan Strait.

A ranking scholar and writer on Flemish art, Dr. Friedlander was frequently consulted on valuable paintings for purposes of authentication.
LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 11 -- The Jackson brothers, Jim and Sid, starred as the Lawrence High eleven turned back Baldwin's Golden Wave, 19 -- 0, in a Class A South Shore League game today.

There was a further rise in the stock market's pulse last week. Profit taking at mid-week clamped a temporary damper on its upward thrust, but on Friday prices soared again to new highs for more than a year in the heaviest trading of 1958.

The "Festa di Gala Italiana," second in an annual series of benefit galas, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 5, will honor Italy and the contribution of Italians to the arts and, specifically, Gian-Carlo Menotti.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11 -- Premier Rashid Karami has agreed to enlarge his Cabinet in a new effort to end civil strife in Lebanon, a spokesman for his party said today.
A seven-year study of antibiotic-resistant germs in a hospital here suggests that the resistance of some common bacteria to the most widely used antibiotics may have increased in 1956 and 1957.

THE Rock Island road will assume operation of the Pullman cars on its lines beginning Nov. 1. The sole exception will be cars on the de luxe streamliner Golden State running between Chicago and Los Angeles. This train is a joint operation with the Southern Pacific which takes over at Tucumcari, N. M.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany complained today that West Germany was slow in making reparations payments to Jewish victims of nazism.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., 11 -- A world-wide radio rk has evolved here in st twelve years.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- A Federal judge ordered yesterday that four Negro students be admitted to a previously all-white school in Okmulgee County, but rejected two other petitions dealing with integration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. YY (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that even a Communist candidate was entitled to radio and television time equal to that given other office-seekers.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- Prof. Riccardo Galeazzi-Lisi, physician to Pius XII, explained to the press today how the Pope's last illness developed.
Gratitude was voiced yesterday for the saving of thousands of European Jews in Roman Catholic monastries and convents during the Hitler era through the intervention of the late Pope Pius XII.
A new food research center will be formally opened tomorrow by the H. J. Heinz Company on the north bank of the Allegheny River in Pittsburgh.
A big, last-day jump in voter registrations yesterday sent total voter enrollments in the city over the registration for 1954 -- the last comparable election year.

OF all the musical wealth Mozart left to us -- between 600 and 700 works have been catalogued -- he work he himself is said to have valued and loved the most his early opera, Idomeneo, Re Creta. This seems odd because it is not his greatest opera.

MORE pear trees should be planted on home properties this fall in the northeastern states. Chief among a number of reasons is higher prices for pears. Production in New York State, as well as elsewhere, has fallen below demand.

TWO lectures and a flower show will be staged Wednesday by the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc. The events, which are open to the public, will take place in the Colonnades Ballroom, Essex House, 160 Central Park South.

THIS is the second time within little more than a year that Leon Wolff has demonstrated a bright talent for telling the story of a military operation so tensely as to hold the interest of the general reader and so understandingly as to command the respect of the specialist.
MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (UPI) -The Montreal Canadiens scored two early goals and blanked the Detroit Red Wings, 2 -- 0, tonight for their second straight victory in the National Hockey League season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -Among the competitors in the two main classes for young riders at the Washington-International Horse Show today were a few from Mexico. They will also participate in the events at New York, Harrisburg and Toronto. They were gaining experience under the fire of competition that may lead to international stature some day.

WEST FRIENDSHIP, Md., Oct 11 -- Ch. Atrru Hot Rod, a honey-colored cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. Arthur H. Benhoff Jr. of Catonsville, Md., today was named best at the Catonsville Kennel club's thirteenth annual all-breed unbenched dog show at the Howard County Fair Grounds. A total of 747 dogs competed.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The proposed professional standards act for teachers was attacked today by the Empire State Federation of Teachers as the federation's two-day convention opened.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- The conclave for the election of a successor to Pope Pius XII will begin Oct. 25.
COLOGNE -- Developments in the lens category at the Photokina show were principally concerned with improving the methods of manipulation in use rather than in the field of advances in optical design.

PHILADELPHIA is in for a livelier opera season than it has had in at least five years. The Metropolitan Opera is increasing its visits to seven, which is one more than has been customary during Rudolf Bing's regime.

RECENT events have served to point up the paradox of the penny: the lower in value it gets, the more prominence it achieves. To be sure, most of that prominence is unfavorable and takes the form of muttering, fumbling around in pocket or purse and complaining about the accumulation of hardware.

Last Thursday at 3:52 A. M. Eugenio Pacelli, who as Pius XII bore these titles for nineteen years, seven months and seven days, died at 82 in the papal palace at Castel Gandolfo. He was 261st in the papal line.

FRANK YERBY'S new novel is about Vienna-trained Dr. Duncan Childers ("absolutely the most terrifically attractive male creature on the face of creation"), who claws his way up from a New Orleans gutter, climbs the social heights of 1903 as the most fashionable surgeon in the city, and finally chucks Antoine's and all that for a horse-and-buggy practice in his old home town.

THE recent season of the American Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House turned out surprisingly well on the whole, in view of the disasters that plagued it on tour in the immediate past and the prospects that faced it for the immediate future -- no contracts signed with the dancers, no bookings ahead, while for at least four months Lucia Chase, director and general panjandrum, concerns herself concentratedly with refinancing and reorientation.
As the shock and resentment over the recent collapse of the Government bond market wears off, hindsight is beginning to distinguish scapegoat from villain.

Tickets are still available for Tuesday's preview performance of "The Girls in 509," which will benefit the U.S.O. Fund of New York. The play, starring Imogene Coca and Peggy Wood, opens Wednesday at the Belasco Theatre.

WASHINGTON -- The process of unwinding the red tape for foreign visitors to the United States has quickened perceptibly with the recent elimination of the sailing permit and of the visa requirement for British subjects residing in Canada or Bermuda when they enter this country from anywhere in the world.
OBERLIN, Ohio. Oct. 11 -Oberlin College will mark its 125th anniversary with a threeday convocation starting next Friday. The theme will be "Education -- Safeguard of a Dynamic Democracy."

PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The green field of the Blind Brook Polo Club was the scene today of the Blind Brook Turf Club's hunts meet for the benefit of the United Hospital of Port Chester. MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 11 -- The first thing the Right Rev. Arthur Carl Lichtenberger did after his election today as the new Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church was to take a swim in the luxurious Deauville Hotel pool here. He told his wife, Florence, that he intended to keep on swimming east but she prevailed on him to stay in this country.

HAVANA, Cuba. DECORATIVE materials -- ceramic tile, marble, iron grillwork, wood filigree and stained glass -- are among the most important home fashion trends of the year. In the Cuban house shown here, all of them blend easily and happily under one roof.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- The death of a Pope and the election of his successor is one of the great, recurring dramas of history. Vacancies of the Holy See marked crucial international junctures in bygone centuries when the Popes wielded great temporal power.

HOUSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -Ernest Fay of Houston took the lead in the Scandinavian Gold Cup sailing races today. He already had captured the Giovanelli Cup and the United States 5.5-meter championship. Fay piloted his Sabre across the finish line 57 seconds ahead of Lars Thorn's Rush V, from Sweden, for his second victory in three races of the cup competition.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 11 -A legal move was made here this week to clear the way for formal legislative consideration in 1960 of a proposal to expand the port of Hampton Roads with state aid.

ALTHOUGH Africa is undoubtedly the home of the greatest variety of wild animals, India runs a close second, in spite of its enormous human population. The elephant is found in both Africa and India, but not the same elephant.

THE third international Bartok Festival in Budapest, which began on Sept. 22 and ended last Monday, brought together great artists, composers and musicologists from all over the world. Boys High upset one of New York City's ranking elevens, Lafayette, 6 -- 0, on the victor's field in Brooklyn yesterday. Charles Young scored on a 1- yard plunge 4 minutes before the end of the game, sending the Frenchies to their first loss in three starts.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 9 -- The news of The Hague to a recent newcomer who has lived a couple of years within earshot of Communist East Berlin is that here the people talk of ideas instead of ideology.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 -- Vice President Nixon is now engaged in a series of speaking tours to raise money for the Republican campaign treasury and banish defeatism from the Republican ranks.

Yesterday's science fiction is becoming today's business reality, as more and more companies speed production of space vehicles and their components. More than 3,000 companies are making devices for the space age. Investment, which includes costly research and development, in addition to production cannot be figured concretely because so many small parts and components and companies are involved. But estimates place expenditures at more than $2,000,000,000 a year.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 11 -- Army scored one of its infrequent victories over Notre Dame today as relations between the famed football rivals ended before a record gathering of 60,564.

VISION is man's most precious sense, and the organs which make it possible are among the body's most complex. "The Story of Eyes" traces the development of this visual apparatus from its simplest form in the one-celled protozoa to its most complicated in the marvelous compound eyes of some insects.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- A month-long series of tests of radiological decontamination techniques just completed at near-by Camp Stoneman proved "nearly 100 per cent successful."

Steel production in the Cleveland-Lorain district fell to 2,400,000 tons in the first nine months of this year, down 47 per cent from 1957. The low point in output came last April and May when ingot production amounted to 30 per cent of capacity.

NOTHING could have been simpler than our first report card. It was a piece of buff-colored pasteboard, about 3 1/2 by 5 inches, and it was set up to carry just five notations -- days absent, times tardy, and the teacher's evaluation of one's conduct, effort and proficiency ("proficiency" was a wonderful word for 6-year-olds to wrap their tongues around!).

HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 11 -- The case on trial before a county judge and jury in the Bergen County Courthouse here will be a bank hold-up. A Connecticut woman, Mrs. Katharine Abt of Branford, would like a recipe for canning spiced crab apples. She reports that local orchards are now offering tempting baskets of the beautiful red apples. Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week for the fourth week in succession.
