President Eisenhower, expressing deep concern yesterday described as "deplorable" the bombing of the temple in Atlanta.
President Eisenhower looked at his most vigorous and ruddiest best yesterday, just two days short of his sixty-eighth birthday, as he spent six and a half crammed hours in the city.

Representative Robert W. Kean of New Jersey has raised again the question of unfair taxation by New York of nonresidents who work in New York State. He talks of Congressional, and perhaps United States constitutional, action.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 12 -- Hotel men here are having a hard time coping with the culinary curiosity of a group of women here for a church convention.
TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Final plans have been made for the seventieth annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball to be held here next Saturday in the Tuxedo Club.
WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 12 -- Probably no nation in history has been the target of so much ill will, disapproval and criticism as has the United States in recent years, George F. Kennan said today.
HONG KONG, Monday, Oct. 13 -- Communist China has ordered its forces to prolong the cease-fire in the Quemoy area for two more weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The possibility that the school integration controversy might trigger a third party movement in the South was raised today by Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana.
Jose Torres, an undefeated Puerto Rican middleweight who now calls Brooklyn his home, gained his seventh straight victory as a professional prizefighter last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 13 -- The trial of ninety-one men and women charged with high treason took a surprising turn today when the prosecution withdrew the indictment.

The Artloom Carpet Company announced yesterday that it would ask stockholders at the annual meeting Nov, 6 to authorize the creation of a $20,000,000 issue of convertible debentures, 1,000,000 shares of convertible preferred and 1,000,000 additional common shares.
Harrison Tweed, chairman of the Temporary Commission on the Courts, analyzed the reasons for the failure of court reorganization proposals in an article published yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court left standing today the 1957 injunction prohibiting Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas from using troops to keep Negro children out of white schools.

ERNEST and Miles Mauney, twin brothers from North Carolina, presented a program of music for two pianos last night at Town Hall. It was their first full length program in New York, for when they played here in 1952 it was in association with the Federation Choral, and their second appearance was a concert of the Haarlem Philharmonic Society in 1956, which also featured Elena Nikolaidi.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union accused the Western powers today of attempting to "drown" the disarmament problem, including the proposed cessation of tests of nuclear weapons, "in endless technical disputes."
President Eisenhower will make a television appeal tonight for Representative Kenneth B. Keating's election to the United States Senate.

CONSERVATION department press agents of Eastern states have lately been sounding their A's in preparation for the annual chorus in which they try to make the hunting prospects of their states sound good.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 13 -The membership of the Protestant Episcopal Church was asked today to raise nearly $27,000,000 in the next three years to carry out the church programs.
THERE is a one-man campaign going on at Austin, Ltd., 45 West Forty-eighth Street, to bring back the good old days when tweeds were bulky and men were glad of it.

Net assets of the United States and Foreign Securities Corporation, a closed-end investment company, rose to $121,362,554, or $36.66 a share, on Sept. 30 from $115,410,679, or $34.86 a share, on Sept. 30, 1957.
The General Electric Company made a third-quarter gain of 6 per cent in earnings over the period last year, despite a 4 per cent drop in sales.

Eight rare birds declined a Tiffany setting yesterday and took wing into Fifty-seventh Street. Shortly thereafter another flew a 100-year-old Spanish coop in the store and fluttered nervously through fields of costly crystal where no man with a net could follow. The jewelry store sent out a missing-bird alarm for two pintail birds of paradise, two paradise whydabs, two Napoleon weavers and two fire finches.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The hula hoop has come to France. With unaccustomed but enthusiastic gyrations, Paris took its first step today into the magic circle (green plastic, about $1.40).
An advertising executive advised the beer industry yesterday to undertake a sharply increased promotion program to help solve its major problem of lower per capita consumption.

ATLANTA, Oct. 13 -- Federal, state and city law enforcement agencies pressed one of the most extensive investigations in Georgia history today in an attempt to solve the dynamiting of The Temple, Reform Jewish Congregation here.
HONG KONG, Oct. 13 -- Experts here regard Communist China's crop reports for 1958 as highly exaggerated. Enormous output increases that have been reported lately are described as impossible.

Sales of the nation's major chains and mail order companies rose sharply in September, topping the 1957 month by 6.3 per cent, the best gain of the year. A compilation by The New York Times yesterday showed total sales by forty-four big chains of $1,432,527,713, against $1,347,303,928 in September, 1957.
Inclement weather did not deter shoppers in the New York area yesterday. Department stores reported that Columbus Day volume was better than many retailers had expected.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Adjectives became stronger and handshakes as well as speeches became more vigorous today as Governor Harriman intensified his campaign for re-election.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 (AP) -- An alliance between the auto and railroad industries to seek fair transport regulation and taxes was proposed today by the president of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to pass on the constitutionality of an Oklahoma law that forbid Safeway Stores to cut prices to meet trading stamp competition.
After more than twelve years of vain efforts to solve the disarmament problem on an allinclusive basis, the United States is now leading the way to a functional approach.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 13 -- Tennessee Democratic leaders are chanting loudly an old, familiar theme: "Now is the time or all good men to come to the aid of the party."
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- This growing 108-year-old village moved tonight to control it future development.

JUST before the seventh game of the world series one Yankee ballplayer offered a rather strange observation. There is no point in identifying him because the front office undoubtedly would resent his attitude.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 -- There was insistent speculation in Belgrade today that a change in the Soviet-bloc campaign against Yugoslavia was in the wind.
A patrons committee has been formed to assist in planning for the annual dinner of the New York Society of Colonial Wars to be held in the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 12.

The New York Rangers yesterday summoned Marcel Paille, a goalie, and Wally Hergesheimer, a right wing, from the Buffalo Bisons of the American Hockey League. Paille will replace the injured Lorne (Gump) Worsley.

Data from Pioneer, the moonprobe vehicle that plunged back into the earth's atmosphere late Sunday, seem to provide the first direct confirmation of scientific theory on the shape of the earth's magnetic field in space.
MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (AP) -The Soviet Government told the United States formally today to quit sending its balloons over Soviet territory.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Britain may accept Archbishop Makarios' proposal for an independent Cyprus, provided its guarantees against eventual union of the island with either Greece or Turkey are strengthened.

Further criticism of proposed revisions in the voluntary oil import program came yesterday from two importing companies. But a group of independent Texas producers said there was "a great need" for limiting imports.

To the $359,583.45 that the office of baseball's Commissioner Ford C. Frick earned from the recent seven-game world series yesterday was added the sum of $1,350. The latest windfall was the result of twenty-three fines the commissioner levied against twentytwo Milwaukee Braves and one Yankee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A pickup in commercial demand and prospects for additional foreign business imparted support to old crop wheat futures today. New-crop wheat and almost all other grain deliveries turned lower.

MOST women consider it an impossible job to keep up with fashion, but Ruth Turner Wilcox knows every turn of the style cycle from Eve to Yves St. Laurent. Mrs. Wilcox is a fashion historian. Hardly a designer or theatrical costumer exists who has not studied her book, "The Mode in Costume."

The steel industry exceeded its scheduled operating rate last week for the second consecutive week and produced 1,933,000 net tons of raw steel. This was the highest output since the week that began last Nov. 18.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Walter F. Tellier, a New York securities broker, was denied a Supreme Court review today of his conviction for mail fraud and violation of the Securities Act of 1933.
A bull escaped from Madison Square Garden yesterday and had a brief night out on the town.

" UNLEAKABLE" is an epithet applied to William C. Foster, a former small businessman who got to know so many top secrets about national security that he was invited to brief Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
The Citizens Union yesterday urged approval of Amendment 1 in the Nov. 4 election.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13 -At least four persons were killed today in a new outbreak of shooting while Lebanese leaders were looking in vain for a compromise to end the bloodshed that has gone on since May 10.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The national debt jumped nearly $2,700,000,000 last week to the highest level in two and one-half years.

The Christiana stables' Endine is a 4-year-old filly that seems to lose the little ones and win the big ones. Before 31,470 rainy-day fans at Belmont yesterday the chestnut scored her second big victory of the year in the $58,100 Ladies Handicap at a mile and a half.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to guarantee a loan of $16,542,000 for the purchase of sixty locomotives.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Without opposition and with only a single abstention -- Saudi Arabia -- the Economic Committee of the General Assembly approved tonight a projected special fund for the economic development of underdeveloped countries. The vote was 73 to 0.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey received the annual Albert Schweitzer Medal of the Animal Welfare Institute yesterday.

Contributions of more than $1,000,000 were made yesterday toward the completion of the medical facilities at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University. The donations were made at a conference of about seventy-five civic leaders at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- John Kasper, segregationist leader, announced today the selection of Dale Birdsell of Baton Rouge, La., as executive secretary of the Seaboard White Citizens Council.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 13 -Suffolk County's powerful Republican organization today promised a plurality of more than 63,000 votes for Nelson A. Rockefeller, the party's candidate for Governor.
TELEVISION has nothing against good music. It just doesn't have time for it very often. Last night's "Voice of Firestone" over Channel 7 provided a happy exception.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle told the French Army bluntly today to get out of politics and to permit completely free legislative elections in Algeria.

" The Night Heaven Fell," a French-made romantic comedydrama, starring Brigitte Bardot, will have its local premiere next Tuesday at the Odeon and Fine Arts Theatres. The film was produced by Raoul J. Levy and directed by Roger Vadim.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 13 -- Two Ivy Leaguers are pitted against each other in the campaign for United States Representative from New York's sprawling First Congressional District.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 13 -- West German business men would be eager to invest in India if they were given 51 per cent partnership in the capital of new industries, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister for Economic Affairs of West Germany, said here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- A Federal judge today paved the way for the start of filming on "The Horse Soldiers" by approving the right of William Holden to accept a co-starring role with John Wayne in the picture.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Bardstown won today's $28,550 Quaker City Handicap at Garden State Park after a late surge.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Oct. 13 -- Australia left the back nine of the rugged Old Course in ruin today. Her big three, Bruce Devlin, Bob Stevens and Peter Toogood ripped 2 strokes off par -- an incredible feat on this tough terrain -- to defeat the United States, 222 to 224, in the 18-hole play-off for the first world amateur golf team championship.
Gray skies, a sprinkling of rain and two crewless ocean liners combined yesterday to take the edge off the reception here for the Grace Line's new Santa Paula.
The New Yorker returning from a summer vacation spent in the tranquillity of rolling countryside or beside a pounding surf often sees his city with a clearer, less jaded eye.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission exploded a nuclear device suspended from a balloon 1,500 feet over Yucca Flat today. The flash was visible in pre-dawn skies in San Francisco, 500 miles away.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court rejected today a petition of the Tuscarora Indians for review of a decision involving condemnation of tribal land in New York State for the $625,000,000 Niagara Falls power project.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany, charged here today that it was the Republicans and not the Democrats in New York who were boss-controlled.

FULTON, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- District Attorney Frank S. Hogan assured the North Country today of his support for the public operation of power projects, the development of natural resources and the small farmer.

PETER LIND HAYES started a variety attraction yesterday -- 11:30 A. M. to 12:30 P. M., Monday through Fridays, over Channel 7 -- and all signs suggest he may have a daytime success. His program is burdened by an unconscionable number of commercials, even if they are permitted by the industry code, but his dry wit and impromptu nonsense helped make them more bearable.
A loan of $3,000,000 to a private company producing paper in Israel was announced yesterday by the Export-Import Bank.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 13 -- Classes started in special schools today for 145 white high school students here. This was six weeks after the students were to have begun the fall term at Little Rock's public schools.
The Order of the Eastern Star, State of New York, the women's auxiliary of the Masonic Order, gave a testimonial dinner last night for its two principal officers, who are retiring.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -Following is the text of President Eisenhower's remarks today at a Georgetown University ceremony dedicating the Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service:

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon accused the Democrats tonight of offering the voters the "same defensive, defeatist, fuzzyheaded" foreign policy program that had led to "retreat, appeasement and war" during the Truman Administration.

The New York Giants will not be at full strength Sunday at the Yankee Stadium for their National Football League home opener against the Chicago Cardinals. Roosevelt Grier, the huge defensive tackle, who missed the game with the Redskins at Washington last Sunday, yesterday was ruled out as a possible starter against the Chicagoans by Dr. Francis J. Sweeny, the team physician.

NEWARK, Oct. 13 -- The state board of the Americans for Democratic Action has endorsed Harrison Williams, a Democrat, for United States Senator. This was announced today by Sidney Weinstein, the state chairman.
More than 1,500 persons thronged into St. James Pro-Cathedral in Brooklyn yesterday for a solemn pontifical mass of requiem for Pope Pius XII.

Contracts are being drawn for Otto Preminger to produce and direct Ira Levin's next play, "General Seeger." The authority for this statement is Mr. Levin, who was responsible for the successful adaptation of Mac Hyman's book, "No Time for Sergeants."
The New York Heart Association opened a campaign for 50,000 fund-drive volunteers yesterday. The appeal was supported by Mabel Chin, the 4-year-old child whose heart surgery was televised recently.
ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP) -Relman Morin, winner of two Pulitzer prizes for news reporting, said today that America's most serious problem was the "general apathy of our people."

COOLER weather brings a revival of interest in smoked pork. Two small cuts with the same rich, smoky flavor of ham are the smoked picnic (the lower section of the shoulder or the foreleg, which weighs from four to seven pounds) and the boneless butt. The latter weighs up to four pounds.

Investors started the week with optimism yesterday and stocks rose to new highs for the year, before a reaction came in the final hour of trading. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange increased by about $1,100,000,000.

Despite all its vigor, stock market activity has not kept pace with the growth of the economy. Between 1950 and 1957 the gross national product, or output of goods and services, rose 28 per cent. The New York Stock Exchange figures that if the volume of trading had increased at the same rate, activity this year should have averaged better than 5,000,000 shares a day.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and The Texas Company, makers of Texaco, are negotiating a proposed $4,500,000 television program deal that would consist of eleven special one-hour shows plus sponsorship of the Cotton Bowl football game.

THE Design Center for Interiors began its fourth week in business yesterday by greeting more than 2,000 visitors. The building, which houses home furnishings exhibits, is at 415 East Fifty-third Street. Admission is free.

Imagine a bowling establishment running at full capacity at 9 A. M. and continuing to do business on each of its lanes until closing at least five days a week. Such are the things of which proprietors dream.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Office of Civilian and Defense Mobilization opened its first cases today under the newly toughened "national security" clause of the Reciprocal Trade Act.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 -- The Central Bank of Argentina removed pharmaceuticals from the preferential exchange list and threw them on the free market today. The prices of many drugs will probably double or triple, an industry source said.

Federal safety regulations to protect shipyard workers against hazards of atomic radiation were urged yesterday by John J. Grogan, Mayor of Hoboken N. J., and president of the Independent Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -United States officials emphasized today that Washington would not put pressure on the Chinese Nationalists to reduce their forces on Quemoy.

Mrs. Charles W. Lewis of 1158 Fifth Avenue, chairman of the dinner dance for the York!ville Community Association, has invited members of her committee to a luncheon tomorrow. in her home. They will inill'e plans for the fete, which will be held on Jan. 23 at the Plaza. . I ,.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The more the political pulse of the American voter is palpated for 1958 Election Day symptoms, the greater the agreement among the pulsetakers that the Democrats will win a sweeping victory in November -for seats in Congress and for state and local officials.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 13 -There was only one brief occasion for a ripple of laughter in the crowded Assize Court here this morning.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A record balance of payments surplus for the first half of this year and the sustained advance on Wall Street encouraged strong demand in the stockmarket today. Prices improved on a wide front, although some shares closed below their best.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Eisenhower suggested today that it was more important to the future of America to understand that "the world is a single entity" than to fear the effects of some competitive import on the nation's economy.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 13 -- A Wild West adventure of Indians and white men, such as the movies and television show daily, came to perilous life for a group of United States oil men in the desolate North Chaco area of Paraguay this week-end.

BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Oct. 13 -- Arthur T. McGonigle, Republican candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania, took issue today with a report in The New York Times forecasting that he would lose in the Nov. 4 election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Union of South Africa was attacked bitterly in two debates here today. In one it was accused of persecuting native tribesmen; in the other it was charged with unjustly maintaining jurisdiction over the neighboring territory of South-West Africa.
Alex Rose, vice chairman of the Liberal party, predicted Governor Harriman's re-election last night and said that "the Liberal party vote will provide the margin of his victory as it did in 1954."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- Neil H. McElroy, United States Secretary of Defense, met with President Chiang Kaishek yesterday amid reports that the American official was seeking a new formula for settlement of the Quemoy crisis.
HAVANA, Oct. 13 -- Rebels and Government troops fought a skirmish yesterday on the outskirts of Santiago de Cuba, the capital of Oriente Province, according to travelers arriving here today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Warner Willcox, who sailed Stardust to the International Class Yacht Racing Association Championship this year, won four of five races with his bluehulled sloop off Larchmont Y. C. today.

Heavy grain loadings and a general increase in freight movements pushed September revenues and earnings of the Great Northern Railway above the levels of a year earlier, John M. Budd, president, reported yesterday.
EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., Oct. 13 -- Supervision of children's parties has become a happy means toward a desirable end for two enterprising 14year-old business women who want to go to Europe.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller carried his campaign tonight into an area where Republicans were fighting desperately to retain a once-assured seat in the House of Representatives.

YONKERS, Oct. 13 -- Shadow Wave, with Joe O'Brien driving, heads the favored 6-to-5 S. A. Camp Farm entry in the $60,457 Cane Pace tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway. Ten horses are slated to go in the event at one mile and a sixteenth.

West Germany endangered the chances of the United States yesterday in the third round of the international team chess finals at Munich. According to a report from Germany, the Germans held a lead of 1 1/2 -- 1/2, with two games adjourned.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 13 -The contrast between the need of Washington and the need of the people outside the capital is startling. At no time since President Eisenhower entered the White House has he been under more severe attack in Washington on the issues of foreign policy and Presidential leadership, but one hears very little criticism or even discussions of these issues in the area between the Appalachians and the Rockies.
Senator Prescott Bush said yesterday that unless state governments participated substantially in underwriting the public costs of urban renewal, "the program faces an extremely uncertain future."

The pillbox hat is heading into fashion importance for late day and evening. This tidy square shape is being designed in velvet, satin and feathers. It can be starkly plain or decorated with shimmering beads, braid, flowers or tulle.

German schemes for espionage are told by Charles Weighton and Gunter Peis in "Hitler's Spies and Saboteurs." The book is based on a diary kept between 1939 and 1943 by Gen. Erwin von Lahousen, right-hand man to the German Secret Service Chief, Admiral Wilhelm Canaris.
DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Air Force has grounded all its 230 C-123 troop-cargo planes similar to one that crashed in Idaho and killed nineteen persons Thursday night.
Encouraging results in the treatment and prevention of strokes through the use of anticoagulant drugs were reported yesterday at the New York Academy of Medicine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Federal Trade. Commission announced today it would investigate the nation's big grocery chains and their suppliers.

The Arkansas Gazette will receive the 1958 Freedom Award of Freedom House at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel tonight. The award will go to the newspaper for its "support of law and order" in the crisis over school integration at Little Rock, Ark.
PRINCETON, IN. J., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Physicians had good news for Princeton today. The injured first-string tailback, Dan Sachs, may be back in three or four weeks.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- The natural gas industry was told here today that "unified action is absolutely essential" to its future.

On Sept. 29 a letter was published from Ben R. Miller on "Choosing the Federal Judiciary," which referred, in part, "to the procedure and effectiveness of the liaison" between the Attorney General of the United States and the Standing Committee on Federal Judiciary of the American Bar Association in the matter of nomination of Federal judges.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review the conviction of Col. Rudolf Ivanovich Abel as a Soviet spy.
ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A total of 502 New York communities have adopted bingo, Judge Richards W. Hannah reported today.

A stock market "virtually powerless" to moderate its rise threatens to weaken the public's inclination to save, William A. Lyon, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, warned yesterday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 13 -Kansas voters are showing an apparent apathy over the campaign for the election of a Governor, other state officers, six Congressmen, and 125 State Representatives. There are no Senatorial contests this year, either for Congress or for the Legislature.
HAVANA, Oct. 13 (AP) -Fidel Castro, the rebel leader, threatened today to kill all candidates in Cuba's Nov. 3 general election unless they withdrew by Oct. 30.
Construction of the $150 000,000 Elizabeth - Port Authority Piers will begin tomorrow. Gov. Robert B. Meyner will participate in the televised ceremonies.

The Da-Po Craft Company, Dayton, Ohio, manufacturer of transistor radios, was honored by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The company reported net income of $105.09 on sales of $2,908.17 in 1957. Its sales manager is 17 years old.

A cocktail party and preview of an exhibition of original covers from The New Yorker magazine for three decades will be held on Oct. 28 in the City Center Gallery, City Center of Music and Drama, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street. The gallery will be the beneficiary of the event, for which Mrs. Basil Lermont is chairman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- American scientists successfully fired five rockets as high as 150 miles above the earth yesterday during the total eclipse of the sun in the South Pacific, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a case in which a broadcasting station that gave a political candidate air time in accordance with Federal law was held to be not responsible for the candidate's libelous remarks.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 8 -Latin America's leading rayon producers met today with suppliers to consider ways of improving the quality of their product and increase its use in the area.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Boeing 707 jet airliner won provisional permission today to use London Airport from the Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation after undergoing the ministry's noise tests.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States, Henry Stump Middendorf Jr., Milton Black and James Thomas Tilt, all of New York, among others, were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:
NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Congressional contest in the Twenty-eighth District appears unequal.
DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Officials of the 2,400,000member United Lutheran Church in America delayed until Wednesday a vote on a proposed merger with three smaller Lutheran churches.
A tour of the kitchens of some prominent New York residents will be held on the afternoons of Nov. 18 and 19.

Operators of small hotels here protested yesterday against a campaign by the State Rent Commission to revoke their hotel classification. Such revocations return the buildings to a rooming-house status and put them back under rent control.
A rainy and cold harvesting season this year in Siberia appears to have dimmed Soviet hopes of gathering a record grain crop in 1958.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Deerfield Academy's thirty-five game unbeaten streak was ended by Vermont Academy nine days ago but the Big Green squad as well as student body have taken the reversal in stride. The players have lost none of their interest and the students have lost none of their enthusiasm.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (UPI) -The Army's forthcoming moon shot will have slightly more ground control than the Air Force Pioneer.
A PROVOCATIVE new String Quartet by Andrew Imbrie began this season's concert series by the Fine Arts Quartet last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
The new General Motors management team expressed optimism yesterday on the strength of the 1959 automobile market -- but with mildly different forecasts.

ATHENS, Oct. 13 -- Archbishop Makarios announced today that he was prepared to agree to a seven-year period of self-government leading to independence for Cyprus. The announcement was made here in a news conference with a group of foreign journalists.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz will be the speaker Friday evening at the twentyfifth anniversary dinnerdance of the New York Metropolitan chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- This center of a world creed, normally a busy metropolis, appeared strangely deserted this afternoon. Mournful chants accompanying the burial of Pope Pius XII in St. Peter's Basilica wafted from open windows throughout the city.

The recent action by Congress in doubling the amount of money asked by President Eisenhower this year for our rural libraries will probably be doubly appreciated by those Americans who live hundreds of miles from the nearest large town and thousands of miles from Greater New York, where there are eighty branch libraries and always thousands of books ready to be borrowed.

ALDERSHOT, England, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Nicolai Tatarinov, 30, a captain in the Soviet Air Force, gave the favored Russians a good start in the world modern pentathlon championship today by winning the cross-country riding event which opened the five-day meet.

A study program to improve what it called the "deplorable cure rates" for lung cancer was announced here yesterday by the American Cancer Society. The program will start in November in association with the Veterans Administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -The Mexican and United States riders tonight put more pressure on the undefeated Germans in the international jumping of the Washington-International horse show.
A CHERRYWOOD chest-onchest that could do a living room or a bedroom proud is easily the most distinguished and the most expensive piece of furniture at the New York Antiques Fair.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review Government efforts to prosecute Frank Brewster, former Western chief of the Teamsters Union, and Nugent La Poma, an officer in Seattle Teamsters Local 174, on charges of contempt of Congress.

Allow me to reply to a letter recently published by you written by Eugene H. Lehman, president emeritus of Monmouth College, in which he states that Northern colleges practice and foster racial segregation and therefore should not criticize the South for its segregation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -Chief Justice Earl Warren read a tribute to Justice Harold H. Burton of Ohio at today's session of the Supreme Court. Justice Burton retired at tile close of business today. His successor, Potter Stewart of Ohio, will be sworn in tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, announced today that oil production on certain Indian and Federal leases in the Aneth area of southeastern Utah's Navaho reservation would be suspended Nov. 10.

That respected civic organization, the League of Women Voters, which performs so ably, diligently and impartially its function of bringing the citizen and his government closer together in understanding, is now asking a little help in return. Over the country there are now more than 1,000 leagues. It is of the league in New York City, with twenty-one branches serving the five boroughs, that we speak a word today.
Time has brought many changes at Kingsborough Houses in Brooklyn since the nights when tenant vigilantes patrolled the sapling-lined walks, clubs in hand, to repel hoodlums from the surrounding slum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers today endorsed forty-six Democrats, eight Republicans and an Independent running for Congress in twenty states. The union withheld endorsement in one of the two Senatorial races in West Virginia, the biggest coal producing state.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 13 -A member of the Brazilian Communist party, running under the guise of a Labor party candidate, has been elected to the federal Chamber of Deputies.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The only film theatre here will close its doors Wednesday night because of box office losses resulting from a sixmonth ban placed against the theatre by a Roman Catholic Church.
Monticello, the museum at Charlottesville, Va., that was once Thomas Jefferson's home, is again displaying a long-absent work of art.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- For the first time since the beginning of the century and possibly earlier, Britain has been able to report a surplus in her exportimport trade.
CAIRO, Oct. 13 -- The Council of the League of Arab States unanimously dissociated itself today from Tunisia's charges that the United Arab Republic dominated the league.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The North Atlantic Council made modest progress today in whittling away obstacles to a conference to seek solution of the BritishGreek-Turkish dispute over Cyprus.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- An inexpensive device said to raise the message-carrying capacity of telephone cables twelve fold was shown at a convention of the United States Independent Telephone Association here today.

In The Times for Oct. 6 Henry C. Wolfe cast doubt on the accuracy of Michael James' reports from Algeria. As one who has followed the situation in that war-torn country rather closely, I think the James dispatches are quite factual.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -West Virginia's two Republican Senators, Chapman Revercomb and John D. Hoblitzell Jr., said after visiting President Eisenbower today that they thought he might visit their state before the November elections.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- Pope Pius XII was laid to rest this evening in the crypt of St. Peter's Basilica. The services were attended by all the pomp and ceremony marking the burial service of a Sovereign Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today dismissed an appeal by John Steinbeck challenging the constitutionality of the gross receipts tax of New York City as it applies to writers.

The news that WOR would televise Public Schools Athletic League football games along with others in the metropolitan area this season was a surprise to Dr. John J. Theobald, the new superintendent of the city school system.
RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 13 -The secretary general of the Moroccan Communist party has been arrested for a breach of immigration law, a Government spokesman confirmed tonight.
Sales and earnings of the H. K. Porter Company for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, fell substantially from those of a year ago, the diversified industrial producer reported yesterday.
Yesterday was a holiday for schools, banks and city and state employes because Columbus Day, Oct. 12, fell on Sunday this year.

Only the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Produce Exchange were open among future's markets here yesterday. Trading in cotton, wool, cocoa, coffee, sugar, rubber, hides and metals was suspended in observance of Columbus Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13--William C. Foster, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, will head the three-man United States delegation to technical East-West talks in Geneva on means of preventing surprise attack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower's representatives would leave here Friday and arrive in Rome Saturday for the solemn requiem mass for Pope Plus XII in St. Peter's Basilica next Monday.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The auto industry s' effort to step up 1959 model output still is hampered by work stoppages and parts shortages.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 -The Air Force has been authorized to launch two space probes in addition to the three lunar shots originally assigned it last spring, informed sources revealed today.

Nearly every member of the armed forces is in a sense, a displaced person. He is away from his home community and for the most part away from his family, whether he serves in this country, overseas or afloat.
A new upsurge in Soviet steel production is taking place this year, the latest Soviet economic data indicate.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 14 (AP) -- The bus segregation law was repealed today by the City Commission.

The twelve-story apartment house at 2 Pierrepont Street overlooking the East River in Brooklyn has been purchased by Benson Asban, realty investors. The deal was negotiated by the David Jaret Corporation, broker. The building, on a plot 42 by 100 feet, was sold for cash over a mortgage of $320,000. Harry Lowenbaum and Vito J. Guaraglia were the sellers. The property is assessed at $580,000.
TUNIS, Oct. 14 (Reuters)--Foreign Minister Sadok Mokkadem said tonight his Government was studying whether to break diplomatic relations with the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A "ready grin" in the face of adversity and avoidance of "family fights" were prescribed by President Eisenhower today as the essentials of a Republican victory in next month's elections.
ROME, Oct. 14 -- Thousands filed through the crypt of St. Peter's today to pray before the grave of Pope Plus XII.
The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a sharp drop in sales for the third quarter. Profits were nearly 57 per cent below those for the 1957 period.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Britain's exports dropped and her imports increased slightly in September, producing a gap of 59,900,000 ($167,920,000), Board of Trade figures showed today.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The Government proposed today a new national old-age pension plan with graduated contributions and pensions linked to the level of earnings.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 -- The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals begins deliberation tomorrow on a case that may decide the fate of plans by some Southern states to turn over public schools to private groups for operation on a segregated basis.

It was moving day at Junior High School 159 in East Harlem yesterday and a parade of youngsters carried chairs, books, globes, baskets and plants from the sixty-year-old building to a new $4,000,000 structure about a block and a half away.
Traffic deaths in the city totaled ten last week, compared with thirteen in the same period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.
JOAN CRAWFORD, long a holdout from television, made an appearance on the "Bob Hope Show" over Channel 4 last night.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Industrial stocks scored widespread gains here today. The record balance of payments, Wall Street's further improvement on Monday and evidence of a recovery in United States business were reelected in higher prices.
SOUTH, POINT, Hawaii, Oct. 14 -- This radio tracking station, at the southernmost tip of the Hawaiian Islands, "saw" the Pioneer moon-probe vehicle plunge back into the earth's atmosphere.

HAVANA, Oct. 14 -- All candidates in the elections scheduled for Nov. 3 will be disqualified for elective or appointive government posts during the next thirty years, Fidel Castro, the rebel leader, has declared, according to the rebel radio heard in Havana last night.

Two Negro leaders who have been active in the Liberal party announced yesterday that they were organizing a committee to aid Peter J. Crotty, the Democratic candidate for State Attorney General.

WHEN James Francis Byrnes was 14 years old he went to work in a Charleston lawyer's office to help support his widowed mother. That was a long time ago. Mr. Byrnes is 79 now and retired with a collection of well-earned laurels unique in the history of American public life.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Throughout history armies have attempted to play politics. Both in imperial Rome and Byzantium it was the army that generally acted as emperor-maker and emperor-breaker. The price of lead was advanced a half-cent a pound yesterday, to 13 cents -- the fifth increase in less than a month.
Australia's triumph in the first world amateur golf tourney was hailed yesterday as "healthy for the sport" by Charley Coe, the United States champion, as he reached here from Scotland.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- Marlon Brando will introduce a new actress from Mexico as his leading lady in "One-Eyed Jacks." Her name is Pina Pelliecer. She speaks English haltingly, but that will not present any problem in the picture because she is supposed to be a native Mexican.

THE third of the great French troupes to come to America arrived at the Broadway Theatre last night and, commendably not waiting for the inevitable latecomers, swiftly transformed its stage into g gaudy but solemn pageant out of Renaissance Italy.

POMEGRANATES, one of the world's most ancient fruits, are in season. From now through the end of January, the reddish, leathery-rinded specimens will be available in certain outlets here.
