With the installation of the goal posts and the covering of the diamond with 13,500 square feet of grass transported from Huntington, L.I., the annual transformation of Yankee Stadium from a baseball to a football arena was completed yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Scientists have immunized mice against a form of cancer with X-rayed cancer cells.

A syndicate of New York investors consisting of Ira M. Belfer, Mark Bogart, David Rudin and Jules Teret has purchased the Colt Industrial Park in Hartford, Conn., for $3,500,000. Mr. Belfer said the purchase represented the first industrial realty syndication to be registered with the Securities Exchange Commission. The B. B. Holding Corporation was the seller.
The Board of Higher Education announced yesterday that a committee of six board members had been appointed to investigate charges of discrimination at Queens College.
ROME, Oct. 14--The chief physician of Pope Pius XII said today that the remains of the Pontiff were embalmed in much the same manner as had been Jesus Christ's body.
Ten new split-level coaches and three lounge cars have been delivered by the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company to the Chicago and North Western Railway Company, it was announced yesterday.

ALGIERS, Oct. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Jacques Massu, leader of the All-Algeria Committee of Public Safety, walked out of that body today in obedience to orders from Premier Charles de Gaulle. Eleven other French officers left with him.

The current investigation into quiz show practices and attendant adverse publicity will not hinder an old show from bouncing back out of retirement. It is "College Quiz Bowl," which features undergraduates competing for cash prizes that go to scholarship funds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The United States suggested today that it would be in the "best interest" of the United Nations if Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was persuaded to accept help in handling administrative and financial matters.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14--President Eisenhower led official and diplomatic Washington today in a farewell tribute to Pope Pius XII at a pontifical requiem mass in St. Matthew's Cathedral here.
A new plan to reorganize the courts of New York State was recommended yesterday by the League of Women Voters.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- Many of the problems facing the gas industry can be traced to a lack of success in getting its story across to the public, it was held here today.
AURORA, Ill., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Mayor Paul Egan was arrested tonight as he called on a mass meeting to "restore law and order."
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Governor Harriman today compared the Republican convention that nominated the state-wide ticket to the autocratic rule of the Supreme Soviet (Parliament).
Three stowaways, all discovered aboard ships operating to Europe, were back on this side of the Atlantic yesterday.
ALDERSHOT, England, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The defending champion, Igor Novikov of the Soviet Union, gained his second straight fencing title at the world pentathlon championship today.
A billion-dollar redevelopment scheme for lower Manhattan was presented in broad outline yesterday at City Hall.
A HAIR stylist who claims more firsts than the United States Patent Office lists has just arrived in Manhattan to introduce additional coiffure innovations.
RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 14 -- Gov. Luther H. Hodges made clear today that his attorney general had not been speaking for him in recent statements concerning school integration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture increased sugar quotas today for the domestic market another 100,000 tons in a move to check an advance in prices.

THE housewares department at Altman's has gone cosmopolitan with its current show, "World of Hospitality," which will be on view through Oct. 25. Not only are all sorts of new pieces from all over the world on display, but food, representative of the various countries, such as Swiss fondue and French onion soup, is being demonstrated and served by cooks in native costumes.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -Henry Cooper, an unheralded Cockney plasterer, tonight won an upset ten-round decision from Zora Folley, America's top ranking heavyweight contender.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The Government said today that it would appeal a Customs Court ruling limiting the President's power to set tariffs or import quotas.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- The Sacred College of Cardinals, in the words of its lean, is praying to God "to grant promptly to His Church, the Supreme Pastor of whom she stands in need in the great hours in which the world is at present living."
MUTTERING softly to himself in French, M'sieu Philippe Henri Watson pored over his statistical charts yesterday and then flung a pencil on his desk.

Following is the text of the recommendations submitted yesterday to Mayor Wagner and Borough President Hulan E. Jack by the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, Inc. References are made to maps that also are printed on this page:

Five members of the Junior League of the City of New York have been chosen as candidates for queen of the league's annual Mardi Gras Ball. The fete, a benefit for the Welfare Trust Fund of the organization, will be held in the Astor on Feb. 6.

Some of the suburbs, specifically those rustic Utopias wanly classified by weather forecasters as "the outlying suburbs," have had their first frost. Well, it was bound to happen one night, and perhaps better sooner than later.
NEWARK, Oct. 14 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, campaigned quietly today in Essex County.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Diplomatic sources here suggested today that the Communist Chinese Government did not now intend, and probably never did intend, to take the Quemoy and Matsu islands by force.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- An organization backing separation of church and state contended today that American Cardinals who vote for a new Roman Catholic Pope will be voiding their United States citizenship.
The Citizens Union yesterday urged a yes vote on four housing proposals that will appear on the top line of voting machines on Nov. 4. These are Amendment 2 and Propositions 1, 2 and 3.

ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 14 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for the Senate, said here tonight that if he was elected he would visit Southern cities to make a personal investigation of the recent bombings there.
A plan to combat juvenile delinquency by developing means of aiding youngsters before they become involved in serious trouble was outlined yesterday by General Sessions Judge Irwin D. Davidson.
An off-duty policeman shot and wounded a robbery suspect in a gun fight early today. A companion of the suspect escaped, the police reported. The shooting followed the hold up of a West Side tavern.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- In the Supreme Court of the United States, Jack Hart and Myron Engelman of New York, N. Y., among others, were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

Possibly a little wearied after eight days of climbing, the stock market fell yesterday. The loss in The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks was the widest since June 19 and trading was the heaviest in three years.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Premier Nu said today the amnesty he offered to Burmese Communist insurgents last June would be withdrawn Oct. 31.

TRENDS in appliance buying for the home were presented recently at a press preview of Frigidaire's 1959 line of products. The preview was held at the General Motors Training Center in Tarrytown, N. Y.

GINGER ROGERS, who did so nicely last season in a number of guest appearances, received her reward last night: her own special program over Channel 2. Looking radiant, she headed a show that was a little erratic in quality but boasted enough style to suggest that she is re-winning her place in the Hollywood firmament.

At Arden House the fourteenth American Assembly begins today a three-day intensive roundtable discussion of a subject that is currently the center of nation-wide public interest. That is the subject of monetary policy.
The J. I. Case Company, manufacturer of farm machinery, is offering today $20,130,400 of 5 1/2 per cent subordinated convertible debentures, due 1983, to its stockholders for subscription at par.

PARIS, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- The Permanent Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization again postponed consideration of the Cyprus question today when Greece asked for more time to consider the plan for a round-table discussion.
ATLANTA, Oct. 15 -- The police raided the homes of four known anti-Semites today to search for evidence connected with Sunday's dynamite-blasting of a Jewish temple here.

Representatives of the Central Park Zoo expressed pleasure yesterday that one of their visitors would be spending her spare time henceforth at the Bronx Zoo. That was one condition ordered by Magistrate A. Lawrence Acquavella in Special Sessions Court when he discharged Miss Yetta Klausner in her own recognizance.

The New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday suspended the owner, driver-trainer and groom of Widower Creed because the horse's saliva showed the presence of a drug after he finished third in the $50,000 Trans-America Pace at Yonkers Raceway on Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The utility room definitely will be a part of new houses in the near future, if the Woman's Conference on Housing has as much effect on the building industry as it has had in the last two years.
An atomic power plant that will serve the area between Naples and Rome will be built by the General Electric Company.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle calmly fended off an offensive by ultra-colonialist elements in Algeria today and counter-attacked in defense of his program for free elections there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A safer sulfonamide compound was announced today at the annual antibiotic symposium. It is called Madribon or sulfadi-methotine.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Doug Ford, playing out of the Paradise Club, Crystal Beach, Fla., and Pat Iannicelli, Harrison, scored a one-stroke victory in the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur tournament with a best-ball 32, 33 -- 65 at Round Hill today.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- The last words of Pope Pius XII in public were an exhortation to found justice on Christian love of man. Twenty-two hours after he said this, the Pope suffered the first of two cerebral strokes that led to his death last Thursday.
The election of three new officers was announced yesterday by the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
How did the Rangers look last night in their home debut at Madison Square Garden?

BRIGHTLY woven textiles of the French Directoire and Empire periods are now on view at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 57 East Fifty-seventh Street. Shimmering silks woven in satin, damask, lampas and velvet are all over the place.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- The United States will send a delegation to Geneva Oct. 31 with a "determination to reach an equitable and lasting agreement" on the testing of atomic weapons, Henry Cabot Lodge said today.
The City's Board of Education has applied to the State Education Department for $325,000 in special aid to improve schools for pupils who are disciplinary problems.
ALBANY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The three major automobile manufacturing companies have asked for legislation to prohibit the sale in New York State of brake fluid that has a low boiling point.

One of the most powerful leaders of New York's waterfront industries charged last night that the Waterfront Commission had failed to make a promised reduction in the magnitude of its operations. The agency is entirely supported by a tax on the port's waterfront employers.
Press Wireless, Inc. has asked for official approval to set up an outer-space communications service whenever manned satellites, space platforms or space expeditions are launched.

MONTREAL, Oct. 15 (AP) -Fast and elusive Ralph Dupas of New Orleans jabbed and slashed his way to a one-sided decision over Gil Turner of Philadelphia in a ten-round bout tonight, Dupas weighed 144 1/2 pounds, Turner 152.

TOKYO, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Ken Venturi of San Francisco shot a par 72 today and tied two Japanese players for first place in the first round of Japan's open golf championship on the Tokyo Country Club's 6,800-yard course.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 15 -- The gas industry is preparing an accelerated fight to capture the home appliances market.

ST. LOUIS, Oct, 15 -- The Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals extended a preliminary injunction to prohibit the Little Rock school board from leasing the city's four high schools to a private corporation.

A ten-month scientific cruise seeking a solution to some of the mysteries of an ancient waterway that once seperated North and South America gets under way tomorrow aboard Columbia University's research vessel, Vema.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- The United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency issued what was essentially a final report today.

CLAYTON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican candidate for the United States Senate, said today that his Democratic opponent was taking the "wrong approach" on Federal aid for school construction.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- The Tunisian delegation here insisted today that diplomatic relations with the United Arab Republic had not been broken.
Three top-level changes in editorial staffs were announced yesterday at Good Housekeeping and Redbook magazines.

Four important state offices besides the Governorship are to be filled by New York's voters on Nov. 4. Other things being equal, we would ordinarily feel that a Governor was entitled to men of his own party in these posts, making up the governing team. Since we are supporting Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor, we would thus on this account alone advise the election of Republicans for the other state offices.
ALGIERS, Oct. 15 -- The right-wing movement of the Committees of Public Safety appeared to be collapsing here tonight in the face of loyalty by the army to Premier Charles de Gaulle.
Foster homes for seven deaf children are being sought as the New York Catholic Charities opens a campaign for homes for handicapped children.

There is a constant numbers game in process in this city and its suburbs, involving not bets but chance meetings. It is a lottery whose ingredients are times, places and multitudes of people. Every commuter with any tenure has had the experience of accidentally falling in with an acquaintance two or three days in succession at a station or in a concourse after not having seen him for months.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Universal Match Corporation disclosed today plans to purchase the remaining 50 per cent of the voting common stock in National Rejectors, Inc., said to be the country's largest manufacturer of coin mechanisms.
South Carolina borrowed $13,000,000 yesterday to finance school construction. The money was raised by the sale of bonds maturing serially from 1959 to 1978, at an interest cost of 3.0616 per cent.

I returned recently from a two-and-a-half-month journey through Latin America and am persuaded that we harbor some misconceptions of attitudes in this part of the world which it would be worth our while to correct.

GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- The outlook for tariff reductions in the next few years will be discussed here tomorrow by ministers from a dozen nations. The subject also will dom inate the meeting beginning Monday of the thirty-seven nations subscribing to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

Many persons have subscribed for the anniversary cocktail dance to be held Nov. 13 in the Pierre ballroom. The Children's Health Service, founded eighty-five years ago by the New York Diet Kitchen Association, will benefit from the fete.
A Department of Commerce official predicted yesterday that economic conditions would continue to improve in 1959.
WARSAW, Oct. 15 -- Poland's Communist leaders began a meeting today that is expected to strengthen the control of Wladyslaw Gomulka over the party.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 15 -- The first of about 90,000 piles was driven yesterday to mark the official start of construction of the $150,000,000 Elizabeth-Port Authority piers.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 15 -- The triennial general convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church elected two bishops here today.
WELLINGTON, N. Z., Thursday, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- Six persons were killed and seven injured when a United States Navy Globemaster plane crashed early today near Cape Hallett in Antarctica.

Casey Stengel yesterday signed his sixth two-year contract to pilot the world champion Yankees. He did it in the plushiest setting for any Yankee signing -- the Crystal Room of the Savoy Hilton Hotel -- where the Yankees held their victory party last Sunday night.

RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- The Burmese Defense Ministry named eight men today to serve as Ministers in the caretaker government of Gen. Ne Win, Army Chief of Staff, when he takes power Oct. 28.

The Great Western Financial Corporation, California savings and loan association holding company, reported earnings yesterday of $4,196,485, or $6.29 a share for the first nine months of 1958. This compares with $4,218,616, or $6.64 a share in the 1957 period.
WHEN it comes to an orchestra Fritz Reiner master builder. In the five years that he has been music director of the Chicago Symphony he has turned it one of the finest in the land.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Bob Kiphuth, Yale's world - renowned swimming coach, will retire from the post he has held for forty years when he reaches the mandatory retirement age of 68 on Nov. 17.

Events tonight: "Carmen," City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein conducting, Van Cliburn, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Nico Castel, tenor, and Vasco Barbosa, violinist, Town Hall, 8:30; Fine Arts Quartet, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Julio Braga, pianist, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8.
A GIANT oak loom in the sixth-floor Men's Shop at Sak's Fifth Avenue is causing such a stir that the allure of top coats, sports jackets and cigars has been temporarily supplanted.

At a tea held yesterday by the women's benefit committee of Big Brothers, Inc., at the organization's headquarters, plans were formulated for the annual Christmas theatre benefit. Mrs. John Bassett Place was chairman of the tea.

BOTH cabbages and kings are served by Jean Marrase. As executive chef of the United Nations kitchens, his customers range in status from casual tourists to official delegates and heads of state. His menus vary from unpretentious salads, including cole slaw, to the sophisticated saffron-tinted fish stew called bouillabaisse.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -- The engineers who fashion new airplanes for North American Aviation are directed by a slim, pleasant-looking man who is likely to brush aside technical road-blocks by telling subordinates:
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- Leading maritime authorities are exploring one of the most critical problems faced by the industry in many years.
The New York Central Building, a thirty-four-story office landmark astride Park Avenue between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets, has been leased by the railroad to an investor.
The superliner United States will start on her second million miles of trans-Atlantic voyaging today when she sails at noon for Channel ports and Bremerhaven.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A new dispute over the Army's vast arsenal system appeared to be developing today as part of the reorganization of the Government's space program.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 15 -- Lincoln's Birthday and Columbus Day, traditional school holidays in New York City and elsewhere, will be regular school days in the Great neck public schools next year.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that Republican candidates faced "inevitable defeat" this year if they refused to hit back against Democratic attacks on foreign and domestic policy.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- A new state socialinsurance program to protect every wage-earner against the danger of sudden catastrophic medical expense was proposed today by Nelson A. Rockefeller.
Carmine G. De Sapio proposed yesterday that free television and radio time be granted to political parties for one month before a general election.
Members of the diplomatic corps, representatives at the United Nations and city officials attended a solemn pontifical mass of requiem for Pope Pius XII yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Three major housing developments to cost more than $82,000,000 were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The stock market lost some of its buoyancy today. The mild setback was ascribed to news of the widening of the trade gap in September, and Wall Street's weakness yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Argentine Ambassador disclosed today the major details of a proposed $800,000,000 deal with a group of American interests to develop the oil and gas resources of his country.
Upton Sinclair, honored here last night on his recent eight-eith birthday, said: "Every time there is a boom, we have a little reaction; then comes a bust, and we make a lot of social progress."

" In these times of uneasy peace, the U. S. O. is more important than ever to the individual serving his country in uniform." This quotation is from a letter sent by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Nathan F. Twining, to the national president of U. S. O., Holgar J. Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -President Eisenhower did not seem disturbed today by criticism of his military strategy in World War II that appeared in published excerpts of the memoirs of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery.

Custom smelters raised the price of refined copper 1 cent a pound to 28 1/2 cents yesterday, reflecting continued brisk demand. The major mine producers advanced their price 1 cent to 27 1/2 cents a few days ago.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following programs as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

Hospitals "sick" with staphylococcal infections can be cleaned up if their doctors and nurses recognize the problem and take steps to control the spread of new infections, a surgeon said here last night.

The twelve-story store and office building at 198 Broadway between Fulton and John Streets has been sold by the estate of Elias Cohen to Morris Karp and Bernard Sanford, realty investors operating under the name of the Realty Equities Corporation of New York.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, denied yesterday that science and mathematics were being neglected in the high schools.

The ambition of President Nasser of predominantly non-Arab Egypt to build for himself an Arab empire stretching from the Atlantic to the Persian Gulf has suffered the worst setback to date owing to a development which seems bound to have wide repercussions throughout the Arab world. This development is Tunisia's startling break in diplomatic relations with Nasser and its virtual walkout from the Arab League, which it joined only fifteen days ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Susan Hayward will star in "The Snow Birch," based on a novel of the Canadian North Woods by John Mantley, as one of the six pictures remaining on her contract with Twentieth Century-Fox.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The Federal Government was urged here tonight to establish an awards system patterned after the Nobel prizes, to spur scientific and engineering advancement in this country.
The Columbia Broadcasting System's hopes for a $4,500,000 program sale to the Texas Company vanished yesterday when negotiations were broken off.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -The X-15 rocket ship, built to carry man twice as fast and more than four times as high as he has ever gone, was rolled from the factory today.
ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Governor Harriman disparaged today the political authority of Carmine De Sapio, head of Tammany Hall.
The United States chess team gained 4 1/2 points in the international team tournament in Munich, according to a report from Germany yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee laid the groundwork today for a year-long, global study aimed at helping shape the foreign policy of the United States.

Stocks tried to rally yesterday morning but failed. The failure, visible before the trading day was more than an hour old, brought a surge of selling on a broad front and lowered market values on the New York Stock Exchange by more than $3,300,000,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Favorable growing weather, lack of commercial demand and increased offerings of wheat in the Southwest resulted in lower prices for all grain futures on the Board of Trade today.
The election of Harry C. Culshaw as executive vice president in charge of the commercial finance division of James Talcott, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Culshaw also was elected a director.

A press conference was called yesterday at Madison Square Garden to explain the unemployment problems of Floyd Patterson, the heavyweight champion, who lately has been unable to afford anything fancier to eat than crepes suzette.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP) -- The second stage of a Polaris experimental rocket twisted crazily over the cape and was deliberately destroyed today.

Vladimir Ashkenazy, Soviet pianist who will give a Carnegie Hall recital on Oct. 24 and will be soloist with the New York Philharmonic in November, will not play his scheduled recitals in Brooklyn and Newark.
The concept behind the extensive traffic improvements suggested for the projected billion-dollar redevelopment of lower Manhattan was termed desirable by experts yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- In the new installment of his memoirs entitled "All in One Lifetime" (Harper Bros., New York), James F. Byrnes has filled in many gaps in contemporary history and supplied the missing portions of many half-told episodes.
HONG KONG, Oct. 15 -- The Chinese Communists have launched a ten-year program to turn Sinkiang Province into one of China's main industrial and agricultural bases.
ATOMIC TEST SITE, Nev., Oct. 15 -- A desert butte rocked tonight as the Atomic Energy Commission set off what officials estimated was one of the largest-yield nuclear devices ever fired underground.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Prison terms ranging from five to ten years were meted out today by a Paris military tribunal to five European residents of Algeria who were convicted of trying to kill Gen. Raoul Salan, French commander in Algeria, in January, 1957, and of killing his aide.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- The first drop in production of electronics equipment in a decade probably will be recorded this year, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Celebrating President Eisenhower's presence at the Washington-International horse show tonight, Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N. J., chalked up the first American victory in international jumping in the closing program of the six-day show.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- A six-member committee recommended today that the United Nations seek to influence world opinion by a "concentrated attack on the minds of people."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The National Gallery of Art has acquired a Rubens painting and a sculpture by Jean-Antoine Houdon.
ROME, Oct. 15 -- The Congregation of Cardinals appointed today three committees to take care of all aspects of preparations for the conclave to select a successor to Pope Pius XII.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 14 points off to 6 up.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A California judge today summoned national officers of the American Legion's 40 and 8 Society to come here from Indianapolis and show cause why a local chapter that had admitted a Chinese-American should not get back its charter.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan accused the Eisenhower Administration last night of laxity in dealing with recent bombings of schools and religious institutions.

Ever since last Aug. 4, when the Federal Reserve Board lifted margin requirements from 50 to 70 per cent, Wall Street has girded itself for a further squeeze in its borrowing power for new stock purchases.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith made public yesterday the backgrounds of the five men now under questioning in connection with the bombing Sunday of The Temple, a Reform Jewish congregation in Atlanta.
WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 15 -- The problem of the roving city dump may be solved next Monday, at least for eight years. But the prospects are for more battling.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 15 -- Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla indicated during an interview today that he considered himself still President of Colombia.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 15 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club was elected president of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the annual meeting in the Piping Rock Club today. Mrs. Torgerson succeeds Mrs. Campbell D. Garrett of The Creek.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15 (AP) -- James McLaughlin, Edward (Snapper) Garrison and Laverne Fator -- names little known outside record books -- have been voted into the National Jockeys Hall of Fame at Pimlico.
MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (UPI) -The works of four American composers were introduced to the music-conscious Russian public tonight. The reaction was a mixture of enthusiasm and puzzlement.
The nation's leading corporations have learned that they cannot reduce advertising expenditures and still sell themselves out of a recession, an industry executive said yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, director of La Prensa in Buenos Aires and new president of the Inter-American Press Association, called today for the abolition of all barriers that hinder the free exchange of persons, goods, ideas and information among the American republics.

AFTER the sixth game of the world series in Milwaukee a lone, hatless figure was encountered outside the stadium, walking slowly toward the club offices with his eyes riveted on the ground. He was Lou Perini, the owner of the Braves.

Tight money and rising interest rates are unlikely to be a major factor in any checking of the business recovery, according to William F. Butler, vice president and economist of the Chase Manhattan Bank. He also discounted the outlook for a sharp rise in prices.
Budding retail merchants were offered a glimpse into their futures yesterday.

ALTHOUGH acts of sadism, murder, mayhem and other indelicacies are perpetrated nightly on the television screen, all to the delight of many young viewers, the unexpurgated versions of fairy tales and children's classics appear to be altogether too stark for the networks.
As a gift for her eighty-sixth birthday yesterday, a hospital room was dedicated in the name of Mrs. Edith Boiling Wilson, widow of former President Woodrow Wilson.
At his press conference on Tuesday, Secretary Dulles said, speaking of Quemoy and Matsu and the situation in the Taiwan Strait:
BEIRUT, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Premier Karami and his new four-man "national salvation" Cabinet pleaded for a return to peace in Lebanon today and plunged quickly into the task of restoring security.
LMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- presentative Kenneth B. ating asserted here tonight t the county was moving o a new era of prosperity.
Futures tended to decline in dull trading on the New York exchanges yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase in margin requirements for trading in stocks from 70 to 90 per cent, effective tomorrow.

The Marine Midland Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to merge subsidiaries in Utica, Rome and Herkimer, N. Y., into a single bank under the name Marine Midland Trust Company of Mohawk Valley. The resulting bank would have resources of about $115,000,000 and ten offices.
TRENTON, Oct. 15 -- New Jersey may carry its fight against the out-of-state taxation of its residents to the New York Legislature, State Senator Wayne Dumont said today.
Allen W. Dulles, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, defended it yesterday against criticism that it had failed to alert Washington about the impending Suez and Iraqi crises.
DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Delegates to the convention of the United Lutheran Church in America overwhelmingly approved yesterday a merger of their group with three small Lutheran churches.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Breaking up the Army missile team when national security and prestige demand a unified effort for rocket supremacy would seem "something less than prudent," Dr. Wernher von Braun warned today.
Municipal Court hearing growing out of a tenants' rent strike was adjourned yesterday when the landlord apeared without a lawyer and with a record of hazardous building violations against him.

Mayor Wagner scoffed yester-y at reports that New York- were moving to the sub-bs in such numbers that the y would be left desolate. At the same time, the Mayor d 250 men at the monthly eting of the Danish Luncheon ub in Miller's Restaurant, 144 lton Street, that it was not curate to call New York a lting pot.
Today's college student is a new and different species of more mature abilities and serious purpose, but he is often hobbled by obsolete college programs, a study commission has concluded.

Tickets are still available for next Tuesday's performance of "The Girls in 509" at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women. Preceding the theatre party a dinner will be held in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 15 -- A missing "key" witness caused State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Markewich to postpone the start of another Suffolk County land-grab trial here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower denounced as "hoodlums" today those responsible for bombing Jewish places of worship in the South and Midwest.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 15 -- President Iskander Mirza said today that he had given instructions for all press censorship in Pakistan to be lifted immediately. He said the press would now be on its honor to deal fairly and objectively with the new regime he instituted last week.

A new dog club with no officers, no dues and no members in the usual sense has been feeling its way in New York. It is the Dog Fanciers' Luncheon Club, which meets the second Monday of each month at the Hotel Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Robert Frost wants to borrow four American paintings for a year to create a discriminating atmosphere in his Federal office.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A two-year test of many foods was reported today to have found no significant increases in their radioactive content since the start of the atomic era in 1945.

YONKERS, Oct. 15 -- The two candidates for Representative in the Twenty-seventh Congressional District of Westchester and Putnam Counties met for the first time at a recent luncheon. Soon they were calling each other Bob and Dick and harmonizing on "My Buddy" and "That Old Gang of Mine."
ELIZABETH, N. J., O 5 -Harrison A. Williams r., Democratic candidate for he Senate, campaigned today in Union County, his home territory.
In The Times of Oct. 6 Dr. Ludwik Gross suggested that litter baskets be removed from residential areas because some people are using them for garbage instead of for ordinary litter.
WARSAW, Oct. 15 -- The United States and Communist China ended another negotiating session here today still deadlocked in the search for a Far Eastern settlement.

An account of the first atomic submarine's voyage from the Pacific to the Atlantic beneath the Arctic ice pack is planned for publication in January by World. It will be called "Nautilus 90 North." The authors are Comdr.

Una Merkel has been signed for the third starring role in Edward Chodorov's new mystery play, "Listen to the Mocking Bird." She will depict one of three retired women in an English rooming home who come under suspicion of murder. Set for the two other roles are Billie Burke and Eva Le Gallienne.
HARTFORD, Oct. 15 -- The re-election of Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, a Democrat, seems assured.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 15 -- The Nassau County Board of Elections said today it had not received evidence that any resident had been denied the right to register last week.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that the Court of Appeals had made it harder for the Little Rock Private School Corporation to use public contributions to open private, segregated high school classes in private quarters.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct 15 -- Finance Minister Lucas Lopes refused today to commit the Brazilian Government to guarantee the price of coffee in producing areas. He took this stand despite threats of a "march on Rio" by thousands of growers.
ALDERSHOT, England, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Kaziamerz Mazur of Poland fired a 194 out of a possible 200 today to win the pistol shooting event at the world modern pentathlon championship.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Adlai E. Stevenson, Governor Harriman and Thomas K. Finletter agreed last night that national issues were uppermost in New York's state elections this year.
The Johns-Manville Corporation has increased earnings so far this year, despite a decline in sales caused primarily by a nine-week strike at its plant in Marrero, La.

TO understand the American Revolutionists, first study the American Colonists. WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- United States District Judge Edward A. Tamm dismissed today a suit by the American Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union to obtain part of the assets of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union.

LINDENHURST, L. I., Oct. 15 -- A twin-engined Air Force transport plane crash-landed in heavy traffic on the Southern State Parkway tonight, fatally injuring the driver of a car. The plane, which had run out of gasoline, skidded more than 1,500 feet and burst into flame.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has sought the Soviet Union's intervention to ease the tightening restrictions on personal liberties recently decreed by the East German Communist Government.
The Continental Can Company had the best quarter in its history in the three months ended Sept. 30. Net income rose 17 per cent to $16,975,000, from $14,537,000 in the third quarter last year.

PRINCETON, Oct. 15 -- The Institute for Advanced Study today named a Federal judge, an executive of community service groups and an insurance company president to its fifteen-member board of trustees.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed the belief today that it would be inadvisable at present to establish a stand-by United Nations military force, whether or not it was modeled on the Emergency Force in Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The national total of personal income rose again in September, largely on the strength of increased employment and longer working hours in factories producing durable goods, the Commerce Department reported today.
A plan to terminate the long-delayed trials of thirteen transit workers charged with having led last December's subway strike ran into further snarls yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 15 -- A party of ten hunters is feared to have become lost in the salt marshes of central Iran while tracking down the wild ass of sports and legendary fame.

A BACKWARD glance at American painting is offered in the Metropolitan Museum's first major exhibition of the season, opening today, "Fourteen American Masters -- Paintings from Colonial Times to Today."

Pile-driving started yesterday on the Port of New York Authority's $150,000,000 waterfront construction at Elizabeth, N. J. This will bring the Newark-Elizabeth Port Authority investment, when expansion of the Newark port is included, to $275,000,000. Sixty-three vessel berths will be provided. On Newark Bay 1,300 acres will be available in the handling of an estimated future annual cargo of 11,000,000 tons, with jobs for 18,000 people at an annual payroll of $90,000,000.

A proposal that all new schools have sub-basements for air raid shelters was put before the City Planning Commission yesterday.

A $20,000,000 apartment development, with gold-braided doormen, oversized living rooms, private balconies, high rents and other luxury features, was dedicated yesterday on a three-block site that had been one of Harlem's most dismal slums.

The acquisition by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company of the Hartol Petroleum Corporation was announced yesterday. Tennessee Gas said Hartol was the largest independent wholesaler of gasoline, kerosene and No. 2 and 4 fuel oils on the Eastern Seaboard.

Governor Harriman appealed to organized labor last night for help in rolling up a large plurality for the Democratic party's state ticket. At the same time, he assured labor that it could depend on him for a sympathetic treatment of its problems.

Two Portuguese - born musicians gave a concert last night in Town Hall. They were the tenor Nico Castel (accompanied by Edward Schick) and the violinist Vasco Barbosa (accompanied by his sister, Grazi Barbosa). Mr. Castel had been heard here previously, but it was Mr. Barbosa's debut.

Your editorial of Oct. 9 on "De Gaulle's Election Reform" offers a good opportunity to correct a widespread misunderstanding. You say "the new electoral law abolishes the French system of proportional representation." The system being abolished usually but incorrectly goes by the name of proportional representation because it was derived by modification of a party-list system of P. R., which France used briefly between 1945 and 1951.

Frank S. Hogan has been an excellent District Attorney of New York County since 1941. Carmine G. De Sapio, the Tammany leader, thought he would be the best Democratic candidate for the United States Senate. It didn't matter that Governor Harriman could think of three other men he believed superior as a Senate nominee, or that Mayor Wagner agreed that the party could do better than Mr. Hogan for a Senator.
HONG KONG, Oct. 16 -- Chinese here with family ties in Communist China are beginning to realize with dismay the profound change coming over life there under the new system of communes.
Madison Square Garden will stage its first boxing show in more than six weeks tonight when a pair of heavyweights -- Pat McMurtry and George Chuvalo -- meet in the ten-round feature bout.

Prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Coffee, cocoa, copper and hides rose; sugar, cottonseed oil, lead and potatoes declined, and price movements for wool, rubber and zinc were mixed.
MONTREAL, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Dickie Moore's goal at 17:09 in the third period tonight lifted the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-3 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

THE college girl I know best is majoring in history. She seems to be interested in most of the information she absorbs from learned works or from her professors' lectures, but facts about parliamentary law or about the importance of the cloth trade don't really charm her. What she really likes are kings and queens, plots and conspiracies, castles and palaces, heroes, heroines and villains.
Two opposing bakery workers union were engaged yesterday in a cross-picketing battle throughout most of the city.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- John Marshall Butler said tonight that he intended to reintroduce the controversial Jenner-Butler bill to limit the Supreme Court's jurisdiction.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Wheat, oats, rye and soybean futures moved higher on the Board of Trade today. But corn continued under pressure, and all contracts finished at the lowest levels of the season.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Representatives of non-atomic powers urged the United Nations today to re-constitute its Disarmament Commission.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 16 -- Warren County, where Virginia closed its first school to avoid racial integration, opened its first private classes today at Front Royal.

Daniel Petrie has resigned as director of "The Disenchanted," starring Jason Robards Jr. and Rosemary Harris. He was replaced by David Pressman. The assignment will mark the Broadway debut of Mr. Pressman, who has staged off-Broadway as well as out-of-town presentations.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 16 (AP) -- About the least lonely man in football is Army's fabled "lonely end," Bill Carpenter.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- Pope Pius XII left several secret documents, including a plan for reforming the Curia, or central administration of the Roman Catholic Church, an unofficial Vatican source said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- A new age of container transport in ocean shipping was forecast today by maritime experts.

Loans to business by the seventeen major New York City banks rose $34,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The rise compared with a $13,000,000 increase in the similar week a year earlier.

Inventories of gasoline and other petroleum products rose in the week ended last Friday as producers raised refinery output, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Crude oil production and imports declined from the week-earlier levels.
"Twenty-One," a television quiz program under investigation by a grand jury here, has been canceled and removed from the National Broadcasting Company network.

IRUMAGAWA, Japan, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Jackie Burke, 35-year-old Houston golfer, and Japan's Canada Cup champion, Torakichi (Pete) Nakamura, shot one-under-par 71's today and moved into a tie with Ken Venturi of San Francisco in the Japan open golf championship.
Columbia's weekly football press luncheon developed into a rave session for Charley Ravenel, Harvard's sophomore quarterback, who leads the Cantabs against the Lions tomorrow.

The huge colored balloons representing figures from the story-book and comic strip world that have been a familiar feature of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade in past years will not be seen in 1958.

Electric power production last week fell to 12,067,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,111,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Oct. 12, 1957, the output was 11,709,000,000 kilowatt hours.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Friday, Oct. 17 (Reuters) -- A rescue helicopter early today landed at Cape Hallett in the Antarctic and picked up four of seven survivors of a United States Air Force Globe-master plane, which crashed there yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A motion for a new trial was filed in United States District Court today by attorneys for seven persons convicted of having conspired to sign false non-Communist affidavits.

The Order of the Eastern Star of New York State yesterday elected Mrs. Viola Hornell Kingston of Hudson as Grand Matron. She succeeds Mrs. Gertrude L. Becker of Bronxville.

From the glare and murk of "Lorenzaccio," the visiting French company moved to the delicately cloud-puffed blue skies of "Le Triomphe de l'Amour." THERE are a good many French art critics who voluntarily defend a single "tendency" in contemporary art, hedging themselves carefully into a fixed position. Michel Ragon, however, a 34-year-old French art critic with seemingly unlimited interests, is emphatically not among them. He is, he declares, at war with the single-minded "theorists" who are more interested in movements than in individuals.
