Bob Turley, the strong right arm of the New York Yankees' pitching staff, yesterday was named American League player of the year by United Press International.

An appeal has gone out from the New York Heart Association, 10 Columbus Circle, New York 19, for 50,000 volunteer workers, not just for the usual one year, but for five years. The volunteers ring doorbells every February on behalf of the Heart Fund, used mainly to finance the continuing war against heart disease. But now the volunteers are asked to enlist for the longer period.
The first annual New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital Ball will be held on Nov. 21 at the New York Athletic Club on Travers Island, New Rochelle.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower rang in this country's commercial jet age today with a "ping" of a bottle filled with water from the oceans.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The city received a plan tonight to convert seven crowded blocks in the old downtown business district into a modern shopping center with pedestrian malls and no vehicle traffic. The streets would be planted with trees, lawns and gardens.
CHICAGO, Oct 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
ROME, Oct. 16 -- Cardinals from all over the world continued to converge on Rome today for the Conclave that will elect the 262d Pope.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Doorbells are ringing, coffee pots are steaming, bandwagons are parading, commuters are being collared and shoppers are hearing curbstone talks in Westchester County's liveliest local election contest this year.
CORNING, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating ridiculed Governor Harriman here today for seeking to depict Carmine G. De Sapio as a minor political figure in the Democratic party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Two new antibiotics were hailed by experimenters today as apparently effective against strains of staphylococcal germs.
TUNIS, Oct. 16 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia gave the West a strong pledge of support today.

Harry Stuhldreher, a member of Notre Dame's "Four Horsemen" backfield of the Nineteen Twenties, and Thomas Albert Dwight (Tad) Jones, late Yale coach, were among nine men named to the Football Hall of Fame yesterday.
Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Communist leader who had been denied permission to speak on the City College campus, addressed students yesterday from a sound truck just one block from the college.
ROME, Oct. 16 -- The stove in which are burned the ballots in the election of a Pope has disappeared.

Seymour M. Wilson, former chief accountant of the city's Bureau of Real Estate, reported yesterday in General Sessions Court through his lawyer, Louis Yavner, that he had repaid more than $10,000 of funds stolen from the city.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- Drastic new security measures were imposed on Cyprus tonight to cope with mounting violence.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 16 -- Justice Robert Doscher of the State Supreme Court today dismissed a petition to compel Rye city officials to place on the Nov. 4 election ballot a proposition for a commission to draft a new city charter.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- Britain has protested to Communist China over the arrest of two British missionaries on a charge of having spread "counter-revolutionary propaganda" the Foreign Office said today.

A young man who makes a habit of carrying a pencil and pad passed along the following notes the other day, avowing that they were the record of a Q. A. conversation he had with a sidewalk philosopher of this city. Subject: Municipal problems.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle continued today to rake in the winnings from his bold political gamble on Algeria.
Vincent A. Corsall, 39-year-old Mayor of Oswego, N. Y., was found not guilty yesterday of a morals offense that he had been accused of commiting in a men's subway washroom on Oct. 4.
MERCED, Calif., Oct. 15 -- What this country needs, Senator William F. Knowland of California proclaimed here today, is more stubborn men.
IT takes two to tango, and some of the best-matched pairs in town are the evening separates at Altman's.

OCEANSIDE, L. I., Oct. 16 -- The Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association pro-pro championship at Middle Bay today ended in a two-team deadlock at 66, six strokes under par. A play-off will be held over eighteen holes.
ALGIERS, Oct. 16 -- Political extremists among the Europeans here suffered a crippling defeat today.
"LITTLE WOMEN" was set to music last night on Channel 2; it was a long evening for the girls.

In 1780 French expeditionary forces, under General Rochambeau, sailed from France for Newport, R. I. An account of their activities in the Colonies was kept by Baron Ludwig von Closen, aide-de-camp to General Rochambeau.
GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- The United States was urged today to take the lead in removing world trade barriers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- Federal Judge F. Dickinson Letts agreed today to hear arguments on Nov. 5 and 6 on a request by the Teamsters Union's board of monitors for power to force the union to clean up its ranks.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 16 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission fired its third nuclear device in twenty-four hours today in a speed-up of its current test series to beat a proposed Oct. 31 international ban on such tests.

BIRD men at the American Museum of Natural History wanted a special souvenir for delegates to this week's Tuesday-to-Friday meeting of the American Ornithologist Union, because the sessions marked the union's seventy-fifth anniversary.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 16 -- Four Chinese Communist planes were reported to have circled Wuchiu Island for nearly half an hour this morning.
Frauds allegedly practiced against the city by private nursing homes have been under official investigation by two public agencies since June.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 16 -- Faulty fuel gauges and severe radio interference were blamed today for the crash-landing last night of a twin-engined Air Force transport plane on the Southern State Parkway.
Ithaca, N. Y., borrowed $5,900,000 in the bond market yesterday for school construction. The money was raised on obligations due serially from 1959 to 1978.
After the Florida - bound pleasure boat gets to Savannah there will be less work and more play. The weather will be warm, the sun bright. It should be shirt-sleeve, instead of overcoat, time.

Leonie Rysanek, Viennese soprano, will join the Metropolitan Opera during the latter part of this season. She will make her debut in the title role of Verdi's "Aida" and will sing the part of Queen Elizabeth in the Metropolitan's revival of Verdi's "Don Carlo."

Customer research men from General Motors mingled with thousands of visitors yesterday at the opening of the Motorama, trying to find out what the public really thought of the company's new automobiles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Britain is planning to develop an all nuclear-powered submarine fleet.
Science has discovered evidence that migratory birds navigate on their long seasonal flights by observing the stars.
MOSCOW, Oct. 16 -- The Soviet Government charged today that United States military planes flew reconnaissance missions over Soviet territory in the Far East in July, August and September.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Americans must be encouraged to make the sacrifices needed to provide for pay-as-you-go financing of national defense and essential Federal services, Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, said here tonight.
CHESHIRE, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Cheshire Academy, which once welcomed outstanding "one-year" schoolboy football players, is making every effort to return to a prep school level in athletics.
The city's school system will begin next February another experiment in its traditional task of assimilating newcomers -- this time Negroes and Puerto Ricans.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords' 4-year-old Bakht fought all the way with Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Indian Creek in today's Executives Purse at Garden State Park and scored a one-length victory.
A seven-foot wooden plank was thrown through a rear window of the Mapleton Park Hebrew Institute at 2022 Sixty-sixth Street in Brooklyn last night at 10 o'clock.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- The United States sternly rebutted today South Africa's contention that its official policy of racial discrimination was a private affair.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent above the level of a year ago.

Sweden could manufacture atomic weapons, but she doesn't want to. This is the gist of what the Swedish Foreign Minister, Oesten Unden, told a United Nations committee. Specifically, what Mr. Unden said was this:

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 16 -- An order requesting Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, former Colombian dictator, to testify on charges against him was signed tonight by the six members of the Senate Subcommittee on Investigations and Procedure.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The Bank of France moved cautiously today to liberalize credit by lowering the discount rate from 5 to 4.5 per cent. The move was designed to stimulate industrial production. It also was dictated by the danger of inflation.

In his survey of American music with the New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein is starting with the composers of the older generation. Last night, in his third Philharmonic "preview" at Carnegie Hall, he introduced three of the "grand old men" in person.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- Yul Brynner is showing a predilection for costume adventure dramas in lining up stories to be filmed by his Alciona Productions for United Artists release.
Elston Howard's tie-breaking single plus Bill Skowron's three-run homer in the eighth inning of the final world series game proved to be financial crushers for the Milwaukee Braves.

A 19-year-old sophomore at New York University was charged with disorderly conduct in Night Court last night as a result of a threatening telephone call received by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at 515 Madison Avenue.
Multicolored flowers bloomed in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night, providing a festive setting for the tenth annual La Fete des Roses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower set up today a committee to recommend the design of the new forty-nine-star American flag made necessary by the forthcoming admission of Alaska into the union.

RUTH V. NOBLE has always liked to cook and to eat well. But even she is surprised sometimes to find herself at one of her present occupations: dining in restaurants in all parts of the country. She samples the cuisine and, if she likes it, includes the restaurant in "A Guide to Distinctive Dining," an enticingly illustrated handbook.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 16 -- Walter Spence, holder of world and national swimming titles in the Nineteen Thirties, was killed tonight as he tried to reboard a commuter train at the North White Plains station.
Congressional help in solving noise problems at New York International Airport and La Guardia Airport was sought yesterday at a conference called by James J. Crisona, Queens Borough President.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 686,138 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

BILL CARPENTER, the extravagantly publicized "lonely end" in Army's new attacking formation, is a nimble-footed young man who handled sprinting and hurdling chores on the track team. He has size at 6 feet 2 inches and an exceptional burst of speed to go with it.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 (AP) -- College enrollment has increased this fall for the sixth consecutive year, Dr. Raymond Walters, president emeritus of the University of Cincinnati, reported today.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Governor Harriman tried today to prove that a man can be both a gentleman and an office-seeker.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Industrial shares retreated today. There was only a little selling, but in the absence of demand declines were widespread and heaviest among shares where there had been most speculation recently.
A committee of merchants, builders and railroad investors has been established by the Fifth Avenue Association to "keep alive" the railroad commuting facilities of the city.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle sent a cool message to Sekou Toure today in reply to a cablegram of Oct. 9 from the President of the Government of newly independent Guinea asking for French diplomatic recognition and "association" with France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, criticized today as economically unsound proposals by two of the nation's biggest electrical equipment companies for employe savings plans.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Evangelical United Brethren Church prohibited today the use of its church facilities as private-school classrooms by those seeking to carry on racial segregation.

A plot adjacent to Castle Hill Houses, a state-aided apartment development in the Bronx, has been sold at auction by the New York City Housing Authority. A bid of $275,000 made by Marvin Kratter, realty operator and syndicator, was the highest of thirteen offers received. The upset price was $105,000.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Monsanto Chemical Company reported today that its sales for the third quarter of the year, traditionally its poorest quarter, were 13 per cent higher than sales in the first quarter, usually its best. Sales in both periods, however, were below 1957 levels.

The Navy's Bureau of Ships has developed a method of packaging bearings in transparent plastic to help reduce packaging costs and damage. The bearings themselves become the mold for a plastic cover, formed of two sheets applied under heat and pressure.
ROME, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Saudi Arabia's offer of a new type of oil concession to an American company has been rejected, but other companies are reported to be interested.
Voters in one of the largest and fastest-growing sections of the city, the Fourth Congressional District in Queens, will send a new man to Washington this year.

The publication of a proposed new judiciary article for the State Constitution, prepared by the Institute of Judicial Administration at the request of the League of Women Voters and the Citizens Union, has revived the issue of court reform, quiescent since the dismal failure of the Legislature last spring to approve the Tweed Commission plan, or any other.
Alerted by the overnight increase of margins to 90 per cent, investors started yesterday's trading with exceptional caution. Volume at the start was the smallest for any opening hour of the year.
"I could not imagine a more worthy public service for you to be doing today," President Eisenhower told a recent meeting of the USO National Council in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- Leaders of the 1,000,000-member Machinists Union aired charges today that the Defense Department was improperly controlling wages in the aircraft and missile industry.
Sales and earnings of Parke, Davis Co. set a record in the first nine months of this year, the producer of pharmaceuticals reported yesterday.

Always the dramatist, Nikita S. Khrushchev has told his people the world will be "amazed" when the goals for the new Soviet seven-year plan for 1959-65 are published. Whether or not that will be true remains to be seen, but certainly even the Soviet Premier knows that the world is always more likely to be amazed by actual accomplishment than by announced plans.

GILDING the lily takes talent. And, no matter how expensive or complete a woman's make-up may be, the final result can prove disastrous unless she knows how to apply it. Eye make-up is as important as lipstick these days but, all too often, eye shadow and mascara look bleary and sloppy a few hours after they have been applied.

The International Longshoremen's Association lost another round yesterday in its five-year campaign to upset the right of the Waterfront Commission to apply disciplinary measures in cases of dock strike misconduct.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- Capital Airlines canceled all its flights at midnight Thursday after operating for a day without nearly 2,600 mechanics who walked out last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- George Meany urged 15,000,000 union members to study the issues and records of candidates and then vote according to their consciences.

IT has been a long time since Carmen was sung as stylishly as Regina Resnik encompassed the role at the City Center last night. Here was a performance based solidly on musical values rather than on the obvious histrionics to which the role tempts so many of its interpreters.
The Fifth Congressional District in Queens is strange. It registers Democratic but votes Republican.
MORRISTOWN, N. J. Oct. 17 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican candidate for Senator, campaigned today on a platform of world peace, national preparedness and labor purity.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Since the Fourth Republic's death last June France's political firmament has undergone great change. Of course, infinitely the most luminous star now dominating the scene is that of General de Gaulle. But there are other asteroids on the horizon. Of these the most important is that of Jacques Soustelle.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Eli Lilly Co. said that a slump in demand for polio vaccine was mainly responsible for a sharp decline in its sales.
ATLANTA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- In denying his participation in the bombing, Griffin said:
ATLANTA, Oct. 17 -- Five men were indicted today on a charge of bombing a synagogue here. Four of them were immediately placed in the Fulton County jail without bond. The other is at large.
Two rival bakery unions agreed yesterday afternoon to submit their jurisdictional dispute to arbitration. The unions had cross-picketed twenty-six shops on Thursday in three boroughs.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 17 -- Two Massachusetts girls were killed and a third was injured when their auto crashed into a tree on the center esplanade of the Merritt Parkway at 5 A.M. today.

The direct interdependence between economic health and defense is emphasized again by Britain's announcement yesterday that as a result of its improved financial condition it has dropped the contemplated further reduction of the Army of the Rhine and will now maintain that force at its present strength of 55,000 men throughout next year.

A modern apartment house will replace six five-story houses on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 435 to 445 West Fifty - seventh Street, according to plans of a syndicate of builders represented by William Himlyn of Dreyer Traub, Brooklyn attorneys.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Representatives of non-Communist political parties and labor unions of six Western European countries resolved today to take steps to make full economic integration a working reality.

MOSCOW, Oct. 17 -- Pravda, the Soviet Union's leading newspaper, had warm praise today for a concert of American music held here Wednesday evening to honor four visiting composers from the United States.

A Japanese mission seeking opportunities to increase exports to this country without causing excessive competition for American producers was warmly welcomed here yesterday. The thirteen-member group of manufacturing and trade experts was honored at a luncheon given by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce of New York at the Astor Hotel.
Columbia's football team will meet Harvard in an Ivy league game before a homecoming alumni gathering at Baker Field today. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.
QUINCY, Ill., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Hunters were urged today to spare a big white bird traveling south along the Mississippi River. The bird is a whooping crane, one of the world's rarest vinged creatures.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 17 -- Dr. Thomas Jefferson Raney Jr. is a man who has his finger firmly on the pulse of Gov. Orval E. Faubus.
SKETCH pad in hand, Nils Landberg, crystal designer, has been walking among New York's midtown skyscrapers since his arrival here on Tuesday.
The Sheraton Corporation of America announced yesterday the purchase of the 1,000-room Cleveland Hotel in Cleveland from the Hotel Corporation of America.
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 17 -- President Eisenhower told a cheering throng of 85,000 farmers today that they were "the strongest fighters in the cause of freedom."
Cocoa futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange rose the daily limit of 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in all contracts yesterday.

Play was resumed yesterday after a day's rest, in the international chess team tournament in Munich, according to a report received from Germany. Not a single decision was reached in the six matches of the sixth round, there being adjournments in every instance.
A 30-year-old employe of a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank was arraigend in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday on a charge of embezzling more than $41,000 through fictitious loans.

ALDERSHOT, England, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Kurt Lindeman, a wavy-haired Finn with a determined stride, thrust himself over two and a half miles of hills today to crack the Soviet Union's stranglehold on the world pentathlon championship.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 9 -- A 47-year-old Roman Catholic priest has surprised Brazil's political experts -- and himself -- with his election to the Federal Senate last week over a favored pro-Communist opponent.
ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Rockwell's anti-Jewish material appears under the name of the National Committee to Free American From Jewish Domination.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Administration is planning to seek an exemption in any international atomic test ban to permit nuclear detonations for peaceful purposes.
George Chuvalo of Toronto may be the Canadian heavyweight champion, but that fact fazed Pat McMurtry of Tacoma, Wash., not at all in their Madison Square Garden bout last night.

Events today: Puccini's "La Boheme," New York City Center, 8:15; Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "I Pagliacci," Long Island Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30; Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15.
LILI KRAUS, absent from the local scene for ten years, returned to Town Hall last night for a piano recital.
HAVANA, Oct. 17 -- The Cuban Government will accept observers from some international organization for the general elections Nov. 3, the Ministry of State announced tonight.
ABILENE, Kan., Oct. 17 -- President Eisenhower returned to the scenes of his boyhood here today and, for about an hour, seemed to forget about the demands of politics and candidates.

THE season of the common cold is off and running. Off and running also are mothers of children who are confined to the bed or home. This is especially the case when a young patient becomes cranky because he can find "nothing" to do.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Legislative elections for Algeria were set by the Cabinet today for Nov. 30.

YONKERS, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- Irish, a 6 - year - old gelding owned by James Scileppi of Massapequa, L. I., came from behind in the final yards to defeat Canny Scot by three-quarters of a length in tonight's $6,000 Thornwood Pace at Yonkers Raceway.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Average wholesale primary market prices were unchanged at 118.8 per cent of their 1947-49 level, for the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
An 18-year-old boy convicted of a minor offense for which he did not have to spend a day in jail now faces the possibility of a three-year prison term because he fought the case.
Carmine G. De Sapio sought yesterday to link Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Republican candidate for Governor, with "the international oil cartel which seeks to capture control" of the country.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 16 -- Friendship and international understanding among school children of the world are being promoted by pupils of the Elizabeth M. Baker Public School here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A satellite engineer has invented apparatus to keep a vehicle from rolling over as it moves through space. In very thin air or a vacuum, the usual type rudders, flaps and fins cannot take hold and guide it.
ROME, Oct. 17 -- The Vatican protested today against what it termed the frivolity with which part of the press was treating the current events in the Roman Catholic Church.

A distance race worth $84,950 and a sprint worth $23,950 will be contested at Belmont Park today. The Jockey Club Gold Cup is the longer, older and richer event and will be run over the distance of two miles.

A Securities and Exchange Commission motion to block temporarily the Arvida Corporation from public sale of its stock was denied yesterday by Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan. The action also was directed against Arthur Vining Davis, 91-year-old holder of $100,000,000 in Florida real estate, and two investment banking houses.
ROME, Oct. 17 -- Celso Cardinal Costantini, Chancellor of the Holy Roman Church, died today. He underwent an operation three weeks ago.

More than $2,550,000,000 was added to the market value of stocks yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as investors continued Thursday's rush to buy. Volume soared to 5,367,910 shares, the largest since Sept. 27, 1955, the day of recovery following the Eisenhower heart attack market.

Five hundred persons yesterday attended ceremonies opening a Japanese department and speciality store, Takashimaya, Inc., at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. The store will be opened to the public at 9:30 A. M. today.
Sam Huff is not exactly an "unsung" hero among the New York Giants. The West Virginian's worth to the squad is known and appreciated by the coaches and the other players.
TELEVISION had one of its unforgettably exciting evenings last night -- an hour with Fred Astaire over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The House Government Information subcommittee today set hearings for Nov. 12-13 on the Air Force's refusal to make available to the General Accounting Office a report on management of the ballistic missiles program.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Ireland proposed today that the United Nations seek to keep nuclear weapons out of the hands of nations that did not now possess them.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 17 -- The Union County prosecutor today ordered an investigation of an allegedly anti-Semitic and anti-Negro newspaper published in near-by Union Township under the name "Common Sense."

Directors of the Kroger Company, the nation's third largest food chain, proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. The board also increased the quarterly dividend rate by 17 1/2 cents to 67 1/2 cents a share.
GREENE, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The season is out of joint in this part of New York and maybe that is why grouse are hard to find. They have been hard to find for two days, anyway.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 17 -- Walter Cooper, a lanky junior from Fordham, set a course record today and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia captured team honors in a triangular cross-country meet.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The American Motors Corporation and the United Auto Workers Union agreed on a new three-year labor contract today.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- Henry T. Heald, president of the Ford Foundation, announced tonight that the foundation was expanding its philanthropic operations to Africa, with initial grants totaling $350,000.

The Times of Oct. 7 contained a letter on the subject of Hungary. A paragraph in it claims to comment on the speech of Dr. E. Sik, chairman of the Hungarian delegation to the United Nations, during the Thirteenth United Nations General Assembly session.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The strong stand of the nation's money managers against inflation is helping to lessen the wage-price spiral, Dr. Neil H. Jacoby said here today.

The chairman of the State Mediation Board yesterday urged the New York Newspaper Guild and the publishers of seven metropolitan newspapers to make "earnest efforts" to resolve their contract differences.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 17 -- The Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church gravely warned here today that continued injustice to the "colored races" might one day leave this nation alone and friendless in a hostile world.
It seems to me that there is a partial solution to the problem -- detailed in recent Times stories -- of traffic congestion due to cars "yielding" to pedestrians.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- Dr. David A. Lockmiller, 52 years old, president of the University of Chattanooga, Tenn., for the last sixteen years, has accepted the presidency of Ohio Wesleyan University. He will succeed Arthur S. Flemming, who left his alma mater in August to become Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI) -- The State Department said today that it was again renewing permission for representatives of twenty-five United States news organizations to travel in Red China if the Communists would let them in.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Richmond shredded George Washington's defenses tonight for a 26-6 upset football victory, its first of the season.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Wheat futures staged a minor upturn today. They were supported by a Government report showing 145,000,000 bushels of bread grain placed under support between Aug. 25 and Sept. 30.

A collection of H. L. Mencken's columns that were published in The Chicago Tribune between 1924 and 1927 will be published Monday by Knopf. The volume, titled "The Bathtub Hoax," has been edited by Robert McHugh, who has written a brief introduction and some connective passages.

GENEVA, Oct. 17 -- Spokesmen for the European Economic Community sought today to allay the apprehensions of other nations regarding the effects on their trade in the formation of a customs union, or Common Market.
The 457-foot Navy ship Lindenwald, with more than 300 men aboard, was wallowing in heavy seas and high winds off the east coast of Greenland yesterday, unable to steer.
The Kaiser Steel Corporation had a loss in the third quarter and a $16,306,247 drop in earnings for the first nine months this year, according to the report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Harold C. McClellan, former president of the National Association of Manufacturers and former Assistant Secretary of Commerce, was named today to manage next summer's United States exhibit in Moscow's Gorki Park.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- The right of the Independent-Socialist Party to have its five state-wide candidates listed on the ballot this fall was upheld today by Justice Kenneth S. MacAffer of the State Supreme Court.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 17 -- Lebanon's four-man Cabinet got a unanimous vote of confidence today from Parliament.
Former President Lazaro Cardenas of Mexico spent his first day in New York yesterday. He sails for Europe on the Liberte today.
LIKE a fond parent, the New York Philharmonic gently chided its Friday afternoon audience at Carnegie Hall yesterday and was apologetic about its severity.
Production of newsprint in September was higher than the year-ago level for the first time in fourteen months, the Newsprint Service Bureau reported yesterday.

The last two weeks of the Republican drive to elect the state ticket headed by Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor will bring into action many prominent Republicans, including former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 17 -- A leading economist said today that the current business recovery would continue and carry the nation to "a higher level of economic activity than we have had at any previous time."
Your issue of Oct. 7 carries a letter by the vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee on the subject of consumer protection. The facts are cleverly assembled for partisan gain.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 17 -- The Little Rock Private School Corporation announced today that it would open classes here Monday for about 500 twelfth grade students.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Federal Housing Administration is running out of mortgage insurance money.
It's homecoming day for Columbia Old Blues at Baker Field today and it's homecoming too, for the first time, for West Pointers from generals to shavetails at the Military Academy.

The distinctive charm, the irresistible appeal of Victoria de los Angeles' recital last night in Carnegie Hall seemed to flow primarily from the collection of Spanish songs in the second half of her program.

The first appearance of Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain on a local court is scheduled at Madison Square Garden tonight. Chamberlain, formerly at Kansas University, will be in the line-up of the Harlem Globetrotters against the Philadelphia Sphas.

One of the tragedies of present-day society is the broken home, destroyed because of internal strife. In some cases the prime sufferers of such a situation, through no fault of their own, are the children. An organization prepared to give skilled assistance to troubled families is the Community Service Society, with its excellent record in family counseling.
DENVER, Oct. 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon warned Republicans today that President Eisenhower could not win this year's campaign for them without "a sustained offensive" by the entire party.
WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 17 (AP) -- A crude dynamite bomb exploded in the Municipal Air Terminal today, killing a man who had brought it with him on ain airliner from Kansas City.

Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan said yesterday that he had assigned twenty investigators to his inquiry into frauds allegedly practiced against the city by private nursing homes. In addition, he said, 15) subpoenas were sent out.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The strength of the British forces in West Germany will stay at 55,000 during 1959, the Foreign Office announced today.
GIRLS from 3 to 6 years old who ride scooters or school buses may now be dressed in imitation of their auto-driving elders.
Minutes after the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. had testified before a grand jury yesterday, the panel indicted Mrs. Izola Ware Curry, for trying to kill him.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the Railway Express Agency today to increase rates up to 15 per cent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that the nation had halted and reversed what he said was a tidal drift toward socialized agriculture.

Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday accepted a challenge from Governor Harriman to debate campaign issues. It seemed unlikely, however, that they would get together on mutually agreeable terms for a verbal bout.

Resident buying offices report that retailers have stepped up their orders in recent weeks. Coats, dresses and sportswear sold well last week, and shortages occurred in popular items of sportswear such as bulky-knit sweaters and helenca stretch tights. Blouses are features for holiday selling.

Coffin is not really worth advancing -- though it intrudes itself, Mrs. Rich, it will be recalled, is the lady who took to the woods in several books and now with equal enthusiasm she has taken to the rock-bound barrens of Gouldsboro, Me. Personal biography is inserted to explain this turn of allegiance, and it does.

MONTREAL -- The first link in the Laurentian Autoroute, the new thoroughfare which is to speed vacationists out of Montreal's congested metropolitan area toward the Laurentian resorts, is expected to open a mid-November. This will bring relief from the critical traffic situation immediately north of the city and provide relatively smooth going for the lite-fall motorists and the winter ski crowd.

ON Dec. 28, 1917, The New York Evening Mail published an article by H. L. Mencken lamenting the indifference of a public which, he reported, had just ignored the seventy-fifth anniversary of the first American bathtub.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The United States and Poland have agreed to reopen consular offices. Under the agreement, the United States will again have a consulate in Poznan, and Poland a consulate in Chicago.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 18 (AP) -- William and Mary recovered a fumble that set up a last-period touchdown and beat North Carolina State, 13-6, today.

In southern states year-round pleasure boating is perfectly possible and feasible. The trick in northern latitudes is to prolong the yachting season by adding two or three fall months and two or three more in the spring to the conventional, traditional summer vacation season and emerge with a sevenmonth, perhaps eight-month, span.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 -- Proctor Academy of Andover, N. H., defeated Westmount High School of Montreal today, 20 -- 6. The first half of the game was played under United States rules, the second half under Canadian rules.
WITH the television season racing along at its autumn pace it might not be amiss to catch one's breath and take a backward glance at some of the early developments.
The formation of an international body to promote the peaceful conquest of space has been proposed in a staff report of the House Select Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration.

CHARLOTTESVTLLE, Va., Oct. 18 -- Members of the Grolier Club of New York, a group of booklovers, will visit the Alderman Library of the University of Virginia next Friday and Saturday to see some of its treasure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The chief of the Federal Children's Bureau said today that the country's school system should assume more responsibility for the increasing number of unmarried mothers who are "children themselves."
A CULTURAL compost of rare books, French paintings and classical music has enabled Harry Kurnitz, globetrotter and gag man, to sprout forth three books and two plays in the space of twenty years.

A fashion show and tea will be given Tuesday afternoon at Watson Hall of the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at Ninety-first Street. The Women's Association of the church is sponsoring the event.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Lawyers for natural gas pipelines arrived in Washington today for one of the most important industry cases ever to come before the Supreme Court -- the Memphis case.
TEANECK, N. J., Oct, 18 -Unbeaten Teaneck High School recorded its third victory today when it crushed Memorial High School of West New York, 33 -- 0, before 8,000 fans.

The focus in the Far East conflict shifted last week to Taipei, capital of the Chinese Nationalist stronghold on Taiwan. There lay the key to a possible break in the impasse over the Nationalist-held offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu. Defense Secretary Neil H. McElroy conferred last week with Nationalist President Chiang Kaishek; Secretary of State Dulles will meet with Chiang in Taipei this week.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- A center, Wayne Berfield, ran an intercepted pass 98 yards for a touchdown today as Penn State routed Boston University, 34 to 0.

ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 18 -- The fourth annual "American Art at Mid-Century" exhibition and sale will be held at Graulich's here from Nov. 15 through Nov. 18. The event, under the sponsorship of the North Essex Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, will help to support the community welfare projects of the group.

I read with interest Paul Friedlander's thoughtful and objective article in Sunday's Travel Section on the arrival of the "Jet Age" at Idlewild Airport. His points are excellent and I would not wish to be among those who hold back the thrust of progress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -The Veterans Administration, with 175 hospitals scattered across the country, is rapidly becoming the nation's largest laboratory for research into diseases of middle and old age.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The North Atlantic alliance is feeling its age. Set up in a period of hurried preparation to meet the obvious conventional Soviet military threat, the alliance is struggling with new and baffling problems arising from political and military circumstances vastly different from those that prevailed ten years ago.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- A bronze bust of the late James Forrestal, the nation's first Secretary of Defense, was presented to Princeton University today.

WHENEVER Franklin R. Uhlig's dog Tinker strayed, neighbors in the Woodedge section of Westbury, L. I., would return him. With Tinker safely home, conversation often turned from dogs to the neglected state of the trees and shrubs on the public plantings.
At the sixth annual luncheon of the Women's Division of the American Friends of Hebrew University, Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt will be cited as "Woman of the Year."
Cement sales, which started to move up a few months ago, after lagging in the first half of the year, are increasing at a more rapid pace.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Ralph J. Cordiner, board chairman of the General Electric Company has told top business men that next month's Congressional elections will probably give "union officials an absolute majority and the power to pass or repeal legislation at will."
Taxpayers and particularly school authorities who are contemplating the construction of new schools were advised last week to pay more attention to upkeep and less to the original price tag.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- A longhaired dachshund from California who has been making the rounds of Eastern events since early September clicked for best in show today in the competition of the Albany Kennel Club.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Cornell defeated Yale at football for the first time since 1951 today, 12-7, after Yale had scored what appeared to be the winning touchdown three seconds before the end.
The Grand Union Company tomorrow will open the largest supermarket ever built by a major food chain in the Greater New York Metropolitan Area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The nation's biggest farm organization gives incumbent Republican Senators a heavy edge over their Democratic colleagues in a "good or bad" study of Senate voting records issued as a pre-election guide for farmer voting.
Harvard, Army and Tulane won major games in the East yesterday. Scores of leading games throughout the nation:

" AFTER more than five hundred volumes, I want to close my literary career with a book on cooking." This statement was written to one of his many publishers by Alexandre Dumas (pere), author of "The Three Musketeers," "The Count of Monte Cristo," etc., whose robust, productive and sometimes suspect life was one of the most picturesque of the nineteenth century.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 12 -The division of the waters of the Jordan River between Israel and the Arab states, a chronic source of friction, is being implemented piecemeal.

In your Oct. 5 "Letters" column Robert Y. Drake Jr., a Southern college teacher at a Northern university, defends "the Southern way of life" in its opposition to integration. His opinions bring to mind what a Southern university president said in 1929 about Southern reactions to comparisons with what Mr. Drake calls "the New York or Chicago way of life."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 18 -Four Latin-American Governments have taken a first major step toward the establishment of a regional common market through a plan for easing tariff regulations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -Early next month Navy astronomers will attempt to measure the water vapor in the atmosphere of Mars with instruments mounted on top of a balloon more than sixteen miles above the earth.
HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 15 -- What to import from the Soviet Union is a major problem for the Finns.

WITH the price of almost everything else going up, is it possible that concert tickets, or at least recital tickets, will go down? Some artists hope so. And there is at least one manager, Herbert Barrett, who does more than hope.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Striking for a touchdown the first time they got the ball, the Air Force Academy Falcons maintained their undefeated record with a 16-0 victory over Stanford today.

More than 3,000 Columbia University alumni attended an annual reunion yesterday at Baker Field, Broadway at 218th Street. They greeted old friends, played games at carnival booths and ate box lunches before watching the Columbia- Harvard football game in the afternoon.

An editor from the Union of South Africa said last week that his country had entered upon a period of terror involving human suffering of such dimensions that it would be an impertinence for him to try to describe it.

Am I wrong to assume that in "Success Story of Modern Art," by Aline B. Saarinen (Oct. 5), you have printed Mondrian's "Trafalgar Square" not only upside down but also reversed? I can think of no greater insult to the work of an artist such as Piet Mondrian, who placed such great importance upon the position of forms.
The Ford Foundation has made a $25,000 grant to the American Council to Improve Our Neighborhoods (ACTION) to conduct seminars on urban renewal in five metropolitan areas.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- The strike of 2,300 employes at five major Pittsburgh hotels neared the end of its third week tonight with little prospect of an early settlement.

ADAM ATWELL, a ginger-colored Negro who can neither read nor write, and Mrs. Lucy Hightower, Charleston-born widow of the best land lawyer in south Georgia at the turn of the century, would not seem to have much in common.
Two women will be aboard when the Amoco Louisiana, latest unit of the American Oil Company's tanker fleet to be "jumboized," makes her sea trials tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Dinner-party conversation here this weekend -- it is a safe bet -- will be devoted largely to speculation on these questions:
MATSU, China, Oct. 12 -- On the surface at least, life on this northern Chinese Nationalist outpost appears not to have changed throughout the current crisis in the Taiwan Strait.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 18 -- The sudden death of Pakistan's ailing parliamentary system on Oct. 7 was the work of two determined and forceful men, President Iskander Mirza and Gen. Mohammed Ayub Khan, Commander in Chief.
Antibiotic drugs, which have powerfully shaped the course of modern medicine since World War II, were the subject of an international conference last week in Washington.

The Great Southwest Corporation is building a warehouse and distribution center on its 5,000-acre industrial district in the Dallas-Fort Worth, Tex. area. The Great Southwest Distribution Center costing about $20,000,000 will be highly mechanized and fully automatic for unloading, storing, loading and accounting.
Plans have been completed for the eighth annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic, which will be held on Nov. 25 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

GREENE, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- This seems to be supreme wood duck headquarters for the Eastern United States, which creates a serious problem in duck recognition. Since a hunter is allowed only one wood duck per day by law, he must be able to separate them from the mallards and blacks.
The Grand Union Company, the nation's second-oldest food chain, has entered the discount house business in a big way.

TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- The Japanese automobile industry is renewing its efforts to turn out lower-priced small cars, designed for export to the United States and other overseas markets as well as for sale here.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 18 -With the Nov. 25 general election little more than a month off, Alaska Democrats are confident of taking three state-wide offices and are fighting hard for the fourth.
ISLA MUJERES, Mexico, Oct. 5 -- This small island, the eastern most outpost of Mexico, is bracing itself for a profound change in its ancient mode of life.

CHARLIE RUGGLES, who has been portraying lovable old codgers of one sort or another for a long time, is doing a sophisticated lovable old codger in "The Pleasure of His Company," which opens in New York on Wednesday.

ONE night in 1926, the brilliant young Broadway composer George Gershwin, tired out after a day's rehearsal of his latest musical, "Oh, Kay," picked up a copy of a novel by DuBose Heyward called "Porgy." In this vivid story of the selfless love of a crippled Negro beggar in Charleston, S. C., for a beautiful but fast-living and weak-willed girl, Gershwin at once saw the foundation for the American opera he longed to write.

Further light on September's upturn in business in the St. Louis area was brought out in the consumption of power by the important industries. Chemical and allied industries' consumption last month was about 2 1/4 per cent above that a year earlier, whereas for August it was down 20 per cent.
Many subscribers have been reported for the theatre party and supper dance for the benefit of Boys Harbor on Oct. 30.

LECTURING in a Chicago theatre one warmish evening in October, 1871, George Francis Train, the ubiquitous world traveler, intoned to his audience: "This is the last public address that will be delivered within these walls! A terrible calamity is impending over the City of Chicago! More I cannot say; more I dare not utter."
A sleepy maker of band instruments has awakened in the last two years as if seventy-six trombones and 110 cornets had suddenly marched up its street.

YONKERS, Oct. 18 (AP) -Charming Barbara, a 4-year-old mare, made her move at the half to win tonight's juniorfree-for-all trot by three and a half lengths from Valiant Rodney at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:02 4/5.

LOME, French Togoland, Oct. 11 -- An exchange shrouded in discretion occurred in Paris in the last week of September between Bernard Cornut-Gentille, Minister for Overseas France, and Sylvanus Olympio, Premier of the Autonomous Republic of Togoland.

Wilt (The Stilt) Chamberlain made his New York debut and the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association made their first appearance of the 1958-59 season at Madison Square Garden last night.

THE Allabout Books have become such a respected addition to the young readers' scientific library that it might appear captious to call attention to their shortcomings. The contribution which they have made is obvious, but these books are most successful when their sub ject is limited and when they are produced by experts in the various fields of science who also know how to write for children.

TWO hard-pressed wartime courtships, set against the background of bombed and bravely warring England, with all four participants uncomplaining in their harried efforts to do more than their bit, are chronicled in D. K. Findlay's starkly moving novel, "Search for Amelia."
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Army is adopting the soft approach to a proposal that would strip it of its missile research team, Wilber M. Brucker said today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Bob Hickey and his favorite receiver, Rich Kreitling, paced Illinois to a 20-8 victory over Minnesota today. It was the Illini's first victory of the year and its first on the Gopher's home field since 1919.

WHETHER or not autumn is the appropriate season for remembrance, this week's program of art exhibitions offers a number of interesting backward glances. The most extensive of these opens up at the Metropolitan Museum, where American painting from Colonial times to the present may be studied with pleasure and profit in the work of fourteen selected masters.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- All British troops will be withdrawn from Jordan by about Nov. 11 the Ministry of Defense announced today.

When Secretary General Hammarskjold reported last week on the operations of the U. N. Emergency Force in the Suez area, one was reminded of many things past and perhaps made vaguely aware of what the late H. G. Wells called the shape of things to come.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- It now is within logic that earth's final rulers will be a race of lifeless, emotionless machines with superhuman brains.

BACKSTAGE complications of an unusual sort caused the Columbia Broadcasting System to lose a $4,500,000 program sale last week. The Texas Company, maker of Texaco products, was set to buy a twelve-program television package when a seemingly minor dispute about the first show in the series erupted into an unsolvable problem.

ROBERTO IGLESIAS is a distinguished artist. When he flashed momentarily through, Carnegie Hall in the spring of last year, that seemed likely; now that he has played a whole week (in the Hurok International Festival at the Broadway Theatre) it is definitely confirmed.
WARSAW, Oct. 18 -- Alas for the fate of the King's borscht, alas for the fate of bigos!
An expansion program at Jewish Memorial Hospital, Broadway and 196th Street, is scheduled to get under way early next year.

There is no crisis in higher education, declared Stringfellow Barr, former president of St. John's College, last week. Dr. Barr, advocate of the Great Books curriculum, said sputnik gave only a momentary illusion of crisis.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -Prolonging the life span is a mixed blessing for the human race, and a potential tensionmaker for the family, delegates to the National Conference on Family Life sponsored by the Methodist Church were told here today.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 18 -The annual Holly Fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James the Less here will take place in the church house on Nov. 10 and 11.

TO see "The World of Suzie Wong" is to doubt the sophistication of the Broadway theatre. Some worldly people inhabit the brisk little area where the business of the theatre is transacted. They have seen everything.

WEST ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 18 -- In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Anastasia here this morning, Miss Eileen Patricia O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bartholomew O'Brien of Tcaneck, became the bride of John Myron Farrell Jr. He is the son of Mrs. John Farrell of Manhasset, L. I., and the late Mr. Farrell.

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 6 -With the double purpose of fighting growing unemployment and conserving El Salvador's foreign exchange, the Government is aiding the development of private industries with loans.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- The Mayors of Kyoto and Nara, two famous Japanese shrine cities, are conducting a drive for financial assistance to the American widow of the late Harvard archaeologist who is credited with saving the two cities from destruction in World War II.

EACH week, millions of viewers tune in on 172 television stations from coast to coast, submerge to periscope depth, level off on the sofa and concentrate on a half-hour of noisily coughing claxons and thunderous depth charges that is labeled "The Silent Service."
For the second time in more than twenty years, yields on common stock are less than yields on high-grade bonds.

SOME years after Georges Bizet died (1875), his widow married a wealthy man named Emile Straus, became one of the great hostesses of Paris and an intimate friend of Marcel Proust, who modeled his Duchesse de Guermantes after her. A dozen years ago, while preparing an English edition of Proust's letters, Mina Curtiss was led inevitably to the Straus family papers, which were then in the possession of the eccentric Mine.

TWO centuries after the British Army's Brig. Gen. John Forbes captured Fort Duquesne from the French and Indians at the confluence of the Monongahela and Allegheny Rivers, at what is now Pittsburgh, Pa.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Arab sources said here today that Tunisia had offered to resume diplomatic relations with the United Arab Republic if Salah ben Youssef, Tunisian opposition leader, were expelled from Cairo.

Mr. and Mrs. William R. Fugitt of Beckley, W. Va., have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Fugitt of Washington, to James McClatchy of Sacramento, Calif. He is the son of Mrs. Carlos K. McClatchy of Fresno, Calif., and the late Mr. McClatchy.
The mother of the fighter sat silently with her head bowed, her eyes half-closed, her fingers ripping nervously at the rolled-up piece of Kleenex in her lap.
Ridley Watts, executive vice president and treasurer of Spartan Mills, Inc., textile sales agent here, has resigned effective Nov. 30. He has been with the company since 1945.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- The passes of Bobby Franklin and Billy Brewer sparked Mississippi to a 24-0 victory over Hardin-Simmons today before 16,000 fans.

DR. HARRY F. HARLOW, the distinguished psychologist at the University of Wisconsin, has built an artificial mother for the monkey babies in his laboratory. He padded a block of wood with foam rubber for softness; wrapped it with terry cloth for cuddliness; arranged a nipple for milk supply; installed a light bulb for warmth, and fixed a head with two eyelike, gleaming red bicycle reflectors for motherly solicitude.

New Utrecht High's unbeat- en, unscored upon and untied eleven rolled to its third straight victory, 22--0, over Jefferson at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. Ai Leibo- witz, a senior halfback, scored ion runs of 7, 62 and 38 yards. The loss was the first for Jef- ferson after a pair of victories.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -From this vantage point, the state capital, it can be seen already that the next session of the State Legislature, which will start in April, 1959, will have to consider many proposals for an extension of legalized gambling in Florida.
Highway progress and safety were the themes yesterday at the opening of the New England Thruway to toll travel.

JULES DASSIN, the expatriate American director who scored an explosive hit here with "Rififi," his suspenseful, French-made film account of a daring robbery, is preparing to tackle a noted and purely American subject in the near future.

A UNIQUE exhibit which opened on the lower level of Grand Central station, this week, is full of do-it-yourself projects and ideas. Jointly sponsored by AMF DeWalt Power Tools and United States Plywood, the exhibit will be on view to the public every weekday from 8:30 A. M. to 6:30 P. M. until Dec. 31.
The Committe for Modern Courts has appointed a legal advisory committee to study new plans for reorganization of the state's court system.

HONG KONG, Oct. 18 -- In both warfare and politics the Chinese Communists have always followed the practice of avoiding head-on assaults against well-defended positions. They appear once again to have pursued this course of conduct in dealing with the United States and Nationalist China.

A large subscription has been reported for the Oct. 29 performance of "Goldilocks" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre. It is being sponsored by Chapter Number One Auxiliary of the Berkshire Industrial Farm.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 18 -Officials sought here tonight to solve an election registration problem caused by a Post Office delay in the return of registration notices.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 -- United States troops in Lebanon are in the final phase of moving out. Preparations were reported unofficially today for an airlift beginning tomorrow that would take most of the remaining Army personnel here back to their base in West Germany.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 18 -- The United States must recognize in its dealings with foreign nations that the Soviet Union is not going to collapse and that China is here to stay and grow ever more powerful, Adlai E. Stevenson said in an address here tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- When a young woman in eighteenth century costume was borne through central London in a sedan chair last January, it was no mere stunt to publicize a coming Hollywood spectacle. The earnest object was to call attention to Britain's obsolete highways.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Lafayette remained undefeated in the Middle Atlantic Conference's University Division today by whipping Temple, 35 -- 0, before 8,000 homecoming fans at Fisher Field.

HERE is another Dogpatch novel, the vernacular tale hillbilly boy and his outlandish dog who get into familiar scrapes, perform the heroic deed, and finally win the 10-year-old heroine. Clancy Carlile, the author, sets it in what apparently are the backcountry hills of Oklahoma, populates it with people who are all "characters," and runs through the usual list of incidents.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 17 -"We do not say that Iran is an undeveloped country. It is a rather rapidly developing country. And Teheran is rapidly overdeveloping."

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Mrs. Langdon Warner said recently that she was unaware of any fund drive being conducted for her benefit in Japan. She said she preferred that nothing further be said about her late husband's being credited with having persuaded the United States Air Force to spare Kyoto and Nara from fire bombs in 1945.
MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (AP) -Two Soviet news organs today wrote off the New York State elections as an impossible choice between a pair of reactionary "billionaires."

IN his long-standing battle with the bugs, the gardener has an ally in the strange looking praying mantis. During its life span one mantis devours millions of smaller chewing, sucking and generally pesky insects.

THOSE who feel the day's novels are becoming unreadably long may now accept Aubrey Menen as a writer of spirit. Mr. Menen the other day delivered to Scribner's the manuscript of a new book, "The Fig Tree."

PRUDERY is always with us, only the subjects about which we are prudish vary. Often it is difficult -- even impossible -for a later generation to understand the reason for some particular prudery of its ancestors.
The Sidney Hillman Foundation has announced its ninth annual contest for outstanding social contributions during 1958 in journalism and other forms of communication.

HERE at last is Muriel Rukeyser's first book of poems since 1950. It includes all her recent short poems, a long narrative poem, "Suite for Lord Timothy Dexter," and a group of translations from the Mexican poet, Octavio Paz.

CAIRO, Oct. 18 -- The Council of the Arab League agreed today to assess its ten members 12,000,000 Egyptian ($34,400,000 at the official rate of exchange) for support of the Algerian rebellion against France.

PEPOTE was not ambitious. Sometime in the future he intended to be a shoeshine boy, but that could wait. Meanwhile he was living life to the full, a 6-year-old orphan sleeping in a hovel on the outskirts of Madrid, riding the water-sprinkler, flaunting his coat like a matador at the indifferent donkeys, thinking up ways of making a quick peseta -- and looking after his uncle Jacinto.

INCREDIBLE events occurred on the continent of North America when a decrepit steamer docked at Seattle in 1897, carrying two tons of pure gold belonging to prospectors who had discovered it near the distant junction of the Yukon and Klondike Rivers.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 18 -- A new hospital, of circular construction, is nearing completion in this Boston suburb. The $1,500,000 facility is due to be opened about Jan. 1.

ARGENTIA, Nfld., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- A United States Navy plane carrying personnel to duty in Newfoundland crashed into Placentia Bay today while trying to make an instrument landing with twenty-nine persons aboard.
Nelson A. Rockefeller charged in a statement last night that Governor Harriman was trying to avoid a debate on state issues that would subject his record to scrutiny.

Ten free lectures on the fine and applied arts are being offered by thhe New York Public Library each Tuesday at 6:15 P. M., beginning this week. Until now, the spring and fall lecture series were held in the Fifth Avenue building.
About 120 persons marked the second anniversary of the Hungarian uprising against Communist rule with demonstrations on Park Avenue and in Times Square last night.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 -- California Republicans looked forward this week-end to a two-day visit by President Eisenhower as a stimulant to their flagging fortunes.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 18 -- A petition calling for the investigation of alleged political influence in the judiciary committee of the Nassau County Bar Association was being circulated today among lawyers belonging to the association.
As many as six United States companies may soon establish plants in Northern Ireland, according to Major W. Cecil McKee, Lord Mayor of Belfast.
TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- The Japanese Welfare Ministry announced today that the natural rise in Japan's population, which had been showing a downward trend since 1950, was again on the increase.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -On the first touchdown of today's game at sunny Franklin Field, Steve Sebo, the University of Pennsylvania's head coach, or his quarterback elected to kick for the extra point, which was a successful move.
The Federal Reserve Board indicated last week that it thought the stock market boom was getting a bit out of hand.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Quarterback Jimmy Dunn threw a 5-yard touchdown pass to David Hudson in the last eight seconds today and Florida gained a 6-6 tie with Vanderbilt before 38,000 rain-drenched Homecoming fans.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Reginald N. Webster's Quill won the $135,960 Gardenia Stakes at Garden State Park today by a half-length from the King Ranch's Resaca.
THIS coming week-end New York City will be host to the most significant contract bridge match that can be played on this continent this year. At stake will be the North American team championship.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Oklahoma rebounded sharply in a bid to regain its national football prestige by beating the Kansas Jayhawks, 43 -- 0, in a Big Eight game played before 30,000 fans today.

Dr. James B. Conant, president emeritus of Harvard University, who has been making a study of the American high school, has urged that each school, after giving aptitude tests, make an "academic inventory'' each year to find out what its good students are studying.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 18 -- The East - West struggle showed up in the voting of awards at the Brussels World Fair this closing week. Still, there were signs that exhibitors had learned something about each other by working side by side for six months.

NOW having read the book myself, I feel it would be a public service to say that Charles Frankel, in his review of William Barrett's "Irrational Man" did much less than justice to the position taken by the author. * * *

A NUMBER of major carriers received permission last week from the Civil Aeronautics Board to raise their fares on flights within the country. The new rates going into effect tomorrow will apply to round-trip and family-plan fares. On roundtrip tickets the present 5 per cent discount will be abolished; and family-plan discounts will be lowered from 50 to 33 1/3 per cent.

A beautifully excuted forgery, bound into a copy of the Gutenberg Bible, will be on view this week -- Bible Week -- at the General Theological Seminary. The seminary is at 175 Ninth Avenue, in Chelsea Square.

WELCH, W. Va., Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson accused the Republicans tonight of "running.against Eugene Debs," the late Socialist leader, and of talcing a "can't afford it" attitude toward the nation's problems.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- If it is true as argued every four years that "nobody ever knew how to be President until confronted with the problems of the Presidency," the same cannot be said of his first assistant and chief of staff.

FOR THIS WEEK: Rake up fallen leaves around rosebushes to prevent overwintering of black spot spores. . . . Store the dahlia tubers and gladiolus corms after they have dried. . . . Clean and oil pruning shears before storing them. . . . Finish cutting back faded foliage of perennials; pull up frost-blackened annuals. . . . Do not drain waterlily pools; the water prevents cracking and buckling during winter months.

PONCE, P. R., Oct. 18 -Puerto Rico is a laboratory in the ways that Government can help bring economic and social progress. But on the southern coast here, Roman Catholics are celebrating a classic nongovernmental effort of their own.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 18 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal was nominated for the Presidency of Venezuela tonight by the Republican Democratic Union. He agreed to run.
TORONTO, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Ron Stewart scored two goals tonight as the Toronto Maple leafs defeated the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 2, for their first victory of the National Hockey League season.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democratic nominee for Senator, said today that Federal aid for school construction would ease the pressure on property owners in New Jersey school districts.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 18 -- Williams downed Bowdoin, 48--28, at Whittier Field today. Long runs and passes featured the game, with only two touchdown plays covering fewer than 10 yards.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- With a short, crisp set of instructions to the military commander in Algeria, Premier Charles de Gaulle this week transformed the political atmosphere in France and produced a wave of almost irrational optimism over the chances of a settlement in the Algerian rebellion.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Colgate, outclassed from the outset, was no match for Princeton's football team today and the Tigers rolled to the easiest of 40-13 victories before 23,500 spectators at Palmer Stadium. Princeton's superiority was clearly established by half-time, at which stage the home side enjoyed a three-touchdown spread.

The City Housing Authority looked back yesterday across ten years and 1,000,000 applications and found some interesting changes among the New Yorkers who want to move into public housing.
DAFFODILS always are abundant at the spring flower shows. Cut specimens in massive displays are seen in horticultural classes. Others are the focal points of high-styled arrangements.

The forty-fifth annual meeting of the American Cancer Society will open tomorrow at the Biltmore Hotel.

Employment in Pennsylvania rose 14,700 between mid-July to and Mid-August, according to the State Bureau of Employment Security. The Aug. 15 total was 4,247,900, reflecting increases of 11,500 in manufacturing, 4,900 in non-manufacturing and 5,400 in agricultural industries.
Baltimore and Cleveland, the National Football League's only unbeaten teams, are expected to retain that status after the afternoon.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- A Soviet TU-104 jet airliner crashed yesterday at Kanash, 400 miles east of Moscow. All on board were killed

ANY reader of John Keats' recent book, "The Insolent Chariots," in search of a second report on what's wrong with the automobile business, need look no further than Harold Livingston's novel, "The Detroiters."

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Rio Grande, on its biggest rise in this century, continued to roll on at flood level. It spread misery among an estimated total of 11,000 persons made homeless by high water.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (UPI) -- Andy Hebenton scored at 8:15 of the final period tonight and the New York Rangers gained a hard-earned 2-2 tie with the Montreal Canadiens. The deadlock was the Rangers' fourth of the National Hockey League season.

THE French film industry's fall production schedule shows some twenty films now under way -- a drop of eight from last year at this time. With the exception of a bare half-dozen, their subject matter is exclusively limited to a collection of froth-light comedies, triangular tales of love and one or two "serie noir" melodramas.

THE Giants wolfed their steak breakfasts just before they played the Chicago Cardinals three weeks ago and moved contentedly but ponderously to either end of the dining hall. At one side was Vince Lombardi, the offensive coach, with his attacking platoon. At the other side was Tom Landry, the defensive coach, with his platoon of tacklers.

The appointment of Dr. Ruth P. Mack as senior management consultant in charge of economic and fiscal research was announced by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse yesterday. Her annual salary will be $11,600.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Vic Stasiuk scored three times tonight in pacing the Boston Bruins to a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game.

SYOSSET, L. I., Oct. 19 -- Although they are too young to vote, a group of students at Syosset High School here have been taking an active interest in the current political campaigns in Nassau County.

Fundamental Investors, Inc., reported over the week-end net assets of $457,380,970, equal to $17 a share on 26,900,447 shares outstanding on Sept. 30. A BRIGHT answer to the question of what to serve for dinner is the new "Betty Crocker's Dinner for Two Cook Book." It was prepared by the home economics staff of General Mills and published by Simon and Schuster.
A leading American retail executive asserted last week that "Europe's Common Market is going to succeed in spite of initial difficulties, complexities and the doubts of skeptics."

A way to "compromise the many violently opposed points of view" on the Washington Square Park roadway has been suggested to the Board of Estimate by the Park Association of New York City.

Net income of the Eastman Kodak Company in the twelve weeks ended Sept. 7 (the third fiscal quarter) was $26,299,098, a gain of about 3 per cent compared with profit of $25,434,611 for the like period a year earlier. Thomas J. Hargrave, chairman, and Albert K. Chapman, president, said that the earnings were above the 1957 level for the first time this year.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 19 -High-level political sources here predicted today that Secretary Dulles would assure President Chiang at their meeting this week that there had been no basic change in United States policy on China.

IN 1953, when Lincoln Kirstein was serving as artistic administrator at the City Center, a joyous, imaginative production of Rossini's "Cenerentola" was introduced into the repertory. Julius Rudel, now general director of the opera company, has had the wit to revive this work after an absence of several seasons. Its return filled the Center last night with the high spirits and gaiety of Rossini's genius.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly downward last week to close in somewhat lower ground, according to the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close of trading on the exchange on Friday, active futures were down 10 to 36 points for the week.
Contributions of $2,221,100 from twenty-three business companies to the projected Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts were announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns' powerful aerial and ground offense overwhelmed the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27-10, today. It was the fourth straight National Football League victory for the Browns and the second over the Steelers.

A tract of land fronting 1,000 feet on Amboy Road, east of Richmond Avenue, Eltingville, S. I., has been purchased by Food Fair Stores for development as a shopping center. The supermarket chain will have a store containing 24,000 square feet in the center.

Undefeated Fordham Prep gained its fourth victory of the football season yesterday by crushing Iona Prep, 34-0, at Fordham Field in the Bronx. The victors have not been scored upon.

SANDS POINT, L. I., Oct. 19 -An eighty-five-acre tract of woodland, used for sheep-grazing by English settlers in 1647, was dedicated as a wild life preserve by Governor Harriman today.

Henderson had just found gold on a near-by creek that he called Gold Bottom. Obeying the code of the North, he told Carmack about it so that he, too, could stake a claim.

Seismographs in the Middle West oscillated furiously Saturday. The toll was something fearful.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Communism is losing strength in Western Europe. After thirteen years of massive and threatening power, the great Marxist parties of France and Italy have started perceptibly to decline. Democratic socialism and other liberal forces are beginning to chip off the fellow-traveling vote so long magnetized by the appeal of Moscow's propaganda.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Federal taxation of wagering reaches its seventh anniversary tomorrow without having brought in much revenue or wiped out much gambling.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The earth's magnetic field can now be measured with greatly increased accuracy through a newly developed device utilizing the spinning nucleus of the hydrogen atom.
WARSAW, Oct. 19 -- The last of the German war criminals to go on trial in Poland will be taken from his prison cell tomorrow to face the judgment of a Warsaw court.

ROME, Oct. 19 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, arrived here tonight for the conclave of Cardinals that will elect the new Pope. He received a highly emotional welcome from several hundred Poles and Romans.
The body of an Air National Guard pilot whose plane exploded and crashed Saturday night off the New Jersey coast was recovered yesterday by a Coast Guard cutter.
Mrs. Charles A. Dana Jr. and Mrs. Robert E. Coulson, chairmen of the committee for the Mistletoe Ball, have been meeting with their aides to further plans for the event.

In a deal involving more than $30,000,000, United Artists Associated, Inc., an affiliate of the United Artists Corporation, film distributing company, has acquired all the assets of Associated Artists Productions Corporation. HONG KONG, Monday, Oct 20 (AP) -- A Chinese Moslem leader is reported in trouble for promoting armed rioting against Communist authorities in the Northwest China province of Ningsia.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Leading by 25 points in the third period, the Syracuse Nationals had to fight off a furious rally by the Detroit Pistons before emerging with a 103-94 victory in their nationally televised National Basketball Association game today. The game opened the N.B.A. season.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 19 Princeton University will grant an annual salary increase of $1,000 for its professors and $500 for associate professors, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, the president, announced today.

The nation's intercity common carrier truckers experienced a sharp decline in traffic during August, according to preliminary figures issued over the week-end by the research department of the American Trucking Associations.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 -- The steel market gained further strength last week, and chances were bright for additional expansion in production this week. While some car makers were ordering more steel, at least one auto company asked some mills to slow deliveries or hold the steel.

The Beckwith estate, a seventy-five-year-old holding in the Riverdale section of the Bronx has been sold by Ruth E. Beckwith to a builder for improvement with an eight-story apartment house. FRESHLY harvested Louisiana yams are here in abundance. From now through November, the supply will be at its peak, and thrifty homemakers are urged to give them a prominent place on menus.
