From the Oregon border to Orange County south of Los Angeles a visitor hears the same story that has followed President Eisenhower since he came into national politics: We like Ike

A king's ransom in eighteenth-century art objects, received recently by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is on view, in part, in the Great Hall. The Samuel H. Kress Foundation was the donor of "the towering gift," as it is described by James J. Rorimer, director of the museum.
TO Mohammed Ayub Khan, a soldier son of a Pathan bugler in the old Indian Army, politics has always seemed a dirty business.

It has been estimated that within a generation military service has touched the lives of 75 per cent of American families. Leaders in government and the military agree that service in the armed forces will be an important factor in the lives of a majority of the country's young people for many years to come.

The failure of the Peronists in Argentina to make anything but a minor nuisance of themselves last Friday is proof of their present weakness. Oct. 17 is the great day of peronism, since it was on that day in 1945 that Juan Peron took power. The Peronists didn't even dare to call a general strike Friday.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The unbeaten Baltimore Colts sent the Detroit Lions to another defeat today, crushing the defending world champions, 40 -- 14, before 55,190 spectators.
YVES ST. LAURENT, a whiz where the trapeze is concerned, is just as good at walking a tightrope.

A drop in the number of grain shipments last week halted the five-week upturn of the steamship charter market. Without the usual support of grain, the sole sustainer of the market in recent weeks, volume plunged to one of the low points of the year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The chairman of the Republican National Committee said today that the election of a big Democratic Congress would "immeasurably undermine" President Eisenhower in dealing with the Communists.
Canadian dollar was strong and actively traded in the foreign exchange market during the past week. British pound sterling was steady and moved within a narrow range.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan refused today to restrict entry of duty-free cotton textiles from Hong Kong, India and Pakistan.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 19 -- A leading scientist urged the Western big powers tonight to establish an "international monetary fund for science" to be used for the development of the scientific and technological potential of small democratic nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--Pentagon officials are considering sympathetically a request to help Spain transform her army into a pentomic-type force. Meeting the request might cost more than $100,000,000.

THE Hewitt Gallery opens the season in new quarters at 22 East Sixty-sixth Street. A group show, presenting gallery regulars, includes varied fare ranging from the extreme illusionism of Robert McClusky to nearly abstract paintings by Elias Friedensohn, whose sepiatoned compositions of emaciated heads become more and more obscured by the heavy, deathly curtains of paint above them.

Both here and abroad television problems continue to receive public attention. Locally and investigation is being pressed into the ethics of quiz programs with special reference to procedure governing contestants.
The sponsors of "The $64,000 Question" are shopping for a television program of another type as a possible replacement for the long-running quiz series.
Five teen-agers were each held in $2,500 bail in Felony Court yesterday in the stabbing of a man at 122 East Seventy-eighth Street Saturday night.
Sante Uberto Barbieri, Presiding Bishop of the Methodist Church in Argentina, Uruguay and Bolivia, said here yesterday that the responsibilities of a Christian were international in scope.
Four films will arrive in first-run theaters this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A magazine has found a majority of Federal judges who answered a survey critical of the Supreme Court.

In tiffs state election year the voters of New York ought to set, as one of their major objectives, the improvement of the quality of the membership in their Legislature. This is not to be achieved by following any blanket injunction to vote Republican, Democratic or Liberal. The prevailing mediocrity in the Legislature crosses party lines with complete impartiality.

A DELIGHTFUL new Adele made her debut with the New York City Opera yesterday afternoon in Johann Strauss' "Die Fledermaus." She is Monte Amundsen, a lyric coloratura soprano, who looked and sounded as if she were born to sing that particular role.
The Arthur Curtiss James residence, a white marble building at Park Avenue and Sixty-ninth Street, will be torn down to make way for an apartment house.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) -- Johnny Olszewski, the fullback, ignited Washington's long-dormant running attack today and led the Redskins to a 37-21 victory over the Green Bay Packers in a National Football League game before 25,228.
The New York City Opera Company presented "La Boheme" at the City Center Saturday evening. John Reardon appeared for the first time with the company as Marcello.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 19 -- Volumes in trading all last week were the heaviest in the history of the Zurich Stock Exchange. The only comparable parallels occurred in the crisis of 1955 and 1956.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 19 -- A great improvement is noticeable in Dutch foreign trade.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Mike Hawthorn, a strapping Briton who once quit racing, today won the world auto driving championship by finishing second to Stirling Moss, another English ace, in the Grand Prix of Morocco.
Winslow Ames, a museum curator, called the Christian laity yesterday to "the ministry of reconciliation."
City Councilman David Ross, Bronx Democrat, announced yesterday that he would introduce in the Council tomorrow a bill aimed at those who evade the city's 3 per cent compensating use tax.
IN SO FAR as tricky heating systems are concerned, a little knowledge goes a long way on a cold night.

A 33-year-old lawyer from Farmingdale, N. J., told the police yesterday that he had been kidnapped here Thursday afternoon by supporters of Fidel Castro, Cuban rebel leader. He said that he had been held in a Bronx apartment until Saturday morning.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 -- The United States scored a diplomatic triumph last night in an international film festival here.
MARLBORO, Md., Oct. 19 (UPI) -- A wind-whipped fire killed twenty-seven race horses at the Marlboro race track today. A big stable was destroyed and two others damaged.

The economic threat posed by Russia has become an increasingly popular subject for writers. Few, if any, of the recent books have related the peril so closely to the interests of American investors as this one.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 19 -- The Brussels World's Fair, dedicated to the theme that man can make the atomic age serve the people of the world, closed tonight.

WHEN Pop Warner had become football's Grand Old Man, the leonine master of gridiron strategy was invariably introduced as "the man who invented the single wing, the double wing and Jim Thorpe." It usually brought a snicker, especially among the graybeards who remembered Thorpe as the greatest player of all.

" SMALL WORLD" on Channel 2 last night offered an amusing instance of tactful handling of a touchy subject. Dr. Willard F. Libby, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, raised the question of why more public attention was not paid to the problem of controlling population growth throughout the world.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Some sixty leaders of business, education and government called today for closer coordination of Federal debt management and tax and expenditure decisions with efforts of the Federal Reserve System to control inflation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Interior Department announced today the establishment of a Branch of Archaeology. It has started operations with a staff of seven employes.

The voters of New York will decide whether Congressman Kenneth Keating or the District Attorney of New York County is better qualified for election to the United States Senate. Ken Keating has served twelve years as the Representative from the Thirty-eighth Congressional District, where in 1956 he received a larger vote than President Eisenhower.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 -- Port promoters here are counting on an extensive expansion of dock and cargo facilities to meet the expected rapid growth of Pacific Ocean commerce.

With a 4-0 defeat of England in the eighth round, the Soviet Union went well out into the lead in the international chess team tournament in Munich with a total score of 23-9, according to a report received last night from Germany.
Total United States waterborne trade, both foreign and domestic, soared to a record high last year when 1,131,400,000 short tons of cargo were moved by ships and barges.
A WOMAN can now wear cashmere from neck to knees, thanks to Bernhard Altmann.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- French liberals who favor negotiations with the Algerian National Liberation Front will present themselves as candidates in the forthcoming Algerian elections, it was indicated tonight.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Secretary of State Dulles and Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd discussed world affairs at a dinner tonight.
Carmine G. De Sapio, the Democratic national committeeman, charged last night that Republicans were trying to sell New York voters three Nelson Rockefellers -- none of them real.
HONG KONG, Oct. 19 -- Under the new system of communes, eight provinces in north and northeast China plan to double this year's record harvests in 1959.

Jack R. Hogan, a dapper, gray-haired Chicago insurance man, played Santa Claus at Belmont yesterday with $2 winning tickets on his Anxious Moment. The 4-year-old gray gelding had just won the $29,300 New York Handicap and each $2 ticket was worth $20.60.

One of the autumn's perennial problems is with us again -- what to do with the fallen leaves. Two main schools rise to give answer to this, although as in most philosophical discussions there are minor divergencies among scholars.
BERNARDSTON, Mass., Oct. 20 -- Opening day of the Massachusetts upland game season couldn't have been more beautiful, but something must have slipped.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Four independent United States oil companies have given up a vast prospecting operation in the Western Desert of Egypt after spending about $30,000,000 in four and a half years.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The six common market countries proposed today that a European free trade area should come into force Jan. 1. This is the date on which the first tariff reductions inside the European Economic Community (Common Market) will take place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Treasury bill rate fell back a little this week, the treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on the latest offering of $1,800,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 2.804 per cent, compared with 2.927 per cent last week.
Resumption of the shelling of Quemoy strengthened several commodities on the New York exchanges yesterday. Wool, cocoa and copper were sharply higher in active trading.

Representative Eugene J. Keogh, Democratic-Liberal incumbent in Brooklyn's Ninth Congressional District for the last twenty-two years, is serenely confident of re-election. By saying he does not like to assume anything, he merely hedges against overconfidence.

THE newest equine dreamboat is a big and handsome 2-year-old named First Landing. He gives off the same electric sparks that made matinee idols of Nashua and Native Dancer. He also carries Eddie Arcaro and that's a hearty recommendation in itself.

Queens College will formally install Dr. Harold W. Stoke as its third president tomorrow. Dr. Stoke has been in office since Sept. 1, succeeding Dr. John J. Theobald, now City Superintendent of Schools.
John F. Gehan retired yesterday as president, director and member of the executive committee of American Export Lines.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. improved its sales and earnings in the third quarter over those of the two previous quarters, but results for the first nine months remained well below those of last year.
Recent evidence that viruses may cause human cancer is expected to bring a parade of virus researchers into cancer studies.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's speech tonight at the Shrine Auditorium:
The policeman who shot and killed four men at a bar early Sunday morning had stopped in at least three bars before the shooting.
TAIPEI, Oct. 20 (Reuters) - A Chinese scientist described Communist China as "hell" today when he arrived in Taiwan after five months on the mainland.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -Post office officials are more concerned with the use of mails by "hate" publications since the recent bombings of places of worship.
HONG KONG, Oct. 20 -- Communist China made a new charge tonight that United States warships had intruded into its territorial waters.

Phillip P. Zipes, real estate investor, has contract to buy the seventeen-story apartment building at 245-9 West 104th Street, at the northwest corner of Broadway. The parcel is being sold by a client of Abraham Sobil, attorney.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and The Cloisters, the museum's medieval branch in Fort Tryon Park, have reported record attendance for the year ended June 30.

UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -- A toll of twentythree thoroughbreds and a lead pony was counted today in the $100,000 fire that swept two barns and damaged two others at Marlboro race track yesterday.
Blood will be donated to the Red Cross today by the 104th Field Artillery Battalion of the New York National Guard at the armory at 93-05 168th Street, Jamaica, Queens.
Net income and gross revenues of the Detroit Edison Company and its subsidiaries declined in the year ended Sept. 30, the company announced yesterday.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating told a rally in Harlem last night that he had a labor reform program that would end contracts that victimize Negro workers.

Plans have been initiated to set up in this country a nation-wide committee to deal with refugee problems. A preliminary meeting has been held in Washington at which representatives of about a dozen private and governmental bodies were present. What is projected is not a government operation, although the first meetings were held in the State Department, with Government sanction, and the department itself was represented by several high officers.

SUFFIELD, Conn., Oct. 20 -The ancient bell that hangs from a scaffold under one of Suffield Academy's many ancients elms has tolled following many an Orange and Black victory. Today the heavy, tarnished bell was examined by Bill Pendleton, the athletic director.

An economist with a lengthy career in education, business and government has been picked by the Commission on Money and Credit as its director of research. He is Dr. Bertrand Fox, director of research at the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration.
NOW available is a new variation on quiche Lorraine, one of the masterpieces of Mme. Colette Hebert's French bakery at 1136 Third Avenue, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets.
The Turkish Government is reported to be considering new measures designed to discipline, intimidate and perhaps silence much of the press of Turkey.

A New Jersey school, making its first entry into varsity football competition this year, is regarded as a power to watch in the future. The school is Bergen Catholic in Oradell, where the Christian Brothers of Ireland have made sports an integral part of student life.

Remedies that go beyond police enforcement of traffic regulations must be found to alleviate the city's vehicular congestion if business life is not to be choked off, a police official told realty men last night.

NEWARK, Oct. 20 -- New Jersey's fight on air pollution was demonstrated today. Some of the results were shown in a four-county tour by members of the New Jersey State Air Pollution Control Commission, municipal health officers and newspaper men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Supreme Court declined today to hear claims by the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation's Frigidaire Division for refunds of millions of dollars in manufacturers excise taxes.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department off Agriculture follows:
A sage thrasher, said to be only the second of its kind ever recorded east of the Mississippi River, was caught on Long Island Saturday by a volunteer bird-bander.
Edward J. Polakowski, a 23year-old part time actor and elevator operator, was sentenced to seven and a half to fifteen years in prison yesterday. He had pleaded guilty to firstdegree manslaughter.
A "sell-out" has been reported for the preview performance of "The Marriage-Go-Round" at the Plymouth Theatre on Oct. 28 for the benefit of the New York City Mission Society.
The United States team tied, 2 -- 2, in matches With Austria and Czechoslovakia in the international chess tournament in Munich, according to a report from Germany yesterday.

I am writing this letter as a former president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and as a present member of its Foreign Policy Committee. I have visited the Far Eastern areas, including the island of Formosa, for several organizations.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Industrials continued to advance on the stock exchange today. However, heavy profit-taking clipped many gains and introduced a sprinkling of losses.
With the onset of a fall season more festive than in many years, women are turning to greater formality.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- A Federal judge dismissed today two French Government suits seeking United States patents on the basic principle of nuclear reactors.
Tributes were paid to the Hungarian freedom fighters in the revolution two years ago at a second anniversary commemoration in Carnegie Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court set aside today the Federal Communications Commission's transfer of television Channel 2 from Springfield, Ill., to St. Louis and its transfer of Channel 8 from Peoria, Ill., to the Davenport -Rock Island-Moline area of Iowa and Illinois.

The Penn-Texas Corporation had a consolidated loss of $747,950, after special charges of $132,920 on sales and operating revenues of $38,436,926, for the eight months ended Aug. 31, 1958. No comparable figures for the previous year were furnished.
MOSCOW, Oct. 20 -- The Soviet Union's new Seven-Year Plan will call on heavy industry to approach by 1965 a number of production goals originally set for 1972.
DENVER, Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower agreed today that Scretary Dulles should make his scheduled visit to Taiwan despite the renewed bombardment of Quemoy.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 20 (AP) -- More than twenty Negroes, seeking to test the validity of Birmingham's new busseating law, were arrested today. Police Chief Jamie Moore said they would be charged with breach of the peace, a misdemeanor.

This is an "off year" for presentation of constitutional issues to the voters in November referendum, so there will be only two amendments and three propositions on the voting machine for state-wide action. We advise a yes vote on the five questions, all but one of which are designed for the encouragement of housing construction.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- Samuel Goldwyn will be honored by the Screen Producers Guild as the recipient of its Milestone Award, to be presented at a banquet in January. The honor is voted by the membership for "historic contribution to the American motion picture."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -The United States Steel Corporation's president asserted today that "unwarranted" Government tax policies were causing a "national crisis" in replacement of industrial capacity.
ANDRE PERUGIA'S French shoe silhouette, its vamp thin and flat and sloping to an oval toe, still reigns supreme in his new spring collection for I. Miller.

Officials of the American Bowling Congress sometimes have the unhappy chore of settling disputes that arise from infractions of rules or misinterpretation. Though each of the nation's bowling leagues is an autonomous body, it must, by A. B. C. regulations, follow the national organization's rules of the game.
AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- British troops began withdrawing from Jordan today.
George Meany, president of the merged labor federation, will attempt to arbitrate the contract dispute between ships' officers and steamship operators in closed hearings that will begin next Tuesday.

The custom smelter price of copper advanced 1 1/2 cents to 30 cents a pound yesterday, as the industry sought to cope with burgeoning industrial and speculative demand in the face of major strikes both in this country and abroad.

During the New York Rangers' training period at Niagara Falls, Ont., Phil Watson, the fiery coach of the Broadway Blues, asked the plucky Wally Hergesheimer this question: "Would you like to join us again?" Hergy's answer: "Why don't you try me?"
LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A new battle of E1 Alamein flared up today, with two British field marshals sniping at each other.
This letter is intended primarily for members of the Congress soon to be elected, but as I am now over 97 years old, I dare not wait.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -Developments in the Taiwan Strait created early demand for grain futures. But the rally falled to hold and prices finished mostly lower on the Board of Trade today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for Pan American World Airways and National Airlines urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to allow an exchange of stock and the leasing of Pan American jets to National.

Eddie Lynch, the West Side pigeon fancier, knocked out Charley Cummings, Philadelphia welterweight, at 1:59 of the ninth round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

All hands were relieved to learn yesterday that the injury to the Giants' Frank Gifford, while severe enough to sideline him for two or three weeks, was not so serious as had been feared. Of course, the most pleased of all was the party of the first part, Gifford.

The situation in French Togoland and the Cameroons, in western Africa, where independent states will take shape by 1960 is illustrative of what can truly be called an enlightened colonial policy on the part of France. It is also an example of the smooth working of the trusteeship system of the United Nations. The object of this system is to prepare dependent peoples for full self-government, and that object is being attained.
Woody Hayes, Ohio State's outspoken football coach, yesterday added to his criticism of Big Ten officials, whom he has accused of allowing "dirty football."
Mayor Wagner announced last night the appointment of six members of a committee to study and report on the feasibility of legalizing off-track betting on horse races. A seventh is to be named later.

Authoritative Hollywood circles have been informed that Charles K. Feldman, independent film producer, is about to receive the screen rights to S. N. Behrman's autobiographical play "The Cold Wind and the Warm." The property is to be acquired by Mr. Feldman through a pre-production arrangement.

HONG KONG, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of today's order ending the ceasefire in the Quemoy area, issued by the Chinese Communist Defense Ministry to Communist troops and published in English by the Hsinhua (New China) news agency:
The women's committee of the United Epilepsy Association will open a $500,000 fund-raising drive at a cocktail party Oct. 29 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh E. Paine of 1 Beekman Place.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Prof. Enrique Rodriguez Fabregat of Uruguay said today he opposed some sections of a report advising changes in the United Nations public information program. He was one of a committee of six that prepared the report for discussion by the General Assembly's Budget Committee.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 20 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus declared today that "it's going to be difficult to even drive Southern Democrats out of the party."
VIENNA, Oct. 20 -- Communist China's intensive drive to set up communes has stunned Eastern European Communists outside the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- A Democratic "family row" over civil rights grew today. It was inflamed by a sharp suggestion from the party's national chairman that Southerners might have to "take political asylum wherever they can find it" if they did not like the party's stand on racial integration.
A cooperative housing development for 500 middle-income families will be built by the Farband Labor Zionist Order in the twenty-block West Side rehabilitation area.
Professional wrestling had a successful fall opening at Madison Square Garden last night.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- A scandal over disclosures to the press about the personal life and last illness of Pope Pius XII led today to the resignation of his former chief physician, Prof. Riccardo Galeazzi-Lisi, as head of the Vatican's Medical Department.

QUEMOY, China, Oct. 20 -The afternoon was peacefully bright and sunny today and this offshore island was bustling with activity, with at least six Nationalist transports riding the surf in Liaolo Bay unloading their cargo.

The Waterfront Commission retorted stingingly yesterday to shipping industry criticism of it as too costly and too big. The New York-New Jersey agency is supported entirely by the employers of waterfront labor through a payroll tax.
John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday that he favored merit salary increases for superior teachers.
PARSIPPANY-TROY HILLS, N. J., Oct. 20 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr. offered tonight to withdraw his charge that his Republican opponent, Robert W. Kean, was an isolationist.

THE memory of man is small; this may be fortunate. His capacity for indignation - - this may be fortunate, too -- is quotidian (a sweat of fretfulness in a crowded subway car) when it is not sectarian (an exhausted tongue-clucking, by all denominations it is true, but a tongue-clucking nevertheless, over the bombing of a synagogue in Atlanta or Peoria).
Steel production continued to rise last week. It topped scheduled output for the fourth consecutive week and reached the highest level in almost a year. Output is expected to climb again this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Argument began in the Supreme Court today on the so-called Memphis Case, regarded as one of unusual importance to the natural gas industry.

The best third quarter in its history enabled the Scott Paper Company to continue its recordbreaking sales through the nine months ended Sept. 27, Thomas B. McCabe, president, reported to stockholders.
The Board of Estimate yesterday ruled out a proposal to substitute the so-called Liberty Bridge from Brooklyn to Jersey City for the projected Narrows Bridge from Brooklyn to Staten Island.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 20 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd announced tonight the names of members of his enlarged Cabinet.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20 -- Brazil's southern coffee-growing regions remained under military occupation today while producers were reported planning other steps to force the Government to guarantee a minimum purchase price.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 20 -- Governor Harriman moved into this Republican stronghold today with a press conference full of reasons why he thinks his re-election campaign is flourishing.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, Oct. 21 -- The Chinese Communists resumed their shelling of the Quemoy area yesterday while Secretary of State Dulles was flying here to discuss the Taiwan Strait situation with President Chiang Kai-shek of Nationalist China.

THE elaborate preparations made by pagan and primitive peoples when setting out on their journey into eternal life are commemorated in the Brooklyn Museum's major fall exhibition. "Bury the Dead -- Equipment for Eternity,'' as the display is called, will open there today and remain on view until Jan. 4.
Representatives of twentytwo Colleges in New York City voted to sponsor an admissions assistance center yesterday to aid college placement.
The State Employment Service merged two of its ofifces into one professional placement center yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Food alone does not fulfill a growing child's nutritional requirements, the American Academy of Pediatrics was told today at the opening sesion of its twenty-seventh annual meeting at the Palmer House.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -The United States decided today not to resume naval convoys to Quemoy for the time being despite the Chinese Communists' termination of the Quemoy cease-fire.

For years textile men have been bemoaning the unhappy state of their industry. Yesterday, however, Halbert M. Jones, of Laurinburg, N. C., president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute, said that "the textile industry . . . is potentially in the strongest position in its history."
The Department of State honored the head of its passport agency here yesterday and disclosed that she will make a study of passport arrangements that may be needed for travel in the jet age.

HAVANA, Oct. 20 -- Fidel Castro, the rebel leader, has ordered the confiscation of property of British companies and citizens in the "Free Territory of Cuba" controlled by him. The action was said to have been taken in reprisal for the sale of jet planes by Britain to the Government of President Fulgencio Batista.

THOMAS SCHERMAN never runs out of attractive ideas for his Little Orchestra Society's concerts. This season he has invited a number of composers to share the stage with him as performers of their own music. Norman Dello Joio was the guest at Town Hall last night.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -President Eisenhower declared all-out partisan war on the Democratic party tonight. He contended that it could offer the nation only a Government "that wages war on itself."
The vanguard of 150,000 business executives expected to attend the five-day National Business Show in the New York Coliseum marched through five acres of exhibits at the opening yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 20 -- The forty-nine Cardinals gathered in Rome for next Saturday's conclave were indignant tonight over a Soviet attempt to influence their choice of the next Pope.
MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Indians must pay state income taxes, Judge Ellsworth N. Lawrence of the Franklin County Court, ruled today.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 20 -- The president of Hadassah emphasized here today that one of the major objectives of the Zionist movement the world over was "to stimulate and maintain a creative Jewish life" outside of Israel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Following is the text of a note delivered today by the United States Embassy in Moscow to the Soviet Foreign Ministry on arrangements for the meeting on suspension of nuclear tests scheduled to begin in Geneva Oct. 31:

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. V., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Russian exports of benzene and naphthalene, two important chemical and raw materials, will provide cut-throat competition to domestic marketers for several years, O. V. Tracy, vice president and director of the Esso Standard Oil Company, said today.
ZESTY applesauce with a natural pink color may be made by using McIntosh apples, which are plentiful now, and freezing the product for use later. The color secret is not to peel the apples.
DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -Labor problems, mainly affecting General Motors, continue to hold 1959 model car production below original projections.
EDISON, N. J., Oct. 20 -- Representative Robert W. Kean carried his fight for a Senate seat into Democratic Middlesex County today for the second time in two months.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20 -Four persons were reported killed today in a new outbreak of shooting in the Basta district of Beirut, which was held by rebels all last summer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -The United States rejected today a Soviet suggestion that the forthcoming negotiations on halting nuclear weapons tests be held at the foreign ministers' level.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Oct. 20 (AP) -- A slender Army recruit from Georgia told a general court-martial board here today that he was dipped head-first into the slime of a mess hall grease trap for a minor violation of orders.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 20 -- Provisional President Wolfgang Larrazabal announced today that he would resign soon "in order to be free to campaign for the Presidency as nominee of the Republican Democratic Union."
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 20. -- It was front-page news in India today that the forces of Lord Rama were fast closing in on the demon King Ravana.
IN "The Family Reunion," acted at the Phoenix last evening, T. S. Eliot set himself a problem, which has given rise to a series of problems.

Democrats have defeated all Republican challengers for the House seat in Brooklyn's Eighth Congressional District since the Harding landslide of 1920. The Democrat is considered the heavy favorite this year, too.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 20 -- The crew that crash-landed an Air Force transport plane on the Southern State Parkway in West Babylon last week drew praise today from 315 residents of the area.
Ed Sullivan plans to make a trip to India late in January to film a one-hour television program. The film will be shown later in the season over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Senator Case of New Jersey has predicted, and Senator Holland of Florida has agreed, that the next attempt to change the Senate rule that enables strong minorities to frustrate the will of majorities will be much more difficult for Southern Democrats to defeat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The conviction of John Joseph Frank on a charge of failing to register as a Dominican agent was reversed today because of prosecution remarks tying him to the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez.

TACOMA, Wash., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Dave Beck lost his plea today for postponement of his income tax-evasion trial, which is scheduled to open in Federal Count here Nov. 10. Beck is a former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- John K. Langum, former vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, warned here today that "a speculative mania on top of an over-extended boom and some further inflation would surely plunge our economy into really serious recession."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court reaffirmed today its stand against racial discrimination in tax-supported facilities such as golf courses, parks and playgrounds.
