This is the season when one of the newer aspects of suburban living -- an interest in the fine arts -- comes vividly to the forefront.
BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- Six men and a woman were named today to the Hall of Fame in Distribution.
Wall Street staged a bull market for a handful of low-priced stocks, but showed a decline for the complete list. The market value of New York Stock Exchange issues fell about $900,000,000 yesterday.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 20 -- A total of 637 students applied today for admission to two private high schools here set up to fill the educational gap created by the desegregation controversy.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 20 -- Frank S. Hogan urged tonight that the question of a cease-fire in the Far East be placed immediately before the United Nations.
Mayor Wagner accused the Republican party last night of "blind opposition to every reform of the past quarter century."
Edward Goodell, Liberal candidate for Attorney General, last night rebutted Republican charges that the state's economy had worsened under the Democratic Administration.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 20 -Public school teachers who are tutoring pupils from schools that were closed because of the desegregation issue gave clear indication today that they did not intend to go along with the tutoring system after this semester.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower lunched today with 100 movie personalities and industrial executives. The principal subject was money to finance the last weeks of California's Republican campaign.
The Community Service Society announced yesterday the beginning of a two-year experiment to improve maternity care and prevent the death of infants just before, during and immediately after birth.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. charged yesterday that the Republican party had attempted to purchase his endorsement of the Republican state ticket.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that Nelson A. Rockefeller "is at least as well equipped" as Governor Harriman to discuss foreign policy but that he preferred "to stick to the business at hand" and talk about state issues.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The gross national product rose briskly in the third quarter to an annual rate of $440,000,000,000, the Council of Economic Advisers estimated today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct, 20 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has indicated that the Soviet Union would be prepared to discuss an agreement with Brazil for the supply of industrial equipment and exchanges of technicians.

Speaking for France at the United Nations yesterday, Jules Moch enlarged upon the nuclear policy stated by himself a year ago and recently restated by Foreign Minister Couve de Murville. This is that his country will make no agreement to suspend atomic weapons tests until there is a satisfactory agreement among the atomic powers to stop making atomic weapons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -The Vice Chief of Staff of the Army declared today that much of the Army's equipment was old and that "many items" were either too costly to maintain or not good enough for modern warfare.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 20 -Vincent I. McInerney, the Democratic candidate for District Attorney, and Harold Fertig, the Democratic candidate for County Controller, called last night for a grand jury investigation into the Nassau County truck rental system.
George H. Gribbin, 51-yearold senior vice president and copy director at Young Rubicam, Inc., has been named president of the agency.
TRENTON, Oct. 20 -- A strong trend toward the Democrats reported to be observable across the country appears to have skipped New Jersey.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The Hill and Dale Garden Club of Tarrytown is sponsoring a "Holiday Previews" benefit tour of six homes here on Wednesday from 1:30 to 5:30. Each of the homes will display flower arrangements and decorations for a different holiday.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Maintenance employes of the British Overseas Airways Corporation voted today to continue the unofficial strike that has kept its planes grounded since last week.

IOSIF IOSIFOVICH KUZMIN, the man in charge of drawing up the new Soviet Seven-Year Plan that Nikita S. Khrushchev thinks will amaze the world, is an engineer turned politician, a typical member of the new class of technocrats that rules in Moscow.
A leading Latin American pulisher and a Canadian official criticized United States economic policies in the Western Hemisphere last night. Both called for truer partnership.
TUNIS, Oct. 20 -- Four thin, shy French soldiers were freed here today by the Algerian Army of National Liberation after more than nine months of captivity in the mountains of North Africa.
After having his case shunted among a half-dozen magistrates since June, 1957, an 18-year-old machine operator was cleared yesterday of opening a fire hydrant that damaged property.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 20 -Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. told the Virginia Congress of Parents and Teachers today that he would fight for public schools, but that he would not permit white and Negro children to be taught in them together.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -Secretary Arthur S. Flemming scheduled eleven meetings today to get the views of interested groups on his Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (UPI) -The head of the National Safety Council warned today that the safety movement still had a long way to go.
FREDERIKA LOUISE Thyra Victoria Margarita Sophia Olga Cecilia Isabella Christa, Queen of Greece, arrives in New York today on her second visit to the United States.
The Citizens Committee for the Greenwich Village area protested to city officials yesterday that no opportunity "for serious negotiations" on Washington Square traffic had been given as promised.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held in a narrow range all day yesterday and closed 4 points lower to 5 points higher than on last Friday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 -James R. Hoffa asserted today that the outcast International Brotherhood of Teamsters was getting more cooperation than ever from unions in the merged labor federation.

The New York Stock Exchange's short-interest report for mid-October would indicate that last week, at least, some of Wall Street's "bears" had decided not to continue fighting a "bull" market. The Exchange reported yesterday a 10.9 per cent drop in the short interest in the month to Oct. 15.
" WELL, I want a hat, but I don't want any of this high style, and I hate roses!"
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 20 (UPI) -- Four horses were made supplementary nominations at a cost of $10,000 each today for Saturday's Garden State Stakes, the world's richest horse race.
Nelson A. Rockefeller pressed his attack on Governor Harriman's economic policies last night.

A plan for a world without crisis and fear of a hydrogen holocaust is presented by Tom Slick, a Texas businessman, in a book titled "Permanent Peace." Prentice-Hall will issue it Nov. 17. The author proposes a program to peace through total disarmament in connection with a collective security force within the framework of the United Nations.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 -Something new has been added to the 1958 political campaign -- a new Eisenhower. The man who came into American politics six years ago as a symbol of moderation tonight made as tough a speech as anything Vice President Richard M. Nixon has offered the electorate
Net assets of the Broad Street Investing Corporation climbed to a record total of $123,396,577 on Sept. 30, Francis F. Randolph, chairman and president, announced yesterday.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 20 -- Field Marshal Sarit Thanarat seized power in Thailand tonight in a silent, bloodless coup in the name of the people and with the agreement of the ousted Government.
ALGIERS, Oct. 20 -- The French Army, in a gesture of conciliation, has decided to free ten Nationalist rebels who were captured in combat.

Today's new film is "The Night Heaven Fell," a French suspense drama, starring Brigitte Bardot, at the Odeon, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street, and the Fine Arts, Fiftyeighth Street west of Lexington Avenue.
A group of Queens homeowners has found a novel way to keep a proposed gasoline station from the neighborhood. They plan to buy the site, develop it as a park and give it to the city.
Five of ninety-five senior pilots of Northeast Airlines have failed re-examinations of instrument flight proficiency being given by the inspectors of the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- President Theodor Heuss of West Germany gave 5,000 ($14,000) tonight to aid in the reconstruction of Coventry Cathedral, destroyed by Ger man bombing on the night of Nov. 14, 1940. At a dinner

Six football old-timers, who soon will be inducted into the Football Hall of Fame, recalled bygone experiences, modestly reported on their present activities and otherwise enjoyed themselves at the weekly luncheon of the metropolitan football writers yesterday at Toots Shor's restaurant.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 (AP) -The International Convention of Christian Churches honored the Rev. T. Hoffman Hurley of Trowbridge, Calif., today as its Rural Minister of the year.
Harry S. Truman expressed doubts yesterday about the administrative capacity of Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Republican candidate for Governor.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20 -- Germany's equestrians continued their domination of international jumping competition in the United States tonight when the team of Fritz Theidemann, Hans Guenther Winkler and Alfons Luetke Westheus won its second straight Olympic class at the Pennsylvania National Horse show.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- France said today that she would not be bound, at least at the outset, by an agreement between the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain to halt tests of nuclear weapons.

Daniel Gutoff made a favorable impression in his debut piano recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Obviously well trained, he played a solid program with musicianship and, for the most pary, technical accuracy.
It didn't take long to fill up a book of trading stamps at the Sales Executives Club yesterday.

Your editorial of Oct. 17 "Keating for Senator" starts with the sentence, "Frank S. Hogan has been an excellent District Attorney of New York County since 1941." I need not recall that during this interval he was elected with the endorsement of both Republican and Democratic parties -- certainly not an indication of dependence on bossism.

DETROIT, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company and its consolidated subsidiaries reported today a net loss of $16,200,000 for the first nine months of 1958. This compared with a profit of $229,500,000, or $4.22 a share in the like 1957 period.
GLEN COVE, L, I., Oct. 21 -- Plans for a new shopping mall to re-establish this city as the leading shopping center on the North Shore were submitted to the City Planning Board today.
The automobile industry, criticized earlier this year for its uninspired salesmanship, appears to be preparing for an aggressive program.

Nine hundred and forty-nine persons were injured in city traffic last week, compared with 981 in the same period a year ago. The Police Safety Bureau also reported that personal-injury accidents were higher.
Eight five-story apartment and store buildings at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street have been purchased by builders and will be replaced by a cooperative apartment house.
May I congratulate you on your wisdom and courage in your Oct. 16 editorial suggesting that Quemoy and Matsu be turned over to the Chinese Communists.

Mrs. Stephen Sanford and Mrs. Winston Guest, chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the committee for the Embassy Ball, will hold a meeting for their aides and members of the dinner committee at Mrs. Sanford's home, 417 Park Avenue, this afternoon.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Dark-colored cars were hard to find among the hundreds shown at a preview today of Britain's annual International Motor Show.
VIENNA, Oct. 21 -- Hungary's traders and independent artisans are to be tolerated for a while because they are making a contribution to the economy in the transition from capitalism to communism.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Edward Swayduck, president of New York Local 1 of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America, criticized the merged labor federation today for its "no raiding" agreement.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 21 -- Twenty-five student delegates who attended a congress in Peiping last month were aboard the Soviet TU-104 jet airliner that crashed last Friday at Kanash, 400 miles east of Moscow.

In the Tenth Congressional District in the heart of Brooklyn, Mrs. Edna F. Kelly, a Democrat, has been elected to Congress five times since 1949 by enormous pluralities. In this election, she confidently expects to equal her 1956 plurality of 63,930 out of 137,686 total votes.
Mary Rockefeller, wife of the Republican candidate for Governor, gave equal time to the Italian version of blintzes yesterday.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The State Public Works Department announced tody a new numbering plan for New York's interstate Highway system.

Sales and earnings of the General Foods Corporation exceeded the highs set last year in both the quarter and six months ended Sept. 30. The figures were reported by Charles G. Mortimer, president, in the statement to more than 63,000 stockholders.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- One drink to a customer -- and a "little" drink at that -- will soon be the rule in all Soviet restaurants and drinking halls.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- It is encouraging to report amid the disorder of a tumultuous world that one major problem seems finally to be nearing solution. This is the Cyprus dispute among Britain, Greece and Turkey. And if it is settled -- which still remains uncertain -- the man most responsible will be Paul-Henri Spaak, NATO's hefty, owlish Secretary General.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan dropped the Washington Square problem back into the lap of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The United States has quietly assured the Algerians and Tunisians here that it will continue sending aid, at the rate of $1,000,000 a year, for Algerian refugees in Tunisia.

The contract for construction of a fifty-three-story office building on the block bounded by Park and Lexington Avenues, Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets, has been awarded to the Gauldwell Wingate Company.

MOSCOW, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- A 19 - year - old "stilyag" (zoot-suiter) was re-tried and sentenced to death following public protests that the original ten to twenty-five-year term imposed for killing a militiaman during a robbery was too lenient, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said today.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The French Socialist party welcomed today a bid for membership by two prominent former Communists and the minuscule independent Communist movement they lead.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 21 -- In the great Midwestern Farm Belt the visible evidence of wealth and wellbeing is dramatic. The land "never looked so good," the golden autumn harvest is amazing and rural towns and villages bustle with prosperity.

Henry C. Alexander, chairman of J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., and Philip D. Reed, chairman of the finance commitee of the General Electric Company, have been nominated as directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
ROME, Oct. 21 -- Preparations have been virtually completed for the conclave that will elect a Pope.
OXFORD, England, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A lanky Yank at Oxford who doesn't like traditional British technique became the center of the biggest rowing row in a century here.

GEORGE BURNS introduced last night the new film series that he has been making since the decision of his wife and stage partner, Gracie Allen, to retire from the entertainment world. It was a difficult night for everybody (9 o'clock on channel 4).

First Landing, a Kentucky-bred horse, is favored in Saturday's $295,250 Garden State Stakes, the world's richest horse race. The field for the Camden, N. J., event now stands at twelve. The owner of the winning horse will gross $177,150.
The sixty-five Presbyterian Churches in the Presbytery of New York have raised $1,200,000 in the last two years for church extension and rehabilitation, it was reported last night.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 21 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike put into words today a fear growing throughout Asia that the party-cabinet system of democratic government may be the wrong one for the area.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Oct. 22 -- Secretary of State Dulles and President Chiang Kai-shek conferred yesterday in the quiet, dimly lit home of the Chinese Nationalist leader.
President Eisenhower's highly partisan, sharply critical speech in Los Angeles Monday night recalled to many his 1954 campaign efforts in a similar vein.
SQUASH in a variety of colors and shapes is now available in local markets.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The United States will oppose any change in the basic policies of the United Nation's Office of Public Information, a spokesman said today.

SOUTHBORO, Mass., Oct. 21 -- Francis J. Mattioli, the chief of the three-man police force in this quiet New England village, is one of the St. Mark's school's most devoted football fans. Each afternoon, he drives up in his cruiser to watch practice.

A MAGNIFICENT brass doorknob from India and a shiny brass plaque that spells Luten-Clarey-Stern are the only indications that a brownstone at 50 East Sixty-fourth Street differs from the many others in New York City.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- At least five persons were injured and four students were arrested late last night when policemen using tear gas and nightsticks dispersed a crowd of about 3,000 that for nearly twelve hours had demonstrated against former President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla.

Paperboard production reached a historic high last week with the production of 314,442 tons, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. The highest previous production was in the week ended Sept. 20 with an output of 311,174 tons.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Army troops smashed a small revolt by anti-Government elements in La Paz today. Three persons were killed and two were wounded in five hours of street fighting.

A 24-year-old Astoria man was arrested last night on charges of robbing four Loft Candy Stores in Queens of $200 in the last month. Two detectives lying in wait at a Loft store at 147-28 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, apprehended William D. Connolly of 31-23 Thirty-sixth.
PERTH, Australia, Oct. 21 (Reuters) -- The Marylebone Cricket Club's first match with Western Australia ended in a draw today.

An executive committee and an acquisition committee were created yesterday by the board of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation. The move took place at the company's offices here during the first directors meeting since shareholders approved the company's refinancing plan last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- What with injuries to top personnel and the unfortunate circumstance of having to play three of its strongest opponents to start its schedule, Pennsylvania has had a trying ordeal for the first month of the football season.
A man's close resemblance to a police composite sketch was instrumental yesterday in his arrest for robbing a faculty member of Columbia University.
Whether he's at West Point, Annapolis or a Long Island college, a football coach seems to have his problems.

ALL sincere hunters are now making agonizing reappraisals of their boots and examining their souls on the subject of how many new pairs they can afford, if any. Nothing is more important to the spirit of man.
Former President Harry S. Truman will campaign in Harlem today with Governor Harriman and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- A magazine poll of fifty Washington correspondents showed today that they believed the Democrats would substantially increase their control of the House and Senate in the Nov. 4 elections.
United States exporters were advised yesterday to consider new measures for holding a strong position in the Middle East, where they can expect eventual emergence of an Arab "Common Market."
BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- American exporters will be at a competitive disadvantage when they start selling to European Common Market countries, a Department of State official warned here today.

In a city as busy in so many different ways as this one centered on Manhattan Island it is not unusual to have numerous spectacular and historic events on the calendar simultaneously. This has been typical of New York for a longer time than many might realize.

OULMES, Morocco, Oct. 21 -- The Royal Moroccan Army has moved into this hilly wooded region one hundred miles north of Rabat to comb out a group of local guerrillas and prevent tribesmen from joining the dissident movement.
Everyone connected with the Giants is convinced that their next opponents, the Pittsburgh Steelers, are considerably better than their 1-3 won-lost record in the National Football League.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Six University of Pittsburgh students, led by a former cadet, tried to steal the Army's mascot mule early today. But all they got was a broken down former mascot.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Jean Lefevre, French pantomimist, left a hospital bed here tonight to carry out an old tradition of the stage -- the show must go on.

" A Night to Remember," British-made film version of the Walter Lord book, starring Kenneth More, has been booked to open at the Criterion Theatre on a reserved-seat basis. The date of the premiere is to be announced.

Soviet grand masters at chess won their unfinished ninth-round match against East Germany by a score of 4 -- 0 yesterday in the international team tournament at Munich and then blanked Austria in the tenth round, according to a report from Germany.
ATLANTA, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Discovery of twenty sticks of dynamite in a patch of weeds, along with the equipment to explode it, touched off a new police investigation here today.

GROVER WHALEN, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, announced yesterday that the first of the "Fifth Avenue Openings" would be held Jan. 21 and 22. The aim of this project is to bring to the attention of the consumer semiannually -- in January for spring and again in September for fall -- the best of American fashion design. Creativity, not price, will be the judge.
HAVANA, Oct. 21 -- Cuban rebels have kidnapped two Americans and seven Cubans employed at an oil refinery of the Texas Company, the United States Embassy said today.
The public rates the eighty-one local voluntary hospitals higher for scientific skill than for human kindness, according to a public opinion survey by Elmo Roper Associates.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The control of the Republican party organization and strategy is now clearly passing into the hands of Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
The election of Frederick H. Cook as president and chief executive officer of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., manufacturer of smooth-surface floor coverings, was announced yesterday.

NEW CASTLE, Pa., Oct. 21 -- Former President Harry S. Truman tonight accused President Eisenhower of "surrendering to the Communists" in Korea in 1952. "He went to Korea and surrendered," Mr. Truman told a Democratic dinner-rally here. "We are now all paying the price."

President Eisenhower, a "truly great man," deserves a major share of the credit for the Allied victory in Europe in World War II, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery says in the third instalment of his memoirs. The installment appeared yesterday in the magazine Life.

The Army will ask for 11,000 draftees during November. The quota was the same for September and October. That means that within a threemonth period 33,000 more young men -- and this does not include those who enter the services through enlistment -- will leave their homes to take up a strange new life.
Mayor Wagner said last night that his administration firmly favored stronger labor unions.

Nelson A. Rockefeller replied angrily last night to charges by Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. that he had never supported the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and that he was not a true friend of the Negro.
The portfolio of the Chicago office of the Merchants Acceptance Company, factors, has been acquired by James Talcott, Inc., factors, here. Terms of the acquisition were not revealed.

It is interesting to read that the State Department is making a study of the long-range implications of the steadily increasing membership of the United Nations, with special regard to the increasing difficulty in passing resolutions supported by the United States.
GIVE Harry Kurnitz a fraudulent environment, and he settles back and feels at home.

Figures for the third quarter of 1958, just released by the Council of Economic Advisers, reveal that the country's gross national product, which fell precipitately from a high of $445.6 billion in the third quarter of 1957 to a low of $425.8 billion the first quarter of 1958 -- an extreme decline of $19.8 billion -- had extended its recovery to a level of $440 billion.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The United Nations appealed to South Africa today to end its official policy of apartheid, or racial segregation.
Patrolman James B. McDermott, who killed four men at a Broadway bar early Sunday morning, died yesterday afternoon at Roosevelt Hospital.
Prepaid medical care of some kind is the "blueprint of the future," Dr. David Kershner, president of the Kings County Medical Society, said last night.

PAINTINGS by various winners in the 1958 Guggenheim International Award, together with work by winners and those who received honorable mentions in the various national sections, will go on view today in the galleries of the Guggenheim Museum in its temporary quarters at 7 East Seventy-second Street.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, Oct. 22 -- The United States warned Communist China again today that it would resume escorting supplies to Quemoy if the renewed Communist bombardment made such convoying militarily necessary.

NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr. urged support of his candidacy today on the ground that New Jersey needed a Senator who would work closely with Gov. Robert B. Meyner in promoting more Federal aid for schools, highways, water supply and flood control.

An American edition of Jean and Simonne Lacouture's history of Egypt will be published Nov. 14 by Criterion Books under the title "Egypt in Transition." The authors, both journalists, have spent much time in Egypt and the Middle East.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The redoubtable peeress who took a place in parliamentary history today as the first woman to sit in the 700-year-old House of Lords has been likened to the prioress of a great order.
Labor and the Republican record on social and labor questions were two of the prominent threads in the fabric of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's day yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Prices retreated in most of the principal sections of the stock market today. Most of the losses were in pennies.

ALBION, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating said here today that New York State was the exception to the political tide reporter to be running against Republicans in many other states.

Two Pats and a pet gathered in the winner's circle yesterday after the twenty-first running of the $17,000 New York Turf Writers Cup, a two-mile event over hurdles. The race headed the opening program of the two-day United Hunts meet that closes the Belmont season today.
A pay inequity that has rankled the terminal supervisors of New York's city-owned ferry system for more than three years may be erased -- at least temporarily -- within the next month or two.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Thomas Robbins of Pinehurst, the medalist, breezed through his first-round North and South seniors' golf tournament match with the loss of only one hole today. He defeated P. J. Farley of Grand Rapids, Mich., 6 and 5.

The Allergy Division of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn reported yesterday that on Sept. 7 the ragweed pollen count reached a high of 188 for the year. The next day an average count of 181 was recorded.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 21 -- State Supreme Court Justice Robert Doscher granted an application today to compel the City of Rye to place on its November ballot a proposition asking a charter-revision commission.

Operating revenues of the Southern Company and its subsidiaries increased in the twelve months ended Sept. 30. The company reported yesterday a rise to $267,828,539 from $247,483,195 in the 1957 period.

Melvin Dean Nimer, the 8-year-old boy who confessed, then denied, stabbing his parents to death in their Staten Island home, will be discharged from a psychiatric ward tomorrow and sent to relatives in Utah.

Rhea Jackson, lyric soprano, sang a highly skillful Town Hall recital last night. She displayed a charm and persuasiveness that reflected experience gained in Europe, where she has been giving concerts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A leading Southern Democratic Senator advised Paul M. Butler today to pipe down on the subject of civil rights.
The Corn Products Company has leased five floors in the building being constructed by the Corning Glass Works at 717 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-sixth Street.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Oct. 21 (UPI) -- A master sergeant was convicted today of having mistreated recruits at this infantry center. He was fined $450 and reduced one grade in rank to technical sergeant.

TO history, as recorded by Winston Churchill, Mary Tudor was "probably the most unhappy and unsuccessful of England's sovereigns." To Victor Hugo, whose "Marie Tudor" was acted in French at the Broadway Theatre last night, she was a passionate, vengeful and distracted woman, seething with both hatred and love for her faithless favorite.

In 1922, the year that Jesse M. Browser, the Republican candidate in the Eleventh Congressional District, was born, Emanuel Celler was elected to Congress for the first time. Mr. Celler has represented the district in Washington ever since.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21 -- Lebanon's former Opposition elements have begun a campaign to withdraw Lebanon's charges in the United Nations Security Council against the United Arab Republic.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower said today that faithless labor union leadership had brought about conditions that had to be "fumigated."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Army's next venture into space will be an attempt to launch a twelve-foot balloon designed to circle the earth at an altitude of about 400 miles.
Tighter money may be on the way, according to Dr. Marcus Nadler, economist for the Hanover Bank and professor of banking and finance at New York University.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Rose Franken and her husband, William Brown Meloney, have sold an original screen story titled "Strange Victory" to Sol Lesser Productions.

The public affairs department of the Columbia Broadcasting System is preparing a new television series titled "Celebrity," a biographical type of program featuring prominent persons in various fields of endeavor.

Two reports in these columns yesterday cast fresh light on what is now happening inside Communist China and repercussions elsewhere in the Communist bloc. A Chinese scientist educated in this country, but who had returned to the mainland and then gone to Taiwan, reports, "The whole country is built on the sufferings of the people. It is hell."
The Union Carbide Corporation in the third quarter this year not only exceeded the second-quarter net, but also that of the third quarter of 1957, Morse G. Dial, president, reported yesterday.
Queen Frederika of Greece arrived yesterday on the Ile de France -- "a modest student," she described herself, hoping to learn something about atomic energy on a six-week tour.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The object of Secretary of State Dulles' trip to Taipei is to explore means of improving Nationalist China's international position, Administration officials said today.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 21 -- Representative Robert W. Kean lashed back tonight at Harrison A. Williams Jr., his Democratic opponent in the race for the United State Senate.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 21 -- The director - general of the Hadassah medical organization in Israel stressed here today that the influx of immigrants to Israel had posed major problems of public health.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Two peeresses, the first to sit in the House of Lords, were introduced to that august assembly in a history-making ceremony today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Supreme Court was told today that reversal of the much-debated Memphis natural gas decision would work great hardship on some industrial users of the fuel. Reuben Goldberg of Washington, counsel for the City of Memphis, made the argument. The city succeeded in the Court of Appeals here in blocking immediate rate increases by the United Gas Pipeline Company.
The city has been warned that continued commuter losses are jeopardizing the existence of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
Where an unbalanced-line formation is involved, the mark of an effective football attack is a team's ability to gain ground to the weak side.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- India asked the United States today to join in sponsoring a compromise disarmament resolution in the General Assembly.
The Cincinnati and Suburban Bell Telephone Company borrowed $25,000,000 yesterday on thirty-five-year debentures at an interest cost of about 4.44 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The only Western non-Communist publication widely available to Soviet readers, the monthly Amerika, published by the United States Government in Russian, began its third year today.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21 -- The United States equestrian team scored its first international jumping victory of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight when Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., rode Nautical and Master William to a pair of faultless performances.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower carried off the political equivalent of a one-man ball game today, adroitly "fielding" a barrage of policy questions directed at him by an array of no fewer than twenty-five women.
Twenty-three of the twenty-five judiciary candidates here were rated "qualified" by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Veterans with G. I. home loans continue to set a remarkable pay-off record.

TOKYO, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- The Nishitetsu Lions completed a spectacular New York Yankee-type comeback today by winning the Japanese baseball world series after having lost the first three games to the Yomiuri Giants.

The prediction was made yesterday that sales of radio and television receiver tubes will rise from 420,000,000 to 450,000,000 a year in the foreseeable future. Don G. Mitchell, chairman and president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., who made the forecast, added that this rate would be held despite the increasing use of transistors and other semi-conductor devices in electronic equipment.
A search is being pressed for a nontoxic chemical to prevent the possible spread of cancer in surgery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- The Interior Department announced today that it had spotted seven new whooping cranes. This means there now are known to be thirty-nine of the long-legged birds in the world.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the resumption of Communist Chinese shelling of Quemoy would not have "any major political effect" on the election campaign. He also said it did not change United States policy, which he called "firm."

LAPEER, Mich., Oct. 21 -- Ezra Taft Benson appealed today to "independent voters and right-thinking Democrats" to prevent the election of a Democratic Congress. He said such a Congress would be more left-wing than the New and Fair Deals.

ALGIERS, Oct. 21 -- French forces killed sixty-eight Algerian nationalist fighters and captured six others in a three-day attack on a rebel stronghold in the mountains of Kabylia, the army command announced here tonight. French losses were not revealed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21 -- A fishing trawler adrift in a rough ocean since Saturday morning was beached late today by three exhausted crew members on the deserted northern tip of nearby Brigantine Island.
In a letter published Oct. 17 a visiting Englishman complained that "post offices are apparently almost nonexistent," and he wonders if advanced standards of living have made letters almost obsolete.
ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- There are 6,769,904 persons registered for the Nov. 4 election -- a record for a gubernatorial election year.

A producing combine has been formed by Law Kerner and Jules Dassin. At the outset, the new concern will devote itself primarily to the stage. Subsequently, its operations will extend into the film and television areas.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 21 -- Nursing schools will be filled to capacity by 1960, Miss Agnes A. Gelinas, chairman of the Skidmore College Department of Nursing, said today. She addressed more than 300 delegates at the biennial sessions of the New York State League of Nursing.
There was a successful snipe hunt early yesterday between St. Paul s Chapel and City Hall in downtown Broadway, probably the first since the Dutch first took over Manhattan more than 300 years ago.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 21 -- This island is facing its worst unemployment problem in years, Chief Minister Lim Yew Hock said today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Joe Longo and Nick Perry of Harrison posted a 32, 30 -- 62 at Hampshire C. C. today and won the Westchester County Golf Association's final pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the season by two strokes. Mike Fetchick of Yonkers, with a 33, 34, and Longo, at 34, 33, tied for individual honors with four-under-par 67's.
A Civil Service examination for firemen candidates has been set tentatively for Nov. 29 to help the Fire Department fill its depleted ranks.

City officials expressed hope yesterday that they would be ready by next spring to sell five acres of rundown shops and waterfront saloons near the Battery to a private developer of luxury apartments.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 21 -- The world grew smaller today -- to about the size of an elementary school -- for 400 pupils at the Edgemont School here.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 21 -- Private classes did not start here today as scheduled because of administrative difficulties.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Rev. F. L. Shuttlesworth, Negro integration leader, surrendered to the police today on charges connected with yesterday's demonstrations by Negroes on buses.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 21 -- Governor Harriman startled a nonpartisan academic ceremony here today by including a sharp political rejoinder to a local Republican critic in his speech.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Oct. 22 -- The police announced today that they had arrested fifty-three editors, writers, labor leaders, teachers, students and business men so far in a continuing roundup of persons suspected of being Communists and Red sympathizers.

Army led The Associated Press and United Press International football polls for the second straight week yesterday. The cadets received ninety first-place votes in the writers' balloting and twenty-three of a possible twenty-five in the coaches' poll.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Treasury will not send to Congress next year a plan for a general manufacturers' excise tax. Nor is there any likelihood that such a plan will be given serious consideration on the initiative of Congress itself.

Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., is the Class C modified sports car racing champion for the second year in a row. During the year in national competition Hansgen won more races and scored more points than any other driver.
The impact of inflation on the structure of banking calls for continuing emphasis on the growth factor, Morris A. Schapiro, president of the securities firm that bears his name, said here yesterday.
The trials of thirteen transit workers charged with having led last December's eight-day subway strike ended yesterday before former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind, special hearing officer.

YONKERS, Oct. 21 -- Circo was clearly the best of the nine 2-year-old trotters in the Hilltop Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight. With Billy Haughton making one big move and no mistakes, the colt, owned by the Ruderman Stables and Farms of Gouverneur, N. Y., took command shortly past the first quarter and led all the way.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, former Democratic candidate for President, said today that the United States should not be entangled in the defense of Quemoy and Matsu but that it had an obligation to defend Taiwan.
About 500 persons active in hunt club and other equestrian activities in the New York metropolitan area attended the United Hunts dinner dance in the ballroom of the Biltmore last night.
Cotton futures closed 6 to 13 points higher on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Treasury will announce its forthcoming $3,000,000,000 cash financing in the first or second week in November, officials said today.
AN unusual new guidebook is out. It is for men and woman who get about in wheel chairs or on crutches or both.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Oct. 21 -- Registration officials in Macon County have withheld their records from Federal agents, it was revealed today.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- A Pan American jetliner with a near-capacity load of 103 passengers touched down at Le Bourget Airport this morning on a preview New York-to-Paris run.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- A warning was sounded today that welfare funds for support of Egyptian Jewish refugees living in Europe were running out.
The Reynolds Metals Company and its wholly-owned subsidiaries had higher earnings in the first nine months of this year than in 1957, despite a decline in third-quarter earnings.

THE only time I ever met Mark Van Doren was on the front steps of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. We were there to make five-minute talks about Thomas Mann. What the occasion was I can't recall; something to do with fighting World War II. Having already admired several of Mr. Van Doren's books, I met him with respectful interest.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Most wheat and all rye deliveries turned sharply lower on the Board of Trade, reflecting hedging and stop loss selling.
NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- The Newark Chamber of Commerce and the Board of Education are at odds over the merits of a Business-Education Day program.

WOMEN were insignificant in the scheme of two sportsmen in 1892. Ezra H. Fitch, lawyer and country gentleman, and David T. Abercrombie, ex-prospector, miner, inventor and engineer, were interested in opening a sporting goods establishment.

IN this country specialists in art songs tend to have followers who are devoted in spirit but relatively small in numbers. For this reason special interest was attached to the size of the turnout for Jennie Tourel's recital last night at Carnegie Hall.
Stocks moved down a little, then up a little and closed almost unchanged in yesterday's trading.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A member of the Federal Reserve Board said today the stock market and the economy were "vulnerable to potentially destructive forces" if Americans believed inflation was inevitable.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said tonight that the Soviet Union "will not give a kopeck" to any joint East-West program for economic assistance to under-developed nations.

The New York State Harness Racing Commission yesterday revoked the license of the owner of Widower Creed and meted out suspensions to two top driver-trainers, Howard F. Beissinger and Jimmy Wingfield.
METHUEN, Mass., Oct. 21 -- A three-car train carrying passengers from the Rockingham, N. H., racetrack to Boston crashed into a freight car here tonight, injuring twenty persons.
The private weather forecast came through "fair and cold" for the Nov. 4 election.
SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 21 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored 3-0 victory over a South Korean all-star team today. It was the closest contest to date in their Far Eastern tour.

Prospect Hill, a two-story garden apartment building with fifty-eight suites at 223 Prospect Street, East Orange, N. J., has been sold by the estate of Earl E. Eby in a deal negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, read the Army a lecture today. He told it to forget about getting more men and more transport planes and --pointedly-- to forget about doing research in fields not its direct concern.

The best bid for $25,000,000 of Cook County, Ill., general obligation expressway bonds was entered yesterday by a group of Chicago and New York Banks and investment bankers. The group included the First National Bank of Chicago, the Northern Trust Company, the Continental Illinois National Bank, the First National City Bank of New York and Halsey Stuart Co., Inc.

Dr. John J. Theobald, the new Superintendent of Schools, may have put his head in the lion's mouth when he came out for some form of merit-rating salary plan for teachers, but we think he has right on his side.

PHOTOGRAPHERS are ingenious citizens, ever on the alert for angles and gimmicks. So when the New York Knickerbockers assembled for their first session of pre-season training a month or so ago, one bright lens-snapper got an idea. Since the Knicks had broken eight scoring records in the National Basketball Association last season, the shutter-bug painted "112" on a ball, and lined up the seven top Knick point-gatherers for a symbolic portrait.
Frank Costello, sullen and in "no mood to talk," surrendered yesterday in Federal Court to resume serving a five-year sentence for income-tax evasion.
Fifty men sailing tomorrow for Antarctica have volunteered to serve as guinea pigs in an effort to identify the viruses that cause outbreaks of severe colds among those returning from that continent.

Copper futures continued active yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York, setting a twenty-five-year record for trading for the second consecutive day. The volume was 784 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), compared with Monday's volume of 516 lots.

Most Northerners who write on the integration issue appear to completely miss the factor which most disturbs white Southerners. The Southern communities are the ones with the heavy concentration of Negroes, from 30 per cent on up. When Southerners are forced, by law, to integrate with Negroes in this proportion they are being required to do that which Northerners do not have to do, nor is it very likely Northerners ever will.

YONKERS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Solid South, a 9-to-1 shot driven by Bill Haughton, splashed through the mud for a nose victory over Easy Adios in the featured Class AA pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The time for the mile was 2:08.
NORWICH, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- John D. Hayes, general counsel and secretary of the Norwich Pharmacal Company, was found dead today in his automobile in the family garage. He was 41 years old.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 22 -- A portrait by Amadeo Modigliani was sold for 220,000 guilders ($57,800) today at an auction of the modern art collection of the late P. A. Regnault.
In reply to your editorial of Oct. 16, Quemoy and Matsu should not be surrendered for these reasons:
Former President Harry S. Truman joined Governor Harriman for a campaign appearance in Harlem yesterday, but their scheduled handshaking tour was rained out.
ANZIO, Italy, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Signora Alida Carini, a Nettuno housewife, looked up and saw the bodies falling.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 22 -- This has been a rank, bitter harvest in the fragrant tea plantations along the high ridges of Kerala, the state in which communism took its first foothold on the Indian subcontinent.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Syracuse University's chances of snapping a long football jinx dimmed considerably today with the disclosure that Ron Luciano was sidelined indefinitely with a "virus pneumonia."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The acting head of the United Nations' aid program for Arab refugees complained today of interference by Arab Governments in the relief operation.
THE words and deeds of Paul Mulholland Butler as Democratic National Chairman seem to have an abrasive quality that rub the wrong way with many Democrats as well as all Republicans.
Former President Harry S. Truman and former British Prime Minister Clement Attlee have agreed to hold a trans-Atlantic telephone conversation for Edward R. Murrow's "Small World" program.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The United States fired three nuclear devices within eleven hours today in a speed-up of its nuclear testing program.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following movies as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. They will be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
It is appropriate that New York City, with an increasingly serious smoke problem of its own, should heed the proclamation of Mayor Wagner to join the annual observance of Cleaner Air Week.

Electric power production last week fell to 12,048,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,067,000,000 a week earlier, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Oct. 19, 1957, the output was 11,684,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
With a decision on the Washington Square roadway problem due today, Greenwich Village residents opened a last-minute drive yesterday to keep all but emergency traffic out of Washington Square Park.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Don Jordan gained a split decision over Gaspar Ortega in a nationally televised twelve-round fight tonight, and clinched a December title fight with the world welterweight champion, Virgil Akins.

On this page yesterday we expressed our views on a number of the important Senatorial contests. Today we begin a series of four editorials on candidates for the House of Representatives in the metropolitan New York area, covering northern New Jersey, the lower Hudson Valley, southwestern Connecticut, eastern Long Island and the five counties of New York City.
If Frank Lane and the eight members of his baseball committee have their way, there will be an unrestricted draft of minor league players in 1959.
A faculty committee was appointed yesterday at Columbia College to study proposals by former Dean Lawrence H. Chamberlain for sweeping revisions in the school's admission requirements.

Directors of Schenley Industries, Inc. yesterday declared four extra stock dividends to be distributed during the fiscal year which began on Sept. 1. Each stock dividend is 5 per cent and is applicable to the number of shares outstanding on each record date.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, Oct. 15, there were:
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 22 -- The scholarship fund of Miss Fine's School will benefit from a Festival of the Arts, to be held at the school here Saturday.
A mosaic mural on the theme of Lower East Side history will be installed soon in the community center of La Guardia Houses, a public housing development on the Lower East Side.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 22 -- The Nassau County Bar Association told today why it had refused last week to endorse two Democratic candidates.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A total of 76,565,504 voters have qualified to cast ballots in the Nov. 4 elections, according to official and unofficial estimates.

Dr. Harold W. Stoke, inaugurated yesterday as the third president of Queens College, declared that the United States was faced with the necessity of stepping up to a new level of intellectual maturity.
CANAJOHARIE, N. Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- A tempest in the coffeepot died down today at the Beech-Nut Life Savers plant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered the United Rubber Workers today to quit picketing and conducting a boycott of the products of the O'Sullivan Rubber Corporation, of Winchester, Va.
The first sale of a large-size dry cargo ship behind the Bamboo Curtain by a Western nation has just been reported in the local ship sales market.
Candidates of the Independent-Socialist party, stressed the issues of peace and a wider recognition of the rights of labor at a street-corner rally in the garment center at noon yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- Leaves should not be burned but should be disposed of through regular garbage collections, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner and chairman of the State Air Pollution Control Board, advised today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday were 170,361,000 barrels, a decrease of 2,553,000 barrels compared with the preceding week. A year ago stocks totaled 179,263,000 barrels.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Federal Housing Administration reported today a "noticeable shift" downward in builders' plans for new housing construction between July 1 and Oct. 1.
It has been thirty-eight years since a Republican was elected to the House of Representatives from the area that is now the Thirteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -- If the talk is of politics and the California participant betrays discouragement, anxiety or bitterness, his 1958 Republicanism is showing.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- A British Super-Viscount airliner collided with an Italian Air Force Sabre jet fighter in almost clear skies over Nettuno today. All twenty-six passengers and five crew members on board the airliner were killed.
A State Supreme Court ruling handed down yesterday directed that a retired policeman be reinstated so that he could be eligible for Social Security benefits.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A honeymooning British-American couple was killed in the collision a day after their wedding in London. They were identified tonight as Mrs. Diana Muckerman Cubitt, formerly of New York, and Desmond Cubitt, whose father is a wealthy contractor.

The question of how to show interest in Negro progress evoked another bitter exchange yesterday between Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Nelson A. Rockefeller, Republican nominee for Governor.

BUFFALO, Oct. 22 -- A heavy drizzle and small crowds formed the backdrop today for the campaigning Kenneth B. Keating. The picture brightened by late afternoon when Nelson A. Rockefeller joined the Republican Senatorial candidate for a joint rally here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Post Office and Justice Department officials met today to consider action against "hate mail" attacking racial and religious groups.
ATLANTA, Oct. 22 -- Five men charged with the dynamite blasting of an Atlanta synagogue were denied bail in Fulton County Superior Court today.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The remaining two of the four life peeresses appointed under the Life Peerages Act were introduced to the House of Lords today. They were Baroness Elliot of Harwood, formerly Dame Katherine Elliot, and Baroness Ravensdale of Kedles-Baroness Ravensdale of Kedlestone.

One of the proudest boasts of the Pennsylvania Railroad was saved yesterday morning when directors of the company voted to pay a 25-cents-a-share dividend on Dec. 8. It will be distributed to holders of record of Nov. 3 of the road's 13,167,754 shares of common stock.
ALBANY, Oct., 22 (AP) -- A plan to prevent television repairmen from cheating set owners was outlined today by Governor Harriman's consumer counsel.

The dread disease arthritis is the most chronic malady in the United States. It strikes more Americans than the combined totals of cancer, heart disease, diabetes and tuberculosis. More than 11,000,000 children and adults suffer from arthritis and other rheumatic ailments. Arthritis is painful -- and much worse. It maims and cripples.
GRANDMA owes her blue hair to a Russian wolfhound. The vogue for tinting white hair blue began in the "Roaring Twenties," according to Antoine, Parisian hair stylist who has been visiting here.
The Holly Corporation yesterday announced the acquisition by a subsidiary of an undivided half interest in two West Texas gas processing plants for $6,000,000.

A new one-story taxpayer at the northeast corner of Crosby and Roberts Avenues in the Bronx has been sold by Land Properties, Inc., to the Colonial Real Estate Association, J. Donald Healy, president. The property is 200 by 100 feet and includes a parking lot.
ALBANY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Fire caused extensive damage tonight to the 106-year-old building of the State Court of Appeals.

Thirty provisional members of the Junior League of Brooklyn, who are working toward active membership, will be introduced formally at the league's annual ball. The fete, the theme of which is "Around the World," will be held in the Brooklyn Heights Casino on Nov. 8.
LOUIS ANNEN of Huntington Station, L. I., hauled a 63-pound 2-ounce striped bass out of the surf early yesterday, thereby bringing into the grim lives of the surf fraternity a blazing shaft of light.

Mrs. Norbert A. McKenna and Mrs. Charles S. Rosenthal, co-chairmen of the benefit committee, have been holding meetings at Carlton House to plan for a theatre party to "The Pleasure of His Company" on Wednesday evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The President in the role of an extreme partisan has adopted the concept of the obligation of party leadership that was subscribed to by most of his predecessors, though not until this century did they actively campaign.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct, 22 -- Premier Samir el-Rifai said today that his Government was confident about the internal situation in Jordan. He declared in an interview that he saw no reason why subversive activities, which he acknowledged were at work in Jordan, should succeed.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 22 -- Hadassah adopted a budget of $9,335,000 for 1958-59 here today.

NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- The president of the Board of Education here advised the local Chamber of Commerce today that an effort would be made to call an emergency board session for further study of a Business-Education Day program.
A woman who charged that she had been given improper medical care and treatment in three city hospitals has been awarded $114,600 in Bronx Supreme Court.

Two hundred eighty-five pupils from the seventh grade of the William J. O'Shea Junior High School were taken on a bus tour of Manhattan yesterday to "enrich" their education. Under the patient instruction of the 11-year-old and 12-year-old children, their teachers and guides learned quite a lot about the city and its institutions.
American Export Lines has decided to establish service through the St. Lawrence Seaway to the Great Lakes.
HONG KONG, Oct. 21 -- Under the new system of communes in Communist China, millions of women have left household tasks to swell the ranks of labor.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, makers of Camel cigarettes, had higher sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 than for any similar period in its eighty-three-year history.
HAVANA, Oct. 22 -- A Cuban airliner carrying eleven passengers was reported missing today in rebel areas.
RICHMOND, Oct. 22 -- The Virginia Congress of Parents and Teachers voted today, 515 to 513, to support local option as the solution to the public school integration problem.

Polly Bergen will undertake her first dramatic role on Broadway this season. She has been signed by Carmen Capalbo to play the leading feminine role in his production of "Faster! Faster!," the new play by William Marchant.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- India and Yugoslavia proposed tonight that the General Assembly enlarge the Disarmament Commission to include all eighty-one members of the United Nations.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 22 -- This was the beginning. On Nov. 6, 1869, Rutgers and Princeton Universities met here in the first game of intercollegiate football. Rutgers won, 6 goals to 4.
Spokesmen for the Republican and Democratic parties took their campaign to the Women's City Club yesterday.
The Lionel Corporation is starting next month an extensive advertising campaign in all media. Its theme was provided by child psychologists.
Two big industrial research centers put up "open for business" signs yesterday.

Having successfully defended the Hamilton Russell chess trophy by clinching the international team tournament at Munich, the Soviet players wound up their schedule last night by defeating Switzerland, 3 1/2 -- 1/2, according to a report from Germany.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 22 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr. today accused Representative Robert W. Kean, his Republican opponent in the race for United States Senator, of having an "isolationist" attitude toward national legislation.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The German equestrian team tonight won the Prix de Nations Cup at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

ON bustling Seventh Avenue, the center of the wholesale dress business, is a men's wear store that turned one window and a corner over to women's clothes. Strange as it may seem, it is doing a booming business.
Metal prices rose again yesterday but corporate earnings were more often down than up and stocks continued their retreat from the year's highs of Oct. 13.
MOSCOW, Oct. 21 -- Soviet scientists and physicians have successfully tested a locally produced polio vaccine patterned after the United States Salk vaccine.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Livingston T. Merchant, now Ambassador to Canada, will soon return to Washington as Assistant Secretary for European Affairs. This is the post he left in May, 1956.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Two of the nation's leading dairy companies announced today a patent-pooling arrangement that will make dry milk products available for the first time to millions of persons in underdeveloped areas of the world.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Prices for old crop wheat futures lost as much as a cent a bushel today, extending yesterday's decline on further liquidation by speculative longs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. (AP) -- The Government suspended efforts today to settle a seven-day-old mechanics strike that has shut down Capital Airlines.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Two Army generals warned strongly today against the break-up of the Army's team of missile and space scientists.
An authority on Latin America said yesterday that the trend toward exaggerated nationalism, antagonistic to foreign capital, must be reversed if American enterprise was to continue to venture abroad.
CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 22 -- Democrats are hoping that the bitterness of last month's Republican primary will bring victory to them in state contests for the first time in thirty-six years.
The Godmothers League will hold its annual benefit luncheon on Tuesday, in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.
THERE is a fashion phrenologist who reads the bumps on women's heads and translates them into flattering hats, coiffures and hair pieces.

JOE BONACORSA dropped back into the deep spot in punt formation, stationing himself inside the 10-yard line. The huge crowd in the Yankee Stadium roared in anticipation because this was developing into one of the wildest football games of the ancient series between New York University and Fordham.
AN old Chinese custom decrees that a newly espoused bridegroom send the parents of the bride a whole roast pig.
Australia yesterday raised $25,000,000 on twenty-year bonds in the American capital market at a net interest cost of about 5.41 per cent.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) up to 4 points (20 cents) off, yesterday. The near months were strongest.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- White students who are high school seniors attended classes here today in a segregated school established with public contributions.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Mr. Truman assailed the Eisenhower Administration's foreign and domestic policies today. He said Vice President Richard M. Nixon was using "verbal garbage" in an attempt to avert defeat at the polls.

As everyone will have heard by now, Halloween comes along at the end of the month. Its imminent arrival is one of October's most poorly kept secrets. To be sure, the school system does not begin to discuss Halloween with early September, suggesting that the days until then be carefully counted.
The Federal Government is trying to interest more large-scale builders and mortgage bankers in undertaking urban renewal projects, which are lagging in several cities and smaller communities.

The American Cancer Society, meeting here yesterday, pondered this question: should the society's support of cancer research be increased, even if it should mean less money for cancer education and for the care of cancer victims?
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 22 -- Motion picture exhibitors should unite to stop further Government interference with their industry, Spyros P. Skouras told the Theatre Owners of America today.
VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- Reports from Budapest picture Hungary as calm and unruffled, at least superficially, on the eve of the second anniversary of the revolt against Communist rule.

NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- Representative Robert W. Kean proposed a complete overhaul of Federal taxes tonight to assist the low-income groups, to encourage incentive and to close loopholes in the existing law.

The relationship between tuition fees and the total cost of operating New York University will be evaluated by a faculty committee appointed this week by Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, president of the university. The committee will try to determine whether an increase in tuition is necessary to keep the operating budget balanced.
CAIRO, Oct. 22 -- The United Arab Republic has asked the Soviet Union to warn the United States, Britain and France against aiding Israel if Israel should renew the war with the Arabs.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 22 -- The Committee on Economic Stability has protested to the Federal Communications Commission and to the Columbia Broadcasting System against radio editorials by station WKRC, a C. B. S. affiliate, in behalf of the "right to work" Ohio constitutional amendment.

BUFFALO, Oct. 22 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller chose today to draw a clear line of distinction between his campaign for Governor in New York and some of President Eisenhower's recent political attacks on Democrats and unions.
The Association of Buying Offices elected its first woman president yesterday at a luncheon in the McAlpin Hotel.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 22 (AP) -- In a sudden turnabout, the Danish Government has decided to support Povi Bang-Jensen, former Danish United Nations official dismissed by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold earlier this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A study made within the Federal Reserve System found today that the nation's banking system was considerably less "liquid" now than at the start of the 1955-57 boom, thus probably lessening the threat of renewed inflation. The study was made by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.

WHEN Ambroise Vollard, one of the most colorful and shrewd French art dealers in history, commissioned Marc Chagall to do a suite of etchings illustrating the Bible, he started Chagall on an arduous and absorbing artistic research. From 1930 until 1939, and from 1952 to 1956, Chagall returned again and again to the plate and stone, finding many interpretations of Biblical themes for his more than 100 prints in this series.
Last night the Metropolitan Opera marked the seventy-fifth anniversary of its opening, and 3,000 members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild were on hand to celebrate the occasion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- A White House spokesman said today that Harry S. Truman was attempting "political rewriting of history" by accusing President Eisenhower of "surrendering to the Communists" in Korea in 1952.
EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Oct. 22 -- William T. Slader of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Soviet Union has refused to accept an official of the Columbia Broadcasting System as a member of a visiting United States delegation under the cultural exchange program.
ROME, Oct. 22 -- The fifty-one Cardinals now in Rome received today an "intimatio" or notification to attend the Mass of the Holy Ghost in St. Peter's Basilica Saturday morning.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A split among stockholders of the Cleveland Indians was disclosed today when a minority bloc, including Hank Greenberg, demanded the resignation of salaried officers of the baseball club.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Modified martial law went into effect throughout Bolivia today following an abortive revolutionary coup against the Government of President Hernan Siles Zuazo.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 22 -- Visiting Amherst is a pleasant way of reaffirming the basic values of intercollegiate athletics.

Operating revenues of the Virginia Electric and Power Company were Up 86 perecnt in the ,twelve months ended Sept. 30, te company announced yesterday. Revenues in the latest period were $137,337,000, compared with $126,415,000. in the similar period of last year.

Here are two recipes featuring ingredients that are not generally available throughout the city, but which are available in Chinatown. The recipes were developed by Mrs. Emily Kwoh, proprietor of the excellent Mandarin House Restaurant, 133 West Thirteenth Street.

Frank Selvy, who led the nation's collegiate basketball scorers during the 1953-54 season, was obtained by the New York Knickerbockers from the St. Louis Hawks yesterday in exchange for the Knicks' second draft choice next spring.

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- New Jersey Republican Senate leaders and representatives from Hudson, Essex and Bergen Counties today failed to reach an accord on a measure to extend rent controls in seventeen North Jersey communities.
The Twelfth Congressional District is that rarity in Democratic Brooklyn, a district represented by a Republican.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- President Eisenhower made another ungloved attack on the Democratic party and its candidates tonight.
SHOES dictate stocking types. Therefore, three distinct shoe categories should be kept in mind when shopping for hose. They are the open shoe, the closed shoe and the casual walking shoe.

CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 22 -- A visitor has to be mighty careful as he passes through the streets of Concord these days. The city's fathers have just passed a law that can penalize a pedestrian as well as a motorist "on the same play."
LEVITTOWN, L. I., Oct. 22 -- A concern that collects garbage at 23,000 Levittown homes offered an unexpected service for some customers today. It scented their garbage cans with lavender.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today a plan to dispose of Government-held cottonseed at the support price in the Texas, New Mexico and Oklahoma area, where the market has dropped below that level.

WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 22. (UPI) -- Three goals by Johnny Haynes sparked England to a 5-0 victory over the Soviet Union today in an international soccer match before a capacity crowd of 100,000 at Wembley Stadium.
PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 22 (UPI) -- John W. McGuire ousted the 65-year-old medalist, Tom Robbins, 2 and 1, today in the second round of the North and South senior golf tournament.

A new production of Wagner's "Tristan un Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera during the 1959-60 season will be conducted by Otto Klemperer, 74-year-old German conductor, who has not led a performance in New York since 1941.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The State Department announced today that the Hungarian Government had rejected a United States request that Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty receive safe conduct to participate in the election of a new Pope.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The United States sharply rejected today Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's charge that the United States gives economic aid to underdeveloped nations merely to enslave them.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Joey Alfidi, 9 - year - old "maestro" who conducted at a concert of the Symphony of the Air last month at Carnegie Hall, held a rehearsal here tonight with the sixty-piece Westchester Symphony Orchestra. Watching and listening was Kirile Kondrasian, conductor of the Moscow Symphony.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A twenty - two - day strike against five major Pittsburgh hotels ended tonight. The hotels expect to be back in business by Friday.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- The Army apparently has failed in an attempt to place a twelve-foot balloon into orbit in space.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- Secretary of State Dulles has extended his visit to Taiwan and was meeting with President Chiang Kai-shek again this morning.
The first in a series of events of the Party of the Month Club will be a Gourmet dinner dance in the Louis XVI Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 31.

Plans of the New York Central Railroad to restrict service at the Valhalla station were opposed yesterday by the Westchester County Commissioner of Public Welfare and the Westchester Community College.

Net income of the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel producer, amounted to $15,184,641, or 97 cents a share, for the third quarter this year. This was only slightly below the previous quarter's net of $15,321,096, or 98 cents a share, but represented a sharp decline from the $20,121,000, or $1.29 a share, reported for the third quarter last year.
JORGE BOLET, Cuban-born pianist, gave his annual Carnegie Hall recital last night and wound up with a blazing performance of the four Scherzos by Chopin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The following is an estimate of the registered and otherwise qualified voters for the Nov. 4 elections as compiled by the Associated Press from official and unofficial sources, together with estimated probable vote in each state. The last column shows the official vote for House candidates in 1954, the last midterm election:

Earnings of the Atlantic Refining Company for the first nine months this year dropped 34.6 per cent from a year ago. Net income for the third quarter, however, was higher than last year and exceeded the combined profits of both the first and second quarters this year.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived at 11 o'clock last night at La Guardia Airport, and went directly to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He is expected to hold fund-raising conferences today with Republican leaders from New York and New Jersey.

DAVID SUSSKIND, who a week ago dropped his chopsticks in trying to deal with "The World of Suzie Wong," completely redeemed himself early yesterday morning in the second installment of the discussion program "Open End" over Channel 13.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- To help unite families separated by disasters, postal notification cards will be added to the relief supplies stocked in strategic parts of the country.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Douglas MacArthur 2d, United States Ambassador, and Aiichiro Fujiyama, Japanese Foreign Minister, held their second meeting today on revision of the seven-year-old United States-Japan security treaty.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Senator Theodore Francis Green, Rhode Island Democrat, asked the Internal Revenue Service today to investigate advertisements in The Wall Street Journal and other papers attacking Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, and other labor leaders.
Young men in the armed forces are not always broke. They may have pockets full of folding money, but it won't buy an ounce of friendship.

Two new films open at first-run theatres today. "The Last Hurrah," John Ford's version of the Edwin O'Connor novel, starring Spencer Tracy, arrives at the Roxy, Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The Columbia presentation was adapted for the screen by Frank Nugent.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Navy faces a "complete rebuilding" of its football team at midseason. It has little left with which to do it.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan accused the Republican party last night of secretly promoting the open shop in other states while opposing it in New York.
The New York Rubber Corporation has announced its plant at Beacon, N. Y., is for sale.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The stock market was unsettled today. Prices moved indecisively and closed with more losses than gains in most principal groups. South African gold mining shares were an exception.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., of Santa Monica, Calif., achieved the highest sales for any similar period in its history in the nine months ended Aug. 31. The total was $888,766,637, $60,349,323 more than the $828,417,314 for the corresponding period last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Arthur G. Trudeau, the Army's chief of research and development, said today that the United States was infested with Soviet spies.
The Moran Towing and Transportation Company, Inc., is negotiating for the purchase of the Curtis Bay Towing Company, it was learned last night.

PLAINVIEW, L. I., Oct. 22 -- The establishment of a state School Bond Financing Authority could save Nassau County $7,000,000 in interest costs on school financing in the next two years, State Controller Arthur Levitt declared here tonight.

The blockfront on the east side of Second Avenue between Forty-seventh and Forty-eighth Streets has been sold by Joseph Lubin to Geller Mitchell, builders. The buyers plan to erect a twenty-story apartment house on the site from plans by Boak Raad, architects.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 22 -- The Central Committee of the Danish Communist party has barred its former leader, Aksel Larsen, from attending party functions until Oct. 30 -- the day before the party congress meets to decide its future policy.

Many of the crowd of 15,162 at Belmont yesterday found themselves cheering a gallant loser in Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji, who lost the thirty-fifth edition of the $55,425 Temple Gwathmey Steeplechase Handicap by a head to Mrs. Marion duPont Scott's Benguala.

When they go to the polls on Nov. 4, the nation's voters will consider authorizing $2,197,000,000 in state and local government bond issues. These would provide for a variety of ventures, from Illinois' Korean veterans' bonus to New Jersey's water supply system to Cleveland's Convention Hall and Court building.
An order to curb drinking by policemen in taverns in their assigned precincts has been put into effect.
The Chicago Metropolitan Fair and Exposition Authority is planning to sell $20,000,000 of revenue bonds next Monday. The issue will be dated last July 1 and will come due July 1, 1995.
Your editorial of Oct. 17 on the continued movement for court reform was indeed timely.
Two of the nation's "big three" copper producers announced yesterday they would raise the price of refined copper 1 1/2 cents a pound. They will apply the new price of 29 cents today.
