SOME fascinating subjects were explored last night by some eminent authorities on the first of a new series of radio programs called "The Hidden Revolution" over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- Karoly Kiss, a leading Hungarian Communist, and four other Hungarians were among the sixty-five passengers killed in the crash of a Soviet TU-104 jet airliner in Russia Friday, the Budapest radio reported tonight.

We are witnessing a strange political campaign in New York State. Although nominated by the Democrats to succeed himself as Governor, Averell Harriman seems to be running mostly against President Eisenhower, with occasional sallies against the Republican candidate for Governor of California, William Knowland, and the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor of New York, Malcolm Wilson.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Michael H. Prendergast, State Democratic Chairman, criticized Nelson A. Rockefeller tonight as a man posing as a liberal but who actually is a front for big business.
PROVIDENCE, Oct. 22 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the symbol of a free and independent Chinese Government on Taiwan was more important than the symbol of Chiang Kai-shek.

Dr. J. C. Geiger of San Francisco, public health authority, will observe his seventy-third birthday on Nov. 18. The day also will mark the publication of his biography, "Crusader Undaunted" by Dr. Max S. Marshall. It will be issued by Macmillan.

Godfrey P. Schmidt, a member of the three-man board of monitors over the Teamsters Union, said yesterday that he had filed with the United States District Court in Washington an affidavit in answer to a union motion seeking his removal.

Heavy volume was registered by copper and cocoa on the New York Commodity Exchanges yesterday. Copper volume was 825 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot), setting a twenty-five-year record for the third consecutive day.
Jan Van Krimpen, a leader in the design of type faces for books and postage stamps, died Monday in Haarlem, the Netherlands. His age was 66.
A FORCEFUL drama, outstandingly performed and directed, marked the start of the weekly "Pursuit" series last night at 8 o'clock on Channel 2.

I fully agree with George Hallett, whose letter you printed on Oct. 17, that France did not have a pure system of proportional representation either before or after 1951. The appointments of Charles A. Wight as president of the Freeport Sulphur Company and Pearson E. Neaman as chairman of the executive committee were announced yesterday by Langbourne M. Williams, chairman.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Negotiations for a free trade area in Europe will be resumed here tomorrow by seventeen nations in a gloomy atmosphere.

ROME, Oct. 22 -- Diaries reportedly left by Pope Pius XII and their whereabouts were publicly discussed here today. It appeared that, if such documents existed at all, they were in the Vatican and might be made available to historians in centuries to come.
Verbal feathers flew yesterday about how to tell a woodcock from a snipe.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Leaders of Little Rock's new private school said today that the rate of teacher applications might soon make it possible to increase the number of students.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The number of persons on the welfare rolls in New York State dropped by 3 per cent from April to August, but the cost of maintaining them remained about the same, the State Board of Social Welfare reported today.

The Chrysler Corporation operated at a loss of $20,000,000 in the third quarter this year. This swelled its deficit for the first nine months to $45,200,000, or $5.18 a share. Directors, however, voted the 25-cent dividend paid in two previous quarters.
The first Japanese soprano engaged as a regular artist at the Metropolitan Opera is one of two new singers announced yesterday.

Lumber production last week was 9 per cent above the level of last year, according to reports to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 5.5 per cent and orders down 5 per cent.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 23 -- For more than a century Blair Academy has occupied an important position among the country's leading prep schools. That place will be greatly enhanced when the school gets a new gymnasium to handle the winter sports program embracing 200 of 300 students.

HASTINGS, Neb., Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, said tonight that Senator John F. Kennedy was an "ambitious young Senator" who "evidently knows more about getting votes than he does about separating fact from fancy."
BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 -- Can a conservative country Democrat pull a liberal big-city boss to victory on Nov. 4?

THE largest and busiest apiary in town, a five-hive establishment, is on the fourth-floor terrace at 44 East Sixty-fifth Street, facing south. It was inherited with the lease for the terrace apartment last May by Ted Ralph and Milburn Butler, young decorators.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Gene Conley defied the wishes of his Milwaukee Braves' baseball bosses today by signing a Boston Celtics' basketball contract after a five-year absence from the sport.

Informal approval of an enlarged staff for Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver in his investigation of welfare abuses was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
More money is urgently needed for cancer research, members of the American Cancer Society agreed here yesterday at the society's annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel.

Member bank reserves fluctuated widely in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. On average, net free reserves increased $203,000,000 from a revised figure of $43,000,000 a week before to $246,000,000.
Aircrafts, rails and steels, neglected in recent days, staged fairly broad but far-from-vigorous advances in yesterday's stock market. Other portions of the list showed more losses than gains.
Queen Frederika of Greece will be the guest of honor Wednesday at a reception to be given by Mayor Wagner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at 5 P. M.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point lower to 1 point higher yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Demon Rum has been sold to a syndicate for $200,000, second highest price paid for a trotting horse.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- Former President Harry S. Truman asserted tonight that lack of leadership in the White House had been largely responsible for eighty-three bombings in the conflict over desegregation since 1954.

A Federal court jury failed to reach a verdict last night in the trial of three members of Local 102, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, on charges of extortion and conspiracy. The jury will resume deliberation today.

New York State has moved ahead of all others in finding jobs for the elderly unemployed, a study prepared by the New York State Employment Service and the State Commission Against Discrimination showed yesterday.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Charles (Rabbit) Calvin probably is the only trainer of a horse that will run in the rich Garden State Stakes who won't know whether to laugh or cry if his horse wins the pot of gold at Garden State Park on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Government dropped its charges today against William J. Walters in the reported theft of papers belonging to Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Eighteen countries were elected today by the Economic and Social Council as members of the Governing Council of the newly created Special Fund. The nations were equally divided between the industrially advanced and the less-developed countries.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Plans for a $3,500,000 biology center at Rutgers University were announced today by Dr. William H. Cole, chairman of the university's biology building committee. The buildings will house instruction and research units.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Dr. T. Keith Glennan, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, is developing a plan for an unhurried absorption of Army space scientists, engineers and facilities in his new organization.

The Moran Towing and Transportation Company confirmed yesterday that it was negotiating for the purchase of the Curtis Bay Towing Company. Edmond J. Moran, president, said he expected that the sale would be concluded early next month.

DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -The United Auto Workers Union released today an exchange of telegrams between its secretary-treasurer, Emil Mazey, and the Democratic nominee for Senator in Vermont, Frederick J. Fayette.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, lead, wool, rubber, hides, coffee and the domestic sugar market declined; cocoa, world sugar months, copper and potatoes advanced, and price movements for zinc were mixed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Post Office Department told New York State today that it was getting better mail service as the result of a directive issued by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield Aug. 7.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Five groups of scientists have subjected experimental animals to cigarette smoke and tars without producing a case of cancer, the Tobacco Institute, Inc., reported today.

" Man of the Hour," the first program in a proposed series simulating comedy testimonial dinners staged by The Friars, an actors club, will be televised Nov. 9 from 8 to 9 P. M. on the Ed Sullivan show.
ROME, Oct. 23 -- The last touches on preparations for the conclave that is to elect a Pope were being added in the Vatican tonight.

An experimental system for transmitting stereophonic sound over a standard AM (amplitude modulation) radio station was announced yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America. The system, still in the laboratory stage, was demonstrated at R. C. A.'s David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N. J.

Residents of Locust Valley, L. I., will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today in the Grenville Baker Boys Club, Forest Avenue and Weir Lane.

The Mercer Street police station at 253 Mercer Street was taken over yesterday by wreckers. The 98-year-old building should be almost gone within a few weeks.

Plans were set in motion yesterday for the annual Heart of America Ball at a luncheon for patronesses at the home of Mrs. Lewis S. Rosenstiel of 15 East Eightieth Street. The fete is scheduled to take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on April 28.
Melvin Dean Nimer left the psychiatric division of Bellevue Hospital yesterday to live with his grandmother in Oren, Utah.

The work of the Speyer Hospital for Animals will be advanced as a result of the proceeds realized from Pets on Parade, a dinner dance held last night in the St. Regis Roof for the benefit of the hospital's mobile unit.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company increased its net income by more than $1,000,000 in the first nine months of this year. It cleared $27,435,010, against $26,227,574 for the 1957 period, J. P. Levis, chairman, reported yesterday.
CAIRO, Oct. 23 -- Major work on widening and deepening the Suez Canal will begin tomorrow.

ROME, Oct. 23 -- The last of the fifty-two Cardinals who are expected to participate in the conclave of the College of Cardinals reached Rome today on a stretcher in a special plane from Germany. He is Thomas Cardinal Tien Ken-sin, exiled Archbishop of Peiping and the first Chinese Prince of the Church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 695,768 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Negotiations among representatives of seventeen European nations on a free trade area began here today. Most nations sent cabinet members.
The controversial Seventh Avenue approach to the Narrows Bridge in Brooklyn was informally approved by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

YONKERS, Oct. 23 -- Nine colts were named today to start next Tuesday night's Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway to make it the richest event for 2-year-olds in the history of harness racing. Fans in the metropolitan area will have an opportunity to see the nation's only undefeated, untied and unscored-on college football team in action tomorrow.

Since the launching of Sputnik I by the Soviet Union, an event that startled the world into more thought and more worry, there has been considerable speculation about the curriculum on all levels from elementary school to college.
Diners' Club, Inc., has acquired the Sheraton Central Credit Corporation and will extend its charge facilities to include the forty-nine Sheraton hotels in North America, it was announced yesterday.
" We're in pretty good shape and we have a good team."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced today that he had urged the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury to investigate fund-raising appeals by the Committee for Constitutional Government, Inc.
WARSAW, Oct. 23 (AP) -Poland's Communist Government announced today that a new five-year plan stressing the development of heavy industry and cutting back consumer goods.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 23 -- Boris Pasternak, the new Nobel Prize winner, was described here today as having been "quite ready to die" in 1937 rather than support Stalin's purges.
In recent weeks there have been increasing demands for a plebiscite among the Chinese on Formosa to decide whom they prefer -- the Nationalists of Chiang Kai-shek or the Communists of Mao Tse-tung.

HAVANA, Oct. 23 -- Cuban Army Headquarters said today that no official statement would be issued concerning the Cuban Airline Company plane that disappeared Tuesday in Oriente Province. This seemed to back up reports that the plane had been seized by rebels and landed at a rebel airfield.
MONTREAL, Oct. 23 (UPI) -Jean Beliveau and a rookie, Ralph Backstrom, scored twice each as the Canadiens crushed the Chicago Black Hawks, 9 -- 1, tonight.

MAHWAH, N. J., Oct. 23 -- A 1909 Model T Ford, painted fire-engine red, rolled off the assembly line here today, the cynosure of an assembly plant crew accustomed to the long, pastel-hued autos of today.

New York Post Office regulations requiring new employes to agree to work on Saturdays are being fought by the Ribinical Council of America, an Orthodox Jewish or ganization. Saturday is the traditional Jewish Sabbath.

Two new films open at first-run theatres here today. "Torpedo Run," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer submarine adventure starring Glenn Ford and Ernest Borgnine, arrives at the Capitol, Broadway and Fiftieth Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -Adlai E. Stevenson said today that "the President has about as much chance of convincing the country that the Democrats are dangerous as he does of persuading Knight to support Knowland."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Eleven New York colleges will build dormitories to house 2,543 students with the aid of $9,200,000 loan announced today by the Community Facilities Administration.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- There will be no all-America players in the line-up that Wesleyan will send against Amherst here on Saturday in the opening game of the Little Three's annual football round-robin.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 --Average consumer prices held steady in September after dropping a bit in August, the Labor Department reported today.
NAUGATUCK, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff brought his special kind of "nonpartisan" campaigning to this Naugatuck Valley city today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to "participate" in the construction of one section of the Aswan High Dam in Egypt. Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev offered to lend the United Arab Republic up to 400,000,000 rubles ($100,000,000 at the official Soviet exchange rate) for the project.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23. (AP) -- Special precautions are being taken so there can be no monitoring of rival telephone lines when the Chicago Bears play the San Francisco 49ers here Sunday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- The influx of foreign ships into the Great Lakes because of the St. Lawrence Seaway is posing a hazard that must be met with a law requiring them to use Lake-trained pilots. the Marine Section of the National Safety Council was told today.
LIVE models parading atop the ticket booths in Grand Central Terminal yesterday gave enduring commuters perhaps their biggest form of diversion since the railroads added club cars.

Two five-story apartment buildings at 390-94 East 184th Street, southwest corner of Webster Avenue, the Bronx, have been sold by the Webster 184th Corporation to an investing client of the Taylor Company, broker.
Leonard Bernstein tried to make the New York Philharmonic play as badly as possible last night, but he admitted he was not very successful.

BUFFALO, Oct. 23 -- Frank S. Hogan said tonight that the country's "greatest domestic crisis" was the decay and blight of its cities. He accused the Republicans of scuttling the 1958 national housing bill and thereby depriving the nation of new funds and for urban renewal and public housing.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan announced tonight a minor reshuffle of his Government, largely as the result of the resignation of three junior Ministers.
Boris Pasternak, the Nobel Prize-winning Soviet author, may never receive a penny in royalties from the sale in the United States of "Doctor Zhivago," his best-selling novel.

This is the twenty-fourth of a series of articles on pleasure boat cruises. Imaginative yachtsmen consider pleasure boat cruising on Florida waters patterned like a letter "H." One upright is the Atlantic intracoastal route, the other upright is along the Gulf of Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board authorized today an increase in the discount rate from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent by the Federal Reserve Banks of Philadelphia, Richmond, St. Louis, Minneapolis and Dallas.
BUFFALO, Oct. 23 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller closed his upstate campaign today by throwing away his prepared speeches and concentrating on handshaking in factories.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Appellate Division ruled today that the Independent-Socialist party should stay on the Nov. 4 state-wide ballot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, motion picture executive, reported today that "The Ten Commandments" was among the American films rejected by the Soviet Union for general showing under a movie agreement with the United States.
OLEAN, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- For the widowed mother of seven children in this industrial city of 23,000 persons luck may take on a hardened face tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 6 per cent above the level of a year ago.

Net income of the nation's largest copper producer, the Kennecott Copper Corporation, was $14,811,203, or $1.37 a common share, in the third quarter this year, C. R. Cox, president, reported yesterday.
The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) "wholeheartedly approves" proposed revisions in the voluntary oil import program, Charles E. Spahr, president, said yesterday.
FORT LEE, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Daniel W. Allen, Democratic candidate for Congress in the Ninth District, proposed tonight the establishment of a Federal economic-renewal program for depressed areas.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- The role of Woody Thrasher, the Madison Avenue-type television executive, has been cast and "The Last Angry Man" will go before the cameras on Nov. 10.

SPRINGHILL, N. S., Friday, Oct. 24 -- A vast underground rockfall last night that shook Springhill like an earthquake trapped 166 miners in Cumberland Pit No. 2, the continent's deepest coal workings.

As an independent newspaper we believe it may be of help to the independent voter if we give our views on the Congressional races in New York City and the metropolitan area. Yesterday we discussed the House contests in northern New Jersey; today we look at those in the other nearby suburban regions and on Monday and Tuesday we will turn to New York City itself.

WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct. 24 -- Secretary of State Dulles reached here early this morning after a grueling flight from Taiwan. He said his conference with President Chiang Kai-shek had been "eminently satisfactory."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The United Nations told South Africa today that it should relinquish neighboring South-West Africa to the United Nations trusteeship system.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -President Eisenhower returned from a campaign tour in the West and Midwest today and reported that "if there was any pessimism or apathy among party workers out there, I didn't find it."

There has been a good deal of talk -- not factual -- about housing and about juvenile delinquency and with it a tendency to connect the two. As a matter of fact the two have no relationship whatsoever.

That pre-eminent census taker, the Department of Commerce, each year will survey private industry's activities in the atomic energy field.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Queen Elizabeth II said today in her speech on the prorogation of Parliament that she rejoiced that United States-British relations were continually growing closer.
Newspaper Guild units at seven metropolitan dailies have voted to strike at midnight on Oct. 31, unless contract renewal terms are reached before then, the union announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -Clarence Mitchell, legislative representative for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today that his organization was working with three Federal departments to obtain the admission of the daughter of an Air Force sergeant to a school built largely with Federal funds.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 23 -Plans for redeveloping the substandard Fairview-Manhattan Park area of Greenburgh, Westchester County's largest township, were outlined in an Urban Renewal progress report released today.

Edward Goodell, Liberal candidate for Attorney General, charged last night that his Republican opponent, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, had been more interested in competing with Governor Harriman than "in conducting his office within its constitutional framework."
A 49-year-old man described by a prosecutor as the country's "top burglar" decided yesterday to enter the legal profession on his own behalf. But after a day in court he was wavering on his choice.

A flock of fifty-nine white balloons sailed over the city in the misty aftermath of yesterday's rainstorm, dispatched on a double mission. They were part of the celebration of Cleaner Air Week and when they return to earth they will dramatize the far-reaching ways of air pollution.
UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Governor Harriman declared today the President Eisenhower had "let the cat out of the bag," and again exposed an anti-labor attitude of the Republican party.

W. T. Grant, chain of variety stores, has leased 18,000 square feet in the proposed Centereach Shopping Center at Jericho Turnpike and Holbrook Avenue, Centereach, L. I. J. Yudel Realty, Inc., agent for the ten-acre development, was the broker.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 23 -- The auction sale of the P. A. Cegnault collection of contemporary paintings that ended today brought $350,000.
Josi Iturbi, who played in the American pavilion at the Brussels World's Fair last summer, opened the current season of the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a recital last night.

Two six-ton marble columns, each seventeen feet high and more than two feet in diameter, were eased yesterday through the front door of the new Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour, Park Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

Pablo Casals, supreme musician, crusader for peace, passionate friend of liberty, will break a long-standing vow this afternoon. He will play his 'cello in a great hall in a structure on the East River that has recently echoed with discordant oratory. With other musicians, Senor Casals will be part of the United Nations program which each year celebrates the coming into effect of the Charter.
Proposed public borrowings totaling more than $100,000,000 were announced yesterday by major cities and other local government bodies.
Two Belgian counts arrived here yesterday determined to obtain a drum majorette's hat and be photographed in fighter's trunks with Sugar Ray Robinson or some other boxer.
The advertising account of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is being moved to Foote, Cone Belding, according to a reliable source.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -The United States Navy has been ordered to evacuate fiftyfive dependents of American employes of the Nicaro nickel plant in eastern Cuba, the State Department announced tonight.

The United States chess team defeated Spain, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, yesterday in their adjourned eleventh and final round match of the international team tournament at Munich, according to a report from Germany.

STONINGTON, Conn., Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Miss Vivien Kellems, independent Republican write-in candidate for the United States Senate, said today "the time has come to get mad."

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Detroit's Miss U. S. I raced to victory in the Sahara Cup race today but Miss Bardahl of Seattle, by coming in second, won the 1958 national title for Unlimited Class hydroplanes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -The Civil Rights Commission will hold public hearings in Montgomery, Ala., beginning Dec. 8 in a move to compel disclosure of Alabama voting records.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Three Bishops and other dignitaries of the Roman Catholic Church joined today in the dedication of the $3,000,000 Stamford Catholic High School, the third in the Bridgeport Diocese.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Development of a photoscanning device to detect cancer of the brain, liver and thyroid was announced today by the State Health Commissioner.
The campaign trails of Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Nelson A. Rockefeller failed to cross in New York last night.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 28 -- The Army announced today that the spotting and tracking of nuclear clouds by radar might now be possible with considerable accuracy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 -- The American Heart Association is expected to double its annual expenditures to nearly $50,000,000 the next decade for an intensive campaign against hardening of the arteries. This affliction is a frequent factor in heart attacks and strokes.

ALGIERS, Oct, 23 -- Europeans in the streets of Algiers expressed surprise, disbelief and even fear today when they heard the news of Premier Charles de Gaulle's offer to negotiate a cease fire with the Algerian rebels.

Contributing members of the American Federation of Arts will have the privilege on Nov. 8 of viewing famous private art collections. This is the sixth of such tours to be sponsored by the nonprofit, educational organization that was founded in 1909 to foster the production and cultivate the appreciation of art.
NOT all beauties sleep. Many spend the wee hours of the morning getting their hair done in all-night beauty salons.
Peace between this country's two major seamen's unions appeared imminent yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 23 (AP) -- An Appellate Court today acquitted three young Italian noblemen and a night club celebrity who had been convicted and jailed in one of Rome's most sensational narcotics trials.
The Shell Oil Company and its subsidiaries increased their net income in the third quarter of 1958 although sales fell.

American Airlines yesterday received its first jet airplane, a Boeing 707, and also received permission to operate jets from Idlewild. The jet was delivered in Seattle, Wash., at a plant of the Boeing Airplane Company.

Daniel P. Loomis, president of the American Association of Railroads, predicted yesterday "a great future for the railroads." He denied recent reports "that railroads want to get out of the passenger business."
Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night attacked "weak, hold-the-status-quo, defeatist" attitudes in international policy and domestic politics.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -Alfred Jonniaux, artist, worked over a portrait of Carl S. Ell, president of Northeastern University, today to improve the likeness and make it "look younger."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The United Nations was cautioned today that Communist China soon might possess the atomic bomb.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- A performance by Pablo Casals, the world famous 'cellist, will highlight the observance of United Nations Day tomorrow. The concert in the General Assembly hall will begin at 3 P. M.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev does not exactly practice what he preaches about liquor.
TABLE settings by sixteen New York women renowned as gracious hostesses are now on view on the second and third floors of Tiffany's. The showing will continue through Nov. 24.
F. Eberstadt Co. and associates are offering today 400,000 shares of Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation common stock at $15 a share. The offering does not represent company financing.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 23 (UPI) -- South Carolina spotted Clemson a second-quarter touchdown today and then spoiled the Tigers' perfect record with a 26-6 upset victory.
The No. 2 Colliery at Springhill, N. S., is described as the deepest coal operation in North America, in a statement by the owners, the Dominion Coal and Steel Company.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Federal Judge J. Skelly Wright handed down a final decree today ordering desegregation of the public schools of Orleans Parish [New Orleans County] as soon as necessary arrangements could be made.

A merger plan has been approved "in principle" by the directors of the McCrory Stores Corporation and the McLellan Stores Company. McCrory would be the surviving name for the combined variety-store operation.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Birdie Tebbetts, the Milwaukee Braves' newly hired executive vice president, emerged today as heir apparent to the presidency of the baseball club.
Nelson A. Rockefeller said last night that the belief of some persons that "politics is a dirty business" was to him "one of the greatest of tragedies."
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 23 -Secretary of State Dulles and President Chiang Kai-shek announced today that it had been agreed that the Nationalists would not use force to return to the Chinese mainland.
Because of their physical limitations New York's piers ought not to be compared unfavorably with European piers, Ralph Kelly, Commissioner of Customs, said yesterday.

AS a rule the only sports writers who discuss football during the world series are the incorrigibles from the Deep South. But the last series seemed to drag out so long that typewriter-pounders from the Southwest, the Pacific Coast and the Midwest began muscling into the conversation.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Nikolai A. Mikhailov, Soviet Minister of Culture, said today that it was up to the Soviet Union of Authors to decide whether Mr. Pasternak would be permitted to receive the prize, it was reported here.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 23 (AP) -- J. Graham Brown's Bornastar surprised almost no one today when she raced to a five-length victory in the $73,650 Spinster Stakes, her second victory in a row in this Keeneland feature.

L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, declared yesterday that Governor Harriman had demonstrated "political hypocrisy at its worst" during his visit to Harlem on Wednesday night with former President Harry S. Truman.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The French sought a showdown today in the talks on the European free trade area by making a proposal that few believed the British would accept.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A Federal judge rejected today a request by the Retail Clerks Union that separate collective bargaining elections be halted in three Toledo department stores.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 25 -- A vehement denunciation of Boris Pasternak and the Swedish Academy that awarded him the 1958 Nobel Prize for Literature Thursday will appear in Moscow this morning.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said last night that those "who besmirch the name of labor are very, very, very few."
Wide gains for a few specialties again gave the stock market a surface appearance of strength yesterday, but in most important groups losses outnumbered gains.

It took the Chilean-bred 5-year-old Meeting to enable Irish-born Johnny Ruane to break his losing streak at fifty-four races yesterday. Ruane, one of the more popular riders competing hereabouts, guided the South American horse to a five-length triumph over Rare Treat in the feature event at Jamaica and was happy, indeed, to do so. It was his first victory since Oct. 6, when he won at Belmont Park.
GENEVA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A new international sugar agreement was unanimously adopted today by a forty-nation conference that includes all major sugar exporting and importing countries.
Nuclear Metals, Inc., one of the pioneer organizations in this country formed to develop materials for nuclear work, formally opened its new $2,000,000 laboratory yesterday at Concord, Mass.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 24 (UPI) -- A left-handed swinger, Jack Brittain Sr., of Woodhaven, Queens, and the Southern senior champion, J. Wolcott Brown, reached the final of the North and South senior golf tournament today with 3-and-2 semifinal victories.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered proceedings to determine whether the broker-dealer registration of the J. H. Lederer Company, Inc., 56 Beaver Street, should be revoked and whether the concern should be suspended or expelled from the National Association of Securities Dealers.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation denied today union allegations that it had filed misleading statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission about its proposed employe stock-saving plan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower claimed new stability for the dollar and Democratic national headquarters alleged "smears" against its candidates today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Tuscarora Indians lost a legal round today in their fight to prevent the New York State Power Authority from taking possession of 1,383 acres of their reservation.

HAVANA, Oct. 24 -- Nearly all the American employes and members of their families at the United States Government-owned Nicaro nickel plant in eastern Cuba were evacuated late today by the United States Navy.
Two men were seized yesterday after the theft of a $1,600 payroll from a woman bookkeeper on Fifth Avenue. Shots were fired along the crowded street in a chase following the robbery.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 24 -- The man they used to call the Lion of Kashmir became a prisoner in the dock today.
The Public Service Commission gave permission yesterday to the Long Island Rail Road to stop handling less-than-carload lots of freight at seven metropolitan stations.

The shuffling of tenors for the Anita Cerquetti recital tomorrow at 5:30 P. M. in Carnegie Hall seems to have been resolved. Not Eugenio Fernandi, or Daniele Barioni, but Flaviano Labo will be the Italian soprano's partner.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Losses continued to predominate among the principal share groups on the stock exchange today. South African gold mining shares, which had been the firm exception in the past few days also turned dull.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 24 -- Less than thirty hours after the lifting of a curfew on youths in Nicosia, a British civilian was shot dead this morning.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood and Charlotte De Cozen of Montclair combined for a gross 41, 39 -- 80 under the Pinehurst scoring system to win a Women's New Jersey Golf Association tournament today at Rock Spring.

Production plans are moving ahead for Edward Chodorov's new mystery play, "Listen to the Mocking Bird." Biff McGuire has been engaged to depict the romantic lead and Francis Compton has agreed to portray the featured role of the British Chief Inspector of Police.

A group of five buildings at 258, 260 and 262 Seigel Street and 237-29 Moore Street in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn has been purchased for investment by the 169 Blake Avenue Realty Corporation. The property, which is assessed at $82,000, contains ninety-three apartments and five stores. It was sold by Betty Schwartz through I. Shifren Sons, brokers.

MESERVEY, Iowa, Oct. 22 -- A complete boarding house for cows that frees farmers from dairy chores and gives many of them a higher milk profit has appeared on the north-central Iowa prairie.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation again operated in the red in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30. But the independent was in prominent company for the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation also reported big losses this week.

LINCOLNTON, N. C., Oct. 24 (AP) -- A posse tracked down a 28-year-old former convict near here tonight and shot him to death in a brief gun battle that ended a trail of slayings.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 -Minus two backfield regulars, Army's undefeated football team regarded tomorrows contest against rugged one-beaten Pittsburgh with considerable trepidation today.

TORONTO, Oct. 24 -- The university's primary task now is to produce members of a new class of professional intellectuals, Dr. Claude T. Bissell said today. He was speaking on the occasion of his installation as eighth president of the University of Toronto.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- United States auto factories built 69,599 cars and 16,288 trucks this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The total of 75,887 contrasted with 59,696, or 45,387 cars and 14,209 trucks, last week.

There were 10,600 fewer claims for unemployment insurance benefits in New York State last week. The total dropped from 353,000 the week before to 342,400.

LODI, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner urged residents of New Jersey today to support the United Nations as the best mechanism for preserving world peace.

Department stores and other retailers are expanding the use of revolving credit to recapture from the automobile industry a larger share of the consumer's dollar. The trend was noted by R. M. Severa, executive manager of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc.

Surrounded with all the political fanfare that Premier Khrushchev could apply, the Russian Government has announced a loan of $100 million (at the official exchange rate) to help President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic to proceed with construction of the Aswan Dam.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 23 -- The revolutoinary actions in Thailand this week have been motivated more by the self-interest of the ruling military clique than by any profound anxiety about Communist subversion here, according to some informed observers.

A group of eminent Republicans in a letter published in The Time on Oct. 20 endorsing Kenneth Keating for the Senate, quote me as having said of Frank Hogan that he had "hardly voiced a public though on a national issue in half a century."

Ten thousand residents of New York State in military service already have returned their ballots for the state election, William T. Simpson, chairman of the State Division for Service Men's Voting, reported yesterday.
EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Oct. 24 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon continued today his party's attack on the "radical bloc" of the Democratic party.
OLEAN, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- A widowed mother of seven children won a new chance today in her effort to keep a foreign car won last week in a nationwide contest.
The names of the patrons and patronesses committee for the ninth annual Fan Ball to be held in the Plaza on Nov. 14 have been announced by Mrs. Diego Suarez, chairman of that committee.
ALBANY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals held today that the Independent-Socialist party's slate of statewide candidates should be listed on the Nov. 4 election ballot.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The orbiting rocket of Sputnik III is due to make a spectacular passage up the East Coast tomorrow night shortly after 7 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

A sharp dispute appears to be developing over the future of the Army's space research program. The question is whether or not the new National Aeronautics and Space Administration should take over key elements of the Army's research organization. President Eisenhower has indicated that no such shift would be approved without careful study.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Frank S. Hogan picked up two unexpected votes and a 13-year-old volunteer campaigner today on a bus ride from Buffalo to Batavia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (UPI) -Every member of the Chicago Black Hawks was fined $100 today for "indifferent play." Tommy Ivan, the club's general manager, said the penalty was triggered by the Hawks' 9-1 loss last night to Montreal.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- That old gang of Jimmy Durante's is a thing of the past after more than four decades.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 24 -- George W. Cornell was chosen this evening by Republican leaders of the Thirty-First State Senatorial District as their candidate to succeed Senator Pliny W. Williamson. Mr. Cornell, a New York lawyer for the last thirty years, has been the Supervisor of Scarsdale since 1947.

The volume of new corporate security offerings should rise sharply next week. More than $175,000,000 in debt securities are to be offered, as well as four major issues of preferred and a number of common stock issues.
The Philharmonic was in good form yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall for its fourth week of the season under the direction of Leonard Bernstein.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 3 points lower yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
A charge that the improvement of schools was sometimes sabotaged by the teaching profession was made yesterday by Henry Toy Jr., president of the National Citizens Council for Better Schools.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Sinclair Weeks resigned today as Secretary of Commerce, effective by Nov. 10. President Eisenhower accepted the resignation "with keen regret."

The board of directors of the American Cancer Society decided yesterday against starting an evaluation of the controversial cancer drug Krebiozen on the terms of a proposal submitted by proponents of the drug.
DETROIT, Oct. 24 -- A Royal Air Force jet bomber, described as an Avro Vulcan delta-wing four-engine craft, crashed and exploded among houses along the Detroit River this afternoon.

Charles Upson Clark's letter published Oct. 11, advocating the commencement of diplomatic relations between the United States and the Vatican, discussed the issue from a rather "practical" point of view. It fails to deal with the very crucial question of the separation of church and state.

Recovery from the business recession which began in August a year ago is now well advanced, President Eisenhower told a group of Republican party workers in Chicago. This has been achieved, he added, without resort to the "massive public works" and the "avalanche of public spending" for which the Democrats in Congress were clamoring last winter.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 24 -Cornell and Princeton, each with 2-0 won-lost records in Ivy League football, will meet before an expected 23,000 spectators at Schoellkopf Field tomorrow.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 24 -- Pablo Casals, the world-famous 'cellist, was a star of the United Nations Day celebrations here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -The forty-third football game between Navy and Pennsylvania since 1888 will be played tomorrow at Franklin Field before an expected crowd of 25,000. A parade of 2,000 midshipmen, will start at 12:40 P. M.
Two officers of Local 102 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union were convicted by a Federal Court jury yesterday of extortion and conspiracy.
WARSAW, Oct. 24 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, heading an eleven-man Government and Communist party delegation, left here by train today for Moscow on a state visit to the Soviet Union.
SPRINGHILL, N. S., Oct. 24 -- Eighty-five men were still missing -- dead or held captive by barriers of rock and gas -- in the depths of a coal mine here tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Saudi Arabia warned today that an Israeli attack on Jordan would call for collective military action by all the Arab states.

A RARE study of an artist and a man was caught on the home screen yesterday afternoon in the televising of the performance by Pablo Casals, the 'cellist, at the United Nations General Assembly Hall. It was a program of quietly moving grandeur.

The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday substantial gains in operating revenues and net income for the September quarter and for the twelve months ended Sept. 30. It attributed the rise to improved business and a rate adjustment granted the fourth quarter last year.

A group of 450 students from high schools here attended yesterday the first city-wide seminar on "Rocketry in the Space Age" at Stuyvesant High School. The rocketeers, including a dozen girls, shot fast questions about so-called exotic fuels and rocket construction at a panel of experts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 -- The first quarterly report of the Firstamerica Corporation, the nation's largest bank holding company, showed today an income of $2,400,000, equal to 22 cents a share. Its consolidated net income, including Firstamerica's proportion of the net income of its subsidiaries, amounted to $3,800,000, or 34 cents a share.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Joan Fontaine, the actress, was convicted of contempt of court today in a child-custody case.
SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Indonesia is urging the United States to fill the need for ships to replace Dutch vessels that formerly served in Indonesia's vital inter-island trade.
Protestants over the country will observe Reformation Sunday tomorrow.

In one of the boldest and most dramatic moves that he has made thus far General de Gaulle has tried to cut right through the Algerian impasse and bring about an honorable peace. He has invited the rebel leaders to come to Paris, under a guarantee of safe conduct, to make a "brave man's peace."

Dr. Charles Malik, president of the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday that "work for peace should take place far more in the member nations than in the United Nations." Prime objectives, he said, should be the spirit of justice and reason and the ideal of the free man.
ROME, Oct. 25 -- The hereditary Marshal of the Conclave, Prince Sigismondo Pietro Chigi della Rovere-Albani, was visiting the World's Fair in Brussels when he learned that Pope Pius XII was dying.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 24 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today he did not favor the abolishment of the public school system in Arkansas as a possible next move in the racial integration dispute.
New York's thirteenth consecutive season in the National Basketball Association will begin tonight at Madison Square Garden.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 24 (Reuters) -- Bela Kovacs, a member of Premier Imre Nagy's "inner cabinet" during the 1956 Hungarian revolt, has been nominated as a parliamentary candidate for the Nov. 16 general election, it was announced here today.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz obtained a court order yesterday against a Brooklyn television repair concern which, he charged, had defrauded customers of more than $500,000 a year.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Oct. 24 -- Governor Harriman was asked today to investigate the legality of permitting Philip B. Kohut, Democratic leader here, to hold a post as Public Safety Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The feeling in official circles here today was that Secretary of State Dulles had persuaded Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek that steps must be taken toward demilitarization of the Chinese offshore islands when the time was propitious.

MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 24 -- A program defining the new objectives of the Zionist movement, including the proposal that Zionism must develop the "creative potentialities" of Jewish life, culture and religion outside of Israel, was projected here today.

A hockey matinee, the first of four Saturday afternoon programs in which the Rangers will be involved on home ice this season, will be presented at Madison Square Garden today. It will be the Rangers against the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League's television game of the week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that the Eisenhower Administration was mistakenly concentrating on military assistance in attempting to win friends abroad for the United States.
The "tall youth" who pushed a trunk containing a murdered man's body into the Hudson River Thursday was described yesterday as the victim's son.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 24 -- The Boeing Airplane Company has found a way to put out fires inside aircraft with a giant "hypodermic." Apparatus patented this week pierces the plane's outer wall with an auger and injects extinguishing fluid.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Corn and soybean futures extended recent declines on the Board of Trade today. Wheat closed mixed with only small price changes.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 24 -- The West German Government rejected today as "political propaganda" a new trade offer from East Germany.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The United States and Canada have undertaken to extend the continental defense systems farther north.
DETROIT, Oct. 23 -- The one great concern of Michigan's voters is their pocketbooks.
HARRISBURG, Oct. 24 (AP) -- West Germany completed its sweep of major honors at the thirteenth Annual Pennsylvania National Horse Show today, winning both international jumping events.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Gen. Mohammed Ayub Khan, a Sandhurst-trained army man who commands in characteristic British accents, was named Prime Minister of Pakistan tonight.
Ground will be broken this morning for the $750,000 Merchant/ Marine Memorial Chapel at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (AP) -A new method of taking antituberculosis vaccine, by inhalation, was described by a scientist tonight.
ROME, Oct. 24 -- Fifty-two cardinals still wearing violet mourning robes will enter into a Conclave of the Sacred College of Cardinals tomorrow afternoon to elect a successor to Pope Pins XII.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery charged today that the United States must bear a large share, "perhaps most of the blame," for the present world situation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.2 per cent to 118.6 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- During his five months of regained power General de Gaulle has put on the most dazzling virtuoso performance since another Frenchman, called Blondin, walked across Niagara Falls on a tightrope just ninety-nine years ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- Senator William F. Knowland indicated today he now was seeking his last public office if Californians failed to elect him Governor on Nov. 4.

PEOPLE who intend to send Christmas presents overseas are reminded that early mailing is imperative because of the long sea transit, customs inspections and delay in delivery. All parcels should be securely packed. Thin pasteboard containers invite trouble; they should be of sturdy cardboard.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet offer of aid to the United Arab Republic for the Aswan High Dam had an immediate and powerful propaganda effect all through the Middle East today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 UPI) -- The United States Department of Agriculture today estimated the world's cotton crop in 1958-59 at 42,300,000 bales, an increase of 2,100,000 from 1957-58.
The basic concept of the U. S. O. is the traditionally American concept of neighborliness and the desire to provide for the needs of others through volunteers working together.

The editorial in The New York Times of Oct. 13 headed "United Hospital Fund" rightly points out the important functions and services which the voluntary hospitals provide to the people in the community. However, to balance this very positive aspect, there is a degree of exploitation, particularly of Negro and Puerto Rican workers, in these voluntary hospitals that does not exist in any other area of private or public endeavor.
Frank S. Hogan, Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator, charged last night that the Republicans "have shown more concern for dollars than for the security of our country."
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The Roman Catholic Church and the state quarreled in public today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, which granted the Jersey Central Railroad an increase last month, has blocked a similar increase request by the Pennsylvania Railroad, pending an investigation.

I note with particular interest the comments in your editorial of Oct. 20 with respect to the endorsement of candidates for the Legislature, more specifically the Twenty-ninth Senatorial District in the Bronx.
WORCESTER, England, Oct. 24 (Reuters) -- Sir Raymond Priestly said today that he was going back to the Antarctic.
Nelson A. Rockefeller delighted a Puerto Rican crowd in East 108th Street last night by introducing his daughter-in-law (nuera) as his granddaughter (nieta).

Consolidated earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first nine months of 1958 were 30 per cent below those of the corresponding period a year ago. Revenues declined about 5 per cent.

WITH the holiday season around the corner, it is not too early to think about Christmas cards. New York stores already have accumulated a multitude of cards of every variety imaginable. Religious themes, which have been gaining in popularity for the last two years, hit a new high this year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt, Democratic candidate for re-election, charged here today that Nelson A. Rockefeller in his Republican campaign for Governor was using "false and irresponsible" data from former Gov, Thomas E. Dewey.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The board of directors of the International Society of Catholic Men, better known as the Knights of Columbus, today re-elected its supreme officers for another year.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Fourteen Negroes were jailed last night following their conviction on misdemeanor charges growing out of demonstrations against racial segregation on buses.
Governor Harriman and Nelson A. Rockefeller met yesterday with two small-party candidates for Governor to record an hour-long program that will be carried on WCBS-TV at 10:30 o'clock tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Musical observances celebrating United Nations Day took place today in Paris, Geneva and the General Assembly hall here.

For the second time in thirteen months Marshal Sarit, the army's strong man in Thailand, has staged a quick and bloodless coup to overthrow the Government. His previous attack was made against a man who was really strong in the political, not the military, sense, Pibul Songgram. That was presumably a coup against a dictatorship.

The Far East crisis has helped farmers in this country somewhat by bolstering prices for this year's record wheat crop, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. It also commented that many farmers have been withholding wheat from the market.

The New York Central Railroad earned $1,907,498 last month, compared with $278,659 in September of 1957, but the system for the first nine months this year suffered an $8,443,064 net loss. In the first three quarters of 1957, net income was $8,759,018, equal to $1.35 a share.
Weeks of organized bedlam at political headquarters go into making a campaign run smoothly. The present race for Governor is no exception.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- Patients suffering from apoplectic strokes, have been relieved of paralysis, loss of speech and visual disturbances' by operatiohs, it" was reported today.
Cocoa futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange rose the daily limit of 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in all but one contract yesterday.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Dr. Isidor S. Ravdin, chairman of the department of surgery at the University of Pennsylvania, asserted today that socialization of medicine in the United States would lead to similar changes in other professions and, very likely, in industry.

PASSAIC, N. J., Oct, 24 -The Forstmann Woolen Company announced today the closing of its manufacturing operation here. Officials of the company, a division of J. P. Stevens Co., declined to say when the move would be effective. An estimated total of 400 employes is involved.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 24 -- Appeals to religious bigotry in national election compaigns have shown a sharp decline in the last decade, Irving M. Engel of New York, president of the American Jewish Committee, said today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 24 (AP) -- An oceangoing ore carrier said to be cheaper and more efficient than vessels now in use was described today by the two young University of Michigan graduate students who designed it.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle waited today for the Algerian rebels to act on his offer of truce talks while totally contradictory French political forces praised his courage and boldness.

Governor Harriman charged last night that his Republican opponent, Nelson A. Rockefeller, was "trying very hard to get people to think he isn't a Republican." Mr. Harriman also accused his rival of "gratuitously" associating himself with many of the accomplishments of his Administration.

The International Business Machines Corporation is selling its domestic time equipment division to the Simplex Time Recorder Company of Gardner. Mass., on Dec. 1. The amount of cash involved was not disclosed.
A leading Viennese psychiatrist said yesterday that insulin shock treatments had "cured" approximately 70 per cent of the schizophrenic patients treated in his clinic in the last ten years.

More than 85,000 acres of South Texas "sorry land," once eroded and overgrown with brush, have been transformed into fertile range with the aid of specially designed tractor plows produced by Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Stan (The Man) Musial disappointed his Japanese fans today by failing to make a hit as the St. Louis Cardinals won the opening game of a tour with the Japanese All-Stars, 5 -- 2.
Things have got to the point where the word science is thought of as synonymous with the word future. Penetrations in space and in the inner world of the atom have made us horizon-conscious.

Earnings of the United States Gypsum company rose in the third quarter over those of a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday. But net for the first nine months of this year was below the level in the period last year.

Today's children's film program at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets, will be "The Chinese Village," "The Grasshopper and the Ant" and "Bushy the Squirrel.'' The showings will be at 11 A. M. and 1:15 P. M.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Efforts by Irish officials in the United Nations were reported today to have paved the way for truce talks that Premier Charles de Gaulle of France proposed to the Algerian rebels.
SEATTLE, Oct. 24 -- Electricity generated by coal-fired steam plants could be produced economically in this region of abundant water power, according to a report made public here today.

Cornucopia Lodge of Masons at 137-70 Northern Boulevard, Flushing. Queens, will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today. There will also be a donation at Floyd Bennet Field, Brooklyn, for the Hemophilia Foundation of New York.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Two Soviet horses and a five-man Soviet delegation leave for Berlin tomorrow -- without American visas -- en route to Laurel Park in Maryland for the Washington D. C. International race.

Howard S. Cullman, United States commissioner general at the Brussels World's Fair, said in his return to New York yesterday that United States participation in the fair had been a major undertaking'' and "a reat success."
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 25 -- A $3000000 scientific research center will be established at Butler University here.

THIS big, tightly controlled first novel by Mildred Savage is an impressive debut. In this reviewer's opinion, here is a new young writer whose style and approach suggest that she has sprung, full-panoplied, from the brow of Edna Ferber.
Governor Harriman and his Republican opponent, Nelson A. Rockefeller, appeared face to face in an hour-long television program last night. It was the nearest thing to a debate in the state campaign.

THE much vaunted World Review of Cinematographic Festival, Mexico's first attempt at an international film convention, now in progress at the huge National Auditorium here, will end tomorrow after seventeen days of confusion, political demonstrations and compounded frustrations.
A new organization has been formed to help finance United States participation in the sailing at the Olympic Games and other international events.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 25 -- Three contenders for the Presidency of Venezuela have accepted nominations. But all three said today -- six weeks before the election Dec. 7 -- that they would withdraw if the three principal political parties would agree on a single "unity" candidate.

IN a recent study conducted by the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan, it was found that the public's greatest interest in science news is centered on new ways of treating disease. It also found that heart disease, which ranks first as the cause of death in the United States, was the diagnostic category in which most persons are interested.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 20 -- The director of Iranian internal security reaffirmed his "complete confidence" today in the loyalty of Iran's Kurds should outside agitators try to stir them up in a new effort to disturb the equilibrium of the Middle East.

THE distinguished gringo H. Allen Smith has written his Mexican memoirs in the book by the above title. He has also discovered an economic theory that has me hanging on the ropes. It seems that a certain United States firm became interested in a straw mat made by a small Mexican Indian tribe.

HAVANA, Oct. 25 -- General elections will be held in Cuba Nov. 3 in an unusual electoral situation that includes suspension of constitutional guarantees and censorship of press and radio. Furthermore, the armed forces have supreme power in the republic.
Recent sharp and unforeseen fluctuations in the market for Government securities have focused attention anew on the machinery for marketing the Government's debt.

French antique furniture, decorations and a large collection of antique watches and other gold and jeweled "objets de vertu" will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Gettysburg kept its unbeaten record today by defeating Muhlenberg, 7 -- 6, before a rain-soaked Homecoming Day crowd of 5,000. The victory was the fourth of the campaign against one tie.
Daylight - saving time ended at 2 A. M. today in the city and many other parts of the country.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 25 -- When Oklahoma voters go to the polls on Nov. 4 to elect a Governor and six United States Representatives, the Democrats will be favored to win in all but one Congressional race.

FIRST as a fan of tender years, later as journalist, broadcaster and author, John R. Tunis has loved sports since the early days of this century. His sports books for boys, particularly those dealing with Indiana and its passion for basketball, have thrilled teen-agers for a generation.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Georgia Bulldogs today scored twice in ten seconds with the aid of a stolen kick-off and trounced Kentucky, 28 -- 0, before 31,000 fans.

FRED ASTAIRE is 59 years young. His recent evening of song and dance over the National Broadcasting Company's television network was a joy, an hour that will rank among the great contemporary theatre nights in any media.

As producer of an enchanting, child-like film, "Around the World in Eighty Days," Mike was at the peak of his career -- triumphant, rich, living flamboyantly in the public eye, which was what he loved to do.
Soviet scientists have reported the discovery of "rich veins of excellent iron ore" in Antarctica. They also believe a large iron ore basin lies beneath the ice covering the continent's interior.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Two-place-kick conversions by the Norwich quarter back, Pete Cronin, coupled with a safety, provided the cadets with the margin for a 16-12 victory over Vermont today.

THE historical novelist, F. W. Kenyon, re-creator of such figures as Empress Josephine and Marie Antoinette, has in his newest book made fiction of the long and extraordinary life of Queen Elizabeth -- from early teens until death.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Arkansas Board of Education said today it would start payment Monday of $24.50 a month to hundreds of students who have transferred from Little Rock's four high schools closed in the integration dispute.

THE Moscow Art Theatre is sixty years old this month, and it is celebrating with memories: memories of the stern Stanislavsky and his once brash Method, memories of a theatre's adolescent ardor and zeal, memories of naughty days when Czarist censors lurked in the wings and policemen masqueraded as ushers but the shows went on, memories of troubles and triumphs before stability and security set in.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct 25 -- (UPI) -- Bill Crank scored once, stopped three touchdown drives with intercepted passes and got Kansas' split-T option play rolling for the first time this season as the lowly Jayhawks startled Tulane by winning, 14 -- 9 today.
The Maritime Overseas Corporation, which was hitherto identified only with dry cargo shipping, has ordered a 35,000-leadweight ton tanker from the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Brookings Institution announced today a grant of $6,200,000 from the Ford Foundation to be used for establishment of a new center for advanced study and research here.

In New York the personalities of the rival candidates for Governor appear far more likely to determine the outcome of this year's state election than any issues that either candidate has raised thus far.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- For the first time in nearly four years of struggle in Algeria, France this week regained the political initiative in dealings with the nationalist rebellion. This was achieved on Thursday by Premier Charles de Gaulle with an off-hand ease that made his predecessors' fumblings with the same problem seem all the more inept.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Republicans searched without much apparent success this week for evidence that two days of California stumping by President Eisenhower had materially helped their election prospects.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct, 25 (AP) -- Two young men were killed and another was seriously injured today when their automobile rammed the rear of a truck carrying pumpkins on the Lincoln Highway, eleven miles east of here.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 25 -- The last United States troops left today after 102 days here to support the Lebanese Government against possible aggression.

THE South's defeat in the Civil War was a tale of three cities: Vicksburg, Atlanta and Richmond. The last of these may have been the latest to fail; but it was both the cause and the result of the losses of the former two, thanks to a Confederate obsession with defending an exposed capital at the expense of an exposed lifeline.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Eisenhower prodded the Soviet Union today to announce whether it would be represented in Geneva next Friday for negotiations to suspend the testing of nuclear weapons.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 25 -- The University of Delaware football team scored a dramatic upset today over Connecticut's highly touted Huskies, 28 -- 0, before 5,184 Homecoming Day fans at Delaware Stadium.

The Children's Convalescent Hospital in Washington, which for seventy years has cared for convalescent indigent children under 6 years old, will benefit from the fourth International Ball at the Sheraton Park Hotel on Nov. 7.
OTTAWA, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A Government commission today recommended putting exports of Canadian natural gas under governmental license.

Teachers College of Columbia University announced yesterday that it had received $12,464,000 in its first ten years of organized fund raising.
