ON the night of June 30, 1958, as the reading clerk intoned the roll, I was presiding over the United States Senate. The ornate chamber bristled with tension and excitement. The first new state in more than forty-six years was being admitted to the Union -- Alaska, soon to become by far the biggest state of all.

The New York Knickerbockers and Boston Celtics, who have waged many an exciting game, put on another thriller last night as they opened their National Basketball Association season at Madison Square Garden.

INDOOR growers now have the green light to go ahead with fall house-plant keeping. And to simplify the chores, garden supply stores are featuring novel pots, tools, soils, fertilizers and insect sprays.
In your issue of Oct. 18 Eugene C. Gerhart assures us that "our Supreme Court is still the most trustworthy guardian of what we are proud to call the American way of life."
Mr. Salisbury (as well as the editors of Fortune and Lewis Mumford) still seem to suffer from a typically prejudiced, "urban" point of view.
DENVER, Oct. 25 -- A $16,000,000 program to fit Denver's Stapleton airfield for the jet age is being delayed by a conflict between the city and Air Force over Federal land needed for expansion.

HOLLYWOOD'S major motion-picture studios, which nave made millions in selling pre-1948 feature films to television, are planning to dig deeper into the barrel. What they have in mind now is additional revenue from the sale of silent movies. Presumably television stations would offer these to a nostalgic viewing public with a little piano music in ragtime.

George Maran, American tenor who was to have made his debut with the New York City Opera last week in Mozart's "Abduction From the Seraglio," appeared in the second performance of the opera yesterday afternoon.
Pablo Casals paid the homage of tears yesterday to his native Spain.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sunday, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Communist guns fired on the Nationalist offshore islands today a few hours after Peiping announced it would withhold firing on an off-again-on-again basis. The defense ministry here reported. Today was the first of the even numbered days.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 -- The Citizens Committee for Economic Stability cited today a Federal Communications Commission report in an effort to prove that radio station WKRC was required to grant free, equal time to oppose radio editorials for the "right to work" Ohio constitutional amendment.
JERSEY CITY, Oct, 25 -- St. Peter's Prep downed Hackensack High, 25 -- 0, today under the worst possible weather conditions before almost 5,000 at Roosevelt Stadium.
IOWA CITY, Oct. 25 -- The deadly aerial shots of Iowa's Randy Duncan swept the unbeaten Hawkeyes into undisputed Big Ten football leadership today with a 26-20 tri umph over Northwestern.
TUNIS, Oct. 25 -- Mathilde Lorrain Bourguiba, the wife of President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia, embraced Islam today after thirty-two years of marriage to the Moslem leader.
AS things look now the supply of wild ducks this year is going to be at least as good as last year's and probably a little better.

ONE realizes that E. E. Cummings knows exactly what he is doing and where he is going -- has known ever since World War I, when a divinely inspired error threw him into a French concentration camp (described in "The Enormous Room," my favorite book of that period) and taught him to keep himself to himself.
Judges, lawyers and legislators from the United States and Europe will attend the 100th anniversary conference of the Columbia University School of Law here from Nov. 6 to 8.
Governor Harriman and Nelson Rockefeller joined last night in paying warm tribute to the old Czechoslovak Republic.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Mississippi, with a sixteen-pound-per-man advantage in the line, just managed to beat the Arkansas football team, 14 -- 12, today, on two first - half touchdowns. The heavily-favored rebels were outplayed in the second half.
NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- The United Nations will be the theme of the Christmas decorations at Bamberger's five department stores in New Jersey.

Art attractions this week include a wide variety of events. Besides one-man shows of work by well-known American and European artists, new exhibitions include primitive sculpture in metal at the Museum of Primitive Art, work by the Japanese master Hiroshige, the forty-ninth annual of painting and sculpture by the Allied Artists, and group shows of work by modern European artists.

PARIS -- Today American and British jet airliners are doing business as usual across the North Atlantic and the long-awaited jet age, so widely and excitedly heralded by the aviation industry, has at last arrived.
The first direct air route between Alaska and Europe will be established by the Scandinavian Airlines System next Wednesday.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- The talks in Paris on a European free trade area have been confused mainly because of basic differences between the aims of the two protagonists, France and Britain.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Bill Austin scored three touchdowns on the ground and passed for two as Rutgers defeated Lehigh 44 -- 13, today.
PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 25 -- One hundred and fifty school children were introduced to opera here this morning by Paterson Lyric Opera Theatre, a new nonprofit group.
Oh Johnny came marching home again at Jamaica yesterday. The 5-year-old won the $28,350 Queens County Handicap for Mrs. Wallace Gilroy, beating Robert S. Howard's Whatitoldyou by a head.

THE author's love affair with Louisiana continues in this romance of the rice and sugar country during the Twenties. A lineal descendant of Frances Parkinson Keyes' last novel, "Blue Camellia," the story of Victorine concerns the return of a cosmopolitan, half-Jewish, half-Roman Catholic girl to Louisiana with her father, a successful merchant and dress designer who has come home to die.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- British neurologists are exploring the mechanism of minute "muscles within the muscles" of human limbs in the hope that it will alleviate cerebral palsy, a fairly widespread disease.
Scare buying, strikes, price rises and production increases all helped give the copper market one of its liveliest romps in years last week.

* * * Your critic has pounced heavily on the book of "Goldilocks," but his perception of the enjoyment that the production brought to those in the audience may be dulled because of his preoccupation with the categories of Broadway: Is this production a musical comedy, a revue, a loose scenario, etc.?
Another entry in the small-car economy import field will make its bow here tomorrow. The car, a two-cylinder rear-engine product is the Prinz.

THE latest fad in humor is the space joke now in orbit. Almost ubiquitous these days are japes like the one about the Martian who lands near a small town, drifts into the local tavern, looks the juke box square in its flashing, jangling, spinning face and says, "What's a hip chick like you doing in a dead burg like this?"
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Criminal Court Judge Homer Weimar overruled today a defense motion to free John Kasper of charges of inciting to riot.
The re-election of Governor Harriman by 318,000 votes was predicted yesterday by Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman.

Stock prices and stock volume went down together last week. No definite reason was evident for the changed appearance of the market. Among the causes advanced, however, were a deterioration in the Far East situation, a belated effect of the recent rise in margins, poor earnings reports and impairment of the market's technical position.
VIENNA, Oct. 23 -- Forty-six thousand Gypsies, itinerant peddlers, knife grinders, umbrella repairmen and hoboes were legislated off the highways and byways of Czechoslovakia last week.

ATHENS, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- Greece will not participate in any round-table conference on Cyprus sponsored by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization unless there are guarantees that its results will be "constructive," official sources said today.
A program to help business education produce more leaders was announced last week by the Ford Foundation.

THE plan of Herbert Barrett and others to produce "popular-price" concerts in Carnegie Hall leaves a number of questions unanswered. If lower admission prices for small ensembles and individual recitalists become the rule, the managers of such concerts will be making an open bid to lure the public from the more expensive concerts of the symphony orchestras and other large ensembles.
" The Armed Forces need the services of U. S. O., and nowhere is the need greater than where our forces are stationed overseas," says Admiral Arthur W. Radford, "

Stop pulling my leg. When you say you have printed a painting by Mondrian upside down -- well, okay, even though I defy anyone who has never seen the painting to say which of the four sides is up. But when you add to that the statement that the picture is called "Trafalgar Square" -- well, have you ever been in Trafalgar Square?
HOUSTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Alvin Hartman, a 207-pound sophomore quarterback, scored two touchdowns tonight as Rice upset previous unbeaten Texas, 34 -- 7, before an overflow crowd of 72,000.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Rolling up a first-half lead of 31 points, the Williams football team then held off previously unbeaten Tufts to win, 37 -- 8, at Weston Field.
World-wide shipbuilding activity continued unabated during the third quarter of this year. As a result ship construction reached the highest level ever recorded.
Yesterday's rainstorm brought misery to most New Yorkers, but it got about twenty music lovers into the Metropolitan Opera House.
Pleas for the support of the city's charitable institutions under Jewish auspices were made yesterday at the Sabbath services in many synagogues.

EARLY along in John Ford's rendering of Edwin O'Connor's "The Last Hurrah," the novel that does for politicians what "The World of Suzie Wong" does for prostitutes, its veteran political hero, silver-haired Frank Skeffington, asks his bright-eyed and bushy-tailed nephew what's the most popular spectator- sport in the land.
DESIGNING a home in this Canadian metropolis, one architect has expressed effectively many of the same theories that govern the work of his U. S. colleagues.

Once upon a time, circa 1930, when the rumble seat was starting go to the way of the roadster and isinglass side curtains, the automobile industry began to give serious attention to what it called the "depot wagon," grandfather of today's station wagon.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 16 -- The film version of Irwin Shaw's "The Young Lions" was being shown this week to packed houses in Jerusalem without major incident.
DENVER, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The Air Force Academy pounced on two fumbles and turned them into rapid-fire touchdowns today and downed Utah, 16 -- 14.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 25 -The key to peace in the Middle East lies in the rapid strengthening of Israel, that nation's envoy to the United States said today.

In the long and sometimes tortuous political career of the "Lion of Kashmir," Sheikh Abdullah, nothing has done him more credit than the charge upon which, at long last, he has now been brought to trial. Ostensibly he is being tried for "conspiracy" against the Indian-controlled Kashmiri Government with a view to promoting Kashmir's adherence to Pakistan.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Jay Rhoads scored two first-half touchdowns today in pacing Princeton to a 41-0 trouncing of Columbia in a 150-pound football game on Bedford Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Every election produces enough bilge to float the Queen Mary, and this one is no exception. The difference now is merely that the right honorable gentlemen seem to be throwing it around with less effect than in days of yore.
VIENNA, Oct. 25 -- The period of grace granted to Gyorgy Lukacs, internationally known Hungarian philosopher, to recant his revisionist ideas came to an end last week.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Chuck Zimmerman's passing sparked Syracuse to a 14-6 victory over Penn State today before 27,000 football fans as the Nittany Lions wasted one scoring opportunity after another.

THE revolution in pipe-organ design, which began at the turn of the century when Dr. Albert Schweitzer observed that newly built instruments did not sound as well as the fine old baroque organs they replaced, has had quietly sweeping results.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Minnesota's go-for-broke Gophers spurned a fourth-period chance to tie Michigan today and lost the forty-ninth Little Brown Jug game, 20 --19.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 21 -- There appears no doubt about the outcome of the farm vote on at least one question.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 -- The United States equestrian team scored its fourth international jumping victory in the closing program of the seven-day Pennsylvania National Horse Show last night.
MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins spotted the Montreal Canadiens two early goals tonight, then scored five times for a 5-2 National Hockey League victory.
The twenty-second anniversary dinner of the New York Cardiac Home will take place on Dec. 6 at the Waldorf-Astoria.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Rain that lasted most of the day provided almost ideal hunting conditions today for the thousands who streamed into the Adirondack Mountains to open the big-game season.

ALTHOUGH "Lolita" continues to set the pace as the number-one fiction best seller -- see across the way -- it lately has run into a couple of snags. Perhaps the weirdest of these has been offered by Paris, where again there is a ban against the book -- although not quite a ban.

THE presentation of the "Best Films of All Time" held here this last week produced highly unexpected results with a near riot, and a jury of distinguished directors refusing to carry out the task set them of classifying the twelve best films in order of their relative merits.
I ENJOYED Mr. Mitgang's account of his troopship experiences on the old Santa Paula [issue of Oct. 19] but was distressed to learn that he had to pay $2 for a loaf of bread to augment his G. I. diet.

The twenty-sixth annual ball of the Kosciuszko Foundation will be held Dec. 27 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Proceeds from the event will aid the foundation's extensive scholarship program.

HELENA, Mont., Oct. 25 -- What started out to be one of Montana's quietest general elections has generated a little more power in the past two weeks. But interest this year fails to compare with that in 1956, when the state was electing a Governor.

With the wind and the rain in his hair and splattered by mud, Pete Hoey of Mountain Lakes (N. J.) High School splashed and slithered to a 10-yard victory yesterday in the eleventh annual Fordham University interscholastic cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
The death knell will sound soon for the battered and war-weary freighter Patrick Henry, first of this country's World War II Liberty ships.

BALBOA, Canal Zone -- While the centenary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt tomorrow is being observed here as well as in the mainland United States, the Canal Zone is holding a special celebration in his memory a little later, that is, in the week of Nov. 9 through 15.

OVER the past six or eight years a renewed emphasis by child development specialists on the value of discipline has been counteracting the let-them-do- as-they-please philosophy that influenced the upbringing of many of today's adolescents and young adults.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25 -- The Swedish Academy said today it had received a cablegram from an "immensely thankful" Boris Pasternak accepting the 1958 Nobel Prize for Literature.

Each year uncounted thousands of high school graduates and hundreds of colleges play a chaotic game of musical chairs that leaves some applicants accepted by several colleges and others by none, while some colleges get too many freshmen and others are left with places unfilled.

Gertrude Samuels, in her report from Moscow, "Russians Through 'Unaccustomed Eyes,'" (Oct. 12), writes that Tonia Kizaleva, a militia woman in Irkutsk who directs traffic, receives "six thousand rubles a month salary" in addition to free travel to any resort for her vacation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- After nearly a decade of delay created by political wrangling over the site for a new airport, the capital is finally preparing for the jet age. Early this year the Administration and Congress finally agreed on the site for a modern new airport -- Chantilly, Va., some twenty-seven miles west of the District of Columbia.
President Eisenhower will mix political with nonpolitical activities in a visit to New York that will begin late tomorrow night and continue until Wednesday morning.
The "dark months" -- bringing increased traffic casualties -- begin this week, Acting Police Commissioner James R. Kennedy warned yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 25 -- The South's largest convention and exhibition hall, nearly five acres under one roof, will be dedicated here Monday.
A 29-year-old Brooklyn man was in critical condition at St. Catherine's Hospital last night after pouring a flammable liquid over himself and setting fire to his clothing.

THE dedication of David Dempsey's first novel defines a part of his intention in writing it: the "restoration of a time and a town." The time-span is 1889-1924, when our grandfathers and our fathers flourished and we were growing up.

The merit pay system for teachers, which has managed to split ranks wherever it has been introduced throughout the nation's school districts, was brought up for consideration in New York City last week.
A major expansion and development program has been recommended for the Port of Mobile, Ala., in a study just completed by Theodore J. Richter, a port consultant here:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Sherman Adams spent his last working day at the White House yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The Hyde Park-Kenwood urban renewal plan for rehabilitating 600 acres of dilapidated property in the vicinity of the University of Chicago campus on the South Side was approved unanimously this week by the City Council Housing and Planning Committee.

TOKYO, Oct. 25 (UPI) -Kazuhisa Inao, Japan's 21-year-old "wonder pitcher," was treated roughly by the St. Louis Cardinals today. They routed him in the fourth inning and went on to an 8-2 victory over an all-star team.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 22 -- His Highness the Sultan of Johore seems to be the elephant's best friend in Malaya these days.

THE Right Rev. Robert R. Brown, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Arkansas, has written a penetrating and objective analysis of the tragic occurrences at Little Rock. This is no sermon, although its end effect is to show that the church, with its ministry of reconciliation, must take the lead in demonstrating that mankind can learn to live as brothers under the love of God.

BUFFALO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- James A. Lundy, Republican candidate for State Controller, said today the Harriman Administration "has been the worst administration in our generation in the really vital fields of state government."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Two Republican spokesmen said today that former President Harry S. Truman had been guilty of recklessness and irresponsibility in campaign debate on the civil rights issue.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct, 25 -- The only national issue common to all three states this Times team has surveyed -- Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Maryland -- is the recession. It appears that the same may be true of Ohio, where the survey is not yet complete All four states are closely linked economically.

NEXT Friday, the ghostly grins of jack-o'-lanterns will usher in the pumpkin season. From All-hallows Eve through the yearend holidays, the golden, ribbed vegetable will appear on the nation's menus, principally in the form of pie.

I take great exception to Howard Taubman's statement, made in a review of the Chicago Symphony, that "any visiting orchestra comes to New York prepared to the teeth." It implies that they aren't really as good as they appear.
PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Efforts are under way to locate and salvage the missing parts of John P. Holland's first submarine from the bed of the Passaic River.

Pablo Casals addressed the U. N. General Assembly and its guests last Friday in what was surely the most eloquent speech ever made in those premises. At 81, he spoke with the genius and undiminished mastery of a virtuoso to whom music has become what words are to great writers. He spoke with a passionate devotion to human dignity and freedom.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 25 -- A resolution urging the abolition of the bracero program, involving the importation of Mexican farm workers, was unanimously adopted here this week by the Texas state convention of the merged labor federation.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 25 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said tonight that Republican prospects had improved more this week than in any week "of all the campaigns in which I have participated since 1946."

BETTY CAVANNA is a fine storyteller, and as such she can always carry you along from page to page, asking no questions as to consistency or motivation until after you have finished the book. Many of her very popular novels for young people are satisfactory on all counts.

TWO years ago this month Joseph R. Vogel became president of Loew's, Inc., and plunged into one of the most turbulent management fights in the history of Hollywood. The company's production arm, Metro-Goldwyn- Mayer, once regarded as the Gibraltar of the film world, was in deep financial trouble and it was the opinion of an influential group of stockholders that it should be liquidated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Even though he travels by jet aircraft, Secretary of State Dulles is hard put to overtake his shifting problems in the Taiwan Strait crisis.

The men's furnishings industry plans many changes in accessories this fall and spring in an effort to keep abreast of new styles. The Continental style in suits has attracted interest to men's apparel, an industry spokesman said, and other sectors of the field are attempting to create additional consumer interest.

GARDENING indoors, to a great extent, is window gardening. Natural light is almost invariably better for plants than artificial light. The so-called poor light of, say, a north window may be poor for house plants that need the sun, but it is ideal for plants which thrive on diffused light. Every window, therefore, no matter what its exposure, will provide good conditions for some kind of an indoor garden.

The New York Rangers did not make the mistake of sitting back and playing defensive hockey after gaining a big lead in their National Hockey League clash with the Chicago Black Hawks yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

SPECULATOR, N. Y. -- A distinct note of optimism about the coming season marked the recent annual New York State Winter Sports Council Forum here. The Council consists of ski operators, representatives from the state, resort associations, Chamber of Commerce and equipment and apparel manufacturers.

WHAT price theatre tickets? For the present and for this season, at least, what they are. Although contractual increases have been granted in recent theatrical labor negotiations the sentiment is that theatre ticket prices will be held in line.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The 1958 Nobel Prize in Physics may go to three Soviet atomic scientists whose research may show that light is not the fastest thing in the universe after all.
A sale of an extensive collection of Pennsylvania Dutch a work and furniture from the estate of Arthur J. Sussel of Philadelphia yesterday brought $202,345 at the Parke-Berne Galleries.

Department stores, collectively, can breathe a little easier this week. Their sales for the year to date, according to the Federal Reserve Board, have finally pulled even with those of the corresponding period in 1957.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- In assuming last week the role of the slugging, two-fisted campaigner in his addresses at Los Angeles and San Francisco, President Eisenhower also disclosed the purpose and much of the strategy of the Republican high command in the short time remaining before the election.
The Citizens Union proposed yesterday that the city Art Commission pass on the design of large garages, bus stations and other private structures requiring approval by the City Planning Commission.
The fourteenth annual dinner of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation will be held Thursday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Bryce N. Harlow was sworn in today as Deputy Assistant to President Eisenhower for Congressional Affairs.
DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Duke punched over two last-period touchdowns today and beat North Carolina State, 20 -- 13, before 20,000 fans.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- Edward Cardinal Mooney, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit, died suddenly here today shortly before he was to have entered the conclave for the election of a new Pope.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 25 -- One of the bitterest local issues in Montclair's history will be decided by referendum at the Nov. 4 general election.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- The French Government is expected to stick to its refusal to engage in political negotiations with the Algerian rebels.

Prices of cocoa reversed their descent and began to advance in the middle of this month. Prices have been working lower since May, but dropped sharply in September. The price shift on the New York Cocoa Exchange has been accompanied by heavy trading.
NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Boston College stalled Miami's surprise "lonesome twosome" offense today and scored a 6-2 football upset in the mud.
MANY home owners burn up unnecessary fuel dollars every winter because their heating plants are not operating efficiently -- or because heat is being needlessly wasted through leakage to the outside.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- A Japanese Matsuri Festival for the benefit of the Japan International Christian University in Tokyo will be held Thursday from 1:30 to 5:30 P. M. in the education wing of the Reformed Church here.

The business of American-flag ship operators is suffering from compounded ills, the Merchant Marine Institute reported last week. Not only are the operators getting a smaller mare of United States foreign trade, but the trade has grown smaller, too.
The tides of economic nationalism are exerting renewed pressures on foreign oil companies operating in the Middle East, the world's largest known oil reservoir.
Frank S. Hogan yesterday endorsed a program of sweeping civil reform.

ROLAND, a tardy French school boy, is made to stand in the corner where he draws a long tiger. Then he says CRACK, and the tiger comes to life and s-t-r-e-t-c-h-e-s out of the classroom. Roland draws a zebra, a window breaks with s CRACK and the zebra jumps into the schoolyard and over the wall -- and Roland's story is well begun.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 -- Harvard's football team rallied in the second half today and toppled Dartmouth from the place it had shared atop the Ivy League. On a muddy field and in a gray setting before 22,500 fans, the Cantabs turned back the favored Hanoverians by 16 -- 8, scoring their points after the intermission.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- Army's undefeated football team bolted to a two-touchdown lead against once-beaten Pittsburgh in the second period today, but all that the cadets got from a bruising contest was a 14-14 tie.

Dr. Harold C. Urey, Nobel Prize-winning chemist, now at the University of California at La Jolla, presents in the Oct. 18 issue of Nature, British scientific weekly, a new hypothesis about the origin of tektites, glassy objects found in widely scattered groups around the world.
Automobile dealers across the country reportedly were fretting last week as they noted a brisk demand for 1959 models and a shortage of new cars to deliver to eager buyers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- More than ninety individuals donated $1,000 or more each to the Republican National Committee's campaign fund between Sept. 1 and Oct. 20.
GRANDIOSE, intimate; ritualistic, informal; austere, human. These paradoxical terms pass through the mind of the observer as he surveys the scene in the Supreme Court of the United States.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Joe Kapp engineered two touchdown drives and raced 92 yards for the third today as California beat favored Oregon, 23 -- 6, remaining unbeaten in Pacific Coast conference play.

The Ethel H., called the largest non-propelled barge ever constructed for the transportation of petroleum products, will be launched Wednesday at the Beaumont, Tex., yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Illinois turned a fumble and a pass interception into fourth-period touchdowns today and handed Michigan State its first shutout in forty games, 16 -- 0, before a homecoming crowd of 68,811.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Unbeaten Hamilton College won its fifth straight today, defeating Haverford, 20 -- 6, in a game featuring long touchdown runs despite a steady downpour. The loss was Haverford's third in four starts.

TWO young men who have never been on television, except inadvertently, are among the most agile members of Perry Como's TV crew. Each Saturday finds them dancing cheek - to - cheek with cameras in a choreography inspired by the placement of booms, production personnel and electric cables as they strive to keep large cue cards before the eyes of the performers.

SEVILLE, Spain, Oct. 16 -The gay pleasure-loving Andalusians here have just had a rude shock. After several years of warnings, which Seville has blithely ignored, the Spanish Government has just closed to wheeled traffic the ancient bridge of Queen Isabella II.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- State Department officials dismissed Peiping's every-other-day cease-fire proclamation today as "the same old cat-and- mouse game."
A contract bridge team captained by Robert Rothlein of Miami Beach led the Harry Fishbein team yesterday in the two-team contest for the 1958 United States team - of - four championship.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Even Stroke, owned by Mrs. George C. White of Hopkinsville, KY., led all the way and set a track record in winning the $11,775 Littletown Handicap before 16,049 at Sportsman's Park today.

THE avalanche of Christmas merchandise will soon engulf us. But it is safe to say that few items will be as uncommercial as the Christmas music included in the current Archive Production releases of the German Grammophon Gesellschaft distributed in this country by Decca.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- New unemployment insurance benefits go into effect Monday for veterans of peace-time military service.

The issue with the greatest emotional impact in the election campaign is the enactment of "right-to-work" laws. Voters in six states, including highly industrialized California and Ohio, will ballot Nov. 4 on proposals to outlaw labor - management agreements that require a worker to join a union as a condition of holding his job.

AQUARIUM plants require attention now just as surely as those on the house plant shelf. The chores may be minor, such as discarding stringy myriophyllum that the platys have picked at or snipping off untidy brown outer leaves. Or the indoor gardener may want to replant the entire tank in a fresh design.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. -- It has been six and a half years since Maryland smoothed the way for Florida-bound tourists on the East Coast by opening its great bridge over Chesapeake Bay. With this new facility, through traffic could speed down the Jersey Turnpike, through the relatively open country of Maryland's Eastern Shore, cross the bridge to Annapolis and then head directly south for Richmond, Va., thus avoiding the traffic snarls of Baltimore and Washington.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Cornell today ran up the biggest score it has ever made against Princeton in their forty-one football games dating from 1891. The stunning 34-8 victory over the favored Ivy champions gave Lefty James' Big Red team undisputed possession of first place in the league as Dartmouth, too, suffered its first Ivy setback in losing to Harvard.
Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald called yesterday for increased flexibility and decentralization in the city school system.
Two retired seamen, who after seventy-five years total service in the Navy shed their uniforms to start new careers, agreed at a reunion last week that a landlubber's life has its challenges.
TOKYO, Oct. 21 -- Abolition of Japan's ancient system of legalized prostitution last spring has produced mixed results, according to a recent survey by the police and welfare authorities.
Dr. Hwa Soo Chin is here to study plastic surgery for the victims of the Communist Chinese bombardment of Quemoy.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 25 -- Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, former dictator, was taken by force this noon to testify before a Senate subcommittee on charges that his regime had abused its powers.

STARTING in 1947, the Salzburg Festival began the policy of including a new contemporary opera in its annual series of summer events. Since then it has twice suspended the practice and in 1951 it let Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" stand as its contemporary contribution.
FALL gardens are bright with colorful chrysanthemums and roses reigning on the landscape. Visitors to the city's botanic gardens also will see scarlet and gold leaves on shrubs and trees.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 15 -- This landlocked, out-of-the-way nation is maintaining a precarious political and economic balance. Despite the abilities and the charm of its people and the fertility of its eastern provinces, it is the poorest and most backward of South American countries.
CAIRO, Oct. 25 -- An authoritative Egyptian source said today that the door still was open for Western governments to invest in the Aswan High Dam project on the Nile if they desired to do so.

Public Law 85-568 says: "A civilian agency [shall] control * * * aeronautical and space activities sponsored by the United States, except that activities peculiar to or primarily associated with the development of weapons systems * * * (including the research and development necessary * * *) shall be the responsibility of and shall be directed by the Department of Defense.

OTTAWA, Oct. 25 -- An explosion destroyed a section of this capital city's downtown business section this morning. The cause of the explosion has not been determined. Damage was estimated at more than $2,000,000. More than thirty persons were taken to hospitals but only one was critically injured.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Some thing of a revolution in facilities for sight-seeing in and around Rio has taken place of late with the adoption by local travel agencies of the package plan. Now Sugar Loaf and Copacabana Beach, the statue of Christ the Redeemer atop Corcovado, and the Botanical Gardens are destined to become as accessible to visitors in Rio as, say, Versailles is to the tourist in Paris.

JERICHO, L. I., Oct. 25 -- Old 16, a racing car that gained America's first victory in the Vanderbilt Cup races fifty years ago, led ninety-one vehicles of similar vintage along parts of the same route today.

WITCHES have come down in the world considerably since Cotton Mather's day (when they were blamed for everything from pinkeye to a sick cow), but for the young there is still a pleasantly shivery feeling in the shadow of a peaked hat or a broomstick -- especially at this time of year.
The world's steamship operators face at least a three-year wait for a return to prosperity, even if trade improves steadily, according to W. G. Weston, Ltd., London shipping analysts.
Refinements in X-ray technique to provide three-dimensional pictures of human blood circulation were described here yesterday.
THE would-be bridge player should start by learning the simple technique of the game, which is fundamental in the same sense that the ABC's and the multiplication tables are.

BONN, Oct. 25 -- Preparations for handling commercial jets at Rhine-Main Airport in Frankfurt, are nearly completed. Airport officials say that the main runway, now 3,000 meters (about 9,850 feet) long -- is the longest in Europe. Plans are to add 600 meters (about 2,000 feet) next year.
BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Australia's Davis Cup team members had little trouble today advancing to the quarter-finals of the Queensland lawn tennis championships.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 25 -- St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here will close the observance of its centennial with a solemn pontifical mass on Nov. 16.
The White Elephant Party, which annually aids the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association, will be held on Jan. 23 at the Astor.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- J. Wolcott Brown of Sea Girt, N. J., shot par golf today to defeat Jack Brittain Sr., 7 and 6, in the final of the seventh annual North and South senior golf tournament.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct 25 (AP) -- Independent oil operators will meet here for the next three days to discuss the industry's lagging economy and chart a Congressional program for 1959.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that the world had lost "an outstanding servant of God" and that he had lost a "warm personal friend" in the death of Cardinal Mooney.
KENT, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Fred R. Zeller, Republican candidate for Governor, campaigned today in rain, fog and drizzle through a large area of Litchfield County.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- An enlarged police force went on emergency duty here this week-end after one of the worst outbreaks of street muggings in the city's recent history.
HONG KONG, Oct. 22 -- The state purchasing and distribution of food crops are seriously behind schedule this year in Communist China.

The 100th anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt was marked yesterday at a ceremony in the American Museum of Natural History. The seventy-sixth President was born in New York City Oct. 27, 1858. He died at his home in Oyster Bay, L. I., Jan. 6, 1919.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -Heart specialists could not agree today how the go-getting, competitive American should cope with coronary artery disease.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Oklahoma struck a touchdown gusher in the third period today and collected bonuses on pass interception, fumbles and fabulous punt returns to defeat Kansas State, 40 -- 6. It was the Sooners' twenty-second consecutive triumph over the Wildcats.
Nelson A. Rockefeller campaigned in the rain yesterday in two suburban counties.
Injections of blood plasma from mentally ill humans hampered the climbing ability of trained rates, according to a report in the October issue of Archives of Neurology and Psychiatry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- When Robert Frost, the poet, now associated with the Library of Congress, expressed the wish last week for the loan of four American paintings, he did not know that one of them was on its way to Washington -- but not to him.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -North American companies and individuals had investments of about $787,000,000 in Mexico in 1957, according to William A. McDonnell, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
TORONTO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Hasty House Farms' Jack Ketch and Mahan ran one, two in the $60,500 Canadian championship at New Woodbine today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The first comprehensive study of the elementary school principal in ten years, issued today by the National Education Association, shows more men than women on this job.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The thirteenth clerk in the history of the United States Supreme Court, a gregarious Westerner, is settled comfortably in the formality established by his precedessors.

CAIRO, Oct. 25 -- One of Cairo's famous old hotels, the Heliopolis Palace, went out of circulation today. It was taken over by the United Arab Republic as a home for the newly appointed Central Government.

Statistics of the play in the international team chess tournament, just concluded at the Deutsche Museum in Munich reveal that the Soviet Union team finished first without the loss of a game in the final. The Russians won the Hamilto Russell Trophy.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 25 -- The withdrawal of British paratroops from Jordan is not expected to disturb the relative calm there in the immediate future, Israeli sources said today.
The Pennsylvania Railroad found the way to the hearts of a hundred passengers yesterday through their stomachs. All aboard the Broadway Limited were treated to a free meal.

IN his forthcoming movie, "The Horse's Mouth," Alec Guinness gives another of his strikingly individual character portraits -this time of a penniless, wild and irresponsible artist fighting the world by every means at his command to carry on with his particular vision of art.

One of the performances at the 1953 Prades Festival. A good, though not especially hi-fi, example of recorded sound; but it is faithful enough to record the awesome groans that Casals makes while playing.

LISBON -- This picturesque capital of Portugal astride seven hills, has many well-known tourist attractions. One of its less widely publicized institutions, however, deserves at least a half-day's visit by any tourist with a taste for fine wines.

Thieves, described as "obvious professionals," broke into a Brooklyn home early yesterday and removed a floor safe containing about $6,500 in cash and $138,775 worth of non-negotiable bonds. The bonds were later recovered.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The prospective retirement of James T. Nicholson, executive vice president of the American National Red Cross, is bringing from around the world expressions of the esteem in which he is held.

GAZA, Oct. 25 -- An Indian colonel told contingents of fighting men of his own and seven other countries this morning that they were here on alien soil not to make war but to make peace and that they were faithfully fulfilling their mission.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Overseas shipments of Canadian wheat totaled 5,000,000 bushels in the week ended Oct. 15. This was almost four times as much as in the corresponding week a year ago.

THE American Automobile Association's first Managers Tour of Europe has been completed. The purpose of the group's thirty-day trip to cities in England, Belgium, Holland, West Germany, Switzerland, Italy, France and Ireland was "to discover how well prepared Europe will be for the jet travel era."

There will be a gala dinner in the Paris manner at Princess Artchil Gourielli's Park Avenue home on Friday. The occasion will mark the opening of a series of ten gourmet dinners to benefit the Florence Crittenton League.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- A spokesman for twenty two rail unions accused the railroads today of negligence in the upkeep of trackage and equipment.

THE Yeats-family-Robinson is no more. The death of Lennox Robinson marks the end of an era in the Irish theatre. Tribute is due Mr. Robinson as a writer of rewarding comedies. He was a competent producer.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Two Russian race horses left Moscow today for the United States. They are believed to be the first Russian thoroughbred racing entries in the West since the days of the Czars.

VOTERS throughout the country during the past few weeks of political tub-thumping have been straining for a view of what has been widely advertised as "the new Nixon." ARTISTS from twenty-two nations were represented in the 1958 Guggenheim International Award, announced a few days ago. In addition to the prize-winning picture in each national section the national jury added four pictures by different artists to be passed on by the international jury for the top award.

ONE of the refreshing and extraordinary aspects of the gubernatorial campaign in New York State is that, uniquely, both candidates have a love for art and a sense of cultural responsibility. They both own art, not as millionaires' fashionable accoutrements, but as something with which they are deeply involved.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 22 -- Official and business leaders give varying estimates of the extent to which the desegregation controversy has damaged this area's industrial economy.
BEETHOVEN: Symphony No. 5; Ernest Ansermet and L'Orchestre de la Suisse Romande (London). A vigorous and exciting Fifth, crisply and even a bit theatrically played.

" PART of the job of every writer of the mystery novel," Hugh Pentecost once wrote, "is the need to find new and fresh backgrounds for his stories." I could wish that more writers followed Mr. Pentecost's precept; fresh backgrounds -- geographical, professional, historical or social -- are uncommon enough that a reviewer's heart leaps up when he beholds a completely unhackneyed one, as in Mollie Hamilton's LATER THAN YOU THINK (Coward - McCann, $3.50).
The continuing high school shutdowns in Arkansas and Virginia as a result of the segregation controversy are raising questions of deep concern about college preparation for their students.

HOW a United States postage stamp, once it has been proposed, is carried through successive stages until the finished product is released to the public will be graphically told by the Post Office Department at the tenth annual National Postage Stamp Show here on Nov. 21, 22 and 23.
The Real Estate Board of New York recommended yesterday a general increase in commission rates charged by realty brokers for arranging leases and sales of property in Manhattan.

FIVE of the thirteen productions the San Francisco Opera Company offered during the course of its thirty-sixth season were new. This is the largest number of new productions in the company's history, and any report on the season as a whole must dwell on them.

One of Orient Steam Navigation Company's ship captains will have an unusual problem in his hands in 1960: What crisp order does a master give to get his vessel moving like a crab?

WHILE "House Happy" can hardly be described as a flawlessly constructed novel, it is doubtful if the author ever intended it to be. Muriel Resnick just seems prepared, in an amiable, rambling way, to give the reader a good time. Judged by this modest ambition, it can be said that her novel succeeds admirably.
New evidence that viruses may cause human cancer was presented last week at the annual meeting of the American Cancer Society in New York City.

Following the Moiseyev Ballet, another dance troupe from the Soviet Union, the Beryozka Ballet, is to tour America. Its ensemble, except for a few male musicians, consists entirely of women.

In appointing a committee to study the feasibility of legal off-track betting on horse races to supplement the city's tax revenues, Mayor Wagner last week specified that any plan it might suggest should be government-operated and should preclude the licensing or legalization of bookmakers to take bets.

Department store sales in the Philadelphia area were 16 per cent higher during the week ended Oct. 18 than in the week of last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank. The sharp increase was a result of good weather and bargain sales, the bank said.

The Security Bureau, Inc., scored an important victory last week in its campaign to prevent port passengers from being "steered" to expressmen who charge extravagant fees for the handling of baggage.
Daily jet airliner service across the Atlantic begins tonight.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. William F. Knowland said today that she had sent to 200 California leaders a letter declaring that Gov. Goodwin J. Knight had avoided a June primary race with her husband because of a "macaroni spine."

AS everybody knows, Jack Webb, the star of the TV program called "Dragnet," is president of the mythical Los Angeles Police Department Fan Club. Naturally. The department's drama, in combination with his own talents, has earned him millions.

FOR more than a hundred and fifty years an imposing Georgian mansion, backed by a double row of smaller houses set around a trim arcade, has stood on the north side of Piccadilly, in London's West End. Known to mailmen as Albany but generally called the Albany, it has sheltered an enduringly English Community, unlike any other in the world.
Retail executives in the New York area estimated Friday that sales for the week would rise 4 to 8 per cent above those of the week last year.

Fiber Industries, Inc., has selected a 215-acre tract near Shelby, N. C., as a site for its new teron polyester fiber plant. Estimates of plant cost range to approximately $50,000,000. When the plant reaches eventual production capacity of 40,000,000 pounds a year it will employ 1,500 persons.

CONSIDERING the incredible number of persons who play contract bridge -- more than fifty million throughout the world, some thirty million of them in the United States -- and the gravity with which so many of them play, the game has been remarkably free of cheating scandals.

CHOUCHOU was a little French donkey, all gray, except for a white muzzle as soft as velvet. Each day he went up the mountain carrying milk, then down. Up and down, every day -- a hard and monotonous job.

RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Patrice M. Jacobs' Basil Bee scored his fifth consecutive victory today by winning the fourteenth running of the Monmouth County Gold Cup at the Monmouth County Hunts meeting.

WARSAW, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- The present system of compulsory deliveries produce to the state will be replaced by a system of taxation under a revision of agricultural policy announced today by the Polish Communist party.

A POLITICIAN'S first job is to get elected, and the first step toward getting elected is getting known. Today, as the race to Nov. 4 goes into its final stretch, candidates for seats in the Senate (thirty-three), the House (432) and Governors' mansions (thirty-three) are trying hard to do just that, as are the tens of thousands of others seeking office in village or town.

HUME CRONYN from London, Ont., and Jessica Tandy from London, England, have become the American theatre's best known husband and wife acting team -- save for one. To this one they do not mind in the least appearing in the position of runner-up.

FOR THIS WEEK: Finish major bulb planting. Almost all hardy bulbs should be in the ground by the end of the month. Tulips and lilies are planted through mid-November. . . . TUCSON, Ariz. -- A three-acre, outdoor, quarter of a million dollar Watershed Exposition -- the first of its kind in the country -- will be opened to the public today as part of the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum's continuing plan to familiarize people with all aspects of life in the desert area of the Southwest.

THIS novel uses as its framework the defeat of the Matabele-Zulu warriors, at the century's turn, by a handful of brave and determined Englishmen, Boers and Australians. The following are excerpts from the novel "Doctor Zhivago," by Boris Pasternak, Soviet writer who last week won the Nobel Prize for Literature. Jensen, who served as art editor for the numerous pictures.

The first volume of Diana Cooper's reminiscences is such a book.

Fresh figs are one of the less common fruits now to be found in markets here. Unlike dried figs, which are available all year, the fresh variety are in the stores only for a few months. Right now, it is the green-skinned figs that are being offered in stores, including fruit stalls on Ninth Avenue below Forty-second Street.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 27 -- The Zionist Organization of America formulated here today plans for strengthening the Zionist movement in this country under a program of "greater Zionism."

The Rev. Dr. Dan M. Potter, director of the Protestant Council of the City of New York, urged yesterday that a public hearing be held "as soon as possible" on Mayor Wagner's proposal to legalize off-track betting.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 26 -- The Soviet Union appears to be brewing new trouble in the Middle East by stirring up the Kurdish nationalist movement.

The program presented by the Singing Boys of Mexico in Carnegie Hall last night was divided into three parts. In each the youngsters performed with remarkable technical control, but only in the middle part devoted to contemporary music was the musicianship on the level that prevailed through most of the concert given here by a similar group four years ago.

Senator Wayne Morse urged last night that the United States take the lead in trying to get the General Assembly of the United Nations to submit the question of Taiwan to the International Court of Justice for an advisory opinion.
WADING RIVER, L. I., Oct. 26 -- A survival experiment that would have tested the mettle of many men was completed here today by thirty teen-aged Explorer Scouts.
Diversified common stock funds are the workhorses of the mutual funds industry.
Four new films will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
A Pan American World Airways clipper named America swooshed off from New York last night to start the first daily jet airliner service across the Atlantic.

The Midland-Ross Corporation plans to acquire for more than $600,000 cash the Transportation Equipment division of the Consolidated Metal Products Corporation, Albany, N. Y. The acquisition is subject to the approval of Consolidated stockholders, who will vote at a special meeting on Thursday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 26 -- Military and political leaders here were somewhat bewildered today by the Chinese Communists' announcement that they would fire at strategic targets on Quemoy only on odd-numbered days of the month.

The Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases has adopted a team approach to top executive responsibility. The institution announced yesterday that a change in its by-laws provided that either its president, its chairman of the board or the chairman of the executive committee might act as chief executive as circumstances require.

THE revamped furniture showrooms of Kagan-Dreyfuss, 125 East Fifty-seventh Street, are all aglitter with aluminum. The metal, with its silvery matte finish, is certainly having a boom year with designers.

The annual card party of the New York Society of Kentucky Women will be held in the ballroom of the Pierre on Thursday. Proceeds will go toward the maintenance of scholarships in the Kentucky mountain schools at Caney Creek and Lotts Creek and of the Hindman Settlment School.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia urged eloquently today that a failure be called a failure from now on -- win sports, that is.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that his Administration would make every effort to provide pay rises for policemen and firemen in the city's expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, 1959.
BY vocation Mrs. June Platt is a designer of wallpaper, rugs and other home decorations. But it is her sparetime occupation, creating incomparable recipes, that endears her to those who like to cook.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 25 -- Long staple cotton from the Nile, the same crop that Egypt had sales problems with before 1955 when the Soviet bloc took it in return for arms and development loans, is being offered around Europe by the Sudan.
The men and ships of the Military Sea Transportation Service have won another battle against weather and ice.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- Willie Galimore sprinted to a pair of touchdowns today as the Chicago Bears defeated the San Francisco Forty-niners, 27 -- 14, in a football contest that saw Coach George Halas of the winners assaulted by a spectator at half-time.
Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland depicted here last night a rising failure to obey law and to support "ideal justice.'' He contended that this could halt all progress."

SYRACUSE, Oct. 26 -- The New York State School Boards Association will poll its members here tomorrow on some of the chief education problems in the state. The association's thirty-ninth annual convention opened today.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 26 (UPI) -- More than 60,000 persons turned out today to hear the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham, Evangelist, at a rally that was transferred from the Capitol's steps because Gov. George Bell Timmerman Jr., had branded Dr. Graham a racial integrationist. The rally was held at near-by Fort Jackson, an infantry center.

James Laver, the English writer, will have a companion volume to his "Victorian Vista" published Nov. 14 by Houghton Mifflin. Called "Edwardian Promenade," the book combines reminiscences, contemporary magazine extracts and verses from popular songs to present the "age of extravagance," the age of Edward the Peacemaker, the Gaiety Girl, the Suffragette, the wasp waist and the flared skirt.

HAVANA, Oct. 26 -- Fidel Castro, leader of the Cuban rebels, warned the United States today to stay out of the rebellion. He issued the warning in a personal broadcast from his hide-out in the Sierra Maestra.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Atomic Energy Commission, racing against a proposed Oct. 31 nuclear test ban, detonated two shots today less than six hours apart -- one by moonlight and the other later this morning.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Seven surprised policemen were needed this afternoon to handle 1,800 teen-agers who showed up to hear a classical pianist play Schumann.
The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street opened the celebration of its 150th anniversary yesterday.
THE image of daring youth that the name jet pilot often conveys is one that airline pilots like Samuel Hudson Miller will almost surely help to change.
ZURICH, Oct. 26 -- "A week of consolidation" was the way most dealers, not quite accurately, described business on the stock exchange last week.
MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Pravda heaped abuse on Boris Pasternak today and said the Russian writer would reject the Nobel Prize awarded him if there were "a spark of Soviet dignity left in him."

Your report on Dr. Robert J. McCracken's Sunday sermon, which appeared on page 60 of your Oct. 20 edition, inspired this letter. Dr. McCracken makes a noteworthy point when he cites the apathy of the people to the disclosure of the deplorable conditions in the Women

The selection of members of Congress is one of the heaviest responsibilities facing the American voter. Considering the power of Congress, and how it affects the life of every inhabitant of this land as well as many millions beyond our borders, it is astonishing how lightly this responsibility is sometimes taken by both the voter and the political party that makes the original selection of candidates.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,531,741,359. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
Thirteen young girl dancers in homemade costumes yesterday entertained fifty-eight residents of the New York Nursing Home, 28 West Seventy-fourth Street.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said last night she was undecided whether she would vote for District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, the Democratic candidate for Senator.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26 -- Seventeen works of art, one-third of the collection of the late Philip L. Goodwin, New York architect, have been given to the Yale University Art Gallery.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The American Jewish Committee charged today that the Soviet Union practiced a "deliberate policy of cruel suppression" of all minority groups in its control.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- National income hit a record rate of nearly $369,000,000,000 in the summer of 1957. It dropped to a low of $350,600,000,000 early this year.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad managed last month, with the help of a subsidy from Massachusetts and increased income from its non railroad investments, to report a profit -- $110,436.

FASHION accessories should be considered an important investment. This is the opinion of Mme. Monique de Nervo, a fashion consultant who is now in the United States as a representative of the leather glove trade of France.
A 2 1/2-year-old pug, Ch. Star Jade of North Boro, captured the best-in-show award yesterday at the twenty-sixth annual toy breeds event of the Progressive Dog Club at The Livingston in Brooklyn.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Guy Mollet, Minister of State and Socialist leader, declared today that the Algerian rebels had made a "crazy" tactical mistake in rejecting Premier de Gaulle's invitation to discuss a cease-fire.

A new Presidential term begins in Chile today in an atmosphere of hope and relative optimism. Chileans, who are among the most democratic and politically mature people in the Western Hemisphere, gave a plurality of their votes to one of their most distinguished citizens, Jorge Alessandri. He takes office at a moment of acute economic difficulties, while long accumulating pressures are reaching an insistency that must be faced.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Two young girls gained notable triumphs today in the annual Harrison Junior Horse Show, staged in rain and mud at the Kentucky Riding Stable. They thus qualified on their last chance for the national equitation finals in the coming National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.
A California airline pilot stepped wearily from his single-engined light plane here yesterday to complete a fifty-day flight around the world.
SEATTLE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A sharp cut in the Philippine five-year development program to save dollar reserves has been reported by a Philippine Central Bank expert.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Jimmy Brown scored four touchdowns today in leading the Cleveland Browns to a 38 -- 24 National Football League victory over the Chicago Cardinals.
Some of the nation's leading educators warned yesterday that graduate schools that have been the principal source of high-caliber college teachers, will no longer be able to meet the demand.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles has returned from the Western Pacific believing that there is greater unity and strength among the anti-Communist countries there than at any time in the last two years.
PARIS, Oct. 26 -- Sekou Toure, Chief of Government of Guinea, which has just won her independence from France, complained today of French delay in recognizing his Government.
SEATTLE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A sharp cut in the Philippine five-year development program to save dollar reserves has been reported by a Philippine Central Bank expert.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 26 -- Complaints by teen-agers that there is "nothing to do on Friday nights" were countered here last week by a "teen-age canteen" in Norwalk High School. More than 500 teen-agers showed up.

IN the summer of 1924 old Myles Rankin was dying. He didn't mind much, being sensible and realistic as well as partially paralyzed. How much his daughters minded was hard to tell. The long death watch in the big house on President Street in New Linden, Ill., brought them together again, anyway. And that was something. Clara
"Madison Avenue is trying to sell us candidates the same way it sells soap and beer."

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Frank S. Hogan, Democratic candidate for the Senate, said tonight that the Congregational experience of his Republican rival, Representative Kenneth B. Keating, was useful for only one purpose.
Puerto Ricans are making significant employment gains in industry here, according to two reports released yesterday. A third report indicated that discrimination against them persisted.
"Neither science, nor technology nor determinism derived from it can function without the individual who has reason, courage and conviction," Dr. John Allen Krout said in a sermon yesterday.
The International Transport Workers Federation will attempt next month to immobilize 1,000 ships in ports over the world in a move to unionize 75,000 seamen.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- The four companies carved out of the old I. G. Farben chemical empire have completed their first joint financing venture -- the construction of an almost fully automatic synthetic rubber plant in the Ruhr.

BEVANS, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Val's Tyson, a 5-year-old White and liver pointer owned and handled by Val Brown of Rahway, N. J., sloshed through rain, sleet and snow today at the Flatbrook Shooting Grounds. He took first honors in the shooting dog stake that completed the annual fall program of the Sussex County Field Trial Club.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Hedge selling and liquidation coupled with slow export demand combined to depress grain futures prices on the Board of Trade last week.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Oct. 26 -- This farm state's "right-to-work" law has suddenly become a major issue in campaigning for the Governorship and the House of Representatives. Both parties agree that if anyone benefits the Republicans will.
OTTAWA, Oct. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Commodity exports in September fell 6.2 per cent below the 1957 level. It was the third straight month that shipments had lagged behind 1957 figures.
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Oct. 26 -- The Soviet Union's chief scientist in the Antarctic urged yesterday that all nations conducting research there pool the results of their efforts.

Witness this past week-end's Soviet press torrent of abuse and vilification directed at him. "Traitor" and "Judas" are only two of the terms from the gutter vocabulary of Stalinism which have been applied to him. Pravda has gone
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- An Army study has concluded that nuclear weapons require more, and not less, manpower.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- The 1958 America-Israel Friendship Award of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America was presented here tonight to The New York Times.
Producers of films for television are casting a hopeful eye at residuals.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens rallied from a 3-1 deficit tonight to gain a 5-3 hockey victory over the Detroit Red Wings. Third-period goals by Claude Provost and Jean Beliveau decided the game.
With reference to the recent drive for greater pedestrian safety, ma I call attention to the dangerous situation existing at the intersection of Vanderbilt Avenue and East Forty-fifth Street ?
Democratic candidates were reported leading yesterday in twenty of the nation's thirty-two gubernatorial elections to be decided Nov. 4.

The question of whether passengers on jet planes should pay more than the regular airline fares is likely to be the prime subject at the annual general meeting of the International Air Transport Association. The meeting opens today in New Delhi, India.

A store-front office in an old building at 938 Simpson Street in the southeast Bronx is a key to understanding the race for Congress in the Twenty-third Congressional District.
A proposal to build an open-deck parking garage behind Queens Borough Hall in Kew Gardens was made public yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

HALLOWEEN is in the air. The skies soon will be streaked with airborne witches, practitioners of one of the more ancient methods of space travel. Here on earth, the holiday belongs to children, including many pre-schoolers who will "trick or treat" in the company of their parents.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 -- The New York Knickerbockers did something tonight they had not accomplished in almost two National Basketball Association campaigns. They beat the Philadelphia Warriors in the Quaker City.
"OMNIBUS," returning for its seventh season on the air yesterday afternoon, scored a blow for the abolition of capital punishment that long will stand as one of television's remarkable programs.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The stock markets opened last week with a good deal of confidence but showed some uncertainty thereafter.

Joseph B. Rosenblatt and Rennold Wacht, realty investors, have acquired a long-term net lease on the seven-story building containing offices and a night club at 151-53 East Fiftieth Street, near Third Avenue. The structure is on a plot 53 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -The State Department denied today charges by Fidel Castro, Cuban rebel leader, that the United States was intervening in the Cuban civil war.
PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Governor Harriman sought today to link his opponent, Nelson A. Rockefeller, with the Eisenhower Administration's "changed" neutrality policy in Israeli-Arab affairs.
David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, "accepted" yesterday the resignation of two local officials who had been convicted of extortion.
Stocks declined for the sixth day yesterday. This trimmed another $1,900,000,000 from the aggregate value of New York Stock Exchange portfolios.
Cotton futures advanced steady 1 to 5 points yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

SEATTLE, Oct. 27 (AP) -Gov. Albert D. Rosellini told Colombo Plan delegates today their work here toward the economic advancement of South and Southeast Asia was contributing to world-wide peace and stability.

Twenty-one officials from eighteen underdeveloped nations in four continents will take part in a six-month course on economic development. The course starts today in Washington under the direction of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Net income of the Armco Steel Corporation in the three months ended Sept. 30 declined to $12,876,598, from $17,600,617 in the corresponding period last year, the company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The State Department pledged today that the views of all Atlantic pact nations would be considered fully before any decision was made on a reported French plan to revise NATO's command operations.

The New York Giants got past the Pittsburgh Steelers without Frank Gifford, their best halfback, but whether they will be able to do the same against their next opponent is debatable. For next on the Giants' National Football League schedule is a meeting at Cleveland with the unbeaten Browns.
Nelson A. Rockefeller said last night that the chief contribution of the Harriman Administration had been "to give new and disturbing meanings to 'do nothing' and 'drift.'"
A masterly young pianist made his New York debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

An over-emphasis on personal ambition is the real enemy of those who would make the country's educational system a scapegoat for technological and other reverses, Dr. Carroll V. Newsom, the president of New York University, charged last night.

Fidel Castro, the rebel leader who has been operating for nearly two years in eastern Cuba, has been tolerantly regarded in this country because most of us did not care for President Batista. Batista's arrogance as well as his fear have grown with time, and both have expressed themselves in illegal arrests, abuse of prisoners and a good deal of wanton shooting.

An exceptionally large number of close legislative races appeared yesterday to be in store for New York this year. In many instances the outcomes seem to depend on the result of the contest for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, New Jersey Republican, accused Senator Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island Democratic chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, of an irresponsible attack on Administration foreign policy today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -The Supreme Court granted a hearing today to a chemical engineer who wants to stop the Atomic Energy Commission from publishing his assertedly improved process for making heavy water.

September was the ninth consecutive month in which the value of building permits exceeded that of the corresponding month of 1957. According to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., however, the September on record. It rep-moderate decline from the preceding month.
WARSAW, Oct. 27 -- The Polish Association of Writers is the only writer's organization behind the Iron Curtain to send a telegram of congratulations to Mr. Pasternak, it was learned here tonight.

Paul W. Williams, former United States Attorney, was sworn in yesterday as a special assistant to the Attorney General to coordinate the activities of the state's Election Frauds Bureau. Mr. Williams was sworn by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, in his office at 80 Centre Street.

In a letter which you printed on Oct. 21, "Chiang Group Deemed Aggressive," a distinguished former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce contends that, in China, as between the Communists and the Nationalists -- the former of whose forces are today shelling Quemoy and the latter of whose forces are taking the shelling -- the latter "group," Chiang Kaishek's Nationalists, are the "true aggressor."

Articles suitable as Christmas gifts will be on sale at the seventh annual bazaar of the Women's Guild of the Central Presbyterian Church. The event will take place in the parish house of the church at Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, on Nov. 12 and 13.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A House Agriculture subcommittee today ordered a staff investigation to determine if a recent increase in the price of bread in New York City was justified.

In his first bout since he retired nearly three years ago, Paddy Young, a 30-year-old Greenwich Village middleweight, was held to a draw by Otis Woodard of Harlem last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.
The Government is still seeking a buyer for the only roll-on, roll-off vessel available to American -flag shipping.

New York City checking account turnover decreased 10 per cent below the previous month in September, but increased 1 1/2 per cent in the rest of the country, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Pan American World Airways tied the knot in its New York-Paris, Paris-New York jet loop today. The Boeing 707, a four-jet clipper named the America, ended its return trip today at International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 12:05 A. M.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday against "fellows with criminal records down in Wall Street."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that Ezra Taft Benson, Agriculture Secretary, "has done little" to put to use an expanded farm surplus export program voted by the last Congress.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- Two black smoke signals rising above the Sistine Chapel announced to crowds of waiting Romans and to the world today that a new Pope had not been elected in the second day's balloting.

Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt, chairman of the benefit committee, has announced that orchestra seats are still available for the Nov. 6 performance of "The Marriage-Go-Round." The new comedy starring Claudette Colbert and Charles Boyer is scheduled to open at the Plymouth Theatre tomorrow.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- A Negro integration leader and his assistant were sentenced to jail and fined tonight on misdemeanor charges. The charges grew out of an attempt to break down racial barriers on city buses. Twelve other Negroes received suspended sentences.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia has applied for "associate membership" in the General Agreement for Tariffs and Trade (GATT), it was learned here today.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -France won West German support today for reorganizing the North Atlantic alliance, but not in the way proposed by Premier Charles de Gaulle.

The Twenty-fifth Congressional District in the Bronx can be a difficult place for a Republican seeking public office. But Representative Paul A. Fino, who is fighting to hold his seat, is undaunted by the Democrats that surround him.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 27 -Twenty-six white Norfolk parents and school children went into Federal court today to challenge Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. and the state's "massive resistance" laws.
Television will offer a new daytime chit-chat team next week -- Jackie Gleason and Arthur Godfrey.
Directors of the George A. Fuller Company, general con[tracting and construction concern, declared an extra dividend of 30 cents a share on the common stock yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Arvida Corporation of Miami today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering its proposed issuance of 2,500,000 shares of $1 par value Class A common stock to finance a Florida real estate development.
DALLAS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America said today he was confident that Federal officials would act to curtail petroleum products imports.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its seventy-fourth season last night with a combination of sure-fire elements: Puccini's "Tosca," led by Dimitri Mitropoulos, and with Renata Tebaldi, Mario Del Monaco and George London in the leading roles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Teamsters Union today scheduled a special convention for March 16-18 in Chicago in the face of efforts by the union's monitors to block such a session.

Net revenues of the New York Stock Exchange for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1958, were $361,026, compared with $250,945 for the same 1957 period. Gross revenue was $11,843,307, compared with $11,453,352.

Directors of U. S. Vitamin Corporation yesterday recommended a stock split an increase in the number of authorized shares. The board also voted to change the name of the company to U. S. Vitamin and Pharmaceutical Corporation.

Malcolm Wilson, Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, who has been pictured by Governor Harriman and other Democrats as an ultra-conservative, called a news conference yesterday to reshape the Malcolm Wilson image.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- William S. Miller's Better Bee won by three lengths in today's Asbury Park Purse at Garden State Park and qualified for the $75,000 added Trenton Handicap on closing day, Nov. 5.
George A. Canary resigned yesterday from his $15,000-a-year post as president of the Amalgamated Lithographers of America.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Donnie Fleeman, the Texas light heavyweight champion, tonight knocked out the former heavyweight champion, Ezzard Charles, in the sixth round.
MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 27 -Thomas J. Dodd, Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, visited stores and factories here today.
Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday that "plenty" of neighborhood rehabilitation in other parts of the city would follow the successful renewal of a twenty-block West Side area now in planning.

POMFRET, Conn., Oct. 27--Pomfret School has become the possessor of a new science building, a sumptuous all-brick structure that was dedicated last Saturday just before the Red and Black's football team defeated Gunnery, 30-6.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Prof. Frederick Sanger of Cambridge University, British pioneer in protein research, was reported today to be the leading candidate for this year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry.
