A British electrical engineer whose luck ran out was ordered excluded and deported from the United States yesterday.
SCANDINAVIAN furniture designers are plagued by the same problem as their colleagues here: Fashions must change.
DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- Most auto makers are back in production and assembly volume is climbing. Last week the industry built 69,049 cars against 45,245 the preceding week and 105,103 in the 1957 week.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Stan Shaughnessy, a reserve Princeton center, has been shifted to second-string guard in place of Gary Loftus, who is sidelined with a sprained ankle.
Richard Hicks Jr., sought in the slaying of his father, was arrested yesterday in Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. He admitted the killing, the police said.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Striking mechanics of Capital Airlines sought today to renew negotiations toward settlement of their walkout. Their union said a new package offer had been prepared.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 27 -- Will the introduction of jet airliners make air travel cheaper or more expensive ? That was the dominant question at the opening of the fourteenth annual general meeting of the International Air Transport Association here today.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 27 -- A protest movement by Negro women against the carrying of identity documents has developed into a large-scale defiance campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The use of great caution in administering tranquilizers to children was urged today by speakers in a symposium sponsored by the National Institute of Mental Health. They stressed that more research was needed.
Frank S. Hogan accused the Republicans last night of embracing "Nixon party policy" in an attempt to win the New York election.
ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- An increase in state spending for mental hygiene research and aid to local psychiatric services was proposed today by a citizen's committee.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Premier de Gaulle was reported today to be angered and disappointed by the Algerian rebels' rejection of his offer to talk peace.

In the last of this series of editorials on the Congressional campaigns in New York City and the metropolitan area, we take a look at the more interesting contests in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today that Rear Admiral David M. Tyree would replace Rear Admiral George J. Dufek as commander of United States forces in the Antarctic next spring.
A SPECTACULAR array of jewelry that looks as if it belonged in the Tower of London is actually as near at hand as Elizabeth Arden's establishment, 691 Fifth Avenue.

Three research chemists responsible for doubling the amount of gasoline available from crude oil were honored yesterday in Whiting, Ind. The occasion was the presentation by Standard Oil Company (Indiana) of their original experimental cracking still to the Smithsonian Institution.

" From the Terrace," John O'Hara's new novel, will be published Nov. 27 by Random House. It is the story of a successful man in the first half of the Twentieth Century and traces his life from boyhood through his career in Wall Street to his years as a high government official.

The Proctor Gamble Company reported yesterday that earnings in the three months ended Sept. 30, the first quarter of its fiscal year, were 16 per cent higher than those for the corresponding period last year.
AGNES MOOREHEAD was a prodigious witch last night in a captivating television production of the fairy tale "Rapunzel."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Defense Department's space agency initiated today a major research program aimed at developing high - powered solid fuels for military and space rockets.
PARIS, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- The French Government is expected to approve a law within the next two weeks that will open the Sahara to foreign oil companies, industry sources said here today.

Cocoa futures opened lower yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, but recovered before the close of trading. Weekly purchases of cocoa beans from farmers by the Ghana Marketing Board were larger than generally expected, inducing liquidation, hedging and profit taking.

Although Robert Whitehead allowed his option to lapse on Arthur Kober's new play, "Now It Is Summer," the incident has not been permitted to mar their friendship. John Foster Furcolo of Massachusetts is the author of the well received political novel, satirical in content.

Fidelity Fund, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $319,471,577, equal to $14.70 a share on 21,738,229 shares outstanding as of Sept. 30. This compared with $247,324,485, or $12.85 a share on 19,242,479 shares, a year earlier.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The marriage of television and politics has caused an unusual political situation in Britain.

Harry Fishbein of New York and his team-mates won the 1958 contract bridge team championship early yesterday morning and nomination as the official squad to represent the United States in next year's world championship tourney.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 -President Eisenhower carried his fight for the election of a Republican Congress today into two states where public polls have indicated Democratic sweeps.
The increasing volume of low-price stocks being traded on the New York Stock Exchange is worrying a good many Wall Street observers.

Voters in the Twenty-fourth Congressional District in the Bronx have a choice of three candidates for their Representative. Two of them, however, readily concede the victory to the third, the Democratic incumbent, Charles A. Buckley.

LONDON, Oct. 27 (Reuters) -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Polish Communist party leader, charged today that the West had realized it could not compete with communism in peaceful ways "and therefore pins all its hopes on armaments and preparations for a new war."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 28 -The Israeli army tonight honored Zino Francescatti, the violinist, in appreciation for his having remained in Israel during the fighting with Egypt in 1956 to complete his concert schedule.

The story about the proposal by the New York Central that the city take over its taxed Park Avenue trackage, lease it back to the two railroads and work out a connection with the East Side subway line to take commuters directly downtown without changing at Grand Central is provocative and promising.
Mergers and acquisitions are accelerating among commercial finance companies, the industry was told yesterday.

James K. Hall Jr., M. D., of Richmond, Va., argues in your Oct. 23 issue that the Northern attitude toward Southern school segregation was "rank hypocrisy" because Northern states haven't the heavy concentration of Negroes that the Southern states have.

Today's new film is "Party Girl," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in color, starring Robert Taylor, Cyd Charisse and Lee J. Cobb, at Loew's State, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street. Nicholas Ray directed the Joe Pasternak production, from a screen play by George Wells.
Goldman, Sachs Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., and associates are offering today 200,000 shares of Central Soya Company, Inc., common stock at $49 a share.
Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday the awarding of two $750 scholarships.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- California led the states in population growth since the 1950 census, the Government reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Supreme Court accepted for review today a broad challenge to the Government's security program for defense plant workers.

While many of the big Eastern railroads even with the help of multimillion-dollar retroactive mail payments, reported record "red-ink" operations for the first nine months this year, the Southern Pacific Company has had better profits this year than in 1957.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Oct. 27 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion banned fund-raising activities by Government officials today, except in aid of the state treasury.

The placing of the city's Bureau of Real Estate in the hands of professional real estate men was probably the most important step in the agency's reorganization, according to the man who headed it during the process.
The kick for the extra point appears to be the popular choice in college football this season, despite the new 2-point conversion rule.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- A widespread study of the problems of birth abnormalities was announced here today at the American Public Health Association's eighty-sixth annual meeting.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 27 -- Field Marshal Sarit Thanarat, whose word is virtually law in Thailand; appears to have embarked on a move to convince the Thai's that revolutions do pay.
The Ford Motor Company received a gold award last night for the best annual report for the year 1957.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The Provisional Algerian Government announced here today that it remained ready to negotiate with France at any time.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 27 -- James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, urged New York State school systems today to fix minimum requirements of competence in the three R's and in civics for the high school diploma.

One of the gentle indoor sports available to the leisured is to stand in the vicinity of the Inquiry Desk in the Fifth Avenue lobby of the New York Public Library. One can pause on the outer edge of the semicircle of activity at a distance which is polite, but still within hearing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The financial reports filed by the national committees today for the period Sept. 1 to Oct. 24 also carry some figures on contributions to Congressional campaigns in New York and New Jersey.
The Ford Motor Company's Thunderbird for 1959 went on display yesterday in dealers' showrooms.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Sylvester (Syl) Veitch, the trainer, has ended his long affiliation with the racing stable of C. V. Whitney.

SENDAI, Japan, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Sam (Toothpick) Jones, the major leagues' strikeout king, lost his control during a four-run seventh-inning rally by the Japanese All-Stars today and the St. Louis Cards lost, 6 -- 3, for their first setback in Japan.

SIGNORA Fedora del Monaco is an imaginative cook whose New York hotel kitchen is not much bigger than a hemidemisemiquaver. Her cooking utensils consist of little more than a skillet, two kettles and a saucepan. Her source of heat is a pair of electric burners.

RUDOLF BING, who last night began his ninth season as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is, like his predecessor, Edward Johnson, a tenor. Resemblance between the two ends there. An incident of Mr. Johnson's regime illustrates his easygoing way of handling talent.

BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 27 (UPI) -- Ashley Cooper and Neale Fraser, a potential doubles team for Australia in December's Davis Cup challenge round, reached the semi-finals today in the Queensland tennis championships.
Widespread informal public approval of Mayor Wagner's proposal to legalize and tax off-track betting on horse races was reported yesterday by Robert W. Dowling.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today rescheduled for filming next year a musical production of Mark Twain's "Huckleberry Finn."
A low requiem mass for Edward Cardinal Mooney, Archbishop of Detroit, was offered yesterday at the Chapel of Our Lady of the Skies at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.
" LISTEN TO THE QUIET," a first playwriting effort by Fred J. Scollay, is a drama about the heroic resistance by a group of people against the tyranny of a totalitarian system.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 27 -West European Neutralists agreed at a week-end Congress in Heidelberg to coordinate their agitation for an "independent European community independent of the two great power blocs."
Six Midwestern barge lines protested in Washington yesterday a selective rate cut by competing railroads under provisions of the Transportation Act of 1958.

Fifteen Roman Catholic Bishops, a score of monsignori and several hundred priests paid tribute last night to the Paulist Fathers at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel marking the close of the order's 100th anniversary year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Representative Robert W. Kean chided his Democratic opponent, Harrison A. Williams Jr., today for his political "inexperience" and his "advocacy of policies that would lead to a weaker America."
FLINT, Mich., Oct. 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon campaigned across Michigan today in the final day of a swing through eleven states in the East and the Midwest.
CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -The top price of butcher hogs slipped to the lowest level of the year today at $18.85. The supply of 14,000 head was the heaviest since Jan. 2.
The New York Daily News has come out in support of Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor of New York.

WORLAND, Wyo., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson warned voters tonight that they faced a choice of "a return to price-fixers and the forces of regimentation or a program under Republican leadership aimed at an expanding, prosperous and free economy."
Conservative and Reform Jews joined Orthodox rabbis yesterday in protesting regulations requiring new postal employes here to work on days that may be their Sabbath.
A campaign to expel the Hungarian delegation from the United Nations was begun yesterday.
Ten members of the new twelve-member Fair Housing Practices Panel were sworn in at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

Fiery Phil Watson tugged thoughtfully at his New York Yankee baseball cap and paid scant attention to his Rangers working out on Madison Square Garden ice yesterday. Phil's baby, the power play, was foremost in his thoughts.
UPTON, L. I., Oct 27 -- Queen Frederika of Greece was briefed on peacetime uses of nuclear energy by scientists today at the Brookhaven National Laboratory.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Supreme Court directed a lower court today to re-examine another Florida television case in which Richard A. Mack was involved.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, former Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, recorded a series of television programs yesterday on behalf of Governor Harriman for showing later in the week.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The stock market remained subdued today. Industrials continued to drift lower.

ROME, Oct. 27 -- The election of a new Pope, not yet decided after two days of voting, has all but paralyzed the Vatican. It also has affected Italian public life, considerably hampering official activities.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Board of Trade announced today the lifting, effective Wednesday, of all limitations on installment buying, or what the British call the "never-never."

BANGOR, Me., Oct. 27 -- The state of Maine is now busy adding up its big freshwater fish caught this year and making statistics to be filed away somewhere until it is time to refer to them for comparison next year. There is some impressive stuff this year.
HAVANA, Oct. 27 -- The Cuban rebels said today they had shot down a Cuban Army fighter plane that was bombing the Campechuela District of southern Oriente Province.
Organized labor is in the unusual position of worrying that it may do too well in next Tuesday's elections.

Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, the "father of the atomic submarine," denounced the waste of natural resources last night. He termed it "a minor form of treason; not deliberate, of course, but rooted in heedless selfishness."
The economic side of medical thinking today may sometimes be closer to 1908 than to 1958, the new president of the New York County Medical Society said last night.

Unbeaten Louisiana State took over the No. 1 spot in the Associated Press college football poll yesterday. Army, the leader the last two weeks, dropped to third place after its 14-14 tie with Pittsburgh.

A two-day donation of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will be begun today by employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company, Inc., at 195 Broadway.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Republic National Bank announced plans today for raising its capital and surplus to $100,000,000 which would make it the largest of any bank in the Southwest.

The following are letters of praise for the United Service Organizations from chaplains of the Armed Forces: "It is heartening for us to know that when a young soldier leaves the base on pass he may hope to find in a strange city the home away from home that is U. S. O." -- Army Chaplain (Maj. Gen.) Ivan L. Bennett.
A special meeting of stockholders in the Upjohn Company, producers of pharmaceuticals, has been called for Nov. 21 to consider a change in the state of incorporation from Michigan to Delaware.

I cannot refrain from commenting on your editorial of Oct. 23 criticizing Governor Harriman, first, for allegedly declining to debate Nelson Rockefeller exclusively on "state issues" and, second, for failing to discuss "state matters" in his campaign speeches.

President Eisenhower will receive the first Gold Medal Award of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame at a $50-a-plate dinner tonight in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor. About 2,000 persons are expected to attend.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Government issued over President Eisenhower's signature today its first national plan for civil and defense mobilization.

Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, said last night that the concept that religion and education could be totally separated was inconsistent with the facts.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Nigeria's political leaders accepted today Britain's offer to grant her independence on Oct. 1, 1960. Nigeria will then join the British Commonwealth.

George Leggett, 21-year-old founder of a racial supremacy club in Queens, was arraigned in Night Court last night on a disorderly conduct charge. He was released in the custody of his parents and lawyer pending a hearing in Queens Magistrates Court next Friday.

An industry executive suggested yesterday that advertising's practitioners remove some of the mystery from their business by recognizing that it is simply a substitute for One person talking to another.

Net income of Textron, Inc., in the quarter ended Sept. 30 rose 64 per cent to $3,283,919, or 79 cents a share, from $2,005,545, or 51 cents a share, in the like period a year ago, Royal Little, chairman, announced yesterday.

Maurice Newton's second-choice Egotistical flashed a high turn of speed at Jamaica yesterday. He won the $6,000 Lefferts Handicap by a length and a half, one watch tick slower than the track record.

The growth of the motel business will be reflected in the designation of next Tuesday as Motel Day at the forty-third annual National Hotel Exposition at the New York Coliseum. This is the first time a special day has been given to motel activities.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 27 -- A cabin cruiser, missing since last night with three persons believed to be aboard, was found floating partly submerged in the Atlantic Ocean today five miles southeast of here.

The current report of the acting director of the United Nations' aid program for the Arab refugees in the Middle East is somewhat disheartening. The United Nations is again asked to appropriate about $37,500,000 for the care of these refugees and the United States will again contribute about 70 per cent of the total cost. The contribution of the United States has averaged more than $20,000,000 in each of the past two years.

The annual rate of the country's national income for the second quarter of 1958, as just revealed by the Department of Commerce, represented a nominal upturn of $1.8 billion over that of the preceding three months' period. That would amount to about only 10 per cent of the decline from the 1957 high of $369 billion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -The downward trend of grain futures prices gathered speed again today on the Board of Trade. It carried all the corn and most of the soybean contracts to new lows for the season.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 27 -- Dutch public opinion is satisfied that Dr. Joseph M. A. H. Luns, Netherlands Foreign Minister, brought back from his recent visit to Washington a moral commitment by the United States to oppose Indonesia if that nation should use force against Netherlands New Guinea.

YONKERS, Oct. 27 -- Meadow Al remains the even-money favorite to take the $57,179 that will be the winner's share of the Empire Pace at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. The total purse is $103,962, which makes the Empire the richest 2-year-old event in the history of harness racing.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 28 -- Boris Pasternak, Soviet winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, has been expelled from the Soviet Writers Union and deprived of the title of Soviet Writer, the Soviet press agency Tass reported early today.

Still another 1958 high -- the fifth in as many weeks -- was set last week by steel production. Output of ingots and steel for castings exceeded scheduled output for the fifth week, but a decline is in prospect for this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday.

In this season of fresh approach to offensive football, Villanova has come up with one of the more interesting variations from the norm.

In 1957 William O. Douglas, associate justice of the Supreme Court, made a 7,000-mile motor trip across five Middle East countries. He has written an account of his observations and experiences in "West of the Indus," which Doubleday will issue Nov. 10.

The southeast and southwest corners of Main Street and Franklin Avenue in Flushing, Queens, have been sold by A. A. Roth of Whitestone, Queens, to Henry Kibel, architect and builder. LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Frederick Sanger, who has won the Nobel Prize for chemistry, is credited with unraveling one of the tightest and toughest knots known to biochemists. The knot is a molecular one; it concerns the exact internal chain-like structure of the insulin molecule, the life-preserving boon of diabetics.
The Composers Group of New York presented an evening of new works at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 28 -- The directors of the Virginia Education Association voted almost unanimously today to press for state legislation assuring "the continued operation of public schools as a state function."
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 28 -- The current stalemate in Taiwan Strait continued today with the Communist artillery fire on Quemoy ebbing to light harassment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that prospects for negotiating a ban on nuclear tests were dim because the Soviet Union had discovered it was "considerably behind" the United States in nuclear weapons development.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The national debt, with larger spending and a decline in Government income as factors, has reached a record high, it was disclosed today.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange dipped 1 to 4 points (5 cents to 20 cents a bale) yesterday after fluctuating in a narrow range.

An art exhibition and sale of more than 400 works of contemporary art by American artists will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, from Nov. 12 through Nov. 16.

Polamby, a bay 3-year-old filly that had not won a race since July 19 at Jamaica, charged down the middle of a rain-drenched track there yesterday and won the $10,000 Laurelton Handicap by three- quarters of a length.
IN Paris, Marcel Achard's "Patate" soothes the citizenry and takes their minds off their troubles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The long, slow decline of grain futures prices may have hit the turning point today. Nearly all futures contracts on the Board of Trade closed with moderate advances, the first general upward swing in more than a week.

Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada said last night that relations between Canada and the United States had improved in the last year, but that problems remained in the field of trade and economic affairs.

The Russian novel "Doctor Zhivago," by Boris Pasternak, who was awarded the Nobel Prize last week, is the subject of local contention as to who will make it into a movie.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Yugoslavia has indicated to the United States and Britain that she is interested in obtaining loans totaling $100,000,000 -- about $60,000,00 from the United States and $40,00,000 from Britain.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 28 -- David and Godfrey Kelly of the Bahamas glided across the finish line first in 1 hour 53 minutes 7 seconds today in the second race of the Hayward Western Hemisphere Snipe championship. The General Motors Corporation was the only member of the automobile industry's "Big Three" to operate at a Profit in the third quarter. The other two -- Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation -- were in the red.

Sales and earnings of the American Can Company in the quarter ended Sept. 30 showed gains over the similar period of 1957, William C. Stolk, president, reported yesterday. Volume in the first nine months was higher than a year ago, but earnings lagged.

The election of John E. Stonington as president of the New York Cocoa Exchange was announced yes-day.

Three young men were arrested yesterday and charged with having stolen a safe containing $6,500 in cash and $138,775 in Government bonds from the Brooklyn apartment of a hospital administrator last Saturady.

Every woman would like to have a jewel box brimming over with a king's ransom in gems, pearls and gold. Because this is out of the question for most, the next best thing is a small investment in costume jewelry that has the look of the McCoy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- John C. Folger, United States Ambassador to Belgium, and Mrs. Folger have contributed $3,000 to the campaign of Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican nominee for Senator in New York.
Tickets are still available for the two theatre paies that will benefit the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House. They may be Iobtained from the beneficiary at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street.
Phil Watson, the coach of the New York Rangers, is a man of many moods. And some of the Rangers find it difficult to keep pace with their boss' frame of mind.
Referring to your editorial of Oct. 22 in which you indicated a preference for Governor Leader over Representative Scott in the Pennsylvania Senatorial contest, may I take issue with your appraisal?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- The conflict that has divided the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists is to be given a full airing at the annual membership meeting of the Guild. The date has been set for Nov. 25 at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

GEORGE HALAS is a benevolent gentleman of 68. His once blond hair is getting sparse and gray. He has moved gracefully into his role as an elder statesman of professional football, a symbolic figure who links the past and the present. His title of Papa Bear denotes characteristics that are noble and admirable.
New financing, unmatched for dollar amount since late this summer and for number and variety since last winter, is being offered to investors today.
NINE gourmet dinners for the benefit of the Florence Crittenton League's Barrett House will be held here this fall.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Secretary Mitchell condemned secondary boycotts and some forms of picketing today as the most fertile sources of union corruption.
The political pot is boiling hot in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District.

I read with great interest the editorial of Oct. 20 with your recommendations to voters with respect to the State Legislature. It was noted, however, with great disappointment that you failed to recommend Bentley Kassal (Democratic-Liberal), candidate for re-election to the Assembly in the Fifth District.

The Police Safety Bureau noted yesterday that the rise in traffic accidents that usually accompanies shorter daylight hours was reflected in the last week when fourteen persons were killed and 1,284 injured in the city.

A pattern has been adopted by Paul Gregory to start his projects far in advance, a method that permits him ample time to build up a huge advance sale. He says this procedure has proved very effective with his entry of "The Marriage-GoRound," which arrives tonight at the Plymouth with Claudette Colbert and Charles Boyer starred.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Business has advanced faster than usual this fall, and the economic recovery is broadening. These were the principal conclusions of the Department of Commerce today in its monthly review.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Four women and seven men were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in connection with a mail fraud involving at least $300,000, United States Attorney Harold K. Wood said.
We summarize today and tomorrow the opinions of the Bar Associations and the Citizens Union concerning competing candidates for judicial office to be voted upon next Tuesday.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported a consolidated net income yesterday of $204,393,000 for the nine months ended Sept. 30. This was equal to $6.31 each on the 32,386,000 shares outstanding following the 4 per cent stock dividend payable Dec. 2.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Parents were urged today to prevent their children from using masks on Halloween because they reduced vision to a dangerous extent.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 28 -- Dr. James B. Conant cautioned state school board members today that many pupils in New York and other metropolitanarea high schools might be overstrained rather than underworked.
A labor headache was added yesterday to Governor Harriman's campaign tribulations.

In a series of editorials this week and last we have given our views and recommendations in respect to some twenty-five of the Congressional contests in New York City and the surrounding area. In none of these contests is the outcome more certain and at the same time more deplorable than in the Sixteenth District of Manhattan, where Adam Clayton Powell Jr. is sure to be reelected for his eighth consecutive term.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Following is the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:
William B. Lewis, president of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., warned advertising men yesterday to get more into the marketing field "or else get out of the agency business."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Bob Reifsnyder, Navy's star tackle who has been sidelined all season with a leg injury, may rejoin the team this week against Notre Dame at Baltimore.

FOR those who are baffled by the problem of what wine to serve with what food, a new chart provides many of the answers. It is a cardboard contrivance called the "Wine Wheel for 1959." It may be purchased at book shops, including the Golden Griffin at Madison Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

The directors of the Blaw-Knox Company increased the regular quarterly cash dividend yesterday from 30 cents to 35 cents a common share, and also approved an extra dividend of 2.5 per cent in capital stock. Both cash and stock dividends are payable Dec. 15.

TUNIS, Oct. 28 -- President Habib Bourguiba urged tonight that Premier Charles de Gaulle liberate Ahmed ben Bella and four other Algerian nationalists held in Paris as a means of thawing the Algerian problem.

Yields on commercial paper traded in the open market were cut one-eighth of a percentage point yesterday by a leading dealer. Commercial paper is the term applied to short - term obligations of major industrial concerns and finance companies.
Former Gov. Thomas A. Dewey charged in a televised speech last night that Governor Harriman was responsible for "the worst revival of the spoils system in our generation."

Academician Igor Y. Tamm, generally considered one of the world's outstanding theoretical physicists, has a much wider reputation and higher standing than the two other Nobel Prize-winning Soviet physicists. Dr. Pavel A. Cherenkov and Prof. Ilya M. Frank.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 28 -- Norman H. Burg and Arthur Raphael of New York left Loon Bay Lodge this morning full of confidence, though it was raining hard and the woods were wet. They were confident because each of them possessed:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 28 -The Carnegie Institute of Technology received a gift of $2,800,000 today for a campus library. The new building would accommodate 350,000 books in the library proper and 125,000 in the basement alcoves.
" THE COUNT OF MONTE CRISTO" was brought to the home screen in a fine display of inventive television stagecraft ("DuPont Show of the Month" over Channel 2).
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 28 -- A Panagra airliner with forty-five persons aboard dived to safety last night under a formation of an Air Force refueling tanker and two jet fighters.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 -- Yugoslavia accused neighboring Albania today of interfering in her internal affairs and of attempting "a direct attack on the territorial integrity" of the nation.
The city was accused yesterday of "sinister and discriminatory purpose in * * * the perpetuation of racial segregation" in five school districts in Harlem.

The destructive early morning fire in P. S. 46 in Harlem mercifully occurred when no children were in the school. This was an old school by acceptable standards, being built in sections in 1878, 1890 and 1900. But it is middle-aged by New York City standards.

As Will Rogers put it, "One-third of the people in the United States promote, while the other two-thirds provide." In an age ridden with cupidity and selfishness it is indeed reassuring and refreshing to know that the New York State finances are administered by Arthur Levitt, who, incidentally, is our fiftieth Controller.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 -- Award of the Nobel Prize in Physics to three Soviet scientists was announced quickly if briefly here this evening.

A prominent educator and university administrator told the American Institute of Planners yesterday that this country had failed to prepare the peoples of underdeveloped lands for the social changes resulting from economic aid and technical assistance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- United States officials indicated today that the organizational structure of the North Atlantic alliance was as good as could be expected, but said they would not oppose some changes.
The world must prevent the creation of a "new race of permanent camp dwellers," Dr. Auguste R. Lindt, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said yesterday.
Twenty-four elderly men interrupted their morning prayer services yesterday in the Yeshiva Torah V'Yirah Synagogue on the lower East Side to pin down a noisy intruder until the police arrived.
A young man who clearly had had one too many was overheard telling a friend on 125th Street the other night that "after what Adam did, Earl is going to trample him on Nov 4."
An electrostatic teletypewriter reported to be capable of producing 3,000 words a minute was demonstrated here yesterday.

Arnold (Red) Auerbach, the explosive coach of the Boston Celtics, was fined $150 yesterday by Maurice Podoloff, the president of the National Basketball Association, "for his complete defiance" of a league rule during last Saturday's game with the New York Knickerbockers.

DON JUAN went to hell again last night, this time on the stage of the Broadway Theatre. But that is not to say that Moliere's difficult "Don Juan" -- part tragedy, part satire, part farce -- came to a bad end.

Another male sanctuary has fallen to the opposite sex. As of 11 A.M. yesterday the noisy trading floor of the American Stock Exchange was thrown open to Mrs. Mary G. Roebling, who had just been named the first woman governor of the exchange.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 -- Charles Abrams, chairman of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination, said today that a more effective Federal Civil Rights Commission was imperative to deal with the problems of migrating groups and minorities.

Although you are giving a nod of editorial approval to Representative Robert W. Kean over his Democratic opponent Harrison Williams in the New Jersey contest for United States Senator, your implication that there is little to choose between the two candidates does a disservice to the Republican Congressman's forth-right stand on key issues.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct 28 -- The American Heart Association's assembly today reaffirmed, with clarification, a policy in favor of raising its money annually through independent voluntary campaigns instead of through united funds or other federated community appeals.

TO save its customers time, energy and patience, Arnold Constable has initiated one of the most pleasant reforms on Fifth Avenue. The store has gathered all its dresses on the third floor and reserved the entire fifth floor for its coats and suits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The National Education Association announced today it would seek legislation in the next Congress to provide Federal aid for school construction and to increase teachers' salaries.

DALLAS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senate majority leader Lyndon B. Johnson, Democrat, Tex., said today that the role of the United States as a world trade competitor was the weakest link in the nation's national security.
A shipment of gold worth $23,780 was reported missing by American Airlines at LaGuardia Airport early today.
The news of the election of Pope John XXIII was received at the chancery offices of the Archdiocese of New York by radio shortly after 11 o'clock yesterday morning.
SUMMERSVILLE, W. Va., Oct. 28 (AP) -- An explosion deep within a south-eastern West Virginia coal mine killed thirteen miners today and injured four others, two of them critically.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union complained today that the United Nations staff had too many Americans in high posts and too few Russians. It said the situation was "intolerable."
Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for Senator, urged last night that the United Nations be given authority to make rules for the use of outer space.

ROME, Wednesday, Oct. 29 -- Pope John XXIII will leave the conclave enclosure later today to take over the government of the Roman Catholic Church. He is expected to celebrate mass within the enclosure and then inspect the papal private apartment on the third floor of the apostolic palace.
An act of mercy at sea may turn out to have been a costly gesture for a small American steamship company.
CHRISTCHURCH, N. Z., Oct. 28 -- The Antarctic may have a nuclear power station within the next two years.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -The United States has proposed that an organization be set up within the North Atlantic alliance to coordinate propaganda on behalf of the free world.
The board of directors of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association voted Dr. J. Burns Amberson general director yesterday.
SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The disappearance of the Southern Cloud twenty-seven years ago was cleared up today.

National racing champions for 1958 have been named by the Sports Car Club of America. Walter Hansgen of Westfield, N. J., who repeated his performance of 1957 in Class C Modified, considered the most important group, scored 11,600 points driving a D Jaguar and a Lister-Jaguar for the Briggs Cunningham team.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 28 -- "Positive traffic control" over civilian and military jet flight was urged today by the international airlines.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- A short-lived peace on troubled Cyprus ended tonight when new violence erupted and curfew measures, lifted a few hours earlier, were clamped down again on many parts of the island.
Five men -- including four named Monday in a Supreme Court order -- have been subpoenaed in the state's inquiry into possible fraud in the sale of Wall Street securities.

ROME, Oct. 28 (AP) -- World food production is rising again and both the Soviet Union and Communist China are expecting to export crops that may influence world trade, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported today.

Pope John XXIII, while an official observer of the Holy See at the United Nations Educational, Social and Cultural Organization, said in a 1952 sermon in Paris that Roman Catholics throughout the world should participate in the work of "this promising institution."

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 28 -- The C. W. Post football team will go to New Haven, Conn., this week-end, hoping to get some of the touchdowns it just missed getting last Saturday against Ithaca College.
The Government's antitrust suits against the Radio Corporation of America ended yesterday in Federal court with a consent judgment and a fine.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan presented to the House of Commons today a broad program of social change involving education, pensions, home ownership and mental health.
COLUMBUS, Oct. 27 -- With barely a week to go before the election, Ohio is a divided and confused state.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Senator William A. Purtell, Republican seeking re-election, visited factories here and in near-by Middlefield today.
YONKERS, Oct. 28 -- Most of the pre-race publicity on the Empire Pace, the richest stake for 2-year-olds in harness racing history, was centered on two colts, Meadow Al and Adios Day.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States and Britain today of trying to find a "respectable pretext" to prevent the complete cessation of nuclear test explosions.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Two University of Michigan athletic stars were arrested with five other students today in a police crackdown on campus gambling.

Mayor Wagner made known last night that the city was subpoenaing the books and records of all 127 private nursing homes in the city. Twenty-eight of them so far are said to have challenged the city's action in court.
ROME, Oct. 28 -- Angelo Giuseppe Cardinal Roncalli, Patriarch of Venice, was elevated to the Papacy this afternoon. He will be 77 years old Nov. 25.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Rocket observations of the Oct. 12 solar eclipse have established for the first time where the sometimes troublesome rays of energy come from in the sun, the Navy announced today.
OTTAWA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Bread is what a family wants most after seven days on nuclear-attack survival rations.
The 1959 Edsel has been cut in size, range and price to fit more realistically into the lowest echelon of the medium-priced market.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Halloween is a night for witches, pumpkins and children -- not for burns and tragic accidents, the National Fire Protection Association cautioned today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr. told a group of labor leaders here tonight that President Eisenhower "must secretly hope for the election of Democrats this year to give needed leadership to the country."
The work that was honored yesterday by the award of the Nobel Prize in physics to three Soviet scientists started with the discovery of the "Cherenkov effect" twenty-four years ago.
The nation's 5,000 travel and resort agencies have asked the Government to intervene in a dispute with steamship passenger conferences over commissions and regulations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Army put a "confidential" stamp on the laws of celestial mechanics and plane geometry today, but quickly removed it when the action became known.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 28 -- Representative Robert W. Keon moved his campaign into the home county of his Democratic opponent today.
A two-day blood donation by employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Electric Company, Inc., at 195 Broadway, will end today.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -Plans for replacing outmoded buildings at the reformatory for women at WestB field State Farm here ere outlined today by Thomas J. McHugh, Stato Commissioner of Correction.
MELBOURNE, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The big Royal Dutch-Shell petroleum group has joined the search for oil in western Australia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks' front line of Ron Murphy, Bobby Hull and Eric Nesterenko scored three times in the last six minutes tonight to tie the National Hockey League-leading Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 5, and break a four-game losing streak.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct., 28 -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi said today his reforms, intended to bring about honest, democratic government for Iran, would be pushed with vigor and determination.
Though the campaign spotlight has been focused on the candidates of the Republican and Democratic parties, two minority groups are seeking support for their state - wide candidates on Election Day.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -- Herbert Hoover endorsed Senator William F. Knowland today for Governor of California.

All television networks expect to present the first filmed coverage of the newly elected Supreme Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church some time today. Films made in Rome yesterday just after the election of Angelo Giuseppe Cardinal Roncalli as Pope were said last night to be en route by plane to New York.
A five-alarm, early-morning fire forced the closing yesterday of eighty-year-old Public School 46 in Washington Heights.

ROBERT GERLE, a Hungarian violinist now resident in America, made his Town Hall debut last night. He has played in this city previously and created a favorable impression -- an impression more than justified last night.

NEW temperature - resistant freezer-to-oven-to-tableware has been introduced by the Corning Glass Works. Called Corning Ware, these cook and serve pieces are made of Pyroceram, a material developed by this company for use in missile cones.

FIFTY years ago the Bohemian Benevolent and Literary Association built an annex in East Seventy-fourth Street between First and Second Avenues. That part of Yorkville then was flooded with Czechs and Slovaks.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The International Court of Justice will open oral hearings Nov. 5 in the Interhandel Corporation case between the United States and Switzerland, a spokesman for the United States Embassy said today.

SOME TRULY remarkable West African sculpture and a large assortment of pre-Columbian gold work of the same period from the region between Costa Rica and Peru will go on view today at the Museum of Primitive Art, 15 West Fifty-fourth street.

SAPPORO, Japan, Oct. 28 (UPI) -- Bob Blaylock, hoping to impress the Cards' manager, Solly Hemus, after compiling a won-lost record of 8 -- 14 at Omaha last season, pitched no-hit ball for six innings today in the St. Louis club's 9-1 romp over the Japanese All-Stars.
The first phase of a major development program inspired by the space age was announced yesterday by Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., yesterday challenged Nelson A. Rockefeller to "repudiate" what he called President Eisenhower's "callous disregard" of a group of school children who staged a demonstration in Washington Saturday on school integration.
The "discontinuance" of negotiations for the purchase of the Cuban-owned Ward-Garcia Corporation was announced here yesterday by the Mamenic Line.
ROME, Oct. 28 -- More Popes have taken ttle name John thani any other, but the name has not been used by any Pope since] early in tho fourteenth century.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 28 -- Former President Iskander Mirza and his wife, Begum Nahid, were flown early this morning to Quetta, a hill resort near the Iranian border.
The opening of Park West Village to its first tenants was marked yesterday in a ceremony outside the first three seventeen-story apartment buildings to be erected.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 28 -- Three Soviet physicists and a British biochemist were named today as winners of Nobel Prizes in science. The 1958 physics prize is to be shared by Dr. Pavel A. Cherenkov, Prof. Ilya M. Frank and Academician Igor Y. Tamm, all members of the Physics Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- The first apostolic blessing imparted by Pope John XXIII was seen and heard today by more Roman Catholics than ever before. Radio and television made the traditional benediction "Urbi et Orbi" (to city of Rome and the world) truly universal by radio and television.
President Eisenhower's electioneering role in New York yesterday was more that of a "distinguished guest" than a hard-hitting campaigner for the Republican slate.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- The Reading Company today reported net income of $576,957 for September, compared with $466,988 in August and $808,636 in September of last year. Earnings for the first nine months of 1958 were $1,479,732, against $7,173,958 in the same period of last year.
The Canadian Pacific Railway's profits fell slightly last month, but for the year to date the road has had better earnings than it did in 1957.
Art of forty nations, from the Age of Pericles to circa 1958, will go on public view today in the Seagram Building, 375 Park Avenue at Fifty-third Street.

PARIS, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -- Crucial negotiations on a European free trade area were stalemated tonight after a day of stormy talks and speeches at headquarters of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
All cocoa options except the September declined the daily limit of 1 cent yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. September deliveries were off 95 points. A point is one one-hundredth of a cent.
After six days of falling prices, the stock market turned around yesterday. Volume declined a little but prices were higher, with general gains extending into every major group except the chemicals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The first batch of cement splashed into the foundation of the San Francisco Giants' new stadium today.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The objective of recent French diplomatic moves has been to give Europe more rather than less voice in international consultation on the free world's strategic and political problems outside the North Atlantic Treaty area, French spokesmen indicated today.

The Transit Authority yesterday announced plans to plug a revenue leak by changing token receivers on 988 turnstiles on the IRT subway system. The agency said it was being cheated out of $10,000 a year.

Queen Elizabeth has opened Parliament amid what Richard Cobden described as "barbaric pomp" and has dutifully delivered her Speech from the Throne. For the first time a Sovereign spoke not only to the Lords, the Commons and their guests, but to many millions who could see and hear on television.

" The Buccaneer," a Paramount production supervised by Cecil B. De Mille and dealing with an account of the pirate Jean Lafitte in New Orleans, at the time of the War of 1812, will have its premiere at the Capitol Theatre on the night of Dec. 22.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The stock market was in a more buoyant mood today. The ending of installment buying restrictions checked the decline among the industrials.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 --The support by the General Electric Company of the "right to work" proposal on the California ballot has led to boycott threats.

Quite a few things will have to happen if the Giants are to upset the unbeaten Browns at Cleveland Sunday. Mind you, no one around the Yankee Stadium, where the Giants watched movies and heard Jack Lavelle's scouting report yesterday, or at adjacent Macombs Dam Park, where they practiced, said the Browns were going to be toppled.

Clifton A. Hipkins of the Riverside Yacht Club was elected president of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound at the organization's annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night. The Junior Y. R. A. that met earlier renamed Everett B. Morris of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club as its chairman.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Two Negro ministers, convicted of violating Birmingham's new bus-seating law, were freed on appeal bonds today. They had been in jail more than five days.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 -- Yugoslavia denied today reports abroad that the United States and Britain had agreed to give this Communist-ruled nation about $300,000,000 in credits to aid its development program.
The public auctioning of perhaps the most valuable stamp collection ever assembled by one person, the late Alfred H. Caspary, ended yesterday. The total realized was $2,895,146.
The cynics, skeptics and critics who make a practice of heaping abuse on college football would do well to read yesterday's newspapers with extra care.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, assuring the new Pontiff of the prayers of New York's Roman Catholics, said here today, "Almighty God has blessed the Church with the election of His Holiness Pope John XXIII."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that Boris Pasternak's refusal to accept a Nobel prize showed that Soviet authorities sought to stamp out freedom of thought.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., first American airline to provide jet passenger service across the Atlantic, has arranged a $130,000,000, three-year revolving credit. The deal was made with a group of thirty-nine banks in seventeen cities headed by the New York Trust Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Mordecai R. Kidron, Israel's delegate at the United Nations since 1953, left today to take over his new post as Ambassador to Thailand. He will go first to Israel.

In most American novels and short stories dealing with athletes, the college football hero usually is an unstoppable super-colossal young man who runs, kicks, throws and eventually gets whisked away to marriage in a convertible driven by a rich girl in a polo coat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower plans to attend the eighteenth meeting of the Colombo Plan nations in Seattle, Wash., on Nov. 10, it was announced at the White House today.

Daylight saving ended over the week-end. Those who remembered about it turned their clocks back an hour before going to bed Saturday evening and thus won an extra hour's sleep. Those who forgot were in church an hour early on Sunday, with a little extra time for reflection.

Future prices on the New York exchanges were irregular yesterday in dull trading. Cocoa, copper, zinc and coffee were down; rubber, wool, cottonseed oil and hides were up, while sugar and lead price movements were mixed.

Leonard J. Winston, realty operator, has resold the five-story apartment house at 1055-57 Grand Concourse near East 165th Street in the Bronx to an investing client of Joseph Cahn, attorney, for cash over mortgages of $214,000. The property is 105 by 141 feet and was sold through Joseph Panman Associates, broker.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Union workers at the last strikebound General Motors plant represented by the United Auto Workers agreed today to return to work tomorrow.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N. Y., gained a, unanimous ten-round decision tonight over Franz Szuzina of Bremen, Germany. Each weighed 164 1/2 pounds.

In an editorial yesterday we dealt with the candidates for the state-wide Court of Appeals and for judicial offices in Manhattan and the Bronx. Today we turn to those who are running in Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond. Again we summarize the opinions of the county bar associations and the Citizens Union.

New York Aviation made its last appearance in the Public Schools Athletic League Manhattan Division cross-country championships a winning one yesterday, posting a low score of 30 points at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

Irwin Untermyer, former Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, has objected to the use of the title "Judge" before his name on the cover and title page of an art-sale catalogue.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 29 -- Chinese Communist artillery fire today against the offshore islands was termed "inconsequential" by Nationalist Defense Ministry officials.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The President of the General Assembly has consulted a representative of the Algerian Provisional Government to explore the United Nations' position in the dispute between France and the rebels.
" Portraits of Personalities -- Past and Present," a loan exhibition of forty art masterpieces, will benefit the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 -- A delegation of American college presidents took a "second look" today at higher education in the Soviet Union and condemned Russian methods as indoctrination with "a basic, long-run built-in limitation."
Admiral Felix B. Stump, retired United States commander in the Pacific, said last night that the nation must risk war to avoid war.

The Dominican Revolutionary party called on Pope John XXIII yesterday to open a papal inquiry into the support it charges the Roman Catholic Church has given Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo in the Dominican Republic.

YONKERS, Oct 29 (AP) -- Easy Adios, a 6-year-old son of Adios, closed fast and won tonight's featured pace by three-quarters of a length from Ted Lybrook at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile over a fast track was 2:06 1-5.

TORONTO, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Extensive regulations proposed for the Canadian gas and oil industry by the Royal Commission on Energy Resources (Borden Commission), should be approached "with great caution" because of possible adverse effects on the industry, an oil company executive said today.

Except only for the year 1934, halfway through Franklin D. Roosevelt's first term, the political party controlling the administration has lost seats in Congress in every mid-term election since the Civil War. Sometimes, as in 1894, when the Democrats dropped 116 House seats, the losses have been gigantic; at other times, as in 1926, when the Republicans lost only ten, they have been nominal.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The Soviet bloc reiterated its refusal today to pay any part of the costs of the United Nations Emergency Force that is patrolling between the United Arab Republic and Israel. The international force was sent to the Middle East after the invasion of Egypt in 1956 by French, British and Israeli troops.

Seats are still available for the Nov. 7 performance of "The Pleasure of His Company" at the Longacre Theatre. The play starring Cornelia Otis Skinner and Cyril Ritchard has been chosen by the Sweet Briar Alumnae Club of New York as its annual scholarship fund benefit.
" Check your firearms at the door" is now the watchword in the city's Domestic Relations Courts.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Government has accepted a United States offer of financial aid to offset losses caused by five months of rebellion, Premier Rashid Karami said today.
PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Three Marine Corps drill instructors, all sergeants, have been accused of maltreating some recruits, it was disclosed here today at the Marines' training center.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that manufacturers' sales in September rose more than seasonally above the August level

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The defending champion, J. Wolcott Brown of Sea Girt, N. J., fired a one-over-par 71 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the men's Southern senior golf tournament.
TORONTO, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens scored three times in the opening period and went on to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

The entire story of how the Democratic party leader and Secretary of State for New York, Carmine De Sapio, tried unsuccessfully to deny a place on the ballot for the Independent-Socialist party should be told.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Bertrand Russell, noted British philosopher and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1950, said tonight that "the Soviet authorities have acted very badly indeed" with respect to the prize awarded to Boris Pasternak.
The General Telephone Corporation and its subsidiaries continued through September to show record revenues and net income, according to the quarterly report released yesterday.
Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation, announced yesterday a $12,000,000, ten-year scholarship program to provide the nation with additional health workers.

Denver, Colo., borrowed $12,750,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of water supply facilities. The bonds, secured by general taxation, were sold to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 3.49483 per cent.

THE formal induction of nine new members into football's Hall of Fame was an appealing ceremony, especially since it was graced by the presence of President Eisenhower, who smiled in benign approval. And the President seemed genuinely touched that the Gold Medal Award should be bestowed "on an obscure football player like myself."
Lovick Pierce of Nashville, Tenn., was elected president yesterday of the Board of Publication of the Methodist Church with the title of publisher. The meeting was held at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
Two hours off with pay is a legal right for all employes of private industry, the state and its civil divisions for voting on Election Day, next Tuesday.
A strike by editorial and commercial employes against one or two New York newspapers at midnight tomorrow appeared a possibility yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon set out tonight on his final campaign swing. It will take him coast-to-coast, and then some.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Two Roman Catholic priests in suburban Waukesha County have banned youngsters in their parish from Hallowe'en "begging" for the United Nation's child relief program.

Stockholders of the H. L. Green Company, Inc., variety chain, voted at a special meeting at the Gramercy Park Hotel yesterday to merge with the Olen Company, Inc. Olen is a department store chain with 126 stores. Its headquarters are in Mobile, Ala. Olen stockholders, meeting in Mobile yesterday, also approved the merger.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Oct. 29 -- The dedication of twelve youths to safety and courtesy on the highways has benefited numerous motorists here in the last seven months.

Along with hundreds of other "independent" voters I am amazed at your advising the voters of Fairfield County to vote out of office an exceptionally capable and fully experienced Congressman, Albert E. Morano.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Spokesmen for the Government and the Radio Corporation of America agreed today that the decree settling their antitrust differences "could get color television off the ground."

Directors of the Rexall Drug Company have voted the regular quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share, payable Dec. 5, and a stock dividend of 3 per cent payable March 6. No stock dividend was paid last year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- The Governments of the United States and Canada will cooperate with Paramount Pictures and Joseph M. Schenck Enterprises, Inc., in the production of a motion picture dealing with the activities of the North American Air Defense Command.
The street sign at Seventh Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street has just been changed temporarily to read, "Buying Office Avenue."

BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Rose Trellis, a gelding sent postward only four previous times this year, went to the outside with a tremendous stretch surge to win the $61,000 Yankee Handicap before a crowd of 17,846 today at Suffolk Downs.

On Tuesday, Phil Watson, the New York Rangers' coach, said his team was too docile in practice. The Rangers certainly were not docile last night even though the best they could do was a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP) -Edward T. Dickinson, State Commerce Commissioner, investigated today a complaint that salt produced by "slave labor" in the Dominican Republic had been shipped to Albany for a Glens Falls company.

A prediction that within five to ten years all four-year, degree-granting educational institutions would require entrance examinations was made yesterday by Frank H. Bowles, president of the College Entrance Examination Board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -Leading Republicans poured it on the Democrats today.
LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 29 -A woman from Loon Bay Lodge slew a deer today under extraordinary circumstances, even for a woman.

The Republican underdog in Manhattan's Eighteenth Congressional District is waging a whirlwind campaign in an attempt to upset the Democratic incumbent.

Beau Diable, a 5-year-old son of Devil Diver, scored the first stakes victory of his career yesterday in the mile-and-fire-eighths Long Island Handicap at Jamaica.

The first English translation of a short novel by Boris Pasternak, who won the Nobel Prize for literature last week, will be published tomorrow by Noonday Press. It is included in "Noonday I," an anthology edited by Cecil Hemley.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower predicted today that there would be a need for future Government reorganization studies like those performed by two Hoover commissions.

A drop of 2,011,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 168,350,000 barrels, compared with 170,361,000 a week earlier and 179,288,000 a year ago.

In your editorial of Oct. 28 regarding Manhattan's Eighteenth Congressional District you have written off the one New York Congressman who has most directly served the people of his community. Surely you cannot find fault with the voting record of Democratic Congressman Alfred E. Santangelo for you have endorsed in the next line an incumbent whose voting record is almost identical with his.
MANY new features have been incorporated in General Electric's 1959 appliances to make them easier to operate and maintain.

Rejection of three proposals on the ballot dealing with housing was urged yesterday by the New York Board of Trade through its president, Ashby E. Bladen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -New obstacles, in the form of unexpected radiation leaks, have developed in research to harness the power of the hydrogen bomb for peaceful purposes, the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 23 points (25 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday, with old crop months showing the most strength.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation's third-quarter earnings were the highest for any comparable quarter since 1950, when a third-quarter record was set, Gwilym A. Price, chairman, reported yesterday. Mr. Price noted that the favorable showing in the latest quarter reflected income tax payments appreciably lower than those in the like 1957 period.

Gross revenues of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad in September were $12,025,403, down only moderately from the $12,296,278 of September, 1957. Net income fell to $1,241,092 from $1,435,921 a year ago.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Britain will continue to seek a conference with Greece and Turkey on Cyprus, despite Greece's rejection today of the proposal for such a meeting under NATO auspices.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -Mrs. Moses Dyckman of New York was elected today to her second term as national president of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 29 (AP) -- London Cry, a 22-to-1 shot, won the one hundred and sixteenth Cambridgeshire Handicap today carrying 131 pounds, the heaviest impost for a winner in the history of the race. The 4-year-old colt finished half a length before Falls of Shin in the mile and one-eighth race.
ROME, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany sent a telegram of good wishes to the Pope on behalf of the Bonn Government.

Getting to see busy physicians and to discuss ethical drugs with them is a perennial problem for ethical drug persons. The pharmaceutical division of the Borden Company has come up with an approach that it contends helps to open some doors.
A study of conditions in three Harlem junior high schools that have been charged with providing inferior educational programs will be made by the State Education Department.

The president of the merged labor federation asserted last night that charges of union efforts to control the Government or push it toward socialism represented a "political scare balloon."

After five years of day-and-night studying on his own time, Patrolman Ian Cosman of the Safety Division of Police Headquarters has become a cantor.

Queen Frederika of Greece was guest of honor at a reception that was given yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Mayor Wagner. For an hour and forty minutes, about 1,800 guests passed through the receiving line in the grand ballroom and shook her] hand.
The G. M. Basford Company is joining the growing ranks of agencies here who are tieing up with international advertising agencies.
In the opinion of Soviet affairs specialists, the violent Moscow reaction in the Boris Paternak case reflects serious concern over the political consequences of literary nonconformism.
The thirty-sixth annual dinner of the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers Association, will be held in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Sunday, Feb. 1.
A statement attributed to Controller Arthur Levitt and quoted in the City Edition of The Times of Oct. 22 is so absurd as to make one wonder whether the State Controller could have made it.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating campaigned in the Bronx yesterday, greeting 1,000 persons, most of them women shoppers.
Prominent American writers, Including Pearl Buck, a Nobel Prize winner, joined yesterday in expressing support for Mr. Pasternak.

HAVANA, Oct. 29 -- Cuban rebels will attack any vehicle moving on the highways and any railway train, beginning tomorrow and through next Monday, the day fixed for the general elections in Cuba, according to a rebel announcement today.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Pope John XXIII radiated human warmth as he took up the reins of Church government today. His modesty and occasional humorous flashes enchanted ecclesiastics and laymen who were admitted to his presence.

Directors of the Tucson (Ariz.) Gas, Electric Light and Power Company increased the cash dividend on the common stock, authorized a two-for-one split, and approved a rights offering of 110,000 common shares yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- A secretary to the Pope telephoned today to his native village of Sotto il Monte. John XXIII sent his greetings and blessings to his relatives, who have no telephone in their modest house, and to the parish priest.
Governor Harriman announced yesterday that he and Mayor Wagner were working out a program to preserve the 15-cent transit fare in New York City.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Philadelphia Port Day was observed here today, but the ceremony was slightly marred by the fact that many piers were idle as a result of a strike over a pay dispute.
SUMMERSVILLE, W. Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Rescuers brought out the last of thirteen bodies from the blast-shattered workings of a southeastern West Virginia coal mine early today.

SPRINGHILL, N. S., Thursday, Oct. 30 -- Rescuers today freed twelve men trapped two and a half miles inside a shattered coal mine for more than six days. The men had been sealed in a chamber 13,000 feet from the pithead.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 29 -- Princeton's Nassau Tavern, successor to a hostelry that once played host to George Washington and other Colonial dignitaries, is about to undergo a $1,000,000 transformation.
Washington Square Park will be closed before noon today to all but emergency vehicles and buses for a thirty-day test period.
James S. Elliott has acquired the English-speaking production rights to three Greek contemporary one-act plays for presentation on Broadway during the 1959-60 season.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 29 -Under an agreement reached today, radio station WKRC and the Citizens Committee for Economic Stability each will broadcast a series of minute "editorials" daily on the proposed "right-to-work" state amendment.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 29 --Princeton's football coach, Richard Colman, was elated today over a report that all five of his tailbacks would be in uniform Saturday against Brown.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 29 -- A Federal court of three judges was named today to rule on the constitutionality of Virginia's laws of "massive resistance" to integration in the public schools.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that she would give her vote next Tuesday to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for United States Senator.
The racial changes that have taken place on the lower East Side are reflected in this year's contest for Representative in the Nineteenth Congressional District.

AMERICA'S predilection for doughnuts is not to be denied. On the eve of Halloween, the festival most frequently associated with the bread, an organization known as the Donut Institute has released figures to show that more than 1,650,000,000 dozen commerciallymade doughnuts were eaten in this country last year. This averaged out, according to the institute's figures, to eightyone doughnuts a person.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 -- So far no medical miracle has emerged to combat one of the most persistent causes of the hospitalization of youngsters -- the common or uncommon, accident, a study showed here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct 29 -- The United States and Britain challenged the Soviet Union today to accept a one-year suspension of tests of nuclear weapons as a step toward world disarmament.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower met for more than an hour today with members of his Space Council, but no decision was announced regarding the effort of the new civilian space agency to take over scientific personnel and facilities of the Army.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower lauded today a new Boy Scout program that goes into effect next month as "promising." He said it should appeal to the Scouts.
The free Republic of Vietnam (South Vietnam) has been celebrating the third anniversary of its proclamation. There is reason to rejoice. South Vietnam is still free.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -President Eisenhower today named Richard B. Wigglesworth, retiring Republican Representative from Massachusetts, as United States Ambassador to Canada.

WHEN a movement or style in art finally establishes itself, paradox occurs. What seemed to be a unit of common feeling and vocabulary inevitably breaks up. The outstanding artists associated with the movement move off into distinct and isolated compartments of their own.

Pope John XXIII placed his reign as Supreme Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church yesterday under the patronage of an ecclesiastic who triumphed over problems as formidable as those now confronting the Papacy.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The grain futures market with-stood moderate profit-taking today on the Board of Trade and moved springly ahead in one of the most active sessions in several weeks.
On Nov. 4 the electorate will be asked to approve three housing propositions. The committee on housing of Community Service Society strongly urges a "Yes" vote on all three proposals.

The November week-ends ahead will bring to New Hampshire and Vermont a form of dog racing that has no parimutuel betting, no cash purses, no crowds, no mechanical rabbits. Plodding, heavy-coated dogs of the North will pull stripped-down Crosley and Austin automobiles in a fairly tame version of more vigorous sport to follow.
The long-stalled merger of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York State was finally achieved yesterday.

The election of D. J. St. German and Maurice S. Benjamin as trustees of the American Surety Company of New York was announced yesterday by William E. McKell, chairman and president.

Industries concerned with import competition were told yesterday that new national security safeguards in the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act offered them no easy or certain means of relief. WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- House investigators plan to question a former Federal Communications Commission chairman, George C. McConnaughey, next month about allegations of influence in a Pittsburgh television case.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Labor party offered in the House of Commons tonight a resolution criticizing the Government's economic policy.

Profits and sales of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company declined substantially in the first nine months this year below those for the 1957 period. But the company reported yesterday that third - quarter results showed improvement enhanced by inventory building by many glass customers.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reported yesterday net assets of $177,478,000, equal to $33.80 a share, as of Sept. 30. This was the highest total in the company's history as an investment company and represented a gain of $28,916,600, or 19 per cent, above the Dec. 31, 1957, figure and 9 per cent higher than the year earlier level.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Herschel D. Newsom, master of the National Grange, said tonight the grange must seek to augment farm income through competitive sales rather than Government aid programs.

The Fulton Operating Corporation bought a six-story apartment building and a taxpayer containing stores and offices at 1 Boulevard, New Rochelle, N. Y. The property, 220 by 169 feet, was sold by A. Breitbart.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- The National Safety Council reported today that traffic deaths in September were 1 per cent lower than the same month last year. The toll was 3,000 deaths this September and 3,300 last September.

Corn Products Refining Company had sharply higher earnings in the third quarter. These results included returns from its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries.

A five-foot, pitted bone that may be part of a prehistoric mastodon skeleton was found in Central Park last night by a business man. He would like to give it back to its owner.

Harry Horwitz, realty operator, has purchased the five four-story and one five-story store and apartment buildings at 814-822 Second Avenue and 300-02 East Forty-fourth Street, the southeast corner. The plot, 91 by 100 feet, was bought from Marvin Windsor and David Fishoff in a deal negotiated by Gerald B. Schwarz of the Cross Brown Company, broker. Mr. Horwitz said he had a deal pending for the resale of the property to a builder.

A pot of yellow chrysanthemums was given to Mrs. Robert F. Wagner yesterday as thanks for the city's floral decorations saluting fall. The gift was presented by Walter J. Salmon Jr. on behalf of the Bryant Park Committee of the Avenue of the Americas Association.

Drought conditions are looming for Federal farm mortgages. Government officials reported yesterday in Washington that private sources of the loans were gradually drying up. The reason is that interest rates on other investments look better than the 3.5 per cent net return on farm loans.
Senator Jacob K. Javits and Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican candidate for Senator, yesterday outlined a program for Federal legislation against "hate mail" and bombings.

Frank Gifford appears likely to be ready for the New York Giants' National Football League game with the Browns in Cleveland Sunday. Gifford, his right knee heavily taped, participated in the Giants' ninety-minute workout at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
