AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A former heavyweight champion, Ezzard Charles, was ordered indefinitely suspended today because of his "poor showing" in a Monday night bout at Dallas.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 30 -- Bob Reifsnyder and John Kanuch were working with the first team today as Navy went at its chores with bursting enthusiasm in preparation for Saturday's football game with Notre Dame in the Baltimore Stadium.
The demands of some foreign governments for a larger share of oil profits are threatening the world's oil supply, P. C. Spencer, chairman of the Sinclair Oil Corporation said yesterday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- The mass protest against identity cards for Negro women erupted into another clash with the police today.
Thomas C. Dillon has been named head of marketing, research and media at Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., effective Jan. 1.

Prices of stocks moved upward strongly for ninety minutes yesterday. Then they fell slowly in an irregular manner. At the close important gains sat uneasily beside important losses. The New York Times combined average registered a small advance.

Hogan (Kid) Bassey, a stubby featherweight who from a distance looks scarcely larger than a midget wrestler, will be featured in a non-title televised ten-rounder against Carmelo Costa tonight at Madison Square Garden.

CAIRO, Oct. 30 -- Newspapers here reported today under large headlines that Israel was mobilizing and was concentrating troops in the vicinity of Jerusalem and Beersheba, on the Jordanian border. One report said the mobilization had been under way for forty-eight hours.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The President of the General Assembly, who consulted a representative of the Algerian rebel government Tuesday, conferred with the head of the French delegation yesterday and today.

The Grantland Rice Fellowship in Journalism for 1958 has been awarded to Robert F. Fachet of Elizabeth, N. J. The announcement was made jointly yesterday by the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and the New York Community Trust.

The New York Central Railroad had to combine its famed Twentieth Century Limited with its Commodore Vanderbilt last spring because it couldn't get enough people to ride the two trains. But out in the West some railroad lines are reporting their best passenger traffic in years.

Construction of the Henry W. Luce Chapel at Tunghai University, Taichung, Taiwan, will begin Nov. 15. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of the United Board for Christian Higher Education, announced yesterday that a grant of $100,000 from the Henry Luce Foundation would make it possible.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- John Diefenbaker, Prime Minister of Canada, arrived today on the first leg of a tour of British Commonwealth countries aimed at bringing economic benefits to all of them through increased trade.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 30 -- President Arturo Frondizi of Argentina called on Latin-American countries today to hasten their economic development by joining forces in an independent regional bloc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above the level of a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The Soviet bloc complained today that the International Atomic Energy Agency was busying itself excessively with parleys and planning and not giving enough practical help to economically backward countries.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The advance in the stock market slowed down today. But gains continued to predominate, particularly among the industrials.

NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Bobby Gene Smith, normally a light-hitting outfielder, slammed a homer, two doubles and a single in four times at bat and led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-2 victory over the Japanese All-Stars today.

The New York Times announced yesterday that it would suspend publication if the New York Newspaper Guild called a strike against another paper and if any craft union refused to work at the struck paper.

" The Spirit of 'Seventy-Six: The Story of the American Revolution," edited by Henry Steele Commager and Richard B. Morris, will be published Monday by Bobbs-Merrill. The two-volume work brings together more than 1,000 pieces of eyewitness writing.

A hand holding a torch is not the same as a hand holding an olive branch; in fact, any confusion between such hands is a fighting matter in the world of socialism. The Board of Elections was so apprised yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson accused President Eisenhower tonight of having used "scare words" in an attempt to purge Congressional Democrats.
Thomas Schippers, taking over the baton from Leonard Bernstein, conducted his first preview concert with the New York Philharmonic last night in Carnegie Hall.

Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in operating revenues for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30. But it said operating revenues for the twelve months ended Sept. 30 had increased slightly over those of the previous year.

During his freshman year in The Yard, which was not long ago, a one-time Harvard student remembers having been awakened occasionally by the singing of upperclassmen returning to their houses along the banks of the Charles River.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The International Association of Machinists today rejected what Trans World Airlines called its final contract offer. The union said its system-wide strike against T. W. A. would start at 11:59 P. M. tomorrow.
In an effort to slow down the Cleveland Browns' speedy runner, Jim Brown, the New York Giants on Sunday will employ a special "cop."

Genes work in teams, and so, it seems, do those who study them. The three United States geneticists honored yesterday with a Nobel Prize have paired off in a number of combinations in their attacks on the problems of heredity.
ANYONE interested in the story of the worm that turns is hereby directed to the Coronet Theatre, where "The Man in the Dog Suit" opened last evening.

Pleasure - boat skippers in Dixie like to think their Gulf Intracoastal Waterway is America's last all but unexplored yachting frontier. Known as it is and enjoyed by the Floridians, Alabamians, Mississippians, Louisianians and Texans, they can't keep it a secret thrill much longer.

The eve of All Hallows is but the domesticated wraith of medieval and pagan superstitions from which, to speak forthrightly, science has set us free. Almost daily now the International Geophysical Year reports bolder invasions of nature's secrets.

Fred C. Hill, realty investor, has purchased the property at 1395 Second Avenue and 232 East Seventy-third Street, the southwest corner, from Harry Horowitz, who acquired it recently. The parcel consists of two five-story apartment buildings, one of which contains an A. P. market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- William M. Holaday, the Pentagon's Director of Guided Missiles, received a key assignment today in resolving civilian and military disputes over the nation's space development program.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored in every period tonight and defeated the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1. The victors gained sole possession of third place in the National Hockey League race. They had lost two games in a row. The Rangers fell to fourth place.
Washington Square Park was closed yesterday to all traffic except buses and emergency equipment. The thirty-day test began smoothly, with only an occasional driver whistled to a stop.
Invisible radioactivity is raining again upon many cities of the world. But it's nothing to worry about, spokesmen of the A. E. C. declare.
" WORD FROM A SEALED-OFF BOX," the autobiographical story of Henriette Roosenburg, was turned into an awkward and third-rate melodrama last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.

Mark a melancholy milestone for jazz enthusiasts: the Commodore Music Shop closes its doors today on Forty-second Street. The blues were in the air and the record shelves were bare last night at the renowed center for jazz musicians and disk collectors.
Nelson A. Rockefeller attacked Governor Harriman yesterday for his statements about the 15-cent transit fare in New York City and about rent control.
An offering of $9,000,000 of Grace Line, Inc., 4.20 per cent, Merchant Marine bonds, S. S. Santa Paula series, due in 1978, is being made today at par.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The General Assembly accused South Africa today of having broken its pledge under the United Nations Charter by espousing segregation.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Negroes attacking bus segregation in Birmingham were denied permission today to amend a Federal Court suit on the subject.
Behind-the-scenes activity is nearing a climactic pace as the big department stores complete their preparations for holiday displays.
Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz granted permission yesterday to the Kings County grand jury investigating the misuse of welfare funds to look into the housing of relief recipients.
Led by Clarence Scott, Automotive High won the team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Torakichi (Pete) Nakamura, burly 42-year-old Canada cup co-champion, tied a course record by shooting 69 on the final round today to win the Japan open golf championship for the third time.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Two disqualification rulings issued today shuffled standings of the Hayward Trophy Western Hemisphere snipe championships and left the United States champion, Terry Whittemore, in the lead.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- A renewed effort to break the deadlock over the project for a European free trade area was decided upon tonight by representatives of the seventeen nations involved.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged John A. Latimer, a New York stock broker, and Hyman Marcus, chairman of the United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation and of the Artloom Carpet Company, with violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
Columbia University's 1958 Maria Moors Cabot gold medals for the "advancement of international friendship in the Americas" will be presented Wednesday to four Latin-American news men.
From all the rave notices that Bill Austin has been receiving -- and they are richly deserved -- one might get the idea that he's the entire Rutgers football team.

Dull trading again prevailed on the New York Commodity exchanges yesterday. Copper, tin, lead, hides, cocoa, wool and rubber prices rose slightly, while burlap, cottonseed oil, and coffee fell and zinc and sugar price movements were mixed.
LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A London subway train roared happily along the Piccadilly line today, past station after station, with seventy excited passengers beating frantically at the locked doors.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson told a Democratic campaign rally today the United States had faced mounting crises at home and abroad during the six years of the Eisenhower Administration.

A former broker was convicted yesterday in connection with the fraudulent sale of $300,000 worth of stock in the Monarch Radio and Television Corporation, now defunct. Two other persons were acquitted.

TRENTON, Oct. 30 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican, and Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat, have entered the campaign's home stretch on their way to a photo-finish in the race for United States Senator from New Jersey.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The state police tonight seized the eighth person in two days in a football bet-card investigation. Another college was involved in the clean-up.

BUFFALO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Joseph F. Carlino, Republican majority leader in the Assembly, accused the Democrats today of urging Italian-Americans to vote Democratic because there was an Italian name on the ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Sidewinder, an air-to-air missile whose effectiveness was noted in the Quemoy crisis, will be distributed to the United States' allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Two fire-prevention laws were signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. They completed the package of eight sponsored by the city administration in a program to reduce factory fires.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- J. Wolcott Brown of Sea Girt, N. J., fired a two-over-par 75 today and increased his lead to five strokes after two rounds of the 54-hole Southern senior golf championship.
Representative Kenneth B. Keating, said yesterday that he would propose the establishment of a new Federal department to deal with problems in urban and suburban areas.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 30 -- The local government of Quemoy, Nationalist island bastion off the Chinese mainland, disclosed today that ninety-nine civilians had been killed by Chinese Communist shelling between Aug. 23 and Oct. 26.
One of four children who had been playing with matches died and nine other persons were injured yesterday in a two-alarm fire at 160 Mott Street on the lower East Side.
In seeking to make up their minds on Election Day many people no doubt wish they personally knew candidates better and knew what to expect of them in key positions of governmental responsibility.
Two new films will open at first-run theatres today.

The Port of New York Authority said yesterday that it would seek competitive bids on Nov. 12 for $25,000,000 of consolidated bonds, maturing from 1959 to 1978. Proceeds will be used primarily for capital expenditures at LaGuardia and New York International (Idle-wild) Airports.

OPERATION INFERNO, a singular marine enterprise has evoked alarms in New York Harbor since last May. Seamen, housewives, fliers and fishermen have called the Coast Guard and municipal departments in high distress to report vessels ablaze in the shallows in the Lower Bay between Staten Island and Sandy Hook, but in each case it was just great mounds of wood burning, mostly old New York piers.
Seldom do the voters in a Congressional district have as unique an opportunity to choose between two well-qualified men as exists today in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District.

Average net free reserves of member banks declined $130,000,000 to $116,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Net reserves are excess reserves less borrowings.
The Grand Central Art Galleries, a cultural oasis on the sixth floor of Grand Central Terminal for the last thirty-six years, will be moved to the Biltmore Hotel about March 1.

Bethlehem Steel Corporation's shipyard at Sparrows Point, Md., has been awarded a $36,388,000 contract for the construction of four ships, Clarence G. Morse, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, announced yesterday.

Studies of how genes control led the chemical processes that take place in living organisms from bacteria to man won the 1958 Nobel Prize in Medicine and Physiology for three United States scientists.

A letter from the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission to Governor Meyner and the New Jersey Legislature asks for a "cessation of visionary debate and an immediate facing up to the stark realities" of the crisis over rapid transit between Jersey and New York City.
LIKE any husband shopping alone for his wife, Albergo Fabiani of Rome is slightly nervous. When he recites the articles on his wife's list, his voice drops and his shoulders twitch.
John T. McManus, Independent-Socialist party candidate for Governor, predicted last night that his party would receive a minimum of 55,000 votes on Election Day and possibly as many as 200,000.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Dr. Galo Plaza Lasso, head of the United Nations observer group here, said today he considered the work of his 400-man mission in Lebanon complete. He said he hoped to arrange for the group's withdrawal as soon as possible.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- The junior class at Taft School is outstanding athletically and academically. Juniors dominate the various squads and the Big Red figures to be stronger in all sports next year.

ROYALTY is invariably the subject of legend. About Frederika, Queen of the Hellenes -- who yesterday, on the tenth day of an unofficial visit here, took a walk on Fifth Avenue and did some shopping -- there have grown up a number of revealing anecdotes.

Hospital Week of the United Hospital Fund's seventy-ninth annual campaign opened yesterday in the sunshine and shadow of the Rockefeller Center skating pond. The goal has been set at $3,000,000 for eighty-one member voluntary hospitals.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A sharp increase in radioactivity over southern California today set off a wave of indignation and apprehension.
Governor Harriman was urged yesterday to call an immediate conference to discuss ways of bringing "some semblance of order out of chaos" in the metropolitan area's railroad commuting.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 30 -- This was the third day of hard, steady, cold rain in this region and it may be reported on good authority that three days of rain do not manufacture the best conditions for deer hunting.

As a Democrat, it's obvious I'm biased in favor of my party's candidate for the Senate, Harrison A. Williams, in New Jersey. However, in espousing Willians I would like to state my cause objectively, substituting logic and reason for party loyalty.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Col. Louis L. Leibel has been relieved as commander at MacDill Air Force Base "pending completion of an investigation into accusations against him," his superior officer said today.

RARELY have New Yorkers been afforded such enchanting views of Manhattan as are to be found by gazing down from the recently opened Top of the Six's restaurant at 666 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets.
To prove a point, Coach Buff Donelli of Columbia took off his coat and stood on a scale before the weekly football writers luncheon got under way yesterday at John Jay Hall.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 30, General Mohammed Ayub Khan, Pakistan's new chief of state, said today that he had turned President Iskander Mirza out of office because the armed services and the people demanded a clean break with the past.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 30 -- Venezuela's three chief political parties agreed today to present their own nominees for the Presidential election and to abandon the idea of a "unity" candidate.

In these days when private citizens find it increasingly difficult to receive prompt and courteous attention from officials of the governments they have elected, it is a pleasure to be able to report on a striking exception to this trend.

THE Metropolitan presented Verdi's "Rigoletto" last night as the third opera of its new season. The production was the one designed by Eugene Berman in the fall of 1951 and most of its elements were familiar.
Many socially prominent persons atteded a theatre party last night for the benefit of Boys Harbor at the performance of "Patate" at Henry Miller's Theatre.

For nearly eighteen years the emblem of the United Service Organizations has been familiar to Americans everywhere. The U. S. O. is a voluntary civilian organization through which the American people serve the religious, spiritual, social, welfare and educational needs of the Armed Forces.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The City Board of Education voted 4-1 tonight to reinstate Mayor Vincent A. Corsall tomorrow as a science teacher as Oswego High School. He will get full back pay.
NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Billum took the lead three furlongs from the finish today and won the seven-furlong Dewhurst Stakes, the last big horse race of the British season for 2-year-olds.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet Union insisted today that the Geneva conference on banning tests of nuclear weapons opening tomorrow, "must" lead to an agreement outlawing tests forever.

A dispatch from Stockholm in yesterday's editions of The New York Times reported that prior to Boris Pasternak's refusal to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature only two other Nobel awards had been refused. There have been three refusals other than Mr. Pasternak's.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will collect blood today for the second of two days at Time, Inc., 9 Rockefeller Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- State Department officials said today that the United States would be willing to take part, as an observer, in any conference on the future of Cyprus organized by the North Atlantic Treaty Council.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Elizabeth Taylor will make her next movie appearance in another Tennessee Williams drama, "Suddenly Last Summer."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 674,264 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

HONG KONG, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Gen. Yang Yung, Chinese Communist Army leader, said today his troops home from Korea were ready to fight for the "liberation" of Taiwan and the other Nationalist-held islands, the Hsinhua (New China) News Agency reported from Peiping.

The second smallest bird in the world had to be held by two grown men yesterday when it received a pedicure at the Bronx Zoo. A vervain hummingbird, weighing less than an ounce and measuring about three inches from beak to tip of one-inch tail feathers, had its eight nails clipped in a tense operation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Aviation sources today identified a Canadian as the airline pilot who had revealed under hypnosis that he was to blame for a 1954 major crash because he did not understand his instruments.

Directors of the American Home Products Corporation have voted the regular monthly dividend of 25 cents a common share and an extra of 50 cents. Both are payable Dec. 1. So far this year the company has paid $3.30, against $2.825 in the like period of last year.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 30 -- All over Indiana, a Midwestern citadel of conservative Republicanism, voters are raising hob with the Republican party.

Your editorial stressing the need to revive the court reform issue prior to the next session of the Legislature and the letter of Edmund T. Delaney of Oct. 23 suggesting that our legislative candidates stand up to be counted on the issue during the current campaign are well taken.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty operators, have contracted to buy the one-story taxpayer building at 1601 Bathgate Avenue in the Bronx from Benjamin and Jack Leichtung. The structure is occupied by the F. W. Woolworth Company for which it was erected twenty-five years ago.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 10 points lower yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Thirteen persons were injured slightly last night when a car struck a Fifth Avenue bus at Seventy-second Street. The bus swerved onto the sidewalk, struck one person and knocked over a lamppost.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The seventh and final volume of the history of the Army Air Forces in World War II was presented to the Air Force today by the two authors and the publisher, the University of Chicago.

Suits brought by two city school teachers to bar the use of revised mortality tables in computing their annuity allowances were scheduled by Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey yesterday for argument on Nov. 12.
The Rev. Hugh Halton, former Roman Catholic chaplain at Princeton University, will sail today on the Holland-America liner Statendam to take a post of teacher of common law at Oxford University.
MERCURY, Nev., Oct. 30 -- An atomic bomb as powerful as the one that devastated Hiroshima, Japan, in World War II was set off in a mountain tunnel today -- harmlessly.
Victor Obeck, New York University's director of athletics, would do well to open an office at the United Nations.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 31 -- Dr. Pavel A. Cherenkov, Soviet Nobel prize winner for physics, discovered the so-called Cherenkov effect eight years after the same effect had been observed and analyzed by a French scientist, according to an interview in the French newspaper Figaro published this morning.

Standard Oil Company (California) reported yesterday its net income had declined in the nine months ended Sept. 30. It showed earnings of $187,743,514 or $2.97 a share, compared with $211,765,184 or $3.35 for the 1957 period.

GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- Negotiators of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union met here today on the eve of talks on suspending tests as an indispensable step toward halting the world nuclear arms race.

LAST night at the Broadway Theatre, a troupe of French - speaking players served its piece de resistance. It was greeted with sighs and bravos. It was Gerard Philipe as Rodrigue in Pierre Corneille's timeless "Le Cid."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce estimated today that paper and board production this year would just about equal the 30,700,000 tons produced in 1957.

The award of the 1958 Nobel Prize in Medicine and Physiology to three American geneticists -- Dr. George W. Beadle of the California Institute of Technology, Dr. Edward L. Tatum of the Rockefeller Institute and Dr. Joshua Lederberg of the University of Wisconsin -- has given highly merited recognition to basic researches that have opened up new vistas in our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms of heredity.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Joseph W. Barr, a Democratic candidate for the House of Representatives, lodged a personal protest today against a campaign technique of Gov. Harold W. Handley, Republican candidate for the Senate.
BEACON, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The century-old New York Rubber Corporation plant here is not going to be closed, after all.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 30 -- A stained glass window depicting God with five great figures of the Patriarchal Period of the Old Testament will be dedicated Sunday in the Princeton University Chapel.
Governor Harriman declared his belief last night that a Roman Catholic could now be elected President.

The failure of Lieutenant General Rojas Pinilla to arouse any popular support or to find any champions in the army since his sensational return to Bogota, Colombia, is of significance in Latin America. General Rojas was forced under humiliating circumstances to appear before a subcommittee of the Colombian Senate to testify on charges of undue and illegal influence in customs affairs while he was dictator from 1953 to 1957.
A campaign to raise $5,000,000 for the construction of a five-story building to house the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross was announced here yesterday.
The Times has published two splendid letters, one by the Hon. Herbert H. Lehman and another by Prof. James L. Landis, in criticism of Times editorials in support of Nelson Rockefeller.

The only benefit performances of the 1958 National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden will be for the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House. The events will be next Wednesday evening and on the evening of Nov. 10. Tickets may be obtained at the beneficiary at 331 East Seventieth Street.
Claims for unemployment benefits rose in New York State last week, reversing a five-week decline. At the same time, applications for benefits from the newly unemployed increased.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Government was asked today to delay or modify an order that would suspend oil production Nov. 10 on Indian and Federal leases in the Aneth area of Utah. Operations there are wasting natural gas.
The city continued yesterday to set the stage for a massive drive to uncover frauds in the operation of private nursing homes.

The annual dinner dance of the Society of Mayflower Descendants was held in the Terrace Room of the Plaza last night. Proceeds from the fete will augment the society's American History Scholarship Fund.

TUNIS, Oct. 30 -- President Habib Bourguiba paid tribute today to Gen. Charles de Gaulle. He said he was "saddened" by the Algerian rebel government's rejection of the French Pre mier's offer of truce negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown.
Paul T. O'Keefe, who was recently appointed Deputy Mayor, was sworn in by Mayor Wagner at City Hall yesterday. About 250 of Mr. O'Keefe's friends attended the ceremony.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A Federal District Court told the state today that it could take over immediately the land on the Tuscarora Reservation needed for the Niagara power project.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The police opened fire on rioting mobs in the center of Sao Paulo tonight, killing five persons and wounding dozens of others.
Governor Harriman was told yesterday that the income of New York families had gone up 58 per cent from 1949 to 1956.
Frank S. Hogan accused the Republican Administration last night of doing nothing to stop the spread of world-wide communism.
Alfred E. Daff has resigned, effective tomorrow, as executive vice president and a member of the board of Universal Pictures.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A new Federal law designed to save the lives of children who become trapped in refrigerators went into effect today.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 30 -- Virginia's public school teachers and administrators called today, in an overwhelming vote, for a special session of the Legislature to keep public schools open.

The Embassy Ball was held last night in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom, which was decorated with blue and white, the national colors of Greece, and classic Greek art. The children's fund of King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece and the Children's Asthma Research Institute of Denver will benefit from the fete.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A Post Office Department attempt to keep the November issue of Playboy magazine out of the mails collapsed in Federal Court today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Justice filed suit today to require Anheuser-Busch, Inc., of St. Louis, to dispose of a Miami brewery it acquired last February.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd cautioned today that the United States might withdraw from "the great responsibilities" it had undertaken in the Far East if it yielded to force in the Taiwan Strait dispute.
ATOMIC TEST SITE, Nev., Oct. 30 -- The United States failed tonight in an eleventh-hour attempt to complete its current nuclear test series with a giant balloon shot.
The police, in a series of narcotics raids arrested 116 persons, including men, women and one boy, Wednesday and early yesterday in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A Government motion for a temporary injunction against du Pont de Nemours Co., and General Motors Corporation was taken under advisement today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A spokesman for the Radio Corporation of America said today that the money it had spent for the development and promotion of color television was a "sound investment," which it expected to recover.

ORAN, Algeria, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Two 105-mm. artillery shells, rigged as time bombs exploded in a crowded downtown street in the western Algerian town of Tiaret today. Nine persons were killed and twenty-six others injured in Algeria's worst individual act of terrorism this year.

Tickets are still available for the Citizens Housing and Planning Committee's theatre benefit at the Nov. 13 performance of "The Marriage-Go-Round." Charles Boyer and Claudette Colbert are starring in the new play at the Plymouth Theatre.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Government rested its case today in the general court-martial of an Army officer charged in connection with alleged abuses of trainees at this infantry training base.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Treasury announced two policy changes today to make it easier for taxpayers to get help in arguing income tax disputes with the Internal Revenue Service.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 30 -- Both Congress and the Cabinet are taking immediate steps to stop abuse of the Costa Rican flag by foreign shipowners.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 -- "I'll believe those horses are here when I see them get off the plane. I've got my fingers crossed until then." Thus spoke Joe Cascarella, executive vice president of the Maryland State Fair, Inc., today.
The Waterfront Commission suffered its first major defeat yesterday after a five-year run of court successes.
Leading world figures, including Dr. Albert Schweitzer, Trygve Lie, Dr. Martin Niemoeller, Bertrand Russell and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, appealed yesterday for an ending of nuclear weapons tests.
Protestant churchgoers were called upon last night to put aside provincialism in favor of "a new Reformation."

Lumber production last week was 13.4 per cent above the level of a year ago, according to reports to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 6.3 per cent and orders up 6.2 per cent.
The Transit Authority went to the public yesterday in an effort to find a remedy for congestion on the IND subway in Queens.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Jack Narz, who was the host on the "Dotto" quiz series when it was canceled suddenly last August, returns to the air Monday as host of "Top Dollar.'' He will succeed Warren Hull.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 30 -- Suffolk County's tentative budget for 1959, calling for a $3,127,308 increase over the current year, was filed here today with the Board of Supervisors.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 30 -- A leaflet circulated in Nicosia tonight contained a hint that the E. O. K. A., the Greek Cypriote terrorist organization, might welcome a truce, provided the security forces first gave up their anti-terrorist operations and the British Government accepted the Greeks' claims.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today was asked to declare that newspaper reporters have a constitutional right to refuse to reveal news sources.
BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Three goals in a ninety-one-second span in the first period tonight carried the Boston Bruins to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

A brokerage firm that guaranteed to repurchase at a higher price stocks it sold to its customers was ordered out of business temporarily yesterday. The State Attorney General's office said it had repurchased so much stock it was $600,000 in the hole.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Union and management officials signed three-year contracts today giving 4,000 workmen at two atomic plants a 10-cent hourly wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Air Force blamed the crew of a commercial plane tonight for the near miss Monday night between an Air Force refueling tanker and a Panagra airliner near Wilmington, N. C.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that if the Federal Government had infringed on states' rights it was generally "only when the states themselves have failed to meet the needs of the people."
Six of the seven starters in the $7,500 Bridgeport at Jamaica yesterday hit the head of the stretch on even terms, each with a good chance to win in the final furlong.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Corn and oats added further small gains today on the Board of Trade. But soybeans and other grains ran out of buyer support and finished slightly lower.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An explosion ripped through a three-story brick factory building here today. Four men were killed and nine others hurt. Waves of toxic smoke poured from shattered windows.

On Nov. 4 the voters of the Seventeenth Congressional District in mid-Manhattan, sometimes referred to as the Silk Stocking District, will choose a new Congressman in one of the most critical races of the day.
Waves from the huge underground atomic explosion in Nevada were picked up yesterday in widespread recordings that might offer a key to a future system of international atomic control.
In an unusual decision a State Supreme Court Justice has enjoined a man from marrying again.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 -- A successful blood test for the detection of cancer in human beings was reported today by a research scientist. He said that he had withheld the report for two years awaiting other research confirmation.

SEATTLE, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Communist China is using the free port of Singapore as a focal point for its cut-rate drive to capture the important southeast Asian textile market from Japan and India, it was charged here today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Gannett Company, owner of the Gannett newspapers, announced today the sale of its 51 per cent interest in the Northern New York Publishing Company to Franklin R. Little of Ogdensburg, the present publisher, for $375,000.
ROME, Oct. 30 -- Pietro Nenni offered tonight to withdraw as leader of the Italian left-wing Socialists because of the reluctance of the party machine to free itself from Communist control.
METROPOLIS, Ill., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Allied Chemical Corporation has begun full-scale production of liquid fluorine, a high energy oxidizer for rocket fuels, at its new facilities here.
In the small but lustrous world of lute music, Julian Bream, who made his American debut last night in Town Hall, must be counted an important figure.

Dollar sales of The American Tobacco Company and its subsidiaries in the third quarter amounted to $292,039,000, compared with $290,290,000 for the comparable period of 1957. The Company makes Lucky Strike and other cigarettes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The chairman of Americans for Democratic Action said today that the "crassness" of the Republican Congressional campaign deserved a resounding repudiation at the polls.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Irving Brown, European representative of American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organization, issued a statement tonight backing the French Government's Algerian policy.
JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30 -- Four bicycles and a hundred other awards will be distributed here tomorrow night in a teen-age telephone quiz designed to reduce Halloween hooliganism.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 -- The Indian Government is believed to be firmly opposed to the maintenance of the same level of fares between jet and conventional piston-engine aircraft
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Political followers of Premier Charles de Gaulle swung today toward the center position desired by their leader and away from a projected alliance with Right-wing forces.
ROME, Oct. 30 -- Pope John XXIII took the reins of the Vatican in his hands today. He also assumed possession of his official apartment on the second floor of the Vatican Palace.

The Army Signal Corps has awarded a $3,858,970 contract to International Business Machines for the development of two electronic "brains" that will be able to add 30,000 ten-digit numbers a second in the heat of battle.
Another ad agency spokesman has added his voice to the growing number who recently have suggested a revision of the traditional 15 per cent commission method of agency compensation.
Your editorial of Oct. 27 concerning the Brooklyn Congressional races has left me somewhat confused.

Twenty thousand garment workers blocked Seventh Avenue between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Streets from noon until 1 P. M. yesterday to cheer the Democratic-Liberal state candidates. Hogan got the Democratic nomination, the Liberal endorsement followed.
The Union Pacific Railroad's profits climbed nearly $1,000,000 last month. It was the railroad's first year-to-year gain for any month this year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The second short course for transportation executives given by the Transportation Center at Northwestern University will graduate thirteen executives of transportation companies and transportation officers tomorrow.
SPRINGHILL, N. S., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Spurred by the rescue of twelve miners after hope was virtually lost, tired teams dug through the rubble of a wrecked coal mine today seeking more survivors.
HARTFORD, Oct. 30 -- The results of the Connecticut election hinge on the voting strength of Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat, who is seeking his second term.

" SO we won the game, 7 to 0," said Rip Miller, gleefully rubbing his hands. Whoa! This was a confusing statement. It had to be. There could be no mistaking the fact that the burly Ripper was discussing a Navy-Notre Dame game but an aura of vagueness surrounded the "we." This was understandable.

Tikhon N. Khrennikov, general secretary of the Union of Soviet Composers, has sent a cablegram to Herman D. Kenin, president of the American Federation of Musicians, expressing pleasure at the successful concert of the works of four American composers at Tchaikovsky Hall in Moscow on Oct. 15.

Business loans outstanding at the larger New York City banks increased $11,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yes terday. This compared with a decline of $22,000,000 in the similar week a year earlier.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The United States will press for priority consideration before the United Nations of its own plan for a suspension of nuclear arms tests, it was announced here tonight.

The Soviets have done their best to destroy any lingering hope that the conference on suspending nuclear tests, which is scheduled to open at Geneva today, will succeed. Yesterday they announced that the offers made by the United States and Britain to stop the tests for one year, beginning tonight, were "utterly unacceptable."
DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Special scrolls were given today to five women for public service.
A protege of Senator Jacob K. Javits hopes to follow in his mentor's footsteps, admittedly against heavy odds, in uptown Manhattan's Twenty-first Congressional District.
A one-story taxpayer building on plot 75 by 120 feet at 1408 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Elle J. Jay Realty Company, Sol Goldman, president.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Controversy arising from a California ballot measure calling for an end to tax exemption for parochial and private schools reached a peak today. Two bishops issued strong statements.

The Day Treatment Center and School for Emotionally Disturbed Children of the Godmothers League, Inc., will benefit from a theatre party to be held by the "Black and White," committee, an affiliate of Godmothers League, at the performance Tuesday of "The Marriage - Go - Round" at the Plymouth Theatre.
SHELBY, N. C., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A banker and his storekeeper friend drew five-year terms today for a $325,000 embezzlement.

MARK ROTHKO, the 55-year-old painter whose luminous abstractions have been the subject of extensive discussions both here and in Europe, has publicly defined his artistic position. In a recent lecture at Pratt Institute, Rothko firmly dissociated himself from any movement and, above all, from the "abstract expressionist" movement.
The largest flower gardens in America will be planted on 125 landscaped acres in the midst of natural woodlands in the Sterling Forest community near Tuxedo, N. Y.
POPCORN that goes into the popper now is vastly improved over that available even a few years ago. The quality of the corn is better because of cross-breeding.
ONE solution for those who cannot afford to buy antiques is to make their own reproductions.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Jim Cassia, Leewood assistant, and Irving Sheib, Harrison, won on a match of cards after finishing in a tie for first in the final pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association season at the Scarsdale Golf Club today.
Textron, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to purchase the American Screw Company for $5,897,600 and to assume all of the latter's liabilities.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Boris Pasternak chose silence today.
Net income of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the third quarter dipped below that of the previous three months and failed to cover the common dividend.
LIGHTING devices that double as sculpture are the latest innovation of Jason Harvey, a designer who seems to keep a jump ahead of furnishings trends.
The State Banking Department has ordered the National Endorsement Corporation, 527 Madison Avenue, to show cause why its license as a sales finance company should not be revoked.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 30 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon made a final swing through the farm belt today to help restore the solid Republican front in two states where the Democrats broke through in 1956.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The National Methodist Conference of Industrial Relations heard a university dean and labor arbitrator declare today that passage or nonpassage of a "right-to-work" law was a political victory for management or labor, but nothing more.
NEWARK, Oct. 31 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr. made his final appeal today for the support of voters in Essex County.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The State Department said today that Nationalist China had the right to use military force in support of any "large-scale uprising" against the Communists on the mainland.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Soviet and United States scientific representatives signed an agreement in Moscow today on the exchange of certain scientific information, the Soviet agency Tass reported.

The state of disorganization into which this over-organized civilization of ours is falling shows itself in little as well as in big ways. Frequently the little ways strike more closely home than the big ones.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle ordered today the release of 1,000 Algerians held in administrative detention in camps in Algeria.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Large increases in United States production of aluminum and bituminous coal were forecast today for 1959 by experts in the industries.
Columbia closes its home football schedule in the game with Cornell, Ivy League leaders, at Baker Field this afternoon. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M.

Frederick Brown, realty operator, has resold the former Misericordia Hospital building at 531 East Eighty-sixth Street near Carl Schurz Park to I. Orlian and A. E. Orlian and Associates, builders. Mr. Brown said the buyers would erect a tall apartment house on the site.
" Here we go again" was the brief summary on the business outlook that the F. W. Dodge Corporation issued as a result of a survey of economists' opinions. Some respondents offered technical analyses.

James M. Power, chairman of the Board of Elections, conceded yesterday that the board had inadvertently erred in identifying the candidates of the Independent-Socialist party in political advertising. He said the advertising would be rerun.
Intercollegiate football's elect find themselves in jeopardy with few exceptions today as the season passes the half way mark.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Makers of cotton clothing have complained to the Department of Commerce that they are being hurt by imports from Japan and increasing competition from Hong Kong.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 31 -- Paraguay's halting steps toward political tolerance were at a dead stop today. A relapse toward harsh measures was feared by the Opposition.
GYORGY CZIFFRA, Hungarian pianist who escaped from his native country during the uprising of 1956, made his New York debut with the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.
H. K. Porter Company, Inc., announced yesterday it would merge with the Thermoid Company under a plan which would make Porter the surviving company.

THE Metropolitan presented Verdi's "Rigoletto" Thursday night as the third opera of its new season. The production was the one designed by Eugene Berman in the fall of 1951 and most of its elements were familiar.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Eighteen years have passed since a Democrat was elected to the House of Representatives in Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District, Representative Albert P. Morano, the Republican incumbent seeking his fifth term, is confident that the record will not be broken on Tuesday.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Princeton's Ivy League hopes will be at stake tomorrow when a resurgent Brown team visits Palmer Stadium.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Home Secretary R. A. Butler outlined to the House of Commons today a far-reaching penal reform program designed to cope with Britain's "very disturbing" rise in crime.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Most sections of the stock market advanced today. The undertone was firm but the rush to buy died down a little.
Installment buyers were warned yesterday to avoid careless buying practices that might cause needless expenditure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The International Association of Machinists today postponed a scheduled midnight strike of mechanics on Trans World Airlines but set a walkout for Monday on Eastern Airlines.

THURSDAY night at the Broadway Theatre, a troupe of French-speaking players served its piece de resistance. It was greeted with sighs and bravos. It was Gerard Philipe as Rodrigue in Pierre Corneille's timeless "Le Cid."
The "suspicious conduct" of some city employes is under investigation by the city in its search for frauds in the operation of private nursing homes.

THE President of the United States, the Senator said, was "a man of weak mind and inordinate vanity who thought himself a great man and a statesman as he played his fantastic tricks before high Heaven."

The coronation Tuesday of Pope John XXIII as televised to Europe will be shown in part the National Broadcasting Company network the same day.
OTTAWA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The United States has a new invitation to join the British Commonwealth -- from the husband of Queen Elizabeth II.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Commonwealth Edison Company's kilowatt-hour sales of electricity fell 1 per cent in the first nine months of 1958, Willis Gals chairman, reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The repayment of money borrowed by the United Nations to clear the Suez Canal will be delayed. The lag is due to the refusal of some governments and shipping companies to pay the 3 per cent surcharge authorized by the General Assembly last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Latin-American offee producers have reached unanimous agreement on the quantity of coffee they will export in the period ending March 31, 1959.
Activity in the new capital market next week will be moderate compared with the heavy schedule of this week.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- The Inland Steel Company's producing capacity will be 6,500,000 ingot tons in 1959, the company said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Growers of burley and flue-cured tobacco may be told to cut production next year, a tobacco expert said today.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Gen. Ne Win, new Burmese Premier, said today that his Government would make no changes in the country's foreign policy.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Koca Popovic, Yugoslav Foreign Minister, showed impatience today with the slowness of the Western powers in responding to his country's requests for loans.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 31 -- A group of ten United States Marine Corps specialists have arrived here from Charleston, S. C., to implement an agreement for assistance in reorganizing Haiti's armed forces.

Richie Guerin will be able and Willie Naulls may be able to play tonight when the New York Knickerbockers oppose the Philadelphia Warriors in a National Basketball Association contest at Madison Square Garden.
Every morning motorists are delayed for as much as twenty minutes in a heavy traffic tie-up on the Belt Parkway at the point where the three-lane portion narrows into two lanes.
WARSAW, Oct. 31 -- Poland is searching for support in the West for a newly broadened version of Warsaw's plan for a zone in Central Europe from which nuclear arms would be barred.

WANTAGH, L. I., Oct. 31 -- A kindergarten teacher costumed as a witch delighted thirty-two 5-year-old boys and girls here today at a Halloween party at the Forest Lake School. The youngsters were dressed as cowboys, cowgirls, Cinderellas, angels and devils.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The Algerian provisional government issued today what was called a "last appeal to France: Begin negotiations for peace or face a war in which the insurgents will try to get help from any outside source.
Trading in futures was unusually dull yesterday on the New York exchanges. Most of the volume involved evening of holdings for the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Court-appointed monitors of the Teamsters Union complained to United States District Judge F. Dickinson Letts today that union officials had adopted unreasonable eligibility restrictions for union office. They said the purpose was to perpetuate incumbents in office.

Burma's new Premier, is a high-spirited, gregarious soldier with a distaste for the complexities of Government politics. He proved this to himself in 1949 when U Nu, then Premier, persuaded him to join the Cabinet as Deputy Premier and Minister of Defense and Home Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today a 5 per cent fare increase in interstate coach travel on the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads. A 15 per cent increase was permitted in first-class fares.
CLOSTER, N. J., Oct. 31 -- A misunderstanding over a Halloween trick-or-treat collection for the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund was cleared up today.
Yeshiva University Women's Organization will hold a benefit at the season's premiere of "La Triavata" tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

All over the city this month New Yorkers will see the sparkling blue banner with a white cross of the United Hospital Fund. The fund, America's oldest federated charity, has for seventy-nine years raised funds to help support its member voluntry hospitals, which now number eighty-one.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren warned today that the United States tradition of equal justice for all was endangered by cumbersome backlogs of cases in Federal and state courts throughout the nation.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union offered the United States and Britain today a draft agreement for the immediate banning of nuclear weapons tests forever.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Predicting a "substantial" Democratic victory next Tuesday, Speaker Sam Rayburn said today he did not expect "bad blood" between President Eisenhower and a new Democratic Congress.

It is a rare political campaign that doesn't find a carfare issue before Election Day. The Harriman-Rockefeller campaign for Governor is no exception. Nelson A. Rockefeller, the Republican candidate, has said that he is "opposed to any increase in the subway fare." Governor Harriman, originally content with an opinion that the 15-cent fare should be "protected," has now picked up the ball with zest and is running with it.
Mayor Wagner predicted yesterday that Governor Harriman would win re-election by a "substantial" plurality.

The Jersey Central Railroad said yesterday that radar, the seeing-eye that guides ship through fog, actually contributes so much to the risk of collision in New York Harbor that the line will cease ferryboat operations in dense fogs.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 -- The 1959 car models have created some new problems for auto washers.
Alexander H. Cohen is back from London with news that he has set his production dates for the Broadway presentation of the intimate British revue "At the Drop of a Hat."
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 31 -- The demand for engineering graduates is expected to be somewhat higher next year, a University of Michigan official predicts.

The Hamilton Stainless Steel Corporation has leased 3,000 square feet of space in a building to be erected to its specifications on the Babylon Turnpike between Fulton and Frederick Streets in Roosevelt, L. I. The lease was negotiated by J. Yudell Realty, Inc., brokers, of Forest Hills, Queens, for the James C. Realty Corporation, which will construct the building.
HOW to make the best use of the freezer compartment of a combination refrigerator-freezer is a question several readers have asked to have answered.

ROME, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The guiding council of the Food and Agriculture Organization agreed today that there was urgent need to coordinate national price support policies to combat increasing agricultural surpluses.
ROME, Oct. 31 -- Pope John XXIII started today the routine of work he will probably follow for the rest of his pontificate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- One of this week's patents explains why the clocks in new automobiles keep good time. When a car owner turns the hands a few minutes back or ahead he is not only setting but regulating his clock.
The tenth annual Religion in American Life campaign, designed to urge all Americans to attend regularly the church or synagogue of their choice, will begin today and continue through the month.

One of the last remaining undeveloped parcels of land in the West Farms area of the Bronx has been sold by Nathaniel D. Gribin, realty investor, to investing clients of Benjamin D. Lichtenstein, attorney.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Dr. Joseph V. Charyk, an aeronautical engineer and chief of space activities for a Ford Motor Company subsidiary, today was named chief scientist of the Air Force.

International diplomacy between two zoos that could serve as a model to state departments has brought to the Bronx Zoo two African flamingos. It is believed that they had never been seen before in this country.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- The home of A. Hunter Bowman, a New York banker, in tile Oenoke Ridge section burned practically to the ground early this morning. CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- There were a few scattered narrow gains in the grain futures market today. But the market tipped more to weakness in draggy dealings on the Board of Trade.
The Texas Company reported yesterday that it had a consolidated net income of $89,157,180, or a $1.53 a share in the third quarter of 1958.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- In the autumn of 1957, when the cold war balance was suddenly upset by Russia's sputnik, NATO decided to restore the Western position by convening a summit meeting of the alliance's governmental chiefs.

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- The Moscow section of the Soviet Union of Writers has petitioned the Government to strip "the traitor Pasternak" of his citizenship and expel him from the country. This formal action, taken today, was the second step in what appeared to be a determined campaign designed at the least to drive Boris L. Pasternak from his native soil.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- The Public Service Commission today approved increases in coach and first-class fares for intrastate travel on the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads. Commuter fares were not affected.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Britain blamed Greece tonight for the failure of the North Atlantic Treaty Council to arrange a conference on Cyprus.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- A Government report from India today showed that at the close of its third fiscal year, the first penicillin plant in Asia had returned a net profit of $600,000. This was an earnings ratio of 15 to 20 per cent, after payment of capital charges and other deductions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave National Airlines conditional authority today to start the nation's first domestic commercial jet service, between New York and Florida, on Dee. 10.

The annual Metropolitan Bridge Championships started yesterday at the Statler-Hilton Hotel with 104 pairs entered in the one-session men's pairs championship and sixty-six pairs in the women's pairs championship.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 31 -- The Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in northern Westchester became the preferred site today for the county's long-proposed sportsmen's center. An advisory committee of county officials and the heads of sportsmen's associations previously had chosen George's Island on the Hudson River at Cortlandt.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Representative Robert W. Kean, Republican candidate for Senator, told a Camden County rally today that he would oppose any legislation permitting the Federal Government to witthhold Philadelphia city wage taxes from nonresident Federal employes.
A speed hammer called a wood hogger, which can smash large timbers into three-inch chips and dump them into a municipal incinerator, will begin operations here next fall.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 31 -- The weather turned bright and fair this morning after four days of steady rain, but by 10 o'clock the clouds were back and everything was gloomy. Still, a morning of hunting earned a little doe.

THE name of Adelaide Milton de Groot is well known to visitors to the Metropolitan Museum, where her remarkable collection of contemporary painting is frequently on loan. The League for Cardiac Children is sponsoring a dinner dance on Nov. 22 in the Sheraton-East.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Sales of wholesalers increased 5 per cent in September and exceeded sales a year ago for the first time in fourteen months, the Department of Commerce has reported.

On Election Day, next Tuesday, the Sanitation Department will make no collection of refuse. All but a skeleton force of its 14,000 employes will be off duty.

Investors Mutual, Inc., reported yesterday record net assets of $1,217,926,124 on Sept. 30, the end of its fiscal year. The big Minneapolis mutual fund thus remained second in size to the Massuchusetts Investors Trust, which reported earlier in the week assets of $1,295,283,816 for Sept. 30.

Nelson A. Rockefeller pulled out all political stops yesterday as he concentrated his gubernatorial campaign mainly in the Democratic citadel of the Bronx. "This looks like an awfully big trick or treat," Mrs. La Guardia said when she opened the door and saw the group of reporters and photographers following Mr. Rockefeller.

Bonds called for redemption in October before maturity totaled $32,837,000, the smallest amount for any month since March, when issues amounting to $14,508,000 were retired. The total compared with $56,254,000 in September and $20,066,000 in October, 1957.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 31 -- (UPI) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture said today that facts proved that agriculture was marching forward in spite of a cost-price squeeze that he said had arisen prior to the Eisenhower Administration.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- The world's major airlines unanimously adopted a resolution today suggesting the establishment of a "collisions convention" on the rights and obligations of aircraft owners.

SOME of the varied pressures now affecting children were aired yesterday at the biennial conference of the Play Schools Association. The parley was held at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

THERE probably are as many brocade dresses in New York these days as there are in Hong Kong. Women who feel that these dresses resemble one another are directed to the third floor of De Pinna's, where a group of brocade separates look different from the usual gold and white pattern.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A record total of 6,787,266 voters are registered for Tuesday's gubernatorial election, the Department of State reported today.

The first Liberty ship ever built is on her way to oblivion, the ship news columns of this paper noted recently. This event, the reduction to scrap of the Patrick Henry, is one of those milestones that symbolize an era.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Lee MacPhail will leave his post as director of player personnel for the New York Yankees to become executive vice president of the Baltimore Orioles, it was reported on excellent authority tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Candidates for election to the first Parliament of the Fifth Republic flocked into prefectures throughout France today in an atmosphere of political ferment more intense than in any other electoral period since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Farm prices fell slightly more than 2 per cent in the month ended Oct. 15. The drop largely reflected the seasonal impact of heavy fall harvests on market prices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent 118.5 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week end last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Events today: Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera House, 2 P.M.; Puccini's "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Rossini's "Cenerentola," New York City Center, 2:30; Strauss' "Die Fledermaus," New York City Center, 8:15; Verdi's "Aida," Long Island Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30; Gounod's "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15.

He had performed before a world public, and had tried to respond as far as he could to the claims of friends and admirers for a share of his time.

THE business of traveling for pleasure, or business, and the industry that thrives in many diverse components upon travel are today jumping with excitement, joy and uncertainty. A week ago today the jet age arrived. A month ago travel on credit, previously tried in a tentative way through bank loans and limited, principally business and income-tax-deductible credit cards, broke out of these confines into the broader world of all travelers.

LOOKING back from the vantage point of age 16 to the time during World War I, when she was 13, Chris Andrews decides to write her memoirs. Mostly she relates how she and her best friend, Junie, rounded up beaux for Chris' charming sister.

With a curious combination of weather -- some heavy rain, some brisk winds and a bit of sunshine -- merchants in the New York area were able to report some cheerful news as last week advanced. They said trade for the week was up a little to as much as 5 per cent above the 1957 level.

Mingled with the leaf-litter beneath the maples is a generous sprinkling of maple keys, nature's original helicopters. Ripe and loosened with the leaves, they come spiraling down, each key's own broad vane like a wing that flips and sails it away from the parent trunk. At the base of that broad vane is a fat kernel, the seed itself, from which, if all conditions are favorable, a seedling will sprout next spring.

After the expenditure of several hundred billion francs and overcoming many political difficulties, France appears about ready to start a program through which she may may become self-sufficient in oil.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 1 -- Upsala's football team gained its first victory in five games this season by defeating the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 31 -- 12, on Tomb Field today. A crowd of 4,200 watched the Vikings play alert football and send Kings Point to its third defeat against three triumphs.
The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will hold its twenty-fourth annual Thansgiv!ing Eve dinner-dance in the iGrand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria on Nov. 26.

WHEN assembling wood joints which are glued and doweled, if the dowel is too snug to fit in the hole there will be no room for glue on the inside. To correct this, cut a groove along the length of the dowel before inserting it, or file a flat spot on one side to form a "pocket" which will let trapped air escape and will provide room for the liquid glue.

IN a recent speech before the National Association of Radio and Television News Directors in Chicago, Edward R. Murrow offered a provocative analysis of how television tends to insulate the viewer from the realities of the world.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Penn State University today entertained fifty-six high school bands and the football team from Furman University. The State football team marched almost as far as the bandsmen in rolling up a 36-0 victory.

" ONE summer Father, Chief White Elk, gave me, Little Elk, Painted Pony." So begins this Cheyenne Indian boy's story, told in pictographs -- the picture writing of the Plains Indians. Little Elk records how he went riding, and his pony, frightened by a rattlesnake, threw him and ran away.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. -- As is the case elsewhere in Florida, last winter's freezes and a below-normal summer tourist business have not discouraged an expansion of tourist facilities here. Four new motels have been completed this year and seven or eight more, with a total of 400 units, are now under construction and will be ready for winter visitors.

The current disarmament debate in the United Nations has given a poor send-off to the negotiations in Geneva between the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union on stopping nuclear test explosions. All attempts at finding a compromise having failed, the two Western powers early yesterday obtained the endorsement by the Political Committee of a General Assembly resolution upholding their position that nuclear test explosions must not be stopped permanently without effective control.

FOR more years than we can number, the words "Boy Scouts of America" have conjured up in many minds the vision of an organization as lofty and unchanging as the gilt eagle atop a flagpole.

GAINESVILLE, Fla. -- A state-run tourist attraction that has not been as widely publicized as Florida's private enterprises, yet draws from 60,000 to 70,000 visitors a year, is the Florida State Museum.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Eddie Cantor, the entertainer, said today that the move for "right-to-work" laws was a threat to majority rule. He compared it with actions that he said had destroyed freedom in Nazi Germany, Fascist Italy and the Soviet Union.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- The Federation of Rhodesia goes to the polls on Nov. 12 to elect second Parliament.

Avco Manufacturing Corporation has acquired Pre-Flite Industries Corporation of Paramount, Calif. Pre-Flite will be operated as a wholly owned subsidiary of Avco. The purchase price was not revealed. Pre-Flite makes pneumatic ground starting units for turbo-jet and turbo-prop engines and hydraulic test stands.

Better dress manufacturers have opened spring lines and have reported good buyer interest. Spring openings in coats, suits and sportswear have been scheduled for the next two weeks. Resident buyers offices have reported fall coat business gaining at retail.

NEWARK, Del., Nov. 1 -- Rutgers' football team sped to a 29 -- 6 half-time lead today and thwarted a second-half bid by Delaware to defeat the Blue Hens, 37 -- 20, and remain unbeaten. The Scarlet has won six games.

A NEW novel by Henry de Montherlant is always an event, and for many reasons. Paradoxical and perverse, Montherlant's mind is never banal. His style, at least in the original, is matchless; his penetration into human motivation commands universal, although grudging, respect.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, told President Eisenhower today that the Democratic campaign "has deteriorated" and that if the Republicans "maintain the pace of the last few days" they can capture the House of Representatives.
The Soviet Union's exports of petroleum, iron ore, grain and other raw materials set a new record last year, recently published official Soviet data reveal.

HAVANA, Nov. 1 -- A plea for a suspension of the elections next Monday in various municipalities of Oriente and Las Villas Provinces was rejected by the Superior Electoral Board of Cuba late yesterday. Violence is flaring in the five provinces as the rebels led by Fidel Castro try to disrupt the elections called by the Government of President Fulgencio Batista.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Wisconsin rolled up an early lead and fought off an inspired Michigan State comeback for a 9-7 Big Ten football victory today.

Gazzo's second play, which opened in Detroit last week prior to its projected arrival on Broadway next month, is in the process of being acquired by Columbia Pictures.

Details of a $27,000,000 Argentine shipbuilding order in West Germany were revealed here last week. The order calls for six dry-cargo motor ships for the two leading steamship lines of the South American country.

DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 1 -- Four Protestant churches here with a combined membership of 3,500 families will conduct a joint budgetary campaign next Sunday.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 1 --In keeping with the @/rchi. tecture of the new Greenville Community Church on Ardsley Road here, a colonial motif has been chosen by the Woman's Service League for its all-day housewarming fair, bazaar and auction, which will be held on Friday.

SABARA, Brazil, Oct. 30 -- When the wind of the mountain springtime blows to the west, the thick smoke of the steel mill in the valley rises to the top of the town's hill and clings to the old churches, old houses and old cobblestones of Sabara.

Corporate profits after taxes for the July-September period, were up 17 per cent over the previous quarter, the First National City Bank of New York reported today in its monthly bank letter. The results are based on reports made in October.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- A jet flagship will leave International Airport here tomorrow for New York on the first commercial jet air mail flight in the United States.
Democrats and Republicans were both preparing yesterday for an exceptionally close state election tomorrow. At the same time spokesmen for each side were predicting victory by a wide margin.

A NEW shoe store, The Shop For Pappagallo, will open today at 42 East Fiftieth Street. Despite its Italian name, this is an American concern that has long been associated with highly styled, moderately priced domestic shoes.

A referendum on bingo for New York City will appear on the ballot tomorrow as Proposition 4. If it passes, it will permit the playing of bingo for charitable and other fund-raising purposes under the local option amendment that was approved last November.
British pound sterling moved narrowly in moderate dealings in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Canadian dollar was fairly active with a steady undertone.

SPRINGHILL, N. S., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Rescue workers dug through the last 270 feet of wrecked mine shaft today in their search for men still missing in North America's deepest coal mine.

Col. Edson D. Raff, the pioneer sky soldier who led the first United States combat parachute jump in World War II, said yesterday that he had requested retirement from the Army at the end of the year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Fred Hall, former G. O. P. Governor of Kansas, today predicted the defeat of "right-to-work" proposals in five of the six states.

Six major airlines united yesterday in a novel strike-aid pact. They agreed that whenever one or more of the lines was struck the others would turn over any increased revenue they picked up as a result of the shutdown.

ATLANTA, Nov. 1 -- Negro voter registration has held steady in eleven Southern states since 1956, the Southern Regional Council reported today.
Holy Cross High routed previously unbeaten Fordham Prep, 30 -- 0, yesterday in a Catholic High School Football League contest at Memorial Field, Flushing, Queens.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Rams, sparked by the brilliant Jon Arnett, today ran up a 24-point first-half lead on the Chicago Bears and then had to struggle for a 41-35 victory before 100,470 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

OTTAWA, Oct. 31 -- The Canadian Government believes it should have an observer at hearings before the United States Federal Power Commission concerning the licensing of exports and imports of natural resources. This is the main point of the so-called Borden report issued here this week.
Carlos Montoya, the Spanish-born guitarist, gave a program of flamenco music on Saturday evening in Town Hall. Everything he played was either one of his arrangements or an original composition.

The steamship charter market last week experienced one of its largest rate index increases of the year. The gain was traced to slight increases in many commodities rather than to a real spurt in any of the mainstays of the market.

GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- The powerful, traditional Soviet opposition to the establishment of alien controls within the Soviet Union appeared tonight to be the chief barrier to conclusion of an agreement for cessation of nuclear weapons tests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- All high school and elementary school programs provided for in the four-year $900,000,000 law for aid to science education that was passed by the last Congress will be under way by Dec. 1.

On the dust jacket of "The Memoirs of Field Marshal Montgomery," which is published today, appears a signed declaration from the Marshal to the effect that every word of his book was written in his own handwriting.
The first Cardinal Spellman Youth Awards were presented to 180 teen-aged members of the Catholic Youth Organization yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SEATTLE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Officials attending the Colombo Plan Conference here said today they thought that President Eisenhower would keep clear of any discussion of United States-China policy when he addresses the eighteen-nation meeting here a week from tomorrow.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- With Stan Musial and Ken Boyer sparking a three-run drive in the seventh inning, the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Japanese All-Stars, 6 -- 1, today.

IT was only the season before last that the Metropolitan Opera restaged "La Traviata." Thus, when the Verdi opera was presented there last night, the stylish production designed by Oliver Smith and worked out by Tyrone Guthrie still looked remarkably fresh and handsome.

The accord reached by the three main political parties in Venezuela for the Presidential and Congressional elections of Dec. 7 may well prove a democratic landmark in Latin America. It was agreed that each party will run its favored candidate but that all three will afterward collaborate loyally with whoever wins and will help carry out economic and social reforms on which they are already in accord.
Army, Iowa and Louisiana State rule as the top triumvirate of intercollegiate football with the added prestige of their latest conquests.

Mrs. Betty Sheinwold of New York and her teammates won the open team-of-four bridge championship early this morning. It was the final event of the 1958 Metropolitan Contract Bridge Championships, held at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- A private study group today recommended suspension of nuclear testing for two years instead of one.

The competitors and judges in the Seventy-Fifth Anniversary National Horse Show will be guests this afternoon at a reception and cocktail party in the Waldorf-Astoria. The eight-day show will open tomorow night at Madison Square Garden.

THE National Broadcasting Company presented yesterday an illuminating examination of the exodus from East to West Germany. It was shown on "Kaleidoscope," a new television series to be offered every second Sunday over Channel 4 from 5 to 6 P. M.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- A new Right-Wing group supporting Premier Charles de Gaulle entered the electoral competition in the Paris region and a few provincial departments today. The campaign for legislative elections Nov. 23 will open tomorrow.

THE Broadway Chapel Players, under the direction of Bill Penn, began their fifth season at the Broadway Congregational Church yesterday with a revival of Graham Greene's "The Potting Shed." Since the purpose of the company is to present religious drama as a form of worship at the church's 5 P. M. Vesper services, and since Mr. Greene's concern in this play is with a latter-day miracle, the selection is apt and on the whole felicitous.
