Looking a little like the backstage of an enormous theatre opened to early morning light, Brussels' Haysel Park is the site today of a vast dismantling of scenery.
HAVANA, Nov. 2 -- Cuba is preparing for general elections tomorrow in the midst of rebel violence and intensive mobilization of government forces.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Monday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Chinese Communist guns resumed their bombardment of Quemoy today after having been silent since Saturday afternoon, a period of about thirty-eight hours.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 28 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) and its president, Eugene R. Black, have come under harsh criticism from sectors of the press and some politicians. The New York City Housing Authority will sell short-term loan notes totaling $56,422,000 this month, William Reid, chairman, said yesterday.

The men's clothing industry operated at 64 per cent of capacity in September, compared with 65 per cent in the 1957 month, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Why is it that, at this particular moment in time, so many military leaders serve as political chiefs of government? An impressive number of countries on five continents are today directed by officers.
YORK, Pa., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Robert A. Carman of Pittsburgh won the National Amateur Athletic Union senior thirty-kilometer championship run today in steady rain and 40-degree temperatures.

The head of an independent union of 4,500 newspaper drivers said yesterday that his union would not accept a two-year package wage increase of $7 a week in its negotiations with the city's publishers.

THE impact of the Italian shoe cannot be underestimated. In recent years, it has been the largest single influence on American footwear. American women traveling abroad have become entranced by the look and feel of Italian shoes and have clamored to buy them here.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Victor Romagna, totaling 229 of a possible 240 points with Scusi, won the second regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite championship season by 5 points today. Accompanied by Susie Gilbreth, 12, Romagna won one of six races.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Nearly a year after it had been proposed by President Eisenhower, the State Department is about to renew its scientific attache program dropped in 1956.
Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday is a holiday for Philip Smith Jr. On those days he is now able to roll his wheelchair into the Columbia College classrooms he could once visit only by telephone.

The United Hospital Fund's seventy-ninth annual campaign is asking New Yorkers to contribute to a basic necessity -- their own health and that of their neighbors. Five thousand volunteers will be calling on people or writing to them soon for contributions.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 2 -- Most of the countries of the world are approaching the end of a banner year in highway construction, preliminary estimates prepared by the International Road Federation indicate.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The grain futures market showed some tendency to climb out of its season's low prices last week but the rally died and by Friday almost none of it was apparent.

Space in the new office building constructed by Joseph Durst at 200 East Forty-second Street has been leased by the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Luxembourg. It will be used for consular offices and headquarters for Luxembourg's delegation to the United Nations.

IF the voters of St. Croix County in Wisconsin have the slightest bit of sense, they will elect as their sheriff John V. McNally. He will be the sort of sheriff who will strap six-shooters to his side and unflinchingly root out all miscreants in their hideouts. If necessary, he will brush aside bullets.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- Boris Pasternak, Nobel Prize-winning novelist, who is fighting to stay in the Soviet Union, is not feeling well and must take a rest, his wife said tonight.
The rear of the Judson Memorial Church, a landmark on Washington Square South, was severely damaged by fire last night, but the worship area was not affected.

LAST September Bernard Law Montgomery, a little man who sometimes gives the impression that he is made of Damascus steel, gunpowder and tabasco sauce, retired from the British Army after fifty years of continuous duty. The son of a poor, saintly and mercilessly henpecked Bishop had come a long way.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Monday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A big Swedish tanker and a smaller Norwegian motorship collided in the English Channel early today. The Norwegian ship was reported on fire and abandoned by her crew and passengers.
Events tonight: Verdi's "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Little Orchestra Society, Morton Gould, guest conductor, composer and pianist, Thomas Scherman, conductor, Town Hall, 8:30.
Two Navy balloonists plan to take a telescope to 80,000 feet in the next week or so to see if they can penetrate some of the mysteries of the planet Mars.

CARLISLE FLOYD'S "Susannah," which was one of the more successful American productions at the Brussels World's Fair last summer, was performed at the New York City Center last night for the first time this season.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- "Operation Re-expansion, the Government's anti-recession campaign, reversed last week the easier tendency that had become apparent in the stock market.

Sarah Lawrence College will enlarge its student body and incorporate study abroad as part of its curriculum. The thirty-year-old Bronxville college for women plans to alter its optional-study program to heighten individual talents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The chairman of the Democratic National Committee and the chairman of the Republican National Committee did their duty today. Each predicted victory for his party in Tuesday's Congressional elections.

Orson Welles' blank-verse adaptation of Herman Melville's "Moby Dick," which aroused considerable interest in London three years ago, may be the third bill in the forthcoming series at the Bijou Theatre.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2 -- Yale University received a record of $33,047,068 in gifts in 1957-58.
THERE is ample cause for rejoicing among New York gastronomes this autumn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Pentagon sources labeled as "moribund" today the Administration's effort to establish a unified organization for military research and engineering.

The Soviet Union's all-girl Beryozka Russian Folk Ballet arrived here yesterday for a twelve-week coast-to-coast tour of the country. There are forty-three girls in the company, which also includes a total of thirteen musicians (male accordionists and balalaika players), ballet and wardrobe mistresses, musical directors and a technical staff.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- The Algerian rebel government announced today that it would request friendly delegations here this week to work for the release of five of its cabinet members from a Paris prison.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- The Giants kicked off to the Browns today and on the first play from scrimmage the mightiest Brown of 'em all, Jimmy Brown, lost 2 yards. That should have been the tip-off on what was soon to unfold -- the most startling upset of the National Football League season.

Ralph Levy has resigned as producer of "The Garry Moore Show," which made its debut five weeks ago. He has been succeeded by Bob Banner, who is expected to make major changes in the show's production staff.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 2 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, international president of the Teamsters Union, attacked Walter P. Reuther in an address to Teamsters Local 20 here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- United States officials welcomed today the Soviet decision to attend an East-West conference of experts on ways to prevent a surprise attack. The meeting is to begin in Geneva Nov. 10.
Governor Harriman and Nelson A. Rockefeller, his Republican opponent in tomorrow's election, traded political blows yesterday, but at arm's length.
Sweeping rains kept Governor Harriman out of Coney Island yesterday, but they could not keep him from filling in the enforced gap in his homestretch drive with an attack on his Republican opponent.
Adolf A. Berle Jr., honorary chairman of the Liberal party, told a radio audience yesterday that the contest for Governor in New York might end in a "photo finish."

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 2 -- St. Peter's Prep overcame a stubborn Lincoln defense with two quick touchdowns late in the second quarter today and went on to a 39-0 football victory before 2,500 at Roosevelt Stadium. Lincoln's regulars sat out the second half as a protest by Coach Sam Lupo against the officiating.
Into the early hours of yesterday morning, Nelson A. Rockefeller, a tired but determined candidate, slugged it out on the political battlefield.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 2 -- Jorge Alessandri, Rightist-supported victor in the September elections, will begin tomorrow a six-year term as President of Chile.

The boards of the Cessna Aircraft Company and the Aircraft Radio Corporation have approved a plan for the acquisition of Aircraft Radio by Cessna, it was announced over the week-end. The announcement said the directors had authorized their executive officers to begin detailed negotiations.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 2 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Government is debating whether to gamble that negotiations for a German peace treaty can be made to work for the country's reunification.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 -- The return of Emilio Donato del Carril, Minister or Economy, from Washington this week will bring to a climax an economic struggle within the Government.

Sir Winston Churchill is the subject of two biographies scheduled for publication four days apart. One is "The Adventurous Life of Winston Churchill," by Geoffrey Bocca, which will have 150 illustrations, including photographs, drawings and cartoons.

SID CAESAR observed the opening of his tenth season on television last night by starring in the hour between 9 and 10 o'clock over Channel 4. The difficulties that currently seem to be besetting so many video comedians also trailed him for most of the period; the humor was very strained.
MOSCOW, Nov. 2 -- The Soviet Government is going into potato and vegetable farming on a large scale, to show collective farmers how much more cheaply it can be done.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus is a "valuable enemy," Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared here today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Norm Van Brocklin rifled two touchdowns in the fourth quarter as the Philadelphia Eagles tied the Chicago Cardinals today, 21 -- 21, before 17,486 fans.
Misgivings about the ability of the United Nations to maintain peace were expressed yesterday by panelists of the New York Times Youth Forum.
ROME, Nov. 2 -- Pope John XXIII will be crowned Supreme Pontiff of the Roman Catholic Church at about midday Tuesday.
A charming new Mimi, Gianna Galli, made her American debut in Puccini's "La Boheme" yesterday afternoon with the New York City Opera at the City Center.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) reported today that ten loans made during the three months ended Sept. 30 raised its loan total to more than $4,000,000,000.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Fredric March and his wife, Florence Eldridge, will join Spencer Tracy in the Stanley Kramer film production of "Inherit the Wind."
BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The undefeated Baltimore Colts crushed the Green Bay Packers, 56 -- 0, today and remained undisputed leaders in the National Football League's Western Division.

GENEVA, Nov. 2 (AP) -- United States and British delegates to the nuclear disarmament talks discussed in a private meeting today how to link the problem of test suspensions with the need for general disarmament.
Scientists say they probably will use the next Pioneer moon probe to relay a message from one continent to another.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- An official denial that France was faced with a general economic recession was given last week by Edouard Ramonet, Minister of Industry and Commerce.

A STORY is told in Oriente Province that Gen. Fulgencia Batista, now President of Cuba, once lifted up a young pupil named Raul Castro in a rural classroom and declared: "The future of Cuba is with youth like you."
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, gave qualified approval yesterday to merit rises in the pay of teachers.

Medals for the "supreme sacrifice" were presented yesterday by the Uniformed Firemen's Association and the Uniformed Fire Officers Association to the families of twelve firemen killed in the line of duty since the middle of last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- California's first systematic television teaching project will get under way in the San Francisco Bay Area tomorrow.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 30 -- President Jose Maria Lemus urged the people of El Salvador today to give their whole-hearted support to a "campaign of national optimism."

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins climbed to within a point of the National Hockey League lead tonight by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, on goals by Real Chevrefils and Jerry Toppazzini.

As the state campaign neared the end, Governor Harriman, Democratic-Liberal candidate for re-election, and Nelson A. Rockefeller, his Republican opponent, issued statements yesterday summarizing their positions on election issues. Following are excerpts from each:

Stephen Emery, Socialist Labor party candidate for United States Senator, vigorously denied yesterday that his organization advocated violence in its aim to lead this country from "political democracy" to "economic democracy."

The current economic recovery, which will no doubt bring the total gross national product above the previous high mark reached in the third quarter of 1957, will no doubt in this quarter bring the total gross national product to a new high record. Continued recovery through the first half of 1959 now seems clear.
Steps must be taken to teach parents how to detect visual disorders in their children before they reach school age, a city health official warned yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The H. K. Porter Company, Inc., of Pittsburgh plans to merge with the Thermoid Company of Trenton, N.J., it was announced yesterday. The merger is subject to approval of the stockholders of both companies.

" Tosca" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening, with Giuseppe Campora appearing for the first time this season as Cavaradossi and Cesare Bardelli singing his first Scarpia with the company.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 2 -- "Sensational" correctly describes the outburst of a new boom on the German stock market last week. German stocks listed in Zurich responded vigorously. A. E. G. jumped from 295 1/2 to 306, once touching 314.
PARIS, Nov. 2 -- The French command in Algeria denied today that Moslem rebels had pierced the electrified barrier along the Tunisian frontier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- It's getting so that even the professionals need a scorecard to recognize the candidates.
Barbering's elite assembled at the Manhattan Hotel yesterday for the annual International Men's Hairstyling Competitions, a two-day round of contests, lectures and exhibits.
MILLBURN, N. J., Nov. 2 -- The Township Committee will decide this week whether to accept a bequest of a seventeen-acre arboretum and bird sanctuary.

Women who are disturbed over the long hours their husbands spend at the office, the late executive-suite sessions and meetings with out-of-town buyers probably will regard Mrs. Ara Parseghian as an extraordinary person.
Earnings of the American Home Products Corporation in the quarter and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30 were higher than for the corresponding periods last year.
Maurice A. Hutcheson, indicted president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, may win a postponement this week of his scheduled showdown with the merged labor federation.

We cannot view without misgiving the transfer of authority in a friendly state to one-man rule. For that reason we must reserve decision upon the dismissal of President Mirza by Pakistan's new "strong man," Gen. Mohammed Ayub Khan. We have always been hopeful that the young, emergent, free Asian states could vindicate the principles of real democracy, which we hold to be the very heart of true freedom.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. added yesterday to his charge that an attempt had been made to buy his support for the Republican slate. He named Charles F. Willis Jr., a former White House assistant to Sherman Adams, as the man and $50,000 in small bills as the amount.
A plea in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday for prayers for the dead reminded Roman Catholics that "it is what happens to the soul after death that matters."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 2 -- Israeli citizens, already painfully taxed and squeezed by rising living costs, will soon be asked to help pay for the settling of 30,000 unexpected immigrants. The newcomers will be arriving in the next six months as a result of changes in policy in East European countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- If the Soviet Union carries out its announced intention to match the number of atomic explosions set off by the Western powers since March 31, it has a considerable test program in prospect.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Y. A. Tittle, out of action three weeks with injuries, returned to the San Francisco line-up in the fourth quarter today and led the 49ers to a 24-21 National Football League victory over the Detroit Lions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Treasury is extending to trust estates and other investors the privilege of buying series E and H savings bonds with the proceeds of series F and G bonds at or after maturity.

THE arrival of fall does not necessarily mean that insect worries are over. To the contrary, many little pests, such as millipedes, lady beetles, elm leaf beetles, box elder bugs, Asiatic oak weevils, clover mites and cluster flies, are eager to find a warm nook indoors.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 -- The Cabinet decided today to open a new investigation of the Kafr Kassim massacre.

HAVANA, Nov. 2 -- The Cubana Airlines announced tonight that seventeen persons were killed in the crash of an airliner last night on the north coast of Oriente Province after the plane had been seized by Cuban rebels.
HOUSEHOLD help is so scarce here that one can hardly get enough cooks together to spoil a broth.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Danny Thomas, comedian, symbolically burned a house here today to make room for the St. Jude Hospital for children, his dream of twenty-one years.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 2 -- The Moroccan Government is taking vigorous and extensive measures to halt rebellious activity in the traditionally explosive Rif mountain region in the northeast.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology claims for its I. B. M. 704 computer a vocabulary larger than Sir Winston Churchill's.
LIVERMORE, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A metal ring about the size of a hula hoop is one of this country's latest gadgets to help usher in the age of thermonuclear power.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Carroll Shelby of Dallas, Jack McAfee of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and Betty Shutes of Hollywood drove to victory today in the fifteenth Palm Springs sports car races.

Samuel Reshevsky, representing the United States in the Israel chess tournament, triumphed in the second round at Haifa, according to a report from Israeli news sources yesterday. He defeated Raaphy Persitz of Israel to tie for first place with Karel Vandenberg of the Netherlands, Robert G. Wade of New Zealand and Arie Rosenberg of Israel.

The Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams, minister of the Park Avenue Christian Church at Eighty-fifth Street, urged his congregation yesterday to vote "No" on the local option referendum to legalize bingo for charitable purposes.
Cotton futures followed an irregular course last week and closed with all but the most distant months up slightly.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 -- The consensus here is that the slight halt last week in the upward march of steel production was temporary. Many sources believe that steel output will exceed 75 per cent of capacity before it turns down seasonally.
Robert R. Newell has been appointed president and chief executive officer in a series of changes in the top management of Cunningham Walsh, Inc.

After two losses last week -- to Detroit Thursday and Toronto Saturday -- Phil Watson was not on speaking terms with his New York Rangers. And after his team's 2-1 setback at the hands of the Red Wings last night, it is probable that Watson wasn't even talking to himself.
Spokesmen for two of the three major Gulf Coast steamship companies that have signed a contract with a ships' officers union declared over the week-end that the agreement contained no hidden clauses.

On this book's back cover there's a color quotient test, which many people might flunk. That's all the more inducement to read it. For example, what is the favorite color of men and women? Men generally prefer blue, women red. And how many colors can the unaided eye detect?

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 2 -- The Dutch publishing company that is to bring out a Russian edition of "Doctor Zhivago" has disclosed that an advance run was distributed to Soviet tourists at the Brussels World's Fair.
The garage industry has decided to impose a 15 to 30 per cent surcharge for parking the longer and wider 1959 automobiles.
HONG KONG, Nov. 2 -- When the gathering of the fall harvests is over this year, there will be no surcease from toil for Communist China's hard-worked peasants.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Representative Robert W. Kean today urged a Republican vote on Tuesday to "maintain the peace through strength."

The George Putnam Fund of Boston reported over the weekend a new high in net assets. These had reached $165,229,000, equal to $12.88 a share on 12,823,637 shares outstanding as of Sept. 30, the fund announced.
A slowdown in city garbage collection and street cleaning was threatened yesterday by unionized employes of the Department of Sanitation.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 2 -- A Pekingese, the smallest dog to enter the final ring at the twentieth annual Union County Kennel Club fixture, loomed large in importance minutes later by gaining a United States best-in-show award for the first time today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Senator William F. Knowland and Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, California candidates for Governor, clashed today over labor issues as their campaign drew toward a climax.

Negroes are now "commonplace" in sales forces of major New York department stores, Charles Abrams, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, said yesterday. A decade ago they were "exceptions," he added.
Kunie Imai, Japanese soprano, will make her Metropolitan Opera debut the evening of Nov. 15 in the title role of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly."

Margaret Roy, who sang yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, has made a number of appearances since her debut here in 1952. She has been a guest artist and an oratorio soloist. She sings regularly at the Marble Collegiate Church and she had small parts in Leonard Bernstein's Broadway musical, "Candide."

POMPTON LAKES, N. J., The search for 7-year-old Paul Grochowicz of Pompton Lakes ended today. The body of the missing boy was found in the Ramapo River, 400 feet from his home on Riveredge Drive. He had been missing since Oct. 16, when he left home on a borrowed bicycle to see his grandparents in Tacoma, Wash.
MONTREAL, Oct. 31 -- A gas well that had been capped and a twelve-mile pipeline soon will be meeting additional gas needs of a Royal Canadian Air Force base in Northern Alberta.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced restraint of trade charges today against Associated Construction Publications, Detroit, and fifteen members who publish construction industry trade papers.
Conservatism is the keynote of balanced funds.

Outlining a foreign policy program yesterday, Corliss Lamont, Independent-Socialist candidate for United States Senator, declared that the Soviet Union desired disarmament "as a matter of she0er self-interest."
Former President Harry S. Truman chuckled in recollection of his famous upset victory over Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for the Presidency ten years ago yesterday.
Backers of the Cuban rebel leader, Fidel Castro, charged here yesterday that the Batista Administration had allowed some voters to register a dozen times for today's elections.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 2 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the Republican position insofar as holding Governorships was concerned was most vulnerable in California, Ohio, and Maryland.

One thousand school teachers, educators and school administrators paid tribute yesterday at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to the three founders of the Jewish Teachers Community Chest. The event also marked the twentieth anniversary of the organization.

LYNBROOK, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Nassau County chapters of Americans for Democratic Action today denounced a printed piece of campaign literature of the Nassau County Republican Committee. The literature charges that the A. D. A. has a "consistent policy of appeasement with atheistic communism and always has praise for the Soviet, its education, its economy, its foreign affairs."

Future prices for commodities closed generally higher in dull trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. All markets will be closed today, Election Day, and little interest was shown as trading was sandwiched between the holiday and the week-end.
Charles Feldman, a vice president, has been named head of the copy department at Young Rubicam, Inc. He succeeds George H. Gribbin, recently named president.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Formation of a five-team basketball conference made up of the University of California at Los Angeles, Southern California, California, Stanford and Washington is under consideration, it was learned today.
The police caught two men yesterday in the act of transferring $10,000 worth of nylon lace goods from one truck to another at Thirty-eighth Street and the Avenue of Americas.
The Democrats, in closing appeals, asked the New York electorate last night for a mandate to continue "government responsive to the needs of the people."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the appointment of John A. Hall as assistant general manager for international affairs.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 3 -- Ulus, Turkey's leading Opposition newspaper, was ordered suspended for a month today for having "insulted" Muntaz Tarhan, former Governor of Istanbul. An article in the paper a year ago said Mr. Tarhan had switched political parties to laud Premier Adnan Menderes.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The ground forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are being converted at a rapid pace to missile warfare, Gen. Lauris Norstad said today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The grain futures market was substantially higher today in one of the most bullish sessions on the Board of Trade in recent weeks.
IVRY GITLIS, Israeli violinist who made his debut with the New York Philharmonic three years ago, gave his first local solo recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

SAUMLAKI, Tanimbar Islands, Indonesia, Nov. 3 -- President Sukarn called the attention of the United States Ambassador today to a hand-painted placard in this remote area saying, "We must invade Irian Barat."
New York City spent $53,298,283 more than was provided for in its expense budget in the fiscal year ended last June 30. Nonetheless the municipal fiscal year was one of prosperity and well-being.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Western Union Telegraph Company today notified the Federal Communications Commission it wants to scale down its proposals for higher rates for private-line teletypewriter service.

Hundreds of fans waited on line yesterday to purchase tickets for Sunday's National Football League game between the Giants and the unbeaten Baltimore Colts at the Yankee Stadium. Added interest in the contest followed the Giants' 21-17 upset of the Browns last sunday at Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The State Department deplored today the "act of brigandage" that brought down a Cuban airliner yesterday with the loss of seventeen lives. Six of the dead were United States citizens.
Yogi Berra now throws a slider.

ACCRA, Ghanna, Nov 3 (Reuters) -- An Opposition leader charged today that Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah was seeking to set himself up as "life president or emperor" of this newly independent West African nation.

PARIS, Tuesday, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The seventeen nation Organization for European Economic Cooperation warned France today that if her credit squeeze was relaxed chances of financial and economic stability would be jeojardized.
The sun came out long enough yesterday to shine on a four-length victory by Georgiana Foster's Prince of Paris in the feature $6,000 Orienta Beach purse at Jamaica.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 3 -Contests for local offices in Nassau County are overshadowing the selection tomorrow of a Governor and a United States Senator.

After climbing to the highest level in almost a year, steel production edged off slightly last week. Output was scheduled to decline a bit more this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The volatile London copper market boiled with activity yesterday. Spot copper prices on the Metal Exchange there rose more than 1 cent a pound to a twenty-one-month high, then eased back to close at 31 3/4 cents asked.

Mrs. Ely Jacques Kahn Jr., benefit chairman, has announced that plans are being made for a theatre party for the benefit of the Scarborough (N. Y.) Country Day School. The committee has selected the Feb. 6 performance of "The Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre for the benefit.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer collected four hits in five trips today to spark the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-3 teninning victory over a Japanese all-star team.
LONDON, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Premier, said today that the Soviet Union had "achieved an increase in the power of our nuclear weapons" after resuming tests a month ago.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The Federal Government's chief economist called today for an end to ceilings on interest rates of Government-backed home mortgages.

Great Britain, the United States and the U. S. S. R. are meeting in Geneva to draft an agreement to end explosion of nuclear weapons, including an inspection system already agreed to by technical representatives of East and West.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock yesterday. It is payable on Dec. 10 to stockholders of record of Nov. 13. The action brought declarations this year to $2 a share, the same as paid in 1957.
Along with almost everyone else, oil companies are wondering what kind of winter we're going to have.

PARIS, Nov. 3 (Reuters) -- In his reply to the criticism of the Atlantic pact, some of it voiced by Field Marshall Montgomery, General Norstad said those who theorized that the NATO type of defense was old-fashioned had lost contact with the people.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- A sharp increase in business following the lifting of installment buying restrictions last week was the one factor that stimulated demand for industrial shares today. Prices moved ahead firmly, particularly among store, television and motor shares.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that a nine-man delegation would represent the United States at an international conference on lead and zinc starting Nov. 6 in Geneva, Switzerland.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The national political campaign ended this department in Georgia, the consequence of doctor's orders to transfer to that milder climate a protracted struggle with a virulent virus. These orders narrowed daily contact with developments of the campaign's last week to television and the radio.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Walter S. Robertson, Assistant Secretary of State, said today that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek would not take offensive action against the Chinese Communist mainland without United States consent.

About 2,500,000 New Yorkers will slip behind green or blue curtains today and pull down voting levers to carry out the mechanics of democracy. All year round, the city's Board of Elections and its staff of 259 work to make sure they can.

ROME, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- The solemn rites that will culminate at midday with the coronation of Pope John XXIII began at 8:05 A. M. today (2:05 A. M. New York time), when he was carried into St. Peter's Basilica.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- In the generally poor, densely populated lake zone of Patzcuaro in Mexico, a banking experiment in unsecured loans has paid off handsomely. Inquiries about it have come from as far as Nigeria and Thailand.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Tudor Era, an English-bred, American-owned racer, today was selected as the second representative of the United States in the $100,000 Washington, D. C. International to be run at Laurel Nov. 11. Eddie Arcaro was named to ride Tharp, an Irish colt.

CHARLEY CONERLY dragged himself off the Yankee Stadium gridiron a fortnight ago with his head bowed. Jeers of the fans accompanied every step of the journey to the sidelines. The Giant quarterback slumped onto the bench. Out on the field the Chicago Cardinals were completing their rout of the favored New Yorkers.
CHESTERFIELD, S. C., Nov. 3 (UPI) -- There is only one name on the ballot, but five persons are running for Chesterfield County Judge of Probate in tomorrow's election.
PARIS, Nov. 3 -- A new and spectacular setting for the United Nations organization for education, science and culture was dedicated today to world peace and understanding.
Construction of an $86,000,000 shipbuilding and ship repair center in Cuba will begin immediately, it was announced here yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Pittsburgh Gus, a 4-year-old chestnut son of Djeddah, completed a double victory for Patrick DeGregoiro of Winthrop, Mass., today as Narragansett Park opened its thirty-day fall meeting in cold, rainy weather.
The former site of the Misericordia Hospital at 531 East Eighty-sixth Street is included among three plots on which developers plan to construct three tall apartment buildings.

The television networks, which engaged in a trans-Atlantic air race in 1952 to bring films here of the British coronation, will fight the battle all over again today with the crowning of Pope John XXIII.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Secretary of Interior Fred A. Seaton today awarded a cost-plus fixed fee contract to the Fluor Corporation of Los Angeles to design and build a Government helium plant for the Bureau of Mines in the Keyes natural gas field of Cimarron County, Okla.

Frank Leahy, often reluctant to discuss his player's merits while he was football coach at Notre Dame, yesterday left no doubt of his admiration for George Izo, the quarterback of the current Fighting Irish.
Stocks made a timid but persistent rise yesterday although volume, pinched between the week-end and the holiday, fell to the lowest level in more than a month.
BONN, Nov. 3 -- The West German Government moved today to exert public pressure on France to modify her policy on the creation of a European free trade zone.

MANY parents are puzzled over the availability of financial assistance for their college-bound children. They are aware of the existence of scholarship and loan funds, but are uncertain about their role in helping their children obtain this money.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point off to 7 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Agreement on a new two-year contract covering 12,000 Greyhound Corporation employees in twenty states was announced today by union and management negotiators.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A charge by Senator Wayne Morse that the Republican candidate for Governor had lied before a jury has become a leading campaign issue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A new Federal agency for training the severely handicapped for independent living was urged today by representatives at a vocational rehabilitation conference called by Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
