LOON BAY, N. B., Nov. 3 -- The question under debate right now at Loon Bay Lodge is: Resolve, that a deer can bark like a dog. In the last half hour it has inspired bursts of inspired eloquence on either side and not very much profanity.
BONN, Nov. 3 -- Workers in West Germany have been ordered to pay their employers for money lost when they went on strike. The sum involved may run up to the equivalent of $6,000,000.
The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad plans to hold the line for the present on passenger fares.

The Railroad Marine Union, a newly formed independent organization, has won the right to represent unlicensed deck and engine room personnel on tugboats and ferryboats of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad in New York harbor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The United States Asphalt Corporation, New York City, agreed today to change its advertising of the price of a roofing material.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The United States delegation to the technical conference on ways to prevent a surprise attack will meet in Geneva with British, French, Canadian and Belgian representatives this week to decide on Western positions, State Department officials said today.
OXFORD, England, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The American-led rowing rebels of Oxford University disbanded today and rejoined the official fold.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- An official of the House of Representatives warned staff employes of two deceased Republican Representatives today that they could lose their jobs for reported political activity.
Foreign visitors often marvel at two things -- our orderly election days and our voluntary health and welfare institutions.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 3 -- Altough martial law is expected to remain in force for many months, the Pakistani Army is gradually being withdrawn from tasks of day-to-day administration.
ROME, Nov. 3 -- Pope John's sister, three brothers and numerous other relatives arrived tonight from his native village in northern Italy to attend the coronation tomorrow.
NASHVILLE, Nov. 3 -- Seven of twelve jurors were chosen today to try John Kasper on charges of inciting a riot while attempting to disrupt the integration of Nashville city schools.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- An eleven-day schedule for the 1960 Winter Olympic Games at Squaw Valley, Calif., was released today.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation showed a slight improvement in earnings in the third quarter of this year but failed to equal last year's figures.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 3 -- Jorge Alessandri, a conservative, took office today for a six-year term as President of Chile.

The Long Island Rail Road is starting to send people to the suburbs by television. At least, it is directing them to Track 18 at Pennsylvania Station by a closed-circuit television screen at the gate, listing the time, route and destination of the next train.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3 -- Westchester officials proposed today to send old cars careening and crashing here soon to determine the qualities of different center barriers for wide roads.
Plans were made yesterday to raise $550,000 for a church and community center at Fifth Avenue and East 110th Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration posted long odds today -- about 1 in 25 -- on chances for success in the next attempt to shoot a rocket to the moon.

As Secretary General of the Communist party of Puerto Rico, Cesar Andreu Iglesias was for the past few years under indictment for conspiring to overthrow the Government. Enforced idleness turned his energies to the pen.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will go to their Gettysburg home tomorrow to vote. They will return to the White House to hear the election returns.
A forecast of clear skies and mild weather raised the possibility yesterday that the election today would see a record off-year turnout at the polls in the state.

MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (Canadian Press) -- The Bell Telephone Company of Canada had net earnings in the nine months ended Sept. 30 of $28,568,815, compared with $27,464,214 in the corresponding period last year.
Issues ranging from "rightto-work" laws to "soak-the-rich" taxes will confront voters in thirty-nine states today.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- France's legislative electoral campaign opened formally today, with 2,978 candidates in the race for 465 seats in the first National Assembly of the Fifth Republic. The elections will be held Nov. 23 and 30.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- The Chinese Communists fired more than 38,000 shells at the Quemoy island group yesterday in one of the heaviest bombardments of the Taiwan Strait war.
A recent letter by a Middle East diplomat on the weakness of Western foreign policy for the East prompts me to send you the following comments:
Joseph E. Seagram Sons, the largest whisky company in the world, plans to produce and market nationally for the first time its own brands of straight bourbon whiskies, it was announced yesterday.

WORK by twenty American printmakers, acclaimed at the big first Inter-American Biennial Exhibition in Mexico City last summer, was selected by the Brooklyn Museum at the request of the United States Information Agency. The thirty-nine prints, ranging from realism to nonobjective in manner, will go on view today in the museum's print galleries.
BOHEMIA, L. I., Nov. 3 -- An electronic "portrait" of Long Island's atmosphere and bedrock formations has been completed.

John Henry Faulk, radio and television entertainer, who is suing Aware, Inc., for $500,000 for libel, was given the right yesterday to question a director of the organization and examine its records. Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine made the ruling.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -California candidates for high office paid final pre-election respects to their rivals today with uncomplimentary phrases.
GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- United States and British disarmament negotiators clashed fundamentally with Soviet diplomats today at the second of the current series of talks on nuclear disarmament here.
Samuel Reshevsky drew his third-round game with Itzchak Aloni of Israel in the international chess tournament at Haifa, it was reported from Israel last night.

Harry Horwitz has purchased the vacant plot, 75 by 100 feet, at 319-323 East Forty-fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues. The seller was represented by Joseph Lubin of Eisner Lubin. The property is near the site of the proposed twelve-story building that will house the United States Mission to the United Nations at the southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street and First Avenue.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Mickey Shuman, the Peddie School's 145-pound coach who has been in charge of the Gold and Blues football fortunes for almost two decades, was extremely easy on his squad this afternoon.

THIS season the Little Orchestra Society is saluting four American composers in its Town Hall series. Morton Gould, the second of them, was honored last night. Like Norman Dello Joio, his predecessor, Mr. Gould appeared as a pianist as well as a composer.

Following are the texts of the statement issued yesterday by Mrs. Dorothy Schiff, publisher of The New York Post, canceling that newspaper's support of Governor Harriman; Mr. Harriman's reply, and telegrams from Nelson A. Rockefeller, Republican candidate for Governor, and Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, to Mrs. Schiff.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3 -- Yale University faculty members and students protested tonight the treatment of Boris Pasternak by the Soviet Government.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Nov. 3 -Wives of striking machinists today picketed gates to two atomic plants in place of their husbands, who had been enjoined from doing so.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Vice Admiral R. B. Pirie said today the Navy was prepared to blockade the Soviet Union's almost 500 submarines with mine fields in case of war.

The season's first snowfall was observed at the observation deck of the Empire State Building at 8:45 A. M. yesterday. But there was only rain at the warmer street level eighty-six stories (1,050 feet) below.

Proceeds from a theatre party at the Dec. 18 performance of "Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre will be used by the Central Synagogue Sisterhood in its program of nonsectarian community service.
Specialization is "the way of the future" in ocean transportation, according to a Norwegian shipping executive who began his career in conventional general-cargo liner operations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- For forty years Dr. Hugh Latimer Dryden has been driven by the scientific urge to discover how man could fly faster and higher into the air. Today the pioneer aeronautical scientist announced that the third United States attempt to shoot a rocket to the moon would be made in a week or so.
ITALY and the Ivy League have struck an entente cordiale at the Village Squire.

AN odd incident of the California Gold Rush was that during it Heinrich Schliemann (1822-1890), the great German archaeologist, became an American citizen. He used the wealth he gained among our Argonauts and in Europe to help rediscover for the world the golden, Homeric story of ancient Greece.

THE word "fresh" is perhaps overworked in art reviewing, but it must be given another chance in the case of Jane Freilicher's paintings at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery, 24 East Sixty-seventh Street. These paintings are fresh as newly cut flowers. Unassuming and direct, the canvases are most often simple statements of pleasure.
A nationally known bridge builder yesterday urged a twelve-lane link between Brooklyn and Jersey City in preference to the proposed Narrows Bridge between Brooklyn and Staten Island.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Disturbances in Aden ended yesterday and life in the colony has returned to normal, Colonial Secretary Alan Lennox-Boyd told the House of Commons today.
United States and Indian companies announced yesterday partnership in a large, privately owned drug manufacturing concern to be located near Bombay.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 -Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute and former president and board chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, was optimistic today about the future of the steel industry.
Talks between the Emil Mogul Company, Inc., and Lewin, Williams Saylor, Inc., are expected to result in a merger.
Heavy buying and a record first-day attendance marked the opening yesterday of the forty-third annual National Hotel Exposition at the New York Coliseum.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP) -Goodyear Tire Rubber Company today reported earnings of $20,196,000, equal to $1.91 a share, for the third quarter of 1958. This was nearly one-third more than the 1957 figure.

A plan to merge the Amphenol Electronics Corporation of Chicago and the George W. Borg Corporation of Delavan, Wis., was announced jointly yesterday by the two companies. The surviving concern would be known as AmphenolBorg Electronic Corporation.
HAVANA, Tuesday, Nov. 4 -- Dr. Andres Rivero Aguero, Presidential candidate of the four-party Government coalition, was the apparent victor today over the three opposition candidates.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy today overruled a Government motion for a temporary injunction in the du PontGeneral Motors antitrust case.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- John Farrow, director and writer, will make his long-contemplated movie about the life of Jesus Christ, "Son of Man," in cooperation with Samuel Bronston, the producer.

Automobile production increased sharply last month. The "Big Three" of the industry -General Motors Corporation, Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation -- assembled 226,874 cars, or more than twice their September total of 112,475. Their assemblies totaled 302,570 in the 1957 month.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The setting of national goals in health, education and welfare was declared imperative today by Arthur S. Flemming, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

William A. Coleman has been elected executive vice president of ACF-Wrigley Stores, Inc., retail food chain, Detroit, Mich. Mr. Coleman, a director and a member of the executive committee of the company, formerly was a vice president.

The nation's major finance companies yesterday cut the rates they pay on the commercial paper placed directly with investors. The reduction represents the first cut since late July. Since then there have been some six increases.
Nelson A. Rockefeller rested his case for the Governorship last night with a half-hour television program that he shared with his Republican running mates.

With one East-West conference already meeting in Geneva to discuss the ending of nuclear weapons tests, another conference is due to start in the same city next Monday. Its purpose will be to deal with the problem of preventing surprise attacks. Both conferences have been initiated by President Eisenhower in an effort to break the twelve-year-old disarmament deadlock.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The Political Committee of the General Assembly approved tonight a compromise proposal under which the membership of the Disarmament Commission would be broadened next year to include all eighty-one members of the United Nations.
New Jersey voters will go to the polls today to elect a United States Senator, fourteen members of the House of Representatives and numerous county and local officials.

Madison Square Garden buzzed with work yesterday in preparation for today's opening of the National Horse Show. It looked a little like a building projeet. Trucks rolled in with tons of black earth for the ring and downstairs.
Carlo Gambino, who attended the Apalachin, N. Y., gangland convention last Nov. 14, was taken ill at the start of his deportation hearing yesterday.

CATERERS equipped to provide food and service for parties of 100 or more guests are relatively easy to find here. But it is likely to be more difficult to locate a caterer willing to prepare a small dinner for ten to twenty guests.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Ten countries joined the United States today in sponsoring a proposal for a worldwide inventory of the investments and the results so far achieved in technical assistance to less-developed nations. The ten are Argentina, Haiti, Iran, Italy, Japan, Laos, Malaya, Pakistan, the Sudan and Uruguay.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- The Tariff Commission ruled out investigations today of manufactured imports simply because they were alleged to compete with domestic production of a raw material from which the product was made.
YONKERS, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- Esther G., a 6-year-old brown mare owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Eyler of Thurmond, Md., and driven by Hugh Bell, won the feature pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Howard Fast, who has written a number of popular books, has turned out a comedy. It is called "The Crossing" and deals with George Washington, one of the author's favorite subjects. Washington was the leading character in "The Unvanquished," Mr. Fast's historical novel that was hailed by reviewers in 1942.
Travel is broadening the outlook for peace, 2,000 delegates to the twenty-eighth annual World Travel Congress were told yesterday by Governor Harriman.

Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons is planning to erect a multi-million-dollar building to house a new medical library and new medical research laboratories at the southeast corner of 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

HAVANA, Nov. 3 -- Ambassador Smith has sent a strong note of protest to the Cuban Government over the arrest and alleged beating of two United States citizens in Havana. The Americans are George Jessel and Oswaldo Urrutia, a Puerto Rican, who were arrested here Oct. 2.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon ended his 1958 campaigning today.

NEWARK, Nov. 3 -- The abandonment of the Hudson River Ferry service by the New York Central and Erie Railroads would "undermine" the economic foundation of thousands of commuters from North Bergen and other communities in the state, Attorney General David D. Furman of New Jersey contended today.

Burke Emery of Sherbrooke, Que., was no match for Jose Torres of Brooklyn -- by way of Puerto Rico -- last night at the St. Nicholas Arena. And many among the 4,116 on hand were wondering who among the middleweights might be after Torres had stopped the Canadian in 2:07 of the fifth round.

Smith, Barney Co. and associates yesterday bought $2,000,000 of Rockford, Ill., Sanitary District bonds, due from 1959 to 1977. The bid was 100.0146 for 4 1/2 s, 4 1/4 s, 3s and 3.10s producing a net interest cost to the district of 3.0884 per cent.
In a reversal of policy, a group of nursing homes that had been challenging city subpoenas of their records dropped their objections yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the provisional Algerian government, will probably arrive here about Nov. 15, according to sources close to the Algerian government. The purpose of the trip would be to help plead the rebel cause before the United Nations.
WATERVILLE, N. H., Tuesday, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- This mountain hamlet was the first town in the nation to vote today. Residents sat up until after midnight and then backed Republican candidates 15 to 6.

The eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area piled up an impressive advance over 1957 during October. Sales topped the volume for the year before by 11 per cent, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

Sales and earnings of the Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation rose to new highs in the quarter ended on Sept. 30. Earnings for the first nine months were higher than in the 1957 period despite a slight decline in sales.
New York Newspaper Guild officials said last night that a final decision would be made next week by members of its unit at The New York Post on acceptance or rejection of a new management offer.
The publisher of The New York Post, which last week came out in support of Governor Harriman, called on the voters yesterday not to cast their ballots for him.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A new Government unit with vast powers over civil and military air traffic -- the Federal Aviation Agency -- came into being today.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -Auto production again is nearing high-volume levels, following work stoppages that have hampered output.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI) -- The House Information Subcommittee warned today that Congress would clamp down on Administration officials who "continue to worship at the shrine of secrecy."
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- In an apparent bid to regain waning public support, the Labor party bitterly assailed the Government's economic policies today.

The Bristol-Myers Company acted yesterday to increase its year-end extra dividend. It also reported that earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 were higher than last year. The company produces ethical and proprietary drugs, toiletries and cosmetics.
State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray yesterday announced tentative plans for a 600-apartment development, exclusively for the elderly, facing the Coney Island boardwalk.

"I Married a Woman," an R. K. O. romantic comedy, starring George Gobel and Diana Dors, arrives today at neighborhood theatres. The film was produced by William Bloom and directed by Hal Ganter, from a screen play by Goodman Ace.

The high school football star weighs 225 pounds and stands 6 feet 4 inches. He is 16 years old. His neck measures 17 inches, his chest 44 (46 expanded) and his shoulders are huge. He wears a size 13 shoe, his fingers are thick and long and he has cuts on his knees and shins.
SPRINGHILL, N. S., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A mulatto miner said today that he would accept an invitation to recuperate in Georgia on a segregated basis.
Spaciousness is the theme of the 1959 Mercury, which will go on sale Nov. 14.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 2 -- The scientists are flying south for the Antarctic summer. Today, for example, eight American Scientists arrived here from New Zealand aboard a Navy four-engine Sky-master.

A Latvian woman, paralyzed from tuberculosis contracted in a slave labor camp, smiled yesterday from her bed in an East Side hotel. Her father, whom she had not seen for fourteen years, had come to take her home.

It is two years today since that tragic morning in 1956 when the Soviet Army struck treacherously and mercilessly in the streets of Budapest to crush the Hungarian people's fight for freedom. The passage of time has not dimmed our admiration for the patriots who fought so bravely, with the crudest of weapons, against Soviet tanks, guns and planes.
A NUMBER of exhibitions were inadvertently omitted from the weekly listing in The New York Times Sunday. Besides those published, other new current exhibitions include:

Two developments in the last few days in Virginia are significant. One is the suit brought by a group of white families in Norfolk to overturn the state laws that have closed six secondary schools in the Old Dominion's largest city because seventeen Negroes were assigned to them by the Federal court.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today he had "pretty reliable" information that the Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals at St. Louis had prepared a "drastic ruling" in the Little Rock school integration case.
A big question that today's election in the state will resolve is: What share of the total state vote does New York City represent ?
A hold-up man who threatened his victim with what looked like a hand grenade escaped with $5,000 yesterday from the branch office of the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank at 1 East Forty-second Street.

The Blue Ridge School of Virginia, which provides an education for children of limited means, will be the beneficiary of the Golden Anniversary Ball. The fete, which is being sponsored by the New York Auxiliary of the school, will be held in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 30.
HAVANA, Nov. 4 -- Opposition candidates made accusations of fraud today after it became known that Dr. Andres Rivero Aguero had won a sweeping victory for Cuba's Presidency.
The American people elected a more liberal Congress yesterday and confronted President Eisenhower with the largest Democratic majorities in the House and Senate since the days of the New Deal.
BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 5 -- Republican Gov. Robert E. Smiley and State Senator A. M. Derr, who campaigned for legalized gambling, battled it out neck-and-neck tonight for the Governorship of Idaho.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- A national appeal has been launched in South Africa to assist in the repatriation of the Angola Boers, an impoverished group of 450 nomadic farmers who trekked with their few possessions from the northern Transvaal to the Portuguese territory of Angola about eighty years ago.

YONKERS, Nov. 4 -- Despite what Billy Haughton, the winning driver, called a "not too sharp" effort, Trader Horn captured the ninth annual Gotham Trot and set a track record at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

An atmosphere of gaiety and color prevailed last evening at the formal opening of the seventy-fifth anniversary National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. Afternoon and evening performances will be held through next Thursday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov, 4 -- The African elected members of the Kenya Legislative Council walked out in a body today while the Governor, Sir Evelyn Baring, was speaking at the new session of the Council.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- A Soviet effort to seat Communist China in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization failed today.
One seaman was killed and seven others were reported injured Monday when the 46,000-deadweight - ton supertanker World Glory encountered heavy seas in the Pacific.
It has been found virtually impossible for the human body to adjust to an environment much colder than that in which Englishmen live.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Despite a wide swing as she went into the home stretch, W. W. Carroll's Curam today won the Norwood Purse over a muddy track at Narragansett Park.

Bowing to Soviet demands backed by a boycott, the United Nations General Assembly has voted to reverse all its previous decisions in the matter and to enlarge the Disarmament 'Commission by including in it all the eighty-one United Nations members.
Democrats seized nearly a score of Republican-held seats in yesterday's elections for the House of Representatives with returns from most of the close races still to be tabulated.

PARIS, Wednesday, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Organization for European Economic Cooperation warned today that if the United States wished to avoid another recession "the authorities will need to be alert to the danger of potential inflationary developments."
An ingenious short-side option play that capitalizes on the special talents of Bill Austin and Bob Simms has helped Rutgers maintain a pristine record in football this season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Interior Department is having its annual big-game disposal sale. And, the department says, more people are interested in buying buffalo, longhorn cattle and elk than ever before.

Harrison A. Williams Jr., the Democrat who was elected Senator from New Jersey yesterday, is a 38-year-old lawyer, who made political history five years ago. It was then that he became the last-minute Democratic nominee for the House in the Sixth Congressional District. A special election was being held to fill the seat vacated by Senator Clifford P. Case.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Plans to give Turkey additional hydroelectric power, improve irrigation and strengthen flood control have been advanced with the completion of the Kemer Dam.
The Most Rev. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, celebrated mass there yesterday in honor of the coronation of Pope John XXIII in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Twelve nations, including the United States, asked the United Nations today to try again to find a solution to the problem of divided Korea.

FLINT, Mich., Nov. 4 (AP) -- General Motors announced today a step-up in employment at both the Buick assembly plant and the Fisher body plant No. 1 here. A total of 1,500 workers will be recalled at both plants.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- Pope John XXIII was incisive and forceful as the principal figure in the five-hour liturgic proceedings today, of which the climax was his coronation.
In a tumultuous scene at Republican headquarters, Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller acknowledged the wild cheering of his joyous party workers last night.
IN "Epitaph for George Dillon," acted at the John Golden last evening, John Osborne and Anthony Creighton have told the story of an English heel who despises himself.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The male preoccupation with keeping the old school tie, slippers beyond repair and a pipe that has long since seen its last puff appears to be well-suited to the archivist.
NEWARK, Nov. 4 -- The Democrats won control of the Essex County government tonight.

A voluntary hospital is based on an idea that all who enjoy health are in some measure responsible for those who are sick, that all who need medical care must receive it regardless of ability to pay, that every community is the better and stronger for taking care of its own sick.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, won easy re-election today for a fifth six-year Senate term.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 4 -- Moroccan and Tunisian leaders believe a break in the Algerian problem will be made this winter, presumably by negotiation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- King Brothers Productions, Inc. has alleged antitrust law violations in connection with the distribution of its movie, "The Brave One," and breach of contract involving release of two other films, "Carnival Story" and "Drums in the Deep South."

Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Rochester Republican, yesterday defeated District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan in the New York race for the United States Senate. On the basis of nearly complete returns, Mr. Keating's plurality over the Democratic-Liberal candidate was expected to reach 160,000.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- A tremendous roar rose from packed St. Peter's Square when the triple crown was placed on the head of Pope John XXIII today.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- For the first time in its 700-year history, the House of Lords heard a female voice join in debate today.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 4 -- Westchester County gave a landslide plurality today to two Republican favorite sons -- Nelson A. Rockefeller of Pocantico Hills for Governor and Malcolm Wilson of Yonkers for Lieutenant Governor.
General Instrument Corporation announced yesterday it had sold the Thermatron division of its subsidiary, Radio Receptor Company, to Willcox Gibbs Sewing Machine Company. Terms were not disclosed.
ROME, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Following is an English translation, issued at the Vatican, of a homily delivered in Latin by Pope John XXIII before his coronation today:
Democratic candidates for the Legislature made a stronger showing last night than Governor Harriman did.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Public interest in the United Nations soared today. It does every Election Day. This is the only place in town where the bars are open.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Bergen County stayed in the Republican column in today's voting, but not by the thumping margins of a decade ago.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 3 -- American Quakers have taken an important but unpublicized role in feeding child victims of the five-month rebellion recently ended here.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat, won re-election by a landslide today in Tennessee. Buford Ellington, the Democratic nominee for Governor, was the victor in the other major contest.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The International Shipping Federation opposed tonight a boycott of ships flying "flags of convenience."

ROME, Nov. 4 -- Official Government missions from fifty-seven countries attended Pope John's coronation today. They included representatives of nations that maintain no diplomatic relations with the Holy See, such as the United States, Canada and Israel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The General Assembly urged the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union tonight to make every effort to reach an early agreement in Geneva on the suspension of nuclear weapons tests "under effective international control."
Louis J. Lefkowitz, Republican incumbent, was elected Attorney General of New York State yesterday by a huge vote.

The often-postponed hearing by the Federal Maritime Board into the practices of ocean freight forwarders is scheduled to commence at 10 o'clock this morning, at 45 Broadway. The proceedings were originally started by the board more than four years ago.

Marking the climax of its autumn funding-raising drive, the New York County Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society is planning a Holiday in New York cocktail party for the afternoon of Dec. 9. The fete will be held in the ballroom and Trianon Room of the Sheraton-East.
The use of teacher aides in classrooms can be a boon to education, if the primary purpose is to save the teacher rather than save money.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- A Swiss law professor will sit as a special judge on the International Court of Justice (World Court) tomorrow in a dispute between the United States and Switzerland, it was announced today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev said yesterday that if the West carried out atomic tests "let them not think that we will meanwhile doze and wait while the imperialists build up their forces against us."
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Business got too good for one of Britain's big automobile dealers as a result of last week's abolition of credit controls. So today he made it more difficult for his customers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- Walt Disney will be the pageantry committee chairman of the Winter Olympic Games at Squaw Valley in February, 1960.
Organized labor won smashing victories yesterday in its top-priority election issue. Union members and their allies swamped proposed "right-to-work" laws in highly industrialized Ohio and California.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Eddie Litzenberger scored two goals and an assist tonight in pacing the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-2 victory over the New York Rangers. Litzenberger took over the National Hockey League scoring lead.

The closing of Washington Square to traffic except buses and emergency equipment, even on a thirty-day experimental basis, is something almost unique in the age of the automobile. It is a response to organized, intelligent, persistent citizen protest -- and some very influential political help as well.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- The housewives of this capital could have done some interesting figuring this week-end if they were willing to read all the fine print in the government's new agricultural decree.

WHEN Col. Laurens van der Post was a boy on his father's farm in the Orange Free State he used to listen to strange stories about the little Bushmen, the only original inhabitants of South Africa. For ages before the black African tribes swarmed down from the north the yellow-skinned, slant-eyed Bushmen had lived on the vast plains, men so ancient and primitive that they seem almost as if they were a different species.
David Dubinsky, vice chairman of the Liberal party, last night sharply criticized an editorial in The New York Post calling upon its readers not to vote for Governor Harriman.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 4 -- Democrats swept to victory in Wisconsin's Senatorial and Gubernatorial races today, breaking the Republican hold on this turbulent political state.
SEATTLE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Boeing Airplane Company last night declared a 4 per cent stock dividend in addition to the regular quarterly cash dividend of 25 cents.

THE Beryozka Russian Dance Company, consisting entirely of girls, except for five male accordionists, opened a five-week engagement last night at the Broadway Theatre under the auspices of S. Hurok in accordance with the exchange agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.

IN 1959 it will be Handel by a landslide. In observance of the 200th anniversary of his death, which occurred on April 14, 1759, his music will be favored everywhere throughout the year. And if the Bach and Mozart bicentennials of the Nineteen Fifties are any indication, the Handel support will spill over into adjoining years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff today carried Fairfield County in his successful bid for re-election to his second term. No Democrat had carried the county in an off-year campaign since 1930.

OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Japanese All-Stars stole the home-run thunder from the St. Louis Cardinals today and pinned the major leaguers with their second loss in eight games on a tour. Futoshi Nakanishi's grand-slam homer sparked a 9-2 triumph before a crowd of 25,000.

FARGO, N. D., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Senator William Langor and Gov. John E. Davis carried the Republican banner into the lead in the top North Dakota races today. But Democrats were showing strength in lesser contests.

HAVANA, Nov. 4 -- Dr. Andres Rivero Aguero, who was elected President of Cuba yesterday, has devoted his adult life to politics. He is a lawyer, but has never actively practiced his profession. Though he has served as Premier and now has been chosen for the nation's high est office, he still is little known to the general public.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Senator Stuart built up a massive victory tonight to win a second term and a running start as a 1960 Democratic Presidential contender.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- The new Pontiff, John XXIII, proclaimed before his coronation today that he wanted above all to be a "Good Shepherd."

On the day before his election as Governor, Nelson A. Rockefeller declared that he would support legislation to protect news reporters in their press freedom if the bills drawn up for that purpose did not permit abuses.
Democrats appeared likely to control more than three-fourths of the forty-eight state governorships when the final tally of yesterday's election was completed.
The New York Central Railroad yesterday announced salary increases to nonunion employes, retroactive to Nov. 1. On that date unionized employes received an 8-cent hourly wage increase.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A Federal grand jury indicted Clyde C. Crosby, teamsters union chief in Oregon today on charges of lying to the Senate rackets inquiry last year.

Since one bears so inexorably on the other, it is appropriate that just as New York City's proposed capital budget is being received by the Board of Estimate the most recently concluded expense budget year should be reported on by the City Controller. The capital budget, which is a schedule of new public improvements of a permanent nature to be built or begun in the 1959 calendar year, is budget based on borrowing.

A New York State Court of Appeals' post and thirteen places on the State Supreme Court bench in New York City were filled at yesterday's election, but there were few contests for the judicial vacancies.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. (Reuters) -- Large quantities of counterfeit Israeli banknotes recently discovered in European banks are believed by the Israeli police to have been made in Cairo.
The New York Stock Exchange has decided that Wall Street professionals as well as school children can learn from educational movies.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Baghdad radio announced tonight that Col. Abdel Salam Arif, former right-hand man of Iraq's revolutionary Premier Abdel Kerim el-Kassem, was arrested in Baghdad today. Colonel Arif recently was appointed Iraqi Ambassador to West Germany.
Army regained the total offense lead among the nation's major college football teams in the statistics released yesterday and San Jose State was back on top in passing.
LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The Government announced today that it would give financial support to British airplane manufacturers competing with the United States for export of planes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The United States will sign an agreement tomorrow to sell Israel $37,700,000 of surplus agricultural products, for Israeli pounds.
The election of Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller as Governor of New York has given the final stamp of public approval to a name that once was among the most hated and feared in America.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 -- Democrats took the Governorship and three House seats from the Republicans in Maryland today, but fell short in their bid for a Senate seat.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- The Democrats wrested California's state government out of Republican hands for the second time in the twentieth century.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Amid union predictions of a unanimous rejection, striking mechanics began voting today on a company offer aimed at settling a 19-day walkout against Capital Airlines.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 4 -- Turkeys Foreign Minister Fatin Rustu Zorlu expressed hope tonight that Greece's decision against a conference on the Cyprus question was "only the result of a misunderstanding."
TELEVISION and radio stations canceled normal schedules last night for extensive coverage of the election returns.
SALISBURY, L. I., Nov. 4 -- Adelphi College has launched a goodwill campaign to win friends and perhaps influence a few fans for its sports program.
With his election to Congress yesterday from the city's Seventeenth Congressional District, John V. Lindsay emerges as one of the bright hopes of the Republican party.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 4 -- Meat exports to the United States next year should largely offset dollar losses through American restrictions on lead and zinc imports, Primary Industry Minister William McMahon said today.
HARTFORD, Nov. 4 -- The Democrats swept Connecticut today.
A group of visitors from others lands converged on polling places in this city yesterday to learn how Americans vote.
The greatest Democratic sweep since 1936 seemed to be in the making as the party scored spectacular gains in races for the House of Representatives.
Committee members have been meeting to plan for the tenth anniversary Tiara Ball, which will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 29.

THE second in a series of exhibitions held as benefits for out-of-town museums will open with a preview this evening at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. Fifty selected paintings from the collection of the City Art Museum of St. Louis will be shown.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 3 -- A six-man tractor party is grinding its way across snow and ice today in a traverse of virgin territory in Marie Byrd Land.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 4 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister for the Economy, warned today that Ceylon's excessive nationalism would inevitably isolate her.

COS COB, Conn., Nov. 4 -- the Radcliffe Club of lower Fairfield County will sponsor a series of two-day sales of special collections of Christmas gift items this month in New Canaan, Darien, Stamford, Greens Farms and Cos Cob.

CALGARY, Alta., Oct. 30 -- One thousand northern Alberta and Saskatchewan Indians, have found new employment in southern Alberta's sugar beat fields and netted $400,000 in take-home pay in a record crop year.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- While the democratic theory is commonly understood and shared by the leading nations of the West, its practice and application vary. These differences are strikingly shown in this month's legislative elections in the United States and France.
George Yardley of the Detroit Pistons, the leading scorer in the National Basketball Association last season, is taking up where he left off.
OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- An experiment in gradual release of long-term penitentiary prisoners is considered a success after having been tried with about twenty in the last year and a half.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- If any Chinese Communists have been overcome by gas, it must have been the effect of "noxious lies emanating from Radio Peking," a State Department spokesman said today.
Adoption of the two referendums on the New Jersey ballot appeared virtually certain as returns indicated an overwhelming majority in favor of them.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 5 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller defeated Governor Harriman in Nassau County yesterday by an unofficial plurality of 122,455 votes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The three American scientists who won the 1958 Nobel Prize in medicine Thursday were assisted in their research by financial support from the Federal Government.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 4 -- Chile's foreign policy under President Jorge Alessandri will be directed at expansion of relations with the United States and Argentina, her traditional trading partners.
WARSAW, Nov. 3 -- In a packed Warsaw trolley car, an 18-year-old college student leaped up, yanked his chum out of his seat and gallantly offered their places to two elderly women.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Republican Daniel Becker, a Newburgh attorney, eked out a victory over Newburgh's Democratic Mayor, William D. Ryan in today's election for the First District Assembly seat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department predicted today that food would be slightly cheaper and more plentiful next year. It said farmers would be paid less for their products.
Shirley Verrett-Carter, mezzo-soprano, winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, sang a debut recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A further decline in the nations dairy herd in 1959 is being forecast by the livestock feed industry.
It took a telephone call from Vice President Richard M. Nixon and some earnest conversation with Nelson A. Rockefeller to convince Kenneth B. Keating that he ought to run for Senator.

Democrats took over two more Congressional seats in upstate New York last night. The upsurge was headed by Mayor Samuel S. Stratton, Schenectady Democrat, who won a seat held by Republicans for forty-two years.
"Now the Colts!" These words on a blackboard greeted the Giants when they entered their dressing room at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The British Government increased military pensions and allowances today. It promised to review pay and pensions in the light of civilian economic standards at least every two years.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 4 -- Former Gov. Harold J. Arthur, a Republican, conceded tonight to William H. Meyer. Mr. Meyer thus became the first Democrat from Vermont to win a seat in the House of Representatives in more than a century.
VIENNA, Nov. 4 -- A Chinese Communist method of solving major economic problems is to be used in Bulgaria's current five-year plan.

Maintaining a 299-seat off-Broadway house on a paying basis seems to have its drawbacks, especially when the current attraction is not a complete sellout. Such a predicament confronts Warner LeRoy, who is involved in a dual capacity at the York Playhouse, First Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

A four-story Walk-up building containing seventeen apartments on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 1035 Willmohr Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. Jennie Stein to Israel Sholom, an investing client of Irving Bira, broker in the deal. It is assessed at $54,000.
Jacob Ruppert is returning to the line-up of brand names.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Oklahoma elected the youngest governor in its history tonight as J. Howard Edmondson swept into office in a Democratic landslide.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The effect of radiation on the blood-forming tissues of the human body can now be estimated almost immediately from a small blood sample, according to a group of German and English researchers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower shunned Republican national headquarters tonight and remained in his study in the White House receiving reports on key contests across the nation.

The opening of a private segregated school in Arkansas under a corporate charter from the state, the appeals for funds to citizens in other states, and presumably its freedom from taxation as an educational institution, in addition to endangering the public school system, raise fundamental questions about our way of life.
HONG KONG, Nov. 4 -- Communist China charged today that Chinese Nationalist artillery on Quemoy used poison gas in shelling positions on the China mainland yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- In the last ten years William F. Callahan has been in charge of the spending of more public funds than any man in Massachusetts history. All told, with a new three-way assignment, the figure totals around $900,000,000.

The most interesting and in some ways most important. Congressional battle in New York City was the one in the Seventeenth District between Anthony B. Akers, Democrat-Liberal, and John V. Lindsay, Republican, for the seat held for the last twelve years by Republican Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 27 -- Iran, trying to develop economically and industrially, is in an acute stage of growing pains. The country has a seven-year plan and more than $100,000,000 a year of oil revenues to put it into effect.

Nahodah and Joe Culmone formed the winning ticket in the $29,900 Sport Page Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Alhambra had been regarded as the most likely candidate, but he finished eleventh in the six-furlong event involving fourteen horses of all ages.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Jim Brown continues to close in on National Football League records for rushing and touchdowns.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 4 -- The controversial charter form of government for Suffolk County appeared likely to be approved by a 3-to-1 margin today on the basis of incomplete returns.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 4 -- Representative Eugene J. McCarthy, St. Paul Democrat, tonight established a growing lead over Senator Edward J. Thye in the contest for Mr. Thye's. seat. Mr. Thye was fighting for a third term.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
"The $64,000 Question" has been canceled, effective immediately.

The city law permitting the operation of bingo games by religious and charitable organizations was approved yesterday by a plurality of 356,775 votes. The margin of victory was substantially more than 2 to 1.

GENEVA, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- The United States policy on disposal of agricultural surpluses went on next year's agenda for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) after criticism of its upsetting effect on world trade, it was learned today.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- A list of parliamentary candidates published for the Hungarian national elections Nov. 16 by the newspaper Esti Hirlap today was headed by Janos Kadar, First Secretary of the Hungarian Communist party.
William Bauer, baritone, who made his debut here several seasons ago and since has been active as a singer and teacher in Europe, returned to sing an all-German program at Town Hall last night.

"What Happened at Pearl Harbor?" a documentary compiled and edited by Hans Louis Trefousse, author and historian, will be published Dec. 8 by Twayne. The volume presents a digest of the most important testimony in the thirty-nine volumes dealing with the Pearl Harbor inquiry and additional information from Tokyo and Berlin, some of which has not appeared in print before.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Mayor David L. Lawrence, a Pittsburgh Democrat, and Representative Hugh Scott, a Philadelphia Republican, won the Governorship of Pennsylvania and a United States Senate seat, respectively, in yesterday's off-year election.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada called tonight for an expansion of trade among free nations as the surest way to combat the mounting economic aggression of communism.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Rockland County gave Nelson A. Rockefeller a 9,412-vote majority here today. He carried four of the five towns.

GLEN ROCK, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Eight Boy Scouts who started in the same cub pack were advanced to Eagle rank tonight in one of the largest group advancements in forty-eight years of scouting in this country.

MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (UPI) -- Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League, said today he was "still studying" reports o critical remarks directed at officials by Coach Phil Watson of the New York Rangers.
Nelson A. Rockefeller scored a resounding victory yesterday over Averell Harriman, who was seeking a second term as Governor of New York.
Falls on stairs, common and often fatal accidents in the home, are due chiefly to the stairs themselves rather than obstacles, such as toys, placed on them.

William L. Mitchell has been elected vice president in charge of the styling staff of the General Motors Corporation. On Dec. 1 he will succeed Harley J. Earl, who will retire after thirty-two years with the company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Paul A. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said tonight that the American people had given the Democratic party "a very heavy mandate and a very heavy responsibility" in today's Congressional election.
Nearly complete returns showed the Republicans and Democrats had battled to a stand-off in yesterday's Congressional elections in New York City. Not a seat changed hands.

CAPT. SLADE CUTTER, U. S. N., is a square-jawed, broad-shouldered man with flashing eyes and the look of a fighter. It's an accurate look. This one-time star tackle and heavyweight boxing champion at the United States Naval Academy went off to war as a submarine commander.
SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Representative George McGovern held a growing lead over Gov. Joe Foss, his Republican foe for the House seat, in early returns tonight.
TOPEKA, Kan., Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Gov. George Docking, Democrat, won a second term, unprecedented for a member of his party, in a normally Republican Kansas in yesterday's election.

Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Program at the Social Security Administration, 250 Hudson Street. Bloodmobiles also will call today at the New York Telephone Company, 230 West Thirty-sixth Street, and, for a donation sponsored by the Knight of Pythias, at Congregation Derech Emunch, 199 Beach Sixty-seventh Street, Rockaway Beach, Queens.

A combination of brisk weather and attractive and well-advertised bargains drew shoppers in force to the city's stores yesterday. From early in the day until closing time, men, women and children crowded downtown stores, discount houses, neighborhood units and branch operations.
Governor Harriman conceded his defeat at 10:45 o'clock last night as Democratic party workers at the Biltmore Hotel showed their deep gloom and disappointment.

CHESTERFIELD, S. C., Wednesday, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- A tie was temporarily declared early today in the Chesterfield County race for Probate Judge. It involved ex-Judge W. E. Redfearn, who was ousted from office and then jailed on a murder charge.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- The United States Border Patrol announced here today that cooperative efforts of two states and the Federal Government had resulted in the captute .of four men allegedly involved in smuggling arms to rebels in Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- An Air Force bomber carrying a nuclear weapon crashed today near Abilene, Tex. There was no contamination or explosion, the Air Force announced.

The two chief methods of operating motel chains -- through chain ownership or by franchise -- were examined yesterday as part of the Motel Day activities of the forty-third National Hotel Exposition at the New York Coliseum.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Philip A. Hart, Democratic Lieutenant Governor, appeared early today to be on the way to victory over Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican.

The first two pieces of silverware in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden went to the riders and mounts of West Germany and the United States yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 4 (AP) -- That all-important pass-interference penalty against the Cleveland Browns Sunday was a "wrong call," their coach, Paul Brown, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Air Force has sent a rocket-powered test vehicle along a New Mexico research track at a peak speed of 2,853 miles an hour. That is about 4.8 times the speed of sound.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Voters in the United States elected Representatives, Senators and Governors today, but as far as the British press was concerned this year's election was a fight between two millionaires in New York State.
Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., is this reporter's selection as America's sports car driver of 1958.

WHETHER or not mattresses murder sleep was the subject of much comment by a bedding manufacturer last week. In presenting the results of a study on the emotional attitudes toward sleep and sleeping equipment, Sealy, Inc., said that the great amount of thought given to the purchase of mattresses and box springs was out of proportion to the money spent.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 4 -- Senator John J. Williams, Republican incumbent, was re-elected to the Senate tonight, defeating former Gov. Elbert N. Carvel.
HELENA, Montana, Nov. 4 -- Early returns from Montana's 1958 general election showed Democratic Senator Mike Mansfield an apparent certainty for re-election tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Industrial shares continued to advance briskly on the stock market today and there were many gains of a shilling (14 cents) or more.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 4 -- The West came East here today as East Hampton merchants passed out silver dollars to their customers. The unexpected "change," given on each $5 purchase, actually was a 20 per cent discount or rebate.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The House of Commons rejected tonight a Labor party attempt to have it censure the Conservative Government for the alleged failure of its economic policies.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The controversial policy of limiting interest rates on Government-backed home loans was defended today by a spokesman on housing matters for the Democratic party.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 4 -- When Congress opened its budget debate today Alfredo Hernandez, Minister of Finance, told the House that serious deficits would be faced.

SIX of the world's most successful secretaries are visiting New York this week as the result of having been chosen "Miss International Secretary" in contests held in their respective countries. The winners represent Argentina, Venezuela, Brazil, England, France and Germany, and each is young, pretty and enthusiastic. The contest was sponsored by Remington Rand.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 4 -- combination of circumstances has Maine's deer season off to a slow start, but things ought to start picking up tomorrow. All wise old heads, including State biologists, say there are lots of deer this year.
ROME, Nov. 4 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Pope John XXIII today that he shared the Pontiff's "fervent desire for a peaceful solution of the momentous problems which beset mankind."

BONN, Germany, Nov. 4 -- A stranger reading an influential section of the West German press today might well put down his papers convinced that only a wicked United States policy was preventing the Federal Government from getting on with the reunification of Germany.
The board of directors and staff of The Henry Street Settlement mourn the passing of Paul Underwood Kellogg, for twenty years an integral part of the settlement which was his home.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today to underwrite $2,450,000 of private borrowing by two railroads.
MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 4 -- The flexibility of antiques for both the modern and traditional homes of Long Island is being emphasized at an annual fair here.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 4 -- The flavor of downtown New Brunswick before the turn of the century lies in a fading "programme" that came to light the other day.
Detectives investigated yesterday a newspaper photographer's complaint that he had been struck by Frank Sinatra's chauffeur-driven car.
Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat, was elected United States Senator from New Jersey.
TEBESSA, Algeria, Nov. 4 -- Six civilian prisoners, including a Roman Catholic missionary who had been abducted by Algerian rebels, were released unharmed and in good health yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- A helicopter and firemen tonight rescued unhurt about ten persons trapped on the roof of the blazing passenger building at Brussels' new $14,000,000 International Airport.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the General Assembly adopted a Western proposal on disarmament today:

The New York Times of Oct. 19 reported that Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano was quoted as telling the Bundestag that it was "an unjust and inhuman hardship that old people were still waiting for the return of their property [from the United States] and in many cases dying before it was returned."
DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 4 -- High school pupils here who show an aptitude for science will be permitted to start laboratory courses in the ninth rather than the tenth grade, as is done now.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's heavily favored A Glitter finished fourth in the $28,775 Jersey Belle Stakes at Garden State while the Mooring Stables' Tempted won by three-quarters of a length under a smart ride by Eldon Nelson today.

CHESTERFIELD, S. C., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A write-in candidate, Mrs. Margie Pusser, last night barely defeated Probate Judge W. E. Redfearn Sr., who had been ousted from office and jailed on a murder charge.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 5 (Wednesday) -- Christopher Del Sesto, a Republican lawyer, successfully bucked a Democratic tide in Rhode Island yesterday to be elected Governor.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 4 -- The City Commission approved today on first reading an ordinance that might result in changing the city's form of government.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The $100,000 Washington D. C. International today welcomed the surprise entry of the 4-year-old Venezuelan colt Escribeno, increasing the field for the race next Tuesday to ten.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- With unusual vehemence, the Soviet Union urged the United States and Britain today to accept immediately its draft agreement banning tests of nuclear weapons.
WARSAW, Nov. 4 -- Poland made public today a new version of her plan for a Central European zone free of atomic weapons and installations.
