CHESTERFIELD, S. C., Nov. 4 (UPI) -- A write-in candidate, Mrs. Margie Pusser, last night barely defeated Probate Judge W. E. Redfearn Sr., who had been ousted from office and jailed on a murder charge.
CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 4 -- High-riding Democrats easily overwhelmed this state's two Republican Senators.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Net earnings of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) in the first three quarters of this year totaled $86,449,150, compared with $113,872,590 a year earlier. Earnings equaled $2.42 a share, against $3.21 on fewer shares in 1957.

Hank Levin's speedy performance plus Peter Close's illness during the race added up to a major upset in the Thirtieth Annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Cross-Country Varsity Championship at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The $100,000 Washington D. C. International today welcomed the surprise entry of the 4-year-old Venezuelan colt Escribeno, increasing the field for the race next Tuesday to ten.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- With unusual vehemence, the Soviet Union urged the United States and Britain today to accept immediately its draft agreement banning tests of nuclear weapons.
WARSAW, Nov. 4 -- Poland made public today a new version of her plan for a Central European zone free of atomic weapons and installations.
RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 4 -- North Carolina State College has announced it is initiating a three-year study of the application of nuclear energy to textile materials and processes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture set planting allotments today for the 1959 peanut crop at 1,610,000 acres, the same as for 1958. This is the minimum level permitted by law.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4 -- Indiana elected its first Democratic United States Senator in twenty years today.

Charles Buchta, a 16-year-old senior at Brooklyn Prep, took individual honors and Mount St. Michael gained the team title yesterday in the thirtieth annual cross-country championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 5 -- Ohioans turned out in record numbers yesterday to elect a Democratic Governor and administer a crushing defeat to a proposed "right-to-work" constitutional amendment.

ROME, Nov. 4 -- Pope John XXIII had tears in his eyes tonight when he spoke about his longing to see his birthplace and Venice, where he had been Patriarch. He addressed more than 10,000 pilgrims from northern Italy in an audience in the Vatican.

Upsetting the general expectations, Kenneth B. Keating, the Republican candidate, has been elected to the United States Senate. It had been widely assumed that his opponent, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, running on the Democratic and Liberal tickets, would easily defeat Mr. Keating. The calculations went badly astray.

The recent General Motors Motorama, which, thanks to closed circuit television, was previewed by the company's dealers in forty cities across the country the day before its opening at the Waldorf-Astoria, points up the latest progress made in the area of business communication.

PHOENIX, Nov. 4 -- Senator Barry Goldwater, a pillar of the Republicans' ultra-conservative wing in Congress, won re-election tonight in an almost complete Republican sweep of the principal Arizona contests.

The New York City Chapter of the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution will hold its annual bridge party on Dec. 1. Through the courtesy of Mrs. Maurice P. Van Buren, the event will take place in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A scheduled world premiere of the French movie "Maxime" was canceled last night because of extensive cuts made in the film by the Quebec Censors Board.

Next Tuesday's performance of "The Marriage-Go-Round," starring Claudette Colbert and Charles Boyer at the Plymouth Theatre, has been taken over for the theatre party that will benefit the Girls Service League, Inc.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- John XXIII was crowned the 262d Pope on a balcony overlooking St. Peter's Square today.
The Democratic party greatly increased its control of the Senate yesterday and was threatening early this morning to roll up a majority that could cost the Republicans as many as a dozen seats.

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that traffic fatalities and accidents in the city declined last week. Fifteen persons were killed and 1,034 injured, compared with sixteen killed and 1,080 injured in the same period in 1957.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- United States officials will bring up the subject of outer space weapons as a key problem in their negotiations with the Soviet Union next week on possible defenses against surprise attack.

Laszlo Szabo of Hungary and Robert G. Wade of New Zealand rose to the top of the standing yesterday in the international chess tournament at Haifa, according to a report from Israel. Both, undefeated, have 3-1 scores, half a point ahead of Itchak Aloni and Arie Rosenberg, both of Israel.
For a while it looked as if there might not be any official winners or losers in the New York City elections yesterday.
ROME, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- Following is the Latin text of the homily delivered today by Pope John XXIII before his coronation:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 4 -- October was Brazil's best month this year for coffee exports, the Brazilian Coffee Institute said today.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the Republicans had lost ground in the Congressional voting yesterday because "our opponents worked for two years" and "the result was inevitable."

The blockfront on the west side of First Avenue from Seventy-first to Seventy-second Streets has been sold by I. Jerome Riker, president of Riker Co., to builders for improvement with two twenty-story apartment houses.
MOSCOW, Nov. 4 -- "Have you got milk in Leningrad?"

THERE are probably more ramifications to rum than to any other spirit. The buyer is confronted with light, medium and heavy bodied rums. He must choose from the products of Puerto Rico, Jamaica, Cuba, other Caribbean islands, New England or British Guiana. And, as he is undoubtedly aware, each rum has its special characteristics and enthusiasts.
THE ninth annual art exhibition and sale due to start tomorrow night at the Walden School, 1 West Eighty-eighth Street, is an unusual show.
Casting ballots was a touch easier than usual for many voters yesterday.

AS the poet sailed to Byzantium, so will the imagination sail to Cambodia when confronted with the large group of stone rubbings from Angkor Wat now on view at the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue, and at the Society of Illustrators, 128 East Sixty-third Street.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- John Kasper asked today that his trial on an inciting-to-riot charge be moved to another city. He contended that widespread prejudice would prevent him from receiving justice in Nashville.
Paperboard production climbed to the highest mark in the industry's history with the production of 317,809 tons last week the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
Late but still incomplete returns from New York City districts tipped the scales this morning in favor of a $100,000,000 state bond issue for low-rent public housing and slum clearance.

Kenneth B. Keating said yesterday that he would introduce a bill into the Senate promptly to make the blowing up of a house of worship or educational institution a Federal crime. The successful Republican candidate for Senator had made such a pledge in his campaign.

WEST RUPERT, Vt., Nov. 5 -- William Henry Meyer, Vermont's first Democrat in the House of Representatives in more than a century, is a rugged 200-pounder who decided last spring there was time for a change.
BOISE, Idaho, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Idaho Democrats contended today they would have won the Governorship -- along with all the other state offices -- if their candidate had shunned legalized gambling.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Two men and a girl were killed in a plane crash about thirty-five miles northwest of here. The wreckage of the plane, missing since Sunday, was found yesterday.

Ruth Gordon has informed David Merrick that she will appear in his forthcoming production of "La Bonne Soupe" (The Good Soup), by Felicien Marceau. Garson Kanin, in private life the actress' husband, has been asked to make the American adaptation and to direct it.

Electric power production last week rose to 12,330,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,174,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Nov. 2, 1957, the output was 11,860,000,000 kilowatt hours.
Mrs. John Jay Ide entertained committee members for the annual Gala de la Mediterranee at a top at her home, 485 Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

Theodore Kheel's suggestion to restrict downtown parking still further reflects an unfortunate tendency on the part of many officials and transportation authorities to consider the private motorist as a barely tolerable nuisance. Most drivers enjoy the use of their automobiles for their own personal convenience, with no malicious desire to undermine further our tottering public transportation system, albeit driving a pleasure vehicle in midtown Manhattan is a masochistic pleasure at best.
ATLANTA, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- J. C. Goosie, Bill Collins and Chick Harbert fired 4-under-par 68's today to share the opening-round lead of the $25,000 Carling open golf tournament.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 5 -- The controversial Suffolk County Charter, designed to modernize the county's patched-up seventeenth century form of government, was adopted yesterday by a vote of almost 3 to 1.
HONOLULU, Nov. 5 -- Democrats swept both houses of the Territorial Legislature yesterday for the third straight time and re-elected John A. Burns as delegate to Congress.

UNION, N. J., Nov. 5 -- In January firemen and patrolmen here will receive higher salaries than police sergeants and the same amount as police captains. This situation, it was revealed today, is partly the result of the voters' rejection yesterday of referendums that would have taken the power to establish superior officers' salaries out of the hands of the voters and given it to the township committee.
The Transit Authority announced plans yesterday to build a $75,000 machine that would clean and return stone ballast to subway roadbeds in one operation.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- The outcome of the Pennsylvania election was viewed today as another example of voters' choosing candidates rather than parties.

With the exception of two adjourned games, the first part of the international chess tournament was concluded in Carmel, Haifa, yesterday, according to a report from Israel. The eight remaining rounds will be contested in Tel Aviv, starting Saturday evening.
Important Democratic gains across the country on Election Day were fully expected; but it is the size and sweep of the Democratic victory that are so impressive.

The Democratic tide in state elections was viewed variously in newspaper editorials yesterday as a trend toward liberalism, a rebuke to Republican leadership and notice that the nation was in a mood for change.
HARTFORD, Nov. 5 -- The Democrats owe their great sweep in Connecticut yesterday to one man -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff.

SANTA FE, N. M., Nov. 5 -- Democrats in this state swept to a landslide victory in all national and state offices in yesterday's balloting. They won the Senate seat, both at-large House seats and are the apparent winners of the Governorship, the only close race.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 5 -- Crowds demonstrated today against Col. Abdel Salam Arif and demanded he be punished.

Third quarter earnings and operating revenues of the Western Union Telegraph Company were slightly higher than in the like 1957 period, Walter P. Marshall, president, reported yesterday. He said both net income and operating revenues for the first nine months of this year were lower than those in the similar period last year.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Vertex, a horse supposedly weak of legs but unquestionably stout of heart, won the $85,650 Trenton Handicap at Garden State Park today in a thrilling stretch duel with the Calumet Farm's favored Bardstown.

Cocoa futures climbed the daily limit of 1 cent a pound in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. There was a split close in the distant December contract, up the 1 cent limit to up 98 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

Latin-American newspaper men frequently are champions of ideas, or politicians and combatants in a daily struggle toward bettering conditions in their countries, Dr. Jose Antonio Mora, Secretary General of the Organization of American States, said last night.
Muzz Patrick, the New York Rangers' general manager, yesterday reprimanded Coach Phil Watson for recent remarks which "upset the league office."
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The election of Dr. Vittorino Veronese of Italy as the next Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization seemed virtually assured today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 5 -- Montclair's controversial minimum-standard housing ordinance was approved yesterday by a 906-vote margin. The ordinance was one of the town's bitterest issues in many years.

Inflation talk was in the air yesterday on the heels of the widespread Democratic victory in the elections. As a result, stocks of the New York Stock Exchange added more than $2,300,000,000 to their market values.
A fast decision in the contract dispute between ships' officers and more than a score of American-flag ship operators was promised yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States would not change its policy of withholding recognition from Communist China while "Red China continues to do some of the things which we cannot possibly stomach." [Question 22, Page 18.]

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 5 -- Democrats sorting their most bountiful harvest in this state in twenty-two years today counted net gains of two United States Senators and a House seat with a most unusual occupant.
Opposition to the issuance of credit cards by the American Express Company was voiced yesterday by the American Society of Travel Agents at a convention in the Commodore Hotel.
Greyhound Bus Lines operations in the eastern part of the United States were hampered yesterday by what the company called a "wildcat" walkout of drivers.

ROME, Nov. 5 -- Pope John XXIII promised today to dedicate his pontificate and to "consecrate all his forces" to a just and brotherly peace among nations. He was speaking to the delegations that represented fifty-seven sovereigns and heads of state and five international organizations at his coronation yesterday.
Organized labor congratulated itself yesterday on having repelled "right to work" proposals in five of the six states in which they were on the ballot.

Directors of the Flintkote Company recommended yesterday that on March 25, 1959, stockholders approve a split of the common stock, three for two. The board also voted the usual quarterly dividend of 60 cents a common share, payable on Nov. 20.

The lengthy arbitration of an automation dispute between the Grace Line and the International Longshoremen's Association ended yesterday with almost five hours of summation by attorneys for both sides.
THERE is nothing old-fashioned about Henri Bendel except a code of manners.
Most of the bonding proposals in the nation were approved by voters yesterday, but some significant disapprovals showed that they were choosy.
Resignations involving at least nine editorial and advertising executives were disclosed yesterday at McCall's magazine. Before the day was over, the publication had a new head man.
The 1960 Presidential campaign began in earnest yesterday even before the ballots of the 1958 elections had been fully counted.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Home Before Dark," a Warner Brothers drama with Jean Simmons, Dan O'Herlihy, Rhonda Fleming and Efrem Zimbalist too is at the Radio City Music Hall.

Controller Arthur Levitt, the only Democratic state candidate to weather the Rockefeller Republican tide, offered yesterday to work on a nonpartisan cooperative basis with the incoming administration.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Johnny Busso, an aggressive New York lightweight, snapped Joe Brown's unbeaten streak at twenty tonight by hammering out a unanimous decision in a non-title ten-rounder at the opening of Miami Beach's new Exhibition Hall.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 5 -- Exceptionally strong labor efforts in rapidly industrializing areas of the state and a protest vote in depressed mining districts were viewed today as the chief factors in the Democratic near-sweep in Utah's major races.
Once again the voters of New York City have performed a ritual of the "popular election" of judges. And once again we are given a chance to make personal appraisals of its wisdom.
In his sweeping victory over Governor Harriman on Tuesday Nelson A. Rockefeller scored significant gains for the Republican party among Jewish, Negro and Puerto Rican voters in this city.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 5 -- Westchester County's political leaders were experiencing plurality shock today -- the shock of the Republicans election margins yesterday.
OTTAWA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Canada's wheat shipments fell substantially in the third quarter of 1958, leading the way to a 6 per cent general decline in exports from the 1957 level.
CHICAGO. Nov. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Children visiting the Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art today will see art work by African teen-agers who never saw paintings, let alone a museum. The pictures on exhibition are by mission school Bantu Boys of Southern Rhodesia, about half of them from the bush.
YONKERS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- McCoy Hanover, driven by William Schrade, won tonight's feature pace by three lengths from Masland Hanover at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:05.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Fredric March and Kim Novak will co-star in Columbia's film version of Paddy Chayefsky's play, "Middle of the Night." The author has written his own adaptation for the picture to be directed by Delbert Mann.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The United States asked the International Court of Justice (World Court) today to rule that the court had no jurisdiction over Switzerland's suit for $100,000,000 worth of assets seized by the United States Government as enemy property in World War II.

It is understandable that Paul Blanshard, special counsel to Protestants and Other Americans United, is pained at The Times' use of "democracy" in editorializing on "the son of a Lombard farm laborer" who is now Pope John XXIII.

TELEVISION'S usefulness as a political campaign tool was vividly illustrated in Nelson A. Rockefeller's victory in the New York Gubernatorial contest. While by no means the decisive factor in his defeat of Governor Harriman, the Democratic incumbent, the home screen proved made to order for the Republican candidate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Court appointed monitors asked a Federal judge today to force the Teamsters Union to comply with clean-up orders and to put off a scheduled convention in March to elect new officers.
The Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America have set a goal of $1,185,800 in their 1959 financial campaign.
The business community took the sweeping Democratic national election victory on Tuesday as a portent of increased Federal spending and increased inflationary pressures.
Governor - elect Nelson A. Rockefeller will seek to establish an era of good feeling with the labor leaders who unanimously opposed his election.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 5 -- Quarterback Bill Gundy's passing was outstanding today in Dartmouth's intensive two-and-one-half-hour drill for Saturday's football game with Columbia here.

GENEVA, Nov. 5 -- The United States and British negotiators are worried over the propaganda effect of the Soviet Union's position since the conference on ending nuclear tests started here six days ago.

IT was cheering to observe last night that Americans had the curiosity and pride to turn out in good numbers to hear a young American pianist who has made his mark as a prize winner. John Browning rewarded them at Town Hall last night with a recital that was alive with excitement.

AHWAZ, Iran, Oct. 30 -- The ancient caravan stop of Ahwaz on the southwest plain of Iran is booming. It is at the heart of an experiment the Government is pushing in the hope that some day it may bring this country even more blessings than the rich oil fields.
NEWTOWN, Pa., Nov. 5 -- The George School, a Friends co-ed boarding school founded in 1893, has its own farm, river, railroad station, stocked fishing pond and plenty of wooded land.
Nelson A. Rockefeller's smashing defeat of Governor Harriman in Tuesday's election promised yesterday to have political repercussions in many areas.

While William F. Gillenwater, a donnish-looking man of 60, seems to be the quintessence of quietude, he secretly loves to see crowds -- crowds of all kinds: mobs, herds, jammed houses, packed arenas, and endless swarms of people pushing each other in line fighting to buy tickets. His tickets.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov 5 -- Mrs. Charles E. White, the daughter of a Baptist clergyman, has become the first Negro to be elected to the board of trustees of the Houston public school system.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Outboard Marine Corporation manufacturer of Johnson and Evinrude outboard motors, Lawn-Boy power mowers and Pioneer chain saws, reported today a 6 per cent gain over 1957 in sales for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Earnings were lower.
MIAMI, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Approximately 5,000 Eastern Air Lines machinists began balloting today on whether to accept a new wage offer by the company or to continue plans to strike.

TOWNSHIP 24, WASHINGTON COUNTY, Me., Nov. 5 -- Eighteen vain shots were fired by three deer hunters at Dan Hartford's Camp today and there may be some truth in the explanation offered about them tonight in several hundred thousand words.
Mark Zborowski, a Russian-born anthropologist, was depicted by the Government yesterday in Federal Court as a Soviet espionage agent in the United States from 1943 through 1947.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
Mayor Wagner indicated a willingness yesterday to assume the State Democratic party leadership that Tuesday's election was considered to have presented to him.

The selected works of seventeen contemporary American artists will be on exhibition at the World House Galleries, 987 Madison Avenue, from Dec. 15 to Jan. 17 for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that the average cost of food per person in this country rose 18 per cent from 1948 to 1957.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A Thor intermediate-range ballistic missile -- the heart of the moon rocket Pioneer -- blew apart with a brilliant flash shortly after launching early today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 5 -- A new military agreement between the United States and Turkey within the Baghdad Pact was reliably reported tonight to be in the final stages of preparation.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- The Republican party of Indiana viewed the wreckage of its fortress today with stunned disbelief.
The Board of Education disclosed yesterday that 126 former members of the Communist party were now teaching in the city schools. The system has a staff of about 35,000.

ELIZABETHAN mariners and American railway builders were at various times rather interested in that part of the country. The missionaries and the soldiers had astonishing experiences there. Others took from the earth gold and silver and copper -- and potatoes. It is a remarkable land and David Lavender has told its story splendidly in "Land of Giants"* -- the drive to the Pacific Northwest, 1750-1950.

The Bronx Zoo's amphibious forces went on a pelican hunt yesterday. For more than an hour, in three rowboats, in wading boots and with or without nets the hunters splashed and floundered up and down Cope Lake to capture nine pelicans.
Scientists at Columbia University have performed a series of tests relating to the velocity of light that may form the most precise experiment in history.
The role of the resident buyer as the link between manufacturer and retailer was commended last night as essential to distribution.

In Baltimore, George Shaw, reserve quarterback, worked out with the Colts' first team. In New York, the Giants' office announced that all reserved seat tickets for Sunday's game between the two teams had now been sold with the exception of a few hundred marked "obstructed view."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- A Tunisian delegate here said today that the reported French incursion into his country caught Tunisia "in the middle of two imperialisms."
The heavy Democratic trend in the election Tuesday was indicated in a political survey made during the campaign by The New York Times.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 5 -- Representative Brooks Hays was defeated for election to a ninth term yesterday apparently because he had adovcated a policy of moderation on integration.
ATLANTA, Nov. 5 -- Southern Democrats found little cause for celebration in Tuesday's elections despite the party's widespread national victories.

Barry Morell, who made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera last Saturday afternoon in "Madama Butterfly," appeared last night in his first "La Traviata." He sang the role of Alfredo, opposite the Violetta of Licia Albanese. The other leading singer in the cast was Robert Merrill, heard in his first Germont of the season.

A little adversity is sometimes strengthening to the character. In this dark hour for Carmine G. De Sapio, the Tammany leader, perhaps such a philosophy of resignation must be his only consolation. The balloon certainly busted with a bang.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 5 -- The Suffolk County budget for 1959, calling for a $3,127,308 increase in expenditures over the current year, was adopted today by the Board of Supervisors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Eisenhower told his news conference today that Republican candidates lost most of the election contests yesterday because too few people understood the great danger of reckless Federal spending.
Civilization may have as little as fifty years left in which to learn the art of human population control, a specialist on fertility said here last night.
For the second time in the 1958 National Horse Show, the American equestrian team led in the international jumping competition last night.
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 6 (Reuters) -- Boris Pasternak said in a letter to Pravda today that he had been "mistaken" in at first welcoming the Nobel Prize for Literature.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5 -- Ohio labor leaders awoke this morning possessed of more political power than they had dared to dream.

AFTER the glory of "The Saint of Bleecker Street," Gian Carlo Menotti's latest "music drama," as he calls it, exists on a more prosaic plane. "Maria Golovin" was originally put on last August at the Brussels Fair, where Howard Taubman reviewed it for these pages.
Burlington Industries, Inc., has completed negotiations for the acquisition of controlling stock interest in Sidney Blumenthal Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday.
A number of customers admit to being confused (and who can blame them?) by the terminology employed to describe some of the football formations in vogue this season.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming pointed out today that the new National Defense Education Act gave him a broad governmental policy-making role in higher education.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 -- Fuzzy Levane, an old hand at the game but a new man at coaching the New York Knickerbockers in the National Basketball Association, spent more than a few trying minutes watching his team beat the Cincinnati Royals, 108 -- 97, tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem of Iraq was said here tonight to have thwarted a serious insurrectionary threat to his authority by partisans of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

Efforts to strengthen the economy of the free world provide the best means for combating the trade offensive threatened by the Soviet Union, according to C. Douglas Dillon, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 5 (AP) -- King Hussein plans to leave for a vacation abroad next week, officials said today.
FARGO, N. D., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Quentin Burdick, an attorney, today became one of the political oddities of the century in North Dakota.
A new process for welding rail, developed in France, is being tested by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway in art attempt to spur savings on track maintenance and provide a smoother ride.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- A call for a Constitutional amendment granting the West German Government special powers to deal with any national emergency has started a political debate reaching back into the history of the Weimar Republic.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 5 -- The City Council popped "the" question for the third time this year. And Toledo voters yesterday said the answer was still "no" despite the more attractive terms this time.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The White House is no place for a man who has reached three score and ten, President Eisenhower said today.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The Tunisian Government charged today that a French force accompanied by tanks had violated the frontier in the region of Kalaat-es-Senam. Foreign Minister Sadok Mokkadem delivered a note of protest to Ambassador Georges Gorse in Tunis.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 5 -- A Democratic sweep reminiscent of the New Deal victory twenty-five years ago has left Wisconsin Republicans disappointed and bitter.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 5 -- "What happened?"
AN abbreviated survey of B. J. O. Nordfeldt's watercolors at the Passedoit Gallery, 121 East Fifty-seventh Street, covers his work from 1925 to 1955, the year of his death.

May I point out that the Nov. 1 reference by your eminent columnist C. L. Sulzberger to Greece as having "after protracted NATO negotiations * * * suddenly torpedoed chances of ending the Cyprus dispute" is hardly justified by the facts.

PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 5, (UPI) -- Mrs. John Pennington of Buffalo took a two-stroke lead in today's first round of the 36-hole women's North and South invitation senior golf tournament. She shot a four-over-par 77.

Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller faithfully upheld a political tradition yesterday by declaring that he had every intention of serving four full years in Albany. He told a skeptical press conference that he had "no other plans" and that he was being "absolutely straightforward."

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 5 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller's sizable plurality of 115,540 votes over Governor Harriman in Nassau County yesterday swelled the margins of virtually all Republican candidates in this heavily Republican county.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- California Democrats have hit the jackpot. They elected a Governor and a United States Senator, seized control of both houses of the Legislature and won either equality or a numerical edge in the thirty-member delegation in the national House of Representatives, all in one day's work.

In the 1956 Eisenhower election year the New York Legislature became more Republican by a net gain of ten seats, while Averell Harriman, Democrat, was being elected Governor. This year, while electing Nelson A. Rockefeller with a landslide, the Republicans suffered a net loss of seven seats. The Legislature remains, however, overwhelmingly Republican in a majority that is stronger in the Senate than in the Assembly.

The American Can Company (Canco) formally opened a new "coil plant" at Hillside, N. J., yesterday. This was the last of eight such facilities built in the last eighteen months as part of the company's $32,000,000 expansion program designed to reduce operating costs. Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey and scores of state and local government officials and industry leaders were present at the dedication ceremonies.

ALGIERS, Nov 5 -- Supporters of Premier Charles de Gaulle here expressed a growing fear today that representative Moslems would refuse to run in the forthcoming election to the French National Assembly.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee shelved today a United States request for planning machinery for a United Nations peace force.
The staff physician of the American President Lines' passenger liner President Cleveland was transferred in midocean yesterday to the battered supertanker World Glory to treat storm-injured crewmen.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Michigan Democrats scored one of their greatest political victories yesterday. But Gov. G. Mennen Williams, although an easy winner, saw his record margin of two years ago cut in half by his hard-running Republican opponent, Paul D. Bagwell.
A freakish result of the statewide referendum Tuesday has assured housing officials of $75,000,000 to build low-rent public housing but has denied them the subsidy required to keep the rents low.

The Democratic party broke the Republican hold on the industrial East Central, Mid-Atlantic and New England States in Tuesday's election and even cut deeply into the G. O. P.'s strength in the West Central Plains States to pile up the largest Congressional majorities since the Nineteen Thirties.
Democrats have won the biggest working majority in the House of Representatives since the high-water mark of the New Deal in 1936.

The Scholarship Fund of the Menninger Foundation Child Psychiatry Service will gain from a theatre party Dec. 1. The event will be given by the New York Committee of the foundation at a performance of "The World of Suzie Wong," at the Broadhurst Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of class one rail carriers for September at $73,000,000, compared with $64,000,000 in the like month of 1957, when the business recession was developing.
The possibility of cutting 25,000 to 30,000 employes from the city's payroll to help balance the city's budget without tax increases was suggested yesterday by the New York Chamber of Commerce.

Unofficial returns from New Jersey's 4,193 election districts showed late yesterday that Harrison A. Williams Jr. had defeated his Republican opponent for the Senate, Representative Robert W. Kean, by 88,316 votes.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine, the industrialist whose generosity led to Sherman Adams' resignation at the White House, was ordered today to tell the whole story -- under oath -- of some $875,000 in cashier's checks.
Lenox Hill Neighborhood House will receive a portion of the proceeds of last nights performance of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

SAMUEL CHAMBERLAIN is an amazing man. He is an architect, a photographer and an etcher of renown. He is a gastronome, a connoisseur of wines and a student of languages. As if these were not sufficient gifts, he writes with humor, charm and style.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The American election here was won by Lincoln. Franklin was second. Herbert Hoover was eighth and last.

TOKYO, Nov. 5 -- More than 4,000,000 Japanese unionists staged brief work stoppages, rallies and marches throughout the nation today in opposition to the Government's plan for increasing the powers of the police.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Stanch Republicanism, a Kansas trademark virtually since statehood, suffered one of its rudest jolts from surging Democrats yesterday.
The Securities and Exchange Commission attacked in Federal Court yesterday a plan said to be aimed at circumventing its registration requirements.
The eighth annual Capezio Dance Award has been made this year to S. Hurok, Russian-born impresario who has sponsored many of the leading dancers and dance companies in this country.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- United States election results took over the principal place on the front pages of French newspapers today.

ONE of the most electrifying personalities ever to appear in the National Horse Show is Brig. Gen. Humberto Mariles of Mexico, as masterful an equestrian as the sport has known. But the general has been grounded for the current Diamond Jubilee show at Madison Square Garden, an inner ear infection robbing him of the balance that's so necessary in this daredevil pastime.

THE Vicrtex Sales Corporation will open today a showroom housing its complete line of vinyl upholstery and wall-covering fabrics. They are available direct to the customer for the first time. This retail outlet is at 226 East Forty-sixth Street.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Mario Laureti and Skip Di-Bicarri of Darien scored a best-ball 31, 32 -- 63, eight below par, at Vernon Hills today to win the annual Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-pro championship by three strokes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Defense Department will be President Eisenhower's primary target in his campaign to curtail Government spending, he indicated strongly at his news conference today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The Soviet Union asserted today that Western disarmament policy was losing support steadily among the neutral nations.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The Federal Government's top officials in the field of home finance agreed today that the money market would tighten in the coming months.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The British public is being told today that the Democratic election victory was a "landslide" vote against President Eisenhower.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants today signed Bill Posedel as coach for 1959 and accepted the resignation of Coach Herman Franks.
Columbia University's School of Law will open a three-day conference today on the future of legal institutions.
BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- Democrats counted substantial gains today in every New England state except New Hampshire.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 5 (AP) -- American and Japanese Davis Cup players meet in the semifinals of the all-Japan national tennis championships Friday.

More books about the incidents that led to the formation of the Confederacy and the subsequent conflict are planned for publication. One is Stanley Kimmel's companion volume to "Mr. Lincoln's Washington," which Coward-McCann will issue tomorrow. "Mr. Davis's Richmond" depicts the Confederate capital during the war in 70,000 words of text and 200 pictures.

Permit me to correct the story in The New York Times of Oct. 31 to the effect that Bard College had awarded to the eminent, freedom-loving Spanish musician Pablo Casals "the first honorary degree he has accepted from an American institution of higher learning."
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- A British party of three men and a woman is planning to cross the Atlantic Ocean next month in a free-flying balloon propelled only by the wind.
Lee MacPhail, the 41-year-old director of player personnel for the New York Yankees, was named general manager of the Baltimore Orioles yesterday at an estimated salary of $35,000 a year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 7 points (10 to 35 cents a bale) yesterday. Trading was light.
The Republican party will still have firm control of the Legislature despite a loss of seven seats in Tuesday's election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The United States delegation to the discussions with the Soviet Union on technique for preventing surprise attack left for Geneva today.
Consolidated net income of the International Nickel Company of Canada and its wholly owned subsidiaries dropped more than 56 per cent in the third quarter, compared with the same months last year.

A Long Island man was arrested yesterday on charges involving a $362,000 bank swindle. He and a Miami man were accused of using worthless checks drawn on a Nassau County bank to cover other checks drawn on a Miami bank.

Big Fright of the Pastorale Stable succeeded in fighting off the closing challenge of Shy Dancer and won the main race at Jamaica yesterday. Her success was the result in good measure of skillful handling by Bob Ussery, who rode three winners.

By all odds the most indefatigable campaigner in the 1958 election was Vice President Richard M. Nixon. The University of Buffalo, which has been feasting on Ivy League teams, moved into first place yesterday in the competition for the Lambert Cup. The cup symbolizes the best small-college football team in the East.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Government put forward today a plan to encourage home ownership.

The public relations profession was commended yesterday by Roy E. Larsen, president of Time, Inc. Mr. Larsen said the industry was "the activating force in releasing for the public good the tremendous resources of manpower and of wealth represented by the American corporation."

An extraordinary chorus, the Salt Lake Mormon Tabernacle Choir, sang at Carnegie Hall last night. The group already had impressed listeners here with its singing in "Messiah" Tuesday evening with the Philadelphia Orchestra.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The Canadian and French chiefs of government met today for what appeared to be a cordial exchange of divergent views on two major issues: European economic organization and affairs the Atlantic alliance.
Chicago, Ill., raised $25,000,000 yesterday to finance improvements to the city's water supply plant. The money was borrowed in the public market on serial bonds secured by revenues of the system.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and Timex watches have arranged for another "All-Star Jazz Show" to be televised on Wednesday, Jan. 7, from 8 to 9 P. M. It will mark the second jazz program of the season under the sponsorship of Timex, which plans a third in March or April.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Whether Illinois' hotly debated judicial reform proposition won or lost in yesterday's election remained in doubt today. The closeness of the vote and technicalities governing vote requirements in amending the state constitution delayed the decision.

The Federal Maritime Board began yesterday its long deferred inquiry into foreign freight forwarding. The headings, before Examiner Arnold J. Roth, at 45 Broadway, a expected to continue for about three weeks.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5 -- The Government was reported today to be considering reducing the jail sentences of many political prisoners, including Milovan Djilas.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Delaware voters re-elected Senator John J. Williams to a third term yesterday but gave the state's lone Congressional seat to a Democrat.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The grain futures market whirled away to broad gains at the opening today of the Board of Trade, but at the close there was scarcely any sign of the bullishness.
