DENVER, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- Colorado Democrats followed the national trend in yesterday's voting. They captured the Governorship, three House seats and all state offices except that of Attorney General.
Many propective donors to the United Hospital Fund say: "I have paid all my hospital bills in full -- why should I give to the fund?" This is a good question and deserves a detailed answer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that he was "not so certain" that a White House conference would be the best way to rally public opinion against racial and religious bigotry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Americans for Democratic Action today hailed the election results as a liberal victory. A statement described as "utterly ludicrous" President Eisenhower's comment that the election had been a victory for "the spenders."
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 5 -- A National Democratic trend coupled with farm unrest teamed to give Democrats two of the four Republican Congressional seats here.

The English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association ran the country's first field trial for the breed on Fishers Island in 1924. Dr. Samuel Milbank of New York joined in the fun three years later. Both are as strong as ever, the club the leader for its breed, Dr. Milbank a topflight competitor.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Prices of a wide range of industrial shares moved up today. Demand was again stimulated by reports of good business in consumer durables and the Board of Trade's optimistic economic survey.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Harry Walters is ready to take his place again in the Army backfield and the cadets will be in their best shape since the Notre Dame game when they face Rice in Houston Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The next few weeks will be of critical importance in the Middle East, in the opinion of United States experts.

The formation of new concerns, the Geophysics Corporation of America, with executive offices at 700 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, has been announced by Milton Greenberg, president. He formerly was director of the Geophysics Directorate of the Air Force Cambridge (Mass.) Research Center.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (UPI) -- European Socialist chiefs declared today that discontinuance of nuclear weapons tests was the world's "major pressing problem."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Oct. 29:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Settlement negotiations are under way in the long battle for control of the General Aniline and Film Corporation.
HAVANA, Nov. 5 -- A DC-3 passenger plane of the Cuban Airlines with twenty-five passengers and a crew of three is reported missing on a flight from Manzanillo to Holguin in Oriente Province.

Democrats kept pushing Republicans out of still more governorships in late returns yesterday -- until they had picked up control of nine new posts. They lost four gubernatorial contests, giving them a net gain of five.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- Coya Knutson's eight-year political career ended today, apparently wrecked by her husband Andy's "Coya, Come Home" campaign.
MARY TODHUNTER CLARK ROCKEFELLER grew up on what had been a farm outside Philadelphia. It had been granted to her Welsh ancestors by George III of England.
Fourteen local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $45,275,000 yesterday on serial bonds maturing from 1959 to 1999 at an interest cost of 3.3509 per cent.
The Tidewater Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net loss in the September quarter of $607,000 and a net loss of $328,000 for the first nine months of this year.
HONG KONG, Nov. 6 -- The Soviet Union has rushed equipment to Communist China this year to meet requirements of Peiping's high-speed development drive.

Directors of W. R. Grace Co. declared a quarterly common cash dividend yesterday of 40 cents a share, payable Dec. 10. The board also voted a stock dividend of 2 per cent, subject to shareholder approval of the issuance of the necessary additional shares.

Three of the eight sprinters in the $5,000 Cedar Island went off at odds of better than 15 -- 1 at Jamaica yesterday and Shield Bearer, one of the trio, won by three-quarters of a length. Under a brisk whipping by Mike Sorrentino, Shield Bearer closed rapidly and returned $33.10 for $2.

The new Moore-McCormack liner Brasil which is now on her second voyage between here and the east coast of South America, has just completed a record run from Buenos Aires to Santos. The run covers 1,104 nautical miles, which the ship completed in forty-six hours, at an average speed of twenty-four knots.

State-wide results on the five questions at the top of voting machines in Tuesday's election in New York will not be fully, and in two cases conclusively, known until the official canvass is completed.

There is no situation in this hemisphere so charged with emotion as the travail that Cuba is now suffering. For United States citizens it should have a special poignancy, as our histories have been mingled for more than a century and we fought a war to help Cuba achieve independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield announced today that he had cut by $2,000,000 a year proposed increases in postage rates on newspapers, magazines, books and sheet music mailed abroad.

TOWNSHIP 24, WASHINGTON COUNTY, Me., Nov. 6 -- Two deer, both does, fell before the furious blasts of the strong hardy outdoorsmen at Dan Hartford's Camp this morning. It took about fifteen shots to get them, but the thing was a triumph of some sort after yesterday's eighteen shots with no deer.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Ernie Broglio, the right-hander acquired by the St. Louis Cardinals from the San Francisco Giants after the 1958 season, survived a shaky start today and went on to beat the Japanese All-Stars, 6 -- 3.
OTTAWA, Nov. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Welland Ship Canal users renewed their battle today against the imposition of tolls on the waterway when the St. Lawrence Seaway opens next year.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Britain's stage censor has lifted the ban on homosexuality as a subject for public dramatic presentations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -President Eisenhower announced today the membership of the National Committee for the White House Conference of Children and Youth, to be held here in March, 1960.

The New York State Thruway Authority had operating revenue of $26,706,144 for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Net revenue before debt service for the period totaled $17,912,689. The authority also earned interest of $1,058,402 on bond holdings.

DURING the last decade the art market has boomed as never before. Millions of people throng museums and galleries. Hundreds of thousands buy paintings. If only a few can pay more than $600,000 for a Cezanne and not many more can afford even an inferior work by the currently coveted French impressionists, a still aston ishing number buy an occasional picture.
A man who had been shot by an acquaintance in a bar last New Year's Day returned the compliment last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Democratic Congressional leadership is preparing o ask its big new majority to pass a comprehensive and distinctively Democratic legislative program in the Eighty-sixth Congress.
HAVANA, Nov. 6 -- The Cubana Airlines passenger plane that disappeared yesterday in Oriente Province is in the hands of Fidel Castro's rebels, according to a message received here today.
William H. Meyer, the first Democrat to be elected to a national office in Vermont since 1850, was in town yesterday for a few hours. And he was still trying to figure out how it happened.

We must not regard what happened in Vermont on Tuesday as merely part of a national trend. When Vermont feels a need for a trend it makes one itself. It fought the Revolutionary War as an independent republic and not always on good terms with the thirteen colonies. To hear a Vermonter tell it, Vermont also won the Civil War, with some small help from other Northern states.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Three men charged with conspiracy in connection with Air Force contracts were found innocent tonight by a Federal jury.
Stockholders of the General Contract Corporation approved yesterday the proposed spin-off of the holding company's non-banking operations in compliance with the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Advertising of a hundred years ago is shown in an exhibit that opened today at the Library of Congress. Sixty-six posters sent in for copyright between 1837 and 1876 constitute the display.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A minor league realignment plan fell through today.

William Ronald McAteer, British electrical engineer, pleaded guilty in Federal Court yesterday to stowing away aboard the Cunard liner Britannic and to eluding examination and inspection by Immigration officials here.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Industrials continued their advance on the stock exchange today, although some closed lower or below the day's best on increased profit-taking.
The Vieux-Colombier de Paris, French acting company, will give four special performances of Jean Racine's "Britannicus" at the Phoenix Theatre, beginning Nov. 28.
GENEVA, Nov. 6 -- Britain proposed today some first principles for organizing effective international control of a pact to outlaw the tests of nuclear weapons.
Mrs. John C. Thaxter of the Leewood Country Club was elected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the annual meeting yesterday at the Hotel Belmont Plaza.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 6 -- Twenty-one men marooned on a drifting Arctic ice island since Sunday were whisked to safety by air tonight. All were reported in good condition.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, Nov. 7 -- The Chinese Communists resumed shelling thirty minutes past midnight in line with their new pattern of firing only on odd-numbered dates. The shell-fire was described as sporadic by the Nationalist Defense Ministry.

Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's "Wedemeyer Reports" will be published Nov. 17 by Holt. It is an account of his wartime experiences that ranged from high-level planning in Washington to troop command and chief of staff to Chiang Kai-shek.
At 1 o'clock, yesterday afternoon a baseball party, including six players, winged away to Caracas, Venezuela, on a chartered Pan-American flight.
An organization has been set up by the Radio Corporation of America to conceive and develop weapons systems for the space age.
The merged labor federation, long plagued by charges of racketeer influence in some of its unions, now has its first complaint of Communist infiltration.
TOWN CREEK, Ala., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The crew of a freight train brought aid today to survivors from an Air Force plane that crashed and burned beside a railroad.
OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 6 (AP) -- America's Davis Cuppers, Hamilton Richardson and Alex Olmedo, advanced today to the final of the All-Japan national doubles tennis championship.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- A three-judge Federal panel dismissed today a suit charging that Negroes had been barred from polls in the state because of their race. It also upheld the constitutionality of the state's registration requirements set in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, won a fourth term in the Senate the easy way.
ROME, Nov. 6 -- "I am your brother. I am the brother of all men, linked to each and every one by sentiments of love."

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Sir Winston Churchill and Gen. Charles de Gaulle, whose strong wills and conflicting patriotism often clashed during their wartime association, buried old disputes today under the Cross of Lorraine.
Cardinal Spellman and James Francis Cardinal McIntyre returned from Rome yesterday with the blessing of the new Pope, John XXIII, for Americans.

LIVABILITY on a budget in the theme of a series of model rooms in W J Sloane' newly decorated Young Sloan Shop on the third floor. Here interesting accessory ideas are shown for a bachelor's apartment, as well as for the modes home of a young married couple

Governor Harriman, emphasizing his position as "titular head" of the state Democratic party, announced yesterday that he would keep a close watch on Nelson A. Rockefeller's progress in redeeming Republican campaign promises.
ALGIERS, Nov. 6 -- The French High Command formally denied today Tunisian charges that French forces supported by tanks had penetrated Tunisian territory from Algeria near Kalaat-es-Senam.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 6 -- Gaston Eyskens announced today the formation of a Cabinet composed of members of the Social Christian (Catholic) party and the Liberal party.
A builder in Huntington. L. I, was accused yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, of bribing a bank manager to get more than $400,000 in fraudulent loans.
VIENNA, Nov. 6 -- Czechoslovakia's economic planners have placed huge farm-machine orders with domestic and foreign concerns for delivery in the next two years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The Soviet Union complained today that it was being asked to contribute too large a share of the United Nations budget.

ATLANTA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., fired an 8-under-par 64 over the Cherokee Country Club course today to take the lead with 136 at the mid-point of the seventy-two hole Carling open golf tournament.
CEDAR KNOLLS, N. J., Nov. 6 -- An 80-year-old man was blown seventy-five feet into the air from the basement of his home tonight in an explosion that was felt two miles away. He was not badly hurt.

The football Giants began drifting into their locker room at Yankee Stadium yesterday at 9 A. M. Some wore white shirts, ties, jackets -- like business men going to the office. Others, attired in sports shirts and sweaters, looked the part of football players.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP) -Robert F. Kennedy asked the United States District Court today to throw out suits totaling $5,000,000 filed against him by William E. Bufalino, president of Teamsters Local 985, and the union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- An official recount started today in the Twenty-third Congressional District in Illinois. It will decide whether Democrats elected to the new House of Representatives will outnumber Republicans 282 to 153 or 281 to 154.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -Union labor's high command today interpreted Tuesday's voting as a mandate to Congress to abolish all state "right-towork" laws.

It is difficult to escape the impression that the world-wide indignation aroused by the Soviet campaign of abuse launched at Boris Pasternak has forced Moscow to make some significant concessions. This impression seems well founded if one compares the violence of the charges made against Russia's greatest living author after he committed the "crime" of winning the Nobel Prize with the contents of the letter of "apology" by Pasternak which Pravda has now printed.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A former Presidential aide tonight urged that Democratic leaders meet and discuss "quite frankly" the "deplorable and inexcusable situation" in the party's state organization.
MOSCOW, Nov. 6 -- The leaders of the Soviet Union chose tonight to dedicate the fortyfirst anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution to the consumer. They promised him peace and a prosperous future.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Friday, Nov. 7 -- The Air Force postponed early today its third attempt to catapult a rocket into an orbit around the moon.

The concern expressed in the several communications on the House of Detention for Women is all to the good, but there is one fundamental aspect overlooked by all -- namely, the socio-medical nature of the problem besetting these women.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The United States today repeated before the World Court objections to the court's jurisdiction over the case of the General Aniline and Film Corporation stock, claimed by Switzerland on behalf of Interhandel.
Scientific and medical figures will join personalities from the entertainment world in a special four-hour program to be televised on Channel 13 on Sunday, Nov. 16.

Directors of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc. (Maryland) approved a sweeping change in the company's capital structure yesterday. In financial circles, it was interpreted as paving the way for public sale of A. P. stock.
YONKERS, Nov. 6 (AP) -Speedy Pick, the 2-5 favorite, closed fast in the stretch to defeat Canny Scot by a halflength in tonight's $8,000 Briarcliff Pace at Yonkers Raceway.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 6 -The Board of Education is trying to find out why an elementary school principal directed that there be no Christmas or Hanukkah observances in his school this year.

The Geneva conference on nuclear weapons tests is off to an inauspicious start. First, it begins work under a misleading label. It is not a conference on the "discontinuance" of such tests, as it has been officially named, but a conference on installing the detection and control system agreed upon by East-West scientists to make such a "discontinuance" possible.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Government substantially reduced today the list of goods that may not be exported to Communist countries.

Imports of crude oil and products in the week ended last Friday were the second highest for any week on record. According to the American Petroleum Institute, they were 1,901,300 barrels a day, compared with 1,425,600 in the preceding week and the record 1,926,800 in the week ended Sept. 26.

Lumber production last week was 9.4 per cent above the level of a year ago, according to reports to The New York Times yesterday by regional associations. Shipments were up 8.4 per cent and orders up 4.2 per cent.
The National Labor Relations Board has scheduled a second representation election for the white-collar workers of American Export Lines.
Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., has won the race for the account of Maxwell House vacuum-packed coffee.
A 10 per cent increase in the number of private housing units started or authorized in September was announced yesterday by the State Housing Commissioner, Joseph P. McMurray.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 6 -Scores of Brazilian Air Force officers were arrested yesterday and today for acts of defiance against the War Minister, Gen. Henrique Teixeira Lott.

The New York Times has been constructive, sensitive and humane in its editorials dealing with the serious and dangerous plight of New York City's school plant and the need for drastic action to correct these conditions.
In cruising along the Gulf harbors over the stretch westward from Pensacola, Fla., to New Orleans, the skipper undeniably is on an intracoastal waterway. But it's not an inland waterway.
JEAN DESSES, the Paris couturier, arrived here this week with the declaration that he felt like "a new man. I'm starting all over again."
In the course of his news conference on Wednesday, President Eisenhower said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The head monitor of the teamsters' union complained to a Federal judge today that the union's president, James R. Hoffa, had balked at bringing ouster "charges" against a close friend, Owen (Bert) Brennan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- The Justice Department said today that it would retry John Joseph Frank, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on charges that he had failed to register as an agent of the Dominican Republic.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 5 per cent above the level of a year ago.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -Dr. Gunnar Gunderson, president of the American Medical Association, today called for an end to compulsory retirement.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- South Korea demanded today that the United Nations be allowed to verify the announcement that Communist China had withdrawn the last of its troops from North Korea.

Late profit-taking trimmed almost $1,000,000,000 from the total, but issues on the New York Stock Exchange added more than $2,000,000,000 to their aggregate market value yesterday. The New York Times' averages reached new 1958 highs.

Travelers who cruise smoothly along the New York Thruway and similar divided-lane superhighways at sixty and seventy miles an hour, pausing infrequently for sustenance or to pay a fare at a toll gate, might think it odd to hear the assertion that the era of the toll road is over.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
DOBO, Aru Islands, Indonesia, Nov. 5 -- Indonesia's campaign to obtain Netherlands New Guinea was carried close to that disputed territory by President Sukarno today.
A one-day wildcat strike by drivers for the Greyhound Bus Lines in the East ended early yesterday morning.
The United States needs "most urgently" a psychological reorientation toward world problems, the Foreign Policy Association declared yesterday.

NEWARK, Nov. 6 -- Joseph F. Weldon, the first nonresident to be appointed Police Director here, will take over his new duties Monday. He will be officially sworn in Wednesday. Mr. Weldon, who is 55 years old and an assistant chief inspector in the New York City Police Department, was nominated by Mayor Leo P. Carlin and confirmed in a six-hour session of the City Council that ended at 1 A.M. today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Mortgage bankers were chided today for not having fully assumed the underwriting function in the home-loan field. At the same time, they were put on notice that their servicing fees might be reduced by several major lending institutions.
PAWLING, N. Y., Nov. 6 -Trinity-Pawling School will have one of the finest prep school athletics plants when Carleton Gymnasium is dedicated next year.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 6 -- The Belgian Government announced today that it had accepted the United States theatre at the Brussels World's Fair as a gift.
Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller held her first official press conference yesterday and demonstrated that, despite her inexperience, she knows how a press conference should be conducted.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6 -- John Kasper pictured himself today as having worked diligently but unsuccessfully to prevent racial violence when schools here began desegregation in September, 1957.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 6 -"Rockefeller, Friend of Brazil Is Elected Governor of the Empire State," read a front-page headline today in Rio's morning newspaper Correio Da Manha.
THANKS largely to some excellent actors, "Comes a Day" has theatrical moments.

Net assets of the Madison Fund, Inc. as of Sept. 30 totaled $104,660,000, equal to $20.34 a share on 5,146,476 shares outstanding. At the end of last year, the big closed end investment company, formerly known as the Pennroad Corporation, had net assets of $86,438,000, equal to $17.15 a share on the same number of shares outstanding.

A recent editorial in The Times referred to the unfair taxation of a non-resident who works in New York State. The point is very well taken. But the editorial completely ignores a far more serious and inequitable form of New York State taxation which applies to non-residents who do not even work in New York State.
ROME, Nov 6 -- Disparaging remarks by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery on the World War II role of Italian soldiers have prompted an Italian diplomatic step.

A one-story taxpayer containing ten stores and occupying a plot 98 by 100 feet at 385-91 First Avenue, southwest corner of East Twenty-third Street, has been sold by the Ess-Ell-Gee Realty Company. It was bought by an investor in a deal negotiated by Alfred Mundheim, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., broker.

"The Coronation of Pope John XXIII," a two-reel, widescreen featurette in color, will be released to theatres here within the next ten days, it was announced yesterday by Rank Film Distributors of America.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The railroad industry and unions have revived the safety debate, a perennial factor in deciding how many working hands a train shall carry.
The United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that refugees from the 1956 Hungarian revolution who came here without visas were entitled to the full protection of the Constitution.
ATLANTA, Nov. 6 -- Kenneth B. Keating, Republican Senatorelect of New York, visited Atlanta and Jacksonville, Fla., today to keep a campaign promise.

A memorial service for Dr. Judah L. Magnes, American rabbi and educator, who served as first president and chancellor of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, was held yesterday at the University House, 9 East Eighty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -President Eisenhower will issue a statement tomorrow reserving the freedom of the United States to continue nuclear tests unless the Soviet Union agrees to the proposal of the United States and Britain for a oneyear suspension of tests.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 6 -- West Germany has won the first relaxation of the armaments restrictions imposed by the Western Allies in 1955. The restrictions, laid down in the treaty setting up the Western European Union, were a condition of West Germany's assumption of sovereignty and membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
TRENTON, Nov. 6 -- The next objective of the Democratic party in New Jersey is to gain control of the State Senate, Gov. Robert B. Meyner asserted today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case said today that the public seemed to have lost confidence in the Eisenhower Administration's handling of foreign and economic affairs.

ABOUT a year ago, words of high praise appeared here for four compotes and three vinaigrette dressings from the Postilion Inn, Fond du Lac, Wis. Now that same establishment is introducing in local delicacy shops an assortment of fine frozen foods.

AN aura of unreality never is distant from Paul Richards, the somewhat astounding man who has served in recent years as both general manager and field manager of the Baltimore Orioles. Only a Richards would have the cool confidence and the background of versatility to try this double-duty backbreaker.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- A political rebellion in Sicily is challenging the authority of Premier Amintore Fanfani. If he fails to bring the centrifugal forces of the largest island in the Mediterranean under control, a split in his Christian Democratic party may result.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem of Iraq, in an apparent rebuff to advocates of merger with the United Arab Republic, vowed today that his Government would preserve his country's independence and sovereignty.
Two Brooklyn baking concerns, struck since midnight Friday by a drivers' union, charged yesterday that the union was "adamant" in its contract demands and refusal to accept mediation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The growth of anti- Jewish agitation in the South is bringing anti-Semitism in this country back into public view, Arnold Forster of New York, national civil rights director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, asserted here today.

The perjury trial of Mark Zborowski was interrupted in Federal Court late yesterday when an unemployed bricklayer strode into a heavily guarded witness room and spoke threateningly to the chief Government witness, Jack Sobre.

Following are excerpts from the majority and dissenting opinions of the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday on the Constitutional rights of Hungarian refugees. The majority opinion was written by Judge Harold R. Medina, with Judge Sterry R. Waterman concurring, and the dissent by Judge Leonard P. Moore.

ATHENS, Nov. 6 -- Foreign Minister Evangelos AveroffTositsas declared today that Greece could not accept the blame for the failure of the Council of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to bring about a conference on Cyprus.

New issues of corporate debt securities amounting to more than $60,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment bankers. The offerings include obligations of public utility, gas pipeline, railroad and horse racing enterprises. They follow:

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 6 -- A volunteer fireman, who also is the Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was honored here tonight on his sixty-eighth birthday by members of his fire company.

A new electronic corporate giant, with assets of more than $1,300,000,000 may soon emerge, if a proposed acquisition of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., by the General Telephone Corporation goes through.

Organized business urged the victorious Democrats yesterday to put the brakes on Federal spending. Industry spokesmen also declared war on labor's effort to kill state "right-to-work" laws through Congressional action.
Two new buildings costing $5,250,000 were dedicated yesterday on the campus of St. John's University in the Hillcrest section of Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Capital Airline mechanics have voted overwhelmingly to reject the company's latest wage offer and continue their twenty-two-day-old strike.

Net income of the Lockheed Aircraft Company in the first nine months of 1958 rose to $13,302,000 from $11,311,000 in the corresponding period of 1957. The latest earnings were equal to $4.48 a share, against $3.83 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week last Saturday totaled 674,477 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

IT takes taste, a quantity of shoe leather and an unsparing amount of elbow grease to furnish a six-room apartment for $1,500. Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Perl have what it takes and they have devoted two years of hard work proving it.

OSCAR LEVANT, humorist and pianist, has been enlivening the West Coast video scene for some time with his well-publicized psyche. Very early yesterday morning on the Jack Paar show he put his neuroses and his wit on the National Broadcasting Company's network and by now his id is a coast-to-coast matter.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- The cost of mental illness in the United States probably exceeds $3,000,000,000 a year, according to Dr. Jack R. Ewalt, director of the Joint Commission on Mental Illness and Health.
Cotton futures closed 1 point higher to 12 points lower on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday (a point equals 5 cents a bale).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- "They obviously voted for people that I would class among the spenders," said the President to his news conference yesterday, thus broadly classifying a good many of the Democrats who were elected or reelected to Congress on Tuesday.

TRENTON, Nov. 6 -- New Jersey Highway Commissioner Dwight R. G. Palmer announced today that the Federal Government had accepted the state's recommended alignment for the $387,000,000 Bergen Expressway.

A decision was made late last night to close "Maria Golovin" tomorrow night. The action was taken by the sponsors, David Merrick and the National Broadcasting Company, in association with Byron Goldman.

Helen Menken, president of the American Theatre Wing, and Eugene J. Taylor, Assistant Profesor of Clinical Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, have been named trustees of the Society for the Facially Disfigured.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 6 -United Nations truce supervisors today halted a border affray between Israeli and United Arab Republic forces. It had started as a skirmish and built up into an artillery duel.

A modern plant, embracing every operation in the making of women's coats is to be opened today at 12-12 Thirtythird Avenue, Long Island City, Queens. Iit is believed to be the first major plant in the garment industry to be so integrated.
Maria Meneghini Callas has parted company with another opera house -- this time the Metropolitan.

The question of whether Brooklyn's Twelfth Assembly District will be represented by Luigi R. Marano, the incumbent Republican, or by Frank Vacaro, the Democratic-Liberal nominee, was still unsettled yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Department of the Army appealed today for 1,000 German shepherd dogs to be trained for sentry duty at Nike and other missile sites over the nation.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said, "me, too," yesterday and raised its discount rate to 2 1/2 per cent from 2 per cent, effective today. It thus became the twelfth and last of the "Feds" to make the move.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers today threatened a strike against International Harvester Company, giant of the farm machinery industry, unless its demands were met in a week.
THE scrubbed look is all washed up, according to an international make-up expert.
MARCUS HOOK, Pa., Nov. 6 -- The commodore of one of the world's biggest independent tanker fleets says he is getting in a rut.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 -Dancer Hanover, a pacer, was sold at auction today for $105,000. It was the highest price ever paid for a yearling, either thoroughbred or standardbred, in this country.
Coach Buff Donelli of Columbia contends that football coaches in the Ivy League use a more imaginative offense than the coaches in any other college conference.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Three more starters for Tuesday's $100,000 Washington D. C. International arrived at Laurel tonight.
Repeal has accomplished what prohibition failed to achieve -- comparative temperance in drinking, according to R. E. Joyce, president of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc.
Five crippled children helped Mayor Wagner open a city wide drive yesterday to recruit volunteers for the 1959 Mothers March on Polio.
The economy is out of the recession and in the full swing of recovery, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- Election errors that changed the outcome of two races -- one for Congress -- prompted the Registrar of Voters today to order a recheck of two other Congressional and five Assembly districts.

Average net free reserves of member banks declined $52,000,000 to $47,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Net free reserves are excess reserves less borrowings.
Consolidated net income of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second-largest copper producer, fell to $7,994,346 in the third quarter of this year, the company reported yesterday.

In his letter published in your issue of Oct. 16 J. K. Galbraith stated that the disorders associated with Vice President Nixon's trip through South America last spring were mainly caused by "popular hostility against Mr. Nixon himself."

Events today: Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" and Leoncavallo's "I Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Verdi's "La Traviata," New York City Center, 8:15; Gounod's "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleeker Street, 8:15.

Sponsors have been announced for Monday's performance of "Once More, With Feeling" at the National Theatre. Mrs. Frank E. Karelsen is chairman of the committee for the event, which will benefit the Child Study Association of America, Inc.

The estate of Willard Regan has sold the four-story building at 796 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-ninth Street, and the adjoining one-story building at 158 East Forty-ninth Street to Brause Brause, realty operators.
Sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation rose to a new high in the quarter ended Sept. 30, E. E. Stewart, president and chairman, reported yesterday.

Justice Charles D. Breitel of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court last night defended the role of the courts in lawmaking and their right to consider social and economic factors in reaching decisions.
The Coast Guard icebreaker Westwind returned here yesterday from her sixth mission in northern waters.
A new detail of the proposed billion-dollar redevelopment of lower Manhattan was disclosed yesterday by David Rockefeller, who said legislation might be required to achieve best results.

The third annual ball to be sponsored by the Women's Committee of the Brooklyn Philharmonia will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, on Nov. 15. Proceeds from the fete will go toward the Youth Concert Series of the orchestra.
A builder who once startled the Government by returning $410,000 of an $8,000,000 construction contract announced plans yesterday for giving hundreds of thousands to charity.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -Grain futures prices made a steady climb with scarcely an interruption today on the Board of Trade and near the close began attracting a good volume of short-covering.

THE future of the three heroic figures above the door of the old St. Paul Building on the east side of Broadway between Ann and Fulton Streets will be weighed this afternoon in the chambers of the Architectural League of New York at 115 East Fortieth Street.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller arranged yesterday to confer with state legislative leaders late today on a start toward "teamwork government."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The United States now has the capability to shoot a rocket to Mars or Venus, a Government space scientist said today.

Billy Steinkraus, the United States Equestrian team captain, turned in a pair of faultless rides to win the President of Mexico Trophy in the international competition at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Sol Lesser Productions, Inc., of Hollywood and the J. Arthur Rank Organization of England have formed a television production partnership, but will continue to operate separately as producers of theatrical motion pictures.

Prices of near December, March, May and July cocoa futures climbed the limit of 1 cent a pound for the second consecutive day yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The deferred positions advanced 43 to 58 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
The Xavier Award for outstanding efforts in behalf of the Roman Catholic missionary movement was bestowed posthumously last night on Samuel Cardinal Stritch of Chicago.
Left-wingers are calling a national conference to study "united Socialist action," including a possible coalition for the 1960 Presidential race. The session is to be in Cleveland Nov. 28 to 30.
Far from the milling throngs that will jam the stadia for tomorrow's football games one of the prized trophies of intercollegiate sports will be up for grabs today.
THE mystery of the rage for patterned carpetings was explored this week at a meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Decorators.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Army has completed its Redstone ballistic missile test program with what was reported to be a perfect 250-mile shot across the Atlantic test range.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UPI) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, called on the nation's police today to crack down on union violations of local laws against violence and crime.

The 1959 Lincoln has been cut two inches in length. But at 227 inches it will still be the longest six-passenger car on the market.

Patients in the Memorial Cancer Center will benefit from the annual fashion show and luncheon to be given by the Society of Memorial Cancer Center on Feb. 3 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The State Commission of Investigation will seek a warrant for the arrest of Joseph Barbara Sr., who was host to the gangland convention at his hilltop estate at Apalachin, N. Y., a year ago. The commission has been unable to get Barbara to accept a subpoena since September.
Two adjourned games were played off in the Israeli international chess tournament yesterday to complete five rounds in Haifa.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Naval Academy injury list is growing as the middies prepare for their meeting with Maryland Saturday in Baltimore.
Loans to business by the seventeen major New York City banks rose $34,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Festivities in connection with the diamond jubilee of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden continued last night with many persons entertaining at prefatory dinner parties and in their boxes at the Garden.
Harold Bowers, a leader of the International Longshoremen's Association and a boss of the tough "pistol local" on the West Side, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital. He had long been ill of cancer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A majority of the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee urged the Justice Department today to investigate the possibility of court action to break up the General Motors Corporation.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company reported yesterday a 25 per cent increase in consolidated net earnings for the twelve months ended Sept. 30 over the previous year.

Rock Island, Ill., has sold $4,550,000 of bridge revenue bonds due from 1960 to 1988 to John Nuveen Co. and associates at an interest cost of 4.242 per cent. A syndicate headed by The First Boston Corporation put in the second-best bid, a cost of 4.328 per cent.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- A parable of a snake that crawled out of its "dungwaters" to threaten a high-flying, proud eagle was published here today by the Union of Soviet Writers. The snake was clearly meant to symbolize Boris Pasternak, although the Nobel Prize winner was not mentioned by name.
LURAY, Va., Nov. 7 -Seventy-seven sports cars started today in the three-day Appalachian Mountain National Rally.

SIMPLE meals turn festive when there is a plate of piping hot muffins on the table. And now that cool weather is here to stimulate home baking, a review of the factors that make for perfect muffins may be helpful. These include a fine even grain, moist tender crumbs and an almost level glossy brown top.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 7 -- Chinese Communist coastal artillery broke a twenty-seven-hour silence at 12:30 A. M. today. Firing fifty-five shells at the Quemoy islands in the predawn hours, the Chinese Reds once more gave notice that their "odd and even" schedule was still in effect.
Vicente Grisolia, a pianist from the Dominican Republic, appeared last night at Carnegie Recital Hall in the second of a series of three programs he is playing there.

Net income of the Cities Service Company and its subsidiaries in the quarter ended Sept. 30 totaled $7,693,060, or 73 cents a share, the company announced yesterday. In the similar period of 1957, net income was $9,340,000, or 91 cents a share.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller hinted last night that his administration might be forced to start out by raising taxes.
The New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn was host yesterday to a ship flying the flag of Japan.
NEWARK, Nov. 7 -- New Jersey's colleges must start planning now for 15,700 more student's in 1965, according to a survey made public today by the League of Women Voters.

The welfare fund of the Russian Nobility Association of America will benefit from a tea dance to be held on Nov. 16 in the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East. Princess Vera of Russia is honorary chairman of the fete.

A colorful assemblage more than 700 box and loge subscribers and their guests attended the Horse Show Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria after last night's performance of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

The Citizens Union gave its support yesterday to a simplified court reorganization plan prepared by the Institute of Judicial Administration.

Directors of Spiegel, Inc., Chicago mail-order house, voted a 10 per cent stock dividend yesterday on the common stock.

Five men involved in an investigation into what Attorney Louis J. Lefkowitz has called "fellows with criminal records down in Wall Street," pleaded the Fifth Amendment and remained silent at a hearing yesterday.

The 44 1/2-carat Hope diamond, a fascinating but often unlucky symbol of wealth and glamour for more than 300 years, is being given to the Smithsonian Institution.

Activity in the new capital market next week will continue at the moderate pace set last week.

Stocks approached the weekend in a cloud of uncertainty yesterday. Prices wavered through the day. Although a few more stocks rose than fell, and although The New York Times' combined average of fifty stocks gained a trifle, other market indicators disagreed.

Lundy, who lost to the incumbent, Arthur Levitt, by 48,308 votes. A novelty store owner was charged yesterday with the grand larceny of $52,000 in diamonds and the attempted grand larceny of $28,000 more in diamonds. He was ordered arrested after being questioned all day in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.
BOSTON, Nov. 10 -- The New York State law on reckless driving is drawn so loosely that it is impossible to sustain convictions on appeal, a traffic law authority said today
Bernard M. Baruch, who was graduated from City College sixty-nine years ago, paid a return call to the school yesterday.

Following are the texts, provided by Reuters, of King Hussein's broadcast from Amman, as received in Beirut, Lebanon, and the communique of the First Army of the United Arab Republic, as broadcast by the Cairo radio (both are unofficial translations from the Arabic):

An articulate spokesman with a Welshman's way with words arrived here yesterday to present the case for Welsh independence to the American people and the United Nations.
On Nov. 4 your column carried a brief obituary of Agnes Goodyear Gould, granddaughter of Charles Goodyear.

A spectacular flaming ground crash destroyed two aircraft yesterday at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. But thanks to swift fire-fighting and good fortune in timing, only eleven persons suffered minor injuries. whom fled in time. In five minutes the plane would have been loading forty passengers and two pilots.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Jack Benny has bought what he couldn't get from the United States Supreme Court: A license to satirize the movie "Gaslight."

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The Christian Democratic party expelled today three Deputies to the Sicilian regional parliament who had helped to form a regional government with Communist participation. A fourth Sicilian Deputy was expelled some days ago for the same reason.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Commerce Department today established voluntary Federal standards subject to state approval, restricting advertising along the new interstate highway system.
Manhattan will have at least one motel by next summer, according to building plans filed yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- A campaign to woo support for organized labor was revealed today by Maurice A. Hutcheson, general president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America.

He was a different man this morning, said the gentleman on the train as he settled into his usual seat, folding his paper lengthwise as he did so. He had had a close look at the future recently, and while he had found much of it incomprehensible, he had been assured, at least, that it was there.

From the outside, the little house at 258 Bradley Avenue in Staten Island looks the same as it did last December. There are a few cracks in the front steps, the frame of the red brick house still requires some work and at the foot of the front door there is the same worn rubber mat that says, "welcome."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower brought home today three shopping bags full of such foreign delicacies as stuffed grape leaves, baklava, pisang goreng and cassava muffins.

Giulietta Simionato, Italian mezzo - soprano, will appear with the Metropolitan Opera during the 1959-60 season, it was announced yesterday by Rudolf Bing, general manager. She will make her debut early in the season, and will sing several roles to be announced later.
LISBON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- United States Navy search planes spotted an oil slick and picked up faint distress signals in the South Atlantic today where a Portuguese flying boat went down yesterday.
The fortieth anniversary of the World War I armistice, now observed as Veterans Day, will be marked today by parades and memorial services.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 --- R. H. Macy Co. lost the last round today in its fight for $12,000,000 in Federal tax refunds.

Bernard J. Gillroy, recently retired head of the Department of Buildings, was guest of honor yesterday at a testimonial luncheon sponsored by the city's construction industry. About 1,300 persons, including Mayor Wagner, attended the luncheon, which was held in the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission postponed a decision today on whether to permit Western Union to file a new, scaled-down proposal for raising its rates on teleprinter service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Presidents of the nation's public universities beginning to abandon their opposition to Federal aid for private colleges, it was indicated here today.

THOSE with a taste for Scandinavian foods are now shopping for raw lingonberries, a tart, delicious fruit that is available here in the fresh form only a few weeks each fall. Lingonberries look very much like miniature cranberries and taste the same, although they are slightly less sour than the native American fruit.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- An advertising executive suggested today the appointment of a new cabinet member to sell America to the world.
The Feb. 3 performance of "Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre has been taken over by the Kidney Disease Foundation of New York, Inc., for its annual theatre fete.
The Potsdam Declaration was issued Aug. 2, 1945, by the Big Three at the conclusion of a seventeen-day conference.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- One of the parties in the Miami Channel 10 case warned today that any rule that disqualified it for a television license might force a "wholesale reorganization" of the radio and television t industry.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The flag that flies over the United States Capitol today may grace a patriotic club or school tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union warned the United Nations today that it would not accept as valid another resolution calling on North Korea and Communist China to accept a supervised election in Korea.
American shipowners with 5,000,000 to 7,000,000 tons of shipping registered under "flags of convenience" have joined in a fight for what they call "flags of necessity."
The National Audubon Society urged its members yesterday to petition Congress to hold up appropriations for the use of pesticides until more was known about their effects.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Navy awarded contracts for seven missile frigates to four private yards today. The contracts totaled $182,493,105.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A uniformed mailman interrupted elaborate ceremonies today to deliver the Hope diamond in a plain brown package plastered over with 9-cent stamp stickers.

The Union of South Africa is planning to borrow $25,000,000 in the United States to help finance public development projects. Wentzel C. duPlessis, the Union of South Africa's Ambassador to the United States said yesterday that his government had registered the proposed (flotation) with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
New York City is planning to borrow $32,800,000 in the bond market on Nov. 25, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court took the unusual course today of dropping a case on which it had heard arguments. By doing so, it denied a $10,500 insurance claim by the widow of a flier who was killed in a plane crash the day after he had paid a first installment on an insurance policy.
CAIRO, Nov. 10 -- A full-dress conference at Cabinet level and perhaps between the heads of state of the United Arab Republic and the Sudan was reported in prospect tonight.

LORD BYRON called it Albany when he lived there. Yet Macaulay, Monk Lewis, Compton Mackenzie and others have referred to that most famous of all London's bachelor cloisters as the Albany -- a way of mentioning it, which, when used by non-U's, is considered a faux pas of the utmost flagrancy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Oats futures made small gains but all other grains and soybeans were weak in slow dealings today on the Board of Trade.
Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack asserted yesterday that the city's policy on widening midtown crosstown streets was "antiquated" and in need of revision.
The high price of keeping themselves in Cadillacs may bring a strike of Cadillac salesmen in this city today.

I fail to understand how any responsible statesman could have initiated, or can seriously discuss, the talks with respect to the prohibition of surprise attacks by one country on another. Nothing seems more futile.

IN art the Japanese are known for their fondness for delicate texture and exact control. Since these have always been characteristics Of Walter Hautzig's piano playing, one can understand why the Vienna-born American pianist has been so well received in Japan, where he has played extensively since 1956.

A deplorable situation exists in our community today, and I can't understand why more people aren't concerned about it. It seems to me that libraries are vital and essential to our educational and cultural system. And yet the libraries in our neighborhood are now closed on Saturdays.
PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The failure of Moslems of stature and nationalist views to present themselves for election to Parliament from Algeria constitutes a severe setback for Premier Charles de Gaulle.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 10 -- The hazards that face any traveler setting off into space were drafted today by some of the world's leading space scientists.

Barring unforeseen obstacles, it is virtually certain that William Faulkner's dramatization of his novel "Requiem for a Nun" will be introduced here in February under the joint auspices of the Theatre Guild and Richard Myers.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 10 -- The Nobel Peace Prize has been awarded to the Rev. Dominique Georges Henri Pire, a Belgian priest, who since 1949 has dedicated himself to giving displaced persons a new start.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Paul Richards said today he had asked the Baltimore Orioles to relieve him of half of his field manager-general manager title, but they relieved him of the halt he had wanted to keep.
BUENOS AIRES, Tuesday, Nov. 11 -- President Arturo Frondizi began security measures early today against opponents of his oil policy.
Robert G. Wade of New Zealand was the only winner in the eighth round of the international chess tournament in Tel Aviv, last night, according to a report from Israel.
Steel production declined slightly last week for the second consecutive week -- but was scheduled to rise this week to the highest level in more than a year.

Even though the Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to permit over-the-counter trading in Cornucopia Gold Mines to resume tomorrow, the American Stock Exchange said yesterday it was "not presently contemplating" a resumption of trading in the shares.

The Southern Pacific Company's bargaining position in its effort to obtain full control of the St. Louis Southwestern (Cotton Belt) Railway was strengthened considerably yesterday, in the opinion of Wall Street observers, by news of action taken during the day by the Supreme Court of Missouri.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- Jerry Wald believes that he has Yul Brynner more than just casually interested in starring in "The Billionaire."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Government offered the nation's movie exhibitors publicized security clearances today to overcome their edginess about showing a new group of Soviet films.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The United States said today it opposed continuing the United Nations aid program for Palestinian Arab refugees after its scheduled expiration in 1960.

A new Broadway theatre will not be built "for a long time," in the opinion of Joel Schenker, president of the Webb Knapp Construction Corporation. The situation was attributed to economic factors by Mr. Schenker, one of the speakers at yesterday's meeting of the Drama Desk in Sardi's.
Directors of National Theatres, Inc., have approved an agreement to purchase the common stock in National Telefilm Associates, Inc., held by National Telefilm's three top officers.

NEWARK, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Public Utilities Commission today ordered the Pennsylvania Railroad, which was curtailed severely by a near blizzard last February, to install new equipment for this winter.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 10 -- Manufacturers of nationally advertised products were urged by a research executive to become more aggressive in their sales battle with private brands.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation had sales and operating revenues of $162,730,000 in the third quarter of this year. This was 10 per cent more than in the second quarter and 2 per cent above the $159,818,000 volume for the third quarter of last year.

I have just returned from a brief but pleasant visit to New York City. During my stay I twice found myself in a maze because of a definite lack of direction and street indicators. I had earlier considered myself quite at home in New York, but came away this time with a feeling that perhaps I should have invested in a long straw to keep in my mouth.
Many persons have purchased tickets for the Nov. 19 performance of "Goldilocks" at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre that will be a benefit for the Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc.
A trailer truck and an empty bus collided near the George Washington Bridge yesterday morning and the bus crashed through the door of a shoe shop at Broadway and 179th Street.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 9 -- Sir Vivian E. Fuchs, the Briton who last March led the first overland crossing of the Antarctic continent, suffered the loss of a gold filling on the trek.
Your editorial of Nov. 6 "How Not to Choose Judges" might have been documented by reference to another page of the same issue.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- Philip Cortney, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, said today the gold value of the dollar would have to be changed sooner than most people thought.
ROME, Nov. 10 -- Cardinals and Bishops from Latin America started week-long consultations under Vatican auspices here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Government reported today a significant drop in long-term unemployment last month. It also said strikes had cut into the factory work force, work week and weekly earnings.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- A German court announced tonight it would send one of its judges to the United States in an effort to solve the riddle of Anastasia, Grand Duchess of Russia.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 10 -- An increase of .096 cent in the Nassau County tax rate is proposed in the 1959 budget made public today.

Net income of the large Canadian aluminum-maker. Aluminium, Ltd., and consolidated subsidiaries, rose to $7,537,000, equal to 25 cents a share, in the third quarter of this year from $4,379,000, or 15 cents a share, for the like period of last year.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A few months ago the auto industry was striving mightily to reduce top-heavy dealer inventories. Today it is trying to rebuild them.
Television's major live shows are pre-recording productions on tape in case the three networks and a performers' union fail to agree on a new contract by the end of this week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Like the soldiers before and after him, the World War I veteran wanted nothing more than to get home. He wanted to get back to his family, back to his sweetheart, back to his interrupted career, most of all perhaps, back to the "good old U. S. A."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's controlled cotton crop at 11,764,000 bales. This harvest-time figure is an increase of nearly 1 per cent over last month's forecast of 11,675,000 bales and compares with 10,964,000 produced last year.
A former Long Island branch bank manager was accused yesterday in the Federal court, Brooklyn, of having accepted a $40,000 bogus check when he knew its depositor was operating a mail fraud scheme.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- A global housing shortage is becoming more acute each year and threatens an explosive situation in many parts of the world, a Point Four official declared here today.
Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull and featureless in most markets. Several exchanges will be closed today in observance of Veteran's Day.

Farm land in the Middle West that was selling ten years ago at between $250 and $275 an acre is now bringing $500, according to a study prepared by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago and reported in this newspaper yesterday. Prices of the more productive acreage are again rising in Illinois, Iowa, Wisconsin, Michigan and Indiana, following a lull during the winter and spring.
LONDON, Nov. 10 --The stock market lost some of its buoyancy today and prices moved irregularly. However, the undertone was said to still be firm.
Blood will be given today at the Union Carbide Corporation, 30 East Forty-second Street, for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

YONKERS, Nov. 10 -- Eleanor Sendall, 14 years old, a Yonkers high school student, was run down and killed by a freight train today while walking with a young man on the tracks of the New York Central Railroad's Putnam division.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 10 -- A code of employment ethics for Nassau County teachers drew a statement of protest today from a county teachers' group. The code was adopted by the county School Superintendents Association last February.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- Listed in order of post positions are the horses, the weights they will carry and the nations they will represent in the Washington D. C. International tomorrow :
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- "Right-to-work" proponents planned today to step up their efforts to obtain laws outlawing the union shop in several states next year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Villanova, nicknamed the Wildcats, will invade Michie Stadium at West Point on Saturday for the first football game with Army since 1951. That year the team beat the cadets, 21 -- 7.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -- More than 4,000 Greek Cypriote workers were barred today from British Army and Royal Air Force bases following acts of sabotage and terrorism within air bases and army installations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- In the week following a party triumph at the polls that, among other trophies, virtually assured Democratic control of the United States Senate until 1963 the most diligent search fails to disclose a Democratic candidate for the Presidential nomination in 1960.
The Louisiana State Tigers, the surprise team of 1958 college football, yesterday capped a steady climb in The United Press International ratings by replacing Iowa in first place.
General Omar N. Bradley and W. Paul Stillman have been elected directors of Food Fair Stores, Inc., Louis Stein, president of the Philadelphia-based food store chain, announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- A Council on Higher Education has been established to give the state's private colleges and universities a greater voice in education planning.
TO the children of most World War II veterans, the war-time experiences of their fathers remain among the best kept secrets of the war.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller named Dr. T. Norman Hurd of Cornell University as Budget Director yesterday. This is a post he held during Thomas E. Dewey's last four years as Governor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- House investigators of alleged improper influence in a Pittsburgh television case summoned today the principal persons named in conflicing stories of favors offered and solicited.

Something both to stump and to satisfy the experts was issued yesterday by the city's Department of Commerce and Public Events. It is a sixty-page book, "The 1958 Statistical Guide for New York City," which appears to answer all one could reasonably expect to be asked about the city.

ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -- The Government of Ghana ordered the immediate arrest tonight of forty-three Ghanaians accused of plotting to assassinate Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah and two other ministers.
TRENTON, Nov. 10 -- A fire tonight damaged two of the three small red brick buildings used as annexes to St. Joachim's parochial school.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Nikita S. Khruschev's challenge to the Western presence in Berlin was denounced by State Department officials today as propagandistic and legally baseless.
Longshot players had a pleasant time at Jamaica yesterday when Walls of Troy produced a $166.60 for $2 pay-off, the second highest of the New York season.

CHESTER, Vt., Nov. 10 -- In this state boys begin their hunting while they are still young enough to think their fathers know something and therefore the boys might be expected to listen. Vermont takes the general position that a boy begins to be responsible for his own actions at about the time he learns to walk.

Not all of the exhibitors at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden are members of high society. Some of them eat in low-class restaurants and worry about feed bills. They do this so they can show their horses.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union was first in the draw this morning, and also last.

Those Moslems who have advanced their candidacies are part of the small group that sees eye-to-eye with the Committee of Public Safety and the French military in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Government called new peace conferences in Atlantic City for tomorrow in the twenty-six-day Capital Airlines mechanics' strike.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 10 (AP) -- An expertly rigged bomb exploded with shattering force early today inside a schoolhouse near here where whites and Negroes attend classes together. It was believed to have been a dynamite explosion.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Week by week the economies of the members of the Soviet bloc are being meshed together more firmly.
A group of Japanese industrialists visited the Takashimaya department store on Fifth Avenue yesterday but left without buying anything.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A liberal-conservative fight for the Republican leadership of the Senate appeared possible today following a veteran liberal's demand that his wing of the party receive "adequate representation" in party councils.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today that he would do everything in his power to see that Dale Alford of Arkansas was accepted by House Democrats and given a good committee assignment.

SEATTLE, Nov. 10 -- The Administration disclosed tonight that it had chosen the Democratic leader of the Senate to help carry the ball in this country's debate before the United Nations General Assembly on the control of outer space.

Of the three ten-rounders that topped the weekly boxing program at the St. Nicholas Arena last night, only one went all the way. In that one, Marvin (Candy) McFarland of Philadelphia upset Isidro Martinez of Panama.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- West German leaders waited tonight to see what, if any, action the Soviet Union would take to back Mr. Khrushchev's threat of withdrawing unilaterally from the Potsdam agreement.

A check for $80,000 -- give or take a thousand or so -- was the balm the Baltimore Colts received yesterday for the 24-21 setback they suffered at the hands of the Giants on Sunday at Yankee Stadium. That represented 40 per cent of the net receipts paid by the 71,163 fans, a record crowd for a professional game here.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 -- In a far corner of the barn area at the Laurel race course is a wire enclosure bearing the sign "International Village." This is where most of the horses are stabled for the capitalistic $100,000 race on the morrow, not including the Scandinavian but certainly including the two sterling Russian steeds.

Desilu Productions, Inc., announced yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering to the public of 525,000 shares of its common stock. The offering will be made through Bache Co. and a nation-wide group of underwriters.
LISBON, Nov. 10 -- The Portuguese Government banned today a proposed speaking tour by Aneurin Bevan, a leader of the British Labor party.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 10 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller disclosed today that he had talked with Mayor Wagner and State Controller Arthur Levitt before leaving for his Venezuelan vacation. Both promised their full cooperation in solving problems in their areas of special concern when Mr. Rockefeller takes over as Governor.

NORTH HILLS, L. I., Nov. 10 -- Ferdie Catropa, Peninsula, and Fred Dugan, Deepdale, scored 34, 35 -- 69, three strokes under par, to win the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association pro-pro championship at the Links Club today.

In your issue of Nov. 6 you published some comments by Zenon Rossides on C. L. Sulzberger's statement that Greece had "torpedoed chances of ending the Cyprus dispute." May I set out the present position?
SEATTLE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address here today to the Colombo Plan conference:
Installment credit delinquencies declined in September, figures published yesterday by the American Bankers Association indicate.
Improved methods of curbing tax evasions are pouring a golden stream into the city's coffers, according to City Treasurer Hilda G. Schwartz.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The United States is negotiating economic and defense agreements with Iran, Turkey and Pakistan as a means of bolstering the Baghdad Pact.
The German Equestrian Team, which began slowly in the international jumping competition of the National Horse Show, yesterday scored a double triumph.

Aides of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan subpoenaed the books of the International Jewelry Workers on yesterday. The 19,000-member union already is facing possible ouster from the merged labor federation on charges of corruption.

The 15,000-gross-ton liner Victoria, the former Union-Castle passenger vessel Dunnottar Castle, is expected to leave London for Genoa soon for conversion into a cruise ship for the Incres Steamship Company Ltd.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- An elder statesman of the oil industry warned yesterday that continued internal disputes might lead to increased Federal regulation of the entire industry.

" ALL-STAR JAZZ" presented a number of luminaries in the world of popular music last night over Channel 2. It was a loud and hurried floor show staged at a convention of wholesale druggists in the ballroom of a Miami, Fla., hotel.
MONTEREY, Calif., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Gordon Crowder Jr. of Claremont, Calif., one of eight persons injured in accidents at the Laguna Seca sports car road races, remained in critical condition today.

Tickets are still available for Zthe Dec. 4 performance of "A [Touch of the Poet" at the Helen Hayes Theatre. They may be obtained at 144 Columbus Avenue, the office of the beneficiary, Pioneer Youth Camp,. a 35-year-old interracial camp in the Catskills.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 10 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit ordered the Little Rock Board of Education today to take positive action to integrate the city's public schools. The three-man bench left to the District Court at Fort Smith, Ark., the decision on the "affirmative steps" the school board must take. The four Little Rock public high schools were closed by the state to avert integration of one.
A General Sessions Court judge ruled yesterday that wiretapping in New York State under a court order was legal.

Jack Wallace of the Upper Montclair Country Club will be nominated again as president of the Metropolitan Golf Association. According to the list to be presented by the organization's nominating committee, Wallace's name will be voted upon at the annual meeting on Dec. 11 at the Princeton Club.

To celebrate its sixtieth year the National Arts Club is sponsoring a Metropolitan Young Artists Show. It will be on view at club headquarters in the Samuel Tilden Mansion, 15 Gramercy Park South, from Nov. 23 to Dec. 3.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 10 -- Morocco asked France today for measures for the benefit of Ahmed ben Bella and four other Algerian nationalist leaders imprisoned in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled 6 -- 3 today that Workmen who pay board and lodging at job sites away from their established residences cannot deduct the cost as business expenses on income tax returns.
Domestic zinc shipments last month were the largest in more than thirteen years, and zinc stocks in the hands of United States smelters declined for the third consecutive month.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 10 (AP) -- The head of the National Grange called today for changes in Federal farm programs that would free the taxpayers from Government subsidies on agricultural production.

When it was "Armistice Day" we celebrated a national victory and the end of hostilities forty years ago. It is now "Veterans Day," dedicated to all the men who have served their country in the armed forces in several conflicts.
The state law against discrimination in publicly assisted housing has not deterred private investment, Commissioner Charles Abrams said yesterday.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday called for United States leadership in an international program of health cooperation.

Probably few Americans had ever heard of the Rev. Dominique Pire before he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize yesterday. But certainly the cause that Father Pire has been striving to serve and the work that he has done deserve high praise in the free world.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 10 -- Former Premier Fadhil al-Jamali and two former army leaders were sentenced to death by a five-man military tribunal here today.
HAVANA, Nov. 10 -- The Cuban Red Cross announced tonight that the rebels began to hand over prisoners at 10 A. M. at the town of San Benito, near Alto Songo, in eastern Cuba.

The women's apparel industry can capitalize on weather conditions in the northern part of the country by bringing out later winter lines, according to Richard H. Davis, vice-president of A. Davis Sons, Inc. Mr Davis is one of the oldest coat and suit manufacturers in the nation.
Thomas K. Finletter, chairman of the Independent Citizens Committee for Harriman and Hogan, said yesterday that Nelson A. Rockefeller had won election as Governor "on more than personality."
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Donald Campbell broke his world speed record today with two runs in his jet hydroplane averaging 248.62 miles an hour.
Assets of Incorporated Investors had risen to $278,000,000 at the close of business on Sept. 30. This was an increase of $65,000,000 over those on last Dec. 31.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 10 -- United States Senator-elect Kenneth B. Keating today denied reports that he was not entirely happy over his surprise victory.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Britain's second atomic power station started operation last night, the Atomic Energy Authority announced today.
A performance of "Porgy and Bess," preceded by an informal supper and followed by a dance, on Sunday at the Harmonie Club will benefit the Grand Street Settlement, 283 Rivington Street.
It's not true that Macy's won't have balloons in its annual Thanksgiving Day Parade Nov. 27.
PONTIAC, Mich., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Herman Kierdorf, a former Teamsters Union business agent, was sentenced to one to five years' imprisonment today for possessing a pistol silencer.

Many subscribers to the seventy-fifth anniversary National Horse Show gave dinner parties before last night's performance at Madison Square Garden. As was the case on Wednesday night, a portion of the receipts will benefit the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House.
YONKERS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Dark Shadow, driven by Paige West, took tonight's feature pace by three-quarters of a length over Wealthy Widower at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:04 1/5.

The Supreme Court decision in Washington yesterday to let stand a lower court ruling on Macy's fight to collect tax refunds on its inventory valuation method ended a long battle that might have meant the payment of as much as $1,000,000,000 by the Treasury.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Tuesday, Nov. 11 -- The Chinese Nationalists said today the Communists had announced that they would resume daily shelling of the Quemoy Islands.

Tiny crystals, said to have exceptionally good electronic "memories," are being synthesized for the United States Air Force at the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation laboratories in Nutley, N. J.
New Dorp, one of the two undefeated and untied high school football teams in the city, will meet Brooklyn Tech at 2 P. M. today at Port Richmond, S. I.

A proposed acquisition of the assets of American Screw Company by Textron, Inc., may be blocked at tomorrow's special meeting of American Screw Company stockholders, a Textron spokesman said yesterday.
NEWARK, Nov. 10 -- The Public Service Coordinated Transport won today a 2-cent increase in its basic bus fare, from 12 to 14 cents. School bus fares will also be increased, from 6 to 8 cents.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- After holding almost stationary most of the day at barely steady prices, the grain futures market began to stir late in the session of the Board of Trade today. Good gains were then posted almost all along the line.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- British women worked on military posts and civilians went shopping with drawn guns today as Britain took drastic steps to stamp out terrorism on this island colony.

Three teams were set up yesterday by the Civil Aeronautics Board to find out why a cargo plane ran wild Monday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens. The flaming aircraft destroyed itself and a passenger plane it struck next to the crowded old terminal.

The Rockefeller-founded American International Association for Economic and Social Development announced yesterday that its program of agricultural education would be expanded to include all of Central and South America.
HICKSVILLE, L. I., Nov. 11 -- A showing of four Charlie Chaplin films by the Hicksville Public Library here has been canceled.

WELCH, W. Va., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A strong no-appeasement policy was necessary for the United States in dealing with Communist aggression, it was declared here on Veterans Day by the Secretary of the Army, Wilber Brucker.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The Soviet Union told the United States tonight that the Geneva talks on prevention of surprise attack would be useless unless linked to disarmament steps.
James D. Zellerbach, this country's Ambassador to Italy, said last night that the United States should define clearly its intentions in other parts of the world.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- The National Theatres Corporation, the country's second largest theatre chain, has implemented its announced intention to buy stock control of National Telefilm Associates, Inc.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Mrs. Ellen Borden Stevenson and her mother began a contest today over possession of their old family mansion.

TORONTO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The head of a big Canadian oil company attacked today the recommendations contained in the first report of the Royal Commission on Energy. J. R. White, president of Imperial Oil, Ltd., said that the report's recommendations held dangers for the oil and gas industries.
