And, as it does with wine and food, all France keeps Paris stocked with its famous fabrics, crystal, porcelain and other regional wares.

The forty-seven-family building at 150 West 175th Street, corner of Popham Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by George Lendzian to a client of Harry Mandell. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, was immediately resold to an investing client of Daniel Spooner for cash above $150,000 of mortgages.
Columbia University's German Club celebrated its sixtieth anniversary last night with traditional German music, German jokes and untraditional roast chicken.
The situation in Argentina is worrisome. The strike of the oil workers in the western Province of Mendoza has now led President Frondizi to declare a state of siege and to order hundreds of arrests.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The free world's oil industry will have to spend $20,000,000,000 in the next twenty years for new refining capacity, an economist predicted today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Lockheed scientists announced today that they have developed a rugged electronic tape recorder able to store 3,000,000 pieces of scientific data -- and yet small enough to be held in one hand.

One of the major killing and crippling afflictions of modern times -- so-called essential high blood pressure, or essential hypertension -- may be linked to the shortage of a specific enzyme in body chemistry, it was suggested here yesterday.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- United States claims that Switzerland failed to exhaust American jurisdiction before seeking the return of General Aniline stock by the World Court were rejected today by a Swiss lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr., the Presidential aide named to coordinate and speed the nation's scientific effort, said today that "already some of the spurt that followed Sputnik has lost its force."
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A contract for $25,306,439 was awarded today for work on Oahe Dam on the Missouri River near Pierre, S. D.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A 5 to 10 per cent dip in farm income in 1959 was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture's marketing service.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- President Arturo Frondizi imposed a state of siege today, suspending constitutional guarantees of basic rights throughout Argentina for thirty days. More than 700 Peronists, Communists and nationalists were arrested.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Jimmy Dykes, who posted a fine short-term managerial record with the Redlegs last season, was added to the Pittsburgh Pirate coaching staff today.

COLUMBIA, Tenn., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today that Democrats in the new Congress would give Eisenhower better support on foreign policy than he had been accustomed to get from his own party.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 11 -- The rocket the Army plans to fire at the moon in early December is to be hurled at sufficient speed to make the trip in thirty-three hours and forty-five minutes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- A business consultant said tonight that negative business forces of a year ago, "without exception," have become positive. Recovery has now assumed "such broad-scale proportions as to suggest that business is establishing an unusually firm foundation for expansion in 1959," he declared.
GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- Western sources at the meetings here on guarding against surprise attack said today that a proposed Soviet agenda was unacceptable.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Administration is already having its troubles with the liberals in the new Congress, Republican as well as Democratic.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today that Britain was not prepared "to accept the Soviet position of prohibiting nuclear tests without agreement on a control system."
ROME, Nov. 11 -- Pope John XXIII has appointed a new Patriarch of Venice, a post he formerly held.

McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 10 -- The Air Force is rushing to completion its mission of parachuting supplies to the South Pole and Byrd Station.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- Sailor's Guide, representing Australia, won the $100,000 Washington, D. C., International at Laurel Race Course today. That 6-year-old horse, ridden by Howard Grant, finished second to the American representative, Tudor Era, but gained the victory after an objection by Grant was upheld by the stewards.
Net income of the Great Northern Railway in October of $4,945,694 was more than double the $2,276,894 cleared a year earlier. It was the highest level of earnings for any October since 1950.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- There was no air of crisis in the State Department today over the announcement yesterday by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev that the Soviet Union would turn over its functions in East Berlin to the East German Government.
HAVANA, Nov. 11 -- Cuban rebels have delivered to the Red Cross the twenty-five passengers and three crew members of the Cubana Airlines plane they seized in the air on Nov. 5.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- The price of land in the nation's suburban areas is being bid up by the relentless pressure of demand for home sites and industrial locations. As land has risen in price, so has almost every type of real estate.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 -- The United States should be equipped for chemical as well as nuclear warfare, Lieut. Gen. Arthur G. Trudeau said today.

In the flood of words set off by the first sputnik about improving educational, scientific and technical performance in the United States there has been little or nothing reported proposing change in our archaic measurement systems.
NORFOLK, Va. Nov. 11 -- A group of Norfolk citizens today lost a state court bid to prevent a public informational referendum next Tuesday on the city's six closed schools.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Bache Co., New York investment house, has formed a syndicate to buy the stock of the General Aniline and Film Corporation if and when the Government puts it on the market.

WALDWICK, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Friends, neighbors and strangers have rallied to aid Mrs. George Ackerman and her three children, who were seriously burned in a fire at their home here early Saturday morning.
The Reid Foundation has awarded $5,000 each to five newspaper men for study abroad, the foundation's fellowship committee announced yesterday.

Prices of cotton futures moved 3 points off to 3 up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday after holding in a narrow range all day. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The General Assembly's Political Committee adopted today a Western resolution calling for the reunification of Korea through elections supervised by the United Nations.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers and Ed Litzenberger of the Chicago Black Hawks shared first place today with 16 points each in the National Hockey League scoring race.

On July 23 the Four-Way Ranch's 2-year-old colt Atoll ran second to First Landing by a neck in the Great American at Jamaica. Yesterday, on his first return visit there, he defeated Rico Tesio by four and a half lengths in winning the forty-fifth running of the Remsen.

Directors of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation yesterday voted a two-for-one split of the company's 2,989,094 outstanding shares, Robert E. Gross, chairman announced. Within eight minutes of the announcement, the stock shot up 6 3/8 points on the Big Board to 62 3/4, the highest price since the peak of 64 1/4 reached in 1955.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- James Marshall of Washington, national director of the Associated General Contractors, appealed today for unions in the construction industry to resolve their jurisdictional disputes.
ARRAS, France, Nov. 10 -- If anything is sure in French politics, it is that a former high school teacher of English here will be elected to the Fifth Republic's new National Assembly.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 11 -- A 68-year-old veteran of World War I who had been listed by the Army as a deserter for forty years was honored today in front of the Alamo with the presentation of the Distinguished Service Cross.
A strike of 1,000 bakers in four baking plants of the A. P. food stores began at 6 P. M. yesterday when fifty workers walked out of the chain's bakery at 52-15 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Queens.

Seven teams will see action tonight when indoor soccer returns to Madison Square Garden after seventeen years. The competition is sponsored by the American Soccer League.

DECATUR, Ill., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Directors of A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company today declared a special 2 per cent stock dividend for the sixth successive year. This was in addition to an extra cash payment and the regular quarterly dividend.
